Africa News


March, 1996


Zaire Poachers Shoot Three of Remaining White Rhinos


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 11, 1996


LENGTH: 187 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire - Poachers last month shot dead three of Zaire's remaining 14 white rhinos in the northern Garamba national park.

The Zairean Environment and nature protection ministry attributed the slaughter to refugees and Sudanese rebels. 

The rare beasts were killed dispite Garamba park being declared as World Heritage by UNESCO since 1980, in an effort to preserve them. Only 31 white rhinocerous are still alive worldwide.

In order to prevent the extinction of the white rhino, 31 of which are living in the wild in the world, the Garamba national park has been lassified "Unesco world heritage" since 1980.

Created in 1938, the Garamba park, which spreads over 5,000 km2 is located in the North of the Upper Zaire province neighbouring Sudan and the Central African Republic in the North and North-west and Uganda in the East.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Zaire Inflation Falls


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 12, 1996 by Munkeni Lapess, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 147 words


 

KINSHASA, ZAIRE - Inflation in Zaire fell to 14.5 per cent in February, down from 38.6 in January, United States embassy sources said in Kinshasa.

The economic section of the US embassy in Kinshasa, on the basis of the price index, said the transport sector recorded the highest rise in prices with 25 per cent in February, up from 14 per cent. 

It was followed by the clothing (17 per cent) and the food products and drinks (16 per cent) sectors, as against 52 per cent and 26 per cent respectively in January.

Non food products recorded a 15 per cent price rise in February (30 per cent in January) and house rents 14 per cent (31 per cent in January).


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Zimbabwe Money Market Rates To Firm


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 12, 1996


LENGTH: 294 words


 

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwean money market rates are expected to firm this week in response to tightening of liquidity levels on the back of a rumoured rollover of government stock issue, dealers said on Tuesday.

The rates firmed slightly the week ending March 8 on the back of a market shortage estimated at just 1.9 million zimdollars (211,111 USD). 

Dealers attributed the move to central bank selling of 90-day treasury bills to discount houses.

The Zimbabwe Development Bank managed to raise 20 million zimdollars (2.2 million USD) from the market through a private placement.

During the week, the treasury bill rate eased slightly to 29.4 percent, while the rediscount rate was quoted at 29.50 percent last week and the central bank penalty rate at 35 percent.

On the foreign exchange market, the Zimbabwe dollar maintained stability with only a large movement of 1.43 percent against the German mark.

Dealers attributed the move to a weakening of the German mark against most European currencies particularly the pound and the yen.

The zimbabwe dollar also gained against the British pound, the Japanese yen but lost 0.26 percent against the US dollar.

Dealers said depreciative pressure should already have emerged in the US/Zimbabwe dollar rate and movement was expected to occur in the very short term (9.09 ZD = 1 USD)


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

4 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zimbabwe Tourism Sector Grows


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 12, 1996


LENGTH: 600 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe's tourism industry is showing unprecedented growth, and last year foreign and domestic tourists earned the country over two billion zimdollars (222 million USD), according to the Zimbabwe Council for Tourism chief, David Chapman.

Chapman said in Harare the turnover from domestic tourists is estimated to have reached 543 million zimdollars (90 million USD).

He said the impact of tourism on the gross domestic product was significant, with its contribution to GDP growth rising from 3.4 percent in 1990 to 6.6 percent in 1995. 

Chapman said this was not bad by world standards and in the next five years, tourism would contribute over 10 percent to GDP.

Tourism earnings, as a proportion of Zimbabwe's total exports, rose from 5.56 percent in the early 1990s to 9.93 percent in 1995, which, in itself, was a "fairly significant increase", he said.

He said new tourism projects were planned, and the industry was confident of further growth during the period up to the turn of the century.

Commenting on the new two percent tourism levy, he said, the council understood the reasons for its implementation and gave it total support.

At present, only the hotel sector was paying the levy, and the council wanted government to include other tourist-related establishments so that the levy could be reduced to 1 or even 0.5 percent.

The levy will finance operations of the Zimbabwe Tourist Authority, responsible for trourism promotion.

The Zimbabwe Host Programme, to be launched at this week's hotel congress in Nyanga, would include a series of seminars on the value of tourists to this country and how to treat tourists.

It would involve people from all walks of life so as to create a "tourism culture." in Zimbabwe, he said.

Initially, the programme would be run by the authority, and would later be run independently of the council.

Chapman said the programme was "long overdue" as the industry needed to offer top-quality service if it was to compete internationally as well as within the region.

The council, he said, was lobbying government to ease movement restrictions in the Victoria Falls/Chobe area on the western border with Botswana, and in the whole of southern Africa.

Chapman said the council would also support indigenisation and would be organising workshops to inform would-be entrepreneurs about the tourism industry.

Problems which faced indigenous businessmen included bureaucracy and the high interest rates.

However, additional funding from the World Bank would soon be made available to the tourism sector, benefiting particularly the indigenous sector.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996

Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large African Capital Markets Forum Postponed


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 4, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The inauguration of the African Capital Markets Forum (ACMF) and the international conference on reviving private investment on the continent is now to hold in Accra, Ghana, in June, the organisers said in Lagos.

An official of the Nigerian Exchange Commission, Sylvester Akele told journalists the twin events earlier scheduled for March had been put forward for "logistics reasons." 

He said the forum's chairman, George Akamiokor, the Director-General of the Nigerian Exchange Commission is to release details of the revised programme.

The events have attracted the attention of many international financial bodies and potential investors.

The conference's steering committee, includes representatives of the World Bank, the United Nations Development Organisation, the UN Conference on Trade and Development and the UN Economic Commision for Africa.

The forum seeks to accelerate the development of existing markets and promote cooperation among African equity markets.

The idea of the forum was first mooted at a 1992 international conference on promoting capital markets in Africa, held in Abuja, Nigeria's capital.

6 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Call for New Energy Policy


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 11, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 574 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria needs a national energy policy that will harness its abundant energy resources in a cost-effective, environmentally friendly perspective to ensure sustainable development, a leading energy expert in the country has said.

Speaking at an energy/environment seminar in Lagos last week, Philip Asiodu, a retired top civil servant and former petroleum resources secretary (minister), said the new policy should lay down a coherent principle for the development of energy resources over the next 20 years.

He said "while Nigeria must continue with its plans for large scale energy schemes...sufficient attention and resources must be devoted to renewable energy resources... because of the immediate beneficial impact on the lives of the majority of the country's population." 

Asiodu, who served in Nigeria's energy sector for many years, including as a 'super' permanent secretary (senior civil servant), and later petroleum minister, said although urbanisation was progressing in the country, "it is estimated that over 70 per cent of Nigerians live in rural areas."

Oil accounts for more than 80 percent of the total foreign exchange earnings in the West African country.

But the oil exploration has not been without costs involving mammoth flaring of gas, amid complaints of air, sea and water pollution.

Asiodu said "it is also better if by the provision of power in rural areas, working and living conditions can be so improved as to reduce the rate of migration of young adults from villages and rural areas to the misery and crime of urban ghettos."

He offered some suggestions for the development and exploitation of renewable energy resources.

Under his proposed national energy policy, Nigeria should tap the abundant solar energy in the country.

"It should not be too difficult to demonstrate the efficacy of solar-powered pumps for water supply from boreholes, or lakes and rivers" and "solar powered refrigerators for storage of drugs and vaccines in rural hospitals, solar energy systems to produce electricity for village community centres as indeed for households in villages as well as towns."

There is also the possibility of developing "wind mills" to power water supply and irrigation schemes in the country, he added.

Asiodu, who spoke on Energy for Sustainable Development, said Nigeria should also exploit biomass fuel directly, including the generation of electricity.

The seminar was the third in a series by the Nigerian group 'Friends of the Environment'.

The group was founded in 1993 to address specific energy and environmental problems in Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

March, 1996


Senegal Journalists Learn About Desertification


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 4, 1996


LENGTH: 174 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - Senegal's Supreme Council of Natural Resources and Environment Monday held a briefing seminar in Dakar on the international convention to combat desertification. 

A statement issued in Dakar, the capital, said the seminar would seek to raise awareness among 35 local and foreign journalists and communication specialists on the convention adopted during the June 1992 Earth Summit in Brazil.

The participants were to be informed on the stage reached by West African states in implementing the convention and Senegal's national action programme to combat desertification.

The seminar was jointly organised with the Senegalese ministry of the
Environment and nature conservation.

Africa News


March, 1996


Tunisia Pollution Control Launched In Coastal Areas


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 4, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya - The Tunisian government has announced plans to develop a new dump for phosphate wastes at Sebkat al-Malah, 30 kilometres northwest of Gabes, by the year 2000.

Media reports received in Tripoli at the weekend said the move seeks to end pollution from phosphate mining which now threatens Tunisia's central and southern coastal areas. 

According to the Tunisian media, phosphate waste dumping in the gulf will be ended by the year 2000.

The decision announced last weekend by the Tunisian minister of the environment, Hedi Ben Mlika, the Tunisian media said, should end decades of pollution in the Gulf of Gabes.

Phosphate wastes have been dumped in the waters of the gulf for at least 30 years.

Between 10,000 and 12,000 tonnes of waste are dumped daily by the phosphate processing factory at Gannouche, near Gabes, 400km south of Tunis.

The situation has become so alarming that Tunisian authorities have now decided to re-establish the zone's ecological balance.

The phosphate waste, which cannot be recycled, will be channeled through pipelines to the proposed new dump, which is expected to cost 100 million U.S dollars.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


9 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Liberia Monrovia in Sanitation Crises As Liberians Fail to Disarm


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 11, 1996 by Terence Sessay, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 347 words


 

MONROVIA, Liberia - The Liberian capital, Monrovia, a city partially destroyed by a six-year civil war, now hosts over one million residents, two and half times more than the number before the conflct.

The rapid population growth rate is not a result of the normal rural-urban migration associated with the search of greener pastures but people fleeing the interior for fear of being killed or hurt. 

The huge population has compounded problems for the city's already inefficient waste disposal system.

Sewers constructed for less than 400,000 residents have now been overstretched. The city's sewers now frequently burst open while clogged gutters and culverts are breeding grounds for rodents and unsightly insects.

The operations of the Monrovia City Corporation, which is responsible for sanitation, have ground to a halt for lack of equipment. As a result, the minimal waste disposal that is carried out in Monrovia is done by private agencies which lack the capacity to effectively handle the garbage generated by the ever increasing number of residents.

It not uncommon to see huge piles of solid waste in various corners of the city. Worse still, even the little amount of waste collected is not properly dumped.

Prior to the war, the almost obsolete land-fill system was the most effective disposal model in Liberia. But this method requires immense capital input in the form of equipment, which government cannot afford at this time.

Cholera and malaria cases have also increased sharply because of the poor sanitation. There are only two government health institutions working in the city.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

10 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Ethiopia Academic Highlights Peasants' Role in Environment


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 4, 1996 by Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 827 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - An Ethiopian academician has advised African and other philosophers to pay more attention to the centuries old experience of peasants in managing the environment.

Workineh Kelbessa of Addis Ababa's Department of Philosophy made this recommendation in a paper entitled 'Ethiopian Peasant Attitudes to the Environment' presented in Dakar last week. The paper was presented at the just-ended symposium organised in the memory of a leading scientist and Egyptologist Prof. Cheikh Anta Diop, who died 10 years ago. 

It highlighted the knowledge of peasants in dealing with pests, weeds, local soils, microclimates, vegetative differences and seasonal environmental changes.

"Indigenous environmental science has played an important role in minimising the ecological constraints," said Kelbessa. He termed as superficial the perception by Western scholars that indigenous environmental knowledge was primitive and backward and that peasants were agents of environmental destruction.

Citing rural people in his often drought stricken country, the psycholigist said that through continuous experirments on their own, Ethiopian peasants " have managed to learn how to control weeds, select crop varieties, classify vegetation types and cope with climatic and environmental changes."

He commended traditional soil conservation practices such as terracing, contour ploughing, bunding, contour ridging and furrows, crop rotation and intercropping of cereals. Ethiopian peasants also have traditional methods to deal with locusts.

"After grinding different types of trees, peasants spray the powder on their land in order to protect it against locusts." Researchers from the Sahel countries could borrow a leaf from the Ethiopians on how to deal with the insects.

Kelbessa also highlighted the contribution of African traditional leaders and local institutions in conserving the natural environment.

"The religious conception of the man-nature relationship reflects how the Ethiopian people, particularly the Oromo, harmonize themselves with nature," he said. The Oromo regard the 'Adbar' tree as a reflection of spirits while the 'Oda' serve as centers for conferences, worship and peace-making. Other sacred trees are the Daki, Miesa, Anfari, Abaye and Galmaa, to name only a few.

The Oromo people give important value to green nature. Wet grass is viewed as a symbol of fertility, life and peace. "In many parts of Ethiopia, trees which are grown in the compound of sacred springs remain untouched. These springs are used only for bathing and drinking. The holy water is believed to be a cure for heart ailments and rheumatism," said Kelbesa. The people believe evil spirits live in these tress and cutting the surrounding trees causes death, noted Kelbessa. Because there are many sacred groves in almost all parts of Ethiopia, this is good for nature conservation.

The philosophy lecturer also spoke about the ability of rural people to use environmental indicators to anticipate changes in the weather.

"On the basis of the movement of migratory birds, peasants anticipate the behaviour of their environment and weather conditions."

Contrary to the blanket condemnation by some Western-educated scholars that African pesants destroy their own environment, Kelbessa highlights indigenous environmental ethics which are embodied in social norms and myths.

Kelbessa disagrees with the allegation by certain academicians that rural people's knowledge is harmful and a major obstacle to development.

Instead, he argues that local ecological knowledge is dynamic and innovative, since it stems from prolonged peasant experience. "Peasants are not only receivers of new technology; they are also initiators of development," he said.

"Thus, modern environmental ethics can derive many lessons from indigenous environmental ethics. The first lesson to be derived is the ethics of preservation," noted Kelbessa in his 17-page presentation.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


11 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Lagos Under Threat Of Coastal Erosion


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 11, 1996


LENGTH: 320 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Lagos, Nigeria's fastest growing city and commercial capital, could be washed into the sea within the next 30 to 40 years, unless urgent steps are taken to stem coastal erosion, a town planner has warned.

The official News Agency of Nigeria on Monday quoted Raphael Kumapayi, vice-president of the Town Planners Registration Council of Nigeria, as saying that something must be done now otherwise the "city of many rivers" could submerge. 

He said Lagos, with a population of six million, had a "fragile coastline."

The city has occasionally been threatened by the ocean surge, which leaves huge flooding in its wake.

Kumapayi blamed the situation on improper or no study of the character of the city's soil before erecting high-rise buildings.

"All the structures are carried by sedementary sand," he said. "The sand ought not to carry too much weight as is the situation at present."

He said the city's coastal problem had been worsened by the prevailing "global warming" and the rise in sea level partly due to pressure from increasing population.

A United Nations report, released in 1995, projected that Lagos would be the 10th most populated city in the world by the year 2000.

Kumapayi said that the environment should be taken into consideration before structures are put in place, adding that Nigerians should be compelled to be environment-friendly.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

March, 1996


Ethiopia Refugees Return


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 11, 1996


LENGTH: 134 words


 

HUMERA, Ethiopia - Over 2,800 Ethiopian refugees have returned home from Sudan during the past two weeks, according to the Administration for Refugees and Returnees Affairs (ARRA). 

ARRA said in a statement that a total of 2,862 Ethiopians had been repatriated in four transport operations.

Some 80,000 refugees are expected to be voluntarily repatriated to Ethiopia by June this year.

Prolonged civil war and economic hardship in the past led to an outflow of Ethiopians to neighboring states.

13 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia and South Africa Cooperation Accord Signed


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 11, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 520 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - South Africa is reviewing trading relationships with neighboring countries which are economically weaker, Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo said Monday.

He spoke in Lusaka, the Zambian capital, on aspects of a joint communique he signed with his Zambian counterpart Lt. Gen. Christon Tembo. The occasion marked the end of Nzo's four-day visit. 

He said that South African trade officials were preparing new trade guidelines to regulate business with neighboring countries.

"South Africa is currently examining these (trade) issues to balance relations not only with Zambia but other countries in the southern African region," he said.

Both men signed a general agreement on economic, social, scientific, technical and cultural cooperation on Monday.

It makes easier cooperation in agriculture, livestock, fisheries, trade, industry, mining and tourism.

Other areas of cooperation provided for in the agreement include monetary and financial arrangements, development of transportation and communications facilities, sport and culture, energy, health and education.

Pretoria and Lusaka will also cooperate in the training, development and utilization of personnel; cooperate also in migration, combating of crime, conserving nature and in the exchange of scientific and technical information. The two countries also agreed to undertake joint research projects in various fields of mutual interest.

Both states have already initiated cooperation on promotion and reciprocal protection of investment, trade, health and science and technology.

Tembo and Nzo said that the agreement laid the basis for furthering cooperation between the two countries since the collapse of apartheid and establishment of Nelson Mandela's democratic government of national unity in 1994.

Both states are members of the 12-nation Southern African Development Community. This body is supposed to integrate and develop economies in the sub-region.

South Africa has been blamed by the other economically weaker community states of dominating trade in the region. Pretoria, therefore, is renegotiating new trade terms with Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia and Swaziland, her coooperating partners in the Southern African Customs Union.

Other union members have also accused Pretoria of monopolizing trade within their grouping.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Fuel Gas Scarcity Bites Harder In Lagos


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 11, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 374 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Long lines at filling stations and a chaotic public transport system continued to afflict Lagos Monday as a gas shortage bit harder in the Nigerian commercial city.

Workers and school children were stranded at bus stops waiting for few available transport, while vehicles lined up bumper to bumper at the few filling stations that still had stock. 

Other towns of the oil-producing country, including the capital of Abuja, have reported fuel shortages.

Meanmwhile, Nigeria's Petroleum Resources Minister Dan Etete has ordered the arrest of five oil marketers accused of hoarding in Lagos.

During an unscheduled tour on arrival from a foreign trip Sunday he ordered the arrest of the five men including four filling station managers after he discovered they had fuel supplies but refused to service desperate motorists.

Etete said he was disgusted at the attitude of the men whom he described as "happy at seeing other Nigerians suffer."

And the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation has said the broken down fluid catalytic cracking unit of one of the nation's four oil refineries in southeastern city of Port Harcourt is to be recommisssioned.

The refineries in Port Harcourt and neighbouring Eleme have an installed capacity of about half of the nation's four refineries, put at 450,000 barrels per day.

The corporation said the fault at the Port Harcourt plant had stalled production and the country's overall supply.

Energy experts say it could take two to three weeks for the unit to resume production after the commissioning, an indication that the fuel shortage could linger for a while.

Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Conference on Children Opens In Harare


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 11, 1996


LENGTH: 200 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - A weeklong African child consultation conference to bring the plight of the continent's children to the attention of governments and policy-makers opened Monday in Harare. 

The meeting is being attended by some 200 delegates from various African countries, United Nations agencies, non-governmental organizations and children.

Zimbabwe Health and Child Welfare Minister Timothy Stamps, who opened the conference, warned governments against concentrating on economic growth at the expense of children.

He said he was concerned at the rising cases of child sex abuse in Zimbabwe.

Under the theme "Generation At Risk - What Future", the consultation will focus on issues such as children in war zones, education and health needs and cultural, political and economic effects on children.

16 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Government Urged Not to Impose Candidates


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 11, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 454 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - The United States government Monday in Lusaka cautioned the government of President Frederick Chiluba to let Zambians themselves choose and elect people they wanted in this year's parliamentary and presidential elections.

Visiting U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for Africa Prudence Bushnell made the call Monday in Lusaka at a luncheon hosted for her by United States embassy officials. 

"Zambia and the U.S. have a lot of things in common. Both countries believe in democracy..." said Bushnell.

Political analysts and diplomatic observers saw Bushnell's remarks as a rebuke to the Chiluba government's determination to pass legislation to block former president Kenneth Kaunda from standing in this year's general elections.

The Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) government has published a constitutional amendment bill which, among others, seeks to bar Zambians born of alien parents from holding the office of president.

Kaunda had Malawian parents who settled in Zambia at the close of the 18th century. They came to the country as missionaries of the Church of Scotland.

The proposal has been widely challenged and Kaunda himself has vowed that he will "fight to the bitter end" to prevent its adoption.

The United States has hailed Zambia as "a model of democracy" in Africa and Washington is thought to have felt "embarrassed" by the MMD's undemocratic tendencies.

Chiluba and his party officials have of late been adamant that the course of Zambia's democracy will not be determined by outsiders.

Speaking at the same function Monday in Lusaka, Zambia's Deputy Foreign Affairs Minister Peter Machungwa told Bushnell that the country would consolidate the "fragile democracy" which he said the U.S. had helped to put in place during the 1991 multiparty elections that had ended Kaunda's 27-year reign.

Bushnell arrived in Zambia Sunday and is scheduled to leave Tuesday after meeting Chiluba.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

17 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Privatisation of Ailing Parastatals to Wait


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 12, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 760 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's military government has said it is putting on hold a plan to privatize inefficient parastatals, especially the national telecommunications and electricity authorities, because of their huge foreign debts.

Finance minister Anthony Ani said at the inauguration of Nigeria's Council of Chartered Instutute of Stockbrokers in Lagos Monday that the government establishments were heavily indebted to the World Bank and other financial institutions.

The government, in response to complaints from Nigerians about the glaring inefficiency of the agencies, had set out plans to privatize or commercialize them. 

But Ani said "we are not going to privatize the parastatals because they are owing heavily."

He said the "indebtedness of the Nigerian Telecommunications Company (NITEL) to the World Bank and others is in billions," of naira (82.5 naira =1usd).

Ani said government would, however, continue with its commercialization of the parastatals.

Meanwhile, the minister said the Nigerian government is to set up a panel to examine reforms of the country's capital market.

The excercise is aimed at "codifying all laws relating to security dealings so that all operators...derive their powers and functions from a common body of legislation."

Ani said government was also going ahead to acquire "golden shares" in the nation's four big banks. These are the First Bank, Union Bank, UBA and Afribank.

Some economic experts had warned that undue government control could scare potential investors from the banks, which enjoy commanding status on the Nigerian stock market.

But Ani dismissed this argument, saying the government plan has received the support of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

"Nobody has objected to the plan," he said, adding: "We discussed with the IMF and the World Bank. They did not object to it."
Benin
Electoral Commission Issues Final Results
(by
Panafrican News Agency
March 11, 1996
by Ali Idrissou Toure, PANA Staff Correspondent
(tx

COTONOU, Benin - Benin's incumbent President Nicephore Soglo and his predecessor Mathieu Kerekou were Sunday night declared the two presidential candidates for the second round of voting March 17 by the country's Constitutional Court.

According to the final results of the first round of elections Soglo won 35.69 percent of the votes, while Kerekou came second with 33.94 percent.

Adrien Houngbedji came third with 19.71 percent, followed by Bruno Amoussou with 6.76 percent, while three candidates polled less than 3 percent each.

Houngbedji and Amoussou have already urged their supporters to vote for Kerekou in the second round on March 17 so as to ensure the ouster of Soglo.

Soglo's camp has to complained about an unspecified international plot to undermine Benin's democracy.

The Constitutional Court nullified 494,673 ballots due to fraud and other irregularities. The figure reprsents 23 percent of the votes.

The court put the voter turn-out rate at 88 percent.

18 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Africa's Economy Grows Slightly


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 12, 1996 by Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 574 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Africa's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) grew by 2.2 percent in 1995 compared with to 1.6 percent the previous year.

The Executive Secretary of the Economic Commission, Kingsley Amoako, said in Addis Ababa Monday that this came about despite a series of conflicts and civil strife, drought and other natural calamities.

Opening the ninth conference of African planners, statisticians, and population and information specialists, the ECA chief said Africa's GDP grew by only 0.8 percent in 1993. 

The conference meets on biennial basis to examine the economic and social situations in Africa.

Its task, within the mandate given by African ministers of planning due to meet here in April, is to advice on what the United Nations Commission for Africa can do to help member states in their development planning challenges.

Reviewing Africa's economic performance in 1995, Amoako said the agricultural sector "virtually stagnated last year after exceptional growth in 1994."

According to him, per capita food production fell by 2.6 percent. Cereal production fell by 15 per cent in 1995, while manufacturing output dropped by 3.7 per cent in 1994 and 2.8 per cent in 1995, due to low levels of investment and inherent structural weaknesses.

Amoako attributed the continent's improved GDP in 1995 to the mining sector, including a 12 percent rise in oil prices and 20 percent in metal prices.

Africa's export that had stagnated in 1994 grew by nearly 16 percent in 1995 as a result of rising commodity prices and external demand generated by the economic recovery in developed states.

Africa's export prices rose by 10.5 percent in 1995, double the 1994 growth rate, while import prices also rose by 7.2 percent the same year against 3.8 percent in 1994.

"As a result, the terms of trade improved by 3 percent in 1995, an increase of over 2 percent improvement on the previous year," the ECA executive said.

"Africa's marginalized position in the world economy makes pursuit of economic integration fundamental to its develop- ment," he observed

Amoako urged the continent's planners and decision makers to see to it that Africa becomes part of the information age to remain competetive and part of an international economic order.

The conference's agenda includes a study entitled "Building Africa's Information Highway," which was requested by the ECA.

Its aim is to put together an African action plan on using upcoming information and communication technologies to accelerate socio-economic development.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


19 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large U.N. Africa Development Drive For Launch Thursday


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 12, 1996 by Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 360 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York - The United Nations Special Initiative on Africa, expected to provide a renewed impetus to the development efforts on the continent, will be launched simultaneously in seven cities around the world Thursday, the world body announced Tuesday.

A U.N. media advisory said the launch would be held at U.N. headquarters in New York as well as in Paris, Geneva, Rome, Nairobi, Johannesburg and Abidjan. 

The Addis Ababa-based Organization of African Unity (OAU) will be linked to the live event in New York by satellite. This will enable the OAU chairman, President Meles Zzenawi of Ethiopia, and the organization's secretary-general, Salim Ahmed Salim, to participate in the launch.

U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and the president of the World Bank, James Wolfensohn, will perform the New York launching of the 10-year, 25-billion-dollar program.

They are expected to be joined by the administrator of the U.N. Development Programme, James Speth, who is a co-chairman of the initiative's steering committee.

The U.N. has described the initiative as the most significant mobilization of international support for development in any region of the world.

It said that most of the 25 billion dollars required for the initiative would come from the re-allocation of existing national and international budget priorities.

The World Bank has agreed to lead in raising the remaining funds, which will be used to provide Africa's basic education, health, peace-building, good governance, water and food security.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


United States and Africa Clinton Asks Eyadema to Help Resolve Liberian Crisis


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 12, 1996


LENGTH: 147 words


 

LOME, Togo - United States President Bill Clinton has asked Togolese President Gnassibgbe Eyadema to help resolve the Liberian crisis, Togolese national radio reported Tuesday. 

It said the American ambassador in Togo, Johnny Young, had Monday handed over a message from Clinton asking Eyadema to help seek a solution to the six-year civil war in Liberia.

Meanwhile, the Economic Community of West African States holds a special summit on Liberia on March 24. The summit, to be held in Accra, Ghana, has been called by President Jerry Rawlings, the current ECOWAS chairman.

The regional grouping has a peacekeeping force in strife-torn Liberia.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


21 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


United States and Africa Africa Begins To Matter To The United States


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 12, 1996 by Felix Njoku, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - European businesses have dominated the African scene since the major powers carved up choice parts of the "Dark Continent" for themselves in Berlin a century ago.

In one form or the other, Belgian, Dutch, French, English and German firms with tacit state backing maintained this dominance until the early 1960s when such Asian tigers like Japan and Taiwan managed to secure a foothold. At the time the United States was busy fighting Soviet Communism in several parts of the "blighted continent".

Now, with the demise of the Soviet Union, Washington says it will no longer play second fiddle in Africa. 

U.S. Commerce Secretary Ron Brown broke the ice last February in a well publicized five-nation African tour poised to scale what he described as "the world's last commerical barrier".

"The United States will no longer concede African markets to traditional colonial powers," Brown was quoted as telling an audience in Washington ahead of the Feb. 17-25 tour.

The European Union countries, he said, gobbled up 40 percent of the market share in sub-Sahara Africa while the United States share was lower than 8 percent.

"That makes no sense at all. We have got to change that ratio," he said.

The team toured Botswana, Ivory Coast, Ghana, Kenya and Uganda, and held discussions with an array of government officials.

Once on the trail, the usual fears about AIDS, monkeys and Ebola were doused by the habitual African hospitality to foreign guests, a detail they could not miss in Ivory Coast, the bastion of Francophone African and a haven for French investment.

In Abidjan, Brown and his team performed what observers say was equal to hoisting the American flag in a foreign land: the inauguration of General Motors sales and maintenance office in West Africa. This was followed by business agreements between U.S. firms and government officials, including a housing contract to Cahdwick International worth 92 million dollars.

These and other ventures were part of some 9 billion dollars worth of potential openings up for grabs in parts of the continent.

In Kenya, Brown and his team were received by President Daniel Arap-Moi and the entire cabinet, a point he did not miss in his up-beat address.

"I am the first American secretary of state to set foot on Kenyan soil. And I hope that sends a clear and undeniable message that Africa is important to the United States of America. We will no longer concede the African marketplace to our European friends or to anybody else.

"We are here to compete for African business on the African continent," he added.

Why the change of heart? Since when did Africa cease to be nothing more than a catalogue of woes, where every benevolent cent that came its way ended up in rat holes?

It took years of lobbying by "Africanists" and politicians including President Bill Clinton to bring America's corporate world to start believing that "Africa matters".

Witney Schneidman, a prominent African affairs analyst and vice president of Samuel's International Associates Inc., says postive trends in the continent are changing American corporate attitude to Africa towards closer ties.

He cited three examples: American multinational corporations reported 25 percent return on their African investments in the past couple of years, outpacing similar ventures in other developing regions.

-In 1994, U.S. firms exported nearly 4.4 billion dollars worth of goods to sub-Sahara Africa. This was 22 percent higher than the country's exports to states of the former Soviet Union.

- African stock markets provided an average of 40 percent return to investors in 1995.

Franklin Kennedy of Equator Bank and president of the African Business Roundtable identified export agriculture, light industry, mining, infrastructure development and finance management services as some of the sectors American investors can tap for profit.

"Based on Equator's experience in managing the African Growth Fund and the Kenya Equity Fund, I can assure you that there is no lack of opportunity for investors," Kennedy told American legislators in Capitol Hill last month.

Elesewhere, reactions to the American drive have ranged from disdain to veiled hostility.

For instance, Washington's brash talk about engaging former colonial powers in business competition in Africa has elicited rumours about "Yankees in a hurry to reap where they did not sow."

France, which has a large political and economic stake in sub-Sahara Africa is not amused by the development which in concrete terms means that Ford vehicles would soon begin to jostle with Peugeot, "the car for Africa", for a niche in the African market.

President Jacques Chirac has let it be known that France does not intend to vacate its high stool in the region.

In a key address in Gabon soon after he moved into the Elysee Palace late in 1995, Chirac acknowledged that Francophone Africa would have to free its trade and open up business to other investors. But he could not hide his misgivings about "Anglo-Saxons (who) dream of pushing France out of its position in Africa without paying a price."

In Africa, pessimists wonder if Africa is not heading for another round of exploitation, in apparent reference to long years of slavery, colonialism and neo-colonialism which stripped the continent of its wealth.

Using the former Belgian Congo (now Zaire) to make his point, Kwame Nkrumah, that African sage of unsurpassed vision, had a word on foregn investment

"The struggle against neo-colonialism is not aimed at excluding the capital of the developed world from operating in developed countries.

"It is aimed at preventing the financial power of the developed countries being used in such a way as to impoverish the less developed," he said in 1974.

Analysts are unsure if most African countries have been weaned from neo-colonialism. But Ron Brown seemed to have allayed these fears when he defined the ultimate goal of the initiative.

"Our commercial mission to sub-Sahara Africa is an important step toward the goal of bringing together African and U.S. public and private sector representatives to determine the most appropriate and effective role that we can play in Africa's future," he said.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Liberia Fresh Fighting Erupts


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 14, 1996


LENGTH: 227 words


 

MONROVIA, Liberia - Fresh fighting is reported to have erupted on the main highway linking Monrovia to Western Liberia.

ECOMOG sources told PANA Thursday that the fighting, between the Ulimo militia loyal to the movement's new leader William Karyee and those loyal to deposed leader Roosevelt Johnson, had broken out Tuesday around Sasstown, some 41 Km from Monrovia. 

Karyee loyalists are reported to have been carrying weapons seized from the West African peacekeeping force (ECOMOG) by Ulimo during fighting in between the two sides in December.

The renewed hostilities, said to have continued until Thursday afternoon, have brought another round of insecurity to the area from which ECOMOG withdrew two weeks ago.

Karyee told PANA Thursday that the fighting in Sasstown had been sparked by Johnson loyalists who were trying to prevent his cadres from returning the weapons seized from ECOMOG.

PANA could not verify the statement with the Johnson faction.

Africa News


March, 1996


Burundi At Least 13 Killed In The South and Northwest


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 14, 1996


LENGTH: 227 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - At least 13 people were killed by Hutu gangs in two Burundi towns in the last 24 hours, the country's news agency, ABP, reported Thursday.

The agency said the attacks took place in in the coastal town of Ramonge, 70 kilometers (43 miles) south of Bujumbura, and in Mpanda, in the northwestern province of Bubanza. 

In Ramonge, several men armed with machine guns and grenades attacked the town center at dawn Thursday. Nine people died and the gangs looted shops.

In Mpanda, 30 kilometers (18.6 miles) northwest of Bujumbura, armed gangs attacked the Guoss camp for displaced persons Wednesday. Two attackers and two displaced people were killed in the attack, police said.

The ongoing ethnic-based violence in Burundi now has spread to Bubanza, one of the few southern Burundian provinces that previously had been spared.

It was unaffected when Hutu militants massacred at least 500,000 Tutsis and moderate Hutus, following the assassination President Melchior Ndadaye, a Hutu, in a failed coup. eng

LANGUAGE: English

24 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Uganda Another Rebel Ambush In North


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 14, 1996 by Moses Draku PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 520 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda - Rebels of Lord's Resistance Army, fighting President Yoweri Museveni's government, shot up a passenger mini-bus Wednesday in northern Uganda killing an unspecified number of people.

The attack, the second in a week, occured two kilometers (1.2 miles) from the Karuma Bridge on the Karuma-Pakwach road leading to the country's West Nile Region.

The mini-bus was heading to Kampala from the West Nile Regional capital of Arua. It carried about 30 people. Six of the known survivors were rescued by Red Cross vehicles heading for Kampala from Arua, one victim said in Kampala. 

Shiama Awuma, whose husband was killed in the latest attack, said a Ugandan army unit at Pakwach allowed her group to travel unescorted through the rebel-infested Murchison Falls National Park.

"They assured us that the road was safe. For a long distance we travelled safely. We even passed the scene of last Friday's ambush without any problem," she said.

But as the bus approached the Karuma Bridge, their bus was shot up by rebels, forcing the driver to stop immediately.

"Several bullets were shot, killing my husband instantly," she said, while breastfeeding her crying child.

She said the rebels later looted the bus and left the survivors and the dead at the scene.

In an earlier attack Friday, units of the Lord's Resistance Army, headed by Joseph Kony, attacked a 17-vehicle convoy killing an estimated 70 people.

As the rebel ambush was happening Wednesday, the minister for defense, Amama Mbabazi, was delivering an official government statement to the National Resistance Council, or parliament, about Friday's attack.

He said 59 of the 71 people abducted by the rebels had been released and 12 are still in captivity. The Ugandan Defense Force, he said, had killed 90 rebels and captured 15. At least 60 surrendered and more than 100 were injured.

He said government would give 300,000 shillings, about 200 U.S. dollars to the families of each murdered ambush victim.

Mbabazi also said an army lieutenant and two other soldiers died when their truck hit a landmine five kilometers (3 miles) outside the northern regional capital, Gulu.

Only two weeks ago, 21 government soldiers were killed by the rebels at Minakulu along Gulu-Kampala road.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


25 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Benin Court Rejects Postponement of Run-Off Polls


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 11, 1996 by Ali Idrissou Toure PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 254 words


 

COTONOU, Benin - The constitutional court in the West African state of Benin rejected the government's decision to shift run-off presidential polls scheduled for March 17 to March 21, saying the postponement was unneeded.

The court said Wednesday the ballot should be held "at the latest on March 18", adding that the postponement was "contrary to the constitution." 

Benin's constitution provides that in the absence of a clear winner in the first round of polling, "a second ballot shall be held within 15 days."

The decision taken Tuesday by the government to postpone the second ballot to March 21 was challenged in the constitutional court on Wednesday by former President Mathieu Kerekou's support committee. Kerekou is running neck-to-neck against incumbent President Nicephore Soglo, after the first round on March 3.

Soglo won 35.69 percent of the total ballots compared to 33.94 percent for Kerekou who headed the country's military Marxist regime for more than a decade until he was replaced by Soglo in multiparty elections in 1992.

Two other prominent candidates -- Adrien Houngbedji who wom 19.71 percent and Bruno Amoussou who won 7.3 percent of the votes -- asked their constituents to vote for Kerekou in the final round.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


26 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Sierra Leone Country Gears up for Run-Off Election Friday


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 11, 1996 by Abdul Jalloh PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 334 words


 

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone - Sierra Leone's Interim National Electoral Commission said the run-off presidential election will take place Friday despite a rebel threat to disrupt the elections.

This second round of voting became necessary when none of the 13 presidential candidates obtained the required 55 percent of the votes in the first election held Feb. 26-27. 

Friday's run-off will be between Tejan Kabba of the Sierra Leone People's Party and John Karefa-Smart of the United National People's Party, the two leading contenders from the first election.

Both men have been campaigning and seeking alliances with lesser parties. Kabba succeeded in gaining the support of the People's Democratic Party, the All People's Congress and the National Unity Party. These are the three parties that gained more than 5 percent of the total votes during the last elections. Parties smaller than these have also given their support to Kabba.

A joint international observer group will monitor the election and will convey to the Interim National Electoral Commission, or to the judiciary, any complaints received about the electoral process. These observers also will monitor the legal process of dealing with such complaints.

Meanwhile, the military is busy with cleaning up operations in rebel-infected areas in the northern and southern provinces of this West African country. The government said it will ensure security on polling day. There are signs that the run-off will be more peaceful than the elections held in Feburary.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa-at-Large Boxing: Boxers Prepare For Atlanta Olympics


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 11, 1996 by Bouazza Ben Bouazza PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 640 words


 

TUNIS, Tunisia - The quarter-final rounds of the African boxing tournament in preparation for the Atlanta Summer Olympics has commenced in Tunis, Tunisia.

The following results were recorded at the end of encounters in various categories on Wednesday: 60kg Category: - Mohamed Allalou (Algeria) defeated Kamal Marjouane (Morocco) on points (8-2), - Nassreddine Jormane (Tunisia) beat Idrissa Kabore (Burkina) on points (14-2), - Yahya Oshanu (Ghana) beat Mnqobi Malophe (Zimbabwe) on points (8-7), - Ogentho Franco (Ouganda) beat Hassen Ally Matumla (Tanzania) abandoned fight in third round.

67kg Category: - Laid Bouneb (Algeria) beat Berkane Henok (Ethiopia) on a computer decision after drawing (7-7) on points - Sinoia Lucos (Mozambique) beat Salif Ouatara (Burkina) abandoned fight in 2nd round, - Hassen Mzonge (Tanzania) beat Balloguo Kodzo Sabou (Togo) on points (8-5), - Lahsen Kabil (Morocco) beat Misere Ngoma (Congo) abandoned fight in 1st round.

54kg Category: - Abdelaziz Boulehia (Algerie) beat Raymond Narh (Ghana) on points (9-2), - Jean Thierry Nzumbat (Gabon) beat Simon Sankulani (Zimbabwe) on points (7-2), - Robert Mutota (Namibie) beat Hicham Nafil (Morocco) by disqualification in the 2nd round, - Stive Naraina (Mauritius) beat Patrick Mabuza Silence (South Africa) on points (7-3).

57kg Category: - Elvis Konamegui (Cameroon) outpunched Adjano Anges (Benin) (5-2), - Mohamed Achik (Morocco) beat Gaston Towo (Zimbabwe) on points (8-2), - Noureddine Madjhoud (Algeria) defeated Ben Odametey (Ghana) on points (9-1), - Albertus Katiti (Namibia) beat Ndirangu Jnhn Muturu (Kenya) on points (6-5).

65.5kg Category: - Evry Le Gras (Seychelles) outpunched Fraus Mambuu (Namibia) (11-1), - Houssine Soltani (Algeria) beat Carr Stefnus (South Africa) on points (6-2), - Tijani Moro (Ghana) defeated Andre-Roger Manga (Cameroon) on points (12-3), - Fethi Missaoui (Tunisia) eliminated Abdallah Benbiar (Morocco) on points (13-8).

The encounter is billed to end on on Saturday.

Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Olympic Meet Set in Nigeria


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 11, 1996 by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 320 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria and Zimbabwe Under-23 national teams are now to play in Lagos Sunday their last qualification match to pick one of Africa's three representatives for the upcoming Summer Olympic Games in Atlanta, United States.

Nigeria won the first leg 1-0 in Harare two weeks ago, and the return leg had been fixed for Saturday. 

But Nigerian sports minister Jim Nwobodo said because of the national local council polls on Saturday, the world's soccer governing body, FIFA has given approval for the match to be played Sunday.

The Zimbabweans are expected in Lagos Thurday.

Meanwhile, an array of Nigeria's foreign based professional players are already in Lagos training with their home-based counterparts for the crucial encounter.

Those in camp, include Teslim Tasusin, scorer of the lone goal in Harare, master dribbler Austin 'Jay-Jay' Okocha from Germany, dreadlocked Taribo West who plays in France, Sunday Oliseh, Victor Igbeba and the Babayaro brothers, Celestine and Emmanuel.

A lagos-based soft drink giant, Pepsi, sponsors of Nigeria's division one professional league has announced a cash prize of 25,000 naira (about 300 USD) for the best player in Sunday's match.

The Nigerian Football Association has cancelled all local league engagements slated for Saturday. The matches will now come up on Monday and Wednesday.

March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Cross Country: 21 African Countries Vie For Championships


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 4, 1996


LENGTH: 187 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - Twenty-one African countries have confirmed their participation to the World Cross Country Championships beginning March 23 in Cape Town, South Africa, The African Amateur Athletics Confederation said.

A total of 329 athletes and 58 officials from Africa are expected at the meet, which will be held for the first time on the continent. 

With 36 athletes each, Kenya and Morocco will field the largest number of runners. This is followed by South Africa and Ethiopia with 27 runner a piece and Angola with 26.

The competition will include women's and men's events at junior and senior level.

The holder of the men's title is Kenya's Paul Tergat. He won the 23rd championships held last year in Durham, Britain, while Ethiopia's Derartu Tulu holds the women's title.

March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Soccer: Ghana Beat Cameroon Olympics Qualifier


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 4, 1996


LENGTH: 227 words


 

KUMASI, Ghana - Ghana on Sunday beat Cameroon 3-0 in the first-leg Olympic Games qualifying match played at the Kumasi Sports Stadium northwest of Accra, thanks to three second half goals.

The Ghanaians, who won a bronze medal at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics, struggled for most of the first half when they could not put their act together.. This gave the defensive-minded Cameroonians the chance to come into the picture. 

But the Ghanaians came back into the game in the second half, and despite throwing away a penalty in the 47th minute, scored three goals in the last 23 minutes to win the day.

The first goal came in the 67th minute when Stephen Baidoo headed home a corner kick taken by Mallam Yahaya.

Ben Hacan scored the second in the 80th minute when he hit the ball into the net after Prince Amoako's shot had bounced off the Cameroonian goalkeeper.

Hacan was on target again in the 85th minute from a solo effort that put the icing on the cake.

Africa-at-Large Ethiopian Athletes Selected for Cross Country Tourney


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 8, 1996


LENGTH: 200 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Ethiopia has selected 27 athletes for next month's cross country competition in Cape Town, South Africa. The Ethiopian Athletic Federation said here over the weekend, the selection was based on the results of the 13th national cross country competition held in Addis Ababa last month. 

The Ethiopian team will include such international athletic luminaries as Haile Gebre-Selassie and Derartu Tulu.

Haile is world record holder in 10,00 m, 5,000 m and 3,000m. Derartu Tulu won a gold medal in Barcelona olympics in 1992.She also won the women cross country title in Durham, England in 1995.

In South Africa, she will team up with Gete Mwami and Fatuma Roba.

On the other hand, Haile will be joined by Habte Jifar, winner of last month's Ethiopian international cross country meet, Worku Bikila, and the brothers Assefa Mezghebu and Ayele Mezghebu.

March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Soccer: Nigeria's Soccer League Defending Champs in Trouble


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 2, 1996 by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 214 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The fate of Nigerian soccer league defending champions, Shooting Stars of Ibadan, remained uncertain Sunday after they disobeyed a "military order" by failing to win Saturday's league goalless tie against Iwuanyanwu Nationale.

The Stars and their officials were ordered Friday by Col. Ike Nwosu, military administrator (governor) of the western state of Oyo, the club's proprietors, to win the match or be "locked up in jail." 

But the 1995 Football League and Challenge Cup champions playing at home before a capacity crowd, which included Nwosu, managed only a 0-0 draw. Apart from missing several scoring chances, the Stars missed a penalty kick. This angered Nwosu, who stormed out of the stadium mid-way through the match. His reaction has left the players and their officials in suspense.

Nwosu has still not commented on the fate of the Shooting Stars, Nigeria's representatives in this year's Africa Champions Cup. The team is third from bottom on the 18-club league table.

March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Soccer: Nigerian League Champions Risk Going to Jail


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996 by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 240 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Players and officials of Nigeria's fumbling league defending champions, Shooting Stars, risk going to jail if they fail to win Saturday's match against another Nigerian team, Inwuanynumu Nationale -- or at least so it seems.

Col. Ike Nwosu, military administrator (governor) of Nigeria's western state of Oyo, owners of the Stars, said at a meeting with the players and their officials Friday he would have them locked up if they failed to deliver. 

He told them "to win the next (Saturday's) match against Inwuanynwu Nationale at all cost... Otherwise I will get all of you locked up."

The administrator, who had earlier threatened to disband the club for poor performance in this year's four-week-old league, warned he would make the players refund their sign-on fees if they failed to improve.

The Stars, who won Nigeria's league and challenge (FA) cups last year, have managed only two draws, and suffered one defeat during 1996.

They are third from the bottom of Nigeria's 18-club league table.

The Stars are Nigeria's representatives in this year's Africa Champions Cup.

35 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Prof. Ake Wins MLK Award


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 294 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerian scholar Prof. Claude Ake has won the 1996 Community Service Award instituted in honour of the late African American civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jnr.

The United States Information Service (USIS) in Lagos said the social scientist clinched the award because of his "exceptional contributions to public education." 

Ake was recognised for "promoting the application of the social sciences to solve critical social problems, such as resolution of conflicts, youth violence, environmental degradation and gender issues."

He was said to have provided an invaluable resource for research and dialogue on critical social issues to the Nigerian society in his position as the founder and director of the Centre for Advanced Social Science, based in Port Harcourt, southeastern Nigeria.

The award was established in 1995 in response to the call by the U.S. President Bill Clinton to make the Martin Luther king holiday a day of national service.

It recognises outstanding achievements of individuals who volunteer their time and talents to improving their communities.

Candidates for this year's award were considered in three categories -- democracy,human rights and rule of law; education, culture and media; and economics, business and environment.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


36 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large World Bank To Lead UN Africa Development Fund Drive


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996 by Nicholas Ibewuike PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 427 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The World Bank will spearhead the drive for funds under the United Nations Special Initiative for African Development, a UN official said in Lagos Friday.

Janet Badjan-Young, director of the UN information centre in Nigeria, told journalists the bank was ready to mobilise more than 85 percent of the 25 billion U.S. dollars earmarked for expenditure over the next 10 years.

She said the bulk of the money under the initiative launched by the UN Secretary-General Friday would go into "improving basic education and health" on the continent. 

She said the initiative for Africa seeks to maximize support for the continent's development efforts.

Badjan-Young said African finance ministers had during their recent meeting in Burkina Faso identified 14 components grouped under four themes that reflect Africa's development priorities.

She said the UN programme was aimed at providing basic education, health care, promote peace, better governance, and improve water supply and food security in Africa.

The UN official however said "while Africa needs external support, it is the Africans themselves, men and women, who must take charge of their destiny and who should have the fundamental responsibility for bringing about development on their continent."

She cited the example of Botswana, which she said was one of the world's poorest countries after its independence in 1966, but which has managed to surmount its socio-economic difficulties. "Today, Botswana has one of the most prosperous economies in Africa," Badjan-Young added. Meanwhile, the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) representative in Nigeria, Babasola Chinsman, said the UN initiative was not new, but a re-alignment of what had been planned for Africa. He urged Africans to fashion out good governance and resource management. A World Bank senior officer, Eileen Nbwanga, said the abandonment of Structural Adjustment Programmes (SAP) had worsened living standards on the continent.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


37 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large OAU Commends United Nations Initiative


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996 by Ghion Hagos PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 427 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Organization of African Unity (OAU) Chairman Meles Zenawi Friday commended the new United Nations intitiative for Africa for its goal-oriented approach.

The Ethiopian Prime Minister said this in a satellite link speech to co-launch the 25-billion US dollar Special Initiative for Africa, inaugurated in New York Friday by UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and World Bank president James Wolfensons. 

Meles said the initiative is based on priorities OAU member states have identified collectively and individually.

Although the future of Africa lies in the hands of the Africans themselves, he said, the international community has a responsibility, in this inter-dependent world to help Africa overcome abject poverty.

Also speaking during the satellite launching ceremony, the Executive Secretary of the Economic Commission for Africa, Kinsley Amoako, said the initiative was a great affirmation of the U.N.'s role and commitment to work with African leaders and peoples "to equip Africa to meet the challenges of the 21st century."

Acting OAU Secretary-General Vijay S. Makham said the continental body was in full agreement "that the ownership of the initiative should be vested in each one of OAU member states and that it be based on national programmes prepared by our respective countries."

Makham said the OAU will popularise the initiative "to ensure the attainment of the laudable objectives of the initiative together with the United Nations."

The multi-billion-dollar initiative is aimed at expanding basic education and health care, promote peace and good governance and improve water and food security throughout Africa over a 10-year period.

The U.N initiative also aims at strengthening the OAU's capacity in conflict management and promoting all-round development in Africa.

The initiative was simultenously launched by heads of United Nations agencies in Geneva, Nairobi, Rome and Vienna.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


38 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zimbabwe Mugabe Now Sole Presidential Candidate


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 614 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe's remaining opposition candidate in the March 16 and 17 presidential elections, Retired Bishop Abel Muzorewa Friday pulled out of the race, leaving President Robert Mugabe unopposed and set to become president for another six-year term.

Muzorewa's withdrawal was announced minutes after his party's application for the postponement of the elections was thrown out by the supreme court in Harare.He is the head of the Unite parties (UP). 

The other opposition candidate, Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole of ZANU (Ndonga), pulled out on March 12, citing interference into the operations of his party by Zimbabwe's Central Intelligence Organisation.

The government election machinery was already in place with thousands of people having been trained in the running of elections already deployed at various stations.

The government on Thursday estimated no less than Zimdollars 50 million (USD 5.6 million) would be wasted if there were no elections.

Muzorewa's withdrawal deals a severe blow to Mugabe's plans of showing the world that he still has a massive following in Zimbabwe.

Faced with a largely apathetic voting population, Mugabe has addressed more than 40 rallies throughout the country in five weeks.

He has appealed for a massive turnout in the elections, saying low participation could be misinterpreted by the international community.

"I am confident that I will win but it is not (so) much of the winning that matters, but that we should turn up in our millions. If there is voter apathy, it will be misinterpreted by the international community," Mugabe told party supporters in Mount Darwin, about 160 km north of Harare, at the start of his campaign trail.

UP publicity and information secretary Isaac Manyemba announced Muzorewa's withdrawal, saying a letter to this effect had already been delivered to the Office of the Registar-General, Tobaiwa Mudede.

A copy of Muzorewa's letter to Mudede made available to the Zimbabwe Inter-African News Agency was dated March 14, showing the possibility that the UP had already made its decision to withdraw from the presidential race earlier and was only awaiting the outcome of the application in the supreme court.

Explaining the reasons for his withdrawal, Muzorewa said Zimbabwean laws were highly heavily tilted in favour of Mugabe's ruling ZANU PF.

His party had also asked for a postponement of the elections.

"In view of the fact that our application for the postponement of the presidential election has been turned down, the United Parties central committee has decided to withdraw participation from the presidential elections with immediate effect.

"The United Parties continues to be convinced that no democratic elections will ever be possible in Zimbabwe as long as the current regime of laws and the institutions that govern the conduct of elections remain unchanged," he said.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


39 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large UNESCO Spells Role In Africa's Special Initiative


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996 by George Ola Davies PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 614 words


 

PARIS, France - The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Friday pledged to contribute towards Africa's education, communication for peace, information technology and solar energy development.

The pledge was made in Paris by the UN agency's director-general, Federico Mayor, as Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the UN secretary general, launched the USD 25 billion dollar Special Initiative for Africa in New York.

"UNESCO will continue cooperating with African governments, the Organisation of African Unity, non-governmental organisations, donors and other partners within and outside the UN system to attain the special initiative's goals," Mayor said. 

UNESCO's Assistant Director-General for External Relations, Henri Lopes, spoke at length on how UNESCO intends to carry out the 10-year programme, saying it would be different from past ones that had suffered setbacks.

In the past, UNESCO's programmes for Africa faltered because of the lack of financial resources to back them up. This time, however, Lopes said, "with the involvement of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, the organisation is assured of obtaining the necessary financial support."

The importance of UNESCO's role should be seen in the context of the large amount of money dedicated to the basic education programme alone, he said.

Half of the intiative's combined costs over the 10-year period will be devoted to this sector.

This, said Lopes, "will be in addition to UNESCO's present USD 100 million annual budget for education and culture for Africa."

Another area in which UNESCO will be involved is the communication for peace-building project which aims at improving communications on the continent, especially radio broadcasting.

Communication for peace building will begin with assessement missions in a few selected countries in each of the five major African sub-regions (west, central, eastern, northern and southern).

It is estimated that USD 7.8 million will be spent on the programme over the next five years.

In cooperation with the World Bank and other UN agencies, UNESCO intends to spend an estimated USD 11.5 million to train systems engineers and operators and set up infrastructure to connect Africa with the Internet, including installation of internet nodes with local servers.

On completion of the programme in five years time, this project will help Africa become a part of the global information revolution.

Lopes said UNESCO will be working on a 400 million-dollar programme to promote the development of solar energy on the continent.

In September, he said, some 15 African heads of state will meet in Harare for a world summit on solar energy. "That the summit will be held in Africa under an African chairmanship, will give the project an upward thrust on the continent," he said.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


40 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Volleyball: Kenya, Nigeria Play Russia, Amid Protest


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996 by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 494 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Bowing to pressure from the International Volleyball Federation, Kenya and Nigeria have at last agreed to play Russia, an European country, in the Africa Zone Women's Olympic qualification matches in Lagos.

The two African countries had earlier threatened to pull out of the play-offs, kicking off here Friday, with Kenya taking on the highly rated Russsians.

The president of the Nigerian Olympic Committee, Raheem Adejumo, had said Thursday "we are determined to go to the level of an appeal if Russia, which was beaten in the European play-offs, comes to infiltrate Africa and attempt to deny the continent its deserved place in Atlanta." 

He was speaking to the president of the Confederation of African Volleyball, Cote D'Ivoire's Gabriel Guigui, who arrived here Thursday for the qualification matches.

However, Guigui gave an assurance the matter would be taken up with the International Volleyball Federation.

Kenya's team manager Njeri Onyango said it took the intervention of her country's volleyball federation to rescind the boycott decision.

She said having failed to pick a European olympic ticket, the Russians, ranked third in the world, had no business jostling to deny Africa its only berth.

However, Onyango said her team "is psychologically and physically prepared" for the tough task ahead.

James Kenami, another member of the Kenyan team, which arrived in Lagos Thursday, said they would play the Russians "under protest."

But in a new twist to the controversy, the president of the Nigeria Volleyball Association, Huba Gumel said Friday in Lagos the IVF was right in drafting Russia into the African zone of the competition.

He told journalists the federation's guideline stipulates that a minimum of three countries should feature in a qualifying series.

Gumel said that five African countries had registered for the olympic games elimination series but that only three -- Egypt, Kenya and Nigeria -- qualified to compete after participating in an African championship.

Russia was shifted to the African group following Egypt's withdrawal. Gumel said the IVF might have chosen Russia because of its past record as one of the best volleyball playing countries. Kenya and Nigeria protested vigourously.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
