Zimbabwe Mugabe Now Unopposed


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 146 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe's presidential elections scheduled for Saturday and Sunday were thrown into disarray Friday as the only remaining opposition candidate, retired Bishop Abel Muzorewa of United Parties, withdrew from the race.

Muzorewa's withdrawal was announced minutes after his party's application for the postponement of the elections was thrown out by the supreme court.

The other opposition candidate, Reverend Ndabaningi Sithole of ZANU (Ndonga), pulled out on March 12, citing interference into the operations of his party by Zimbabwe's Central Intelligence Organisation.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


42 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Uganda Ugandans Mourn Rebel Victims


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996 by Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 560 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda - Uganda observed Friday a day of national mourning for people killed recently by rebels of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) in an ambush in the country's north.

An estimated 70 people were shot dead and at least 80 others abducted last Friday when the LRA, headed by Joseph Kony, attacked a convoy of 17 civilian vehicles, escorted by a score of soldiers, on the road betwen Karuma and Pakwach in northern Uganda.

Sixty of those abducted have been released. 

Speaking at an inter-denominational service in Kampala, Prime Minister Kintu Musoke appealed to Ugandans to galvanise themselves for peace and fight evil wherever it exists.

He urged Ugandan politicians not to exploit the tragedy for political gain.

Meanwhile, President Yoweri Museveni has vowed to deal with the LRA rebels by April when he expects to have furnished adequate fire-power to the Uganda Peoples Defence Forces (UPDF).

"We need comprehensive capacity to deal with a large scale, reasonably equipped aggression if it ever comes, or the nomadic bandits who specialise in attacking soft targets.

"I am informing Ugandans, that by the middle of April, this capacity will be operational," Museveni said in an article published Friday.

He said the Ugandan army is using a new approach of diminishing expenditure by using less manpower and more technology.

"There is now a transformation from a large force of 100,000 men to a smaller force of tanks, aircraft, helicopters and other equipment which will be fully operational by next month," he said.

Museveni ruled out any peace talks with the rebels saying "I am, personally, very opposed to this idea. We extended an amnesty to all rebels many years ago. Many came. Some were even elected to lead up to the National Resistance Council (parliament)."

He castigated unnamed Ugandans who think that to bring peace to the north "we need to go to Khartoum (Sudan) and pledge our readiness to Tourabi to islamise and Arabize Uganda by force.We therefore, need to put the whole question into perspective" he said.

Hassan Tourabi is believed to be the ideological mentor of the of Gen. Omar Bashir's Islamic government.

Sudan and Uganda have on several occassions, especially last year, accused each other of supporting rebels from their territories.

At one stage, Khartoum accused Museveni's army of fighting alongside John Garang's Sudan People's Liberation Army fighting against Khartoum in southern Sudan.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


43 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Angola Savimbi May Not Take Vice-Presidency


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 227 words


 

PARIS, France - Unita's secretary general Paulo Lukamba 'Gato' said in Paris Thursday that the movement's political commission may not nominate Jonas Savimbi to the post of Angolan vice-president in a new government of national unity.

The Angolan government has offered Unita one of the two vice-presidencies to be created under a government of national unity. It had been widely assumed that Savimbi, the Unita leader, would take one of the positions.

"It is unlikely the Unita political commission will appoint Jonas Savimbi to the post," Lukamba said.

Lukamba said Savimbi was not very keen on the job and might instead concentrate on his responsibilities as head of his party and de facto leader of the opposition.

Savimbi has, however, submitted a list of Unita members that are to be part of the Angolan government of national unity to President Eduardo Dos Santos. The president heads the rival MPLA.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


44 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Weekly Press Review


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996 by Olu Sarr PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The murder trial March 11 of apartheid generals, among them Magnus Malan, attracted surprisingly little comment from the African press. However, one paper which did write on it was the privately-owned Dakar daily, Sud Quotidien.

The generals are facing charges of masterminding the 1987 killing of 13 African National Congress activitists in Kwazulu, Natal, South Africa. The accused have denied doing so. 

"Once the truth is established and justice prevails, it would be better to forgive," Sud Quotidien said.

"However risky this undertaking," it went on, "it gives a chance to those who think they are unfairly accused to prove their innocence and thus put an end to allegations of collusion between Inkhata and the white right wing."

The ANC, it said, was also taking risks.

"But it is worth the trouble if this allows the nation to look at itself in the mirror and see its true image," it said. "Therein lies the first truth and justice will follow: The one that leads to forgiveness, and the basis of true reconciliation."

Nigeria's semi-official Daily Times talked of Sierra Leone's run-off election due March 15, saying it would be "a dangerous and costly" affair.

"This is especially because the Revolutionary United Front, which had called for negotiations before the Feb. 26 elections (should be held), has threatened to disrupt the elections," it said.

"However," it said, "Gen. Julius Bio's government must be commended for placing great premium on the will of the people and going ahead with the elections in spite of the security implications," it said. "This is a mark of statesmanship in tune with the mood of the times."

It added: "It is now up to the political elite, who clamored for the elections to hold against all odds, to demonstrate their commitment to national unity and the public interest."

In Addis Ababa, Ethiopia's two state-owned dailies, the Amharic language Addis Zemen, and the English medium Ethiopian Herald focused on last week's ministerial meeting on sustainable development and the environment, and on the March 8 Women's Day, respectively.

The Herald commended the conference's call for measures to alleviate the plight of the hungry poor in the continent through "food safety net."

It said the call was important as Africa remains trapped in the quagmires of endemic poverty and degradation, despite its enourmous resources.

To the question "how goes the much discussed and debated food security crusade in the continent?, the Herald replied "not all that well, if documented evidence is any guide."

"There has no doubt been some progress in some African countries -- not least our own -- but neither fast nor substantially enough to warrant a sense of fulfilment."

The Amharic Addis Zemen, writing on the international women's day, wrote "about this alarming global problem" of violence against women.

"Dealing with gender violence in Africa is difficult everywhere. Violence against women and young girls remains a chronic problem in Africa in both urban and rural areas."

In Ethiopia, criminal acts like rape, abduction and child molesting are growing alarmingly to the extent of preventing women from going to schools as well as taking part in other social activities, the paper said.

For its part, Zambia's privately-owned daily, the Post, commented on the imprisonment of two of its editors: Fred M'Membe, the managing director and editor-in-chief, Bright Mwape, the managing editor; and columnist Lucy Sichone.

They were jailed by parliament for contempt of parliament and breach of parliamentary privileges.

The paper noted that there was plenty of vocal opposition to the jailings.

"Most, if not all, are surprised how it was possible in modern day Zambia for an institution to have the courage to send its citizens to imprisonment without being heard or being given a chance to defend themselves," the paper said.

It said that Health Minister Michael Sata and the chairman for the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy, Sikota Wina, claimed parliament's decisions could not be questioned by anybody.

"All serious legal opinion is agreed that our parliament has no power to try or jail citizens," it said.

"But so far all government officials have failed to counter the legal evidence that the speaker and his national assembly are wrong in jailing the three writers and should, therefore, release them," it said.

It charged the government with detaining the editors "out of spite and a vindictive trait" which, it said, was plain to see.

If this were not so and if government had the ability to accept its mistake, it said, Chiluba could have easily ordered "his rubber stamp parliament" to release the detainees.

"But President Chiluba is far from being a statesman and a rational leader. We have to wait and see which way the man who calls himself a born again Christian acts," it said.

"There is no doubt that government has lost face, that is, if it has any face to lose at all," it said.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


45 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large COMESA Enjoys Trade Cooperation


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Trade among the 20 states of the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa, or COMESA, is running at an average of 10.1 percent yearly, marking a substantial degree of cooperation in business and among customs departments, an official said.

Overall COMESA trade with the rest of the world is growing at 7.4 percent per annum.

Addressing journalists Thusday in Harare the official, COMESA Secretary-General Bingu Wa Mutharika, said several measures had been adapted to promote intro-community trade. 

"As a result, COMESA is now posed to attain the zero tariff target for intra-COMESA trade by the year 2000," he said.

This assessment arises from a 70 percent reduction of customs tariffs by most countries within the community.

Mutharika said member states were negotiating the introduction of the COMESA single goods declaration document which would facilitate the transit of goods across state lines boundries within the community.

Here are two other projects on the Automated System of Customs Data, or ASYCUDA, and Eurotrace as well as the Trade Information Network, TINET. All of these make trade information readily available to businesses.

Considerable progress has been made, in the year, to connect telecommunications networks among the community members. The effort is being funded by the African Development Bank and will cost 275 million U.S. dollars.

Of the 20 countries which signed the COMESA treaty, 14 have ratified the document over the past 15 months. These are Burundi, Comoros, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritius, Rwanda, Sudan, Tanzania, Uganda, Zaire and Zambia,

Angola, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland and Zimbabwe have not yet ratified the treaty.

On the dual membership to COMESA and the smaller Southern African Development Community, he said relationships between the two groups had made significant improvements over the past four to five months. He said that after the consultative meeting they would continue with the dialogue.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


46 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large UNESCO Spells Role In Africa's Special Initiative


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996 by George Ola Davies PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 614 words


 

PARIS, France - The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Friday pledged to contribute towards Africa's education, communication for peace, information technology and solar energy development.

The pledge was made in Paris by the U.N. agency's director-general, Federico Mayor, as Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the UN secretary general, launched the 25 billion dollars Special Initiative for Africa in New York.

"UNESCO will continue cooperating with African governments, the Organization of African Unity, non-governmental organizations, donors and other partners within and outside the U.N. system to attain the special initiative's goals," Mayor said. 

UNESCO's Assistant Director-General for External Relations, Henri Lopes, spoke at length on how UNESCO intends to carry out the 10-year programme, saying it would be different from past ones that had suffered setbacks.

In the past, UNESCO's programmes for Africa faltered because of the lack of financial resources to back them up. This time, however, Lopes said, "with the involvement of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, the organization is assured of obtaining the necessary financial support."

The importance of UNESCO's role should be seen in the context of the large amount of money dedicated to the basic education programme alone, he said.

Half of the intiative's combined costs over the 10-year period will be devoted to this sector.

This, said Lopes, "will be in addition to UNESCO's present USD 100 million annual budget for education and culture for Africa."

Another area in which UNESCO will be involved is the communication for peace-building project which aims at improving communications on the continent, especially radio broadcasting.

It is estimated that 7.8 million dollars will be spent on the program over the next five years.

In cooperation with the World Bank and other UN agencies, UNESCO intends to spend an estimated 11.5 million dollars to train systems engineers and operators and set up infrastructure to connect Africa with the Internet, including installation of internet nodes with local servers.

On completion of the program in five years time, this project will help Africa become a part of the global information revolution.

Lopes said UNESCO will be working on a 400 million-dollar program to promote the development of solar energy on the continent.

In September, he said, some 15 African heads of state will meet in Harare for a world summit on solar energy.

"That the summit will be held in Africa under an African chairmanship, will give the project an upward thrust on the continent," he said.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


47 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Cameroon and Nigeria Peaceful Solution On Bakassi Favored


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996 by Segun Adeyemi PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 454 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York - Cameroonian President Paul Biya says his country is committed to a peaceful resolution of its dispute with Nigeria over ownership of the Bakassi peninsula in the Gulf of Guinea.

In a letter to the United Nations Security Council, released in New York Thursday, Biya promised that Cameroon would abide by the decision of the Council, to which the country referred the dispute Feb. 23.

The council on Feb. 29, wrote to the heads of state of the two countries urging them to seek a peaceful solution to the dispute, avoid the use of force, and to withdraw their forces to the positions they occupied before the case was referred to the International Court of Justice at the Hague. 

The council also requested them to respect the cease-fire which they negotiated in Kara, Togo, in February.

The world court at the Hague is expected Friday to give preliminary ruling on the dispute over the oil-rich peninsula.

Biya said in his letter dated March 7, "I welcome this decision by the Security Council, the only possible guarantor of peace and security in the region, while awaiting the judgement of the International Court of Justice."

"I take this opportunity to reaffirm the determination of Cameroon to make every effort to settle this dispute by peaceful means," he added.

The Cameroonian leader also promised to cooperate with a UN fact-finding mission to be sent to the peninsula.

Cameroon sought the council's intervention on the issue, for the second time in two years, after fresh fighting broke out in the peninsula in February.

Nigeria in a letter to the council Feb. 27, accused Cameroon of instigating the latest attacks, and the previous ones.

Nigeria said in a statement its forces acted in self defence.

Both countries have troops on either side of the disputed territory, where tension flared resulting in skirmishes in February and April 1994.

Cameroon also reported the matter to the Organization of African Unity, based in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

Togolese President Gnassingbe Eyadema has initiated diplomatic efforts to settle the dispute.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


48 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Another Attempt On Democracy


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Corresspondent


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria, Africa's most populous country and under intense international pressure, takes yet another key step in its troubled march to democracy in Saturday's local council polls, political analysts say in Lagos.

In the non-party elections, the first in a series under military ruler Gen. Sani Abacha's controversial 36-month transition programme, Nigerian voters are to choose some 200,000 delegates Saturday through the open ballot system.

The polls, foreshadowed by fuel crisis in parts of the oil-producing country, will hold in some 6,919 wards scattered within the 593 local councils of the 30 states federation.

Using the electoral college system, the elected delegates will choose councillors from among themselves March 23, who will in turn elect a chairman for each council two days later. 

Barring logistic problems, the elections would be the first since the last military regime of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida annulled the controverial June 1993 presidential election in the country.

The cancellation of that poll, which had been adjudged free and fair by international observers after some eight years of Babangida's transition programme, threw Nigeria into political turmoil. The effects of this still linger in this country of some 100 million people.

Millionaire-politician Moshood Abiola, who claimed victory in the annulled presidential elections, is in detention. He is awaiting trial for treasonable felony after declaring himself Nigeria's president in June 1994.

After crushing internal opposition, mainly from uncoordinated pro-democracy groups, the Abacha administration which took power in November 1993 when Babangida left office in confusion, has stuck to its own political agenda.

A partly elected and nominated National Conference after one-year deliberation submitted a draft constitution to Abacha in July 1995.

This forms the plank of the three-year political timetable announced October 1995 by Anacha. It is expected to end with military handover to an elected civilian government Oct. 1, 1998.

Critics of the regime, including the British-led Commonwealth which suspended Nigeria over the execution in November 1995 of nine minority leaders, have dismissed the transition program as too long. The Commonwealth asked Nigeria to democratize within two years or be expelled from the body.

The United States, South Africa and the 15 European Union countries imposed sanctions on Nigeria for its hanging of nine Ogoni activists, among them author Ken Saro-Wiwa from southeastern Nigeria. They were executed for the May 1994 murder of four of their kinsmen.

Despite mounting pressure which has, however, fallen short of an oil embargo that would have hurt Nigeria most, the Abacha administration has insisted its transition program is irreversible.

Receiving a group of foreign envoys recently, who returned from a four-month recall for consultation over the November executions, Nigerian Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi underscored the country's peculiar political problem.

Urging the cooperation of the international community, he said, "our democracy is that which recognises our cultural, economic and social circumstances."

Justifying his return to Nigeria following the November recall, Washington's ambassador to Abuja, Walter Carrington, said resumption of his post "should not be interpreted as a lessening of U.S. concerns over the length of the (Nigerian) transition process of the human rights situation."

This was a veiled reference to criticism by Nigerian pro-democracy groups that the United States and western countries were softening their hard stance on Nigeria.

But one African diplomat, who wished to remain anonymous, said Washington and Western countries appeared hamstrung on Nigeria.

"Everyone is avoiding the much-talked about oil embargo, because of the huge investments by the Western countries in Nigeria's major oil industry," he said.

Nigerian officials have also slammed the "double standards" of the West on democracy and human rights matters.

Meanwhile, the military government has stepped up arrangements for a hitch-free local council polls, shrugging off critics who see the elections as unncessary and a waste of resources.

The opposition National Democratic Coalition, in a belated reaction to Abacha's 36-month transition program, recently called for an alternative one-year timetable and a government of national unity to be headed by Abiola.

The Abacha administration has dismissed the opposition view as a recipe for chaos.

Faced with an upsurge in violent crimes, Abacha has said his government would deal ruthlessly with "threats to life and properties," by strengthening the security services.

The government has promised tough actions against any attempt to sabotage the transition program. It has also rolled out a new law prescribing up to five years in jail for electoral malpractice.

From various accounts, there seems an apparent enthusiasm among Nigerian politicians toward the council polls.

But some political analysts are cautious, given the recent experience of the Babangida transition that ended in the annulled presidential elections.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


49 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Kaunda Denies Training Mercenary Army


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 494 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Former President Kenneth Kaunda's main opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP) is reportedly training a mercenary army to topple the Lusaka government if he is barred from running for president in forthcoming elections, the official Zambia Daily Main newspaper reported Friday.

The mail, quoting a senior official of President Frederick Chiluba's ruling Movement For Multiparty Democracy (MMD) government, claimed that Kaunda's UNIP had sent a number of former police and army officers to South Africa and Iraq for military training.

South Africa's High Commissioner to Zambia John Sterban Friday declined to comment on the report saying he still had to verify its origins. 

"I am sorry I am unable to say anything until I ascertain where the report came from," Sterban told PANA.

The ruling party provincial chairman for Lusaka Christopher Chawinga, a former Zambia airforce officer himself, told the mail Thursday that an MMD sympathiser within UNIP handed over a list of 15 men sent by UNIP to South Africa for military training.

UNIP Secretary-General Sebastian Zulu was Friday quoted by the mail to have denied knowledge of the plot.

Government officials are known to be suspicious about Kaunda's "cordial" relationship with South African President Nelson Mandela and his ANC-led government of national unity.

Kaunda said Wednesday that he had last week in Lusaka met visiting South African foreign minister Alfred Nzo who had paid a four-day official visit to Zambia at the invitation of the government.

The former president is this weekend scheduled to travel to Cape Town, to attend the inauguration of an anc archives at Fort Hare University.

Mandela will be the guest of honour at the ceremony and officials of the university were this week quoted as saying that they had invited kaunda in appreciation of his personal contribution to the South African Liberation struggle.

Chiluba's government has proposed legislation to bar first-generation Zambians from holding the office of president. This would effectively block kaunda who is of Malawian parentage.

Kaunda has vowed to challenge the proposed law and last week said there could be violence if the government went ahead to exclude him from the polls.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


50 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Two Million Voters Ready For Zambia's Elections


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 467 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Only about two million people, or 46 percent of Zambia's eligible voters have been registered for upcoming elections during a three-month exercise which ends Friday, officials said.

The public liaison officer of the electoral commission, Joel Sikazwe told local reporters in the capital, Lusaka, that only 2,032,324 voters had registered as of 1 March when the exercise was extended for the third time to March 15.

Initial projections were that between 4 million and 4.5 million voters would participate in the presidential and parliamentary elections. The country's population is curently estimated at nine million. 

The registration exercise which began Dec. 12 had been extended two times. It was originally scheduled to end Feb. 9 when it was brought forward to March 1, and later to March 15.

The last registration exercise carried out in 1987 and updated during the 1991 first multiparty elections in 17 years documented 2.9 million voters.

Those now registered will be issued with voter's cards to be prepared by Nikuv Computers, an Israeli firm contracted by government to update the national voters register.

Sikazwe said Nikuv would compile a list of the voters on a computer disk and take them to Israel where the cards will be printed.

The company cannot produce the cards locally because the machines needed for the job were too huge to be shipped to Zambia, he said.

A Zambian high court is currently dealing with a fresh petition filed by the main opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP) of former President Kenneth Kaunda and the Liberal Progressive Front (LPF) of former legal affairs minister Roger Chongwe challenging the Nikuv contract.

They charged that the contract was fraudulent and that the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) government of President Frederick Chiluba plan to rig the election using the Israeli company.

The court last week heard that Nikuv had not registered with the government and that it was not known in Israel.

The opposition claimed that the company was part of the Israeli intelligence service, Mossad.

A similar petition was rejected last year for technical reasons.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

March, 1996


Benin Uncertainty Over Date For Run-Off Election


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

COTONOU, Benin - President Nicephore Soglo of Benin was Thursday reported to have denied saying run-off presidential poll would be held on Monday, the national radio reported Friday.

However, it was the same radio station which covered Soglo's electoral campaign in the Oueme department (southeastern Benin), which said Thursday afternoon that the president endosred March 18 for the poll after the constitutional court rejected the government's postponement of the exercise to March 21. 

The Radio said Soglo made the denial Thursday afternoon in Dangbo (Oueme department).

There is confusion now even among members of the government with certain ministers talking of March 21, while others supported March 18.

Another source close to the president said the government would take stock of technical and material preparation for the run-off with the electoral commission on Friday, before announcing a final date.

In the first round ballot on March 3, Soglo ran neck-to-neck with Mathieu Kerekou, head of the Marxist military regime which ruled the country for 17 years until Soglo replaced Kerekou in the multiparty elections held in 1992.

Two other runners-up have switched support to Kerekou.

Zimbabwe Mugabe Now Unoppsoed


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 146 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe's presidential elections scheduled for Saturday and Sunday were thrown into disarray Friday as the only remaining opposition candidate, retired Bishop Abel Muzorewa of United Parties, withdrew from the race.

Muzorewa's withdrawal was announced minutes after his party's application for the postponement of the elections was thrown out by the supreme court.

The other opposition candidate, Reverend Ndabaningi Sithole of ZANU (Ndonga), pulled out on March 12, citing interference into the operations of his party by Zimbabwe's Central Intelligence Organisation.

53 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Trans-Border Trade Stalled by Border Closure


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 467 words


 

BADAGRY, Nigeria - Trans-border trade between Nigeria and 15 other countries of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) has been paralysed since the Feb. 29 closure of the Nigeria-Benin borders, the official News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) has reported.

The situation has resulted in "colossal losses" to businesses and traders in the sub-region, the agency reported, quoting investigations by its reporters from the border town of Badagry.

The Nigeria-Benin frontier is a major route for the movement of goods and services within the 16-nation community. 

Benin closed its side of the border for four days starting Feb. 29 for its presidential elections.

Nigeria, citing "national interest and security reasons," closed its side of the border on the same day.

The Benin ambassador in Nigeria, Jean-Claude Kpakpo, told PANA Nigeria had notified his government it was closing the borders "temporarily until further notice."

NAN reported that hundreds of travellers from ECOWAS countries were now stranded with their goods at both sides of the border posts following the closure.

It said a large number of Nigerian importers who use the Cotonou seaport in Benin were "groaning under accumulated demurrage and freight charges as their goods could not be brought into Nigeria through the borders."

According to the agency, more than 500 imported second-hand vehicles and about 300 trailers loaded with iron rods, cotton, spare parts, grains and textiles are parked at the Benin end of Seme border, while a large quantity of goods bound for Nigeria are still at the Cotonou port.

Many of the stranded travellers are camped in mission houses at the border towns of Badagry and Owode, NAN said.

It quoted one stranded traveller, Mathew Ogundele, as saying, "This is our third week here, and having spent all our money on feeding and other expenses, we don't know when the border will be reopened."

Ogundele, who said he was travelling to Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire said the Catholic mission in Badagry had provided him and some 200 others free accommodation, while those who could not wait had abandoned the journey.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

March, 1996


Burundi Police Arrest Newspaper Director


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 187 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The publisher of the Bujumbura newspaper L'Eclaireur has been arrested by police, the country's journalists' association said Tuesday.

The charge against the Michel Nziguheba was not immediately known. 

He was arrested in the association's offices where he had gone to complain about the closure of his and six other privately-owned newspapers.

The newspapers were suspended by the national Communication Council. This followed a recent study by the French non-governmental agency, Reporters Without Borders, accusing the newspapers of spreading ethnic hatred and inciting violence in this politically troubled Central African nation.

Nziguheba is the third private print journalist to be arrested. Others are the editors in chief of La Nation, Jean-Marie Bizimana, and Dimas Doweri of La Balance. They have been held for four months.

March, 1996


Sierra Leone President-Elect Kaba Assumes Office March 29


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Abdul Jalloh, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 267 words


 

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone - President-elect Ahmed Kabba, 64, of the Sierra Leone People's Party, will be sworn into office March 29, the country's military ruler said Tuesday.

In a nation-wide radio broadcast, the chairman of the National Provisional Ruling Council and head of state, Brig. Gen. Julius Bio, called on all Sierra Leoneans to support Kaba in establishing democracy. 

Bio said, also, that he would meet Monday in Abidjan, Cote D'Ivoire, with the leader of the rebel Revolutionary United Front, Foday Sankoh.

The front had opposed elections and tried to disrupt them in attacks in the first round. However the rebels, who have been trying to overthrow successive administrations in Freetown, declared an uncondiditional ceasefire after Kaba's election Sunday.

Bio said this was a welcome gesture toward the final end of the conflict.

Meanwhile, the ruling council has issued Decree No.6, "the idemnity and transition decree 1996." This indemnifies members of the junta and their agents from any wrongdoing since they assumed office April 29, 1992.

The measure also revokes the proclamation which established the council and serves other connected purposes and will come into effect on the date Kaba assumes office.

56 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zimbabwe Presidential Election: A Vote To Uphold The Law


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 15, 1996 by Tarcey Munaku and Ndaba Nyoni PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 867 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - It was a vote to give legitimacy to the presidency of Zimbabwe but in the end it was also a vote to uphold the law.

It was a thmubs-up vote from the rural peasantry, constituting about 80 percent of Zimbabwe's population and the main beneficiaries of government largesse.

It was also a protest by urban Zimbabweans who are most affected by government's austere economic reform program launched in 1990.

And when it all ended in Zimbabwe's second presidential elections March 16 and 17, this southern African nation of 10.5 million was back to where it all started 16 years ago: The ruling Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front (ZANU PF) leader, Robert Mugabe, 72, being declared President for yet another six years. 

But he begins the second and probably his last term standing on a much reduced popularity pedestal.

Mugabe, who was assured of victory from the start because of a weak and disorganized opposition, spent more than five weeks addressing rallies throughout Zimbabwe imploring his supporters to turn out in their millions in the elections.

"I am confident that I will win but it is not much of the winning that matters, but that we should turn up in our millions. If there is voter apathy, it will be misinterpreted by the international community," he said at one rally.

However, some 600,000 people who voted Mugabe into power in 1990 changed their minds this year.

There was a total drop of 1.03 million in the number of people who cast their votes in the presidential elections between 1990 and this year.

A total of 1.56 million cast their ballots, representing 31.8 percent of registered voters. Of these, 1.4 million or 28.7 percent of registered voters supported Mugabe. However, he received 92.8 percent of valid votes cast.

In the 1990 presidential elections, some 2.58 million people cast their ballots with 2.03 million or 42.2 percent of registered voters supporting Mugabe.

Were it not for recognizing the provisions of the electoral act, the presidential race would have been aborted following the last moment withdrawal of challengers Reverend Ndabaningi Sithole of ZANU (Ndonga) and retired United Methodist Bishop Abel Muzorewa of the United Parties.

The gospel, according to the two preachers, was that the playing field was uneven and that the constitution governing Zimbabwe was lopsided in favour of the incumbent and his party.

However, being such a stickler for the law, Mugabe told the nation to regard Sithole and Muzorewa's apparent withdrawal as legally null and void. Mugabe called on voters to turn out in their thousands to exercise their right and elect a national leader of their choice.

Several hundreds of thousands heeded Mugabe's call in the rural areas. Since independence in 1980, the countryside has been the target of government-subsidised health services, primary school education and, during recurrent drought periods, free food handouts and agricultural inputs.

But in the main urban centres, choking with rampant unemployment and poverty due to the debilitating effects of the harsh economic reform programme, only a trickle of party faithfuls trudged to polling stations.

Although Muzorewa and Sithole pulled out of the race last week, citing flawed electoral laws and government interference in their operations, their withdrawals were declared invalid as they were made less than 21 days before the first day of polling.

Despite the pull out, Muzorewa got 4.8 percent of the valid votes (72,600) while Sithole had 2.4 percent or 36,960 votes.

This weekend election could signal the last in which the three veteran politicians will participate, judging from their ages.

Mugabe will be 78 years at the expiry of his term of office. Sithole will be 82 years and Muzorewa 77 years six years from now.

But who knows, Zimbabwe might see another presidential contest pitting the three against each other.

If so, there should be no surprise as Zimbabwe would not be the first country with an octogenarian leader.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


57 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zimbabwe Mugabe Wins Presidential Elections


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 334 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - President Robert Mugabe Tuesday was declared winner of Zimbabwe's presidential elections.

He obtained 92.7 percent of the votes in the elections held during the weekend, the Registrar General Tobaiwa Mudede announced in Harare, the capital. 

He said 31.8 percent of registered voters participated in the elections.

Mugabe, 72, who has led the country since independence in 1980, will now be at the helm for another six-year term. His current term of office ends March 31.

He collected 1,404,501 of the 1,514,061 votes cast.

Retired Bishop Abel Muzorewa of the United Parties and Reverend Ndabaningi Sithole of ZANU (Ndonga) pulled out of the race last week, citing flawed electoral laws and government interference in their operations. Their withdrawals, however, were invalidated because they were made less than 21 days before the first day of polling.

Despite his attempt to pull out of the race, Muzorewa clinched 4.8 percent of the votes while Sithole had 2.4 percent.

The low voter turnout was believed to have dealt a heavy blow to Mugabe's determination to show the world that he still enjoys massive support in Zimbabwe.

In the 1990 presidential elections, 2,587,204 people cast their ballots with 2,026,976, or 78.3 percent, voting for Mugabe.

There were 43,497 spoilt papers from the weekend elections. Election directorate chairman Mariyawanda Nzuwah attributed this to mainly illiteracy.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


58 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Benin Kerekou Elected President


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cotonou, Benin - Mathieu Kerekou, once head of a Marxist military regime in the West African state of Benin has been elected president of the republic, according to provisional results obtained by PANA in run-off elections held Monday.

Kerekou received 59 percent of the total votes cast to defeat incumbent President Nicephore Soglo, a former World Bank official who replced him five years ago.

Kerekou, was born Sept. 2, 1933 at Kouarfa in the northwestern Atacora Division of Benin. 

Kerekou attended Saint-Louis secondary school in northern Senegal and Frejus and Saint Raphael military schools in France. He joined the army and was commissioned in August 1961 as a sub-lieutenant. He became lieutenant the following year.

He served as aide-de-camp to the first president of Dahomey (later renamed Benin), Hubert Maga, up to 1963.

Kerekou was promoted commander of the 1st Company of the 1st Infantary Battalion of the Benin army from 1963 to 1966.

He participated in a 1967 coup d'etat which overthrew the regime of Christophe Soglo, uncle of the outgoing president Soglo whom Kerekou defeated in run-off presidential elections Monday.

Solgo ousted Kerekou in Benin's first multiparty elections in 1991.

Between 1967 and 1968, Kerekou was chairman of the ruling Revolutionary Military Committee, during the military regime in which Lt. Col. Alphonse Alley was head of state.

In 1970, Kerekou graduated from the Infantry Staff School in Paris.

From 1970 to 1972, he was appointed head of the infantry and in October 1972 he led the coup d'etat which brought him to power.

His regime embraced Marxism after mercenaries led by Bob Denard invaded Benin in 1977. Circumstances forced him to drop the ideology in 1990, and later a national conference adopted a new constitution which barred army personnel from holding political office.

Gen. Kerekou is often referred to as "the Cameleon" because he was fond of repeating the proverb according to which "the cameleon will never break the twig on which its stands"

After the national conference, Soglo replaced Kerekou as head of a transition government which prepared for the country's first multiparty elections in more than two decades.

Kerekou was considered "politically dead" after Soglo defeated him by a wide margin in the 1991 elections.

But like the cameleon, Kerekou hibernated in his family home in Cotonou only to surface a few months to the March 3 election when he emerged runner-up to Soglo.

He finally won the run-off Monday when two other political partities threw their support behind him.

Provisional results released Tuesday by the election commission in Cotonou said he received 59 percent of the total votes cast.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


59 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Senegal Fishing Campanies Told To Comply With EU Standards


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Aminata Toure PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 440 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The decision of the European Union to subject senegalese fish exports to it new quality standards as from June, has begun to take its toll on the country's fishries industry.

Most of the fishing companies in Senegal may not be able to meet the new standards for exports to European markets, Dougoutigui Coulibaly, Permanent Secretary General of the Shipowners and Fishries Industries in Senegal (GAIPES) told PANA.

These companies, he said, may have to suspended operations pending compliance with European requirements, Coulibaly said. 

European Union countries, especially France, Italy, Germany and Spain, received 90 percent of Senegalese exports of sea foods worth more than 100 billion Francs Cfa (about 200, million dollars) in 1995, Coulibaly said.

"It is preferable that Senegal decides to temorarily shut a few companies not approved by the EU, rather than lose the entire European market," he added.

Some of the companies he added may howver never be able to meet the high standards set by the Union, meaning they would be eliminated from exporting products up north.

Coulibaly acknowledged that the companies were warned in 1989 about the new standards, but added that most of them lacked the financial means to upgrade their operations.

He cited the case of 'AMERGER' company, which invested one billion CFA francs (about 2 million dollars) in upgrading its operations to meet the standards.

The measure has also affected the Senegalese Small-Scale fishing since three-quarters of the fish exported come from small fishermen, coulibaly said. Cape Verde and Mauritania had even suffered more severe penalties over standards of fish exports.

"Senegalese products are known for their quality and have rarely been rejected in European markets", he stated.

The deadline set by the EU, to start implementing sanctions against any country not complying with its standards, is June 1996.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


60 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa 5.2 Billions Dollars Attracted in 1995


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 360 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - South Africa, which has been described as an emerging market, attracted 5.2 billion U.S. dollars (20 billion rand) of overseas investment in 1995. The managing director of Cazenove Co. Stock Brokers in London, James Skinner, attributed this success to international goodwill resulting greater political and economic stability since the election of Nelson Mandela's government of national unity in April 1994. Addressing an investment forum in Lusaka Tuesday, Skinner said South Africa's strengths as an investment site had attracted both short-term portfolio investment and more long-term fixed investment.

He cited these as significant mineral resources, large pool of accessible labour and diversified and well organised agricultural sector. However, he said the continuing risk of investing in South Africa could come from the alienation of the Inkatha Freedom Party from the constitutional process and failure to hold elections in Kwazulu Natal and the Western Cape.

Other risks, he said, were the high rate of crime and violence, lack of commitment to privatisation and administrative failure in a number of regions and problems in central government, particularly with revenue collection.

He noted that of the 10 world exchanges that showed the greatest gains in gross domestic product in 1994 six were in Africa: They were Egypt, Ghana and Tunisia which rose more than 100 percent; and Kenya, Morocco and Nigeria which rose to 75 percent.

However, he said the problem in these countries remained the lack of liquidity, which was bad in 1995.

Cazenove, one of the leading London stockbrokers, acts as London broker for some 25 South African companies. It is also broker for Zambia Consolidated Copper Mining Limited.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Kwacha Continues To Depreciate


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 334 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - The Zambian kwacha continued to deppreciate against major foreign currencies this week, amid fears among currency dealers of further decline during 1996 due to inflation currently running at an annual rate of more than 50 percentt.

A forecast published Tuesday by Standard Chartered Commercial Bank said that there was a danger the local currency could continue to fall and adversely affect government's projected six percent growth in real Gross Domestic Product (GDP). 

The kwacha was Tuesday selling for at 1,158 for one U.S. dollar and at 1,770 for the British pound sterling. The South African rand fetched 295 kwacha at the main Barclays Bank business center.

Analysts said Tuesday the irregular hard currency inflows from donors and the generally high demand for foreign currency by local importers had contributed to the presure on the kwacha.

Zambia has since late 1995 been importing famine relief maize grain to make for the local shortfall caused by drought.

Finance minister Ronald Penza in January when he presented the 1996 budget forecast six percent growth in the national GDP between now and 1998.

Zambia late last year qualified to borrow under the more favourable Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) of the International Monetary Fund.

Penza has said that the longer repayment periods and lower interest rates under the facility would bring more hard currency available in the country and help to stabilise the kwacha.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

March, 1996


Zambia Kwacha In the Doldrums


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Felix Njoku, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 294 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The Zambian kwacha continued its depreciation against major foreign currencies opening Tuesday at the mean rate of 1,140 to one U.S. dollar from 990 previously. The slump has raised fears among local currency dealers of further decline during 1996 due to inflation currently running at an annual rate of more than 50 percent. 

A forecast published Tuesday by Standard Chartered Commercial Bank in Lusaka said that there was a danger the kwacha would continue to fall and adversely affect government's projected 6 percent growth in the real Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

The kwacha exchanged Tuesday at 1,123 (buying) and 1,158 (selling) for one dollar.

Analysts said Tuesday irregular hard currency inflows from donors and the generally high demand for foreign currency by local importers had contributed to the presure on the kwacha. Ten kwacha bought one dollar in 1991. The Ghanaian Cedi also dropped a few points while the CFA franc remained stable for the third week in a row. The CFA (African Finance Community) franc, used in 13 French-speaking African countries, opened Tuesday at the nominal rate of 500.5 to one dollar up from 500.8 to the greenback on the same day last week. In Dakar, Senegal, Tuesday the CFA exchanged at 490 (buying) and 520 (selling) to the dollar from 493 (buying) and 523 (selling) last week Tuesday.

Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Stocks In Moderate Trading


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 507 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Trading was moderate last week at the six floors of the Nigerian Stock Exchange (NSE) where some 6.3 million shares valued at 51.6 million naira changes hands in 1,051 deals (82.5 naira =1 USD).

The figures compared with 11.96 million shares valued at 117.3 million naira in 1,010 deals in the preceding week.

The Lagos floor recorded a decline with 837 deals for 4.2 million shares worth 37.8 million naira compared with 896 deals in the preceding week for 8.3 million shares valued at 91.4 million naira. 

Turnover also fell at the Ibadan floor with 300,000 shares valued at 3.1 million naira changing hands in 66 deals as against 1.6 million shares with a market capitalisation of 5.09 million naira in 67 deals in the preceding week.

In Port Harcourt 34 deals were executed for 60,000 shares worth 900,000 naira, while the turnover in Kaduna stood at 25 deals for 40,000 shares value at 400,000 naira for the week under review.

Investors in Onitsha traded 1.3 million shares worth 6.5 million naira in 60 deals as against no transaction in the preceding week.

The Kano floor recorded 400,000 shares worth 3 million naira in 29 deals compared with the preceeding week's 2 million shares executed in 19 deals.

Overall, the price movement remained positive as the NSE all-shares index appreciated by 48.95 points to close at 5229.49 in the review period.

Meanwhile, activity in the money market was mixed last week with the securities market becoming bullish, while inter-bank market remained sluggish.

The open market operations (OMO), where short term security instruments of government are discounted, maintained the upbeat with 6.280 billion naira worth of treasury bills.

But this fell short of the bids which closed at 9.460 billion naira, up by 3.180 billion naira.

The 35-day instrument matures on April 19, with the Central Bank of Nigeria selling rate closing at 12.4413 percent.

Three weeks after the release of the guidelines on credit, monetary and exchange policies by the apex bank, lending activity had still to pick up.

Analysts blamed the lull in treasury activity on bankers' reservation with the cap on lending and interest rates.

They say a floating rate is preferred.

There was indication that some banks have been defying the official interest rate policy, by lending at an average of 35 percent above the statutory maximum of 21 percent.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


64 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zimbabwe Foreigners Invest Over One Billion


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 427 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Foreign investors, allowed for the first time to participate on the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange in June 1993, have so far purchased and sold shares worth over 2.312 billion zimdollars (257 million USD), brokers said on Tuesday.

In a commentary, the stockbroking firm Edwards (Amper) Company said the net inflow between June 23, 1993, and the week ending March 8, 1996, was 1.153 billion zimdollars (140.2 million USD).

The company, in a review of the performance of the stock market, said there were indications foreign investors were still in the market as net buyers, amid signs the economy could recover on the back of an improved agricultural season and the mining sector's performance. 

It said there were a lot of foreign-to-foreign deals, particularly in the industrial heavyweights such as Bindura Nickel Corporation, Delta Corporation and PG Industries.

Edwards said local investors had retreated to the sidelines to digest recent corporate results, and also await new incentives which might emerge after presidential elections held on March 16 and 17.

Over the next few weeks, it said, the movement of the key industrial index, a safe barometer used to gauge the country's economic performance, would be guided by political developments and exchange rate fluctuations, rather than market sentiment.

However, the index could either soar to new heights or downsurge depending on the outcome of the eagerly awaited company results from Delta, its subsidiary Zimbabwe Sun, and the timber production firm PG Timbers.

Zimbabwe's stock market, once judged the worst performer among 54 emerging indices surveyed by the International Finance Corporation in 1993, has staged a dramatic recovery, ending 1995 as the third best emerging market for the second year running.

Recovery of the stock market, which in 1993 crashed by over 70 percent in value terms, has been boosted by government moves to liberalise investment and exchange controls under market reforms launched over five years ago.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

65 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Ethiopia $ 67.7 Million Earned in Hides and Skins


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Miraw Eshetu, head of the foreign trade section of the bank disclosed Tuesday that the amount earned from 20,750 tonnes of oil seeds and an undisclosed quantity of hides and skins exported from July 1995 to February 1996. This represented an increase of 23 million dollars compared with earnings from the same products during the same period in 1995. 

Revenue from oil seeds alone accounted for an increase of 19 million dollars compared with the same period in 1995.

The price of sesame seeds went up from 700 dollars to 1,100 dollars during the period and Eshetu attributed the boost in revenue to the hike.

Thirteen private firms and one state enterprise handled the oil seeds exports, while hides and skins were exported by six government and three private firms.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Chiluba Orders Sale Of Council Houses


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 400 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - President Frederick Chiluba has ordered drastic reduction on the prices of council houses currently on sale by various local authorities to sitting tenants, in a move generally seen as intended to appease the electorate ahead of this year's general elections.

The houses were being sold under a revived home-ownership scheme initiated by former president Kenneth Kaunda's regime in the 1980s.

Chiluba's Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) government had in 1995 revised the conditions of sale and allowed councils to determine pricing for the various housing units in their respective areas of jurisdiction. 

Chiluba last week intervened in the sales and accused councils of "exploiting" the public by charging high prices.

"Politics now is about shelter and food. Most of those houses are old and dilapidated...moreover the tenants have already paid back what had been spent by councils to put up the houses years ago," he said last Wednesday at a news conference in the capital, Lusaka.

The president is currently touring council housing estates in the northern copperbelt region. Last Saturday, he undertook a similar tour of several council townships in the capital.

Some councils, including Lusaka City Council had pegged some of the bigger medium density housing units at 9,000 U.S. dollars each, and up to 30,000 dollars for those in the low density areas.

Similar houses in the capital, Lusaka, cost between 1, 800 and 4,000 U.S. dollars during the last sales in 1989 when the local currency exchanged at 10 kwacha to one U.S. dollar. Chiluba Monday in northern copperbelt town of Chilabombwe suggested that some of the more dilapidated units could be given out "free" to the tenants.

Analysts have reported a slump in the housing construction sector over the past several years due to high cost of materials and decline in effective demand for urban housing.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


67 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Ghana Expert Predicts Hard Times In 1996


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 920 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana - The Centre for Policy Analysis (CEPA), has called for a holistic approach to the country's management to avoid more negative repercussions in the economy.

CEPA, which is an independent non-governmental body, criticised the government's economic policy management in recent years and said the the policy frameork is flawed for its over-reliance on aggregate demand management to the exclusion of supply enhancement.

Launching the 'Macro-Economic Review and Outlook for 1996' in Accra last week, Dr. Joe Abbey, executive director for CEPA, said the prospect for improved economic performance for 1996 remains dim.

"CEPA's independent assessment of key macro-economic variables such as the rate of inflation, the exchange rate, the interest rate and real GDP growth rate suggest that the government is more likely to incur a budget deficit for the fiscal year," Abbey said. 

The Centre, he said, believes that major components of revenue projected by the government in the 1996 budget are out of trend, unidentiflable, unsustainable or unattainable. Abbey said average inflation in 1996 will be in excess of 70 percent and the end of year inflation in expected to be in excess of 80 percent.

He explained that weak monetary management by the central bank does not help to keep inflation under control.

"This weak monetary control coupled with strong inertia forces will cause inflation in 1996 to be even more problematic, and if care is not taken to prevent this, the country is likely to end up with a high monetary growth rate with its consequent inflationary ramifications," Abbey said. CEPA projects that the trade deficit of the country will increase from 235.8 million dollars in 1995 to 333.9 million dollars in 1996.

It explained that the current account deficit is expected to increase from 1.8 percent of GDP during last year to 2.7 percent in 1996, while the overall balance of payment deficit will rise from 247 million dollars to about 503 million dollars.

"Thus, the trend toward declining trade deficits and current account deficit as propositions of GDP experienced over the last two years will be reversed in 1996."

Abbey said Ghana's external debt is projected to increase by about 8.4 percent to five billion dollars, a rate not higher than real GDP growth of five per cent, "raising issues of sustainability and future debt burdens".

He said 1996 may be worse unless the nation wakes up to the hard realities and signals from the economy and takes decisive and appropriate measures.

The wide fluctuations in the GDP growth rate and the sharp divergences in sectoral growth patterns during the period of 1990 to 1995, he said, are suggestive of systematic weaknesses, which if not reversed may have dire consequences for future.

For instance, he said, the agriculture sector which is vulnerable to weather extremes has seen a decline in its share of GDP during the period with low levels of investment and technological backwardness continue to plague the sector. Economic growth has been further constrained by the level of both domestic and foreign savings.

"As a result of declining incomes, private domestic savings has also been declining, as private households struggle to cope with higher expendittures resulting from higher inflation. "This review and prognosis suggest that we must re-examine our policy framework and directon", Abbey said. He stressed the need to devise and introduce measures to improve the capacity and the ability of the real (agriculture) sector to respond to incentive signals, with enhanced private sector participation. He said fiscal discipline must also be an integral part of any genuine development programme, adding that there is the need to re-examine the level and quality of public expenditure. The exchange rate, he said, must be managed to maintain external competitiveness. The said intervention by the central bank to smooth out fluctuations in exchange rate using foreign loans and divestiture receipts is not a viable strategy. Abbey also stressed the need for political parties to subsume short term political gains in favour of long-term national development objectives. Ghana is regaded as a model of economic structural adjustment and trade liberalisation espoused by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The backbone of its economy is the Ashanti Goalfields Company Limited, which was listed on the New York Stock Exchange last month.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


68 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Manufacturing Industry Declines


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 387 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - The manufacturing sector's share of Zambia's total Gross Domestic Product (GDP) fell marginally from 24.7 percent in 1994 to 24.6 percent in 1995, the country's National Commission for Development Planning has said in its 'Economic Report 1995'.

The report attributed the decline partly to governement's continued trade liberalisation which had increased competition on the local market from cheaper or better imported products. 

Zambia's manufacturing industry in 1995 earned some USD 525,000 from USD 550,000 recorded the previous year.

According to the report, only non-metallic mineral products and fabricated metal products had registered increases in their contribution to real output while the basic metal products sub-sector had also stagnated, for the third year running. Among manufacturing sub-sectors which experienced a decline were food, beverages and tobacco, textiles and leather industries, wood and wood products, paper and paper products. Others included chemicals, rubber and plastic products.

The Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) government of president Frederick Chiluba in 1994 enacted "the competition and fair trading act" to regulate trade competition locally. The law is intended to introduce a code of conduct for all business entities and ensure fair competition on the market. Chiluba's government has been blamed, by the opposition and commercial and industrial sectors, for stiffling local industry since the adoption in 1992 of a free market economy. Zambia has been swamped by cheap goods, including textiles and foodstuffs, from especially neighbouring South Africa. South African foreign minister Alfred Nzo said during a recent visit that Pretoria was currently trying to balance its trade with Zambia and other neighbouring states. The trade is currently in South Africa's favour.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Trans-Border Trade Stalled By Border Closure


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 467 words


 

BADAGRY, Nigeria - Trans-border trade between Nigeria and 15 other countries of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) has been paralysed since the February 29 closure of the Nigeria-Benin borders, the official News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) has reported.

The situation has resulted in "colossal losses" to businessmen and traders in the sub-region, the agency reported, quoting investigations by its reporters from the border town of Badagry.

The Nigeria-Benin frontier is a major route for the movement of goods and services within the 16-nation community. 

Benin shut its own side of the frontier for four days from February 29 for its presidential elections.

Nigeria, citing "national interest and security reasons," closed its own side of the borders on the same day.

The Benin ambassador in Nigeria Jean-Claude Kpakpo told PANA Nigeria had notified his government it was closing the borders "temporarily until further notice."

NAN reported that hundreds of travellers from ECOWAS countries were now stranded with their goods at both sides of the border posts following the closure.

It said a large number of Nigerian importers who use the Cotonou Seaport in Benin were "groaning under accumulated demurrage and freight charges as their goods could not be brought into Nigeria through the borders."

According to the agency, more than 500 imported second-hand vehicles and about 300 trailers loaded with iron rods, cotton, spare parts, grains and textiles are parked at the Benin end of Seme border, while a large quantity of goods bound for Nigeria are still at the Cotonou port.

Many of the stranded travellers are camped in mission houses at the border towns of Badagry and Owode, NAN said.

It quoted one stranded traveller Mathew Ogundele as saying "this is our third week here and having spent all our money on feeding and other expenses, we don't know when the border will be reopened."

Ogundele, who said he was travelling to Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire said the Catholic mission in Badagry had provided him and some 200 others free accommodation, while those who could not wait had abandoned the journey.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large G-15 Countries Set Up Committee To Promote Trade


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 614 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - A committee formed last year to promote trade and investment in developing countries began a two-day meeting in Harare on Tuesday, to map out strategies to revive third world economies.

The inaugural meeting of the Committee on Investment Trade and Technology (CITT), which was launched in November last year at the G-15 summit of developing countries in Buenos Aires, is expected to come up with recommendations to guide the future of economic co-operation among them.

In a statement at the opening ceremony, Zimbabwe's industry and commerce minister, Herbert Murerwa, said the objective of CITT was to broaden and intensify the scope of intra-G-15 economic co-operation, particularly in the areas of the liberalisation, facilitation and promotion of trade, investment and technology. 

He said the two-day deliberations and their outcome would be crucial in setting the tone, direction and impact of the initiative on the future development of economic co-operation.

The main function of the committee, he said, was to serve as "a flexible, consultative, overeaching and trans-regional mechanism to facilitate continuos dialogue" among member countries in the three main areas of trade, investment and technology.

To perform this function, the CITT would draw extensively from the the work and contributions of existing G-15 projects and structures, Murerwa said.

Murerwa said establishing priorities for the CITT work programme would not be an easy task as there would be need to avoid duplication on the one hand and establish a limited, focused and business-responsive list of priorities on the other.

Commenting on the current global economic situation, Murerwa said it was characterised by growing interdependence and greater integration among countries of varying levels of development.

He noted that effects of globalisation and liberalisation of such areas as production, trade, investment, money and finance, services and technology were increasingly impacting on the member countries' economies.

The impact he said, could be both positive and negative, presenting new opportunities for growth and development as well as challenges for the member countries.

In concluding his speech, he said that while everyone was aware of the objectives of the G-15, it was necessary to define the practical mechanisms and means for achieving the end.

In this regard, he said, the establishment of the G-15 projects, particularly the South Investment, Trade and Technological Data Exchange Centre (SITTDEC) and the Business and Investment Forum (BIF) represented the member countries' resolve to promote "feasible and meaningful co-operation among the countries."

The G-15 is a loose coalition of developing countries comprising Argentina, Algeria, Brazil, Chile, Egypt, Mexico, Jamaica, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Senegal, Venezuela, Peru, Nigeria and Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


71 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Sudan Date Palms Boost Food Self-sufficiency Drive


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Yahia El Hassan, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 840 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Date palms, introduced in Sudan from Saudi Arabia centuries ago, have fully adapted to the climate and the palms now contribute significantly to the country's food self-sufficiency drive.

The crop, which usually competes with the minarets of mosques in desert oasis in the race towrad the sky, has been adapted to the humid tropical climate of Equatoria, where temperatures average 40 degrees centrigrade in certian periods and annual rainfalls reach 1,000 cubic millimeters.

The date palm fruit is rich in glucose sugar, a fact which explains why muslims use it as starter for Ramdan meals after the day-long fast. Doctors also recommend it for patients with hemoglobin and other blood blood related deficiencies. 

Experts say a handfull of dates can sustain a human being for six hours.

Dates are also useful as "food nuts" during long travels and periods of famine. If properly sun-dried, hard dates can be preserved for more than twelve months. They can be preserved soft and fresh for more than a year if packaged in polythene bags or tin containers.

The number of date palm trees in Sudan is currently estimated at one million, concentrated in the extreme northern part of the country along the River Nile. They produce 100,000 tonnes of dates each year, most of which are consumed locally.

The high adaptability of date palms have encouraged farmers to grow them in Darfur State in the extreme West and in the coastal areas of the Red Sea, known to suffer long periods of drought.

Abdalla Ali, a Khartoum-based farmer says the trees he planted have fully adapted to the weather.

"In the past I used to harvest my dates during the rainy season but little by little this has changed and I can now harvest them before the rains," he said.

However, an Iraqi expert has warned that offshoots should not be left to grow with the mother tree as they will reduce its consumption of food and nitrates and reduce its productivity.

Dr. Salih Muhsin Badr of the Arab Organisation for Agricultural Development working on a project for improving and multiplying date palms in Sudan told PANA "offshoots should be weeded as early as possible because if left to grow they will share the food it obtains from the soil and it will grow weak and fruitless."

He said Sudanese and other African producers should recognize the viabilty of fertilization of date palms to achieve higher yields.

Branches should be reduced to the minimum and dry branches should be cut immediately while date clusters should be reduced to let the fruit grow big, headded.

Salih also advised farmers to grow lemon and orange trees below the date palms to protect the soil and sustain humidity.

Dates can produce good quality jams. The facutly of agriculture of the University of Khartoum, has been able to produce honey, cakes and jam from the crop.

However, date palm farming is not without its problems. One of them has to do with how to pollinate and harvest them due to their trmendous heights. Khairy Ahmed Ali, a director of horticulture, recommends mechanisation using light pollination machines, since experienced climbers were becoming scarce.

Date seeds can also produce rich animal fodder. Seeds can be crushed to small pieces and mixed with sorghum and salt to produce rich animal fodder.

Doctors also recommend the nuts for patients with chronic constipation. When softened in a pot containing water all night and taken early in the morning, dates can guarantee easy stooling for these patients, they say.

The Arab Organisation for Agricultural Development quoting 1993 figures put total annual output of dates at 2,918,000 tonnes. Iraq is the world's biggest producer with an output of 631,300 tonnes in 1993, followed by Egypt with 613,000 tonnes, Saudi Arabia with 560,000 tonnes and Algeria with 262,000 tonnes. Other major producers include the Sultanate of Oman (126,000), Morocco (111,100), the organisation said. In the United States, the state of Indiana is now known to produce good quality dates.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

March, 1996


Burundi Police Arrest Newspaper Director


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 187 words


 

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The publisher of the Bujumbura newspaper L'Eclaireur has been arrested by police, the country's journalists' association said Tuesday.

The charge against the Michel Nziguheba was not immediately known. 

He was arrested in the association's offices where he had gone to complain about the closure of his and six other privately-owned newspapers.

The newspapers were suspended by the national Communication Council. This followed a recent study by the French non-governmental agency, Reporters Without Borders, accusing the newspapers of spreading ethnic hatred and inciting violence in this politically troubled Central African nation.

Nziguheba is the third private print journalist to be arrested. Others are the editors in chief of La Nation, Jean-Marie Bizimana, and Dimas Doweri of La Balance. They have been held for four months.

March, 1996


Sierra Leone President-Elect Kaba Assumes Office March 29


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Abdul Jalloh PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 267 words


 

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone - President-elect Ahmed Kabba, 64, of the Sierra Leone People's Party, will be sworn into office March 29, the country's military ruler said Tuesday.

In a nation-wide radio broadcast, the chairman of the National Provisional Ruling Council and head of state, Brig. Gen. Julius Bio, called on all Sierra Leoneans to support Kaba in establishing democracy. 

Bio said, also, that he would meet Monday in Abidjan, Cote D'Ivoire, with the leader of the rebel Revolutionary United Front, Foday Sankoh.

The front had opposed elections and tried to disrupt them in attacks in the first round. However the rebels, who have been trying to overthrow successive administrations in Freetown, declared an uncondiditional ceasefire after Kaba's election Sunday.

Bio said this was a welcome gesture toward the final end of the conflict.

Meanwhile, the ruling council has issued Decree No.6, "the idemnity and transition decree 1996." This indemnifies members of the junta and their agents from any wrongdoing since they assumed office April 29, 1992.

The measure also revokes the proclamation which established the council and serves other connected purposes and will come into effect on the date Kaba assumes office.
