74 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zimbabwe Presidential Election: A Vote To Uphold The Law


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Tarcey Munaku and Ndaba Nyoni PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 867 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - It was a vote to give legitimacy to the presidency of Zimbabwe but in the end it was also a vote to uphold the law.

It was a thmubs-up vote from the rural peasantry, constituting about 80 percent of Zimbabwe's population and the main beneficiaries of government largesse.

It was also a protest by urban Zimbabweans who are most affected by government's austere economic reform program launched in 1990.

And when it all ended in Zimbabwe's second presidential elections March 16 and 17, this southern African nation of 10.5 million was back to where it all started 16 years ago: The ruling Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front (ZANU PF) leader, Robert Mugabe, 72, being declared President for yet another six years. 

But he begins the second and probably his last term standing on a much reduced popularity pedestal.

Mugabe, who was assured of victory from the start because of a weak and disorganized opposition, spent more than five weeks addressing rallies throughout Zimbabwe imploring his supporters to turn out in their millions in the elections.

"I am confident that I will win but it is not much of the winning that matters, but that we should turn up in our millions. If there is voter apathy, it will be misinterpreted by the international community," he said at one rally.

However, some 600,000 people who voted Mugabe into power in 1990 changed their minds this year.

There was a total drop of 1.03 million in the number of people who cast their votes in the presidential elections between 1990 and this year.

A total of 1.56 million cast their ballots, representing 31.8 percent of registered voters. Of these, 1.4 million or 28.7 percent of registered voters supported Mugabe. However, he received 92.8 percent of valid votes cast.

In the 1990 presidential elections, some 2.58 million people cast their ballots with 2.03 million or 42.2 percent of registered voters supporting Mugabe.

Were it not for recognizing the provisions of the electoral act, the presidential race would have been aborted following the last moment withdrawal of challengers Reverend Ndabaningi Sithole of ZANU (Ndonga) and retired United Methodist Bishop Abel Muzorewa of the United Parties.

The gospel, according to the two preachers, was that the playing field was uneven and that the constitution governing Zimbabwe was lopsided in favour of the incumbent and his party.

However, being such a stickler for the law, Mugabe told the nation to regard Sithole and Muzorewa's apparent withdrawal as legally null and void. Mugabe called on voters to turn out in their thousands to exercise their right and elect a national leader of their choice.

Several hundreds of thousands heeded Mugabe's call in the rural areas. Since independence in 1980, the countryside has been the target of government-subsidised health services, primary school education and, during recurrent drought periods, free food handouts and agricultural inputs.

But in the main urban centres, choking with rampant unemployment and poverty due to the debilitating effects of the harsh economic reform programme, only a trickle of party faithfuls trudged to polling stations.

Although Muzorewa and Sithole pulled out of the race last week, citing flawed electoral laws and government interference in their operations, their withdrawals were declared invalid as they were made less than 21 days before the first day of polling.

Despite the pull out, Muzorewa got 4.8 percent of the valid votes (72,600) while Sithole had 2.4 percent or 36,960 votes.

This weekend election could signal the last in which the three veteran politicians will participate, judging from their ages.

Mugabe will be 78 years at the expiry of his term of office. Sithole will be 82 years and Muzorewa 77 years six years from now.

But who knows, Zimbabwe might see another presidential contest pitting the three against each other.

If so, there should be no surprise as Zimbabwe would not be the first country with an octogenarian leader.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


75 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zimbabwe Mugabe Wins Presidential Elections


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 334 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - President Robert Mugabe Tuesday was declared winner of Zimbabwe's presidential elections.

He obtained 92.7 percent of the votes in the elections held during the weekend, the Registrar General Tobaiwa Mudede announced in Harare, the capital. 

He said 31.8 percent of registered voters participated in the elections.

Mugabe, 72, who has led the country since independence in 1980, will now be at the helm for another six-year term. His current term of office ends March 31.

He collected 1,404,501 of the 1,514,061 votes cast.

Retired Bishop Abel Muzorewa of the United Parties and Reverend Ndabaningi Sithole of ZANU (Ndonga) pulled out of the race last week, citing flawed electoral laws and government interference in their operations. Their withdrawals, however, were invalidated because they were made less than 21 days before the first day of polling.

Despite his attempt to pull out of the race, Muzorewa clinched 4.8 percent of the votes while Sithole had 2.4 percent.

The low voter turnout was believed to have dealt a heavy blow to Mugabe's determination to show the world that he still enjoys massive support in Zimbabwe.

In the 1990 presidential elections, 2,587,204 people cast their ballots with 2,026,976, or 78.3 percent, voting for Mugabe.

There were 43,497 spoilt papers from the weekend elections. Election directorate chairman Mariyawanda Nzuwah attributed this to mainly illiteracy.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


76 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Benin Kerekou Elected President


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Cotonou, Benin - Mathieu Kerekou, once head of a Marxist military regime in the West African state of Benin has been elected president of the republic, according to provisional results obtained by PANA in run-off elections held Monday.

Kerekou received 59 percent of the total votes cast to defeat incumbent President Nicephore Soglo, a former World Bank official who replced him five years ago.

Kerekou, was born Sept. 2, 1933 at Kouarfa in the northwestern Atacora Division of Benin. 

Kerekou attended Saint-Louis secondary school in northern Senegal and Frejus and Saint Raphael military schools in France. He joined the army and was commissioned in August 1961 as a sub-lieutenant. He became lieutenant the following year.

He served as aide-de-camp to the first president of Dahomey (later renamed Benin), Hubert Maga, up to 1963.

Kerekou was promoted commander of the 1st Company of the 1st Infantary Battalion of the Benin army from 1963 to 1966.

He participated in a 1967 coup d'etat which overthrew the regime of Christophe Soglo, uncle of the outgoing president Soglo whom Kerekou defeated in run-off presidential elections Monday.

Solgo ousted Kerekou in Benin's first multiparty elections in 1991.

Between 1967 and 1968, Kerekou was chairman of the ruling Revolutionary Military Committee, during the military regime in which Lt. Col. Alphonse Alley was head of state.

In 1970, Kerekou graduated from the Infantry Staff School in Paris.

From 1970 to 1972, he was appointed head of the infantry and in October 1972 he led the coup d'etat which brought him to power.

His regime embraced Marxism after mercenaries led by Bob Denard invaded Benin in 1977. Circumstances forced him to drop the ideology in 1990, and later a national conference adopted a new constitution which barred army personnel from holding political office.

Gen. Kerekou is often referred to as "the Cameleon" because he was fond of repeating the proverb according to which "the cameleon will never break the twig on which its stands"

After the national conference, Soglo replaced Kerekou as head of a transition government which prepared for the country's first multiparty elections in more than two decades.

Kerekou was considered "politically dead" after Soglo defeated him by a wide margin in the 1991 elections.

But like the cameleon, Kerekou hibernated in his family home in Cotonou only to surface a few months to the March 3 election when he emerged runner-up to Soglo.

He finally won the run-off Monday when two other political partities threw their support behind him.

Provisional results released Tuesday by the election commission in Cotonou said he received 59 percent of the total votes cast.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


77 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Senegal Fishing Campanies Told To Comply With EU Standards


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Aminata Toure PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 454 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The decision of the European Union to subject senegalese fish exports to it new quality standards as from June, has begun to take its toll on the country's fishries industry.

Most of the fishing companies in Senegal may not be able to meet the new standards for exports to European markets, Dougoutigui Coulibaly, Permanent Secretary General of the Shipowners and Fishries Industries in Senegal (GAIPES) told PANA.

These companies, he said, may have to suspended operations pending compliance with European requirements, Coulibaly said. 

European Union countries, especially France, Italy, Germany and Spain, received 90 percent of Senegalese exports of sea foods worth more than 100 billion Francs Cfa (about 200, million dollars) in 1995, Coulibaly said.

"It is preferable that Senegal decides to temorarily shut a few companies not approved by the EU, rather than lose the entire European market," he added.

Some of the companies he added may howver never be able to meet the high standards set by the Union, meaning they would be eliminated from exporting products up north.

Coulibaly acknowledged that the companies were warned in 1989 about the new standards, but added that most of them lacked the financial means to upgrade their operations.

He cited the case of 'AMERGER' company, which invested one billion CFA francs (about 2 million dollars) in upgrading its operations to meet the standards.

The measure has also affected the Senegalese Small-Scale fishing since three-quarters of the fish exported come from small fishermen, coulibaly said.

Cape Verde and Mauritania had even suffered more severe penalties over standards of fish exports.

"Senegalese products are known for their quality and have rarely been rejected in European markets", he stated.

The deadline set by the EU, to start implementing sanctions against any country not complying with its standards, is June 1996.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


78 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria and South Africa Nigerian Envoy Allays Fears Of S. African Bizmen


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Adamu Lawal Toro PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 480 words


 

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Nigeria has assured South African business people they have nothingg to fear about travelling to Nigeria to do business.

Nigerian Consul-General in Johannesburg, Adamu Abbas, told members of the Cape Town Chamber of Commerce at a meeting on Monday the fears and anxieties they harboured about doing business in Nigeria were being fully addressed by the Abuja government.

Nigeria and South Africa resumed diplomatic ties after the 1994 all-race elections that ended apartheid and brought President Nelson Mandela to power. 

This raised hope of improved bilateral relations.

But the relations have been strained in the recent past over Nigeria's troubled democratisation process and human rights record.

Abbas urged the South African business people to contact his office whenever they had doubts about business proposals from Nigeria.

He said the Nigerian government had taken "drastic measures about the activitis of a few individuals who try to tarnish the image of the country."

The envoy said he was in Cape Town to listen the complaints of the businessmen and to "seek ways of helping to deal with matters of trade for the mutual benefit of our two countries."

Many South African bisinesmen have reportedly expressed fears about travelling to Nigeria although they are attracted by the country's business potentials.

The businessmen claimed the stories they read about Nigeria were negative.

But with the assurances from visiting Nigerian businessmen and Nigerian diplomats in Southern Africa, some of the South African businessmen say they are "now prepared to look at the prospects once again."

South African High Commissioner in Lagos, George Nene returned to his post last month.

He was one of the foreign envoys recalled for four months over the execution in November 1995 of four minority leaders, among them the author Ken Saro-Wiwa.

The execution of the men for the 1994 murder of four of their kinsmen in ogoniland, southeastern Nigeria, brought international conddemnation and sanctions on the West African country.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


79 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa 5.2 Billions Dollars Attracted In 1995


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 400 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - South Africa, which has been described as an emerging market, attracted 5.2 billion U.S. dollars (20 billion rand) of overseas investment in 1995.

The managing director of Cazenove Co. Stock Brokers in London, James Skinner, attributed this success to international goodwill resulting greater political and economic stability since the election of Nelson Mandela's government of national unity in April 1994.

Addressing an investment forum in Lusaka Tuesday, Skinner said South Africa's strengths as an investment site had attracted both short-term portfolio investment and more long-term fixed investment.

He cited these as significant mineral resources, large pool of accessible labour and diversified and well organised agricultural sector.

However, he said the continuing risk of investing in South Africa could come from the alienation of the Inkatha Freedom Party from the constitutional process and failure to hold elections in Kwazulu Natal and the Western Cape.

Other risks, he said, were the high rate of crime and violence, lack of commitment to privatisation and administrative failure in a number of regions and problems in central government, particularly with revenue collection.

He noted that of the 10 world exchanges that showed the greatest gains in gross domestic product in 1994 six were in Africa: They were Egypt, Ghana and Tunisia which rose more than 100 percent; and Kenya, Morocco and Nigeria which rose to 75 percent.

However, he said the problem in these countries remained the lack of liquidity, which was bad in 1995.

Cazenove, one of the leading London stockbrokers, acts as London broker for some 25 South African companies. It is also broker for Zambia Consolidated Copper Mining Limited.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


80 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia- Kwacha Continues To Depreciate


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 334 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - The Zambian kwacha continued to deppreciate against major foreign currencies this week, amid fears among currency dealers of further decline during 1996 due to inflation currently running at an annual rate of more than 50 percentt.

A forecast published Tuesday by Standard Chartered Commercial Bank said that there was a danger the local currency could continue to fall and adversely affect government's projected six percent growth in real Gross Domestic Product (GDP). 

The kwacha was Tuesday selling for at 1,158 for one U.S. dollar and at 1,770 for the British pound sterling. The South African rand fetched 295 kwacha at the main Barclays Bank business center.

Analysts said Tuesday the irregular hard currency inflows from donors and the generally high demand for foreign currency by local importers had contributed to the presure on the kwacha.

Zambia has since late 1995 been importing famine relief maize grain to make for the local shortfall caused by drought.

Finance minister Ronald Penza in January when he presented the 1996 budget forecast six percent growth in the national GDP between now and 1998.

Zambia late last year qualified to borrow under the more favourable Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) of the International Monetary Fund.

Penza has said that the longer repayment periods and lower interest rates under the facility would bring more hard currency available in the country and help to stabilise the kwacha.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Kwacha In the Doldrums


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Felix Njoku PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 334 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The Zambian kwacha continued its depreciation against major foreign currencies opening Tuesday at the mean rate of 1,140 to one U.S. dollar from 990 previously.

The slump has raised fears among local currency dealers of further decline during 1996 due to inflation currently running at an annual rate of more than 50 percent. 

A forecast published Tuesday by Standard Chartered Commercial Bank in Lusaka said that there was a danger the kwacha would continue to fall and adversely affect government's projected 6 percent growth in the real Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

The kwacha exchanged Tuesday at 1,123 (buying) and 1,158 (selling) for one dollar.

Analysts said Tuesday irregular hard currency inflows from donors and the generally high demand for foreign currency by local importers had contributed to the presure on the kwacha.

Ten kwacha bought one dollar in 1991.

The Ghanaian Cedi also dropped a few points while the CFA franc remained stable for the third week in a row.

The CFA (African Finance Community) franc, used in 13 French-speaking African countries, opened Tuesday at the nominal rate of 500.5 to one dollar up from 500.8 to the greenback on the same day last week.

In Dakar, Senegal, Tuesday the CFA exchanged at 490 (buying) and 520 (selling) to the dollar from 493 (buying) and 523 (selling) last week Tuesday.

Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Stocks In Moderate Trading


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 560 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Trading was moderate last week at the six floors of the Nigerian Stock Exchange (NSE) where some 6.3 million shares valued at 51.6 million naira changes hands in 1,051 deals (82.5 naira =1 USD).

The figures compared with 11.96 million shares valued at 117.3 million naira in 1,010 deals in the preceding week.

The Lagos floor recorded a decline with 837 deals for 4.2 million shares worth 37.8 million naira compared with 896 deals in the preceding week for 8.3 million shares valued at 91.4 million naira. 

Turnover also fell at the Ibadan floor with 300,000 shares valued at 3.1 million naira changing hands in 66 deals as against 1.6 million shares with a market capitalisation of 5.09 million naira in 67 deals in the preceding week.

In Port Harcourt 34 deals were executed for 60,000 shares worth 900,000 naira, while the turnover in Kaduna stood at 25 deals for 40,000 shares value at 400,000 naira for the week under review.

Investors in Onitsha traded 1.3 million shares worth 6.5 million naira in 60 deals as against no transaction in the preceding week.

The Kano floor recorded 400,000 shares worth 3 million naira in 29 deals compared with the preceeding week's 2 million shares executed in 19 deals.

Overall, the price movement remained positive as the NSE all-shares index appreciated by 48.95 points to close at 5229.49 in the review period.

Meanwhile, activity in the money market was mixed last week with the securities market becoming bullish, while inter-bank market remained sluggish.

The open market operations (OMO), where short term security instruments of government are discounted, maintained the upbeat with 6.280 billion naira worth of treasury bills.

But this fell short of the bids which closed at 9.460 billion naira, up by 3.180 billion naira.

The 35-day instrument matures on April 19, with the Central Bank of Nigeria selling rate closing at 12.4413 percent.

Three weeks after the release of the guidelines on credit, monetary and exchange policies by the apex bank, lending activity had still to pick up.

Analysts blamed the lull in treasury activity on bankers' reservation with the cap on lending and interest rates.

They say a floating rate is preferred.

There was indication that some banks have been defying the official interest rate policy, by lending at an average of 35 percent above the statutory maximum of 21 percent.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zimbabwe Foreigners Invest Over One Billion


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Foreign investors, allowed for the first time to participate on the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange in June 1993, have so far purchased and sold shares worth over 2.312 billion zimdollars (257 million USD), brokers said on Tuesday.

In a commentary, the stockbroking firm Edwards (Amper) Company said the net inflow between June 23, 1993, and the week ending March 8, 1996, was 1.153 billion zimdollars (140.2 million USD).

The company, in a review of the performance of the stock market, said there were indications foreign investors were still in the market as net buyers, amid signs the economy could recover on the back of an improved agricultural season and the mining sector's performance. 

It said there were a lot of foreign-to-foreign deals, particularly in the industrial heavyweights such as Bindura Nickel Corporation, Delta Corporation and PG Industries.

Edwards said local investors had retreated to the sidelines to digest recent corporate results, and also await new incentives which might emerge after presidential elections held on March 16 and 17.

Over the next few weeks, it said, the movement of the key industrial index, a safe barometer used to gauge the country's economic performance, would be guided by political developments and exchange rate fluctuations, rather than market sentiment.

However, the index could either soar to new heights or downsurge depending on the outcome of the eagerly awaited company results from Delta, its subsidiary Zimbabwe Sun, and the timber production firm PG Timbers.

Zimbabwe's stock market, once judged the worst performer among 54 emerging indices surveyed by the International Finance Corporation in 1993, has staged a dramatic recovery, ending 1995 as the third best emerging market for the second year running.

Recovery of the stock market, which in 1993 crashed by over 70 percent in value terms, has been boosted by government moves to liberalise investment and exchange controls under market reforms launched over five years ago.

Africa News


March, 1996


Ethiopia $67.7 Million Earned on Hides and Skins


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Ghion Hagos PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 227 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Ethiopia has earned over 67.76 million U.S. dollars from exports of hides and skins and oil seeds during the past eight months, an official of the National Bank of Ethiopia said.

Miraw Eshetu, head of the foreign trade section of the bank disclosed Tuesday that the amount earned from 20,750 tonnes of oil seeds and an undisclosed quantity of hides and skins exported from July 1995 to February 1996. 

This represented an increase of 23 million dollars compared with earnings from the same products during the same period in 1995.

Revenue from oil seeds alone accounted for an increase of 19 million dollars compared with the same period in 1995.

The price of sesame seeds went up from 700 dollars to 1,100 dollars during the period and Eshetu attributed the boost in revenue to the hike.

Thirteen private firms and one state enterprise handled the oil seeds exports, while hides and skins were exported by six government and three private firms.

85 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Chiluba Orders Sale Of Council Houses


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 427 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - President Frederick Chiluba has ordered drastic reduction on the prices of council houses currently on sale by various local authorities to sitting tenants, in a move generally seen as intended to appease the electorate ahead of this year's general elections.

The houses were being sold under a revived home-ownership scheme initiated by former president Kenneth Kaunda's regime in the 1980s.

Chiluba's Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) government had in 1995 revised the conditions of sale and allowed councils to determine pricing for the various housing units in their respective areas of jurisdiction. 

Chiluba last week intervened in the sales and accused councils of "exploiting" the public by charging high prices.

"Politics now is about shelter and food. Most of those houses are old and dilapidated...moreover the tenants have already paid back what had been spent by councils to put up the houses years ago," he said last Wednesday at a news conference in the capital, Lusaka.

The president is currently touring council housing estates in the northern copperbelt region. Last Saturday, he undertook a similar tour of several council townships in the capital.

Some councils, including Lusaka City Council had pegged some of the bigger medium density housing units at 9,000 U.S. dollars each, and up to 30,000 dollars for those in the low density areas.

Similar houses in the capital, Lusaka, cost between 1, 800 and 4,000 U.S. dollars during the last sales in 1989 when the local currency exchanged at 10 kwacha to one U.S. dollar.

Chiluba Monday in northern copperbelt town of Chilabombwe suggested that some of the more dilapidated units could be given out "free" to the tenants.

Analysts have reported a slump in the housing construction sector over the past several years due to high cost of materials and decline in effective demand for urban housing.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


86 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Ghana Expert Predicts Hard Times In 1996


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 974 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana - The Centre for Policy Analysis (CEPA), has called for a holistic approach to the country's management to avoid more negative repercussions in the economy.

CEPA, which is an independent non-governmental body, criticised the government's economic policy management in recent years and said the the policy frameork is flawed for its over-reliance on aggregate demand management to the exclusion of supply enhancement.

Launching the 'Macro-Economic Review and Outlook for 1996' in Accra last week, Dr. Joe Abbey, executive director for CEPA, said the prospect for improved economic performance for 1996 remains dim.

"CEPA's independent assessment of key macro-economic variables such as the rate of inflation, the exchange rate, the interest rate and real GDP growth rate suggest that the government is more likely to incur a budget deficit for the fiscal year," Abbey said. 

The Centre, he said, believes that major components of revenue projected by the government in the 1996 budget are out of trend, unidentiflable, unsustainable or unattainable.

Abbey said average inflation in 1996 will be in excess of 70 percent and the end of year inflation in expected to be in excess of 80 percent.

He explained that weak monetary management by the central bank does not help to keep inflation under control.

"This weak monetary control coupled with strong inertia forces will cause inflation in 1996 to be even more problematic, and if care is not taken to prevent this, the country is likely to end up with a high monetary growth rate with its consequent inflationary ramifications," Abbey said.

CEPA projects that the trade deficit of the country will increase from 235.8 million dollars in 1995 to 333.9 million dollars in 1996.

It explained that the current account deficit is expected to increase from 1.8 percent of GDP during last year to 2.7 percent in 1996, while the overall balance of payment deficit will rise from 247 million dollars to about 503 million dollars.

"Thus, the trend toward declining trade deficits and current account deficit as propositions of GDP experienced over the last two years will be reversed in 1996."

Abbey said Ghana's external debt is projected to increase by about 8.4 percent to five billion dollars, a rate not higher than real GDP growth of five per cent, "raising issues of sustainability and future debt burdens".

He said 1996 may be worse unless the nation wakes up to the hard realities and signals from the economy and takes decisive and appropriate measures.

The wide fluctuations in the GDP growth rate and the sharp divergences in sectoral growth patterns during the period of 1990 to 1995, he said, are suggestive of systematic weaknesses, which if not reversed may have dire consequences for future.

For instance, he said, the agriculture sector which is vulnerable to weather extremes has seen a decline in its share of GDP during the period with low levels of investment and technological backwardness continue to plague the sector.

Economic growth has been further constrained by the level of both domestic and foreign savings.

"As a result of declining incomes, private domestic savings has also been declining, as private households struggle to cope with higher expendittures resulting from higher inflation.

"This review and prognosis suggest that we must re-examine our policy framework and directon", Abbey said.

He stressed the need to devise and introduce measures to improve the capacity and the ability of the real (agriculture) sector to respond to incentive signals, with enhanced private sector participation.

He said fiscal discipline must also be an integral part of any genuine development programme, adding that there is the need to re-examine the level and quality of public expenditure.

The exchange rate, he said, must be managed to maintain external competitiveness. The said intervention by the central bank to smooth out fluctuations in exchange rate using foreign loans and divestiture receipts is not a viable strategy.

Abbey also stressed the need for political parties to subsume short term political gains in favour of long-term national development objectives.

Ghana is regaded as a model of economic structural adjustment and trade liberalisation espoused by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

The backbone of its economy is the Ashanti Goalfields Company Limited, which was listed on the New York Stock Exchange last month.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


87 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Manufacturing Industry Declines by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 414 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - The manufacturing sector's share of Zambia's total Gross Domestic Product (GDP) fell marginally from 24.7 percent in 1994 to 24.6 percent in 1995, the country's National Commission for Development Planning has said in its 'Economic Report 1995'.

The report attributed the decline partly to governement's continued trade liberalisation which had increased competition on the local market from cheaper or better imported products. 

Zambia's manufacturing industry in 1995 earned some USD 525,000 from USD 550,000 recorded the previous year.

According to the report, only non-metallic mineral products and fabricated metal products had registered increases in their contribution to real output while the basic metal products sub-sector had also stagnated, for the third year running.

Among manufacturing sub-sectors which experienced a decline were food, beverages and tobacco, textiles and leather industries, wood and wood products, paper and paper products. Others included chemicals, rubber and plastic products.

The Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) government of president Frederick Chiluba in 1994 enacted "the competition and fair trading act" to regulate trade competition locally.

The law is intended to introduce a code of conduct for all business entities and ensure fair competition on the market.

Chiluba's government has been blamed, by the opposition and commercial and industrial sectors, for stiffling local industry since the adoption in 1992 of a free market economy.

Zambia has been swamped by cheap goods, including textiles and foodstuffs, from especially neighbouring South Africa.

South African foreign minister Alfred Nzo said during a recent visit that Pretoria was currently trying to balance its trade with Zambia and other neighbouring states. The trade is currently in South Africa's favour.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


88 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Trans-Border Trade Stalled By Border Closure


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 480 words


 

BADAGRY, Nigeria - Trans-border trade between Nigeria and 15 other countries of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) has been paralysed since the February 29 closure of the Nigeria-Benin borders, the official News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) has reported.

The situation has resulted in "colossal losses" to businessmen and traders in the sub-region, the agency reported, quoting investigations by its reporters from the border town of Badagry.

The Nigeria-Benin frontier is a major route for the movement of goods and services within the 16-nation community. 

Benin shut its own side of the frontier for four days from February 29 for its presidential elections.

Nigeria, citing "national interest and security reasons," closed its own side of the borders on the same day.

The Benin ambassador in Nigeria Jean-Claude Kpakpo told PANA Nigeria had notified his government it was closing the borders "temporarily until further notice."

NAN reported that hundreds of travellers from ECOWAS countries were now stranded with their goods at both sides of the border posts following the closure.

It said a large number of Nigerian importers who use the Cotonou Seaport in Benin were "groaning under accumulated demurrage and freight charges as their goods could not be brought into Nigeria through the borders."

According to the agency, more than 500 imported second-hand vehicles and about 300 trailers loaded with iron rods, cotton, spare parts, grains and textiles are parked at the Benin end of Seme border, while a large quantity of goods bound for Nigeria are still at the Cotonou port.

Many of the stranded travellers are camped in mission houses at the border towns of Badagry and Owode, NAN said.

It quoted one stranded traveller Mathew Ogundele as saying "this is our third week here and having spent all our money on feeding and other expenses, we don't know when the border will be reopened."

Ogundele, who said he was travelling to Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire said the Catholic mission in Badagry had provided him and some 200 others free accommodation, while those who could not wait had abandoned the journey.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


89 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large G-15 Countries Set Up Committee To Promote Trade


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 627 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - A committee formed last year to promote trade and investment in developing countries began a two-day meeting in Harare on Tuesday, to map out strategies to revive third world economies.

The inaugural meeting of the Committee on Investment Trade and Technology (CITT), which was launched in November last year at the G-15 summit of developing countries in Buenos Aires, is expected to come up with recommendations to guide the future of economic co-operation among them.

In a statement at the opening ceremony, Zimbabwe's industry and commerce minister, Herbert Murerwa, said the objective of CITT was to broaden and intensify the scope of intra-G-15 economic co-operation, particularly in the areas of the liberalisation, facilitation and promotion of trade, investment and technology. 

He said the two-day deliberations and their outcome would be crucial in setting the tone, direction and impact of the initiative on the future development of economic co-operation.

The main function of the committee, he said, was to serve as "a flexible, consultative, overeaching and trans-regional mechanism to facilitate continuos dialogue" among member countries in the three main areas of trade, investment and technology.

To perform this function, the CITT would draw extensively from the the work and contributions of existing G-15 projects and structures, Murerwa said.

Murerwa said establishing priorities for the CITT work programme would not be an easy task as there would be need to avoid duplication on the one hand and establish a limited, focused and business-responsive list of priorities on the other.

Commenting on the current global economic situation, Murerwa said it was characterised by growing interdependence and greater integration among countries of varying levels of development.

He noted that effects of globalisation and liberalisation of such areas as production, trade, investment, money and finance, services and technology were increasingly impacting on the member countries' economies.

The impact he said, could be both positive and negative, presenting new opportunities for growth and development as well as challenges for the member countries.

In concluding his speech, he said that while everyone was aware of the objectives of the G-15, it was necessary to define the practical mechanisms and means for achieving the end.

In this regard, he said, the establishment of the G-15 projects, particularly the South Investment, Trade and Technological Data Exchange Centre (SITTDEC) and the Business and Investment Forum (BIF) represented the member countries' resolve to promote "feasible and meaningful co-operation among the countries."

The G-15 is a loose coalition of developing countries comprising Argentina, Algeria, Brazil, Chile, Egypt, Mexico, Jamaica, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Senegal, Venezuela, Peru, Nigeria and Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


90 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Sudan Date Palms Boost Food Self-Sufficiency Drive


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Yahia El Hassan PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 880 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Date palms, introduced in Sudan from Saudi Arabia centuries ago, have fully adapted to the climate and the palms now contribute significantly to the country's food self-sufficiency drive.

The crop, which usually competes with the minarets of mosques in desert oasis in the race towrad the sky, has been adapted to the humid tropical climate of Equatoria, where temperatures average 40 degrees centrigrade in certian periods and annual rainfalls reach 1,000 cubic millimeters.

The date palm fruit is rich in glucose sugar, a fact which explains why muslims use it as starter for Ramdan meals after the day-long fast.

Doctors also recommend it for patients with hemoglobin and other blood blood related deficiencies. 

Experts say a handfull of dates can sustain a human being for six hours.

Dates are also useful as "food nuts" during long travels and periods of famine. If properly sun-dried, hard dates can be preserved for more than twelve months. They can be preserved soft and fresh for more than a year if packaged in polythene bags or tin containers.

The number of date palm trees in Sudan is currently estimated at one million, concentrated in the extreme northern part of the country along the River Nile. They produce 100,000 tonnes of dates each year, most of which are consumed locally.

The high adaptability of date palms have encouraged farmers to grow them in Darfur State in the extreme West and in the coastal areas of the Red Sea, known to suffer long periods of drought.

Abdalla Ali, a Khartoum-based farmer says the trees he planted have fully adapted to the weather.

"In the past I used to harvest my dates during the rainy season but little by little this has changed and I can now harvest them before the rains," he said.

However, an Iraqi expert has warned that offshoots should not be left to grow with the mother tree as they will reduce its consumption of food and nitrates and reduce its productivity.

Dr. Salih Muhsin Badr of the Arab Organisation for Agricultural Development working on a project for improving and multiplying date palms in Sudan told PANA "offshoots should be weeded as early as possible because if left to grow they will share the food it obtains from the soil and it will grow weak and fruitless."

He said Sudanese and other African producers should recognize the viabilty of fertilization of date palms to achieve higher yields.

Branches should be reduced to the minimum and dry branches should be cut immediately while date clusters should be reduced to let the fruit grow big, headded.

Salih also advised farmers to grow lemon and orange trees below the date palms to protect the soil and sustain humidity.

Dates can produce good quality jams. The facutly of agriculture of the University of Khartoum, has been able to produce honey, cakes and jam from the crop.

However, date palm farming is not without its problems. One of them has to do with how to pollinate and harvest them due to their trmendous heights.

Khairy Ahmed Ali, a director of horticulture, recommends mechanisation using light pollination machines, since experienced climbers were becoming scarce.

Date seeds can also produce rich animal fodder. Seeds can be crushed to small pieces and mixed with sorghum and salt to produce rich animal fodder.

Doctors also recommend the nuts for patients with chronic constipation. When softened in a pot containing water all night and taken early in the morning, dates can guarantee easy stooling for these patients, they say.

The Arab Organisation for Agricultural Development quoting 1993 figures put total annual output of dates at 2,918,000 tonnes.

Iraq is the world's biggest producer with an output of 631,300 tonnes in 1993, followed by Egypt with 613,000 tonnes, Saudi Arabia with 560,000 tonnes and Algeria with 262,000 tonnes.

Other major producers include the Sultanate of Oman (126,000), Morocco (111,100), the organisation said.

In the United States, the state of Indiana is now known to produce good quality dates.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


91 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Manufacturing Industry Declines by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996


LENGTH: 400 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - The manufacturing sector's share of Zambia's total Gross Domestic Product (GDP) fell marginally from 24.7 percent in 1994 to 24.6 percent in 1995, the government has said in a report on the economy.

The report attributed the decline partly to governement's continued trade liberalisation which had increased competition on the local market from cheaper or better imported products. 

Zambia's manufacturing industry in 1995 earned some USD 525,000 from USD 550,000 recorded the previous year.

According to the report, only non-metallic mineral products and fabricated metal products had registered increases in their contribution to real output while the basic metal products sub-sector had also stagnated, for the third year running.

Among manufacturing sub-sectors which experienced a decline were food, beverages and tobacco, textiles and leather industries, wood and wood products, paper and paper products. Others included chemicals, rubber and plastic products.

The Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) government of president Frederick Chiluba in 1994 enacted "the competition and fair trading act" to regulate trade competition locally.

The law is intended to introduce a code of conduct for all business entities and ensure fair competition on the market.

Chiluba's government has been blamed, by the opposition and commercial and industrial sectors, for stiffling local industry since the adoption in 1992 of a free market economy.

Zambia has been swamped by cheap goods, including textiles and foodstuffs, from especially neighbouring South Africa.

South African foreign minister Alfred Nzo said during a recent visit that Pretoria was currently trying to balance its trade with Zambia and other neighbouring states. The trade is currently in South Africa's favour.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


92 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Central Bank Fires 178 Executives


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 19, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 627 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The Central Bank of Nigeria announced Monday it has fired 178 bank directors and blacklisted 75 others in connection with sundry abuses.

It also said it recovered some 700 million naira from some officials as a result of financial impropriety arising from credits they granted themselves, relatives and companies (82.5 naira =1 USD).

The apex bank did not name the executives concerned but said the move was in pursuance of ongoing efforts to sanitise Nigeria's financial services industry. 

More than 30 commercial banks have been declared insolvent while the operating licences of several others have been revoked in the last one year over financial impropriety.

At least two executives of the failed banks have been jailed on corruption-related charges.

A number of other bank executives are awaiting trial, while others have fled the country fearing prosecution under the military government's tough banking decree.

The central bank said after a comprehensive review, it was discovered that many insider credits were "delinquent and non-performing."

"Consequently," it added, "after due process and fair hearing, sanctions including removal of the defaulting directors and blacklisting from appointment into the boards of institutions under the bank's supervisory preview, have been imposed."

It said that insiders, who failed to settle loans or engaged in malpractices would be brought before a bankruptcy tribunal for debt recovery or criminal sanctions.

The apex bank said the exercise would be a continuous one.

In a related development, the Nigerian Securities and Exchanges Commission (SEC), which runs the local capital market, has withdrawn the licence of a stock broking firm and suspended 20 others.

The Commission said it revoked the registration certificate of Majestic Securities Ltd because of the firm's alleged failure to render accounts of the public offer on 10 issues in which it had acted as agent.

In the first major move at implementing government's pledge to sanitise the capital market, the Commission also said the stock broking firm was being penalised for alleged inability to renew its registration.

The commission said investigation on the activities of the company revealed that proceeds from an oil company for public offer of 57.5 million naira and 30 million naira ordinary shares for public subscription and rights issue respectively were unremitted.

SEC accused the stockbroking firm of compromising professional ethics by issuing dud cheques.

The Commission warned investors against transacting capital market business with the company and the suspended stockbroking firms.

According to brokers, the affected firms have either been declared distressed or have had their operations trimmed.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


93 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Sierra Leone U.N. Mobilizes Financial Support


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 20, 1996 by Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 440 words


 

NEW YORK, United Nations - The United Nations launched an appeal for 57 million U.S. dollars to address humanitarian needs in Sierra Leone, where an election concluded Sunday to return the nation to civilian rule.

The U.N. Department of Humanitarian Affairs (DHA) said the money would be used by the United Nations and non-governmental organizations to provide relief assistance to people displaced or affected by the country's five-year civil war.

The United Nations raised about 10 million dollars for the recent elections in the West African country. 

The DHA said the latest appeal, to last until February 1997, would cover programs in food aid and production, health and nutrition, non-food aid, assistance to children, education, demobilization, and coordination of humanitarian assistance.

"The emergency in Sierra Leone is occurring within the broader context of a country undergoing structural adjustment, seeking long-term development and moving towards democratic governance," it added.

"It is foreseen that emergency programs will be required for the remainder of 1996," the agency said, "in order to sustain those worst affected by the crisis and to stabilize the areas of the country that can be reached by relief and development organizations."

The civil war between the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) and the military government in Freetown has forced about 2.1 million people to abandon their homes.

The United Nations estimates that 1.6 million people are internally displaced while about 370,000 fled to neighboring countries.

Meanwhile, the U.N. Security Council Tuesday congratulated Sierra Leone for successfully holding Saturday's runoff presidential elections, in which Ahmed Tejan Kabbah of the Sierra Leone's Peoples Party emerged winner.

Its president, Botswana's Legwaila Legwaila, called on the RUF to accept the elections' result and enter into peace talks with the government.

The council also called on the international community to provide the country with humanitarian assistance.

Africa News


March, 1996


United States and Africa United States Debt to the United Nations Worries Citizens


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 20, 1996 by Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 307 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York - Some American nationals, embarrassed by their country's huge debt to the United Nations, have started mailing checks to the organization to reduce the arrears.

The United States owes more to the United Nations than any other country, 1.6 billion dollars of the total 3.1 billion dollars owed to the world body. 

The arrears are for regular and peacekeeping contributions.

A number of Americans, who believe their country should pay its dues, have sent in cheques of 4.4 dollars each. The amount is what each U.S. citizen would pay if the debt were divided among the American population.

A U.N. spokesman, Ahmed Fawzi, said Tuesday 462 checks had been received so far from more than 1,047 Americans.

"We are still receiving letters (and checks) from U.S. citizens who wish to make their small contributions to the U.S. debt," he said.

Fawzi said although the total amount of contributions as of March 18 was less than 6,500 dollars, "it is very much appreciated."

The local newspaper in the small U.S. town of New Canaan even ran an advertisement from 33 residents announcing their contributions.

Only 41 of the 185 U.N. member-states have paid their assessed contributions to the organization this year, a situation that has put the organization in its worst financial situation since it was founded more than 50 years ago.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Mozambique Radioactive Waste Found in Tete


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 20, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

MAPUTO, Mozambique - Mozambique's Geology and Mines Directorate recommended the sealing off of areas in the northwestern city of Tete, where containers of radioactive material have been found, to prevent any harm to members of the public.

Wednesday's issue of the Maputo daily paper 'Noticias' reported that the directorate sent a team to analyze the radioactive waste. 

A geophysical survey was also undertaken in the area where the waste was dumped. Samples taken will be analyzed further in Maputo.

The material was discovered at Chingozi and Nhambira on the outskirts of Tete. It had been used for geophysical work in the coal mining industry but was abandoned in the mid-1980s.

The discovery was immediately communicated to the ministries of energy and mineral resources, and of environmental coordination.

Branquinho Nhombe, head of the Tete Provincial Mineral Resources Directorate, added that until the results of the survey are known, the directorate will take preventive measures by posting signs warning passers-by to avoid the area.

Nhombe said the province does not have the financial or technical means to render the material safe. He hoped non-governmental organizations who operate in this part of the country would provide aid.

Africa News


March, 1996


Uganda Four Aspirants for Presidency


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 20, 1996


LENGTH: 454 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda - Four candidates, including the incumbent, Yoweri Museveni, are set to contest Uganda's presidential elections this May.

Museveni will run as chairman of the ruling National Resistance Movement.

Another candidate is the Democratic Party president-general Paul Semwogerere, who will run as the joint candidate of the Inter-Party Cooperation, an alliance of several Ugandan political parties. 

The other two are the little-known Herman Ssemujju and Mohammed Mayanja, an academic whose bid to contest the presidential elections was known only this week.

The aspirants were issued their nomination papers Tuesday in Kampala by the chairman of Uganda's interim electoral commission, Stephen Akabway. The documents were received by the candidates' campaign managers.

Officially, the elections are to be held under a "no party system" whereby candidates stand as independents.

Opposition candidates have complained this system favors Museveni, who has a well-structured organization of which he was the candidate in the multiparty polls of 1981.

The aspiring candidates will have to obtain 100 signatures of supporters in each of the country's districts before they can officially become presidential candidates.

Akabway said no person must intimidate, threaten or harass the aspiring presidential candidates' campaign agents as they mobilize to collect the signatures.

The presidential campaign formally begins on March 29.

The election will be the first since Museveni and his National Resistance Army shot their way to power in January 1986 after a five-year guerilla war.

Uganda's last multiparty polls were held in 1981, two years after a combined force of Ugandan exiles and Tanzanian troops dislodged Gen. Idi Amin, the dictator who had ruled the East African country from January 1971.

Museveni took up arms shortly after those Commonwealth- observed elections, amid claims that they were flawed in favor of Milton Obote. Obote's force was the largest in the effort to topple Amin.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


97 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Liberia West African Community to Adhere to Peace Deal


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 20, 1996 by Terence Sesay, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 654 words


 

MONROVIA, Liberia - Military chiefs from the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) resolved Tuesday to adhere strictly to the peace accord signed in 1995 by Liberia's warring factions.

The meeting of military chiefs is only the second since the Abuja Accord was signed Aug. 17, 1995, and comes at a time when the peace process is on the verge of collapse as rebel forces reportedly are nearing the capital, Monrovia.

At a news conference after the two-day meeting, the community's executive secretary, Edouard Benjamin, said the peace plan designed by the 16 ECOWAS nations was working, but with difficulty. 

Military chiefs from 11 of the 16 states attended the conference. Those who did not show were from Benin, Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Mauritania and Togo. No reason was given for their absence.

The meeting reviewed the conflicts in Liberia and neighboring Sierra Leone -- where a rebellion in Sierra Leone sprouted from the Liberian war -- and what ECOWAS could do to bring the Liberian peace process back on track.

Fighting between some Liberian factions continues to endanger the peace process. Fighters are supposed to allow the West African peacekeeping force, ECOMOG, to deploy throughout the country, disarm the factions, then canton them before elections are held.

Benjamim said difficulties in implementing the accord lay with factors beyond their control. This could refer to the international community's unwillingness to provide logistics for ECOMOG to fan out throughout Liberia, patrol its borders to prevent weapons smuggling, and provide a peaceful environment within.

Benjamin said ECOWAS would help provide the right climate to resolve the six-year conflict.

ECOMOG Field Commander Maj. Gen. John Inienger described as "unfortunate" the recent occupation of the town Kakata by rebels from National Patriotic Front of Liberia. He said his staff was studying the reported rebel advance toward Monrovia.

The peacekeepers withdrew from the town of Tubmanburg after they were ambushed there in December 1995 by one of the warring groups that seized heavy weapons from the peacekeepers and left many dead.

Inienger, a Nigerian army general, said his troops would not go back to Tubmanburg unless the weapons were returned.

Witnesses fleeing Kakata said despite orders to withdraw from rebel leader Charles Taylor, now a member of Liberia's ruling six-man Council of State, his men had continued to rape, loot, and terrorize residents. It is unclear whether Taylor still has complete control of his forces.

Other fleeing Kataka residents said the rebels' marine forces were the unit that attacked the town. They have gained notoriety for their "viciousness, lust and greed." The town now is deserted as residents seek refuge in the Booker Washington Institute where ECOMOG has its base.

The rebels also occupied Bensonville, about 40 kilometers (25 miles) from Kakata and about 32 kilometers (20 miles) from Monrovia. They have also taken White Plains, about 11 kilometers (seven miles) outside the capital.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Benin Election Results Not Yet Official


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 20, 1996 by Ali Idrissou Toure, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 414 words


 

COTONOU, Benin - Benin's autonomous National Electoral Commission Tuesday night said the election results announced earlier in the day, which declared former president Mathieu Kerekou the winner, were not official.

In a statement on Monday's second round presidential polls, the commission said the results, published by several international news organs, had not yet been confirmed. 

The document entitled "Clarification on the Results Released by the National Institute for Statistics and Economic Analysis", was read to journalists by the commission's chairman, Leopold Dossou.

Dossou said although the institute and the commission were jointly involved in the computer processing of election data, the institute is not charged with the actual organizing or publication of the results.

"The commission informs local and international opinion that as at Tuesday March 19, 1996, at 4 p.m., it does not yet possess adequate information to be able to release complete provisional results for any of the six districts in the country," the statement said.

Dossou told the journalists that he had just been given written confirmation of provisional results for the southeastern Mono District, where Kerekou won 122,706 votes against 95,200 for the incumbent Nicephore Soglo.

Dossou added that he also had the provisional results of seven out of 14 sub-districts in the central Zou district. These were in favour of Soglo.

Meanwhile, supporters of Soglo denounced Tuesday night what they claimed was "manipulation of information" in favor of his adversary.

Provisional results placed Kerekou ahead of Soglo. They said Kerekou had 59 percent of the ballots. However, estimates published later indicated the general had won with 52.84 percent of the votes.

The final results are expected to be issued by the country's Constitutional Court after it reviews the entire provisional results provided by the electoral commission.
