99 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Guineaworm Awards Presented


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 20, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 587 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Three Nigerians and a Briton Tuesday in Lagos received the 'Jimmy and Rosalyn Carter' awards for helping to reduce the spread of guineaworm in Nigeria.

The awards were given Wednesday, the eve of the International Guineaworm Day.

The first award -- a plaque and an undisclosed sum of money -- went to Colins Davis, an employee of the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). 

A disabled retired Nigerian civil servant, A.K. Salami, was named the second recipient. He was recognised for being in the vanguard of Nigeria's guineaworm eradication campaign.

A fresh university graduate, Lola Olopade, and a programme officer, Niran Fatinilu, were the other award recipients.

The awards were given at a ceremony to celebrate Nigeria's success reducing of its guineaworm cases by 97 percent over the past eight years.

The awards bear the names of former United States president Jimmy Carter and his wife, who have led the drive against the debilitating disease, especially in Africa.

The former U.S. leader and his 'Global 2000' have been in the forefront of guineaworm eradication efforts in Nigeria and other African countries.

Davis was praised for backing with "technical assistance and substantial financial resources" cooperation with the Nigeria Guineaworm Eradication Programme (NIGEP).

The awards were introduced by Carter as an incentive to hasten the complete eradication of guineaworm globally.

Similar awards were also presented to six states and Abuja, the Nigerian capital, which recorded no guineaworm cases by 1995, the previous eradication target date.

Nigeria reduced its cases of guineaworm from 653,620 from 1988 to about 15,000 cases in Dec. 1995.

Meanwhile, the Nigerian health minister Ihechukwu Madubuike said Tuesday in Lagos that financial and political commitments were essential for a successful eradication of the disease in the country.

He said there must be increased funding, effective supervision, sustained high surveillance and the provision of potable water.

The minister urged greater co-operation from within and outside the country for the achievement of the goal.

"If we must truly develop and turn our rural areas to economically viable entities, the problems of guineaworm and other endemic diseases must be adequately addressed," he added.

Nigeria, with some 100 million people, is second in the World Health Organisation's ranking of 18 countries that have the debilitating disease.

Sudan leads the group with some 60,000 cases. These are mainly found in the country's south, where a civil war has been going on since 1983.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


100 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Ghana Country Moves To Change Sexual Behaviours As AIDS Strikes


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 20, 1996 by Yaa Acquah, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 854 words


 

ACCRA, Ghana - The global threat posed by the AIDS calls for emergencies to address the challenging task of bringing about a change in the lifestyles of populations.

The world is still a long way from discovering a cure for HIV, the virus which causes aids, and even if one is found now, new treatments need to be tested for safety and effectiveness at several stages before they can be licenced for use. The same applies to the discovery of a vaccine.

According to Dr. Peter Piot, Executive Director of the joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS, "the world-wide epidemic of AIDS is one of the major tragedies of our time." 

"The HIV epidemic, now in its second decade, continues to grow...at a rate of over 6,000 new infections every day, and the resulting sickness and death from AIDS continue to wreak unprecedented havoc among individuals, families and societies," says Dr. Piot.

He warns that no country will be able to able to insulate itself from the shock waves of HIV/AIDS.

In view of these factors, the Ghanaian government has been urging the population, especially workers, to adopt healthier lifestyles that will help check the epidemic's spread.

This is because statistics show that about 80 percent of Ghana's 15,600 AIDS victims are aged between 19 and 45 years.

Even this is an under-estimate. The Ministry of health in Accra says that the official number of aids cases is only a small figure of those affected.

Consequently, the ministry has been urging workers to discuss and take action that will protect them and other support activities they can offer to other to protect themselves.

The ministry has been doing so by encouraging workers to help their collegues who already have the virus as way of controlling its spread.

It advises that once a worker has AIDS he should be placed on light duties to enable him or her seek medical attention.

He has to pay for the medical bills, and if he is self-employed he loses his income during the treatment period. If the patient works with the government or a private company, the employer pays the bills, loses money and loses man hours leading, to a fall in productivity.

If the patient is married, the partner may stay away from home at various times to take care of the needs of his spouse.

Profit will be affected thus affecting the national economy as the company's tax will also be reduced.

AIDS is expected to cost Ghana a lot of skilled and semi-skilled workers who will need to be replaced. Recruiting and training of staff to replace those lost to AIDS will be time consuming and costly as money will go into the education/training of the new employee.

In addition, employers have lost a lot of man hours due to AIDS. Once an AIDS patient dies, a number of workers will always stay away from work to attend to the funeral, thus affecting productivity.

In spite of this, many Ghanaians appear to be indifferent to the AIDS pandemic because they have not seen an AIDS patient. A lot of people have various impressions about the incurable disease.

Some even go to the extent of blaming some journalists the health authorities of making too much noise about the illness.

Their jargon is "every die be die", whether it is from malaria, an accident or AIDS you will be gone for ever.

To justify the multiplicity of sexual partners, the common remark is: "What if I decide to have some palm nut soup after taking light soup for a long time?"

Such statements show the need for intensive and effective workplace educational programmes to help workers avoid behaviour patterns that open them to infection.

Both management and workers should develop an effective response to the anti-aids campagign and develop programmes on aids counselling, medical care and social support for their employees, families and other people in their local communities.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


101 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Spinal-Cerebro Meningitis Kills Over 5000 Africans


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 20, 1996


LENGTH: 320 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - A total of 5,392 people had died of spinal-cerebro meningitis in 10 mainly West African countries between January 1 and March 18 this year, according to figures issued by the Brazzaville-based Regional office of the World Health Organization (WHO).

The disease is spread by a germ known as 'meningococcus' which attacks the working of the nervous system in the spinal cord. The germ multiplies quickly in hot and dusty zones.

The WHO indicated that the deaths were out of a total 38,169 cases of the illness diagnosed in the 10 countries.

Nigeria led the table with 3,634 deaths out of 20,982 cases. The northern state of Kano was the most affected.

Burkina Faso in the West African Sahel registered 859 deaths out of 9,532 cases while Niger, also in the same zone, recorded 584 deaths out of 5,529 cases.

Mali, another Sahelian country -- whose report to the WHO regional office dates to March 16 -- recorded 158 deaths out of 787 cases while Chad had 53 deaths out of 505 recorded cases.

Benin had 46 deaths out of 362 patients. In neighbouring Togo, 33 deaths were recorded out of 183 cases.

The Central African Republic had 22 deaths from 99 cases.

Tanzania was the only East African country to be affected by the disease with eight deaths out of 99 cases. Cameroon registered one death out of the five cases detected.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


102 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Mozambique Workshop Hosted on Post-Conflict Health


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 20, 1996


LENGTH: 414 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - A three-day international workshop on 'the Health Impact of Large Post-Conflict Migratory Movements' opens Wednesday in Maputo, Mozambique.

The workshop, organised by the International Organization for Migration (IOM), brings together agencies and individuals with experience in issues related to the health impact of conflicts and the health concerns of the Mozambican peace and reconstruction process. 

An IOM news release to PANA said topics for discussion will focus on the impact of the 16-year Mozambican war on the country's health infrastructure, health and forced migration, health care in refugee camps, emergency health intervention, migratory movements and infectious diseases.

Participants will also review the demobilization of combatants, food security, safe transportation of returning refugees and internally displaced persons, pre-integration health screening and health care in assembly areas.

They will also exmaine the challenges in the reintegration of refugees and displaced persons, physical and pyscho-social rehabilitation, military personnel and their reintegration into civil life, disabled soldiers and pension eligibility, mine-awareness campaigns and demographic studies.

The meeting will also examine issues relating to long-term national reconstruction, including planning and priority setting, health facilities reconstruction, primary health care, reproductive health, environmental health and training of personnel.

The meeting is taking place at a time when the Mozambican health sector is completeley overwhelmed by demands created by the massive return of refugees over the last three years.

Their return was facilitated by the general peace agreement signed by the Mozambican government and Renamo rebels in Rome on Oct. 4, 1992.

On their return, these refugees found that between 30 and 50 percent of their health infrastructure had been looted, destroyed or forced to close during the civil war.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


103 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Gambia Ban on Skin-Bleaching Gets Boost


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 20, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

BANJUL, Gambia - World Health Organization (WHO) Regional Director for Africa Dr Ebrahim Samba has endorsed the ban imposed by the Gambian military government on skin-bleaching.

Addressing a news conference in Banjul on March 16, Samba, who is Gambian and once served as his country's medical director, described the decision as "a very good move." 

Capt. Yahya Jammeh's Armed Forces Provisional Ruling Council has effective January 1996 banned skin-bleaching, which was gaining increased popularity among women in this tiny West African state with a population of about one million people. Samba said that he had, in his capacity as director of medical services, spoken out against the practice and had seen people suffer and die as a result of skin bleaching.

According to the Gambia News Agency (GAMNA), the regional director described the government's action as not so much an act of banning but a step towards the "protection of our sisters, mothers and wives" from harm.

Skin bleaching "is a very dangerous practice", Samba said at a news conference held at the WHO office in Banjul.

The WHO Regional Director was in Banjul to review preparations for a forthcoming roundtable between Gambian health authorities and donors to be held in August. Four WHO consultants have been in Banjul since the beginning of March working with Gambian officials on the proposed donors' conference.

Samba arrived in the Gambian capital from Dakar, Senegal, where he insisted, during another news conference, on the need for African countries to effectively fund their own health requirements instead of waiting for donors.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


104 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large First World TB Day To Be Observed


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 20, 1996 by Peter Masebu, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 934 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The international community observes the first World Tuberculosis Day Saturday.

The event is being held to commemorate the day TB bacillus, the agent that causes the disease, was discovered by a German microbiologist Dr Robert Koch in 1882.

To draw attention to the TB crisis, which will kill some 3 million people in 1996 alone, the World Health Organization (WHO) Director General Dr Hiroshi Nakajima on Tuesday launched a week of TB Day activities in Osaka, Japan.

This will be followed by the publication in London on Thursday of the WHO report on the 'Tuberculosis Epidemic 1996' at a news conference. 

Two events are scheduled to take place in Africa as part of the World TB week.

The first of these will take place Thursday at Nigeria's Nnamdi Azikiwe University in Nnewi, eastern Nigeria. It will be a seminar to appraise the current knowledge of TB.

In Cape Town, South Africa, Bishop Desmond Tutu, a former TB patient, will officiate at a special service at Guguletu Sports Complex on March 24.

TB is transmitted from person to person by bacilli spread into the air when a patient with active pulmonary tuberculosis coughs, sneezes or even talks.

It can also be spread through consumption of contaminated unpasturized milk or dairy products. This mode of transmission occurs mainly among farmers and animal handlers.

According to the WHO, there is a resurgence of TB because of limited use of the effective drugs developed after Koch's discovery of the disease's causing germ.

"As a result, TB has sent at least 200 million people to their graves since 1882," said the UN health agency in a pre- World TB Day advisory.

Worse still is the emergence of multi-drug resistant TB strains that "are threatening to make the disease incurable for future generations," said the WHO.

It was only in the 1940s that anti-tuberculosis drugs were discovered.

These were mainly drinkable or injectable anti-biotics such as streptomycin and ethambutol and several others which have been placed on the WHO list of essential drugs.

Complete treatment of TB patients costs between 15 and 40 USD, which is unfortunately beyond the reach of the majority in Africa where access to elementary health care is often poor.

Drug resistant TB strains are emerging mainly due to poor diagnosis and because patients do not adhere to the prescriptions given to them.

The result is the hardening of the TB bacillus against prescribed drugs.

Poor diagnosis and a failure to stick to prescriptions can make TB patients chronic sufferers.

According to the WHO African regional office in Brazzaville, Congo, 600,000 TB-related deaths occur in the region each year. This represents a fifth of all TB-caused deaths worldwide.

The regional WHO office says 1.5 million cases are registered on the continent every year. Of these, 300,000 are found in those also infected with HIV, the virus believed to cause Aids.

TB is now said to account for 40 percent of mortality among Africa's AIDS patients.

The HIV-TB infected persons react very poorly to certain anti-TB drugs, Thiocetazone in particular.

WHO experts in Brazzaville fear that up to 10 million Africans could die of TB due to inadequate treatment in the next decade.

The most efficient treatment is currently a combination of drugs which not only prevent the spread of TB infection but also prevent the emergence of drug-resistant bacillus.

The method is known as directly-observed treatment, short course (DOTS).

But this method requires a strict follow-up of patients for six to eight months.

Diagnosis and adequate treatment and systematic vaccination of children against TB considerably reduce the risk of mortality. However, TB thrives most among migrants, aged people, AIDS carriers and alcoholics.

The WHO has encouraged the media to carry the anti-TB message beyond the World TB day to raise public awareness on the gravity of the TB situation.

It has urged its partners to mobilise further resources to combat the disease.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


105 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zaire Lawyers Volunteer to Defend Crash Victims


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 21, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

KINSHASA, Zaire - Fifteen members of the Zairean Bar Association offered to give free legal services to an undetermined number of poverty-striken people injured when a plane plunged into a central Kinshasa market early this year.

A Russian-made plane failed to take-off from an airport located near a big market in the Zairean capital on Jan. 8. 

The aircraft sped into the market, killing nearly 300 people and injuring at least 250 others.

Some accident victims are still undergoing treatment in Kinshasa's health centers.

The lawyers will appear on behalf of the victims when the case reopens Monday.

The association said it will give legal assistance to the plaintiffs upon presentation of a document confirming their inability to pay legal fees. The certificates are issued by local council authorities.

Among those affected are civil servants who are regarded as poor, given their low incomes.

Appearing in the case are two Russian pilots, the operator of the plane, African Air, and 'Scibe-Air-Lift', which hired out the 'Antonov 32' aircraft to the Zairean Civil Aviation Authority.

When the hearing started March 4, defense lawyers protested the ommission of the Zairean government from the list of the defendants citing its "heavy responsibility" in the disaster.

The case was postponed for three weeks to enable all the interested parties prepare their cases.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


106 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria U.N. Sending Fact-Finding Mission


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 21, 1996 by Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 587 words


 

UNITED NATIONS, New York - The United Nations is sending a three-member fact-finding mission to Nigeria next week.

A U.N. spokesman, Ahmad Fawzi, said Wednesday the team, scheduled to leave on March 27, would address itself to "two issues of concern" to the international community.

He said the delegation will examine "the trial and execution of Ken Saro-Wiwa and others, including the judicial procedures of the trial in the context of the various international human rights instruments to which Nigeria is a party and of relevant Nigerian law." 

"The plans of the government of Nigeria to implement its declared commitment to restore the country to democratic rule," is the other issue to be examined, Fawzi added.

The mission includes Atsu Koffi Amega, Togo's former foreign minister and member of the African Commission on Human and People's Rights, based in Banjul, Gambia.

The others are Justice V.S. Malimath, a member of the National Human Rights Commission of India, and John Pace, chief of the legislation and prevention of discrimination branch, at the U.N. Center for Human Rights in Geneva, Switzerland.

The mission will be accompanied by Amer Araim, a senior political affairs officer in the U.N. department of political affairs.

Nigeria has come under international pressure for its troubled democratization process and human rights record.

The execution Nov. 10, 1995, of author Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight other Ogoni minority-rights leaders on charges of murdering four of their kinsmen in 1994, unleashed international condemnation and sanctions against the populous West African country.

Upon completion of its work, the group will submit a report to Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali.

On the duration of the visit, Fawzi said: "As long as it takes, we don't have a time frame."

Fawzi said the mission was being sent at the request Nigeria's government and in in accordance with a December 1995 General Assembly resolution asking the secretary-general to undertake discussions with the Nigerian government and to report on the progress in the implementation of the resolution.

Sponsored by the United States and the European Union, it condemned what it called the "arbitrary execution" of Saro-Wiwa and the eight others who were found guilty of the murder of four Ogoni leaders opposed to their movement.

The resolution also expressed concern about "other violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms in Nigeria" and urged the government to take immediate and concrete steps to restore democratic rule.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


107 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Sierra Leone Six Parties Gain Seats in Parliament


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 21, 1996 by Abdul Jalloh, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 440 words


 

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone - Six of the 13 political parties that presented candidates in legislative elections held in Sierra Leone in February have gained seats in parliament, according to final results released by the election commission chairman, James Jonah.

The six parties were able to obtain the required five percent of the total votes cast in the polls held on February 26 and 27 to gain seats in parliament, he said.

According to the results, the Sierra Leone People's Party (SLPP) received 269,888 votes or 36 percent to gain 27 seats. 

The United National People's Party (UNPP) followed with 165,219 votes or 22 percent to gain 17 seats, while the People's Democratic Party (PDP) with 114,429 votes or 15 percent of the votes, gained 12 seats.

The All People's Congress (APC) which received 42,467 votes or 6 percent, gained five seats, the Natioanal Unity Party (NUP) with 39,285 votes and 5 percent, gained four seats while the Democratic Centre Party (DCP) with 35,632 votes or 5 percent, gained three seats.

Jonah's report showed 750,858 people nationwide voted for 68 parliament seats.

There was regional balance in the distribution of seats with the three parties based in the north -- UNPP, PDP and APC -- collecting 34 seats, the same number as the three south-eastern oriented parties, SLPP, NUP and DCP.

Twelve paramount chiefs, one from each district, were also elected to parliament by local chiefdom councillors on a non-patry basis, thus bringing the total membership of parliament to eighty.

Meanwhile, in the presidential run-off poll of March 15 which elected Ahmad Tejan Kabba of the SLPP, voter turn-out was 1,044,158 or 70 percent of the national electorate.

There were 1,028,851 were valid votes from a total of 1,496,749 registered.

There were a number of compaints of irregularities which, Jonah said, were not made public because of the understanding and reconciliation shown by the various political leaders.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Liberia West African Peacekeepers Ask Rebels to Withdraw Troops


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 21, 1996 by Terrance Sesay, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 360 words


 

MONROVIA, Liberia - The High Command of the West African peacekeeping force in Liberia has asked one of several rebel factions in the country to pull out of areas recently declared safe havens to facilitate the return of civil administration in the affected areas.

The command said Wednesday now only its troops will be allowed to carry arms in these havens. 

The peacekeeping group, known by its acronym ECOMOG, said it was concerned that the National Patriotic Front of Liberia had continued to occupy the locations of Kakata, Todee and Bong Mines.

The rebel action, it said, "led to the displacement of thousands of unarmed civilians whose only hope lies in an end to the carnage that the civil war has brought to the Liberian people."

ECOMOG emphasized the need for all parties to the conflict to abide by the Abuja agreement which they signed.

About two weeks ago, the front attacked and overran another splinter faction, ULIMO-J, from the three locations. Then, the front lost the ground to the main ULIMO body during "Operation Octopus" launched by the front to complete its military conquest of Liberia.

The reason given by the front's leader, Councilman Charles Taylor, for his attacks was to keep the road to the interior of the country open. Taylor said his troops wanted to ensure free movement of civilians and ensure constant supply of food and other commodities to residents of Monrovia, the capital.

Nevertheless, the fighters continue to occupy the areas and even to set up bases several kilometers beyond Kakata, Bong Mines and Todee, posing a threat to the entire peace proces.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


109 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Burundi OAU Mission's Mandate Extended


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 21, 1996 by Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 347 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - The Organization of African Unity (OAU) said Thursday it is extending the mandate of its Observer Mission to Burundi for only one month "due to financial constraints."

Burundi had asked the mission be extended by 58 more observers. It had also asked for a six month extension of its mandate, which expires at the end of March.

The mission's mandate was extended for three months late last December.

In a prepared statement, the OAU secretariat said the decision to extend the mandate would be reviewed by a summit of the OAU's 16-nation Central Mechanism on Conflict Management, to be held April 15-16 in Addis Ababa.

The extension was made by the conflict management body's meeting at the ambassadorial level at the request of the Burundi government.

The continental body maintains a token observer mission of 40 military and 30 civilian personnel in the central African state, rocked by ethnic violence since October 1993.

The violence, between the majority Hutu population and the minority Tutsi, was sparked by the assassination of President Melchior Ndadaye on Oct. 21, 1993.

He was killed by Tutsi soldiers who constitute the majority in the Burundian army. This led to revenge killings by Hutus against Tutsis.

Burundi has vehemently resisted a proposal by United Nations Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to send in an international force to stop the violence that has led to between 50,000 and 100,000 deaths.

The violence has also forced thousands of Burundians into exile in neighboring countries, especially Zaire.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


110 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Amnesty Intervenes in Zambian Editors Jailing


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 21, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 454 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Amnesty International, the London-based human rights group, has launched a campaign for the release of the two 'Post' newspaper editors jailed by the Zambian parliament for alleged contempt of the house.

A statement from Amnesty in London, quoted by the Post Thursday, said the organization had launched a campaign to alert the international community of the editors' plight.

Amnesty adopted the two, post managing director and editor-in-chief Fred M'membe and managing editor Bright Mwape as "prisoners of conscience." 

Amnesty said it feared the Zambian government would abduct and torture the detainees, given the admission by the government's own commission of enquiry that torture remains a widespread practice by Zambian police.

M'membe and Mwape have been in detention since March 4. Zambian speaker Robinson Nabulyato in February sentenced the two to "indefinite" incarceration for alleged contempt and breach of parliamentary privileges in newspaper articles the Post had published in January.

"Amnesty International is concerned for the safety of M'membe and Mwape...Both are prisoners of conscience being held for the peaceful expression of their criticism of the Zambian government," the organization said in the statement quoted by the Post Thursday.

Post chief legal counsel Sakwiba Sikota last week claimed that state security agents had planned to "abduct" his clients, allegedly for torture.

Zambian police have said that M'membe is being held in the capital, Lusaka, while Mwape is being held in the midlands town of Kabwe.

Sikota has since petitioned the high court for the state to show cause why it should continue to hold the two editors.

Post columnist Lucy Sichone, who was sentenced along with M'membe and Mwape on similar charges, is still at large. Sources within the government said last week in newspaper reports that they believed she had taken refugee in neighboring Zimbabwe.

A human rights commission of enquiry appointed late in 1995 found evidence of police torture both during the previous regime of former President Kenneth Kaunda and that the practice had continued since President Frederick Chiluba's government came to power in 1991.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

March, 1996


Africa-at-Large


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 22, 1996


LENGTH: 574 words


 

COTONOU, Benin - The home of Maurice Ahanhanzo Glele, one of the seven members of Benin's constitutional court, was machine-gunned early Friday morning by unknown assailants, state radio reported.

A gendarme guarding the house, near the home of President Nicephore Soglo, said the vehicle sped toward the house before showing down and raining the house with gunfire.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerian Finance Minister, Anthony Ani inaugurated a seven-member panel Friday to sanitise the country's capital market, which he said was "in a lethargic state and incapable of meeting the needs of the nation." 

The panel is composed mainly of market operators. It will review the market in all its ramifications and codify all laws relating to it.

It is also to examine the activities of key players such as the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Nigerian Stock Exchange, stock brokers and the banks.

COTONOU, Benin - Benin's Audiovisual and Communication High Authority has ordered government-owned media to only publish official results of the second round presidential poll, held March 17.

In a statement read on the local television Thursday, the authority barred the official media from reporting "any news conference or statement related to the election" without its prior approval.

The authority is an independent institution in charge of regulating mass communication in the country.

LUSAKA, Zambia - The International Federation of Association Football, or FIFA, says Zambian soccer star Dennis Lota cannot sign up with a European club until he has been released by a South African side with which he has been committed.

FIFA told the Football Association of Zambia Thursday that Lota risked a ban from playing in Europe if he signed up with a European club while his earlier contract with Witbank Aces of South Africa was valid.

Lota reportedly signed, as yet an unspecified playing contract with Aces of Johannesburg. He travelled recently to Netherlands and Belgium, reportedly in search of a professional soccer playing career.

ACCRA, Ghana - The Accra summit March 27 to discuss Liberia's flagging peace process has been postponed because of Nigeria's local council elections.

Ghana's foreign minister Obed Asamoah told the Ghana News Agency that Nigeria had asked for a postponement. He said a new date for the Economic Community of West African States meeting would be announced later.

The summit was to have been preceded by a two-day of meeeting of the foreign ministers of Cote D'Ivoire, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Mali, Nigeria, Sierra Leone, Senegal and Togo. These are in the ECOWAS committee of nine on Liberia.

112 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large North Africa Threatened by Water Scarcity


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 25, 1996 by Ali Delali, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 400 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya - The World Bank has warned about the threat of water scarcity in Northern Africa and the Middle East.

In a report published last Friday in Maghreb countries on the occasion of the world water day, the bank said 45 million prople or 16 percent of the region's population in the region have no access to adequate quantities of drinking water.

The situation has deteriorated from 1960 when each inhabitant in the region had at least 3,360 cubic metres of water per year. 

Last year, the amount dwindled to 1,250 cubic metres and if the appropriate steps are not taken, this could be reduced by half in the next decade, or 600 cubic metres per year and per person by the year 2,025.

According to the World Bank, the water scarcity partly results from the region's high population growth.

The number of people has, indeed, doubled over the last 30 years and has reached 280 million individuals. It could double in the next 30 years.

But the water is also the result of wasteful use of existing water resources.

For instance, 87 percent of the water in the region is used for irrigation. This leaves only 13 percent for human consumption and industry, compared with 31 percent in the rest of the world.

Due to inadequate water, a resident of Gaza has access to 57 litres of water a day while an American in the same day can use up to 3,040 litres.

The World Bank proposes several remedial measures including a transnational partnership strategy between the countries in the region and national strategies involving the private and public sectors, as well as donors.

The bank said that an investment of 50 billion U.S dollars was required to deal with the region's water scarcity.

This has to be raised by the concerned countries and by donors.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


113 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large World's Freshwater Ecosystems and Fish Species Threathened


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 25, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 787 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Biologically diverse freshwater ecosystems and fish species are threatened or disappearing in "every part of the world," says a report by an American research group.

A report by the Worldwatch environment research organisation said fish species in East Africa's Lake Victoria and other parts of Africa are threatened.

The report published Monday by the U.S state department's 'Washigton Line," quoted its author Janet Abramovitz as saying that 20 percent of the world's 9,000 fish species were now either extinct or in danger of becoming extinct. 

According to the report, 60 percent of Lake Victoria's 350 native fish species were extinct and the remaining 150 species were at risk.

In Africa, fish provide 21 percent of the total animal protein, according to the study.

"Even more alarming is the fact that extinction rates today are about 100 to 1000 times higher than before humans existed. So what we're doing is running a biodiversity deficit -- we're destroying species and ecosystems faster than nature can create new ones," said Abramovitz in her report.

She said that since the beginning of the century about 10 percent of the species had become extinct and the rest were in jeopardy.

"This is a problem of global importance. These unassuming little creatures (fish) are very important. They sit in one spot and they filter and clean vast quantities of water."

She said that the numerous problems had also been caused by overconsumption of water for irrigation purposes.

An estimated 30 out of 47 commercial fish species in the River Nile had become economically or biologically extinct, she said.

Lake Chad, in Africa's Sahel region had shrunk by 75 percent in the last 30 years due to drought and water diversion for agriculture, to the detriment of important inland fisheries and the people reliant on its diverse resources.

Lake Victoria had been cited as suffering from the effects of an introduced species "the Nile perch" which is said to be "conspiring with changing land use, pollution and growing population pressures." The Nile perch has been said by marine scientists to have eaten up most of the local fish species in the lake.

Other pressures on the lake's ecosystem include untreated sewage and industrial waste flowing in from Kisumu, Kenya's third largest city and from Mwanza, Tanzania.

Watershed degradation and agricultural runoff also contributed chemicals, nutrients and sediment in addition to the "grisly addition of 40,000 genocide victims that floated down the Kagera river in May 1994," said the report.

In Lake Victoria, a major cooperative effort among Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda, is in the pipeline to focus on water quality, land use management, control of the exotics (fish species) and water hyacinth and community-based enforcement.

The cooperation by the three East African countries may restore Lake Victoria.

There is also need for preserve the less-degraded Lakes Malawi and Tanganyika, said Abramovits who added that many of today's problems resulted from "short-sighted" and fragmented attempts to improve on nature such as introducing the varacious Nile perch at Lake Victoria.

"Both the concept of sustainability and the nature of ecosystems require that decisions affecting them look not only beyond the next few years but beyond the next decades as well.

"Regional efforts like those around...Lake Victoria that set long-term goals and include all countries are starting to reflect this reality."


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


114 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Senegal Dam Infrastructure Underutilised


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 25, 1996 by Aminata Toure, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 507 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The Commissioner of the Organization for the Development of the Senegal River (OMVS) Baba Ould Andallah says the three member states have so far not exploited their common infrastructure to the maximum.

Abdallah said in an interview that with the Diama Dam, which became operational in 1986, the member states -- Mali, Mauritania and Senegal -- could have attained food self-sufficiency through irrigated agriculture.

He said that in spite of new health problems and changes in the ecosystems for which solutions are being sought or implemented, there was proof that the completed projects were likely to benefit member states a great deal. 

According to the commission, Senegal has exploited less than 50,000 hectares out of the 240,000 hectares that have been made arable since the Diama Dam was constructed.

On the other hand, Mauritania does not exploit more than 25,000 hectares out of the 120,000 hectares available while Mali has never used more than 18,000 hectares made available.

The commissioner conceded that Mali was getting comparatively less benefits from the Diama Dam, which cost 14 million U.S. dollars to construct.

As a result, he said, Mali's financial contribution to the OMVS will be reduced during the organization's next extraordinary ministerial session scheduled for July this year.

Abdallah said from now on charges and costs of joint projects will be distributed equally between the organization's member states.

Meanwhile, Abdallah said a hydro-electric power station will be constructed at the Manantali Dam in Mali before the end of this financial year. It will supply the three countries.

Mali is expected to be the major beneficiary. It will draw 51 percent of the 800 million kilowatts to be generated each year.

He said the hydro-electric power station is expected to cost 400 million US dollars.

Manantali, constructed at a cost of 200 million U.S dollars, is the OMVS's biggest dam since the three-nation organisation was created in 1972.

The OMVS high commissioner said studies were underway to develop all-year navigation on the Senegal River at a cost of 70 million U.S dollars.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large North Africa Threatened By Water Shortage


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 25, 1996 by Ali Dellali, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 400 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya - North African and Middle East countries face serious shortage of potable water, according to a recent World Bank report receive by PANA in Tripoli.

The report said 16 percent of the population of the region or 45 million people do not have access to potable water. 

In 1960, people residing in North Africa and the Middle-East had at least 3,360 cubic metres of water per year. Last year, the figure fell by half to only 1,250. Projections are that this will futher drup to 600 cubic metres by 2025.

The Bank attributes this situation to rising population, saying the number of people living in the region has doubled to 280 million in 30 years, with projections of two times this number by the next generations.

Rising population apart, the bank has also faulted wastage as part of the problem.

For example, 87 percent of the water collected in this region is devoted to irrigation, leaving only 13 percent for industrial and household use, compared to a world average of 31 percent.

This explains why one inhabitant of Gaza in the Middle East has 57 litres of water per day when his American counterpart uses 3,040 litres in 24 hours.

The report suggests series of measures including a transnational partnership strategy involving countries of the region, the public and private sectors as well as donors.

Naturally such common action would depend on mutual understanding between governments.

The Bank projects that some 50 billion dollars would have to be invested on water projects in the next 10 years to improve the situation.

Donor countries and the World Bank could contribute 15 billion dollars of the total amount, it said.

LANGUAGE: English

March, 1996


Africa-at-Large SADC Environment Experts Call For Regional Approach


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 25, 1996


LENGTH: 294 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Environment experts from the Southern African Development Community have called for programmes to alleviate poverty and promote sustainable development in the region.

At the end of their two-day workshop in Harare Friday, the experts issued a statement saying that they recognised the potential for new approaches to promoting development, focusing on such areas as agro-forestry and eco-tourism. 

"As such, they are key mechanisms to address ... poverty alleviation and sustainable development in southern Africa," said the statement.

Among other conclusions, delegates agreed that desertification, land degradation, water problems and drought preparedness were "among the key development challenges facing this region," the statement said.

"Participants recognised the need and potential for participatory approaches to improve the quality of development programming within the region."

The workshop was designed to facilitate discussion on such key issues as desertification and land degradation, agro-forestry and transboundary water issues, and was jointly organised by the Canadian International Development Agency and the Japanese International Co-operation Agency.

The statement said representatives from all SADC member states had participated in the workshop.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Kwacha Continues To Depreciate


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 26, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - The Zambian kwacha has continued to depreciate against major foreign currencies, dropping by as much as 10.6 percent in one month.

Latest statistics released by the Bank of Zambia show the local currency which fell by 7.2 percent on Feb. 23 had shed a further 3.4 percent to K1,064.29 to One U.S. dollar. 

The official exchange rate went down to K1,000.26 for one dollar on March 8, from K995.40 to the greenback on Feb. 8.

The fall of the kwacha in relation to the dollar worsened in Dec. 1995 following what analysts said was due to the demand for hard currency created by the importation of maize.

Demand for the dollar has been in excess of supply because of high demand for maize, vehicles, spare-parts and machinery, they said.

According to the bank, excess demand for the dollar in December 1995 stood at 35,521,100.00.

The local currency market could only supply 6,627,300.00 and 174,700 dollars for January and February respectively, it added.

Depreciation of the local currency is taking a toll on the country's debt obligation, reflected in further government borrowing leading to a rise in domestic debt to some K240.342 billion in February from K203.087 billion the previous month.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Market Trades Six Million Shares


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 26, 1996 by Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 427 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - The Nigerian Stock Exchange (NSE) recorded a total of 6.12 million shares valued at 52.7 million naira (N82=1USD) in 960 deals in all floors of the exchange located in Lagos, Ibadan, Kaduna, Port Harcourt and Onitsha last week.

This represents a slight drop in volume and value terms when compared with 6.3 million naira crossed in 1,051 deals in the preceding week.

As usual, the Lagos floor accounted for the bulk of the transactions during the week with a turnover of 5.3 million shares worth 43.8 million naira in 813 deals as against a turnover of 4.2 million shares worth 37.8 million naira traded in 837 deals two weeks ago. 

Ibadan exchange also recorded a transaction of 0.2 million shares worth 2.9 million naira in 79 deals compared with 0.3 million shares worth 3.1 million crossed in 66 deals in the upper week, representing a slight decline in volume and value.

In Port Harcourt, 0.1 million shares valued at 1.7 million naira were exchanged in 33 deals while Kaduna recorded 0.3 million shares with market capitalization of 4 million naira in 25 deals. Investors traded 0.02 million shares worth 0.3 million naira shares in 10 deals on the Onitsha floor.

However, a sectoral analysis of trading activities on the Lagos floor in volume terms, showed the banking sub-sector as the most active with 2.5 shares worth 12.5 million naira crossed in 100 deals, followed by the packaging sub-sector which recorded 0.6 million shares of 3.1 million naira in 24 deals.

The banking sub-sector had led in the preceding week with 1.5 million shares valued at 7.1 million naira traded in 102 deals trailed by the conglomerates sub-sector which traded 0.5 million shares worth 8.0 million naira in 141 deals.

The NSE all-shares index gained a total of 29.07 points to close on Friday at 5258.55, compared to 48.95 points by which the index grew the previous week. Overall mood of the market had remained optimistic despite losses ranging between one kobo and 22 kobo last week.

119 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Oil Price Up


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 26, 1996 by Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 534 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's high quality Bonny Light crude again appreciated in price last weekend, over its United Kingdom counterpart, the Brent, at 21.25 dollars per barrel as against 20.30 dollars per barrel for the British brand.

The Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC), quoting the London spot market, said the latest rise represents a modest increase of 90 cents over the 20.35 us dollars price for the preceding week which also outpaced the Brent by 1.25 dollars.

Forcados, another high quality crude in the country, also gained in price closing at the same 21.25 dollars per barrel, or an increase of 2.02 dollars a barrel over its price for the preceding week. 

With the latest upward movement, the third in three consecutive weeks, Nigeria could exceed its projected 19 billion naira (232 dollars) surplus for the current fiscal year.

Fears of an oil glut were expressed a fortnight ago by the re-opening of negotiations between Iraq and the United Nations over the Iraq's re-entry into the market, and the over supply of the product at the North Sea.

But the Nigerian star crude, according to analysts, is expected to continue its upward trend, due mainly to the growing interest in the nation's oil.

India and Taiwan, a fortnight ago, joined the increasing list of buyers when they purchased a total of six cargoes of both the Forcados and the Qua Iboe to be delivered to them next month.

Nigeria's 1996 budget predicated an oil earnings of 16 dollars per barrel and a target of total oil revenue of 214 billion naira. With the weekend's price level at 21.25 dollars, the nation would have raked an extra 5.25 dollars on each barrel sold per day vis-a-vis the budget estimates.

This means the government, which sells an estimated 913,000 out of its share of 1.163 million barrels per day gains additional 4.65 million dollars every day crude is sold at 21.25 dollars per barrel.

The price of Bonny Light has been on the upward movement since the release of the 1996 budget on Feb. 15. It recorded a drop from 19.65 dollars immediately after the budget to 17.90 dollars two weeks later - a price which remains the closest to the 16 dollars budget estimates.

Oil market analysts last week predicted the continued rise in price of crude.

They attributed the favorable performance to both the growing interest in the brand among international buyers and the prolonged cold weather in most Western countries.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


120 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Cameroon Coloring Kerosene Green to Curb Abuses


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 26, 1996


LENGTH: 307 words


 

YAOUNDE, Cameroon - The colour of kerosene sold in the Central African state of Cameroon will from Tuesday appear greenish in colour, a blend which is expected to stem the growing incidence of adulteration of the product which have led to many accidents sometimes resulting in deaths.

In a statement released in Yaounde on Monday, Minister of Mines Water Resources and Energy Bello Mbelle said the measure was being taken to check fraud in the marketing of petroleum products. 

A substantial number of the country's 13 million people, especially city dwellers, use usually colorless kerosene, both for cooking and lighting.

But use of adulterated kerosene in stoves and lamps have often led to explosions and fire incidents sometimes with fatalities.

Sometimes kerosene, which is cheaper, is mixed with other fuels and oils and sold off as either diesel or regular petrol.

Various government initiatives to check the fraud have tended to fail because the fraudsters always sought efficient ways of deceiving customers, the minister said.

"But With the green color, consumers will henceforth easily detect the presence of kerosene in any fuel destined for use in engines, thanks to the green color which will tend to dominate when mixed with any other fuel," he added.

The statement said all studies had been carried out in the laboratory to ensure that the coloring agent used is good for public consumption.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


121 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Ethiopia Air Services Agreement Signed with Japan


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 26, 1996 by Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 400 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Ethiopian Airlines is to begin scheduled flights to Tokyo, Japan, in early 1997, under an agreement signed by the two countries here Monday.

The air services agreement states that "any Japanese airline" was also authorized to begin similar operations to Ethiopia. 

Ethiopian officials said in Addis Ababa the accord gives their national carrier access "to one of the most lucrative destinations in air travel industry."

The agreement was signed by the Director-General of the Ethiopian Civil Aviation Authority, Meshesha Belayneh and Japan's ambassador to Ethiopia Yasuhiro Hamada.

The Japanese envoy said the accord was significant to Ethiopia and Japan as well as to the African and Asian continent.

"The signing of this agreement not only augments the future development of Ethiopian Airlines' business, but also proves advantageous to many other related industries and sectors in the African continent," Hamada said.

On his part, Belayneh said the agreement was important for the flexible and competitive operations of the airlines in the fast expanding aviation industry.

An Ethiopian Airlines official said the new route to Japan will bring the state-owned company face-to-face with the highly competitive airlines of Far Eastern countries.

Tokyo will raise Ethiopian Airlines' international destinations to 44. Half of these are in Africa.

The airline started its operations on April 21, 1946, with weekly flights to Cairo in Africa and Aden in Yemen. Its only plane was a converted World War II DC-3 aircraft.

Currently it operates a fleet of 34 aircraft including Boeing 767, 575 and 737 passenger planes and Boeing 707 and l-100 cargo planes.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


122 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large NGOs Call For Free Judiciaries


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 26, 1996 by Mfumu Kibaniakina, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 227 words


 

OUAGADOU, Burkina Faso - African human rights non-governmental organizations (NGOs) have condemned human rights abuses in Burundi and Nigeria and urged an end to double standards in Zaire's judicial system.

Ending their 10th meeting in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, Monday the NGOs passed resolutions urging the governments to respect and ensure the judiciary's independence through the use of "democratic methods" in appointing judges. 

They said the African judiciary should respect the African Charter on Human and Peoples Rights and other ninternational conventions in their handling of cases.

They also urged African judges to make sure that the constitutional rights of African NGOs are respected.

The meeting, attended by 20 African countries, was organized by the Geneva-based International Commission of Jurists to prepare the NGO's participation in the 19th session of the African Human and Peoples Rights Commission.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


123 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Liberia U.N. Food Agency Starts Emergency Airlift


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 26, 1996


LENGTH: 334 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The World Food Programme (WFP) has begun airlifting emergency food supplies to some 22,000 women, children and aged people trapped by fighting in camps in western Liberia.

Almost 100,000 refugees and displaced persons have been trapped without food in Cap Mount county on Liberia's border with Sierra Leone. Fighting led to closure of the highway to the area in mid-December 1995.

WFP officials in Monrovia said they began the airlift Monday after getting reports that at least five people a day were dying of malnutrition in Cap Mount county.

A WFP news release faxed to PANA quoted Liberia's WFP's country director Tarek el Guindi as saying "these people have been trapped since December. There's no food there at all and the conditions in the shelter camps are wretched."

The WFP plans to airlift 60 metric tons of assorted foods for the 22,000 people thought most at risk in the sprawling refugee centers in western Liberia.

It said the food will be airlifted using two helicopters donated by the United States to the West African Peace monitoring Force (Ecomog) in Liberia. The operation is expected to take about four days.

WFP's last food convoy to Cap Mount county was on Dec. 14, 1995, before fighting led to the closure of the route.

WFP officials say they can feed only those most at risk of starvation until the highway is reopened to allow for greater amounts of food to be delivered.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


124 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Sudan and Ethiopia Sudan Claims Ethiopian Attack


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 26, 1996


LENGTH: 387 words


 

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Sudan's army claimed Tuesday Ethiopian mechanized units had launched a series of attacks on its positions along their common border.

It said in a statement the attacks were on Sudan's Blue Nile and Upper Nile states. 

The Sudanese army said the Ethiopian army had used heavy guns and tanks to launch the attacks from inside Ethiopia.

The Sudanese army units had to withdraw from Yabus and Pochalla after the areas had come under heavy Ethiopian attack.

It said, however, that the Ethiopian army had after the attacks occupied the two areas before handing them over to the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA).

Relations between the two neighboring states soared after Egypt and Ethiopia accused the Sudanese government of complicity in a botched assassination attempt on Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak as he arrived in Addis Ababa for an OAU summit last June.

The two accused Sudan of harboring the would-be assassins. Sudan has denied the accusations.

Ethiopia took the issue to the United Nations Security Council which passed Resolution 1044 calling on Sudan to cooperate in tracking down and extraditing the suspects to Ethiopia.

Meanwhile, the SPLA Monday announced it had overrun the town of Pachalla in the Upper Nile State and that its troops were on their way to another town, Pibor, in the same state.

The SPLA, led by a former army colonel from southern Sudan, Col. John Garang de Mabior, has fought Khartoum since 1983.

It until 1989 controlled almost 80 percent of rural southern Sudan.

It was however weakened by several major offensives.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


125 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia UN Commission Probes Jailing Of Zambian Editors


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 26, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 507 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - The United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva was scheduled Tuesday and Wednesday to hear the case of the two 'Post' newspaper editors jailed by the Zambian parliament for contempt.

The Inter-African Network for Human Rights and Development (AFRONET) Executive Director Ngande Mwanajiti told PANA in Lusaka Tuesday that the commission is expected to make a ruling Wednesday.

"I can confirm that UNHRC will sit today and tomorrow to look at the post editors' case. The document on the matter was embargoed unitl yesterday (Monday)," Mwanajiti said. 

He said apart from the editors' case, the commission would also hear Zambia's human rights abuses under the international covenant on civil and political rights.

Post newspaper Managing Director and Editor-In-Chief Fred Mmembe and Managing Editor Bright Mwape have been in detention since last March.

They were sentenced to an "indefinite" prison term last February by Speaker of Parliament Robinson Nabulyato for alleged contempt and breach of parliamentary privileges in articles printed by the paper last January.

Columnist Lucy Sichone who was sentenced along with Mmembe and Mwape on similar charges is still at large.

Sichone who is believed to have taken refugee in neighboring Zimbabwe has continued writing her column which appears every Monday.

The Zambia chapter of the Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA) has written to members of the Commission to highlight what it calls "the dramatic deterioration in media freedom and free expression in Zambia".

The London-based Amnesty International has also launched a campaign for the release of the two editors.

The organization which has alerted the international community about the editors' plight has also adopted the two editors as "prisoners of conscience."

The newspaper's chief legal counsel Sakwiba Sikota has petitioned the high court for the state to show cause why it should continue to hold the two editors. The court is also expected Wednesday to deliver judgement on the matter.

A commission of enquiry appointed by President Frederick Chiluba late in 1995 said evidence of police torture during the previous government of President Kenneth Kaunda continued after Chiluba's government came to power in 1991.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Nigeria Allays Fears Of Mad Cow Disease


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 27, 1996 by Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 267 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's health authorities Wednesday allayed fears of a possible spread of the "mad cow disease" that has affected cattle in Britain.

They however called for vigilance in tracking down imported beef and beef products. 

A statement by the National Agency for Food and Drug Administration and Control (NAFDAC) said there was little risk of the mad cow disease spreading to Nigeria because the importation of meat and meat products have been banned since 1989.

Recent scientific findings linked the disease to a brain disorder in humans called Creutzfeld Jacd disease. The scientific name for the mad cow disease is Bovine Spongioform Encephalopathy, prevalent among British cattle

NAFDAC said in the release that "decree 36 of 1989 which places the importation of meat and meat products into Nigeria on absolute prohibition is still very much in force."

NAFDAC inspectors, it said, had been doing everything possible to ensure that the decree was not violated.

But it at the same time, it urged the public to cooperate in reporting any cases of suspected importation of meat and meat products.

Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Investors Discuss ECOWAS Airline


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 27, 1996 by Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 294 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Officials and investors began talks Wednesday on the distribution of equity shares for the proposed regional carrier, ECOWAS airline, the organization's secretariat said.

ECOWAS is the Economic Community of West African States whose headquarters is in the Nigerian capital, Abuja. Some of its members are already shareholders in Air Afrique, the multinational airline of some French-speaking states in West and Central Africa.

The high-level meeting is being attended by officials from the West African Chamber of Commerce and the African Business Roundtable. Both organizations represent business interests in the region. Representatives of foreign banks, aircraft manufacturers, insurance companies and tourist firms are also at the meeting.

The proposed airline would begin operation later in 1996 with an initial capital of 20 million U.S. dollars. The airline's network would cover most of Africa and would fly to North American and European countries.

ECOWAS officials said the groundwork for launching the airline had been completed, the remaining hurdle being the formal endorsement of the project by the council of ministers and heads of state of the 16-nation economic community.

The meeting of the council and the summit of West African leaders are scheduled for May and June respectively.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Locusts Threaten Southern Africa


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 27, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - The International Red Locust Control Organisation of Central and Southern Africa (IRLCO) has alerted member-states to take preventive measures against the spread of red locusts which have already invaded seven countries, including Botswana, Namibia and South Africa.

Zambia's Deputy Agriculture Minister Dickson Matutu told journalists in Lusaka Tuesday that the IRLCO had early this month advised his government to take precautionary measures following the outbreak. 

Other countries reported to be affected by the invasion include Malawi, Mozambique and Tanzania.

The director of IRLCO, John Bahana, said that Zambia faced a real threat of an invasion, particularly from neighboring Tanzania. IRLCO is based in Ndola, northern Zambia, John Bahana,

Bahana attributed the pest's resurgence to the prolonged drought which provided ideal breeding conditions for the insect.

Zambia's bumper maize harvest this season is already threatened by the large grain-borer believed to have been brought into the country through famine relief maize from Tanzania.

Maize is the Zambian staple.

The large grain-borer normally attacks dried maize cobs and cassava tubers.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

129 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Ethiopia and Sudan Ethiopia Denies Attacking Sudanese Towns


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 27, 1996 by Ghion Hagos, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 400 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - The Ethiopian government has firmly denied Sudanese accusations of helping rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) capture two coastal towns in southern Sudan early this week.

A statement issued Tuesday night by the Ethiopian foreign ministry described the allegation made by Khartoum earlier in the day as "baseless." 

The Sudanese Army's General Command had accused Ethiopia of a series of attacks against Sudanese positions across the border using mechanised units, heavy guns and tanks.

The attacks, the Sudanese said, had forced their army units to withdraw from the towns of Yabus and Pochalla.

They said the Ethiopian army had after the attacks, launched from within its own territory, occupied the two areas before handing them over to the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA).

But the Ethiopian foreign office said the Sudanese allegations were merely "a means of covering up its internal problem."

"Ethiopia does not and will not interfere in domestic affairs of neighboring countries," the statement said.

The SPLA announced Monday it had overrun the town of Pachalla in Sudan's Upper Nile State and that its troops were on their way to another town, Pibor, in the same state.

Relations between Ethiopia and Sudan were severely strained following last June's failed assassination of the Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak after he landed in Addis Ababa for an OAU summit.

Sudan denies Egyptian and Ethiopian charges of involvement in the abortive attack and of also harboring three of the would-be assassins.

Ethiopia in September sought the help of the Organization of African Unity, and in December that of the United Nations Security Council to have the three extradited. They are believed to be Egyptian Muslim fundamentalists.

Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria U.N. Fact-Finding Mission Arrives


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 27, 1996 by Randy Zormelo, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 307 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - A United Nations fact-finding mission arrives in Nigeria Thursday to investigate the circumstances surrounding the execution of nine minority rights activists including writer Ken Saro-Wiwa, official sources announced in Lagos Wednesday.

Members of the mission are also expected to hold discussions with the military authorities on possible international assistance for the restoration of democracy in Nigeria. 

U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutro-Ghali decided to send the mission to the West African country at the request of the Nigerian government and also in line with a resolution of the General Assembly adopted on Dec. 12.

The resolution condemned the "arbitrary execution" in November the same year of the 'Ogoni Nine' and called on the secretary general to hold discussions with the Nigerian government on the democratic process in the country.

Among members of the mission is a Togolese jurist, Atsu Koffi Amega.

Other members are Justice V.S. Malimath, member of the National Human Rights Commission of India; John Pace, chief of the Legislation and Prevention of Discrimination Division of the Centre for Human Rights in Geneva; and Amer Araim, a representative of the secretary general.

The team is expected to meet top government officials, key bodies involved in the political transition process and non-governmental organizations.

131 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia High Court Releases Post Editors


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 27, 1996 by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Lusaka, Zambia -- Zambian High Court Wednesday ordered the release of two newspaper editors imprisoned by the country's parliament for contempt of the house.

Editors Fred M'membe and Bright Mwape of The Post, a daily newspaper published in Lusaka, were last February sentenced to "indefinite imprisonment" for publishing material infringing parliamentary privileges.

High Court Judge Kabazo Chanda in his ruling however ordered M'membe to appear before parliament on one count of contempt of the house in an article published last January. He is alleged to have insulted a member of parliament. 

Justice Chanda said he had found Mwape without a case to answer.

He was hearing the editors' appeal in which they had sought for the state to show cause why they were being detained.

M'membe and Mwape have been in detention since March 4 following their sentencing by house Speaker Robinson Nabulyato who said he found them quilty of contempt and gross breach of parliamentary privilege.

In his ruling, Justice Chanda said that the "indefinite" remand of the editors by parliament was "incompatible" with Zambian law.

He said the Zambian parliament was not a court in "any sense at all" but the supreme legislative organ in the land with powers to make, amend, repeal or re-make any laws.

"It is my legal duty to interfere with unorthodox disciplinary procedures like this one. I therefore order their (editors) release from prison forthwith," said Justice Chanda.

He described as an aberration of "natural justice," the house's conviction and sentencing of the accused in their absentia.

"The person charged with contempt has to appear before the bar. Failure by him to appear at the required time and date is no reason for dispensing with this legal procedure and rule of natural justice," Chanda ruled.

He said that his court has powers over major parliamentary actions, especially those that affected persons from outside the house.

He noted, however, that although the Zambian parliament was not a court as such, it retained powers to punish for contempt and imprison under common law.

He cited the use of abusive language in a statement, speech or writing as some of the actions that could amount to contempt of parliament.

Columnist Lucy Sichone, who was sentenced along with M'membe and Mwape on similar charges and is still at large, was also ordered by the High Court to surrender herself to parliament for contempt. She was said by the court to have used "scornful language" in her newspaper article last February.

The three were arraigned by parliament following a complaint by leader of the house Vice-President Bri.Gen. Godfrey Miyanda in January over articles they wrote which he said brought the house into ridicule.

The articles by M'membe and Sichone commented on Miyanda's criticism of the Supreme Court ruling to quash the public order act which required that people obtain police permits for any public gatherings.

Justice Chanda noted that M'membe's article said Deputy Minister "Ernest Mwansa's underwear is an imitation" and "Ernest Mwansa must shut up". He said this had established a prima facie case of contempt of parliament.

Sichone was alleged to have referred to the speaker of parliament as " a grandmother in whose skirts the vice-president sought refugee," and further called the vice-president a hypocrite and a coward.

"I have looked at Mwape's whole article and I find nothing insulting in it.

"I am a Zambian, and by my society, the use of odious and rude phrases against elders in society in contemptuous," Chanda said.

Chanda said he could not have "interfered" in the detention had a a specified period been fixed for the editors to be held before appearing before a judiciary.

The United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva was Wednesday also expected to make a ruling on the case referred to it by the Zambian chapter of the Media Institute of Southern Africa (Misa).

The London-based human rights organization Amnesty International said recently that it was launching an international campaign to have the editors, whom it adopted as prisoners of conscience, freed.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


132 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Nigeria Allays Fears Of 'Mad Cow Disease'


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 27, 1996 by Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 520 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's health authorities Wednesday allayed fears of the possible spread of the "mad cow disease", or BSE, that has reportedly affected cattle in Britain.

They however called for vigilance in tracking down imported beef and beef products. The importation of these products into the European Union was officially banned Wednesday. 

A statement by the National Agency for Food and Drug Administration and Control (NAFDAC) said there was little risk of the BSE or 'mad cow disease' spreading to Nigeria because the importation of meat and meat products have been banned since 1989.

Recent scientific findings linked the disease, known as 'Bovine Spongioform Encephalopathy', prevalent among British cattle to a brain disorder in humans called 'creutzfeld jaco disease (CJD).

The drug and food agency said in the release that "decree 36 of 1989 which places the importation of meat and meat products into Nigeria on absolute prohibition is still very much in force."

NAFDAC inspectors, it said, had been doing everything possible to ensure that the decree was not violated.

But it at the same time urged the public to cooperate in reporting any cases of suspected importation of meat and meat products to NAFDAC offices across the nation.

The current BSE scare in Europe prompted the agency's officials to hold a meeting in Lagos Tuesday.

The organisation is working towards obtaining official approval for a fresh drive to enforce the ban on meat and meat product importation, especially from Britain.

European Union countries have already slammed a ban on the importation of British beef.

British health officials and scientists rushed to Brussels, headquaters of the union, tuesday to ask its members to reconsider the ban but failed.

BSE, discovered 10 years, ago is believed to have been contracted by cattle from feed laced with the brains of sheep infected with a similar disease known as 'scrapie'.

Initially, it was thought scrapie could not affect other animal species and was harmless to humans.

But it has now been proven that BSE also affected domestic cats, zoo animals and humans who fed on British beef.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Funds Raised To Combat Meningitis


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 27, 1996 by Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 360 words


 

NEW YORK, United States - Nigerians around the world, communicating through the international Electronic Mail system or Internet, have launched a fund drive to help combat the meningitis epidemic currently wreaking havoc in some parts of the country.

They have so far pledged about 3,000 dollars to the Nigerian Meningitis Assistance Fund, which was established some weeks ago through the Nigerian Information Network, 'Naijanet'. 

'The Predominantly Nigerian subscribers to Naijanet were initially using the network as a forum for discussing the political situation in Nigeria but have now found a common cause in contributing to the meningitis fund.

The idea of the fund was mooted by Kasirim Nwuke, a Naijanet suscriber based in the United States.

Since then, the names of those wishing to contribute to the fund and the amount to be contributed have been regularly sent to the forum.

A bank account has been opened in Boston for the fund to which some 60 subscribers and non-subscribers have so far contributed amounts ranging from 10 to 100 dollars.

One of the contributors, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he was particularly impressed by the "atmosphere of trust and commitment" surrounding the whole exercise.

"For people to send their money to those they have never met, just to support this cause, gives me a feeling that there is still hope for our country," he added.

Thousands of people have died following the outbreak of the spinal desease mainly in the northern parts of Nigeria early this year.

LANGUAGE: English
