134 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Major Vaccination In Africa Starts June


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 27, 1996


LENGTH: 614 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - A major anti-poliomyelitis immunization programme covering 50 million African children starts in June, Rotary International said.

The organisation, a non-governmental body which funds such operations, said the effort will seek "to eradicate polio from Africa." The programme will be repeated in 1997 and 1988. 

In addition, the programme will help to strengthen primary health delivery in the 25-target countries.

They will receive technical, financial and volunteer support from the World Health Organisation, Rotary International, the United Nations Chuldren's Fund, the Centre for Disease Control of the United States and that country's Agency for International Development, USAID.

The countries involved will organise national immunization days during which two doses of oral polio vaccine must be administered to all children under the age of five years, four to six weeks apart.

The vaccination campaigns are expected to cost at least 33 million U.S. dollars. Rotary will contributed 8.5 million dollars, the Centre for Disease Control seven million dollars. South Africa, one of the 25 countries African countries in the project, will fund its own programme with 2.84 million dollars.

The Director of Disease Control and Prevention at the World Health Organisation Africa Office, Dr. Deogratias Barakamfitiye, said that "the wild polio virus continues to cripple children in at least half the 54 African countries. He cited the 1995 outbreak of polio in Zaire with at least 500 reported cases.

He was briefing members of Rotary's sub-Saharan PoliPlus Committee meeting March 20 in Johannesburg.

He said the challenge of mobilising resources in the 25 countries will be met by the continued determination of all the partners at country, regional and international level "despite competing priorities resulting from other epidemics and civil unrest in a number of countries.

Rotary's PolioPlus Committee said members in Africa should "to make themeslves available and contribute to the successful implementation of the programme to help reach a polio-free world by the year 2000."

Rotary will vaccinate 5.9 million people in Tanzania, 5.1 million in Kenya, 5.04 million in Mozambique and 4.46 million in Uganda.

Another 3.35 million children in Cote D'Ivoire will be vaccinated, 3.34 million in Ghana, 2.7 million in Angola, 2.3 million in Burkina Faso, 2.2 million in Zimbabwe and 2.04 million in Malawi.

Cameroon will have 1.96 million children vaccinated, Benin 1.24 million, Chad 1.21 million, Togo 867,000, Congo 568,370, Central African Republic 555,289, Namibia 303,000 and Lesotho 276,252.

Other countries in the programme will be Gabon 275,000, Botswana 227,116, Swaziland 177,094 and Equatorial Guinea 73,850. The figure for South Africa was unspecified.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


135 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Medic Says Tight Men's Pants Cause Sterility


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 27, 1996 by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 440 words


 

LAGOS, Nigeria - Sterility in men is a controversial issue worldwide as they erroneously tend to believe it is a one side affair.

But now, a Nigerian medical doctor has added a new dimension to the controversy, linking the medical condition to tight pants.

Speaking at a seminar organised by a Catholic church in Lagos Saturday, Dr. Okokon Ekandem claimed that such pants increased the temperature of sperm producing testes by pushing them close to the stomach, thereby reducing their capability to produce spermatozoa. 

Spermatozoa is the medical term for the male reproductive fluid. Medical experts trace a man's inability to impregnate a woman to low sperm count among other medical conditions.

In his the paper entitled "health related problems in marriage," Ekandem explained that testes develop at the back of the abdomen of the male child during pregnancy but grow outside its stomach after delivery, due to their sensitivity to heat.

"For semen to be very effective, there should be about 20 million spermatozoa per millimetre," the doctor said, adding that excessive heat reduces the number of sperms per millimetre of semen.

He said infertility had been one of the biggest problems affecting marriages, especially in developing countries.

But Ekandem said with adequate care, the problem could be controlled.

According to him, "infertility is like being bereaved of the child you never had."

On the issue of blood geno-type tests before marriages, he said science and medicine had taken care of old beliefs that once someone had the "SS" chromosones, or blood type, death would be imminent.

Although he conceded that such tests were necessary for each party to be aware of what could happen to their offspring, Ekanem said love still had a great role to play in the sustenance pof happy marriages.

"Love is a critical factor in marriages and the decision over matters relating to genotype cannot be taken by a medical expert on behalf of couples," he added.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zimbabwe More Alcohol Being Consumed


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 27, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe's health and child welfare secretary Rufaro Chatora on Monday expressed concern at the increase and excessive consumption of alcohol and other psycho-active substances in the southern African nation.

Chatora told participants to a meeting on psycho-active substance use and community involvement in health that the excessive consumption of such substances had resulted in numerous health and socio-economic problems. 

He said although the problem used to be confined to men, it was rapidly spreading among women and children who had previously been spared.

Chatora said to make matters worse, the more dangeyous drugs such as mandrax, cocaine and heroin, which are not produced in Zimbabwe, were now freely available in the country and were being abused by a growing number of people.

He said because of this increase, his ministry anticipated an escalation in the number of people seeking or requiring treatment for alcohol and drug related problems in the very near future.

The secretary said as a result there was need to explore alternative methods of treatment particularly simpler and cheaper methods that can be applied to the remote parts of the country.

The meeting was convened to discuss and work out strategies for dealing with substance abuse in primary health care settings and in the community.

March, 1996


Ethiopia Ethiopia Has 1.7 Million Seropositive People


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 27, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - An estimated 1.7 million people in Ethiopia have already been infected with the human immunedeficiency virus (HIV) that causes the incurable AIDS disease.

According to the head of the epidemiology and AIDS department in the Ethiopian health ministry, Dr. Hailu Negassa, 120,000 of those infected were children. infected

In a report issued in Addis Ababa at a workshop on sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), Dr Negassa said 1.5 percent of the rular population and 12 percent of the urban population have been infected with the virus which causes AIDS. 

According to these figures, Addis Ababa has the largest number of HIV infections.

Ethiopia's population stood at more than 51 million before Eritrea pulled out to become a separate state in April 1993.

An official from Region 14 health bureau in Addis Ababa, Dr, Eyob Tsegaye stressed the need for coordinated efforts by governmental and non governmental organizations to promote the dissemination and exchange of information on AIDS.

The two-day workshop was organised by St. Marry Counselling and Social Service Centre of the Catholic church.

138 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Liberia Monrovia's Rising Tuberculosis Cases


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 27, 1996 by Terence Sessay PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 467 words


 

MONROVIA, Liberia - Liberia's health ministry disclosed in Monrovia that four out of every 1000 persons in the capital are active carriers of tuberculosis.

In a press issued here Tuesday, the ministry said the 1995 statistics for TB cases in Monrovia alone showed 1,408 new cases in addition to the 1,376 recorded cases per year.

"The 1996 records could be worse, considering the increase in the number of deaths related to TB in 1995 to 60, representing five deaths per month," the ministry said. 

The ministry said between January and February 1996, 13 persons died of T.B in Monrovia, and that there are indications that tuberculosis-related deaths are progressively increasing, sometimes at the rate of three deaths per day.

Hospital sources said many of the TB patients were from rural Liberia where the number of cases could be higher than suspected.

The ministry attributed the unprecedented increase in TB to the six-year running conflict which it noted, has seriously disrupted farming activities, resulting in a decline in the nutritional status of most persons.

The release said the high incidence of TB is also a result of overcrowding.

Citing the case of monrovia whose population has swelled from 400,000 prior to the war to over one million at present, the ministry said the entire Liberian population has been displaced with large numbers of persons presently residing in congested centers.

It said this high population density in areas considered safe from harrassment and intimidation by fighters of the numerous warring facstions, has led to the rapid spread of the disease.

TB has also been bouyed by the rapid spread of the Human Immuno Defiency Virus (HIV) and AIDS which weakens the human body's resistance to disease in general.

The release noted that the rate at which TB is spreading demands that urgent measures be taken so that the disease does not get out of hand.

The World Health Organization says TB kills at least 600,000 Africans annualy out of the three million people it kills each year worldwide.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

March, 1996


Togo Beef Imports Banned From Europe


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 28, 1996


LENGTH: 147 words


 
LOME, Togo - The Togolese government Wednesday banned "until further notice, the importation of beef and beef products from Europe." 

A statement issued at the end of a cabinet meeting said "imports of beef and beef products from Africa, America and Asia, will be subjected to prior control by relevant services."

The decision was apparently taken as a precaution against imports of British beef. Part of the British herd has been hit by mad cow disease.

It is still unclear whether the disease can be transmitted to human beings. Most European nations have, however, imposed a temporary ban on the importation of British beef.

140 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Benin Beef Imports Banned


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 28, 1996


LENGTH: 240 words


 
COTONOU, Benin - The Benin government has slapped a ban on beef imports into the country as a way of protecting local comsumers against the mad cow disease now prevalent in the United Kingdom.

The minister of trade and tourism, Aguemon Sikirath, who announced the ban Wednesday, said on national television that Benin does not have the means of monitoring the country of origin and quality of beef imported into the country. 

"One may import beef from Britain and put the label of another country on the product, and we cannot verify this", she explained in reference to the ban.

Violation of the law could attract between one and five years imprisonment or a fine of 1,000-2,000 U.S. dollars.

Benin imports some 6,000 cattle a year, according to the country's national television,.

Many countries have banned beef imports from Britain following the discovery that consumption of infected beef could cause a fatal brain disease against humans.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


141 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Uganda Museveni Wants Strong Army


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 28, 1996 by Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent


LENGTH: 587 words


 

KAMPALA, Uganda, - President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda has said he intends to build a strong army in the East African country, if elected President in May.

"I am totally opposed to the idea of a weak army. My policy is to maintain a strong army because this world is still turbulent. The day of being in the bosom of our father Abraham has not come" Museveni said in Kampala Wednesday. 

He was speaking at the launch of his election campaign manifesto, shortly after being nominated a candidate for presidential polls scheduled in May this year.

Museveni said if he is elected president, he would foster regional cooperation including political federation where possible.

He said he had prepared a document on East African cooperation which advocates a common market and army. He criticized interference of Western powers in Uganda's internal politics.

"Some of our friends in the West are entitled to advise anyone without ideas. We have our own ideas. Intereference in our politics frustrates the enthusiasm of the masses and it is not good for democracy. Democracy will be secure if we understand it in our own way" he said.

The 47-page manifesto stresses building of factories, creation of service industries and modernization of agriculture.

It also calls for the provision of universal education, building of modern infrastructure and reinforcing defence and security.

He promised that if elected, he will ensure that four children in each family as well as all orphans get free education.

Meanwhile, tens of thousands of supporters of the two presidential candidates -- Museveni and Paul Ssemwogerere -- paralysed business in Kampala on Wednesday.

The two were nominated candidates for the first direct presidential elections scheduled for May at the independence grounds, Kololo, in the Ugandan capital.

Museveni is seeking to retain the presidency after 10 years in power but this time as an elected leader.

His supporters converged on Kololo very early in the morning in buses, taxis, lorries, pick-ups and saloon cars bearing his portraits.

The situation became more hectic and confused in the afternoon as Ssemwogerere's supporters who came in a long convoy waving tree branches, moved across the city centre to Kololo.

The crowd, at both nominations were estimated to be between 30,000 to 40,000 people.

Little known Mohammed Mayanja Kibirege, a university teacher and a late comer in the race, is expacted to join the two political giants after he is nominated on Thursday.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


142 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Burundi Red Alert On Conflict


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 28, 1996 by Felix Njoku PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 814 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The situation in the Central African state of Burundi remains tense but the United States is teaming up with European and African friends to pre-empt another bloodbath in the country, Brian Atwood, the administrator of the U.S. Agency for International Development has said.

"Our feeling is that the situation in Burundi is very fragile but there is a possibility of a settlement at least for now," he said.

Atwood spoke Thursday to the Pan African News Agency in Dakar, Senegal, while on the first leg of an African tour.

He said the U.S., in partnership with the European Union and the Oganization of African Unity, should be able to bring all Burundi's parties to a conference, including extremists of the two major ethnic groups fanning the embers of hate in the country. 

USAID and the European Commission announced March 22 a joint mission to Burundi and Rwanda for April to tackle the disastrous humanitarian situation in the two war-torn countries.

Atwood said the mission, which he and Emma Bonino of the Commission will undertake April 2-3 would assess the situation of repatriation and rehabilitation of refugees, reconstruction, reconciliation and empowerment of the civil society.

Meanwhile, daily clashes between the Hutu majority and Tutsi minority, have continued in Burundi since October 1993 when the country's first elected president, Melchior Ndadaye, a Hutu, was killed in a failed coup mounted by the army dominated by the Tutsi ethnic group.

Up to 100,000 Tutsi and moderate Hutu were killed in the mayhem that ensued.

Atwood fears ongoing "creeping genocide" could escallate to mass killings similar to events in neighboring Rwanda where some one million people, mainly Tutsi, were massacred by Hutu extremists in 1994.

He said the joint mission will try to quicken preparations for the trial of the genocide suspects by an internatonal tribunal.

The mission will also work out modalities for a lasting political settlement while the economy, presently dominated by one group, will have to open up to the population and the outside world to bring in an element of stability.

The return of thousands of refugees will also be encouraged. So far, some 40,000 of an estimated two million refugess in neighboring countries have returned.

Atwood said the mission will learn from the scathing criticism levelled againt the international community in the way it handled the situation in Rwanda.

He was referring to the division between the United States and European countries, especially France and Belgium, on how to resolve the conflict in the two former Belgian colonies which have the same ethnic configuration.

While France and Belgium seemed to be supporting the majority Hutu, Washington was acccused of using "African fronts" to support the powerful minority Tutsi group which took over power in Rwanda in 1994.

But Atwood said: "A rough stablilization may be occuring in the army as the Tutsi are beginning to realize that they cannot cope with the increasing inflitration of Hutu extremists from neighboring countries."

The Hutu account for some 85 percent of the six million Burundians. The Tutsi make up about 15 percent while the third group, the Twa, account for 1 percent. In Rwanda, Hutus make up 90 percent as against 9 percent and 1 percent for the Tutsi and the Twa.

The French, he said, have a history which have caused friction in their relations with the countries "but our position is to work effectively with the French in order to avoid the type of crisis we had in Rwanda," he said.

The seeming rapprochement between the United States and Europe on this and other problems in Africa, is part of the New Trans-Atlantic Plan aimed at strengthening cooperation between the two sides who are the two major donors in Africa.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


143 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large USAID Stops Aid To Cameroon, Togo


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 28, 1996 by Felix Njoku, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 600 words


 

DAKAR, Senegal - The United States Agency for International Development (USAID) has stopped its aid to Cameroon and Togo, after a disagreement on how assistance should be chanelled.

USAID Aministrator Brian Atwood said in an interview in Dakar the govenments in Younde and Lome insist on managing such aid while the agency prefers direct links with grassroots communities.

"The closer you get to the people the more likely it is for development aid to achieve a positive impact," Atwood said. 

He said the agency, whose aid funds are increasingly being reduced by the Republican party-dominated Congress, is trying to strengthen links with credible non-governmental organizations to channel assistance to the needy in recepient countries.

USAID, launched in 1961 under the administration of President John F. Kennedy, began implementing a new cost-cutting initiative with Atwood's assumption of office in 1993.

This focuses on the minimal presence of American personnel and effective intervention in most crucial areas.

In 1993 the agency was present in 120 countries. By the year 2000 its programs will be targeted on some 75 countries.

Atwood said most of the 700 million dallars USAID will be spending in Africa this fiscal year will go to countries which practise democracy and observe human rights.

"Foreign assistance is a vital foreign policy tool for preventing crises and avoiding the high cost of peacekeeping and emergency relief operations.

"Also, by fostering an enabling environment for free markets and increasing the economic capacity of developing nations, foreign aid creates markets abroad for U.S. goods and helps ensure the economic well-being of the United States in the next century," a USAID brief said in reference to the increasing tendency by Capitol Hill to slash aid money.

Atwood said many African countries -- including Botswana, Ghana and Zimbabwe -- had become attractive for foreign investment.

A dozen others were set to "take off" by the next decade, and for the Unites States to win part of this market, it must also be engaged in their development, he added.

Asked what his country was doing for Liberia which has been wrecked by a six-year old civil war, Atwood said his agency was providing significant humanitarian assistance to Monrovia.

Atwood said that he would discuss Liberia and Niger where the military took over power from elected civilians recently, with Senegal's President Abdou Diouf.

The USAID administrator, who is also President of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC), arrived in Dakar on March 26 to begin an African tour that will take him to Burundi, Rwanda and other Great Lakes countries.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


ZambiaPolice Block Kaunda's Rally


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 28, 1996 by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 374 words


 

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian police in the northern copperbelt town of Kitwe Wednesday barred former President Kenneth Kaunda from addressing a public meeting of his opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP) because he did not have a police permit for the gathering.

Dunstan Simukoko, in charge of Kitwe district police command said his men had advised Kaunda not to go ahead with the rally which, he said, would breach a new public order act. 

He said Kaunda was issued with a permit to address an in-door meeting but that he later changed his mind and wanted to hold an outdoor rally in one of the townships.

The police action was in accordance with the "reinstated" public order act requiring police permits for public meetings and demonstrations.

Organizers of public gatherings and processions now need to give police 14 days notice, unlike in the past when police had the discretion to issue the permits on the spot.

Chief Justice Matthew Ngulube had earlier this year quashed the order, which he said, was at variance with the country's new multiparty political order.

The Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) government of President Frederick Chiluba, however, reintroduced the law and prescribed the 14-day notice requirement.

Kaunda was in 1995 prosecuted on two counts of addressing political meetings without police permit. This prompted UNIP lawyers to challenge the act in court, leading to its annulment by the chief justice.

The opposition has criticized the law which they say could be manipulated by senior officials of the ruling party including the president and cabinet ministers.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


145 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Role of the Military in Africa Discussed


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 28, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso - Senior army officers from five West African states are attending an international seminar on the role of the military in modern-day Africa.

The theme of the meeting, which opened Tuesday in Ougadougou, Burkina Faso, is "The Military and Democracy in Africa." It has been organized by Germany's Konrad Adenauer Foundation.

Among the major topics being discussed is the reemergence of military coups in Africa.

The officers at the meeting are from five Francophone countries -- Benin, Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger and Togo. The five have at one time or another other fallen under military rule since independence in the 1960s.

One of them, Niger suffered a coup d'etat in January 1996 when the army seized power from a bickering president and his prime minister.

In Benin, a former military ruler, Gen. Mathieu Kerekou, has been re-relected president after being beaten in 1991.

The participants are examining proposals for the creation of a regional force along the model of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).

The meeting coincides with the official end of northern Mali's Tuareg rebellion with the destruction Wednesday of 3,000 pieces of war material used during a campaign by the nomads for an autonomous state.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Libya and Egypt Passengers in Hijacked Plane Rescued


BYLINE: Panafrican News Agency March 28, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 414 words


 

TRIPOLI, Libya - An Egyptian plane landed Thursday morning at Libya's Benghazi airport, 651 miles east of Tripoli, to take back 159 passengers and crew of an Egypt Air plane hijacked from the Egyptian town of Luxor Wednesday and forced to fly to Tobruk in eastern Libya.

The plane came with an unspecified number of Egyptian journalists on board, the Libyan News Agecy (JANA) reported.

The hijacking ended peacefully Wednesday evening when the hijacker surrendered to Libyan security forces. None of the passengers were hurt. 

A PANA correspondent who witnessed negotiations at the control tower, reported that the hijacker initially sought direct access to Libyan leader Col. Moammar Kadhafi, before accepting an indirect conversation through the airport's liaison officer.

Kadhafi demanded that the hijacker guarantee the safety of all passengers before meeting his requirements. The latter assured Kadhafi that no one would be hurt.

"I am not a terrorist. I would only like to inform President Hosni Mubarak that I have information on the failed assassination attempt against him at the last OAU summit in Addis Abeba", the hijacker said.

The hijacker also demanded the lifting of the Israeli blockade in Palestinian territories.

According to Libyan television, the Egypt Air Airbus had on board 59 Canadians, 16 French, 16 Egyptians and 18 other nationals including Japanese.

Libyan television and news agency JANA confirmed late Wednesday that a lone man was involved in the hijack of the Egyptian plane.

But Cairo television spoke of three pirates, all of them Egyptians.

The plane was flying from Djeddah to Cairo when it was hijacked and forced to land at Tobruk after a scheduled stop-over in Luxor, Egypt.

Libya is currently under a United Nations air embargo for having failed to hand over two suspects believed to have been involved in the bombing of a Pan Am plane over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Sports: Soccer Zambian Star Departure to Columbia Blocked


BYLINE: Times of Zambia(Lusaka) March 28, 1996 by


LENGTH: 1163 words


 

Lusaka - International Vincent Mutale is about to sneak out to Columbia but Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) blocked him until some contentious issues in his contract are clarified. And FAZ has summoned Mutale's club Mufulira Wanderers and Dennis Lota's Konkola Blades officials to a meeting in Kitwe this Sunday.

General secretary Colonel Hermann Mpashi said in Lusaka Wednesday FAZ had invited the two clubs to discuss their players who are emroiled in transfer wrangles. 

''We have asked Mutale's club and Konkola to a meeting after the Charity Shield on Sunday on matters pertaining to their players,'' Mpashi said.

Lota who is currently attending trials in Europe has apparently signed a contract with Witbank Aces of South Africa who have demanded the right to negotiate for him should he be successful in Europe. But after the Africa Cup of Nations in South Africa two months ago, Lota, the most sought after Zambian player, linked to five European clubs, has been told by FIFA, the world soccer governing body he will have to play for Aces.

Mutale should have left for Columbia on March 12 but was blocked because his club contract did not adequately provide for early release for him to feature for Zambia.

The contentious clause has something to do with the player's release for national duty and the Columbian club has not made its position clear.

Mpashi, while quoting article 35 of the FIFA statutes on players transfers, said the club will have to respect the clause. FIFA insists that a club must allow for training time before international matches.

The FIFA rules state that the club is obliged to release a player 48 hours before a friendly match, five days before an international qualifying encounter and at least 14 days before the finals of an international tournament such as the Olympics, Africa Cup and the World Cup.

Mpashi said until the proper proceedures are followed, Mutale will not be released. He said Mutale's local agent erred when he signed a contract binding the player to 48 hours no release before any match.

When the matter is resolved, Mpashi said Mutale will be released and allowed to travel to South America. But sources said the Columbian club did not want to deal with a local agent and had demanded that they be allowed to talk to FAZ and Wanderers direct.

Wanderers officials held a meeting Wednesday but were persuaded to hold their cool since the player had to feature for Wanderers in the Africa Club Champions Cup second round second leg last Sunday against Mbabane Highlanders.

Mutale has risen to stardom since joining Wanderers four seasons ago. He broke into the under-23 squad and was an automatic choice for the midfield senior national team place.

During the last Africa Cup, Mutale was a regular for Zambia and scored one of Zambia's 12 goals in six matches.

Zambia Beauty Queen Not Funded for Travel to Las Vegas


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency (Lusaka) March 28, 1996 by


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia's entrant to the 1996 Miss Universe Beauty Pageant, Tamara Kaluba, may not attend the final glitter as her backers have no money with which to send her to the American city of Las Vegas.

Organisers of the Miss Universe Championship in Zambia, Lute Perfumeries Limited, say the change of venue from Carlton centre in Johannesburg to Las Vegas in Nevada has thrown a big set-back in the way of Tamara attending the world event as this has pushed up costs to very high levels. 

One of the Organisers, Ms Eve Kazembe, said because of the high cost of sending Tamara to the States it has been found necessary to send out appeals to airlines, hotels, travel agents and others in the tourism sector so that they may help the entrant travel to Nevada.

Tamara - The Miss Zambia for the competition - won the title in December 1995. She is 21 and is due to go to a Marketing College later in the year.

The Miss Universe competition is due to take place on May 17, 1996 and Miss Zambia was to have travelled out on April 28 to join other contestants from 85 countries for training and rehearsals.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Post Editors Freed


BYLINE: Times of Zambia (Lusaka) March 27, 1996


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - The Lusaka High Court Wednesday freed two Post Editors and ruled that Parliament erred by sentencing them and a columnist in absentia.

High Court judge, Justice Kabazo Chanda, said he had also found Post Managing Editor Bright Mwape innocent on both counts but editor-in-chief Fred M'membe and Lucy Sichone needed to defend themselves for contempt.

Mr Justice Chanda was delivering judgement in an application for the issue of habeas corpus asking the court to order the two editors released from prison. 

"Indefinite jail terms are incompatible with our legal system and unorthodox disciplinary proceedures cannot be allowed,'' he said.

He had found Mwape innocent on both counts though M'membe needed to defend himself for contempt.

Mr Justice Chanda said Mwape was a free man but M'membe needed to appear before Parliament and be formally charged when its sittings resume.

He had established a prima facie case of the charge of contempt for columnist Lucy Sichone who has gone into hiding and advised her to report to Parliament with M'membe.

Parliament was not a court in any judicial sense but it had power to commit people to prison because that was the only way it would guard against being defamed.

M'membe, Mwape and Sichone were summoned to appear before the House on February 23 but did not show up until March 4 when a warrant for their arrest had already been issued and an indefinite jail term slapped on them.

Mr Justice Chanda said Parliament should have found out why the duo had not reported for a whole week.

He censured M'membe and Sichone for alleged vulgar language on members of the House and urged them to desist from using terminology that was incompatible with Zambian tradition.

After judgement, Mr Justice Chanda told Post Lawyers and State Advocates that they were free to appeal. Later, Mr M'membe bemoaned the poor prison conditions as he came out of Lusaka Remand Prison.

''This prison was built in 1905 and it has not been extended since,'' he lamented.

''Conditions are bad and there are more than 1,000 prisoners including children between 10 and 12 years,'' he added.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Kaunda To Set Up Truth Commission


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency (Lusaka) March 28, 1996


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Lusaka - Former President and opposition UNIP leader, Dr Kenneth Kaunda, is to set up a 'Truth Commission' to be served by human rights experts from other countries - once returned into office.

The main task of this commission will be to enquire into how Zambian parastatal companies were sold or privatised and how proceeds of their sales were used.

But Dr Kaunda's statement has prompted Information and Broadcasting Services Minister and Chief Government Spokesman, Amusaa Mwanamwambwa, Tuesday to dismiss the idea as 'misguided and totally unjustified.' 

The Minister noted that in the Zambian context such a commission would be a sheer waste of time and resources which would rather be spent on development.

At his meetings, both in Ndola on Monday and Lusaka rural at the week-end, the former head of state maintained that his 'truth commission' will try to establish who had bought the parastatals and where money from sales of these companies had gone since he suspects that leaders had sold off the majority of the companies to themselves 'at give away prices and resulting in many rendundancies.'

Reacting to the demands for a 'truth commission', Mr Mwanamwambwa pointed out that such a commission can only be set up in a country where there have been serious crimes against humanity such as genocide, or countries emerging out of a war situation.

''Zambia is far from such a state of affairs, and it is hoped that this is not the basis for the opposition parties' war talk to justify a truth commission,'' Mr Mwanamwambwa said.

He cited South Africa, as one country in Southern Africa which had justifiably established a truth commission and a government of national unity.

''The history of that country is well known. To compare the conditions in South Africa to those in Zambia is, therefore, fallacious; based on an incorrect premise and an unjustified position,'' Mr Mwanamwambwa noted.

He wondered why it should be necessary to involve members of the international community in an issue which is purely domestic and which can be resolved by the Zambian people themselves.

"If individuals have committed crimes, Zambia has adequate legal institutional framework to deal with such matters,'' Mr Mwanamwambwa observed adding that the 'truth commission' may still have to refer its work to the Zambian legal system now in place.

Dr Kaunda told his meetings in Lusaka rural that his previous administration had built schools, colleges and two universities which gave thousands of Zambians skills and academic knowledge.

To underscore his declaration that he was still both mentally and physically alert to function as State President Dr Kaunda, who will be 72 later this year, jumped up and down the meeting platform shouting that he was still strong enough to rule Zambia again.

March, 1996


Sports: Soccer Zambian's Columbia Deal Botched by Tunisia Team


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 28, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Lusaka - Kenneth "Bubble" Malitoli's Columbian professional deal has been botched by his former Tunisian side who have placed a US$50,000 tag for every move the Zambian makes.

The situation has forced the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) to seek FIFA, the world football governing body to intervene in what has been described as a crisis. 

Esperance released Malitoli last year on a free transfer but changed their mind after seeing the midfielder in action for Zambia during the Africa Cup of Nations in South Africa recently.

"It seems there is a big problem with Esperance because they still insist on getting a certain percentage of Malitoli's transfer fee,"said FAZ member Musa Kasonka .

"We have since written to FIFA to see how we can be helped on this issue. We want to see that our player is not held hostage by anyone because it's not fair,"said Kasonka.

Malitoli has been offered a playing contract in Columbia which insiders described as lucrative.

But the Tunisians have refused to do the paperwork insisting that they be paid US$50,000.

However, Malitoli has been allowed to feature for his childhood side Nkana on a temporary clearance.

"Kenneth was offered a well-paying contract in Colombia but because Esperance want to get a US$50,000 from the deal, the Colombians refused to pay Esperance," said a source.

And FAZ will this Sunday hold an emergency meeting in Kitwe to make its stand on the globe-trotting Zambian International Denis Lota.

152 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Judge Orders Post Editors Released


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 28, 1996 by Sundie Sinkala


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Lusaka - Two Post editors imprisoned indefinitely by parliament for contempt yesterday walked to freedom when High Court judge Kabazo Chanda released them.

Judge Chanda ordered the release of managing director and editor-in-chief Fred M'membe, and managing editor Bright Mwape, and ruled that the manner and procedure in which Parliament sentenced the duo without them presenting their case was unorthodox and incompatible with the rule of law.

Judge Chanda however, found that some of the words used by M'membe and columnist Lucy Sichone in their articles on the Speaker and deputy minister Ernest Mwansa were very strong and constituted contempt of parliament while Mwape's was said to be non contemptuous. 

He said both M'membe and Sichone should present themselves before the national Assembly when it resumes and clarified his ruling by saying that Sichone was free until she presents herself to the house.

Judge Chanda also ruled that both articles did not breach the parliamentary priviledges as everyone was free to make comments on public institutions and figures.

The judge told a packed courtroom in the absence of M'membe, who could not attend the proceedings that Parliament was not a court while the High and Supreme courts had power to inquire into actions of parliament.

"I wish to say that parliament is not a court in any judicial sense. And because it is not a court, it can not be above or at par with the High Court. It is indeed the supreme legislative body in the country," he said.

Judge Chanda further ruled that Zambian courts were at liberty to intervene in matters of law where it involves the National Assembly such as to settle disputes that may have been caused to individuals by the house.

And reacting to the release of the editors, Senanga MP Inonge Mbikusita Lewanika said that she was happy with the court's decision because it had made the position clear.

"I am happy with the decision especially that the position of parliament not being a court has been clarified.

She said she had been saddened by the decision by parliament to imprison the two and hoped that such barbaric behaviour by an organ of government would not be repeated.

She however cautioned adults and political leaders to refrain from acts that would force young ones to ridicule them by leading a dignified life.

UNIP's Rupiah Banda said he was overwhelmed by the court's judgement which would go along way in ensuring that parliament does not infringe on people's rights.

National Mirror editor in chief and Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA) Zambia chapter chairman Fanwell Chembo lauded the judgement.

"It is a pity that such a decision was made by parliament on the duo. But the High Court ruling is encouraging. This is what should be happening in this country. Justice must be seen to be done to all," he said.

But the Presidential aide for press and public relations who came shortly after the judgement was passed shook hands but had nothing to say about the judgement.

Asked for a coment on the release of the Post editors, presidential press aide Richard Sakala who was shaking hands with Mwape hesistantly replied: "I don't think I am the right person to do so."


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


153 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Sports: General Cross Country: De Reuck Sticks With The Best


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 29, 1996 by Julian Drew


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Johannesburg - Just over a year ago Colleen de Reuck gave birth to her first child, and ever since the soon-to-be-32 year-old Durbanite's running form has been on an upward spiral. Last Saturday she registered possibly the greatest achievement of her career when she placed fifth in the world cross country championships in Stellenbosch, missing the bronze medal by the narrowest of margins.

The world cross country championships are widely regarded as the toughest distance race on the calendar with many of the world's top distance runners in events from 1 500m up to the marathon taking part. As she left the Danie Craven Stadium for the final round of the three-lap race she put in a surge going down the ramp and took the lead accompanied by an expectant roar from the home crowd. But it was short-lived and Ethiopia's Gete Wami and the Kenyans Rose Cheruiyot and Naomi Mugo overtook her. 

She stuck resolutely to them though and only Wami put any real distance between her as she broke over the final 200m for a convincing victory. As De Reuck made a brave attempt to take Mugo on the line, Olympic 10 000m champion Derartu Tulu of Ethiopia sprinted past her. All three of them finished with the same time.

Behind De Reuck were some of the world's greatest runners like world 10 000m champion, Fernanda Ribeiro of Portugal, Sally Barsosio of Kenya and Ireland's Catherina McKiernan. "I don't put myself up there with the world's best and I think that's half my problem. I'm slowly beginning to believe that I'm also good and I guess I just need to work on it a bit more," says De Reuck.

Since returning to South Africa just before the cross country trials which she won in February she has she has also run an Olympic qualifying time of 15:24,77 in the 5 000m. "Since I came back I've set two personal bests on the track and yet they were my first track races in three years and I haven't done any track work what so ever. All I know is that I'm in very good shape right now and it must be Bobby (McGee's) training programmes.

"I'm not doing high mileage or fast track work. He says I must rest because I've just done a marathon," says De Reuck. The marathon is a sore point for her right now because although she is truly world class over the distance she won't be going to Atlanta for the marathon. Last year she planned to record an Olympic qualifying time of below 2:35 at the New York Marathon in November but then the cold weather and problems in getting her drinks at the water tables reduced her to a walk before she finally finished 14th outside the required time.

Blood tests revealed the race had taken little out of her and so she decided to try again four weeks later at the Honolulu Marathon. A notoriously humid race, last year's proved to be the worst on record and although she won she again missed out on an "A" standard Olympic qualifier. She opted out of the South African marathon trials a month ago. "If I'd done New York, Honolulu and then SAs I wouldn't have been in my best shape in Atlanta. I really had bad luck with my races and I was hoping they would take that in to consideration but obviously they can't take me on a "B" standard if Elana (Meyer) already has an "A" standard," she says.

The irony is that with the humidity and extremely tough course in Atlanta (people are predicting the men's winning time at over 2:20) there are many who believe that De Reuck would be a better bet than Meyer. Instead she will now have to hope the wind doesn't blow at the national track and field championships in Cape Town next month and aim for a 10 000m qualifying time.


LOAD-DATE: April 1, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


154 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Sports: General Cross Country: Organisers Winners In Well-run Event


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 29, 1996


LENGTH: 1080 words


 

Johannesburg - The Kenyans dominated the world cross country championships once again, but the organisers were the real winners

SOUTH AFRICA'S aspirations to host the world's top sporting events received a significant boost after last Saturday's world cross country championships in Stellenbosch which many experienced observers considered the best they had ever attended.

The local organising committee (LOC), which put together the event on behalf of Athletics South Africa (ASA), encountered unprecedented difficulties in its task of signing up sponsors and making the championships financially viable, but that did not prevent it from putting on an extremely slick and professional show.

Most of the credit for this belongs to a small number of dedicated people on the executive committee who rolled up their sleeves and decided the championships would be a success, irrespective of the financial problems. These problems were brought about by the International Amateur Athletic Federation's own difficulties in signing new sponsors for its four-year package known as the World Athletic Series, the most recent of which came to an end last year. 

The world cross country championships form part of this series and the LOC was only given the go-ahead to source sponsors locally less than a month before they were due to take place.

The Cape Town city council, which at the beginning rather hesitantly provided a R1- million guarantee, eventually converted part of this guarantee into a substantial sponsorship and it was joined by 11 other companies and organisations as official product/service companies.

Old Mutual also became the first South African company to obtain title sponsor rights to an IAAF event and because of the world governing body's current problems it can be safely assumed it got them at a very favourable price. While most of the advertising that was produced early for the event contained only two IAAF official sponsors, the LOC was told four days before the championships to include Carlsberg as a third.

So desperate is the IAAF to sort out its sponsorship crisis that it can be reliably reported that Carlsberg had still not signed its deal with the IAAF and was holding out with an offer that was $500 000 less than the IAAF expected.

Television coverage of the championships was also provided free of charge internationally by the IAAF, using its own in-house production team, after it failed to complete television contracts for the new period.

The European Broadcasting Union, which handles the negotiations for all European national networks, offered just half the R346-million it paid for the last four years.

Perhaps the biggest winner out of the sponsorship wheeling and dealing was the Cape Town 2004 Olympic Bid Company. "There was a tremendous benefit to the bid from these championships although they at times seemed reluctant to come on board," said LOC financial manager Gareth Griffiths.

But while the superb organisation of the championships certainly did the bid no harm, an equally important spin-off for the bid was the IAAF council meeting held last Sunday and Monday which brought five International Olympic Committee members to Cape Town.

The council meeting was never part of the LOC's budget for the championships. and considering its other financial problems, it is not surprising there was resentment from the LOC when it was told it would have to foot the bill for it as well.

The cost of holding the meeting was thrust upon the LOC in January after ASA president Leonard Chuene offered to host it at a meeting in Gothenburg last year.

Fortunately, when the Bid Company signed an official service company contract it agreed to contribute to some of the costs of the council meeting.

On race day the people of the Western Cape came out in their thousands to support the championships which rarely attract big crowds. The estimated throng of around 15 000 gave vociferous support to all the runners and especially the South Africans. The atmosphere was as memorable as the glorious setting of the University of Stellenbosch playing fields in the shadow of the Helderberg and Simonsig mountains.

The real success of the championships, however, belongs to people like Griffiths, Joel Ramatlhape and Roy Cheesman, the project managers appointed from the executive committee to oversee the organisation of the event. They more than anyone put in the long hours and came up with solutions to the many teething problems, ensuring there were no hitches come zero hour.

Former mayor of Cape Town, Sol Kreiner, did most of the lobbying for sponsors while the well-designed and testing course was the work of environmental consultant, Stephen Grainger, who combined his technical knowledge with a genuine love and understanding of the sport.

So happy were the IAAF with the arrangements for the championships that its event director, Eric Savard, said the LOC was the best he'd ever worked with.

Following on the successful Rugby World Cup and African Cup of Nations, the world cross country championships will have sent another clear message to the world that South Africa is ready and able to stage the two biggest prizes of all, the 2004 Olympic Games and the 2006 soccer World Cup.
