Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Catholics Stress African Values In Gospel Teaching


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 22, 1996 by Osman Njuguna


LENGTH: 1933 words


 

Nairobi - It was considered taboo for the early Catholic missionaries in Africa to express theological sympathy for African cultural values in evangelisation. But today, the leadership of the Catholic Church in Africa and at the Vatican are emphasizing links between scripture and African values.

In their historic special assembly, held in Rome in 1994, African Catholic Bishops said of inculturation; "The synod considers inculturation an urgent priority in the life of the particular churches, for a firm rooting of the Gospel in Africa."

Whereas the Catholic Church in Africa has not instituted a well defined approach to realise the goal of Gospel inculturation, Pope John Paul II has already launched the Post Synodal Exhortation, Ecclesia in Africa, which highlights the synod for the African Catholic bishops. 

On March 14, Rev. Dr. Aylward Shorter, of the Missionaries of Africa Order, launched a book, "Christianity and the African Imagination," which is an attempt to carry out a dialogue with African oral tradition and use this as a resource for the incuturation of the Gospel.

Through the 128-page volume, the author highlights the impact of African cultural values in the teaching of the Gospel message in Africa, the misplacement of African values in the teaching of the Gospel by the early Church, some efforts in promoting African cultural values by some missionaries and the current position of the Vatican in the incorporation of African values in the Catholic teachings.

The author, who has spent 30 of his missionary service in Africa and has visited half of the countries on the continent, explores his subject under six well selected topics. They include Religion and Imagination in Contemporary Africa; Mission, Language and Culture, (the case of Charles Lavigerie); The Function and Future of African Christian Art; Christian Themes in African Creative Writing; Christianity and Oral Tradition; and The African Synod: Dialogue with the African Imagination.

The African culture should not be defined eurocentrically, in terms of what European culture is not, cations the author, while addressing himself to the subject of culture, imagination and faith.

He advances that "it would be a dangerous over-simplification to characterise European culture as rational and African culture as symbolic." Dr. Shorter argues that African thought forms are far from being impervious to rational analysis and symbolism is far from unknown in Europe and America.

According to Fr. Shorter, Africans have a legitimate desire to reformulate the truths of faith in accordance with their own cultural forms of expression. "They need not and should not replicate the intellectual history of Europe in order to understand what the Gospels say about Jesus. Ultimately, an existential - not a pseudo- objective interpretation of scripture is necessary," he recommends.

The author laments that the Rwandan holocaust underlines the ambiguity of the contemporary cultural situation in Africa. He says that sophisticated ideas of multi-party democracy from the West have followed upon a history of Western colonial and neo-colonial manipulation. These, he adds, have fostered ethnic antagonism and ultimately ethnic violence on a massive scale.

The Christian faith, also brought by Westerners, has flourished in Rwanda on an extensive scale, says Dr. Shorter. He adds; "This faith, however, was sufficiently rooted in the hearts and minds of Rwandans for some heroic Christians to resist the violence and to give their lives for their brothers and sisters of the other ethnic group."

On the church's recognition and cultural pluralism, the author says of the Catholic Church of the past; "For centuries, the Catholic Church espoused a philosophy of eurocentric monoculturalism.

"This is what Bernard Lonergan has called classicist assumption that there was single, universal, normative criterion, usually called civilisation, according to which the cultivation or barbarism of human individuals could be assessed," laments Dr. Shorter.

But the author cites two outstanding foreign missionaries to Africa, whose pastoral work went hand in hand with their commitment towards promoting African values. He cites Cardinal Lavigerie, the founder of the Missionaries Society of Africa Catholic Order and Bishop Daniel Comboni, whose early missionary work in Central Africa made a remarkable contribution to the evangelisation of the Gospel among the local people in the region.

He quotes a letter the Cardinal wrote to the missionaries of the first caravan to Equatorial Africa in 1878; "I desire that as soon as such a thing is possible, and not later than six months after your arrival in the mission, all missionaries shall speak with each other only in the language of the people among whom they live."

In his concluding chapter, The African Synod: Dialogue with the African Imagination, Dr. Shorter says of the African imagination -- the African imagination is not merely religious; it also has a strong and specific affinity with Christianity. He further argues that the African religious imagination is the substratum that underlies all the Christian denominations and indeed, all the immigrant religions in Africa. This fact should facilitate Christian and interreligious dialogue, he adds.

The author further cites the development of Black theology in South Africa as a case in point to prove that Christianity was not absent from the African imagination. "Indeed, Black Theology developed as a creative religious response to the Black Theology consciousness movement.

Steve Biko saw this as the most positive facet of the interaction of the movement with Christianity," writes Dr. Shorter.

However, Dr. Shorter admits that the mission of inculturating the Christian message in Africa is not smooth sailing. The author talks of fears and difficulties ahead for the Catholic Church in Africa as it endeavours to inculturate the Gospel.

He says; "Some theologians of liberation have seen inculturation as running the risk of becoming an antiquarian irrelevance, a form of indigenism or else of being open to idealist misunderstanding."

According to Dr. Shorter, the inculturation praxis has an important role to play in the liberation of Africa and in bringing into existence a new humanity and a new society in the continent.

The liberation and inculturation agenda are therefore closer than originally thought, argues Dr. Shorter. "In culturally disoriented situations like that of Rwanda, as indeed in other situations in Africa and outside, inculturation and liberation is an on-going process," he adds.

"It is not a fact which is either accomplished or not accomplished..It is, moreover, a process that is informed by the African religious imagination, challenged by the gospel brought to Africa via an historical, intercultural, missionary movement."


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


180 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Malaria Treatment Using Chloroquine To Be Phased Out Africa-at-Large


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 22, 1996 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

Nairobi - Ministry of Health officials in Kenya have recommended the discontinuation of the malaria drug chloroquine, in the treatment of children with malaria. Widely used and cheap, health officials say that, to a large extent, chloroquine "is no longer effective.": Children are most in danger because their natural immune response is still under-developed.

Despite the intense publicity given to diseases like the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS), malaria remains a major killer in many African countries. Reports of several hundred deaths that
occurred in Swaziland in a malaria epidemic early this month bear witness to the seriousness of this disease. 

In Kenya, doctors are also recommending that first-time pregnant women and travellers into endemic malaria areas who become infected be treated with medicines other than chloroquine, to which the malaria causing parasite - plasmodium falciparum - has developed considerable resistance. The parasite is transmitted by certain mosquitoes.

Senior officials of the Ministry of Health Malaria Project confirmed to APS that the recommendation for the phasing out of chloroquine in the treatment of specific groups "will soon be implemented."

Dr. Beth Rapuodo, Manager of the Malaria Control Unit of the Ministry of Health emphasised that while "deeply regrettable," the phase out of chloroquine was inevitable. Asserted Dr. Rapuodo: "Chloroquine will be badly missed by the medical profession and the wider public. It is easily the best drug in decades. It is cheap, has minimum side effects and was widely available. Frankly, we will be sorry to see chloroquine go but it has been overtaken by events."

Dr. Christopher Nevill, a malaria specialist with the African Medical Research Foundation (AMREF), and member of the Ministry of Health technical committee on drugs, equally noted the inevitability that chloroquine would eventually give way to other drugs. "It is parasite dynamics - we are looking at an old parasite that has changed to cope with what we have been throwing at it. Certainly, it is not a brand new parasite, but one that has been evolving."

Dr. Nevill emphasized that the most important group as far as malaria is concerned are children. In Africa, children comprise 75 per cent of mortality victims attributed to malaria - more than 1.5 million deaths per annum.

All over Kenya, more than 70 per cent of the children treated with chloroquine still have a parasite load after one week. "We cannot continue with a drug like that, it is dangerous," says Dr. Nevill.

First time pregnant mothers too are susceptible to malaria because changes in a woman's body during the first pregnancy depress her immunity, thus affecting the ability to fend off diseases like malaria.

The Ministry of Health recommends that two drugs currently in use replace chloroquine. These are Comaquin (Amodiaquin) and Fansidar (Pyrimethamine Sulfadioxine). Dr. Nevill emphasized that these drugs should not be used for prophylaxis - that is, prevention of malaria. "The World Health Organisation (WHO), has recommended that these drugs should not be used in the routine prevention of malaria, otherwise this will encourage faster development of resistant strains." Furthermore if used for prevention on a weekly basis, there is greater danger of severe side effects.

Asked about the cost, Dr. Nevill conceded that this would "more than double." However, a reduction in child mortality and the number of people with severe diseases taking up hospital beds will compensate for the rise in costs.

Another critical factor contributing to recurrent high costs in treating malaria, is the absence of low cost laboratory services at rural dispensaries throughout Eastern Africa.

"The work of Dr. Carter of AMREF has shown that it should not cost more than Kshs.10 to Kshs.20 (about US 20 to 40 cents) to test for malaria." Dr. Nevill further said the AMREF study has shown that with properly equipped, funded and motivated workers, rural dispensaries in Eastern Africa can provide crucial services in the fight against malaria.

"Low cost laboratory services are important because, without a bloodslide you can never be sure whether a patient has malaria or any number of other diseases that mimic the symptoms associated with malaria.

There are myriads of diseases both viral and bacterial - that, at first sight, may be confused for malaria. "You must have a blood test," emphasized Dr. Nevill. He gave an example of Kilifi District, a moderately high malaria zone on the Kenyan coast. He noted that outside the rainy season in the area, only 40 out of every 100 children who turn up with fevers and other malaria symptoms are actually diagnosed with malaria. The figure rises steeply for Kisumu in the west, a high malaria zone on the shores of Lake Victoria. At least 70 per cent of the children in this lake region will be found to have malaria.

By contrast, in Nairobi, a low malaria zone, less than one per cent of the children will be found to have malaria. Dr. Nevill noted that the figures rise dramatically in each area during the rainy season when malaria incidence peaks.

Dr. Rapuodo told APS that the WHO allowed each country to make independent decisions on problems like drug resistance. However, because there are many difficulties of logistics associated with phasing out a widely used drug like chloroquine, the Ministry of Health intends to undertake the process in stages, starting with a pilot project that would gather data on factors like side effects, distribution and other constraints that would be associated with Fansidar/Comoquin becoming first line treatment drugs for children with malaria.

Dr. Nevill who pioneered the use of impregnated mosquito nets in Kenya 10 years ago, urges more people to use the nets for prevention. These devices have a small amount of insecticide coated on the fabric and are able to repel malaria mosquitoes.

He pointed out that in some malaria endemic areas of Kenya, people receive between 100 to 300 infected mosquito bites per annum, which explains the high mortality rates due to malaria in those areas.

He promised that a WHO funded project in Kilifi District of Kenya, will reveal "exciting data" on the effectiveness of impregnated nets in malaria prevention. The results will be published in May this year.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


181 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Hospice Offers Dignified Way To Cope With Cancer


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 22, 1996 by James Macharia


LENGTH: 1854 words


 

Nairobi - Millions of people all over the world fall victim to cancer, a terminal disease with no known cure. The World Health Organisation (WHO) estimates that there are 25,000 new cases of cancer every year worldwide.

Although no national statistics exist at the Kenya Cancer Association's registry, the traumatic experience undergone by cancer patients who have to live in constant pain and fear of looming death is not alien to many Kenyan families.

Many patients will tell tales of being isolated by their illness, of pain which cannot be adequately controlled, eventually rendering them invalids and dependent upon their families, for whom they have been providing.

For Jane Nzioka, a 56-year-old widower from Machakos, in Eastern Province, the pain, loneliness and loss of livelihood as a result of being afflicted by cancer of the maxilla or cheekbone three years ago, has been lessened by emotional, spiritual and social support. Her childhood ability to weave ciondos (bags made from sisal) has not only been preserved but also enhanced to become a source of income for the family, thanks to the Nairobi Hospice, the only centre for the terminally ill in Kenya and until recently the only one in East Africa. 

Located on a plot next to the imposing Kenyatta National Hospital, some three kilometres from the city centre, the Nairobi Hospice offers palliative medical and nursing care and psychological counselling by people especially trained in the needs of the terminally ill and their families.

The Nairobi Hospice celebrated its sixth anniversary on February 27, 1996. However, when this writer visited the centre to interview the Medical Officer, Dr. Michael Hughes, neither he nor any of the staff or patients were in a festive mood. The busy schedule of caring for cancer patients in the hospice and outside is an arduous task for the staff who stress on the quality of life lived for the day as stated in their motto: "Put life in their days, not just days into their life." Dr. Hughes who joined the centre in 1993 says the Nairobi Hospice is not fighting for a cure for cancer but concentrates on the comfort and "quality of life, not just the quantity or length of life."

From a staff of one nurse and a secretary in February 1990, the Hospice today has a staff of more than 14 full-time workers including five nurses, two doctors and a social worker, not to mention the growing number of volunteers offering various services. "During this period, we have looked after more than 1500 patients, and on average have 180 patients under our care at any one time, including 120 from up-country," Dr. Hughes told this writer.

When the late Prof. Edward Kasili began the hospice together with two nurses, Ruth Wooldridge and Jane Moore in 1990, little did the cancer researcher know that he himself would also benefit from the centre's services. Several years later, he was diagnosed with cancer of the liver and was cared for by the Hospice staff until the day he passed away. Before his death, the pioneer researcher whose life was dedicated to finding out the causes of certain cancers in Africa in the hope of finding a cure, also established the Nairobi Terminal Care Centre, the fore-runner to the Nairobi Hospice.

We look after patients and the families of patients who have a cancer that cannot be completely cured. We help the patient to cope with the disease by giving him or her feedback and counselling on the nature of the sickness. Therefore we treat patients with an attitude of counselling by looking after the patient and also counselling the whole family to remove fear and inadequacy so that our patients can die in dignity," Dr. Hughes explained.

The difference between a hospice and a hospital, is that in the former, "palliative" or "terminal" care are the operative words. This means that appropriate medical and nursing care to relieve pain, which 70 per cent of cancer patients suffer from are provided alongside psychological counselling and recreation on an out-patient and home-visitation basis.

Dr. Hughes describes cancer as a large group of diseases characterised by uncontrolled growth and spread of abnormal cells. Normal cells grow for a purpose to replace worn out tissues or repair injuries but cancer cells grow for no reason and destroy normal cells in the process. "The causes of cancer are still unclear," he says.

Minus statistics, the Nairobi Hospice Medical Officer says, "60 per cent of our patients are women suffering from cancer of the cervix and breast while the remainder are men and children afflicted with bowel, stomach and leukemia cancers. The average age of our patients is 46 years and 50 per cent of our patients come from up-country."

He notes that of late, some skin cancers and cancers affecting the blood have been reported and that these are common with HIV patients. He says cancer is also caused by certain habits which may trigger changes in the cell function. "Cigarette smoking can cause lung, mouth or oesophagus cancer while excessive alcohol intake can lead to cancer of the throat, liver and stomach," adds the Nairobi Hospice Medical Officer.

Dr. Hughes points out that although not inherited, some cancers are common within certain families such as cancer of the breast or stomach. "Therefore, close relatives of patients with these cancers may need more frequent cancer related check-ups, though the risk is still very small. Cancer is neither infectious nor contagious," he says. He adds that some of the more than 100 types of cancer affecting the body can be cured, including breast, cervical and leukemia, but the majority of the patients seek treatment at a very late stage.

The Nairobi Hospice chief executive and project coordinator Brigid Sirengo says, "the Hospice approach is to give a family and community involvement in caring for the patients unlike an in-patient facility which can be taken as a dumping ground for patients." The Hospice hopes that palliative care can be introduced in training to help nurses cope with the psychological and physical pain of the patients.

For the ailing, Dr. Hughes says, chemotherapy treatment is given. "Chemotherapy is derived from two words: chemical and therapy, but in a layman's language, it means the use of anti-cancer drugs to destroy cancer cells." Another treatment is the use of powerful X-rays to destroy the cancer cells or injections to administer doses of morphine to ease pain.

The Nairobi Hospice also runs a day care centre every Thursday. Introduced in December 1993, it serves as an informal session, bringing together patients, doctors, nurses, social workers and volunteers. When this writer visited the centre early March, several patients were cheerfully seated enjoying a cup of tea. Upon introduction to Jane Nzioka, she told this writer; "I look forward to this day because it helps me to see other patients who are my best friends, especially Nelly (the day care coordinator) and it gives me an opportunity to use my hands which are still fit to make ciondos."

Nelly Oyamo, the head nurse at the Hospice, has been involved in its work for four years now and is in charge of the Day Care activities. "We provide games like scrabble, cards and even rounders out in the field. Some women like knitting while other patients prefer to watch television or videos. Some prefer to just keep quiet and we let them do so. We also provide physiotherapy exercises for them," she told this writer.

At least once a month, the patients are taken out to cultural centres such as the National Museum and other tourist sites like Lake Nakuru in the Rift Valley. The day care service benefits 12 regular patients, some of whom have to walk quite some distance to share in the six-hour session from 9a.m to 3p.m. "The attendance could be more if transport was available from well-wishers, especially for our patients in the outskirts of Nairobi," says Nelly.

The Nairobi Hospice is run with the help of volunteers like those on the day care centre as well as well-wishers from all walks of life. They undergo a training course, thus qualifying to assist in visiting patients at home, fundraising and other administrative duties. Currently, the centre has 68 such workers.

It is in the same spirit that the Nyeri Hospice, in Central Province, about 200 kilometres north of Nairobi opened its doors to the public last December. Kathy Sembi, Mary Kihara and Florence Kiama who are the project coordinator, nurse and secretary respectively, rent a vehicle to conduct home visits that take care of upto 13 families so far.

This is a vital service to rural cancer patients who mainly have to travel all the way to Nairobi for drugs or palliative care. The Nyeri Hospice which is part of the Nairobi Hospice plans to branch out to other towns in the near future, says Dr. Hughes.

It is this ability to take on the odds and prevail that marks out the Nairobi Hospice as a unique treatment centre. The Chief Executive Brigid Sirengo sums up its services thus; "Cancer patients do not need advanced technology or such complications, they need you and me to show that we care and this quality can be found even in developing countries which may not have much technology." It is in this light that others can take up the challenge to support the Hospice, but better till, begin one that will cater for other terminal illnesses, top on the list being the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


182 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Churches To Lobby For Child Rights Charter


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 22, 1996


LENGTH: 600 words


 

HARARE - African churches should lobby their governments for the ratification of the African Charter on the rights and welfare of the child.

Delegates to a church-sponsored consultation on the African child, held here from March 10 to 17, were surprised to hear that only a few African countries had so far signed and ratified the charter.

"It was out of this shocking information that the delegates, who included social workers, parliamentarians, scholars, church ministers and scores of children, called for the lobbying and advocacy for the ratification of the charter," said Rev. Dr. Setri Nyomi who attended the meeting. 

The Ghanaian church minister, who represented the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC), told APS that delegates to the consultation agreed that the signing and ratification of this charter by African governments, was crucial to solving problems facing the African child today.

The week long consultation was sponsored by the Association of Evangelicals in Africa (AEA) in partnership with the World Vision International, Compasion International and the AACC.

The meeting which deliberated on the theme-Generation at Risk: What Future, highlighted among other issues, children of war, education, child growth and development and political effects on the child.

The consultation also called on churches in Africa to provide pastoral services for children and encourage every Christian to be a child evangelist.

The delegates recommended that churches should work hand in hand with organisations already engaged in child social work at local, national and continental levels with the aim to strengthen effectiveness in ensuring child survival.

The church at various levels should create and strengthen fora for discussion of social issues related to children, the meeting further recommended.

Participants also called on churches to train lay counsellors and provide counselling and guidance for children and youth.

Churches and para-church organisations should directly monitor child abuse, neglect and exploitation in communities and also provide help (including counselling) for victims, they recommended.

The meeting also urged African governments to commit greater resources to programmes for alleviation of poverty in both rural and urban areas.

According to the Nairobi-based African Network for the Prevention and Protection Against Child Abuse and Neglect (ANPPCAN), by 1995, only six African countries had so far ratified the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) Charter on the rights and welfare of the child, since its adoption by member states in 1979.

These countries include Burkina Faso, Cape Verde, Mauritius, Sierra Leone, Uganda and Zimbabwe.

A total of 15 countries are supposed to sign and ratify the charter before it becomes operational.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


183 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


United States and Africa Pentagon Provides Dogs To Detect Landmines In Rwanda


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 22, 1996


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Kigali - The United States Department of Defence is donating to Rwanda 20 dogs which have been trained to sniff landmines.

The dogs will be involved in a de-mining programme which is being implemented by a private company called RONCO. The company has previously carried out demining work in Mozambique. 

In Rwanda, landmines and the smaller anti-personnel mines were liberally planted by members of the defeated army and militias associated with the regime of the late President Juvenal Habyarimana, both during the civil war in the early 90s and later as the war intensified in 1994.

The Hutu army and militias, feeling more and more insecure planted so many mines that the country is considered one vast minefield. Rwanda has more than 300 amputees as a result. Many others have died from mine related incidents.

At least a dozen out of the 20 dogs are already in the country. They are aged between 16 and 24 months and are said to have a lifespan of at least eight years.

The Department of Defence in Washington has given these dogs at least six to 10 weeks of training. The dogs will receive a further eight weeks of training while in Rwanda jointly with their handlers who are members of the Rwanda Defence Force.

Mr. Case Stek, a senior official of the United States Embassy in Kigali, Rwanda, told APS that "it takes special dogs to do this high specialised work."

He noted that just as it requires special dogs to guide blind people, it also takes special dogs to locate landmines. "These dogs are particularly suitable for the hilly countryside that is characteristic of Rwanda. They will work where other equipments like bulldozers may be entirely unsuitable."

Once a dog detects a suspected landmine, electronic devices may then be used to verify that it is indeed a landmine.

Other sources say these dogs originate from Belgium. The US Department of Defence acquired the dogs from the breeder for about US dollars 1500 each. The entire cost of training these dogs is put at about US dollars 8,000.

The input of the US government into the entire demining programme in Rwanda is expected to cost US dollars 3 million. This includes vehicles, bulldozers, specialised clothing and other equipment.

Meanwhile, the Managing Director of Zimbabwe Defence Industries (ZDI) Colonel Dube, has denied recent news reports in Europe which claimed that Zimbabwe was a major producer of landmines in Eastern and Southern Africa. The ZDI is a subsidiary of the Ministry of Defence.

Colonel Dube emphasised that "no landmines are made by the ZDI. We have invited the Red Cross and the United Nations (UN) to verify the fact," he said in a recent radio interview.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


184 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Sierra Leone Celebration Follows Successful Election


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 22, 1996


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Freetown - Ahmad Tejan Kabbah was declared Sierra Leone's new president on March 17 after winning a presidential election run-off in this west African nation, electoral commission chairman James Jonah announced.

Kabbah, who heads the Sierra Leone People's Party (SLPP), won 608,419 votes, 59.49 per cent of those cast, in a run-off poll held on March 15, against the 414,335, or 40.51 per cent, won by his sole rival, John Karefa Smart of the United National People's Party (UNPP), Jonah said in a statement broadcast on national radio.

Turnout in the run-off was more than 81 per cent, according to the figures released by the commission chairman.

The poll, the country's first real opportunity for 30 years to elect a chief executive, is due to clinch the transition from military to civilian rule. 

The run-off followed an inconclusive first round -- held late February together with legislative polls -- where Kabbah won 35.8 per cent of the vote against Karefa-Smart's 22.6 per cent.

Election regulations stipulated a run-off would be held if no candidate won at least 55 per cent.

Although both the SLPP and the UNPP had said they were confident of victory before the announcement of the results, most observers had predicted a win for Kabbah not only because of his first round lead, but also because he had managed to garner the support of several other parties before the second round was held.

The SLPP, the oldest political party in the country, also led the legislative poll, held under a proportional representation system with 36.1 per cent of the vote.

The Revolutionary United Front (RUF) is a rebel group that plunged Sierra Leone into civil war five years ago. Since then at least 10,000 people have died and almost half the west African country's 4.5 million inhabitants have been forced to flee their homes.

The conflict has devastated the country, now one of the poorest in the world despite an abundance of valuable natural resources, and there can be little hope of development promised by politicians across the board, until the fighting stops.

The RUF does not recognise these elections -- and hence neither the president nor government they produce -- saying peace should be brought to the country first.

This was a view shared by the military junta, in power since a 1992 coup, which failed to persuade a conference of prominent civilians to postpone the election process.

Fearing a continuation of military rule with which most of the country is fed up, these civilians decided to uphold the election date they had set last summer.

Soon after the announcement, thousands of Sierra Leoneans danced in the streets of the capital Freetown until the early hours on March 18 to celebrate the return of democracy heralded by the election of the new president.

Spontaneous processions formed in the winding streets of Freetown soon after the result was announced, bringing traffic first to a standstill, then to a horn-honking participation in the general euphoria.

Many marchers carried palm fronds, the SLPP's emblem, and sang songs of victory in Krio, Mende, and Limba, three of the country's languages.

"The general prayer of every Sierra Leonean was, 'give us a leader who has sympathy for the masses'," explained Mohammed, a 25-year-old driver.

The army was notable by its absence from election's result festivities, perhaps aware that the capital was celebrating not so much the victory of Kabbah, as the demise of a military regime that has ruled by decree since it took power in 1992.

The new developments got a shot in the arm when military ruler Brigadier-General Julius Maada Bio announced that the junta would hand over power to the democratically-elected government on March 29 when the new president would be sworn in.

Maada Bio also announced that a summit between himself and RUF leader Foday Sankoh would be held on March 25 in Ivory Coast's economic capital, Abidjan.

"Soon, we will all witness the dawn of a new era in our country's history when on March 29, 1996 the new President will be sworn in to assume office," Maada Bio said.

The RUF, who claim to be "fighting for democracy," have called a two- month ceasefire and in a turnabout, also said that they were willing to talk to Kabbah, although they maintain that they do not recognise him as president and the legitimacy of the process that elected him.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


185 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa Security Tightened Amid Reported Threats To Zulu King


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 22, 1996 by


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Durban - Zulu King Goodwill Zwelithini is under increased police protection following intelligence reports that hardline right wing elements in South Africa could kill the king and plunge the Zulu nation into civil war, according to a Radio Vatican report.

South African Police Commissioner George Fivaz reinforced police protection for King Zwelithini at his palace near Nangoma in Kwa- Zulu-Natal, the traditional homeland of some 8 million Zulus, according to other reports.

On March 15, the Zulu King hosted peace talks that were called by South African President Nelson Mandela, with the aim of defusing the long running feud between supporters of the Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP) under Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi who is the arch-rival and antagonist of King Zwelithini. The King and his supporters back Mandela's African National Congress (ANC) party. 

The rivalry among the factions within the Zulu nation has cost the lives of some 20,000 people in the last 10 years. These include an estimated 250 policemen killed in the last 18 months alone.

News reports of President Mandela's peacemaking efforts in Kwa-Zulu- Natal emphasised the negative aspects such as the jeering and the discordance that Mandela faced when he addressed nearly 2,000 traditional rulers gathered in one of the King's houses near Nangoma Palace.

He said President Mandela's important message to the protagonists in the trouble torn region was simply; "You don't have to kill to put your point across."

Political analysts in South Africa say by going to Kwa-Zulu-Natal in a fighting mood, Mandela has shown that he can take a difficult bull by the horns. Many people in Kwa-Zulu-Natal thought Mandela had neglected their conflicts which continue to claim 100 lives every month.

Mandela himself said optimistically, "people are beginning to think." The President sees light at the end of the tunnel as far as resolving the violence in Natal is concerned.

186 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Egypt Government Ends Curfew In Heartland Of Muslim Militant Violence


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 22, 1996


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Cairo - Egyptian Interior Minister Hassan al-Alfi announced on March 17 the lifting of a 17-month curfew imposed on the southern town of Mallawi, one of the centres of Muslim militant violence in the country for the past three years.

"The curfew is permanently lifted in Mallawi town starting March 17, as the people of Mallawi have affirmed that they will stand with police against terrorism, and will be lifted in stages in 12 nearby villages," Alfi told journalists during a tour of the town, 300 kilometres south of Cairo.

The curfew was slapped on the town of around 400,000 residents after it became centre stage for attacks by Muslim militants waging an armed anti-government campaign which has left 987 dead since March 1992.

But the measure devastated Mallawi, which had long been the main commercial hub for south Egypt, as more than 2,000 businesses went bankrupt and residents fled to find work elsewhere. 

Aside from the economic loss, the town became a site of mourning as many of its families had relatives in armed fundamentalist groups or the police force who died, or others who were simply killed in the crossfire between the two sides.

Around 70 police, militants and civilians have been killed in Minya province since violence erupted there in mid-1994, most of them in Mallawi or surrounding villages.

On hearing the announcement, overjoyed inhabitant's of Mallawi enjoyed their first full day of freedom on March 18, celebrating the end of the 17-month curfew which stifled the town, once the main killing ground of south Egypt's Muslim militants.

Youths sang and played horns and drums in the streets and sidewalk cafes swarmed with customers, the first time since October 1994 that residents were allowed outdoors after 6 p.m.

"Today is a holiday for everyone in Mallawi," said Sayed Farghali Balih, 18, a housepainter.

"The lifting of the curfew was a request by the public to break the stranglehold which terrorism had placed around our necks," Hosni Abdel Karim Yunis, a pharmacist, said.

"I just happened to come into town and was surprised to find this," said Ali Osman Ali, who left his failing car dealership in Mallawi to find work in the Red Sea resort of Hurghada.

"Once things calm down I am going to return here, because this is my hometown," said Ali, smoking a waterpipe at the Sohag cafe, where not a single seat was empty on the night of March 17.

"I was not expecting people would come out so quickly after the lifting," said the Sohag cafe's owner Gamal Ahmed Hussein, smiling at the crowds.

"I used to have seven workers here before the curfew. I had to fire all but two and I still could not pay my bills," Hussein said.

"Merchants have been waiting for this lifting for a long time because the curfew paralyzed the market. Now all we need is for it to be lifted in the neighbouring village where we can sell our goods," Ali Mahmud, a shopowner said.

"The happiness here is indescribable. But it will only be complete if they decide to write off the taxes of all Mallawi's merchants," said Shehata Gadullah Saadullah, a tax collector.

Mallawi's lone cinema stopped showing films long ago and its owner began renting it out for weddings after slashing its staff from more than 20 employees to only two.

"But I think now the owner will renovate and start showing films again," Magdi Halim, one of the employees, said.

But surprisingly, Osman Mohammed Osman, the owner of the only hotel in Mallawi, which has a potential tourist draw in its numerous archaeological sites, was not enthusiastic.

Police took over his entire 45-room Semiramis to use as a base in their fierce repression of the militants. "If they leave now, then the lifting is good. If not, then what good is it to me?" Osman said.

Alfi also said "licences for automatic weapons have been cancelled for all persons, without exception" amid an arms control campaign by the ministry.

More than 3,000 other private gun licences have been revoked throughout Egypt "due to the absence of sufficient reason for holding them or due to misuse of the weapons," the Interior Minister said.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


187 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Pontiff Beatifies Two Missionaries Despite Poor Health


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 22, 1996


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Vatican City - Pope John Paul II on March 17 participated in the beatification of two missionaries, one in Africa and the other in China, despite intestinal problems that forced him a day earlier to postpone a visit he had scheduled to make to the Tuscan city of Siena.

The 75-year-old Roman Catholic pontiff appeared at St Peter's basilica mid-morning to declare the beatification of Italian missionaries Daniel Comboni and Guido Maria Conforti, pioneers in the 1800s of "a new missionary spirit" for the Catholic Church in Africa and China.

As he walked down the basilica's central aisle, the Pope stopped often to greet the ill and the faithful, and although his face showed signs of fatigue, he looked relatively healthy.

When the Vatican announced the previous day that the Pope would visit Siena on March 30 instead of earlier as planned, it said his health had improved "markedly" after a high temperature on March 12 that prompted him to cancel a public meeting the following day. 

The Pope left the basilica at around 10:30 a.m. (9:30 GMT) to return to his private apartment where his doctors had advised him to rest for a few more days, after Angelo Cardinal Sadano, the Vatican's secretary of state, had said mass during the beatification in the ageing pontiff's place.

The two beatified missionaries, Father Daniel Comboni and Father Guido Maria Conforti, were Italian pioneers of the "new missionary spirit" that gripped the Roman Catholic Church in the 19th century.

Comboni, who spent his career in Africa, is being recognized by the Vatican as a "genuine forbearer" of modern missionary work, reflected by his principle: "Save Africa for the Africans."

The ideas he promoted at the Vatican Council of 1869-70 were novel for their time -- a role for lay Roman Catholics and women in missionary work, for instance, and putting confidence in Africans to spread the Gospel themselves.

Born into a gardener's family in northern Italy in 1831, Comboni became a priest when he was 23 and left immediately for Africa.

He founded two orders, in 1867 and 1872, during the Vatican Council - - best known in history for enshrining the dogma of papal infallibility -- he got 70 bishops to sign a petition for the evangelization of central Africa.

In 1877 he was named vicar apostolic for central Africa, as he continued to devote himself to his work.

Comboni died in Khartoum, aged 50, but his work is carried on today by more than 4,000 so-called Combonians, including 14 bishops, who come from 30 countries.

They work in more than 40 countries in Africa, Asia, the America and Europe. Some have been arrested in Sudan and expelled.

Comboni's beatification -- a major step on the road to sainthood -- follows nearly seven decades of investigation by the church which ended in 1995 with the acknowledgement that a miracle said to have been experienced by a 10-year-old girl in a Brazilian slum was attributable to him.

The other missionary, Conforti, born in 1865, was archbishop of Parma, Italy for a quarter-century and became noteworthy for founding the congregation of St. Francis Xavier.

This order is best known for its work in China, where its first missionaries arrived in 1899.

It continued to operate there until the early 1950s, when Chairman Mao Zedong broke off ties with the Vatican -- at the time very anti- communist -- and expelled all foreign missionaries.

Despite its expulsion from China, Conforti's order carried on its work but elsewhere in Asia, in Latin America and Africa, notably in Zaire and Burundi, where its members witnessed the inter-tribal massacres that left at least 500,000 dead.

Two of its members were slain in Burundi last year, near Buyengero. The order today now counts 1,000 members, three of them bishops. Conforti died at the age of 66. His beatification process, from 1942 through last year, was completed upon verification of the supposedly miraculous return to health of a 13-year-old Burundi girl, who suffered from a tumor, in 1965.

Pope John Paul II has in recent years beatified many founders of missionary orders.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


188 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Uganda Mystery Surrounds Death Of American Professor


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 22, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Kampala - Mystery still surrounds the death of Prof. Rodney Belcher, the American orthopedic surgeon gunned down as he arrived for work outside his clinic at Old Mulago Hospital, Kampala on March 11.

Initially, police said Prof. Belcher, 64, considered "the father of orthopedics" (bone medicine) in Uganda was the victim of car robbers, but it has since emerged that there may have been sinister political motives associated with his murder. His death comes in the wake of a spate of violence directed against civilians by rebels in northern Uganda. At least 200 civilians have died as a result since the beginning of this month. 

On March 15, the United States Embassy in Kampala summoned more than 100 American citizens living and working in Uganda to update them on security issues following the cold blooded murder of Prof. Belcher.

Embassy spokesman, Julie Nickels said the meeting was convened "to sort out the facts "related to the murder of Prof. Belcher. "We did not want them to depend on rumours."

Prof. Belcher's Nissan Patrol was discovered in a Kampala suburb two days after he was killed. Ms. Nickels read out the note discovered in Prof. Belcher's car that said in part "We did not intend to kill... We did not need the car..."

Some sources in Kampala said the killers were an unknown group opposed to the support given by the American government to the government of Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni. Prof. Belcher, a Bahai, was buried at the Bahai House of Faith on Kikaya Hill just outside Kampala, in accordance with Bahai tenets that a dead body is not to be transported on a journey exceeding an hour.

Hundreds of his colleagues and patients wept openly for a man whose efforts have sustained the once run-down Orthopaedics Department.

Among mourners was Ugandan Vice-President, Dr. Specioza Kazibwe, a surgeon who was a former pupil of Prof. Belcher, the country's Health Minister James Makumbi who posthumously bestowed on Belcher the title "Honorary Consultant of the Ministry of Health of Uganda," the highest honour for the medical profession in Uganda.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Science, Medicine and Technology (DOCUMENT) Cholera On the Rise in Zaire


BYLINE: Federation of American Scientists March 15, 1996 by Dorothy B. Preslar


LENGTH: 147 words


 

Washington, D.C. - In the past three months there have been 22 outbreaks of cholera in Zaire. The cases have thus far been in Bukama, Likasi and Kalemie provinces in the southern mining district of Shaba; in Bolobo in Bandundu province; in Uvira in Kivu province and the capital city of Kinshasa.

According to news sources, a local WHO official said there had been 10 deaths out of 60 reported cases, but it is not known if that number represents a tally in Kinshasa or another location and for what period of
time.

A doctor at the capital's Mama Yemo hospital said there had been 12 cases in the past three days at that one facility alone.

Science, Medicine and Technology Scientists Convene Mining & Energy Meeting in Ethiopia


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency March 22, 1996


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Axum - Scientists from 21 African countries including Eritrea and Ethiopia have gathered in this historical town to share experiences and knowledge in mining and energy.

Taking part in a five-day international workshop convened Friday, participants would deal with both theoretical and practical aspects of mining and energy with particular emphasis on different types of minerals and stones. 

Ethiopian senior geologist Dr. Tarekegn Tadesse said participants are expected to map out prospect uses for various minerals including gold, copper and zinc after at least 20 days field visit in Eritrea and Tigray regional state.

The prospectuses to be prepared in different languages would provide ample information to the public, investors and foreign companies, he added.

Eritrean mining division representative Wolde-Gabriel Genzebu and water resources, mining and energy bureau head in Tigray Ato Berhanu Wondifraw said the outcome of the workshop, held after peace and democracy had held firmly in the country, would make significant contribution to ward tapping regional resources for the benefit of the people.

Ethiopia Patriarch Seeks to Popularise the Faith


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency March 22, 1996


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Addis Ababa - A statement issued March 18, 1996 by the Patriarchate said the aim of the recent publication of a book by the Ethiopian Orthodox Church (EOC) was to popularize the fundamentals of the Christian faith among its followers and foreign readers.

The statement read out at an appraisal meeting indicated that the book would have a significant contribution in promoting the Christian belief among the Orthodox worshipers. 

According to the statement the book titled "Belief, rituals and foreign relations" will also have a role of facilitating mutual assistance with sisterly churches through the World Federation of Churches.

It sharply criticised demonstrators who took out to the streets last week demanding the evaluation of the book by elite's from churches and monasteries, saying that it was prepared and published with the approval of the church's scholars and the Holy Synod.

With regard to the construction of the Patriarch Palace, the statement said it is the living symbol of national unity, societal progress, the preservation of cultural and historical heritage's, and the dignity and sovereignty of the church.

The psychology of the demonstrators taken into consideration, the statement said, they are bent on attaining the sinister aim of personal enrichments under the pretext of protecting workers rights.

The meeting attended by archbishops, administrators of churches and monasteries in Addis Ababa, the laity and students of Sunday schools as well as the elderly, has called on the faithful who, it said, innocently participated in the demonstration to refrain from such activities.

Meeting participants vowed to stand along side the church which, they said, under the leadership of His Holiness Abune Paulos, Patriarch of the EOC, has registered remarkable achievements in the development endeavours.

192 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zimbabwe 'A King Like Mugabe Is Not Contested'


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 22, 1996 by Iden Wetherell


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Johannesburg - The state-owned media tried to put a brave face on it. "Landslide win for Mugabe", trumpeted The Herald after the final tally in Zimbabwe's presidential poll was in. But nothing could disguise the truth: the result was a humiliating blow to the nation's 72- year-old ruler. 

Robert Mugabe had been anxious to crown his fourth term with what his Zanu PF party had forecast as "a crushing victory". Over his 16 years of iron rule, "landslide" and "crushing" have become common epithets to describe Mugabe's carefully managed electoral triumphs. All that is history now. Last weekend's contest may indeed have seen the incumbent raking in more than 90% of the votes cast. But with a 30% turnout of eligible voters, this was hardly the unambiguous mandate he had sought.

The result is all the more remarkable given the pressure on voters to return the president to power. Rural voters were left in no doubt that the distribution of maize and seed packs was dependent upon their continued obedience. And village headmen were given the task of delivering their communities to the polling stations. White farmers, who had received the usual drubbing from Mugabe during the campaign, were also told to transport their workers to the polls. They dutifully obliged.

In the townships, bands of Zanu PF youths were despatched to find reluctant voters. Although Mugabe didn't repeat the scarcely veiled threat he made in April's parliamentary poll, that people not voting might be mistaken for opposition supporters, his officials did make it clear they expected people to vote in large numbers so there could be no doubt at home or abroad as to where the country stood.

When his two lightweight opponents, Ndabaningi Sithole and Bishop Abel Muzorewa, withdrew from the contest, Mugabe went on TV to declare their withdrawal invalid, exhorting the nation to go to the polls. For once, Zanu PF's formidable propaganda machine failed.

In a sense, Mugabe has been the victim of his own success. Having established a de facto one-party state which discourages dissent of any sort, he has been left in solitary possession of a vacant field.

Zanu PF secretary for administration Didymus Mutasa reflected a view widely held in his party when he told British journalists that "Mugabe is our king. A king like Mugabe is not contested." He added disarmingly that "this exercise we are only doing to satisfy outside interests".

The president recently declared his opposition to reform of the Constitution which was tailored for a presidential dictatorship. But this latest hollow contest will now push reform to the top of the political agenda. In particular, attention will focus on media regulation, electoral laws, the sweeping Presidential Powers Act, and the Political Parties (Finance) Act which benefits only the ruling party.

Whatever is proposed, one thing is certain: Mugabe will no longer be able to claim the mandate of the masses in resisting change.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


193 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Swaziland and South Africa Mandela's Secret Plan


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 22, 1996 by Stefaans Brummer


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Johannesburg - Secret discussions between King Mswati III and Nelson Mandela have left diplomats pondering the details of a policy they are to implement, reports

PRESIDENT Nelson Mandela is playing his cards in the Swaziland democratisation game close to his chest -- so close, in fact, that Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo and South Africa's Foreign Affairs Department are in the dark about the details of his strategy.

Mandela has taken immense personal interest in helping Swaziland resolve its domestic crisis, which came to a head in January when virtually the entire workforce, led by the Swaziland Federation of Trade Unions (SFTU), embarked on a one-week stayaway to demand a return to constitutional rule.

Last Saturday Mandela, joined by his counterparts from Botswana and Zimbabwe, Quett Masire and Robert Mugabe, met with Swaziland's young King Mswati III in Pretoria. It followed a meeting on March 1 between Mandela and Mswati in Swaziland. 

At both meetings, only the heads of state spoke and not even Nzo, who was at the Pretoria venue last weekend, joined in.

This week neither Nzo nor Foreign Affairs Director General Rusty Evans had been briefed on what had been said, a senior Foreign Affairs official confirmed. South African diplomats admitted to a degree of frustration at not knowing the details of a policy they are supposed to implement, but acknowledged Mandela's indulgence of the king's need for absolute confidentiality may be the only way.

"We have no knowledge of the contents (of the talks). It is quite a problem for us, because we have to work with it. Our Swazi counterparts also do not know what has been said," a member of South Africa's High Commission in Mbabane, capital of Swaziland, said.

But he believed Mandela's strategy had a purpose: "Mswati cannot be humiliated before his own people, and he cannot appear to be succumbing to pressure. But there will definitely be pressure on him, from inside Swaziland and from outside ... and from President Mandela."

Mswati's father, the late King Sobhuza II, suspended Swaziland's Westminster-style constitution in 1973, banning political parties and free political activity. Mswati (27) ---who rules as absolute monarch, the last in sub-Saharan Africa -- has publicly blamed "foreigners" for the troubles in his country and, as a sovereign monarch in a deeply traditional society, has repeatedly demonstrated he will not appear to succumb to pressure.

It is widely held -- and South African foreign policy is premised on this assessment -- that Mswati is personally in favour of at least limited change, but is held back by his traditional advisers and the extended royal family, which stands to lose more from reform.

Around August last year, Mswati invited Mandela on a state visit to Swaziland, where it is understood he intended to use the cover of general relations to discuss the clamour for democracy in his country.

While that visit did not materialise, Zulu King Goodwill Zwelethini had talks with Mswati in which the benefits of democracy and a return to a constitutional monarchy were apparently raised.

Then Mandela's deputy Thabo Mbeki was to have visited Swaziland during the labour unrest earlier this year, primarily to discuss a long-standing land claim the kingdom has against South Africa. But Mswati stopped the visit; a move interpreted by South Africa at the time as an attempt by the king not to have it appear that Mbeki was there to advise on Swaziland's internal situation.

Meanwhile, Mandela was coming under increasing pressure to ensure Swaziland moves towards democracy. A source close to the presidency said Mandela, who had taken an active personal stance against Nigerian military dictator Sani Abacha, was being criticised for not taking an equally tough line against undemocratic rule in a neighbouring country.

The Congress of South African Trade Unions, which is close to the SFTU, also agitated for South Africa to get involved. "We couldn't delay any longer," the source said.

Mandela invited Mswati to visit Pretoria on March 1. Mswati agreed, but asked for secrecy. When the President's office announced that it would take place -- apparently under the mistaken impression that it would be enough to keep the contents secret as opposed to the fact of the meeting -- Mswati called it off. Mandela offered to visit Mswati in Swaziland instead, where they had one-on-one talks.

It is believed Mandela would have stressed to Mswati the importance of reform, but did not want to be seen again to be the "bullyboy of the region", an epithet reinforced when Mandela outpaced his regional partners in criticism of Abacha.

Mandela asked Masire and Mugabe -- significantly, the two who had helped him avert a coup in Lesotho in 1994 -- to join him for last Saturday's discussions in Pretoria.

The source close to the presidency said Mswati had wanted this meeting to be a secret too, but it was confirmed when a Swazi journalist got wind of it. "It is very difficult to keep a meeting secret if you bring together four heads of government," he said.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


194 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa and Mozambique Witness in Generals' Trial Reveals Renamo links


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 22, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Johannesburg - A key witness in the Magnus Malan trial has provided details of the close-knit relationship between military officers who ran clandestine supply lines to Renamo rebels in Mozambique and the covert plan to use Inkatha as a surrogate offensive force against the ANC inside South Africa.

One of JP Opperman's rare outbursts in court this week about secret military operations outside of Operation Marion corroborates widely-held beliefs that support for Renamo and Inkatha were two sides of the same coin in the 1980s.

When he was told under cross-examination that the accused would deny his allegations, Opperman announced he wanted to tell the court that they could "deny as much as they like" but he knew they had lied to the National Party government and the South African public for years after the Nkomati Accord was signed with Mozambique.

Asked to explain what Opperman was getting at, Colonel Frank Dutton of the Investigative Task Unit said the witness had given the team an affidavit that describes personal involvement in clandestine support by special forces of the SADF for Renamo rebels in Mozambique in breach of the accord. 

"He alleges that in the early part of 1988 he and others drove a military convoy through the Kruger National Park to a fence on the Mozambican border. He says they stopped there and that Renamo soldiers climbed onto the trucks and offloaded the supplies. Radio equipment was allegedly part of the equipment."

Much of the information contained in secret military documents placed before the courts detail how Operation Marion was seen by its architects as a strategy to turn the Renamo option, which had brought Mozambique's leftwing government to its knees, inside on the country.

The special forces unit that ran Renamo operations for many years after the non- aggression Nkomati Accord was signed with Mozambique in 1984, the Directorate of Special Tasks (DST), was the same unit that set up Operation Marion -- named for its aim to turn Inkatha into a marionette or surrogate of Pretoria's special forces.

The same men who ran Renamo operations from DST headquarters in Pretoria were responsible for implementing a State Security Council decision to set up Operation Marion. Three of the accused -- Brigadier Cornelius Van Niekerk, Brigadier John More and Colonel Cornelius van Tonder -- were directly involved in coordinating support for Renamo in direct violation of the Nkomati accord.

The DST was also in charge of training Unita soldiers in northern Namibia.

Opperman was the commander of seven Unita bases in the Caprivi Strip before he applied for a transfer to the base that had been set up in the same area for Inkatha's paramilitary squads.

Atrocities committed by Renamo have been described by an American State Department report as worse than those of the Pol Pot regime in Cambodia. The cost of South African- sponsored wars of destabilisation in Angola and Mozambique has been estimated by the Southern African Research and Documentation Service in Harare at more than a million lives and between$45-billion and $60-billion since 1980.

Senior officials in the truth commission confirmed this week they will be monitoring testimony delivered at the Malan trial even if it is not directly relevant to the execution of the KwaMakutha massacre -- and that violations of human rights and international law, committed outside South Africa's borders, will be scrutinised by the commission.

So if the evidence presented at the trial shows that some of the accused were involved in facilitating Renamo's abuses, described by some as among the worst committed in the world this century, it is likely they will be called to account regardless of the trial's outcome.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


195 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa St Lucia's Villagers Feel Snubbed on Mining Ban


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 22, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 1494 words


 

Johannesburg - People living in the Dukuduku forest on the outskirts of St Lucia are threatening to blockade the holiday town in peak season over the Easter weekend in protest against the Cabinet's move this month to ban titanium mining in the nearby nature reserve.

Local plans to organise a "strike" over the government's decision could embarrass African National Congress ministers Derek Hanekom and Kader Asmal, along with National Party minister Dawie de Villiers -- all three have committed themselves to consulting widely before taking important government action.

On March 6 a ministers' committee -- made up of Hanekom from Land Affairs, Asmal from Water Affairs and Forestry, De Villiers from Environment Affairs and Tourism and Ben Ngubane from Arts, Culture, Science and Technology -- issued a statement saying dune mining would not be allowed so that "the great tourism potential of the area can now be fully exploited".

A broad alliance of some 200 environmental organisations under the umbrella of the Save St Lucia Campaign has waged a protracted battle -- probably the longest and biggest green protest in the country's history -- to stop Richards Bay Minerals from stripmining the rare coastal dunes north of St Lucia dunes.

They are delighted at the Cabinet's move, saying mining would have devastated a rare combination of ecosystems and that nature- tourism is bound to bring in more jobs. 

But representatives of the two Dukuduku communities told the Mail & Guardian that the government made its landmark decision without speaking to them -- even though their livelihoods will probably be the most seriously affected.

Some of the elders who live in the Dukuduku forest were forcibly removed from the proposed mining site on the eastern shores in the mid- 1950s and feel they should especially have been consulted as formal claims for restitution have been lodged by their representatives.

These people live a marginal existence in the forest, growing bananas and other crops illegally. They are among the poorest communities in KwaZulu-Natal and claim that nature conservation and tourism have always been detrimental to their lifestyles (see accompanying story).

A few of the residents told an M&G team, who joined two community meetings in the forest over the weekend, that the government's announcement was no different to that of old apartheid decrees despite cabinet claims that "amakhosi" from the region discussed and agreed with the move.

"We can be happy if this government can take us back to the land. We should be part of the decision on whether Richards Bay be chased away from there or if we are to have nature conservation and tourism. We are the owners of the land," said an old man named MS Gumede at a civic meeting held on Sunday this week in a settlement called Dukuduku Two.

The hostility expressed towards Cabinet over its St Lucia move appears to derive from a general perception among the forest communities that a top-down decision was made about how local peoples' land should be used -- thus pre-empting the outcome of formal land claims by two groups who say they used to live on the eastern shores.

"It is all the same story," said Raymond Nkuni at the civic meeting. "We don't know if we would have benefited from mining. We don't know if we would benefit from tourism and conservation. All we know is that nobody has spoken to us. Now that we have applied to get our land back, they are telling us what to do with it."

Most people spoken to expressed general support for mining because "you can see that we need jobs very badly here" and an overwhelming hostility towards "nature" (the Natal Parks Board) who they blame for arresting people who go into the nature reserve to fish or to visit old ancestral graves.

These sentiments were shared by speakers at another community in Dukuduku One which is made up of settlers who have invaded the forest and subsist there by growing bananas and sweet potatoes through slash-and-burn agriculture and by fishing illegally in the St Lucia estuary.

Dukuduku One is an Inkatha Freedom Party stronghold, while people at Dukuduku Two are politically non-aligned. The latter is a more settled area made up of people who agreed to move out of the forest in return for proper housing sites and the promise of development services.

It thus appears that disillusionment in the forest at the Cabinet decision crosses political lines. Speakers from both meetings said they would back an Easter-time blockade during the peak tourist season at St Lucia -- - although formal threats and plans to organise the protest have come only from the IFP's Youth Brigade in the nearby town of KwaMbonambi.

Two groups of people who claim to be the legitimate owners of the eastern shores, one led by Chief Mineas Mkhwanazi and the other by Chief Phineas Mbuyaze, have lodged official claims for the eastern shores with the Land Claims Commission in KwaZulu-Natal.

The St Lucia area was annexed as state land to the colony of Natal in 1897. People continued to live in the area and were removed in the mid-1950s after the area was declared a state forest.

The ministers' committee said in its statement that the decision to ban mining on the eastern shores had to be made urgently because "the uncertainty had a detrimental effect on development" and that it was taken only after discussing the matter fully with the KwaZulu- Natal government and the "amakhosi".

It added: "It was also decided that an application to register St Lucia as a World Heritage Site would go ahead urgently ... The Cabinet also decided that consultants be appointed to investigate and advise on an optimal strategy for sustainable development at St Lucia ... It was agreed that acceptable alternatives to the restoration of the land would be further explored with the affected amakhosi."

Hanekom's office failed to comment at the time of going to press when asked about the apparent discrepancy between his committee's claim that it had consulted the chiefs and popular attitudes expressed at the community meetings.

Asmal's office referred similar queries to the Department of Environment Affairs and Tourism. De Villiers's office replied by saying: "The debate surrounding the future of St Lucia has dragged on for many years and during this time interested parties and stakeholders have had ample opportunity to make an input."

De Villiers's officials, in turn, referred the M&G to NJ Ngubane, MEC for Traditional and Environmental Affairs in the KwaZulu-Natal provincial government, for details about which chiefs had apparently endorsed the Cabinet decision.

Ngubane's office had failed to reply to repeated queries by the time of our going to press.

But representatives from some of the environmental organisations that ran the campaign to save St Lucia from mining admit that they found it difficult during the five- year campaign to recruit support from rural communities who have a stake in the future of the eastern shores.

"The only solution is action now with local communities coming into new ecotourism lodges around the estuary as full partners. We need to show in a concrete way that they can benefit more from mining than they would have from tourism," adds Wally Menne, a supporter of the Campaign to Save St Lucia.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa How Mandela and His Deputies Will Use Their Cash


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 22, 1996 by Rehana Rossouw


LENGTH: 1440 words


 

Johannesburg - President Nelson Mandela's office will spend R21-million this year, Executive Deputy President Thabo Mbeki R9-million and Deputy President FW de Klerk R12-million.

This pays for the smooth running of their offices and households: all three have offices and official homes in Cape Town and Pretoria.

Last week, the delivery of four luxury armoured Mercedes Benzes to the Houses of Parliament for Mandela and his deputies caused a stir when it was discovered the Department of Transport spent R1-million on each and has ordered three more for use in Gauteng.

However, the department's spokesman, Elsa Kruger denied the purchase was "reckless", saying they had a responsibility to ensure the safety of the president and his deputies. 

While the three-headed presidency does add an additional burden to the tax-paying public because of the addition of two deputies, surprisingly the trio's administration is still far more streamlined than PW Botha's Tuynhuys staff of 500. Their combined staff is 309.

President Nelson Mandela's financial comptrollers received an explicit instruction from the South African head of state to keep his budget increase to a minimum this year -- - up from R16 299 000 to R21 705 000 -- because he wants to set an example of fiscal discipline.

The R5-million increase, says his spokesman Parks Mankahlana, is a reflection of the increase of the duties and demands on the president which have spiralled enormously compared to those in the previous dispensation.

Other reasons were the implementation of the newly-appointed Commission on the Remuneration of Representatives at a cost of R1-million and an increase in the staff of the office.

New staffers will be appointed in a new directorate of personal services and in expanding existing components of the president's office.

The largest allocation in the budget -- R17- million -- is for adminstration costs with expenditure for the 190 staffers increasing by 36 percent this year. Mandela had 206 staffers last year.

His salary is R552 000 a year, including a R115 000 car allowance. His budget also includes a salary of R352 000 for RDP Minister Jay Naidoo, including a car allowance of R70 560.

The president's office employs six messengers, an operator, three drivers, two telecom operators, four secretaries, 19 typists, five accounting clerks, 11 clerks, four network controllers, one programmer, seven personnel officers, six registry clerks, nine administrative officers, four personnel practitioners, three state accountants, two communication officers, five assistant directors, nine deputy directors, six directors, two chief directors and a director general.

His household staff includes 61 cleaners, three food service aides, eight household aides, a general foreman, a storekeeper, three household managers, one guesthouse manager, two household supervisors and two household controllers. The Department of Public Works employs gardeners and pays for general repairs and renovations, but no major work is planned for this year.

R2-million has been allocated for Cabinet services, which involve providing secretarial and executive services to the Cabinet and its committees.

Taxpayers can rest assured: the president isn't planning any wild parties with their money. His modest entertainment allowance of R290 000 for the year, which he shares with his senior management, will be used for state banquets for visiting foreign dignitaries as well.

Executive Deputy President Thabo Mbeki asked for R10-million this year but was only allocated R9 387 000 -- an increase of six percent over last year.

"Despite being the second most senior political office in the country, we have one of the smallest budgets and are headed by an office with the rank of only chief director," said Mbeki's spokesman Ricky Naidoo.

Besides the ongoing responsibilities delegated by Mandela, Mbeki's office has the additional burden this year of establishing an Office on the Status of Women, Youth and the Disabled.

Mbeki earns R480 000 a year, including an R80 000 car allowance.

His staff complement grew from 50 last year to 63. His office staff includes five clerks, an administrative officer, an administrative secretary, a personnel assistant director, a financial assistant director, a chief director, an adminstrative director, a deputy adminstrative director, a driver, a minsterial typist, a network controller, a personnel practitioner, a messenger, a personnel officer, three private secretaries, a public relations officer, a registry clerk, eight secretaries, four special advisors and a telecom operator.

His household staff includes a food services aide, a household controller, two household managers, two housekeepers and six household aides.

The deputy president's office entertainment allocation for the year is R50 000, of which R30 000 is allocated to Mbeki specifically for meetings and consultations.

"It should be stressed that the entire allocation is not an entertainment allowance but is utilised exclusively in the performance of official duties," Naidoo said.

There is also R10 000 allocated for gifts, used exclusively by Mbeki and his wife.

Deputy President FW de Klerk's budget of R12- million may at first glance appear suspiciously larger than Mbeki's, but it includes major hidden costs as well.

There is R2,3-million allocated for the General Services Ministry and a further R1,9- million for the investigation into lotteries and gambling. The budget allocated directly to De Klerk is R8-million.

De Klerk's staff complement decreased from 61 last year to 56 this year. There are nine vacant posts, which will be filled by General Services Minister John Mavuso when he assumes office at the end of the month.

De Klerk earns R480 000 a year, including an R80 000 car allowance. Mavuso's salary is R424 000, including a car allowance of R70 560.

De Klerk's office staff includes two fulltime and four part-time advisors, an office head, an adminstrative director, a communications director, a deputy adminstrative director, three private secretaries, two administrative secretaries, a personnel officer, a network controller, six clerks, a driver, a messenger, a registry clerk, four secretaries, four typists and a chief administration clerk.

His household staff includes seven cleaners, three food service aides, four household aides, a household controller, a household manager and four housekeeping supervisors. The costs of managing his official household amount to R1 067 000.

His office provides advisory services to Mbeki and the General Services Ministry, as well as to National Party ministers on economic, constitutional, education, health and welfare and legal matters.

De Klerk's allowance for entertainment is R159 000 with R10 000 annually for gifts.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996
