Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa Winnie Left Empty-Handed


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 22, 1996 by Philippa Garson


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Johannesburg - Lawyers are baffled at how Winnie Madikizela- Mandela's legal team handled the divorce, which ended so suddenly, with her defeated and empty-handed.

A successful challenge to the divorce judgment in the Constitutional Court is seen as unlikely. Madikizela-Mandela must now rely on the "goodness of heart" of President Nelson Mandela, who has offered her an ex gratia settlement and waived legal costs she was ordered to pay. 

He has already paid her at least R3-million and two of his daughters R1,3-million.

Lawyers said it was "unheard of" to request a postponement for reconciliation purposes. Details like these and the question of his assets would be discussed in pre-trial conferences. Madikizela-Mandela dodged confronting the issue until it came to court. But when it did, she and her legal team were entirely unprepared for it.

While weeks of court disclosures on more intimate details of the marriage would have ground the country to a voyeuristic standstill, the theoretical possibility exists that elements potentially harmful to the president's image could have emerged in court.

Dismissing her advocate Ismail Semenya led Judge Frikkie Eloff to request her to defend herself. Unable or unwilling to do this, she did not arrive in court the following day and so lost the opportunity to fight for a portion of his assets. The judge could reopen the settlement hearing if she furnishes very good reasons for her absence in court within the next two weeks.

But legal sources say had she arrived in court that day and asked for a postponement until she acquired a new legal team, she would have got it.

Having been married to the president for 38 years she stood to gain as much as a third of his estate. Or, had she simply settled out of court her settlement could have been "handsome".

Madikizela-Mandela has since denied firing Semenya, a Natal University graduate and member of a panel of legal experts to the Constituent Assembly. Semenya served on the Skweyiya Commission into corruption in former Bophuthatswana and co-authored a book on the draft Constitution.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


198 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa Mandela versus Mandela


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 22, 1996 by Philippa Garson


LENGTH: 960 words


 

Johannesburg - The flagrant contravention by the media this week of a section of the Divorce Act has raised questions about whether that aspect of the legislation is unconstitutional.

The media had a "field-week" reporting on the ins and outs of the emotional court room drama of one of the world's most high-profile divorce cases -- that between 77-year-old President Nelson Mandela and his former wife, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela.

This, despite the fact that the Divorce Act limits reporting on divorce to the names of the parties, the fact of the divorce action and the judgment.

Mandela, his legal team or Justice Frikkie Eloff could by rights have objected to the publication of details of the divorce and the transgressors (the media at large) would face a maximum prison sentence of one year and/or a fine of R1 000. 

A member of Mandela's legal team said: "I don't know what our client's attitude is. We did not discuss it and no one from our legal side expressed any objection. The publicity did not do him any harm. It would have done him more harm if the trial was held in secret."

He added that the team would not want to enforce a ban whose constitutionality was up for question and that the "paltry" penalty for contravention would not act as a deterrent to the media in such a high-profile case.

The ban was a good one in certain instances, but should allow for discretion in cases like the Mandela divorce which contained elements of public interest, he said.

Most would agree that Mandela's almost indestructible image was in no way damaged by revelations of his private life. In fact, if possible, it was even enhanced, evoking deep sympathy for him from the public. But things could have been different if, for example, Madikizela-Mandela had given evidence and made damaging allegations against him. This was an unlikely but not impossible scenario given that she contested the divorce.

According to lawyers, this is the first time such a flagrant contravention has been made since the Act was amended in 1979.

The details of the divorce between high-flying socialites Philip Tucker and Anneline Kriel were reported only because they emerged in a criminal trial arising from dagga charges against the two.

The issue highlights the tension between the public's right to know and an individual's right to privacy. Do public figures forgo all rights to privacy?

Leading divorce lawyer Billy Gundlefinger said he was "astounded by the flagrant disregard of the law by the media. Just because he's the president, why should he have his personal life paraded?"

Constitutional expert Dennis Davis said it could be argued that the provision was unconstitutional in that it infringed on the right to freedom of expression.

However he said he found it "unbelievable" that such a provision, no matter how controversial, was so brazenly breached. "Being president gives you a reduced right to privacy but it can't possibly destroy your privacy completely. He might be the most famous person in the world but he is not public property."

Raymond Louw, chairman of the Freedom of Expression Institute (FXI), was part of a Newspaper Press Union delegation to the former government opposing the amendment when it was passed, believing that it was introduced to hide potentially important information from the public.

"I'm all in favour of divorce evidence being available to the public on the grounds that the public has a right to know," said Louw.

He continued to say that "double standards" were implicit if people were allowed to listen to court proceedings but media were prevented from reporting them.

"I feel sympathy for the President that his private life has to be bundled out in public in this way, but this is the price one pays for democracy."

Director of the FXI Jeanette Minnie said the public had a right to know about the divorce partly because "the country has felt the ramifications of the tensions between the two. It has been part of the political scenario on South Africa over the past few years."

The right to privacy versus the public's right to know "are not in contradiction so much as that they encroach on each other. The constitutional court must balance them." Minnie said it took 10 years for a country to establish new constitutional law. The organisation is involved in a research project identifying bits and pieces of existing legislation that places curbs on press freedom.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


199 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa Mandela in Court: The President's Masterful Performance


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 22, 1996 by David Beresford


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Johannesburg - In the final adjournment on Tuesday in the case of Mandela vs Mandela -- waiting for the Judge President of the Transvaal, Judge Frikkie Eloff, to deliver the by-now inevitable decree of divorce -- the state president sat slumped in his chair, gazing into the middle distance.

Gone was his bonhomie with the press and his old-world gallantry with his beautiful junior counsel.

In the rare glimpse of misery on his unguarded face, it was possible to read the story of a family life gone wrong: the brutal break-up with his first wife; the loss of a beloved son in a car crash; the turbulent life of a fatherless Zinzi ... and now Winnie.

"I have been fairly successful in putting on a mask behind which I have pined for the family, alone," he once told Winnie in a letter from Robben Island. 

At 3.15pm on Tuesday the stony-faced mask of dignity was back on. But as Judge Eloff pronounced the decree, one could sense that behind the mask he was mourning another loss, another defeat.

And yet, curiously, the divorce action represented yet another triumph in the life of Nelson Mandela. Because, behind the salacious detail of bedroom snubs, adultery and Winnie's extravagance, the court heard a testament from the president which was reminiscent of the glorious "speech from the dock" at Rivonia.

Ishmael Semenya, counsel for Winnie Madikizela- Mandela (as she now wishes to be known) faced an almost impossible task in his conduct of the defence and it was mirrored in the increasingly desperate smiles with which he met the president's rejoinders to his questions.

Semenya's task was to clear the way for two key witnesses underpinning the defence: the former security branch agent, Paul Erasmus, and Chief Kaiser Matanzima.

Erasmus was to give substance to that familiar refrain that apartheid was to blame -- that dirty tricks operations by the top-secret police unit "Stratcom" had poisoned the well- spring of the marriage.

That established, Matanzima was to take the marital dispute out of the jurisdiction of the court into the realm of tribal "custom" in which the affairs of Thembu royalty were arbitrated and mediated by their peers.

Semenya battled to breach Mandela's implacable refusal to give ground on either count. "Winnie underwent gross persecution, brutal treatment by the police," conceded the president. But, he qualified: "There were many women in this country who suffered far more than she did," citing Albertina Sisulu as an example.

Madikizela-Mandela's counsel continued pressing the line of security police manipulation. "I have never been influenced by my enemies, by those ... who sent me to jail for 27 years," the president flared with exasperation.

Finally, he resorted to threat. Declaring there were "even more serious reasons why I left home", he said: "I appeal to you not to put any questions which might compel me to reveal facts which might damage her image and bring pain to my children and grandchildren."

Semenya had even more difficulty with Matanzima, Mandela bridling at every mention of the former homeland leader's name. Denouncing the chief as a "collaborator" and a "liar", Mandela said: "Nothing agitates me more than the attempt to bring Matanzima into these proceedings."

The efforts by the defence to establish the superiority of tribal custom over civil law earned the court a lecture on the subject. "I respect custom. But I am not a tribalist. I fought as an African nationalist and I have no commitment to the custom of any particular tribe," he told Judge Eloff.

As for the right of Tembu chiefs to interfere in a civil divorce suit: "This particular kind of custom I am not even aware of."

It was hopeless and Semenya knew it. As he bowed his way out of the cross-examination -- - "no further questions, my lord" -- the case was already over. He had failed to challenge the adultery allegation and failed to establish the faintest prospect of reconciliation. The president had shut him out.

As Judge Eloff finished pronouncing the final decree and rose, Mandela the litigant stood with the rest of the courtroom in respect for the bench. Then Mandela, the president, barked an order to his aides who scurried across the courtroom to summon Semenya to his presence.

The diminutive lawyer hurried, wide-eyed to him. Mandela solemnly shook his hand and congratulated him on his conduct of the defence. The mask was in place. It was the closing scene of a truly presidential performance.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia: Vice-Chancellor Fails To Convince UNZA Students


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 20, 1996 by Kunda Mwila


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - University of Zambia acting Vice-Chancellor Jorry Mwenechanya yesterday failed to convince students who are on a class boycott over government's intentions to underpay them this month's meal allowance to resume normal activities.

"I have done just what you demanded, I have written the letter to the Bursaries Committee and the Ministry of Education is informed, the issue of the semester break is not a problem anymore," Mwenechanya reported to students who had earlier given him an hour ultimatum to sort out the two issues. 

The class boycott which started on Monday evening caused confusion at the Great East Road Campus after students learned that government intended to deduct K21,000 for the week during which students will be on a Mid-Semester break which begins on Good Friday and that students will not be allowed to remain in their rooms.

Mwenechanya, heavily guarded by university employed security men had difficult time calming down the irate students.

"What I would like to appeal to you now is to leave the matter in the hands of the students executive," Mwenechanya pleaded. "I would like the rest of you to report for normal class work at 14hrs."

But students, uttering invectives and booing him, maintained they will not relent until they get their K90, 000. They refused to return to classes.

"The situation will be determined by the outcome of our meeting with the Bursary Committee this afternoon (Tuesday)," University of Zambia Students Union (UNZASU) president Emmanuel Tembo said in an interview. "Meanwhile, the class boycott continues."

Efforts to get the comment from education ministry failed.

By yesterday afternoon, armed paramiltary officers were deployed along the Great East Road.

March, 1996


Zambia Party Works on Master Plan For '96


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 21, 1996 by George Jambwa


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - The United National Independence Party (UNIP) is working on what it calls a "master plan" to thwart any attempts to bar its president, Kenneth Kaunda, from contesting the forth coming presidential elections .

Addressing pressmen in Lusaka yesterday, UNIP publicity secretary Bweendo Mulengela said the master plan was already on the drawing board and would be set in motion if attempts to bar Kaunda are made. 

"We will unveil our master plan if MMD attempts to bar our presidential candidate from contesting the forthcoming presidential elections," Mulengela promised, adding: "The plan is already on the drawing board."

But Mulengela declined to disclose the contents of the master plan.

"I can't disclose what the plan contains as at now. But all I can say is that it is a peaceful master plan. It does not contain guns or bullets. We are a peaceful party and we always discuss peace," he said.

Mulengela was reacting to government spokesman, Amusaa Mwanamwambwa's refusal to yield to UNIP's demands that the draft constitution bill, which contains a clause which bars second generation Zambians from standing for presidency, be withdrawn from parliament.

And in another development, Mulengela has announced that the UNIP central committee would meet soon and discuss health minister Micheal Sata's threats against Kaunda's relatives and other opposition leaders.

"I will consult the central committee very soon so that we can discuss Sata and then we may consider making a formal complaint to police," Mulengela said.

Africa-at-Large Swimming: Two Teams Enter Gala


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 21, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia has entered two teams in the International Swimming Gala which opens in Lusaka at the weekend.

The two day tournament at Olympia Swimming bath has attracted more than three countries and the locals were hopeful of scooping medals and emerging the overall winners. 

Zambia Amateur Swimming Union ( ZASU) president, Nangalingham Sothy- lingham, declared yesterday: "I hate to predict that we are going to win.

"But we shall have the advantage of being at home."

Zimbabwe, Swaziland and Kenya are the three countries that will lock horns with Zambia.

According to Sothy- lingham, the first team will be termed "Zambia" and the second "Zambia A".

"We will field two teams with a total of 93 swimmers from the two teams because we want to win," disclosed Sothylingham.

Zimbabwe will field 29 swimmers, Kenya 38 with a paltry 13 coming from the tiny moutain kingdom of Swaziland.

Simon Faherty, who recently shattered four records at the Zambia Closed gala in Mufulira is expected to lead the Zambians to victory, especially that he has been listed for the 1996 Rothmans junior sportsman of the year award. Another swimmer likely to steer Zambia to victory is Ellen Hight, who is also in the running for the junior sportswoman of the year award.

March, 1996


Business and Finance Asbestos Firm To Be Sold


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 20, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia's only asbestos manufacturing firm, TAP building products, is to be sold for more than US$60 million together with the associated companies in neighbouring Zimbabwe.

The companies will be sold to African Resources Limited (ARL) based in Zimbabwe.

Managing director, Jeff Poole, said in an interview on Friday that TAP( holding company, T&N Plc of Zimbabwe, had agreed in principle to sell TAP Zambia and other companies. 

"This is a deal that incorporates not only TAP but a number of our Zimbabwean operations. The total cost of the deal is US$60 million," Poole said.

The announcement of the sale last week sent shivers among the workers who feared losing their jobs.

Workers union secretary, Brian Kalaluka, said in an interview yesterday that workers were uncertain about their future under the new owners.

"There were fears of job losses and retrenchment among the workers when the announcement of the sale was made last Thursday. But after we met the management, we assured them (workers) that no one would lose his job as a result of the sale everything has since stabilised, "fKalaluka said.

And group marketing manager, Roy Shepard reassured the workers that no one would be retrenched on the basis of the company sale .

"There are no plans for retrenchment that will come up as a result of the sale,"fShepard said.

Poole also shared Shepard's sentiments about the sale of the company.

"This is a very positive move for us. The new owners are very enthusiastic about the future," Poole said adding: "Instead of being just a very small part of a large multinational group with diverse interests we are going to be the core business of the new owners."

TAP has taken advantage of the monopoly in the region and recently sealed a deal with Malawi and Namibia to export roofing sheets worth K1 billion (about $ 1 million). .

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Business and Finance Relax Rules On Stock Exchange


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 21, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - Government has been urged to consider removing restrictions against foreigners buying shares in companies being floated on the Lusaka Stock Exchange (LuSE) for the first time to boost the securities business.

Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) chief executive, Mumba Kapumpa, told a seminar on Tuesday on emerging markets organised by Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) that the initial objective of enhancing share ownership by Zambians had largely been achieved with about 9,000 Zambians now owning shares in Chilanga Cement and Rothmans of Pall Mall which were floated last May and November. 

"Maybe there is need not to restrict shares to Zambians. The restriction was justifiable at the beginning but now it is unreasonable especially that we want to attract money into the the economy," Kapumpa said.

Kapumpa, who was speaking in his personal capacity argued that since foreigners were allowed to buy shares once they were listed on the secondary market, they might as well be allowed to participate in the initial flotations.

At present, deeds of the Zambia Privatisation Trust Fund (ZPTF) stipulate that shares previously owned by government can only be offered to Zambians through initial public offers while foreigners can only buy them once they are listed on the exchange through the secondary market.

ZPTF's Tom Ryan declined to comment on Kapumpa's proposal saying his job was simply to implement a decision passed by parliament: "We are implementing something that was done by parliament in the Privatisation Act."


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


205 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Party A Threat To Justice


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 21, 1996 by George Jambwa


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - A senior opposition leader and Human Rights activist fears that the judiciary in Zambia is likely to become subservient to the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD).

In a paper presented at a one day conference on Southern African and Constitutionalism held in the Zimbabwean capital, Harare, last weekend Liberal Progresive Front (LPF) president Roger Chongwe said the courts were slowly moving away from their roles as protectors of the rights and liberties of the citizens. 

Chongwe said during the second republic where the former ruling party UNIP was supreme over the three organs of the state - the executive, legislature and the judiciary - the judiciary demonstrated its independence even if the Inspector General of police, the army and airforce chiefs became membes of the party's central committee.

"Although there was strict adherence to the principle of the seperation of powers between and among the three organs of the state, nonetheless, as the years of one-party state took root and branch, pronouncements from the top party brass were to be heard entrenching UNIP as the supreme organ of the state.

"The functions between those of the only political party and the government became blurred and so did the distinction between the state's civil service and the party oligarchy. In this atmosphere, one would have naturally expected that the Judiciary would be subservient to the party, but it was not," Chongwe said in his paper.

He explained that the period of one party state rule in Zambia witnessed the growth of judicial activism.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Business and Finance Stock Exchange Praised


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 20, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - The Lusaka Stock Exchange (LuSE) has won praises from London based stock brokers Cazenove and Comapany for its impressive setup.

"There is a tremendous achievement at LuSE especially the depository and other systems in place," said Michael Wentworth-Stanley, a partner in the firm. 

Cazenove have been handling the Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) shares on the London Stock Exchange since 1932.

Wentworth-Stanley remarked that it was "odd" that there were only three listed companies on LuSE but he was sympathetic that the exchange was still in its infancy.

He suggested that the managers of LuSE should begin a marketing exercise to attract such investors.

"People to invest in small markets to exist," he said. "The key to finding them is marketing."

However, he noted that lack of liquidity and access to credit such as exist in Zambia could be an inhibiting factor to such investors.

James skinner who works in the Cazenove Johannesburg office said if more people like him came and were impressed, they would spread the word around about prospects in Zambia.

Earlier, Skinner said global emerging markets were attracting interest worldwide because of their tremendous gross domestic product growth potential which in many countries had exceeded the G7 countries average of about 2 per cent per annum.

However, he said factors which influenced investment decisions included sustainable economic growth, low inflation rates, deficit control, cost of capital and labour.

The meeting was organised by Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines and was attended by a cross section of the business community.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Let's Be Serious


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 22, 1996 by Sibalwa Mwanga (Column)


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - Many people are baffled by the Hon. Speaker's "judgment" leading to the jailing of Fred M'membe, Bright Mwape and "fugitive mother" Lucy sichone.In attempting to answer the numerous questions that have been directed to me on this matter, I have had to admit that I am equally baffled by the whole thing for it goes completely against my layman's perception of law and justice.

Observation

The only thing that did make sense to me though was Speaker Nabulyato's observation that this law is in fact archaic. 

He of course went on to say that archaic or not, it is still the law and we should all obey it until it is changed, or face the consequences as the Post trio have done. I have been pondering the speaker's words and I cannot but agree with his reasoning.

I mean people have examined the articles by Fred, Bright and Lucy, virtually putting them under a microscope in a futile effort to discover what hidden meanings could possibly be lurking between the lines that warrant an indefinite invitation to a government cell. They've all come up with zlich.

Archaic

If you happen to have had any luck, please let me know; I can offer K2m for the answer, but it would be nice to know. What is really baffling about this archaic piece of legislation is that it allows MPs to be stopped from debating certain issues. Quite recently in fact, the deputy speaker of the house stopped Hon. members from further debate on the defence budget. there was nothing wrong with that since the law allows it and the gentleman was perfectly within his rights.

what is against the law is for anybody else to make any remark that just might be interpreted as infringing on the MPs' freedom of debate in the house, whether or not such a comment in fact does curtail the Hon. members' freedom of debate.

Competent

I am not competent to judge which of these circumstances detracts more from the MPs' freedom of debate than the other.

What I am dead certain about is that Speaker Nabulyato was right:this law, if it in fact exists, is indeed archaic and needs to be changed. the sooner this is done, the better.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

March, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Government Appeals For Help For Pest Control


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 20, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - The state has sent out an urgent appeal to international donors agencies for funds to combat the deadly Larger Grain Borer (LGB) infestation threatening more than 15 million maize.

Government sources reveal that the target has been the European Union (EU).

"I know the government has submitted a project proposal to the EU and they have expressed interest in assisting," the source said. 

Agriculture ministry permanent secretary Austin Sichinga acknowledged the presence of the pest but refused to discuss measures that have been put in place to combat the scourge.

But the Zambia National Farmers Union (ZNFU) were more than concerned that the LGB has been allowed to spread to even the Northern, Central and Southern provinces.

ZNFU president Ben Kapita said the result of the infestation would be immediate not through crop losses but through the ban on maize movement.

"Once the maize marketing season has begun, this will undoubtedly reduce the price of maize in the latter two provinces which are major grain producing areas, while increasing prices in the urban centres,"fhe said.

Last Friday, experts in the agriculture ministry's plant protection unit expressed despair about their inability to act against the LGB because of the lack of funds.

"We are waiting for a response to our requests for funding," a highly placed official said. "It is a big project and it is not possible to use government funds alone."

Officials at the ministry of agriculture were yesterday locked in meetings with various officials possibly discussing strategies to combat the LGB.

On Friday, chairman of the LGB national committee Songowayo Zyambo accused the government of not taking the LGB invasion seriously.

President Chiluba on Wednesday last week warned officials in his ministry of dire consequences for failing to inform him about the invasion of the LGB.

The pest has in recent months been imported in large numbers from Tanzania through grain. It was first identified in this country in 1993.

March, 1996


Business and Finance Air France's Withdrawal To Affect Zambia's Tourism


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 21, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - The ailing tourism sector is to suffer yet another blow, when the long serving airline, Air France, stops its flights to Zambia later this month.

According to a ticket sales official at the airline, the last flight into the country would be March 27.

"It is true that the airline's last flight into the country will be on March 27 but after that, passengers intending to use the airline would have to use Aero Zambia which will be our feeder airline to Harare, Nairobi and Johannesburg for direct flights to Paris," the lady disclosed. 

Air France will be the second airline to pull out of Zambia after, Botswana Airways took a similar move two weeks ago.

Commenting on the development, prominent wildlife writer, Priscila D'elbee, felt the move would worsen Zambia's already 'chaotic' airlinks from abroad.

"Its difficult to tell people in France and Europe generally, how to get to Zambia especially with the worsening airlinks. People know Kenya and Zambia because of easy access to these places which have many direct airlinks," D'elbee said, adding: "People are interested in coming to Zambia but the airlinks are rather confusing to them."

And Chairman of the Hotels and Catering Association of Zambia, Gaudensio Rossi, said the drop in Hotel business was also a result of a reduction in the number of direct airlinks to the country and the government's continued delays in signing of the tourism lease agreements. "Do we need to go to the President to sign the lease agreements, it simply means that someone is not doing his job," Rossi said adding: "We feel badly let down by the delay and government should take the blame for our declining bsuiness."

Tourism minister, Gabriel Maka, refused to comment saying; he doesn't talk to The Post.

Tour Operators chairman, Mark Harvey said the develoment would adversely affect his industry.

"This will have tremendous effects on our industry especially that the French have shown a lot of interest in coming to Zambia," Harvey said.

The problem of accessibility to Zambia has further been compounded by the transport and communications ministry's delays to award international routes to the local airlines which was due in December last year.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia 'Proposals On Judiciary A Recipe For Anarchy'


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 20, 1996 by Mukalya Nampito


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - The Magistrates and Judges Association (MJA) and the Law Association of Zambia (LAZ) have described as a recipe for anarchy government proposals on the judiciary.

They say the recent proposed Constitutional Amendment Bill which contains a clause which empowers the President to dismiss a Judge for gross misconduct is unprecedented in Commonwealth jurisprudence.

Both the MJA and LAZ have said this amendment is an erosion of the independence of the judiciary. 

"Draft article 98 (3) which provides for the removal of a judge from office by the president subject to ratification by National Assembly is a recipe for anarchy in that the term 'gross misconduct' upon which a judge will be removed will receive a subjective interpretation by the president and National Assembly," the MJA through its chairman, Timothy Katanekwa said yesterday, adding: "where such a situation exists the continuance in office of judges particularly in circumstances where they preside over cases with political implications will be left to the pleasure of the President and the National Assembly."

Katanekwa also declared: "This situation is totally alien in the Commonwealth and an erosion of the independence of the judiciary which we feel is rather unfortunate and should not be allowed in our country."

He also confirmed the views he was expressing were aired by judges at a meeting held last week.

And LAZ said the essence of the decision will give the President the power of interpreting the law.

"The present constitution provides that the Supreme court will be the final body that will interpret the constitution or any written law. This is consistent with all constitutions in democratic societies. It is also consistent with the principles of separation of power and independence of the judiciary," the LAZ statement said yesterday, and added; "It also inculcates the populace with a sense of confidence in the judiciary."

According to Article 98 (3) "a judge of the Supreme Court or High Court shall be removed from office by the President, subject to ratification by the National Assembly, for gross misconduct."

MJA feels that once the independence of the judiciary is eroded, the integrity of the judiciary will quickly follow suit and the nation will be placed on a fast track to anarchy as people might tend to take the law into their own hands.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Business and Finance Aircraft Fleet To Increase


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 22, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - Aero Zambia will soon increase its fleet of aircraft to four with the delivery of another Boeing 737, an official said yesterday.

"It is true Aero Zambia is adding another B737 QC aircraft to its fleet and that this aircraft is currently undergoing pre-flight tests in Johannesburg," general manager for marketing, Ivan Todoric said in response to a press query. 

He said the aircraft which seats 100 passengers, with 12 in business class would be brought into the country soon.

The move which is certain to put the airline in a commanding position as far as domestic and regional flights are concerned has been welcomed by some travel agents.

"The move is welcome to the industry," said Deila Paulsen of Steve Blagus in Lusaka. "Being a young airline, this will bring public confidence to the travel industry."

She said with more aircraft, passengers were less likely to be completely stranded since another airplane could be sent to rescue them.

She urged the airline to consider expanding its flights to more tourist destinations locally like Mfuwe, Livingstone and Kasaba Bay Lodge which have remained largely unserviced.

Meanwhile, a new local airline, Eastern Air, will be inaugurated on Tuesday next week says Yusuf Zumla, its managing director.

He said the airline will be using a 17 seater Let 410 turbo prop aircraft being leased from Slovakia.

March, 1996


Zambia Prisoners Won't Vote


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 19, 1996 by Masauso Lungu


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Lusaka - Thousands of convicts in Zambian prisons will not vote in the forthcoming parlimentary and general elections, it has been learned.

Acting commissioner of prisons, Philip Sinyangwe, said in a telephone interview from Kabwe yesterday that prisoners have no right to vote under the Zambian constitution. 

"According to the law, once a person is convicted by the courts, he automatically loses most of his liberties and rights, and the right to vote is one of them," Sinyangwe said.

He said no prisoner was allowed to register in the just ended voter registration exercise because they all forfieted their rights and liberties immediately the courts pronounced their imprisoment.

But human rights lawyer Roger Chongwe said a prisoner is just as much human as any one else and should be allowed to vote.

"Even when a person is in prison, he is entitled to choose a leader of his choice, the difference is that he is confined to the prison," Chongwe said.

He said if the constitution bars a prisoner to vote then it is inconsistent with the same constitution on the basic rights and privileges.

But Chairman for the magistrate's association of Zambia Timothy Katanekwa supported Sinyangwe saying: "a person in custody can not vote, his liberties are curtailed."

But Katanekwa failed to explain what the law says on persons jailed for short terms.

"Let me look at the law again and I will come back to you," he said.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Post Editors' Bail Revoked


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 19, 1996 by Mukalya Nampito


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - Lusaka High Court judge, David Lewanika, yesterday revoked the bail he granted on February 7, to Post editors Fred M'membe, Masautso Phiri and Bright Mwape.

But he stayed his own judgement and also granted the applicants leave to appeal to the Supreme Court.

In revoking the bail, Justice Lewanika said section 123 (4) of the criminal procedure code (CPC) was clear and mandatory that no person can be granted bail once the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) has decided otherwise. 

"The question of malafide does not arise and I am not competent to question the exercise of his (DPP) discretion. In the circumstances I have decided to review my decision and I revoke the bail that I granted the applicants on February 7, 1996," Justice Lewanika said in his judgment.

But lawyer for the Post, John Sangwa later applied for an order before the same judge to stay his decision and for permission to appeal.

The judge granted both applications pending hearing of the appeal in the Supreme Court.

The question of bail for the three editors arose in the case in which they are charged with receiving classified information relating to a story on a referendum government was planning secretly.

They are also charged for having a prohibited publication Post edition 401 which exposed the secret plans for a referendum and was subsequently banned by President Chiluba under section 53 of CAP 146 of the Penal Code.

The State challenged the bail granted by Justice Lewanika and applied that he reviews his own ruling because section 123 (4) of the CPC under which the DPP issued the certificate did not require him to prove prejudice of the interest of the republic.

"That the proof is a matter of evidence which can only come up during the trial. Further that the DPP does not have to furnish reason prior to the issuance of the certificates," the State Advocates, L.E. Eya and a Lewis argued.

Sangwa said the argument that the exercise of the powers by the DPP under section 123 (4) of the CPC cannot be questioned is not founded on law.

He further submitted that it was a well settled principle that the exercise of any authority directly affecting the interest of citizens must rest on legitimate foundations of the law.

Judge Lewanika ruled in favour of the State but stayed his ruling.


LOAD-DATE: March 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia NGOs Deplore Chiluba's Remarks


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 19, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Lusaka - Non-Governmental Organisations (NGO's) have deplored President Frederick Chiluba's remarks that they have no right to discuss matters of national interest.

Chiluba told a press conference last week Wednesday that he was "baffled that most NGO's are externally financed and their leaders are not part time."

"That makes the character of the NGO's suspect and I become suspicious," Chiluba said adding: "I have never heard of NGO's talk of national interest." 

But Principal consultant at the Media Resource Centre(MRC) Robby Makayi charged that the President was being insincere because he also came from an NGO.

"The president has forgotten that the Zambia Congress of Trade Unions where he came from is an NGO," Makayi said in an interview on Saturday.

And Executive Director for Inter-African Network for human Rights and Development (AFRONET), Ngande Mwanajiti called on the government to "commend the role played by NGO's, churches and the labour movement in pressing for the re-introduction of a multi-party system of governance."

"The image of the NGOs has not changed since then. If anything, it is only fair for all those that campaigned for the restoration of democracy to ensure that the gains are not lost," Mwanajiti said.

Mwanajiti also dismissed claims that NGO's were accountable to people who finance them adding: "It is important to note that governments in Africa have tended to blame external forces every time citizens raise their voices. The UNIP government blamed most of its difficulties on external enemies too."

Non-governmental Organisations Coordinating Committee chairperson (NGOCC), Susan Jere also declared on ZNBC TV "tell the nation" programme last week that "NGO's have the right to discuss matters of national interest."

Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace secretary general, Father Joe Komakoma called on the government to desist from making accusations against NGO's.

"We have no private agendas apart from reminding the government of what the Mwanakatwe Review Commission report says," Komakoma said in an interview last Thursday.

Youth Federation of Zambia member Lee Habasonda also charged that the government had a hand in the proliferation of NGO's in the country.

"The same MMD government signed an agreement with Southern University democratic governance project of the United States Agency for International Development(USAID), that is what has caused the proliferation of civic education organisations," Habasonda said in an interview on Saturday,adding:"Therefore we have a common interest contrary to what the President said.

Komakoma also disclosed that the "Green paper " of the citizens convention would be ready in the next two weeks.

The paper will be circulated to all NGO's, the church, the government and international organisations.

215 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Business African Economies Linked To Politics


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 19, 1996 by Maidstone Mulenga in New York (Column)


LENGTH: 694 words


 

Lusaka - When the United Nations announced a $25 billion programme for Africa last Friday, it cited the end of the apartheid regime in South Africa and democratically elected governments in Angola and Mozambique as examples of progress that the international community must encourage.

Whether Zambia wants to admit it or not, the international community is linking politics to economy. It is clear that the donors are more willing to spend their money in countries with encouraging signs of democracy. 

The United Nations System-wide Special Initiative On Africa will seek to raise $25 billion from the World Bank, donor countries and other sources over a 10-year period.

The funding will finance "goal-oriented" programs in such fields as education, health, food security, governance, sanitation and "peace-building," the specifics of which will be developed by the African governments themselves.

Most of the $25 billion -which represents 20 per cent of the development money rich countries currently provide to Africa will come primarily from the redirecting of existing international aid.

Initially, the World Bank will be in charge of generating the funds for programs in the areas of health and education, according to the UN Development Program.

UN officials said the effort is unprecedented because of the World Bank's role and because it marks the first time all UN agencies have agreed to coordinate activities to hold themselves "mutually accountable for achieving results."

The development program comes at a time when the United Nations is facing the gravest financial crisis of its 50-year history. Officials, however, said they were confident it could meet its obligations because the program's funding will come mostly from private sources, wealthy donors and UN agencies that maintain budgets separate from the UN headquarters in New York.

UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, an Egyptian, has long complained that Africa has become the "forgotten continent," with the international community concentrating its attention and resources on areas such as the Middle East and the Balkans.

UN officials have also noted that Africa's daunting problems have led to "donor fatigue" in the United States, Japan and Western Europe.

While economic vitality has aided formerly impoverished areas such as East Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe, Africa has steadily fallen behind economically, politically and socially.

The United Nations estimates that 54 per cent of Africa's people live in absolute poverty; it is the only part of the world where poverty is expected to increase over the next decade.

Despite the continent's enormous resources, all but two of the world's 25 least developed countries are in Africa, according to the UN Development Program.

"Africa is a continent at a critical turning point in its history," the UN Development Program said in a statement. "It is a continent beset by economic and social crises, yet it is also a continent on the march, full of promise."

And that promising march should not be derailed by the ill-intentions of politicians who are just eager to stay in power by all means necessary.


LOAD-DATE: March 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


216 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Enraged Students Block UNZA Gates


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 19, 1996 by Goodson Machona


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - University of Zambia students yesterday barricaded the entrance to the campus demanding immediate payment of the promised K90,000 meal allowances.

The students, who were chanting anti-MMD slogans, blocked the main entrance with huge boulders and tree trunks and for nearly five hours turned the campus into a no-go-fortress. They stoned any cars that tried to drive into the campus.

"We feel cheated,"an enraged third-year economics students said, adding; "Government promised to increase our meal allowances from K60,000 to K90, 000 but up to now they haven't paid us. It seems the only language the government understands is violence."

Another student added: "Chiluba should not treat us like kids."

By 20.00 hours last night, the mood at the campus was tense as students milled around in groups plotting their next course of action.

According to a source at the campus, yesterday's demonstration was "a harbinger" of things to come.

"The demonstration is continuing tomorrow (today) at 08.00 hours," the source said.

The stand-off between the students and government started on February 20 when the University of Zambia students Union (UNZASU) reached a deadlock with the Bursaries committee over increased meal allowances for the students.

In the confusion that followed, two cars were smashed and the Great East road was momentarily blocked.

After demonstrations at the ministries of education and finance and State House, students then gave President Chiluba 48 hours within which to solve their problems failure to which they vowed "to do something."

Chiluba, in a bid to calm the situation, upped the students meal allowances from K60,000 to K90,000 but it appears government has failed to live up to its promise.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Government To Face More Pressure on Election Law


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 19, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - Two committees comprising scholars, political parties, the church and Non-governmental Organisations(NGO's) will be formed to pressure government to revise the current electoral law before the Presidential and general elections this year.

The decision was arrived at on Saturday during a freedom forum discussion "voter apathy-its implications", organised by the Media Resource Centre(MRC) at Pamodzi hotel in Lusaka.

Participants observed that the current electoral law contributed to the voter apathy because of the complicated procedures and systems being used. 

Movement for Multi-party Democracy(MMD) chairman Sikota Wina,the first MMD official to accept an invitation to the discussions, admitted the laws needed to be changed but said they required more time.

"I admit that much has not been done in that area. But who is going to accept if we said we postpone the Presidential and general elections in order to facilitate the change of legislation?" Wina asked.

But chairperson of the National Womens Lobby Group(NWLG) Gladys Mutukwa said there was still time to change the laws.

"It can be done within this period especially that the government has shown that it can pass laws within 24 hours," She said.

Mutukwa's sentiments were echoed by Foundation for Democratic Process(FODEP) president Reverend Foston Sakala.

"We still have time. Let that law change to have a simple voting process," Sakala said.

Director of elections Rabson Mwansa also alluded to the fact that the electoral process was being impeded by legislation.

The MRC has also offered an olive branch to both government and the opposition to mediate in their intended talks on unconditional terms from both parties.

The forum observed that government was reluctant to call for the mediation talks.

But health minister and MMD national secretary Michael Sata said yesterday that they were ready.

"We are open for the talks at any time except that there are no political parties but names of people only," Sata claimed.

MRC is the second NGO to offer to mediate after government's failure to respond to FODEP's request.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


218 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Sudan War Costs Mount As Opposition Holds Initiative


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London) March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 1814 words


 

London - The financial and human cost of the war in Southern Sudan is causing tremendous problems for the National Islamic Front (NIF) regime. It's own propaganda machine is struggling to contain the news of military defeats. The public in the North is well aware of the wounded soldiers filling the hospitals, even when whole wings of these institutions are sealed off from public view.

Officially, the public in Northen Sudan is being told that the regime's forces are currently pushing back the forces of the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) and are recapturing the land and military outposts overrun by the SPLA since October. According to the Khartoum media, the regime's forces are poised to recapture the border outpost of Nimule. Lieutenant General El Beshir must dearly wish that this propaganda ws actually true because the reality in the South is extremely depressing for the regime. 

Kit River: The regime has no forces between Kit River, some sixty kilometres south of Juba, and Nimule. Its garrisons at Kapoeta and Torit to the southeast are both under SPLA siege. Three thousand troops of the regime had barricaded themselves into the Aswa valley following the SPLA's siege in January. The commanding officer, a major general, is presumed to have died with his men. The SPLA captured large amounts of weaponry and equipment including: three T-55 tanks; eleven 122 mm howitzers; nine 107 mm mortars; nine 120 mm mortars; sixteen 60 mm mortars; five 82 mm mortars; eight long range and fifteen short range radios; as well as seventeen heavy trucks and four pick-ups. Various hand guns, rifles, machine guns and a large quantity of ammunition were also captured.

On 7 and 8 February, the regime's forces once again attempted to break through the SPLA's lines on the south bank of the Kit River. At least forty soldiers and officers were killed and around 130 wounded. Three officers killed in the attack were First Liteutenants Adam Harroun and Abdel Hadi Hassan Abdel Karim, and Second Lietenant Mahgoub Salih.

The regime no longer announces the names of its troops killed in action because the numbers have risen so high that to make them public would immediately contradict the propaganda stories of battle victories in the South, which the regime is always portrayed as winning. The relatives of officers killed in action are still privately informed about their deaths, but relatives or ordinary soldiers are told nothing.

The SPLA has suffered losses as well since launching its offensive lst October. It would be impossible not to have done when faced with the regime's human wave tactics at Kit Riber. However, these losses have been light in comparison to those inflicted on the regime's forces.

Whilst the SPLA regularly compiles lists of the regime's officers and men killed on the battlefield, the regime's forces do not do likewise with the SPLA dead. It would be interesting, if such a list existed from the regime's side, to compare its contents with that of the SPLA's announcements to its troops of the casualties it has suffered in battle. At present, the SPLA does not publicise such announcements.

Prisoners of War: One area in which the SPLA keeps meticulous figures is the capture of the regime's soldiers. The SPLA regularly hands over these lists to the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), which arranges visits to check on their health and conditions of captivity. Occasionally, the SPLA has made token gestures of releasing a few of its captives. The guerrilla army insists that large scale release can only be part of a final peace settlement.

For its part, the regime claims that it does not have any prisoners of war due to its policy of immediate release of any SPLA soldier its forces capture. Strangely enough, not one SPLA soldier has ever claimed to have been captured and then released by the regime's forces. Many independent observers believe that the regime's forces simply execute any SPLA soldiers they capture in the battlefields of Southern Sudan.

Other Battles: On 7 and 8 February, the regime also launched a second counter attack on SPLA positions at Labone. Nearly one hundred "mujahideen" were killed in the attack, including Lieutenant General El Beshir's younger brother, Osma Hassan El Beshir. Three other officers were also killed: Mohamed Harroun El Haj; Ibraham Harroun and Adam Musa Yagoub. Four officers were wounded and captured by the SPLA: Lieutenant Adam Abdulla Mohamed Musa and Second Lieutenant Ibrahim Izz El Din.

During the past year, the number of casualties involving the relatives of prominent members of the NIF regime has steadily risen. A younger brother of the NIF leader, Dr. Hassan Abdulla El Turabi, was killed last year, as was a son of Ibrahim El Sunusi, another NIF leader. Despite forced conscription, the public is not rallying around the armed forces and instead actively tries to circumvent the recruitment of all the able bodied young men. The regime's leadership cannot refrain from sending their own sons and brothers to the war front if they want the ordinary citizens to do likewise.

Dr. El Turabi has been engaged in a recruitment campaign all his own. His public utterances are becoming increasingly bizarre, suggesting that the physical assault on his person in Canada several years ago may have done more permanent damage than previously believed. In keeping with the official line that the war in the South is a holy war against infidels, he has regularly announced that all the "mujahideen" martyrs have gone straight to heaven. Recently, he took that idea one step further and revealed that he had been divinely informed that each and every one of the regime's dead had arrived in heaven. Furthermore, he suggested that wedding ceremonies ought to be performed for them so as to mimic what God had already done for them in heaven. Anywhere other than Sudan, Dr. El Turabi would probably have been certified.

The Northern Fronts: The economy is bankrupt and the cost of the war is by now approximately $3 million US dollars a day. The money is simply not here and the attempts to find it are having a significant impact on the public. Even some supporters of the regime are beginning to complain about the situation. The atmosphere of rebellion and civil disobedience is permeating every level of society in Northern Sudan.

The United Nations Security Council resolution demanding that the regime hand over to Ethiopia for trial three Egyptian terrorist suspects involved in the assassination attempt on Egyptian president Hosni Mubarek last June has added to the regime's problems. Whilst having no intention of carrying out the resolution, the regime's leaders know that the UN will not refrain from imposing sanctions on Sudan if they do not comply. The regime has realised that sanctions could sound its own death knell and so has frantically been trying to find a way around the resolution. All avenues have been explored, including attempts at reconciliation with opposition leaders in the North.

Storm From The East: A real worry for the regime's commanders in the possible opening of military fronts in eastern Sudan. The SPLA's New Sudan Brigade, the forces of the Beja Congress and of the Sudan Alliance Forces, are all said to be preparing to launch an offensive in the Kassala area. Such an offensive would definitely stretch the regime's military capacity to the breaking point. There has already been discussion in the leadership circles of the NIF about abandoning the South in order to defend Kassala, if necessary.

Meanwhile, the NIF regime's first line of defence in the east is still to maintain its accusations that both Eritrea and Ethiopia are planning to invade Sudan. Such a tactic cannot and will not deflect the opposition forces from carrying out their offensive.

Wiliam Nyuon's Death: More evidence has come to light concerning both the regime's and Riek Machar's duplicity and conspiracy in the assassination of Commander William Nyoun Bany in January.

Three weeks or so before his death, Commander Nyuon received news that a much larger force near Fangak wished to defect to his side. He set off for Fangak with some of his trusted old guard to protect him. It was almost as if he sensed that something was not quite right. His force was ambushed enroute and all of his guard was killed, including some of the conspirators in the plot who had not been told of when the final blow would come.

Khartoum has distanced itself from the plot, preferring to let Riek Machar claim to have killed Commander Nyuon in action. However, the planning, the weapons and the supplies all came from the NIF regime. Khartoum's intention was to secure the Eastern Upper Nile for Riek Machar's Southern Sudan Independence Movement (SSIM) as part of a political deal and a new era of cooperation with that organisation.

Khartoum's meticulous plans have not accounted for events since Commander Nyoun's death. The provisional executive council of William Nyoun's faction of the SSIM immediately elected his deputy, Commander John Luk Jok, as his successor. He has since travelled throughout Eastern Upper Nile consolidating his leadership and command of his faction. In addition, he has continued with Commander Nyuon's reconciliation with the mainstream SPLA, all of which has undermined Khartoum's attempts to re-establish Riek Machar as a credible military leader in the South.


LOAD-DATE: March 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


219 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Eritrea and Sudan Eritrea Hands Over Sudanese Embassy To Opposition


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London) March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 840 words


 

London - In one of the most open demonstrations of support for the opposition National Democratic Alliance (NDA), the Eritrean government last month handed over the Sudanese embassy in Asmara for use as the NDA's headquarters. The building had been closed since December 1994 when Eritrea broke off diplomatic relations with the National Islamic Front (NIF) regime in Khartoum and expelled the Sudanese diplomats whilst withdrawing its own officials from Sudan. The NIF regime is currently complaining to anyone who will listen that the Eritrean action over the embassy building was illegal.

The embassy was handed over to the NDA in a ceremony attended by representatives of the ruling Eritrean party, the Popular Front for Democracy and Justice. The Ertireans said that they were pleased to hand over the embassy building to the legitimate representatives of the Sudanese people so that they can carry out their legitimate activities of bringing about democratic change in Sudan. 

On behalf of the NDA, the chairperson and leader of the Democratic Unionist Party, Mohamed Osman el Mirghani said: "From its new headquarters in Asmara, the NDA will now march triumphantly to Khartoum." He pledged that the NDA will make great use of the building by making a more concerted effort from within it to bring about a change in Sudan.

The NDA representatives at the ceremony incuded: General Fatih Ahmed Ali, deputy chairperson of the NDA and leader of the Legitimate Command of the Armed Forces; Dr. Omer Nur El Dayem, secretary general of the Umma Party; Mohamed Tahir Abubakr, leader of the Beja Congress; Brigadier Abdel Aziz Khaled, leader of the Sudan Alliance Forces; as well as representatives of the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), the Sudan Communist Party, and a large crowd of Sudanese residents in Eritrea.

Khartoum Complains: Since the ceremony, the NIF regime has complained to the Arab League in Cairo and the Organization for African Unity (OAU) in Addis Ababa. Exactly why the regime has complained to the Arab League is unclear, because Eritrea is not a member of that organisation . Perhaps Khartoum wishes to whip up racial enmity against the Eritreans! Whatever the case, the regime is unlikely to get much support in Cairo because its own rogue activities have done much to alienate many Arab League members.

Although Eritrea is a member of the OAU, it is unlikely that the regime will receive any support there because it has regularly flouted the organisation's requests for it to curtail its rogue behaviour. In particular, the regime ignored the OAU's requests that it hand over the three terrorist suspects to Ethiopia that were implicated in the attempt to assasinate Egyptian president Hosni Mubarek. Khartoum refused to carry out those requests which forced Ethiopia to take its case to the United Nations Security Council, which has now condemned these activities and has given Khartoum sixty days to hand over the three terrorists for trial in Ethiopia.

Unclear Status: Questions have been raised about the ownership of the embassy building in Asmara. It was said to have been given as a gift to a former Sudanese leader, General Abboud, by the Ethiopian emperor, Haile Selassie, the then colonial ruler of Eritrea. It is not known whether a reciprocal gift in Sudan was ever made. No doubt, the regime is looking into that matter.

When relations between Khartoum and Asmara were normal, the building's status never came into question. When relations were broken off because of the regime's misconduct, the Eritreans were within their right to take possession of the empty building that was naturally theirs.

It is far from certain whether Khartoum is complaining about the fact that the opposition have been given the building or if they were merely object to a building, that they believe they own, being given away. Whatever the objection, the fact remains that the Eritreans consider the NDA to be a government-in-exile and the regime as an illegitimate body that seized power from democratic representatives in a coup d'etat. As such, the NDA is entitled to make use of the building even if it once was a gift to the Sudanese state.

It would be interesting to see how the OAU would rule in this situation, although intervention by that organisation appears most unlikely.


LOAD-DATE: March 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


220 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Ministers' Foreign Travel Restriction Long Overdue


BYLINE: Post Of Zambia (Lusaka) March 15, 1996 by Munachoonga H. Chipewo (Column)


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Lusaka - The restriction by the President on foreign travel by ministers and government officials was one of the most important strategic decisions to have been made in many years.

The wealth of a nation is made in many ways. Some of the ways are the additions in assets from the beginning of a particular period to its end, the rehabilitation of existing asset stock and savings arising from cost cutting measures such as the ones announced by the President. 

The culture of spend thrift has not been with the nation for a long time. This is not surprising as the nation as a whole suffers from deficient strategic management practices. Strategic management of an economy whether macro or micro depends largely on the ability of middle and top management staff in politics and business to manage information whereupon a right decision making process can be based. In a nation where information management is strategic, invinsible costs, which in the majority of cases constitute 45 per cent of the total costs, are drastically reduced. There is really no compelling reason why home based ministers should be globe trotting spending an enormous amount of hard earned foreign exchange in terms of allowances and expensive air fares when the country is adequately represented in embassies of the countries so often visited. What are the duties of the ambassadors, trade attaches and whatever other titles they are called if they cannot represent the ministries back home?

This failure to practice management principles of delegation, communicating, co-ordination and decision-making affects not only the political sphere but the parastatal sector as well.

At one time, the former PTC won the best customer praise from Hotel Intercontinental because staff of the head office in Ndola often travelled to Lusaka on business en masse in spite of the existence of middle management staff representing the Head Office, who could submit information required by management for decision making.

In TAZARA and Zambia Railways, it is common to see scores of managers on 'trips' from head office and regions spending millions on Kwacha on subsistance for no results at all.

In ministries such as education, agriculture and the like, chief officers regularly travel to provinces and districts and yet no impact of the visits is made as schools are getting dirtier every day and extension workers do not even visit the farmers to advise them on how to preserve the little food they have produced, all because officers do not travel to work.

It is, therefore, safe to say that the motive for travel among politicians and management staff in parastatal organisations is not service to a large extent but earning of extra income for personal wealth at the expense of national development.

What has happened, therefore, should be commended because if it persists, it will bring about a new culture of work in government and ministers will ensure that their ministries design effecient information systems for efficient performance. The top-down and bottom-up management information strategy will definitely show up sooner that later the majority deadwood in the civil service locally and abroad and will give ministries the chance to boot them out on incompetence as part of the civil service reform programme.

At the moment they are hiding behind the visitations of bosses at places of work.

The nation has to start from somewhere. Cost cutting should be enhanced everywhere in the nation if we are to develop. This should include chief executives who play Golf during working hours when they are supposed to be in their offices producing and solving company problems.

There is so much play than work in this country that this has ultimately made Zambia a dull boy when others are busy working and developing. The sooner this is realised, the better.


LOAD-DATE: March 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa-at-Large Olympics: Soccer Team To Go To Atlanta


BYLINE: Tunisian Press Agency March 17, 1996


LENGTH: 120 words


 

Tunis - Despite losing 2-0 to the Guinean national team in a game played today in Conakry, the Tunisian national soccer team won its ticket to the Olympics. 

The Tunisian team was saved by the large lead (5-2) it had won over its Guinean rival during the home game it had played in Tunis two weeks ago.

The Guinean goals were scored at the 31st minute of the first half and the 21st minute of the second half. Two players, one from each team, were ejected by the referee early in the second half of the game.

March, 1996


Tunisia Arab Environment Ministers Council Awards Prize


BYLINE: Tunisian Press Agency March 6, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Tunis - In a ceremony held today at the Arab League center in Tunis, Mr. Mohamed Mehdi Mlika, Tunisian minister of environment and land development received the award of the Council of Arab ministers of environment in recognition of the efforts carried out by Tunisia in the field of solid household waste collection and processing.

Mr. Noureddine Hached, Arab League Deputy Secretary General and Chairman of the Arab League center in Tunis, presented the award to Mr. Mlika, on behalf of both the League Secretary General and the Chairman of the Council's executive committee. 

Mr. Hached said Tunisia was awarded this prize in recognition of its project in treating household solid waste, initiated in "Cit El Khadra", Tunis. This project included the technical set up of the solid waste management as well as getting the population to actively contribute to this project's success.

The prize comes also as a crowning of Tunisia's efforts in reconciling the imperative of development with that of ensuring balance of the ecosystem, he added.

The Tunisian minister expressed Tunisia's pride in being awarded this prize, and said that Tunisia has taken the initiative of creating a center of ecotechnology, the aim of which is providing technical solutions to problems common to Arab countries, as well as taking advantage of the Tunisian experience in this field.

He finally called for more coordinated Arab action so as to achieve sustainable development and cope with the ecological needs in the coming century.

Tunisia New Internet Agency Created


BYLINE: Tunisian Press Agency March 12, 1996


LENGTH: 147 words


 

Tunis - A new agency was created today to oversee Internet service providing and development in Tunisia. The creation of the "Agence Tunisienne Internet" (ATI) was announced after a special cabinet meeting chaired by President Ben Ali.

The meeting was dedicated to the study of "the means of upgrading the country's communication systems and international connections so as to ensure their adjustment to the global technological advances made in these fields," said the Tunisian News Agency, TAP.

This effort aims at "strengthening Tunisia's contribution in this sector with regards to the African and Euro-mediterannean regions."

March, 1996


Zambia Donors Keep Mute Over FTJ's Attack


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 15, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - The donor community was yesterday guarded in its response to President Chiluba's State House press conference attack on them on Wednesday.

The President told his press conference audience that donor countries must respect Zambia's sovereignty by desisting from commenting on domestic issues. 

But United States Embassy spokesman Steadman Howard said his government was still reviewing the press conference and he could not say whether there would be an official response or not.

He however, repeated his government's concerns about free elections and press freedom.

"We are concerned as we have always been that there are free and fair elections and that press freedom is preserved," Howard said in an interview yesterday, adding: "We are watching developments carefully."

And the usually outspoken German ambassador Peter Schmidt when apporached responded:

"As heads of missions, we are not in the habit of commenting on statements by the head of state. I have explained our position in the past and I have nothing to add."

An official from the Japanese Embassy said only the ambassador could comment on the issue and he was away attending a meeting.

"I have no comment to make," she said.

Donors have at various fora stated that they wanted the constitution to be broadly based and adopted by consensus.

Among the countries that have said this are Britain, Denmark, Germany and the United States.

March, 1996


Zambia It's KKK For President!


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 18, 1996 by Masauso Lungu


LENGTH: 414 words


 

Lusaka - UNIP vice-president chief Inyambo Yeta has demanded that the MMD government respects his party's right and decision to field a presidential candidate of its choice in the forthcoming presidential elections.

"We in UNIP have the right to decide who we shall field as our republican presidential candidate, and we have made a decision, we demand that the MMD government must respect our decision," chief Inyambo said at a press conference in Lusaka yesterday.

He said UNIP will not change its presidential candidate regardless of what MMD will do. 

"We have said it and we will repeat for the sake of this nation that, regardless of what MMD will do, the only candidate UNIP shall present to the people of Zambia shall be Dr. Kenneth David Kaunda," chief Inyambo emphasised.

But MMD national secretary Micheal Sata said every party has the right to choose a presidential candidate, but that candidate must qualify to the requirements of the law.

"Any party can field their candidate, but he must meet the requirements of the law, if he does not, then it's hard luck," Sata said in an interview yesterday.

The chief challenged President Chiluba to face Kaunda in a free and fair election, reminding him of what he said on arrival from a state visit to Israel.

"We dare you Mr. Chiluba to face Dr Kaunda in a free and fair election, remember what you said at the Lusaka International Airport upon your return from Israel: 'everybody is welcome, it will be a nice tangle to welcome him (Kaunda) in the political field, we will defeat him again,'" he said.

He added that the government has the responsibilty of creating conditions under which peace and stability will prevail.

"And these conditions can only be guaranteed by withdrawing the proposed constitutional bill," he said.

March, 1996


Zambia MMD Training Guerrillas


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 18, 1996 by Masauso Lungu


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - The Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) has sent people to train in various military fields including guerrilla warfare, MMD national secretary, Micheal Sata, disclosed in an interview yesterday.

Sata was commenting on UNIP vice-president Chief Inyambo's allegations at yesterday's press conference that MMD has sent people to train in Israel to help rig the forthcoming elections, but said it's not MMD as a party but government.

"Yes people have been sent to train abroad in various fields including medicine, law, engineering and others to fulfill government's policy," Sata said, adding, "it is not MMD as a party which has sent them, but MMD as government." 

He said government had sent people to train in various military fields to acquire new knowledge because it does not want to be caught napping by UNIP's and ZDC's violence threats.

"What about all these threats from UNIP and ZDC on civil disobiediance and violence, we do not want to be caught napping, and government has sent them to acquire new knowledge in various military discplines including guerilla warfare" Sata said.

Sata's admission is further confirmation that there is more to the relationship between the Zambia government and the Israeli intelligence service Mossad. Last year some diplomatic sources observed that about 500 MMD cadres were trained in subversion by Mossad between September and October in Chief Chiawa's area.

And Inyambo yesterday claimed MMD is training people in Israel to help in rigging the elections.

" We have information MMD has sent people to train in Israel to come and rig elections," Inyambo claimed and denied his party was training an army in South Africa and Israel.

Inyambo described MMD Lusaka province chairman Christoper Chawinga's allegations as "total rubbish" and challenged police to get Chawinga to prove his allegations.

"It's rubbish, and I challenge police to get Chawinga to prove his allegations against our party, it is not true, UNIP is not training any army," Inyambo said yesterday.

But Chawinga yesterday refused to comment.

"Not now, let them go to court then I will be more than ready to prove my allegations," Chawinga said.


LOAD-DATE: March 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
