227 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Business Stock Exchange Revokes Membership


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 15, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Lusaka - The Lusaka Stock Exchange (LuSE) has revoked Meridien Securities Limited (MSL)'s membership for failing to comply with requirements and rules of the exchange.

LuSE board chairman, Tom Ryan, disclosed in an interview on Monday that the decision to revoke MSL's membership was jointly arrived at by the LuSE board recently.

"The decision was arrived a couple of weeks ago by the LuSE board and the revocation was effective February 29," Ryan said in an interview on Monday. 

LuSE general manager, Charles Mate disclosed that the move was in line with bringing order in the market and also to enable continued participation of MSL investors .

He said among the rules that MSL had failed to comply with were their failure to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission(SEC).

"The MSL has not applied to the SEC for membership this year and it seemed fair to revoke their membership. The list of brokers has already been published by SEC and MSL did not apply," Mate said .

He revealed that LuSE was trying not to disadvantage the investors who had bought shares on the exchange through MSL as they could not trade.

"What we have done is to allow the free transfer of shares from MSL to other registered brokers so that they can start trading on the exchange," Mate said adding that: "We want to bring order and clarity in the market ."

LuSE has since advised all investors with shares purchased under MSL to transfer their accounts to other brokers of their choice who are members of the exchange.

A statement from LuSE sent to the investors, disclosed that the transfer of shares would be done free of charge.

Trading in Meridien Baby Bonds and Meridien Family Bonds which were being offered by MSL on LuSE was suspended in June last year following problems arising from the closure of the holding company Meridien BIAO Bank in May.


LOAD-DATE: March 20, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


228 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Uganda North In Grip Of Insecurity Again


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 15, 1996 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1996 words


 

Nairobi - Ugandan authorities are organising a mass funeral for a large proportion of travellers among the 110-plus people killed in a rebel ambush of a 17-vehicle convoy travelling between the capital Kampala and West Nile area of north-western Uganda.

The vehicles were hit by the rebels in the Murchison Falls Park area between Karuma and Pakwach, some 250 kilometres from Kampala on the afternoon of March 8.

The latest deaths bring to more than 200 civilians believed killed as a result of the activities of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) of Joseph Kony, often described by newspapers as a Christian fundamentalist group "who want to rule Uganda according to the 10 Commandments of the Bible". However, the killing of innocent civilians is the hallmark of their terrorist activities in the rural areas of Kitgum and Gulu Districts of northern Uganda, home to the Acholi people who straggle northern Uganda and southern Sudan. 

The LRA is an offshoot of a Holy Spiritist movement led in the mid- eighties by Prophetess Alice Lakwena now in exile in Kenya. Hundreds of the rebels died in attacks against the Ugandan Army between 1985 and 1987 as they believed the Holy Spirit would grant them the magic to withstand army bullets. Joseph Kony, believed to be about 35 is a relative of "Prophetess" Lakwena.

The rebels' cruelty to civilians has turned people against them in Kitgum and Gulu Districts where they indulged in abducting villagers for forceful conscription, raping women, sometimes slashing off their noses with machetes for no apparent reason. Many of the survivors of past attacks have been treated by Italian missionary workers, at Lacor Hospital in Gulu.

The March 8 carnage between Karuma and Pakwach is the second incident in less than a year in which more than 100 innocent civilians have lost their lives. In April 1995, the LRA mowed down 250 civilians at Atiak near the Sudanese border. These were subsequently buried in a mass grave. That massacre caused a major diplomatic row between Sudan and Uganda with each ordering out the other's envoys.

Diplomatic relations were terminated with Uganda accusing Sudan of arming the LRA. Sudan in turn has accused Uganda of supporting the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) of Colonel John Garang. In November 1995, the SPLA, seemingly in a resurgence, smashed Sudanese government garrison towns at Palutaka and Parajok in southern Sudan and have large areas now under their control. Indeed during their offensives in November and December last year, they seized over 200 LRA trainees working alongside the Sudanese Army, and handed them over to Ugandan authorities. At the time, Ugandan authorities believed Kony was finished but senior LRA operatives withdrew deeper into Sudan.

In early February, at least 550 rebels were noted crossing back into Uganda at Bibia crossing point on the Uganda/Sudan border. Between then and the March 8 carnage, the rebels have engaged the Army in a number of hit and run attacks, leaving at least 50 soldiers dead, while rebel losses are put at more than 120 men and many injured.

The Uganda People's Defence Force (UPDF) lost another 20 men leading the 17 vehicle convoy atop Tata trucks. Badly outnumbered by at least 20 to one, the army truck and its occupants appear to have been destroyed by a rocket propelled grenade. The rest of the convoy was sprayed with sub-machine gun fire by rebels who had positioned themselves on both sides of the road.

Survivors have given harrowing accounts of what happened in the immediate aftermath of the attack. Mubarak Belwa, a driver of one of the ambushed buses recovering in hospital in Kampala where the Army took him and 15 other severely injured survivors, said he saw "very many bodies" both inside and outside the six buses in the 17-vehicle convoy. Abductees who numbered several dozens were forced to carry property pillaged from the buses and trucks. The rebels set alight most of the trucks including 4x4 wheel drive vehicles in the convoy.

One woman who survived the carnage and managed to escape said rebels forced her to throw away her dead child with whom she had refused to part.

The driver, Belwa, corroborated earlier accounts of rebels being "heavily armed." Rebels who surrendered to the Army said that while in Sudan, they had been given a light machine gun, LMG, anti- personnel and anti-tank mine, and Sudanese Army uniforms while others carried armour piercing weapons, rocket propelled grenades and mortar bombs, reportedly with Arabic inscriptions.

Following the March 8 attack, a terse military statement signed by Uganda's Defence Minister Amama Mbabazi said: "It is with profound shock and sorrow that the Ministry of Defence informs the country of the loss of lives in an attack by Kony outlaws on a convoy travelling from Kakuma to Pakwach." The statement described the attack as an act of barbarity and bestiality and went on to promise the government's commitment to the eradication of rebels in the north.

But the massacres at Karuma have already ignited recriminations. Defence Minister Mbabazi had previously said, "we are not scared of any invasion from Sudan. Why should we deploy heavily?" When the SPLA struck LRA training camps in Sudan last November, Mbabazi predicted the LRA "were finished."

Now Mr. Mbabazi has blamed the Army for negligence particularly the ineffective surveillance of the Karuma - Pakwach stretch where the massacre happened.

But the Army has logistical problems of its own. The UPDF Chief of Combat Operations, Brigadier Joram Mugume had sensed trouble on that stretch two weeks earlier and ordered the road closed between February 23 and 25. He lamented poor telecommunication facilities in the field had hampered work at his headquarters in Kampala. The Army was particularly worried about landmines hitting even the best protected convoy.

Now there is a feeling of great insecurity all over Gulu District. In particular, the Gulu-Kampala, Gulu-Kitgum, Gulu-Moroto, Gulu- Adjuman roads are now prone to rebel attacks. Moreover in the bush country of Acholi land, rebels roam at will, especially in the night. They set on fire villages they attack, destroying granaries as a strategy to force the people to flee.

There are reports of rebels issuing leaflets in Acholi language, saying all homesteads should be moved four kilometers from any highway. This appears to signal a campaign to make travel impossible in the region. Needless to say, people are fleeing in large numbers to the towns, particularly Gulu.

Opposition leader and presidential aspirant, Dr. Paul Ssemogerere says there should be "an international inquiry" into the situation in the north of the country. Acholiland was previously a stronghold of the Democratic Party (DP). With elections due in May, it is unlikely that security would be guaranteed for him for the purpose of electioneering or peaceful voting.

Uganda's top military men and President Yoweri Museveni are reported to be meeting to work out how best to defeat the rebels. The 4th Division Commander, Brigadier Cheefe Ali has however accused some Acholi people of supporting the rebels despite the pain they are causing to their own people."

Similar sentiments are echoed by Mrs. Betty Bigombe, an Acholi, who is State Minister in Charge of Pacification of the North.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


229 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Christians and Muslims On Unity Path


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 15, 1996 by Osman Njuguna


LENGTH: 2000 words


 

Nairobi - In a recent Friday Prayers sermon, Kenyan Islamic scholar, Sheikh Ali Shee, the chief Imam at Nairobi's Jamia Mosque, dedicated his day's preaching to unity among the people of Allah (God).

We must accept and believe that we are people of one Allah (God) and we must keep peace, unity and understanding among ourselves, for that is what Allah (God) expects from us, the Islamic leader appealed to the packed congregation.

He stressed that it mattered less whether one is Christian or Muslim. "We are all children of one Allah (God)," he told the mid-day Islamic worshippers. He reminded his congregation that many wars and civil strife have surfaced in Africa and other parts of the world, because people have defied God's wish that all must live together as children of one Allah (God). 

He summarized his sermon thus, we have no choice but to abide by the tenets of love, peace and understanding among ourselves to avert the current material and human destruction that the world is witnessing today.

For a passer-by, the Imam's message may not be any different from other sermons delivered by Islamic preachers. But those who have closely followed the recent trends of inter-faith relations will agree that there is need to build and promote relations between the faithful of both religions.

Vatican's Pontifical Council for Inter-Religious Dialogue, a department currently headed by Nigerian Cardinal Francis Arinze, is charged with the responsibility of promoting and developing effective communication between the Catholic Church and people of other faith.

Through this department Pope John Paul II in February sent a message of congratulations to the worldwide Muslim community as they celebrated the end of the holy month of Ramadhan. "For us as Christians and Muslims to reach beyond tolerance to reconciliation and love, there is still a long way to go. Christians and Muslims can become an example of reconciliation and instruments of peace in today's world," the Pope's message based on the theme-Beyond Tolerance said in part.

In Africa major Protestant churches through the Project for Christian-Muslim Relations in Africa (PROCMURA) hope to institute and promote better and effective relations between the Christians and Muslims on the continent.

"Our mission is simple. Helping both Christians and Muslims live together harmoniously in their day-to-day life. One of our major concerns is the formation of Christian-Muslim relations committees at the lowest levels such as parishes, dioceses and villages," stresses Rev.Dr. Johannes Haafkens who heads the PROCMURA office from the Kenyan capital, Nairobi. PROCMURA was begun in 1959.

He says such committees have made remarkable achievements in various parts of Africa. However, he notes that there are incidences in which issues have gone out of control, resulting in "bad blood" between members of the two communities. Cases of fighting have been reported resulting in physical injuries to individuals, property loss and damage.

Dr. Haafkens cited countries like Nigeria and Egypt, where hostilities between Muslims and Christians have resulted in loss of life on both sides.

Talking to APS recently, Sheikh Ali Shee said he was concerned about some "grey areas" that still exist in the process of inter-faith relations. "I am disturbed by some people in the Christian world who either write books, articles or use the mass media in general to mar the good name of Islam," cautioned the Islamic leader.

Ali Shee was alluding to a February 15 report, Islamic Expansion in Eastern Africa? What is Our Responsibility? written by the Rev. Wolfgang Schonecke for the Association of Member Episcopal Conferences in Eastern Africa (AMECEA) Documentation Service. AMECEA comprises Catholics in the East and Central African countries of Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Malawi, Zambia, and Sudan.

"While the report has some basic truth about the picture of the Islamic faith in the region, some information has either been jumbled up or messed up to give the wrong picture. I would quickly want to single out the researcher's table of statistics showing the population of Muslims in the various countries in the region," said Sheikh Shee.

Referring to statistics listed under, RELIGIOUS STATISTICS FOR AMECEA COUNTRIES, credited to the Catholic Mission Education Centre (CAMECO-1990) and Barret's works in "MUSLIMS, Nationalities of the World", the Nairobi Imam questioned figures which indicate that Muslims comprise only six per cent of Kenya's population of about 25 million. The Islamic scholar said the figures given represent the population of Muslims somewhere before independence in 1963. He argued that Kenyan Muslims are currently about 30 per cent of the national population.

"I think the challenge is for both Christians and Muslims. We must strive to reflect the true picture of each of us in the best way possible. We must try to be open to each other and refrain from mispresenting facts on and about each other. This is vital in the new world of opening up to each other," explained Sheikh Ali Shee.

In his report, Rev. Fr. Schonecke, a member of the Catholic Order of the Missionary Society of Africa, says Christians have an in-built fear of Islam and their reactions go from anxiety or panic to explaining Islamic revival away in terms of petrol-dollars. But neither fear nor illusion are good guides to creative action, he argues, adding; "If anything, Islamic revival is a challenge to Christianity's complacency and shows up the weaknesses and shortcomings of our evangelising efforts."

Fr. Schonecke laments that there is a great mutual ignorance of Christians and Muslims, which he says breeds prejudice and false fears.

A better catechism adapted to the context of Islamic proselytism could help, he recommends, adding that this would show the common ground of shared values and beliefs in both religions and speak with respect of the meaning of the various religious rites and practices.

This would also go a long way to explain mysteries that are particular and fundamental to the Christian faith, such as the trinity, and sonship of Jesus, in a way that is meaningful to their own life and at the same time intelligible to Muslims, he further recommends.

Fr. Schonecke says the resurgence of Islam in Eastern Africa cannot be overlooked. It shows itself not just in the countries with a traditionally high proportion of Muslims but also in countries where not too long ago, Islam was virtually absent.

The Catholic priest cites the spread of thousands of mosques in every village or every quarter of town amplifying the call to prayer; Islamic universities, schools, dispensaries and cultural centres; Islamic television programmes, video and newspapers; Islamic political parties or organisations; Islamic bank and financial institutions as well as the Islamic dress as the clearest signs of Islamic expansion in the Eastern African region.

According to the report, Muslims take new pride in their religion and way of life, claim a greater role in society and display great zeal to convert others to their religion. The proclaimed aim of Da'wa Al- Islamiya (Islamic Mission/Call) is to make Africa islamic by the year 2000.

Under the subtitle-Christian Challenge, the AMECEA report says mosques and Islamic centres are often the centre of the community, not just for prayer, but also places of meeting, discussion, study and leisure for the young and old.

Where priests see their function mainly as liturgical, parishes tend to overflow on Sundays, but are dead for the rest of the week, points out Fr. Schonecke. He recommends, "we need to have a holistic vision of faith and of church, to make our parishes and outstation the home of the community where not only religious ceremonies, but the celebration of all aspects of life takes place."

Under the subject Dialogue, the Catholic priest, suggests that the majority of moderate Muslims could be encouraged and supported in their efforts to reject violent extremist elements.

The paper also suggests that meetings and exchanges between Christian and Muslim theologians in universities and seminaries could foster personal links and help to remove mutual distrust.

It also recommends that an up-dated catechism can overcome the great ignorance of most Christians about Islam, make them aware of the common beliefs and moral values in both religions, help Christians to be able to express the fundamentals of faith in intelligible form and be aware of weaknesses and contradictions within Islam.

The AMECEA paper describes Africa as a continent with a strong tradition of religious tolerance where Christians, Muslims and traditionalists live peacefully in the same family, but cautions that "the same tradition is being threatened by small groups of religious extremists."

The dialogue of life, joining in family feasts, marriages and funerals and showing respect and interest in each other's religious celebrations, should be positively encouraged, says Fr. Schonecke.

Pointing out that the media can give the impression that Islam as a whole has become aggressive, fundamentalist, violent, more visible, noisy and seeks political power thus creating fear in many Christians, Fr. Schonecke recommends that Christians need to be prudent, nuanced and Gospel-inspired when reacting to such opinions.

Fr. Schonecke ends his paper with a strong quote from Pope John Paul II in the book, The Church in Africa (Ecclesia in Africa) - Post- Synodal Apostolic Exhortations, that "commitment to dialogue must also embrace all Muslims of good will. Christians cannot forget that many Muslims try to imitate the faith of Abraham and to live the demands of the Decalogue. Christians and Muslims are called to commit themselves to promoting a dialogue free from risks of false irenicism or militant fundamentalism and to raising their voices against unfair policies and practices, as well as against the lack of reciprocity in matters of religious freedom."


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


230 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zimbabwe Church Group Proposes Ways To Improve Prison Conditions


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 15, 1996 by Tim Chigodo


LENGTH: 2014 words


 

Nairobi - Following visits to 40 reformatories and probation hostels in Zimbabwe, the Catholic (Church) Commission for Justice and Peace (CCJP) last year compiled a 76-page book entitled Prison Talk: The Law versus the Practice.

The report evolves around 94 questions whose approach is based on the United Nations Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners and the Prison Act of Zimbabwe under 12 topics which include; health and hygiene, food and nutrition, accommodation and sleeping facilities, the position of women, guard brutality and humanity among others.

The Zimbabwe CCJP team also noted views from prisoners. However, researchers took into account the fact that the attitude of inmates towards certain issues may be clouded and influenced by bitterness towards incarceration. Thus, the opinions of prison administrators were a major component of the study. 

The CCJP report particularly focused on the overcrowding aspect, poor diet, lack of ventilation and exercise and unhygienic conditions culminating in numerous respiratory diseases such as pulmonary tuberculosis. Other ailments include dysentery, diarrhoea, eye infection and skin diseases. Incidences of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) were also linked to poor conditions in Zimbabwe's prisons.

Most prisons were found to be bursting at the seams - for example 24 people squeezed together in a small cell measuring 3.5 x 4.5 metres and 18 in a cell measuring 4 x 6 metres is serious overcrowding.

As prisoners literally "sleep on top of each other" in some jails, detailed accounts of the prevalence of homosexuality were given at WhaWha Medium Prison in central Zimbabwe.

A remand prisoner facing fraud charges said; "Homosexuality is rampant. We are dying in this place. Some of the guys in there have been there too long. Usually however, they establish a permanent understanding with a person, but you see, this is remand. We are constantly moved and partners are separated and the rest of us are harassed. The victims get food or sweets for services rendered. For those who do not get visitors, the offers are attractive enough."

He noted that "no one attempts to make a report any more because the guards do not respond at all. If they do, they take their time. Meanwhile, danger will be looming in the cells. Once, an elderly white man reported his case. He was beaten at night and is now partially deaf." An account of sexual harassment in the prison truck to and from court was also given by a female prisoner serving a 16- year term.

Women to a certain extent are a special category of prisoners, requiring facilities not otherwise needed by male inmates, such as sanitary towels whenever the need arises. But these are not provided.

At Mutoko Prison in the north-eastern part of the country, a female inmate imprisoned for infanticide faked illness during her menstruation period so that she could stay in the cells since she did not have sanitary towels. Another woman at Mutare Prison said she had to use her daughter's nappies during her cycles.

Pregnant female prisoners also require medical check-ups. Participants in a group discussion at Chikurubi Female prison cited a case whereby an inmate had labour pains but was ignored and told to wait for transport which hardly ever came. It is not uncommon for babies to be born in the prison cells without receiving any medical attention. The prison nurses did not work at night. Chikurubi Female Prison has a capacity of 287 but holds a population of up to 430 inmates.

Provision for babies born in prison is also a matter of serious concern. Once an inmate had delivered, she would be transferred to a maternity cell. Chikurubi Female Prison has four such cells, each holding 38 inmates with babies. Although some of the inmates sleep on the bunk beds provided, others sleep on the floor as the beds are inadequate. The babies are not accorded any special provisions such as baby-cots, infant food or clothing. In addition, lactating mothers neither get extra food nor supplementary diet.

The standard diet for all prisoners in Zimbabwe comprises, breakfast -- coffee or tea with milk plus 1/8 of a loaf of bread, lunch -- sadza (maizemeal cake) and vegetables or beans and supper -- sadza and vegetables or beans. Pork is served four times a week.

Reports say although the prison population had increased rapidly, in some cases almost doubling, food rations had not been increased proportionately. Prisons situated along borders experienced the biggest problems.

The unprecedented increases were mostly caused by border jumping into South Africa and Botswana and from Mozambique into Zambia and vice- versa. At Beitbridge Prison in the south-east near the border with South Africa, the number fluctuated between two and 200 new inmates on some days.

Food in Zimbabwe's prisons is generally badly cooked, overcooked and cold because it is prepared long before it is actually eaten, says the CCJP report. For example, the preparation of breakfast commences at 4 am, yet the cells are opened at 6 am.

At Mutare Prison, the sadza which the researchers saw being dished out was cold and "half cooked" with maize-meal granules actually disintegrating in the plates. The spinach was of a greenish black or khaki colour.

At Khami Maximum Prison in the south-west, near Zimbabwe's second city, Bulawayo, the nyimo (groundnuts) served with sadza were full of weevils. In fact, the weevils covered the entire top surface of the nuts such that it was only after a physical check that the researcher established what the relish was.

Nevertheless, the inmates were apparently nonchalant as none was observed removing the weevils. One inmate actually said: "Ndiyo nyama yacho iyoyo" (That is the meat).

Such are the general standards in the older prisons. The new prisons like Chipinge and hopefully the New Mutare and Kadoma Prisons, have better cooking and dining facilities.

An aspect of prison conditions that the CCJP researchers found most dehumanising was that of strip searches. Before the prisoners return to their cells, they were made to strip and thoroughly searched. During this exposure, other inmates stood watching. Only at Chipinge Prison was there a special shed built for this purpose to maintain the dignity of the individuals.

The main objective of the CCJP research was to examine and compare the legislation on which prison conditions and administration are based with the actual implementation of that legislation. The comparison is based on the concept of human rights.

Justice Anthony Gubbay, Zimbabwe's Chief Justice describes human rights as "....claims which every individual has, or should have, upon the society in which she or he lives. To call them human rights suggests that they are universal, they are due to every human society. They do not differ with geography or history, culture or development. They do not depend on gender or race, class or status. To call them rights implies that they are claims as of right, not merely appeals to grace, charity or brotherhood or love; they need not be earned or deserved. They are more than aspirations or assertions of the good but claims, of entitlement and corresponding obligation in some political order under some applicable law, if only in a moral order under a moral law.

"When used carefully, human rights are not some abstract, inchoate good. The rights are particular, defined and familiar, reflecting respect for individual dignity and a substantial autonomy, as well as a common sense of justice and injustice," says the Chief Justice.

The CCJP report made recommendations to the Government based on its findings which encompass four broad categories of law reform, changes in the administration of the law, legal education and training and others.

Throughout the discussion on the findings, overcrowding in the prisons stood out as the cause for most of the other problems. It is recommended that the prison population be controlled by legislation which presents incarceration as a last resort. The proposed legislation should provide alternatives to imprisonment such as community service programmes.

In 1993, the Zimbabwe government introduced a community service programme. By mid-1995 some 5,000 offenders had benefited from the process. Rendering service to the community in exchange for jailing has also tremendously reduced overcrowding in the country's prisons.

And the Prisons Director, Mr. Langton Chigwida, speaking at a magistrates' Legal Forum in 1995 said: "Prisons are expected to fulfill a number of roles for the community which at times appear to be contradictory depending on the climate of public opinion. In short, the task assigned to prisons by society is to turn society's rejects into model citizens. This is not an easy task."

Highlighting the advantages of the community service alternative, the CCJP report says the programme would be cheaper to run than conventional prisons and would also keep hardened criminals and first, young or non-violent offenders apart. It would also enable convicts with small sentences or even petty offenders to keep their jobs and continue to sustain their families. Experts here estimate that the average length of imprisonment on those given community service would have been three months at a monthly cost of Zimbabwe dollars 442 (US dollars 50). The 5,000 offenders who served in the programme have so far saved the government Zimbabwe dollars 6.6 million (US dollars 730,000).

The CCJP report also argues that although the Prison Act of 1956 and the whole legal framework pertaining to the administration of Zimbabwe's prisons is in line with international standards, the system nevertheless, contains many wrongs which impede and perhaps render futile efforts at reformation. The small, unhealthy cells, the bad odours, the vermin, the idleness, the brutality for instance, could almost be entirely eliminated by the engagement of officials and appropriately trained prison administrators.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Benin Former Dictator Eyes Return Through the Ballot


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Cotonou - Feeling deeply insecure following his poor showing in the first round of Benin's Presidential elections on March 3, President Nicephore Soglo has postponed, by three days, the eagerly awaited second round of the voting, which will now take place on March 20.

In the first round on March 3, none of the seven contenders managed an outright victory of the 51 per cent required to avoid a run-off. Both Soglo and his nearest rival, former military strongman, Mathieu Kerekou each received about 35 per cent of the votes cast. Kerekou trailed Soglo by a mere 20,000 votes out of the 1.5 million votes that were cast. In all, there are 2.5 million registered voters in Benin. 

But election observers affiliated to Benin's Constitutional Court believe the irregularities in the elections were so widespread as to justify a nullification of the results. Among fraudulent practices noted, were under age voting and ballot stuffing.

Soglo, while announcing the three day postponement, said it was "to redress the shortcomings noted on March 30."

The third runner-up to Soglo after Kerekou, was Adrien Houngbedji, former Speaker of the National Assembly. He obtained about 20 per cent of the votes and promptly announced he would back Kerekou's quest for the presidency.

Houngbedji's move is seen as quite upsetting to Soglo. There is now a very real likelihood of Kerekou returning to power after an absence of five years.

Kerekou, 63, is a northerner and most northerners voted as a block for one of their own. Soglo, a southerner, was surprised by the large number of disenchanted southerners who voted for Kerekou, a former dictator with a poor human rights record, besides his Marxist policies that ruined the economy of tiny Benin in the 17 years that he ruled the country. He came to power in a coup in 1972.

Soglo is widely credited with turning around the economic fortune of Benin through his World Bank/International Monetary Fund (IMF) supported reforms. Unfortunately Soglo has discovered that people do not eat statistics.

It became clear after the parliamentary elections of March 1995, that the honeymoon with people of Benin was over. He tried a few populist stratagies like making spiritism (voodoo) a national religion,. Although widely practised this move appears to have been of no political consequence.

Meanwhile, the former Marxist strongman, Kerekou, has indicated that he will overturn the World Bank reform programmes once elected. Many Beninois are impatient and prone to believe that they were better without the World Bank/IMF reform programmes.

Kerekou was driven out of office in 1989 after widespread disturbances during the "wind of change" that swept through many African countries in the late 80s and early 90s.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


232 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Kenyan Professor Maintains His Medicine Treats Aids


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Nairobi - Professor Arthur Obel of the Faculty of Medicine, University of Nairobi and Director of the Kenya Biodiversity Centre here, has reiterated his claim that his self formulated drug called Pearl Omega made from herbal ingredients, is effective in the treatment of the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).

Even more controversially, he says the compound reversed the HIV status of seven patients out of 31 who have used it as per recommendations. He claims their HIV status changed from positive to negative. He says that a senior World Health Organisation (WHO) scientist/virologist, Dr. Tukei, was involved in the verification process. 

On March 11, Prof. Obel, 54, a clinical pharmacologist by training, gave a well attended public talk on Pearl Omega, at the University of Nairobi School of Medicine.

But fellow scholars and medical practitioners felt badly let down, not only because the facilities were completely inadequate but also because Prof. Obel was deliberately frugal with information.

Most doctors were unimpressed by the small sample of patients and the methodology used.

Professor William Lore of the Kenya Medical Association said: "My colleague did not address any issues. He was more of a politician than a scientist - he must discuss his study design." Lore complained that Prof. Obel did not follow the accepted norms in science and therefore, any claims, of efficiency remain largely unproven.

Prof. Obel has come under unprecedented criticism since he announced Pearl Omega through the ruling Kenya African National Union (KANU) party-owned Kenya Times on March 1.

Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi said that as far as the government was concerned "no cure (for AIDS) had been discovered yet."

Intriguingly, Prof. Obel seems quite anxious about his personal security. When he prematurely excused himself and terminated his public lecture - at a point when discussions were getting heated, he drove away in a convoy, with a security car infront and at the rear of his self driven vehicle. Prof. Obel appears genuinely to believe that he is guarding very vital secrets.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Mozambique Islamic Dates Proposal Sparks Row


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Maputo - A bill introduced in parliament by Mozambique's ruling FRELIMO party proposing that Islam's holy dates be recognised as national holidays in this southern African country just emerging from 16 years of civil war, has sparked political controversy and forced President Joaquim Chissano to intervene.

Chissano met with Christian representatives over the row on March 12 and urged dialogue between members of parliament from the Front for the Liberation of Mozambique (FRELIMO) and those from the opposition Mozambique National Resistance (RENAMO), who have opposed the proposal.

Christian leaders, including the head of the Catholic Church, Cardinal Alexandre Maria Dos Santos, have met Chissano over the dispute which threatens to antagonise Christians and Muslims even before the healing of wounds inflicted by years of war, which pitted Chissano's FRELIMO government against the former RENAMO rebels led by Afonso Dhlakama. 

Aware of the Christians' discontent, the FRELIMO parliamentarians have also proposed that Holy Friday or Easter be a national holiday as well, a suggestion rejected by the Christians outright.

RENAMO, as expected, voted against the bill in February, but its few Muslim members voted with FRELIMO MPs who were in favour.

Government critics allege that economic interests are attached to FRELIMO's decision and pointed out that Mozambique recently joined the Arab Development Bank and the Islamic Organisation Conference.

Observers here said Mozambique's cash-strapped government decided to join the two organisations to win the favour of rich Gulf states from whom it expects rewards in the form of development aid.

Christianity and Islam are the country's two main religions, with Islam gaining ground in recent years.

But many of Mozambique's estimated 16 million people follow traditional beliefs, with an estimated five million Christians, four million Muslims and a small Hindu community.

FRELIMO and RENAMO reached a peace pact that ended the war in 1992. Elections in which FRELIMO emerged winner were held in October 1994.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


234 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Lawyers Fear Jailed Editors May Be Abducted


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Lusaka - Lawyers for jailed editors of Zambia's controversial bi-weekly, The Post, have expressed fears that the state security agents are planning to abduct the two journalists from jail.

The pair, Fred M'Membe (Editor-in-Chief) and Bright Mwape, the Managing Editor are currently serving an indefinite prison term for being found in contempt of parliament by the Speaker of the National Assembly Dr. Robinson Nabulyato, on February 27.

The Windhoek (Namibia)-based Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA) in a press release dated March 12, quoted one of the editors' lawyers, Mr. Sakwiba Sikota saying that he had information that undercover security agents were intending to carry out the abduction. 

According to MISA, Mr. Sikota said he had with him a letter dated March 6, addressed to the Officer-in-Charge of Lusaka Central Prison to prove his case.

According to the MISA dispatch, Mr. Sikota had confirmed on March 11 that his office had "reliable information" that security agents had held discussions on how to abduct the editors.

Sikota said his office had since written to the prison officials asking them not to move the editors from their cells in the lawyers' absence, or without a valid warrant.

Meanwhile, the National Assembly has written to the Commissioner of Prisons in Lusaka and Kabwe, where M'Membe and Mwape are being held, confirming the arrest and imprisonment of the two editors. The letter, marked CONFIDENTIAL, partly reads: "They will be held in custody until they show contrition or until such time that the National Assembly shall have reversed its decision (to jail the editors) upon motion."

But the letter advises that, "only their (M'Membe and Mwape's) freedom of movement has been curtailed. They will continue to enjoy all other civil rights."

Zambia's Home Affairs Minister Chitalu Sampa, was quoted early this month by the state-run media saying that M'Membe and Mwape "should be treated like ordinary criminals" while in Jail, and were not to receive preferential treatment.

"A prisoner is a prisoner and there is no special treatment," the Times of Zambia quoted the minister saying.

The Post is well known for crusading investigative journalism. In 1994 as Managing Editor of the independent bi-weekly, M'Membe was summoned to give evidence in the trial of a minister who accused President Chiluba of drug trafficking, an allegation made at a press conference. M'Membe declined to testify since other newspapers were not summoned.

Earlier the same year, he was charged following the publication of controversial remarks by another minister who had quit his post.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


235 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Rwanda Agencies Challenge Donor Governments


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Geneva - A comprehensive report, the "Joint Evaluation of Emergency Assistance to Rwanda", undertaken by 19 donor governments, was released here on March 12.

Welcoming the report at a press conference here, the Steering Committee for Humanitarian Response (SCHR), made up of six of the world's biggest private humanitarian assistance organisations, describe the report into how the international community responded to the 1994/95 Rwandan crisis, as a "lesson to be heeded by political leaders responsible for taking action against genocide."

The 19 donor governments that participated in the joint evaluation are Australia, Austria, Canada, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Ireland, Italy, Germany, Japan, Luxembourg, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Britain and the United States of America. 

SCHR, which comprises Caritas Internationalis, International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, International Save the Children Alliance, Lutheran World Federation, Oxfam and the World Council of Churches, called on donor governments to strengthen the United Nations conflict prevention and emergency coordination mechanisms.

SCHR noted that such coordinating efforts in conflict prevention and response would help save thousands more lives in the event of another major humanitarian emergency.

The SCHR members however note that "humanitarian action cannot substitute for political action."

"We, the churches and the private aid agencies cannot fill the vacuum caused when nation states refuse to take action to resolve political problems. There is not enough humanitarian aid in the world to do that," says Rev. Rudolf Hinz, Director of the Lutheran World Federation's Department for World Service.

But the SCHR members do not agree with the report's recommendations to merge all UN humanitarian agencies into one body. Instead, they call for the UN Department of Humanitarian Affairs (DHA) to be strengthened.

While the report praises the aid effort, which dealt with a series of humanitarian crises of unprecedented scale, it criticises a few aid agencies whose performance was not up to the high standards of care.

"The rapid response of humanitarian aid agencies saved many lives when hundreds of thousands of people crossed borders in a matter of hours. But some agencies did not uphold professional standards of assistance. We urge all humanitarian agencies to subscribe to the SCHR and Red Cross Movement's Code of Conduct which affirms that all aid beneficiaries are treated with dignity and all aid agencies are held accountable to the beneficiaries as well as to the donors," says Rev. Myra Blyth of the World Council of Churches Unit on Sharing and Service.

While welcoming the report and its recommendations, the agencies point out some crucial changes which need to be made.

They call on governments and the UN to seriously consider the criticism that the UN Secretariat ignored its own early warning mechanisms before the genocide and reflect how best to ensure that such negligence does not happen again.

The private agencies also emphasise that all non-governmental agencies should subscribe to the Code of Conduct developed by SCHR and the Red Cross Movement. NGO networks should be given greater capacity to monitor compliance with the Code. SCHR is planning to develop a series of professional and technical standards of performance to accompany the Code.

In addition, they urge donor governments to continue to support efforts to resolve problems in the Great Lakes region of Central Africa by supporting the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)'s seriously under-funded refugee programmes and working to resolve the painful crisis in neighouring Burundi.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


236 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Is South Africa's Mandela Bungling Diplomacy?


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 787 words


 

Nairobi - South African President Nelson Mandela has rekindled debate about whether he is simply more tolerant to divergent opinions than most other world leaders or he is guilty of diplomatic bungling.

President Mandela caused outrage on March 6,when he said that while he had not been officially informed of an impending visit to South Africa by senior representatives of HAMAS, the Islamic fundamentalist group responsible for four recent suicide bombings that have killed over 60 people in Israel, he would be willing to meet with the organization.

The South African Jewish Board of Deputies and the South African Zionist Federation wasted no time in condemning Mandela for his remarks: "We are angry that these people whose hands are dripping with blood intend visiting our country. Indeed their terror deeds have been condemned by all, including our own government. We call on responsible politicians not to meet with these people," the two Jewish groups were reported saying. 

Reports have been rife in South Africa that President Mandela planned to meet HAMAS in a bid to mediate for peace between this group, Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Liberation Organization (PLO) and the Israeli government.

Mr. Mandela has not denied this assertion either. Although the elder statesman is on record as having condemned the HAMAS bombings "in the strongest possible terms" adding that "violence does not help solve problems," he is also known for his open door policy of meeting just about anyone, regardless of their policies or world-wide acceptance.

In February, President Mandela met with officials of the outlawed Algerian Islamic Salvation Front (FIS), which is said to be responsible for a reign of terror which has left over 40,000 people dead in this northern African country. Algeria is said to have been so outraged by the meetings that they were close to recalling their ambassador to South Africa.

Last year, a meeting between Mr. Mandela and Lybian strongman Muammar Gaddafi, a long time foe of Washington, is said to have upset the United States.

True to his "open door" policy, Mandela has also given audience to Gerry Adams, leader of the political wing of the Irish Republican Army (IRA) Sinn Fein, much to the displeasure of the British government.

Commenting about the proposed meeting with the HAMAS leadership, Democratic Party leader in South Africa, Tony Leon, said South Africans were "outraged by the idea of such a meeting: If the President believes that by meeting HAMAS he can change their views, he is sadly mistaken," Leon was reported saying.

"All he will do is further embarrass South Africa internationally and add fuel to the already existing suspicion that South Africa is not a responsible and reliable member of the international community," he concluded.

Mandela's "open door" policy in relation to the HAMAS has drawn varying reactions from other people. Mr. Jonathan Meidan of the Israeli Embassy in Nairobi told APS, "as a free man and a president of a free country, Mandela is free to meet whoever he wishes."

On the other hand, the Second Secretary of the South African High Commission in Nairobi, Wielly H. Van Derwesthuizea said that if president Mandela were to meet HAMAS officials then the public should trust that he would do so for a noble cause. "Israel cannot openly speak to HAMAS. It is safer for a neutral party, an outsider to mediate between all the parties concerned. It could be a way of getting the peace process on course yet once again," observed the diplomat.

Even as President Mandela's approach draws heated debate, his government is said to be making plans for an official visit by Cuban president Fidel Castro later in the year.

This is expected not only to raise a lot of talk but also to cause a possible rift in the United States/South African relations, given the worsening US/Cuban relations, observers say.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


237 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


MALAWI Publisher Urges Bible Scholars To Book Writing


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Lilongwe - A publisher of Christian books in Malawi is daring Bible scholars and writers in Africa to a special assignment -- that of writing more books.

Dr. Augustine Musopole, 47, a self-confessed born-again Christian, came to the helm of the Christian Literature Association in Malawi (CLAIM) on August 1 last year. His determination to challenge writers in Malawi and all over Africa is part of his multi-faceted plans to revamp the operations of CLAIM and make the organisation more relevant to the people.

"It is a great pity that Bible scholars and writers in Africa have not done much in terms of writing quality books on theology and Bible commentaries. CLAIM will now encourage these people to write. Apart from taking care of the local market, we are determined to sell some of the outstanding works overseas where there is a great demand for such books, particularly in some universities," he says. 

Dr. Musopole recently returned to Malawi after a 10-year educational and working stint in the United States of America.

Dr. Musopole says CLAIM plans to hold a series of national and regional workshops for writers to help induce people to turn to book writing. "We hope non-governmental organisations and other well- wishers elsewhere in the world will co-operate with us in funding the workshops," he adds.

An avid reader himself and an author of well-published essays, Musopole hopes CLAIM will live up to writers' expectations. "The CLAIM mandate says the organisation should publish and sell books and I think we have over many years, failed in this aspect. I hope we will reset our targets and look well beyond Malawi's borders for our market," he notes.

On the religious front, he sees potential in CLAIM publishing various books on theology, Bible commentaries, with some copies translated into several vernacular languages, Bible hand-books, tracts and other works aimed at assisting Gospel preachers to expound the Word of God better.

On the social level, Musopole talks of the need to publish more books on topics like family planning, parenting, struggles of growing-up, advice for youth and tips on education, including what to expect at universities.

"The list of possible titles is almost endless and I am sure if we put our act together, CLAIM can establish itself as a publisher of quality books which can be sought after even by readers overseas. But we first have to encourage the writers and modernise our publishing capacity," he states.

CLAIM, which started operations in Malawi in the late 1960s, has published nearly 40 books and booklets the hard way -- by using manual type-writers and hiring the services of printing houses to do virtually all the work, from the keying-in of manuscripts to the final production stage. The new CLAIM head is presently scouting around for desk-top publishing facilities for the organisation.

Dr. Musopole says he intends to encourage several writers to contribute chapters to a book for some works, while also letting those who can write books on their own do just that. "I would be happy if in the near future CLAIM can be publishing up to 50 titles in a year: that could be a good start," he enthuses.

The new CLAIM chief says he hopes to propose the introduction of a "Reading Week" or a "Reading Month", when the general public -- particularly school and college going youth can be challenged to read an entire book. "CLAIM will be suggesting some books to read, for those who need prompting...because the idea is to promote the book- reading discipline, for knowledge is power," he declares.

A self-confessed book-worm who says he reads and works to just over midnight everyday, Dr. Musopole has now challenged his entire CLAIM staff of 60 to read widely. "I have encouraged every member of staff -- from the watchman (security guard) to the top-most person in the organisation -- to be reading, for this will be one of the determining factors for promotion; I cannot see how people (staff) can be in a book trade and yet not read," he says firmly.

The CLAIM General Manager explains that he has been talking to his staff on a one-on-one basis and also consulting leaders from churches and Christian organisations on how CLAIM can interact with them better. "I have been talking to the staff to see where and how I can try and motivate them in our new determination to make CLAIM a more forward-looking organisation," he says.

Many CLAIM members of staff and some observers in Christian circles in Malawi welcome Dr. Musopole's emergence in the new post as a blessing that will go well beyond the CLAIM ministry, especially if he can translate his clear-cut if not revolutionary ideas into reality.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


238 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Authorities Shut Down Christian Schools


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 15, 1996


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Lagos - Government officials in Nigeria's central Kwara State have closed down three private Christian secondary schools in the state capital, Ilorin, accusing them of failing to provide Islamic religious courses.

In an official communication dated March 4, the state Ministry of Education withdrew temporary approval given in January to the three new schools in the state capital, because of what it described as their "deliberate violation of the relevant provisions of the provisional approval letter."

The state authorities insisted that the schools should provide for lessons in the Islamic religion and recruit qualified teachers for the subject. 

The closure of the schools effectively blocked the chances of pupils in one of the schools to enrol for Junior Secondary School Certificate examinations scheduled for later this year, according to local press reports.

The schools will remain closed for the next six months and will be re-opened after they reapply for approval, according to conditions set by the government when the schools were allowed to commence operations.

Armed policemen were on March 5 deployed to the schools to chase away students and teachers.

Kwara State is predominantly Muslim and the head of the State Education Ministry, Halimat Ajoke Yusuf, is a Muslim.

The chairman of the state branch of the Christian Association of Nigeria (CAN), Bishop Kolawole Solanke, described the government action as "simply too bad."

The CAN had in February threatened to resist any attempt by government to impose the Islamic religion on the schools, which were founded and funded by churches.

In another development, Nigeria's military government has issued a decree imposing a five-year jail term for any person or group convicted of involvement in an attempt to sabotage the military government's transition programme.

No option of a fine would be granted anyone found guilty under the Transition to Civil Rule (Political Programme) Decree number one of 1936, signed January 5 by military ruler General Sani Abacha.

The tribunal, whose chairman shall be a serving or retired senior judge, would also include a member of the armed forces, according to the decree.

The transition programme announced last October 1 by Abacha is scheduled to culminate on October 1, 1998 in the military handing over power to an elected civilian president.

The municipal elections, scheduled for between March 16 and 25, are an important component of the programme. They will be held nationwide on a "no-party basis."

The opposition National Democratic Coalition (NADECO) and human rights organisations in Nigeria have called for a boycott of the elections, describing them as an irrelevant waste of time and money.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


239 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


United States and Africa U.S. Press Freedom Group Launches Zambia Campaign Protested


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (New York) March 12, 1996


LENGTH: 1494 words


 

New York - The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), a nonpartisan advocate for press freedom, today condemned the banning of the Internet and printed editions of Zambia's leading independent newspaper, "The Post," and protests the continued legal harassment of the daily's editorial staff, including CPJ's 1995 International Press Freedom Award winner, managing director and editor in chief Fred M'membe, the latest of which has forced M'membe and his colleagues to turn themselves in after ten days in hiding.

"The suppression of the printed and electronic editions of The Post and the continued legal harassment of editor Fred M'membe and his colleagues call into question the Zambian government's proclaimed commitment to democracy," said CPJ's Executive Director, William Orme. "The censorship of independent news reporting is especially troubling during an election year, when Zambians rely on news organizations such as "The Post" for information about opposition viewpoints and government actions and policies." 

CPJ denounces the following incidents of detention without trial, censorship and the protracted legal harassment of the "The Post"'s editorial staff:

* The February 5 issue of "The Post," which revealed the Zambian government's plan to hold a referendum in March to promulgate a controversial draft constitution, was banned by presidential decree and declared a "prohibited publication" under Section 53 of the Penal Code. The decree also warned the public that any citizen caught in possession of the edition, including the on-line version, could be charged with committing a criminal offense under the Prohibited Publications Act.

* M'membe, managing editor Bright Mwape and special projects editor Masautso Phiri were arrested on Feb. 6 and charged with possessing state secrets, a violation of Section 4 of the State Security Act, and possessing a banned publication. The three were released on bail of US$350 each on Feb. 7, the same day that President Chiluba ordered the removal of the February 5 edition from "The Post"'s World Wide Web site. President Chiluba's decree marks the first act of censorship of the internet on the African continent. If convicted, M'membe, Phiri and Mwape face a maximum of 25 years in prison.

* In a separate incident, on February 23, M'membe, Mwape and columnist Lucy Banda Sichone, went into hiding to avoid imprisonment on charges of contempt of Parliament after the Zambian National Assembly, on February 21, found the three journalists guilty of violating the Powers and Privileges Act. The Act is a colonial law which prohibits non-members of parliament from criticizing proclamations issued by members of parliament. In the January 29 edition of "The Post," M'membe, Mwape and Sichone had written articles commenting on the vice president's criticism, in parliament, of a recent Supreme Court decision. The National Assembly Standing Orders Committee sentenced the three journalists to indefinite detention until they publicly apologized for breach of Parliament.

* On March 4, M'membe and Mwape surrendered to parliamentary authorities, explaining that they would not apologize to the House. M'membe pleaded with the speaker of the National Assembly to absolve Sichone, who remains in hiding with her three-month-old infant, of blame. Attorneys for "The Post" have petitioned the High Court, challenging the constitutionality of the National Assembly Powers and Privileges Act.

As reported in CPJ's annual report, "Attacks on the Press in 1995": "After a promising start, President Frederick Chiluba's government reneged on its promises to reform repressive legislation. Instead, it embarked on a deliberate campaign to restrict press freedom and is rapidly becoming one of the worst violators of press freedom in southern Africa."

Since its launch in 1991, "The Post" has endured military raids, censorship, arrests and numerous legal actions sanctioned by President Chiluba's government. For their exposure of government corruption, the journalists face countless charges, including defamation of the president, which amount to more than 125 years in prison.

CPJ has initiated a campaign to bring world attention to this pattern of harassment of the Zambian independent press and to urge President Chiluba to ensure an environment in which Zambian journalists can work freely. We encourage all those interested in participating to sign the attached letter to President Chiluba, then mail or fax it to CPJ. CPJ will forward the protest letters to the State House in Lusaka.

CPJ applauds the "World Press Review"'s recent choice of Fred M'membe as co-winner of the magazine's 1995 International Editor of the Year Award. The award is given annually to editors working outside the United States, honoring "enterprise, courage, and leadership in advancing the freedom and responsibility of the press, enhancing human rights, and fostering excellence in journalism." M'membe shares the award with Dapo Olorunyomi, editor in chief of "TheNEWS," a Lagos-based news magazine.

(For up-to-date information on the state of the media worldwide, and CPJ's activities and publications, visit CPJ's World Wide Web site at http://www.cpj.org.)

**********

His Excellency President Frederick Chiluba President of the Republic of Zambia State House Independence Avenue P. O. Box 30208 Lusaka, ZAMBIA

Your Excellency,

As an advocate of press freedom, I write to express my concern over the persecution of the staff of your country's leading independent daily newspaper, "The Post." Managing director and editor in chief Fred M'membe and his colleagues, managing editor Bright Mwape, special projects editor Masautso Phiri and columnist Lucy Sichone, have endured relentless harassment and an unprecedented number of legal charges since the newspaper was launched in 1991. For exercising their rights as journalists to freely express ideas and opinions, M'membe, a winner of three international press freedom awards, and his colleagues face countless charges which amount to more than 125 years in jail.

More recently, on March 4, M'membe and Mwape surrendered to parliamentary authorities after spending 10 days in hiding to avoid imprisonment on charges of contempt of parliament. They were sentenced by the National Assembly Standing Orders Committee which convicted the journalists, without trial in a court of law, under the National Assembly Powers and Privileges Act. They are now serving an indefinite prison sentence. Sichone, who was also convicted with M'membe and Mwape, remains in hiding with her three-month-old infant.

Furthermore, M'membe, Mwape and Phiri are facing charges of violating Section 4 of the State Security Act, the conviction of which has a jail sentence of 25 years, in connection with the banned printed and on-line editions of "The Post," which Your Excellency decreed a "prohibited publication." This decree marks the first act of censorship of the Internet on the African continent.

I strongly urge Your Excellency to annul the convictions of the three journalists, and to immediately and unconditionally release M'membe and Mwape. I also urge you to revoke the ban on the February 5 edition of "The Post," and to revoke the colonial National Assembly Powers and Privileges Act.

Finally, I call on Your Excellency, in this election year, to intervene on the side of press freedom, and to uphold your public proclamations of support for a free and independent press by ensuring an environment in which journalists may work and safely.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

March, 1996


Ethiopia Ministerial Council Approves Additional Budget


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency March 13, 1996


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Council of Ministers at its extraordinary meeting held Monday approved additional 413.1 million birr budget for ventures to be undertaken this fiscal year.

The council, following deliberations on request for the additional budget by executive offices for undertakings in the 1988 E.C. budget year, has ratified the utilization of 413.1 million of the total 651.9 million birr, excess from the annual capital and regular budget allocated to the offices. 

It underscored the need to transfer the excess budget for the implementation of new and existing projects specially to speed up their completion.

The additional budget would help reduce the capital budget to be allocated for the coming budget year, it added.

Of the additional budget, 102.5 million birr would go to promoting the Bahir Dar Polytechnic and the Makelle University Colleges to degree level, to constructing a training faculty for secondary teachers in Dilla town and equipping the Addis Ababa and the Alemaya agricultural universities with necessary facilities.

March, 1996


Arts, Culture and Entertainment (DOCUMENT) International Film Festival Seeks Africa Entries


BYLINE: Planet Africa (Toronto) March 12, 1996


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Toronto - Planet Africa is the new section at the Toronto International Film Festival; the section is devoted to films from Africa and the African diaspora. Launched at last year's Festival, Planet Africa was an immediate hit with audiences, critics and attending filmmakers. 

Among the screenings of Planet Africa are the North American premieres of Drissa TourU's Haramuya and Cheick Oumar Sissoko's Guimba. Guimba went on to play the New York Film Festival. From the U.S. came the world premieres of Thomas Allen Harris's fearless documentary, Vintage: Families of Value and Tanya Hamilton's Jamaica-set short film, The Killers. The Killers recently won Best Short in the Panorama section at the 1996 Berlin Film Festival.

Programming is starting for this year's Planet Africa. We are looking for the best new feature films (and exceptional shorts) to premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival, which runs September 5 to 14, 1996.

Over its 20-year history, the Toronto Film Festival (formerly the Festival of Festivals) has become the leading film festival in the English-speaking world. Within that, Planet Africa is a showcase for the limitless creativity of the African diaspora, unfolding in one of the world's most culturally diverse cities. There are large, thriving communities in Toronto from every corner of the African world.

If you have, or know of a film appropriate for Planet Africa that will be completed before August 12, 1996, please get in touch as soon as possible.

Contact Planet Africa, (416) 967-7371 ext. 7006, Tel; (416) 967-9477, Fax;
E-mail: dubwise@interlog.com

Africa-at-LArge Zambia Hockey Team Headed to Champion Round


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 12, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Lusaka - The hockey national side has set its eyes on the zone six championship slated for South Africa next month.

More than seven countries are expected to take part in the annual event and the Zambians say they would soon embark on a vigorous training programme to prepare for the event. 

"We want to start preparations as soon as possible," said Kennedy.

But the preparation received a setback yesterday after Kennedy announced that they were not sending a team to the Malawian invitation because of the wrong timing.

"We could have really loved to send a team to Malawi but after sitting as an executive we decided that the (invitation) had come at the wrong time.

We just closed our local season and we thought players need to rest," Kennedy said from her Kalulushi base.

Zambia last year humbled Malawi in an international friendly played in the Malawian capital of Lilongwe, winning all the three matches played.

The Malawians had requested Zambia to send two teams, a men's and a women's, for the friendlies which they had set for the end of this month.

"We wanted to travel but we just decided that it would be risky to send teams there at this stage.

We really thank the Malawians for their offer," said Kennedy.

March, 1996


Zambia Gabon Air Report To Be Released Next Month


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 14, 1996 by Goodson Machona


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Lusaka - The Gabon air disaster report will be released early next month, President Chiluba promised yesterday at a press conference.

He explained that the delay in releasing the report was because the last part of the report was yet to be received from the manufacturers of the military plane that carried 30 soccer players and officials when it plunged into the Atlantic Ocean. 

"The report took time because some parts of the aircraft had to be fished out of the sea," Chiluba said, adding: "Certain aspects of the report are already in place but we can't reveal the contents in the first report in the absence of the other report." He said the remaining report "mentions certain things that could have caused the accident." "Until the two reports are in place, we can't release the report," Chiluba said.

March, 1996


Business Anglo Looking For A Consortium For Zambian Mine


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 12, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Lusaka - Anglo American Corporation (AAC) is still trying to bring together an international consortium to finance the development of the $600 million (K600 billion) Konkola Deep Mining Project (KDMP) on the Copperbelt, a company spokesman has said.

"Negotiations are continuing.

However, I can not tell you how far we are in reaching an agreement," AAC (Central Africa) managing director Anderson Mazoka said last week Friday. 

The company signed an agreement with the Zambian government in January this year giving it the go ahead to find investors willing to invest in the mine seen as the key to the survival of the copper mining industry in Zambia.

Copper still earns about 90 per cent of of the country's foreign exchange annually.

And talks began in London the same month after the agreement was signed but little has been said about the progress made.

"We can not disclose details of negotiations," Mazoka said.

But a statement from Jack Holmes, leader of the Anglo American delegation on January 23 said the consortium would "seek to conclude agreements with government and ZCCM and will review and refine the KDMP feasibility study to a satisfactory level of confidence for a financing decision." He said feasibility studies indicated that the project was viable but "subject to further technical evaluations and the resolution of other important issues including an internationally competitive tax protocol." And finance minister Ronald Penza in his budget address last month reiterated the government's commitment to the success of the project.

"Negotiations between Anglo-American and the government have started," Penza said.

"Both sides are fully committed to moving the project forward as rapidly as possible."
No.

429, THURSDAY EDITION, MARCH 14, 1996 -FTJ won't give in to pressure By Goodson Machona THE government will not succumb to calls by opposition parties and civic organisations to adopt the new republican constitution by a constituent assembly, president Chiluba has said.

He ticked off the donor community and foreign governments who have hinted that further aid would depend on good governance and the rule of law.

"They should deal with us on the basis of partnership knowing that we are a sovereign independent state.

"I ask of you that we have had enough lessons on how countries evolve their own constitutions," Chiluba said.

Speaking at a press conference yesterday, Chiluba said there was no need for a constituent assembly because the composition of the Mwanakatwe constitution review commission was reflective of the character of the Zambian people.

"We had chiefs, non governmental organisations, churches and political parties because we didn't want to be accused of having doctored the constitution," Chiluba said, adding: "Those who meet in conventions talking about a constituent assembly, we say enjoy your time.

But my government will not capitulate or surrender its authority and power by calling for a constituent assembly." He said calling for a constituent assembly is like creating parliament by default.

"Having appointed a cross section of people who went round and gathered evidence, what will be the role of the constituent assembly?" Chiluba asked, adding: "What the people have said is already in the document (the Mwanakatwe report).

Those people calling for a constituent assembly have other designs in their mind."

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Maize Sales Raise K1 Billion


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 11, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Lusaka - About K1 billion has been raised from the sale of strategic maize reserves since the exercise began three weeks ago an official from the agricultural commodities exchange (ACE) said yesterday.

General Manager of ACE, Andrew Fletcher, said in an interview on Friday, however, that the recent political controversy over the price of mealie meal had reduced the demand by half.

"Sales have declined," Fletcher said. 

"Bids have dropped by 50 per cent." He said apart from the wrangling over the price of mealie-meal, the maize market appears to have peaked.

"The downward pressure on prices is squeezing millers who are now reluctant to buy the maize now," he said.

A recent report from the Agricultural Marketing Information Centre of the Ministry of Agriculture said bids for the maize in strategic reserves had declined to 25 totaling 1010 tonnes last week from 66 totaling 3940 tonnes in the second week and 113 totaling 3140 tonnes in the first week.

Reports that a Copperbelt miller was offering breakfast meal at K11,000 per 25 kg bag appears to have disturbed the market.

"Genuine maize traders and millers have stopped buying maize for the time being," the report said.

"Those about to import maize and or mealie meal have put their bids on hold because one can not compete with such a low price for breakfast meal." Fletcher advised politicians to allow market forces to work because trying to keep prices for consumers low now would logically require the government to support farmers when the price of local maize drops later in the season.

"If we subsidise consumption when the price is high will it mean that when prices are low the farmers will be subsidised?" he asked.

On Thursday, agriculture deputy minister Mathias Mpande advised politicians to stop interfering in the market because this was undermining the confidence of traders.

"My minister and I have worked hard to give confidence to the private sector and if they stopped participating in the maize market shortages could result in prices going as high as K30,000," he said.

Zambia National Farmers Union president Ben Kapita also criticised politicians over their recent utterances because they amounted to hypocrisy.

"This government has never kept maize prices from falling.

When farmers faced ruin in 1993 they were given promissory notes instead of a good maize price," Kapita said.

"But when prices rise it appears that farmers will not be allowed to benefit." Fletcher earlier said the controversy had created uncertainty in the maize market but he was confident it would settle down later.

March, 1996


Business Lusaka Exchange Records K140m Profit


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 11, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - The Lusaka Stock Exchange (LuSE) recorded a turnover of K139.5m last week, a big increase from the K19.7m recorded the previous week, the Weekly Stock News reveals.

A total of 25 trades were recorded during the week beginning March 4 to 8, down 10 from the previous week's 35. 

A large single transaction of K136.5 million for 2,393,846 Chilanga Cement shares at K57 each on March 6, helped to boost trade volumes on the exchange.

A total of eight trades were recorded in Chilanga Cement shares during the week under review, the price however, remained stable at K57 per share.

Only three trades were again recorded in Rothmans of Pall Mall shares with 3,000 shares valued at K120,000 exchanging hands.

Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines 'B' shares dropped to K1,000 from K1,500 last week with only one trade taking place for 167 shares valued at K167,000.

Among the five unlisted securities Standard Chartered Bank and Zambia Sugar were the only actively traded shares.

The price of the Standard Chartered shares dropped from K10 to K8, with 9 trades of 39,745 shares valued at K334,877 being recorded.

Zambia Sugar shares were down to K25 from K30 last week and four trades of 11,214 shares valued at K280,350 were recorded.
