March, 1996


Zambia MPs Warned Over Draft Constitution


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 12, 1996 by Samson Mujuda and George Jambwa


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Lusaka - After ten days of deliberations, the 'Concerned Citizens' have vowed not to vote for any member of parliament who does not support the adoption of the republican constitution through a Constituent Assembly.

One participant, Lee Habasonda, advised other delegates to campaign against any members of parliament who are opposed to a Constituent Assembly.

"We should not allow ourselves to be manipulated by these politicians. 

We should still insist that we adopt our constitution through a Constituent Assembly if the views of the people are to be reflected," Habasonda said.

Most delegates felt a Constituent Assembly be organised despite the government's opposition and disregard of the debates on the Mwanakatwe Draft Constitution by presenting the Amendment Bill to Parliament.

"In 1991 we fought against that monster of dictatorship and now we have to fight that monster of total injustice to liberate ourselves from this bondage." "In 1991 there was an uprising against the UNIP government by every Zambian, we need another uprising against these men who are taking our country backwards," the participants said.

Daniel Lisulo also asked the participants to work out possible measures should government refuse to listen to the people.

"We should make sure that the 'Green Paper' that will be prepared should reflect the true views of the people.

And after this we should make sure we publicise it so that people can compare it with the government white paper.

The 'Green paper' should be outstanding from the white paper," Lisulo said.

John Mfula who travelled from Kasama said they should make it clear that the ruling MMD succumbs to their demands over the constitituion.

"Lets show them that if they fail to listen to our demands, we should make it very clear when they come to us to ask for a vote," he said.

The 'Green Paper' will be handed to the President, the Chief Justice and the speaker of the National Assembly.

Last week foreign affairs minister Christon Tembo was reported to have assured South Africa foreign minister Alfred Nzo who is currently in the country that government would consider some of the 'reasonable' proposals from the 'Citizen Convention'.

March, 1996


Business Former Zambian Minister Named To Head Mining Board


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 14, 1996 by Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Lusaka - Former finance minister Luke Mwananshiku has been appointed to chair the ZCCM board to make sure operations are smooth before the privatisation of the mining conglomerate.

President Chiluba announced yesterday at a State House press conference that Mwananshiku and two other independent board members had been appointed to the board to streamlime operations.

"The decline of ZCCM is really a worrying issue and government is doing something to ensure that all is well by the time it is privatised," he said. 

Chiluba said that proper management was crucial in the running of ZCCM affairs if things were to move accordingly before privitisation.

On its privatisation, he said the whole programme was on course but he could not indicate the time frame within which the exercise would be concluded. And Chiluba has said that his government has performed well on the economic front since it came into power and asked people to give it another mandate to complete its programme.

The MMD had proved to be a responsible government which had established and mantained staunch relations with both the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

He said government has been serious about reform and that it would take a lot of time before some of the fruits of the current government could be realised.

"The government has been particular and concerned about reforms, which has caused a lot of suffering for the ordinary people.

But it should be realised that it is a long road to cover," he said.

On the increase of mealie-meal prices, the President accused some farmers of using the maize issue to generate dissent against government.

It was being parochial, he said, for farmers to tell politicians to stop talking about maize and mealie meal price when people's lives were being affected.

"These people are being parochial by telling us not to talk about maize and mealie meal price.

Politics in Africa are about food and shelter, how can we stop talking about it?" he asked.

LANGUAGE: English

249 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia NP Condemns Draft Constitutional Bill


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 13, 1996 by Masauso Lungu


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - The National Party (NP) has condemned the draft constitutional bill empowering the President to dismiss Supreme and High Court judges.

NP spokesman, Sam Chipungu, said in an interview yesterday that the hasty publication of the bill has put the independence of the judiciary at stake. 

Chipungu said the problem started when the bill for the conditions of service for the judges was passed.

"If the President has powers of giving judges conditions of service, what can stop him from firing them?" Chipungu asked, adding, "We condemn this article because it undermines the independence of the judiciary.

The article may look innocent on the surface of it, but it is very serious in reality," Chipungu carped.

And NP Legal chairman Ludwig Sondashi said the amendment cannot be accepted in a civilised society as it greatly violates the independence of the judiciary by insisting to know the reason why the judge acted in the manner he did.

"The article can only be effected by a primitive government such as ours as is proving to be," Sondashi said, adding,"the MMD should also know that they will not stay in power forever, the same article they are effecting today will work against them tomorrow." Chipungu further condemned the recalling of retired judges to the bench and described them as 'client judges'.

"If a recalled retired judge is handling a sensetive political case, what will stop him from being on the realms of the executive?" he asked.

He said President Chiluba wants to take full control of the judiciary so that it could be easier to overturn the judges decisions in some cases like they have done to the landmark Supreme Court judgment by the Chief Justice Matthew Ngulube on the Public Order Act.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


250 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia New Powers for President Stir Opposition


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 11, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 560 words


 

Lusaka - Opposition parties and human rights organisations have reacted sharply to an article in the draft constitutional bill empowering the President to dismiss Supreme or High Court judges.

Section 98(3) grants the President power to remove a judge from office subject to ratification by the National Assembly, for gross misconduct which 98 (5) defines as: "the taking into account of extraneous considerations whether political, personal or otherwise, which have the effect of causing gross misapplication or misinterpretation of the law resulting in gross injustice to an individual or the state or to the general public welfare and good governance." Liberal Progress Front secretary Rolf Shenton charged that the whole constitution was a "fraud". 

"I don't want to discuss any part of the constitution.

The whole thing is just a fraud which is just being imposed on the people," he said.

The Legal Resources Foundation(LRF) charged that the clause was meant to undermine the judiciary.

"There is no law anywhere where a judge can be removed for misinterpreting the law, this is completely against the legal principles," LRF legal officer Robby Shabwanga said," adding: "This shows how intolerant the government is towards calls for an independent judiciary." But efforts to get a comment from the government officials failed.

Vice President Godfrey Miyanda, chief government spokesman Amusaa Mwanamwambwa and Home Affairs Minister Chitalu Sampa were all said to be out of Lusaka.

And Zambia Democratic Congress(ZDC) Vice-President Kasuka Mutukwa said the "the constitutional making process had a totally punitive approach and should be rejected by the people".

"This clause specifically targeted at the judiciary clearly shows that the MMD government would like to have a free hand to tamper with the independence of the judiciary," Mutukwa said in an interview yesterday.

National Party secretary general Akashambatwa Mbikusita Lewanika said the MMD government had personalised the constitutional process.

"This shows the personalised partisan position from the government in trying to intimidate the bench into making decisions in line with their political considerations," Lewanika said.

But CHAKA party president Jairus Kalisilira suggested that the independence of the judiciary can only be maintained if the existing parliamentary system is changed.

"What we need is to have an upper and lower house system of parliament.

Appointments should be done by the upper house so that the President becomes a complete servant of the people," Kalisilira said.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

March, 1996


Business Sale of BP Zambia To Be Completed Soon


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 13, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - British Petroleum (Zambia) managing director, Roger Griffiths, has said the sale of the company may be concluded with the Zambia Privatisation Agency within two months.

"The heads of agreement has been reached and the sales agreement may be finalised in the next month or two," he said at a press briefing on Monday. 

He said the 51 per cent government shares would be floated to the public by the Zambia Privatisation Trust Fund to enable Zambians buy shares in the company.

Griffiths also said that he would like BP shares listed on the Lusaka Stock Exchange to benefit from the five per cent reduction in corporate tax given to companies so listed.

"It would be part of the negotiating stance, we would be interested in that," he said.

The February 28 privatisation status report says BP had acquired 25 per cent shares in BP Zambia for $3.2 million (K3.2 billion) under its pre-emptive rights.

And visiting BP Southern Africa and BP Africa chief executive Fred Phaswana said BP employees would be able to own shares in BP International once BP Zambia was privatised because of the company's employee share scheme.

He reaffirmed that BP was here to stay and as proof of this, the company has budgeted US $2 million annually for infrastructure development such as filling stations, storage depots for customers and other facilities.

Phaswana ruled out the possibility of BP and Mobil merging in Zambia like they have done in Europe because conditions here were different.

"The BP and Mobil merger in Europe was dictated by conditions in Europe," he said.

"I don't see those circumstances here."

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia University Body Banned For Siding With Post


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 12, 1996 by Kunda Mwila


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - The University of Zambia Political, Social and Economic Debate Association (UNZAPOSED) has been banned for one year for issuing a press statement against the sentencing of The Post editors by the speaker of National Assembly.

The banning of UNZAPOSED, which was announced by the dean of students last Thursday, came after the University of Zambia Students Union (UNZASU) complained to the dean that the association had violated the affiliation regulations by issuing a statement without consulting it as the mother body.

"We recommended to the dean of students affairs to have UNZAPOSED banned because its executive ignored the regulation which stipulates that all clubs at the campus can only issue press statements through or after consulting UNZASU," UNZASU secretary general Chungu Malitonga said in an interview last Thursday, adding: "But this is not about what the club said but the kind of way the statement was issued." UNZAPOSED President Henry Malikyama last Tuesday condemned the move by the speaker of the National Assembly Robinson Nabulyato to jail indefinitely managing director and editor-in-chief Fred M'membe, managing editor Bright Mwape and columnist Lucy Sichone. 

He demanded the immediate lifting of the sentence unconditionally.

But the banning has been condemned by UNZAPOSED.

"The punishment is too much on us," Malikyama complained in an interview on Thursday night.

"We did not speak on behalf of all the students so it is very unfair to ban the club." The association was banned on the day it was supposed to hold a debate with political leaders from the ruling MMD and opposition parties on the "Public Order Act amendment versus Constitutional liberties".

"The banning of UNZAPOSED is very unfortunate because academic freedom of expression which exists at UNZA has grossly been done away with," senior student Namakando Sumbwa said.

The ban almost caused confusion at UNZA on Thursday evening and students who wanted to attend the debate immediately demanded the impeachment of the entire UNZASU executive.

UNZASU president Emmanuel Tembo is expected to hold a press conference sometime this week to discuss the students' position on the mode of adoption of the constitution, the arrest of Post editors, UNZASU's role in the forthcoming general elections and other important national issues.

UNZASU publicity secretary Brian Mulenga confirmed the press conference in a notice to students released on Friday, but no date has been set.

Zambia UNZA students support the 'Citizen Convention'


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 12, 1996 by George Jambwa


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - University students have described the just ended 'Citizen Convention' as a very progressive tool and a fundamental pillar of the democratisation process.

In a joint letter sent to the Civil Society chairman Morse Nanchenga, both University of Zambia and Copperbelt University students said they were in total support of the noble cause the convention was pursuing. 

"We would like to assure you that the students of CBU and UNZA are in total support of this noble cause the convention is pursuing.

We seem to have appeared at the last minute because of some other official duties that needed quick attention".

"However, we perceive this convention as a very progressive tool intended to create a fundamental pillar of our democratisation process," reads a letter signed by two union presidents, Emmanuel Tembo and Ronald Hatoongu respectively.

The students said they realise that the constitution should not protect systems.

"We realise that the constitution should not protect systems but should make systems effective and stand the test of time," the letter reads further.

March, 1996


United States and Africa US Monitors Zambia's Democratisation Process


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 14, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Lusaka - The United States (US) government is keenly monitoring the current democratisation process taking place in Zambia.

Visiting US principal deputy assistant secretary for African affairs, Prudence Bushnell, said during a press briefing in Lusaka yesterday that her visit was aimed at consolidating democracy.

"We saw the first democratic elections in Zambia. 

But what is important is not the elections but what comes afterwards in the consolidation of this democracy," Bushnell said, adding: "The second elections are also important because when you talk about democracy you do not only talk about specific insitutions, but also the underpinnings to it like freedom of the press, freedom of assembly, corruption and need for transparency," she said.

Bushnell also disclosed that the question of the two detained Post editors was discussed during the talks with President Chiluba but could not give further details.

"That was one of the issues we discussed but I was informed that they were jailed on a parliamentary law of this country, and I accept that," she said.

She also called on both the government and the opposition parties to promote a culture of democracy which she said could only be created by parliament, government, the press and the people.

"The government has a responsibility to apply laws fairly and listen to all citizens.

The opposition has a responsibility to make their programmes known to their citizens and the press has also got a responsibilty to report truthfully without exageration," Bushnell said.

Opposition parties and other interested groups recently called on the donor community to impose sanctions on Zambia, but Bushnell warned that the consequences of sanctions would be adverse.

"I held discussions with various leaders of opposition parties but none of them brought up the issue of sanctions, but I wish to say that the impact of the results go beyond what you may want to achieve," warned Bushnell, adding: "So that if you want to impose economic sanctions they must be well targeted."

Africa News


March, 1996


Business Zambian Manufacturers Appeal Ruling on Duties


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 12, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Association of Manufacturers (ZAM) has urged the government to review its decision to classify some inputs as finished goods, thereby attracting duty.

ZAM Vice-chairman, Anthony Simmonds, said in an interview yesterday that government's move defeated finance minister Ronald Penza's recent budget announcement that duty on manufacturing raw materials would be reduced to 5 per cent from 20 per cent.

"The government gave certain reductions in tariffs for manufacturing raw materials. 

But the ministry of finance and Zambia Revenue Authority have redefined some previously regarded as manufacturing inputs as finished goods and the duty has gone up," Simmonds said.

He gave examples of bearings and wire used in the manufacture of goods for the mines.

"Both to a certain extent are finished products," he admitted.

"But if they are used to manufacture other items they are raw materials." Simmonds said the measure was annoying because manufacturers expected duty rates to fall instead of rising.

"The major effect has been to move the duty from 20 to 25 per cent in many cases instead of down to 5 per cent," he said.

And acting ZRA public relations officer Nkweto Tembwe confirmed that discussions had taken place between ZAM, ZRA and the ministry of finance on the complaints raised by the manufacturers.

"The difficulty is that what one manufacturer considers a raw material is not necessarily a raw material as defined by the very comprehensive customs tariff code," Tembwe said.

However, he said as a result of lobbying and political representations, some adjustments have been made to the tariffs in the committee stage of the Customs Amendment Bill presented to parliament in the last session.

Tembwe said further adjustments could be made by way of statutory instruments.

Finance minister Ronald Penza said in his budget address in January that duty on raw materials and productive machinery was being reduced from 20 per cent to 5 per cent and on intermediate goods from 30 per cent to 15 per cent.

He said the measure was meant to remove tariff anomalies and improve competitiveness of Zambia's producers relative to those in the sub region

Zambia Elections office to sue ZIMT


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 13, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Lusaka - Elections office has commenced legal proceedings against the Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) after The Post carried a story that ZIMT had discovered secret voter registration centres in Lusaka's Kaunda square compound in February.

Field registration supervisor for Lusaka, George Phiri disclosed this in an interview on Monday but could not give details. 

"I have been directed by the director of elections to inform you to be on stand-by as the case will be coming up in court soon,"JPhiri said without disclosing the date of the case.

But ZIMT president Alfred Zulu described the action as a mere threat and said his organisation was ready to go to court.

"We are ready to go to court as we have evidence on the irregularities we have so far uncovered in the on-going voters registration exercise," Zulu said in a separate interview on Monday.

Both Zulu and his vice-president Isaac Zimba disclosed earlier that they had received reports of secret vote centres in Lusaka and said one such place was a residential home, No 29,in Kaunda square stage two,which was suspected to belong to an MMD official.

Registration officer for Lusaka, John Mulenga, who had earlier admitted receiving the reports, later denied claiming the information was false.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Economists Want Foreign Exchange Controls To Stop Depreciating Kwacha


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 12, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Lusaka - As the Kwacha continues to depreciate, there are growing calls among the business houses and some economists to re-introduce controls on the foreign exchange rates.

Zambia Education Publising House managing director, Henry Chipewo, says there is need to introduce some form of control on the ever soaring exhange rates. He called for a fixed exchange rate by the central bank which he felt was more appropriate to the country. 

"A flexible fixed exchange rate is more desirable in Zambia," Chipewo observed, explaining: "The Bank of Zambia should have a duty of closely studying the behaviour of macro-economic factors and simply make timely adjustments than is the case now where everything is just let loose without any control."

He said that the current Kwacha devaluation at the expense of the liberalised exchange rate controls had only inflicted poverty on citizens as Zambia's core export copper was subjected to low prices and felt that these kind of scenario was only workable in industrialised countries like Japan.

"Zambia at the moment produces nothing that should induce natural devaluation of the Kwacha to create any competitive edge against anyone," he said adding that:

"If anything, devaluation has only enabled us to inflict more poverty on our selves by selling more copper for less money in real terms and more over whatever we export is for peanuts."

But Chipewo's suggestions were quickly shot down by Central Bank spokesman, Kabinga Pande last Friday, who felt introducing such controls was going back to the old system of governing economic affairs which inhibited economic growth.

"I don't think that would be the best thing to do as it would be like going back to the old system of running economic affairs,"JPande said but declined to further comment on the matter but promised to issue a detailed statement later.

Pande's sentiments were supported by former Bankers Association of Zambia chairman and managing director of Barclays Bank Zambia Limited, Michael McNie who termed the calls for exchange controls as "appalling."

"It would be appalling to go back to the exchange control system. We've got a liberalised economy and a free market economy, what should just be worked out to halt further devaluation of the Kwacha is a proper management of the economy," McNie observed, adding:J"Even if we went back to the old system the value of the Kwacha would still continue to fall with the high inflation in the country."


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Do Not Politicise Our Funds, Youths Say


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 13, 1996 by Reuben Phiri


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - YOUTHS have asked the President to ensure the Youth Constituency Funds launched last year was not politicised.

The message was delivered to President Frederick Chiluba by Lenganji Namumba, a grade 12 pupil of Matero girls secondary in Lusaka. She also called for the funds to be unblocked from the current bureaucratic systems of disbursement. 

"We would like you to ensure that the fund and the youth enterprises revolving fund are not held up in local government and political bureaucratic procedures," Namumba said, adding: "Local government institutions have also become political rather than service to the communities where they belong."

In his speech President Chiluba said the youths were a major resource of output who should take full responsibility to participate.

"The youth consist of a major resource of output in this country and the economy will only be successful if each and everyone of you embraces the responsibilty to fully participate," Chiluba said, and he disclosed: "Government has increased the allocation of the youth enterprises revolving fund and will keep increasing when the budget allows."

He also promised that the issue of constituency funds would be addressed and that the youths were free to give their views on their use.

"We shall ensure that the disbursement of the fund is not subjected to partisanism. You should also be free to express critical views on how the fund is progressing," Chiluba said.

The youth week reached a climax with hundreds of youths attending a wreath laying ceremony officiated by President Chiluba at the Freedom statue in Lusaka yesterday to mark the end of the celebrations.

Chiluba disclosed at the same function that 70 per cent of the Zambian population were below the age of thirty.

Members of the diplomatic corp also attended the ceremony and laid wreaths at the statue.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Clause not aimed at KK


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 14, 1996 by Goodson Machona and Masautso Phiri


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Lusaka - PRESIDENT Frederick Chiluba has dissociated himself and his government from the decision to include the citizenship clause which will bar former president Kenneth Kaunda from contesting the forthcoming elections.

"Nothing can be further from the truth. That is totally false. Our constitution shall not be tailored around one man," Chiluba told a State House press conference yesterday. 

But Kaunda described Chiluba's performance at the press conference as "dishonest" and nothing of importance except "play acting".

"You cannot play act on important issues such as a constitution of a country. The constitution of the Republic is a sacred document and it must be treated as such," Kaunda said in an interview yesterday. UNIP will hold a press conference on Sunday, he said and added: "To say the least it is a sad thing to have a head of state who is dishonest with himself and the nation."

Liberal Progressive Front secretary Rolf Shenton described Chiluba's performance as "nothing new".

"I have heard nothing new from President Chiluba for the past four years. It is sad that he is not prepared to listen when the country is crying out for compromise. All he is talking about is power because that is what he has and he is not prepared to listen," Shenton said.

At the press conference yesterday Chiluba claimed the clause in the Mwanakatwe draft constitution which bars people whose parents are not Zambians from standing as Republican Presidents was included by the Mwanakatwe constitutional review commission.

He also claimed that the Mwanakatwe commission concluded its work long before Kaunda announced his return to politics.

"Kaunda could not have been a factor in this report because just before the commission commenced work our dear Kenneth Kaunda announced his retirement from politics," Chiluba said, adding: "He did not come back until the commission had collected all the evidence. I would like to know how he could have been a factor while he was in retirement."

But this is disputed by both Kaunda and his press assistant Muhabi Lungu who is a former staunch MMD supporter. Lungu said Kaunda made known his intentions to return to politics long before Mwanakatwe made his report.

"It is a deliberate lie by Chiluba, a deliberate manipulation of facts," said Lungu who also said that by the time Sikota Wina was making the MMD submission to the commission Kaunda had already completed his tour of the country. "President Chiluba is lying," Lungu insisted yesterday.

And Kaunda described as "criminal" Chiluba's inclusion in the draft constitutional bill of a clause which will give him power to dismiss judges of the Supreme and High courts.

"This is one of the criminal acts by this president and his government. Today judges are under pressure, what type of democracy is that - to intimidate judges? That is not done by any democrat," Kaunda said, adding: "It demonstrates the type of man he is. A man who thinks like that is a dictator of the worst kind."

Kaunda, who described his relationship with Chiluba as far from being cordial as the President claimed, also charged that Chiluba should take his hands off the judges because his actions "will bring bloodshed to Zambia."

"It shows the man is sick. The relationship is nasty. The last time he talked to me on the phone he literally insulted me," Kaunda said.

Both Kaunda and his press assistant insisted that the former president would contest this year's elections.

"He will stand no matter what they do," Lungu said yesterday.

"Nothing will stop me from contesting the presidency of this country, I have come to lead this country into second liberation and I will do it," Kaunda said at a rally a week ago.

But Chiluba says Kaunda will only stand "if the law does not define or prescribe" what it says.

"When the constitution says this is the position, that is the position everyone follows," Chiluba declared.

The clause has been a contentious issue ever since the government white paper was released.

Last week "concerned citizens" drawn from various political parties, NGOs and other interested parties met at Lusaka's Mulungushi conference centre where they unanimously agreed that anyone can stand as Republican President as long as he or she was Zambian.

March, 1996


Zambia Chainama golfer maintains lead


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 14, 1996 by Jeff Kapembwa


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - Kelvin Phiri of Chainama maintained his supremacy at the weekend when he lifted the Livingstone open golf Championship after grossing 146.

Phiri, playing off scratch handicap, emerged overall winner of the tournament when he amassed 7 gross in the morning and brought home 67 in the afternoon to beat more than 89 other golfers. 

Phiri beat his club mate and two handicap Martin Banda who got 151 gross after amassing 73 gross in the morning and 78 in the afternoon.

Banda had an impressive seven birdies. He gunned four birdies after playing nine holes and had two birdies after the 27th round.

In a related development, Zambia Airforce (ZAF) has donated K1.2million to Chainama Golf club for its upkeep.

ZAF Commander Ronnie Shikapwasha said the money donated is intended to assist in the maintenance of the course and that the money was a gesture of goodwill.

Shikapwasha made the announcement during the ZAF invitation golf tournament at the weekend which was won by Ignitius Kashoki who had an impressive 39 points.

March, 1996


Zambia 1996 Basketball: Losing candidate cries


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 11, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - A LOSING candidate at the Zambia Basketball Association elections held last Saturday has attributed his defeat to a smear campaign by his club chairman.

Anderson Nyembe, who was highly-tipped for the job, charged that Lusaka City Council (LCC) Looters chairman, Wesly Katepu played tricks against him. 

"Just before the voting started as contesting persons, we were asked to leave the room but shortly after we left , Katepu lied to the out-going chairman , Brian Chisengalumbwe, that all people that had nominated me were not representatives of the clubs. But what even surprised me was that voting went on even after that without informing me. I think it would be fair for Katepu to stop personal vendettas, he won't develop sport like this," observed Nyembe in an interview yesterday.

Nyembe was nominated by Willy Chama of Roan and Lottie Zulu of LCC.

But the former LCC Looters and national team trainer, Nyembe maintained that he will still continue working with the new executive despite losing.

"I am not bitter and I will now try all I can to help where I can. My plans are that basketball should be re-orgainsed in schools before concentration on higher levels," said Nyembe.

Kaonga polled 9 votes to emerge as the new chief for the assocaition while Davy Katete was second with six votes in a three-man contest which saw Nyenbe getting no votes.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia 'Nikuv operating illegally in Zambia'


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 12, 1996 by Mukalya Nampito


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Lusaka - NIKUV Computers is not a registered company in Zambia, the Lusaka High Court was told yesterday.

Deputy Registrar of Companies in the ministry of commerce George Lipimile told High Court Commissioner Bornaventure Mutale that according to a search conducted last Friday, Nikuv was not registered to operate in Zambia.

"From the search we conducted last Friday (February 8, 1996) in both local and foreign registers, the company that was stated on the summons, Nikuv Computers Israel Limited, is not registered," Lipimile said. 

The revelations came during the continued trial in the case in which the United National Independence Party ( UNIP ) and the Liberal Progressive Front (LPF) have sued the government over the hiring of Nikuv Computers to do this year's registration of voters.

And a former Nikuv Computers employee, Jeffrey Chanda, said there was a possibility that some voters names would be omitted on the final computer printout sheet.

Chanda said the procedure used to verify information in the computers was such that if something was omitted, a person was required to put zero.

"For example if on the application form, your registration number has been correctly put but the computer operator missed out a figure, instead of correcting it, I had to put a zero in that place which would change the meaning of the number," Chanda said.

And Lipimile said according to the law, any foreign company that is working in Zambia is required to register within 28 days of operation.

The two parties' lawyer, Nosiku Kawanambulu, asked whether the registrar of companies would have had documents if it was registered in Zambia.

"If it was registered, it was going to appear on our local or foreign company registers and we were going to have a file on promoters. We don't have any particulars relating to Nikuv," Lipimile said.

Defense counsel solicitor general, Sam Chisulo, asked Lipimile whether in a situation such as this one where the government had hired a foreign company to do work for it in short term, the company would have still to be registered.

"The question would require for him to interpret the law because the Companies Act requires that the type of business being done in Zambia be stated but for this one I wouldn't exactly know because I don't know what the company is doing here," said Lipimile.

Zambia Independent Monitoring Team vice-president Isaac Zimba also testified on the experience he had in Kaunda Square stage two where a house there was being used to register only MMD members and the fact that the house was not a legal registration place.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


263 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia 'I'm not at large, simply protecting my rights. . .'


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 11, 1996 by Lucy Sichone


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

Lusaka - Last week's news was devoted to the surrender and committal to an indefinite term of imprisonment of two young heroes Fred M'membe and Bright Mwape. The sentence was passed by Miyanda and Nabulyato for offences committed against their persons in that Fred, Bright and myself did not acknowledge the infallibility of these two god heads.

Since the three of us have made it clear that we have no intention of committing idolatry by "repentance", the two men may spend some time in prison. But that is what principle, integrity and freedom fighting is all about. That is how South Africa gave birth to Mandela currently doing Africa proud. 

I am still reported as at large with a K2 million price tag on my head. I take issue with the description of being at large and with the price tag of K2 million being put on my option not to submit to Nabulyato's unconstitutional decree depriving me of my personal liberty.

Article 28 of the Republican constitution tells me that if any of my rights and freedoms vested in me by the Constitution has been, is being or is likely to be contravened I should apply to the High Court for redress.

Consequently, when Nabulyato issued his unlawful edict, application was made to the High Court that my right to personal liberty (Article 13), protection of the law (Article 18), right to freedom of expression had been contravened and the court should consider the issues and offer me protection pending final court verdict. Deputy Chief Justice, Bweupe, doesn't believe that a contravention of my rights guaranteed by the constitution should move the court, the protector of last defence at a pace that would have protected Bright, Fred and myself from being deprived of our personal liberties without due process of the law. He set the date for May 7 and advised that meanwhile we go and serve a prison sentence which offends against the constitution, natural justice and plain commonsense.

I asked myself: if the institutions which are supposed to ensure that my rights and freedoms under the constitution are not taken away arbitrarily and without regard to the rule of law are unwilling to discharge this sacred duty- who is going to save me from the perverse rule of men.

The old age answer points to me as an individual. If today, Nabu-lyato can sign a warrant not provided for under any law purporting to deprive me of my personal liberty and I succumb; tomorrow as a result of this article the same Nabulyato will sign a warrant for my execution.

When I appeal to Bweupe under the constitution to save me from death, which is not sanctioned by any law, from the evidence available in this case, I will be told to go and be hanged. The question of whether my hanging was lawful or not can be left to the administrator of my estate to sort out.

The fight for rights and freedoms has always been an individual one-that is why we have the Nelson Mandela's, Abraham Lincoln, and their genre.

Martin Luther King's Civil Rights Movement has origins in the courage of one old black woman, who took up a seat in an all white section of a bus risking being thrown under the wheels of a moving bus. King responded to the life sacrificing courage of that old lady to mobilise the march to freedom to which millions of Americans responded ending with a mammoth rally and with King's "I have a dream" epic speech.

It was in response to the courage of that same woman to exercise her right that galvanised the Kennedy/Johnson Administration to put the state machinery in defence of the rights and freedoms of black America. There is also the story of that courageous black man, the first to enter the all white University in Alabama. He went under the protection of the American Home Guard, who surrounded the university and the lecture hall in which he spent the first day without other white students or lecturers.

It is those actions, that define the sanctity of the rights and freedoms enshrined in the Bill of Rights and make it a sacred duty for me to defend them to the death. The sacred duty of individuals to fight for their freedoms shouldn't be degraded by cheap price tags of any amount , Kwacha prizes are for drug traffickers, murderers and those who pervert justice.

My right to personal liberty won't be taken away without the due process of the law. If I am found tomorrow it must be understood that I, an unarmed woman with a baby on my back will have to be executed for resisting the unlawful deprivation of my personal liberty. My life will be my contribution to the old age struggle of freedom against all forms of slavery, dictatorship and tyranny such as that of Nabulyato and Miyanda that detracts from my dignity as a human being. This is why I object to the cheapening of the issues involved in the Nabu-lyato saga to K2 million. Freedom is priceless;that is why Fred and Bright surrendered to imprisonment; it places the fight into proper perspective beyond prices but where it focuses the attention of men of honour and integrity and sows the seeds for our own King's style of march to freedom and Zambia's own collective dream of a government established on the principles of human rights and freedoms, equality before the law, justice and governance dictated by the rule of law.

Meanwhile, I am not at large; I am protecting my constitutional right to liberty, protection of the law, freedom of expression until the matter comes before the courts.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


264 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia 'Constitution discriminatory against women'


BYLINE: Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 11, 1996 By Kunda Mwila


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Lusaka - THE new Republican Constitution should stop the current legalised discrimination against women, Non-Governmental Organisation Committee (NGOCC) chairperson Susan Jere demanded in a press statement released on International Women's Day on Friday last week.

"The current Republican Constitution of Zambia allows discrimination of women under customary law, marriage law and personal law," Jere said. 

"Article 23 of the 1991 Constitution which purports to protect women against discrimination actually serves to legalise discrimination in wide areas of administrative and social practice."

She said the nation is living in a critical moment as to the protection of women's rights and eradication of discrimination based on gender.

"The submissions to this effect by the women's movement to the Mwanakatwe Constitution Review Commission were incorporated in its draft but the government in its white paper No 1 rejected these submissions and maintained the current laws and practices," she said.

And the University of Zambia Department of Development Studies lecturer Charlotte Wonani, who led UNZA students in a march past Friday from the Lusaka main Post Office to the High Court, said women are eventually succeeding in their battle for equal rights.

"The fact that women now can gather and have their message heard indicates a major success in our fight for equalJrights," Wonani said in an interview after the march past.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa (DOCUMENT) ANC Statement On The 1996/97 Budget


BYLINE: African National Congress of South Africa March 13, 1996


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Johannesburg - The ANC welcomes the major thrust of the 1996/97 budget and would like to urge the government to remain firmly focused throughout the year on the critical areas of RDP delivery as envisaged in the Minister's speech. We fully support his view that this is The Year of Meaningful Delivery on the RDP. In this context, the government is urged to develop clearly implementable plans to achieve this objective.

We see the budgets of the Government of National Unity as building blocks in the transition process from an Apartheid era through reconstruction and development to full democracy . In a number of areas, reprioritisation still needs to be driven firmly and the government should develop fairly quickly, the multi-year fiscal plan which the Minister has made mention of. This is critical in ensuring a decisive break with the past. 

The budget should have a positive impact on economic development in the coming year and every effort should be made to galvanise the country around this perspective. Job creating measures should be enhanced and policies tightly co-ordinated so that we do not lose the momentum required for this gigantic task. In this regard, the ANC welcomes the emphasis placed on the creation of jobs by the Minister. We are extremely concerned that over the past year, very few jobs have been created in both the private and public sectors of the economy.

In this context, the government will need to concentrate its efforts more effectively at the national public works programme as one of the job creating strategies. This will contribute both towards poverty alleviation and development, particularly in areas of infrastructural development and upgrading. The ANC would like to urge the government to consider a more bold initiative which ensures and takes advantage of complementarities between the RDP and public works programmes.

The African National Congress notes the progress being made in the area of taxation policy. We need to move with some speed in bringing to finality the work of the Katz Commission so that certainty can be achieved. In this budget, we would like to make special mention of the way in which the incorporation of the retirement industry into the tax system has been addressed. The Minister and his department have handled this matter in a responsible and strategic manner. The ANC therefore calls upon the industry to cooperate with the authorities in making these proposals a success . There is no cause in our view for any alarm on the part of members of retirement funds.

As far as VAT is concerned, we are pleased that the Minister was wise enough not to heed some of the more short-sighted and insensitive "free advice" to raise the rate and again has set out a strategic approach to this issue. As stated by the ANC on numerous occasions before, VAT is an effective yet regressive tax which in the absence of a social security system, would place an undue burden on the poor.

We are encouraged by the progress being made with regard to personal taxes. We note that the middle and lower income earners will receive some relief. We urge the government to continue to do more in this regard.

The year's budget is beginning to show signs of the required shift in allocations towards our objectives as contained in the RDP. We are particularly pleased to see that through reducing expenditure on non-priority areas such as nuclear energy, the defence special account, the General Export Incentive Scheme and administrative expenditure in the education department, the government has been able to provide additional resources available for education, state aided training centres, community policing, health care, housing , water affairs, land redistribution and welfare. There has also been allocations to the RDP fund as promised. We are also pleased to see that in this budget, for the first time, full information is provided indicating how these funds will be allocated. This is good news for our people. The government needs to ensure that this time next year, we must not be lamenting about unspent funds. Funds allocated must be spent effectively and timeously!

The ANC supports the policy of the government with regard to the commitment to reduce the budget deficit in a gradual and systematic manner. The overall level of indebtedness is a serious problem which demands careful management. The current level of the debt as a percentage of GDP imposes tremendous difficulties for fiscal policy. An effective debt management strategy and system is therefore critical.

The commitment to gender equality and equity in the budget is to be welcome.

Issued by: African National Congress Dept of Information and Publicity PO Box 61884 Marshalltown 2107


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Science, Medicine and Technology (DOCUMENT) Meningitis Takes A Toll In Burkina Faso


BYLINE: Federation of American Scientists March 15, 1996 by Dorothy B. Preslar


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Washington, D.C. - The Burkina Faso state epidemiology survey service
has, according to news services, issued a statement saying that 722
people have died from meningitis in the last two months. Total
reported cases are 8,252.
The country's director of preventive medicine, it is reported, said
that the epidemic is continuing even though 1.3 million people have
been vaccinated and despite public information campaigns. A new
vaccination effort has begun, using 200,000 doses on hand and 400,000
doses now in transit.
This report brings the number of reported deaths from meningitis in
West Africa to almost 3500 -- 722 in Burkina Faso, over 200 in Niger
and 2,550 in northern Nigeria.

Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-LArge Cricket: Beaten, But Not In Behaviour


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 15, 1996 by Mark Lamport-Stokes


LENGTH: 987 words


 

Johannesburg - South Africa may have suffered the extreme disappointment of exiting stage left from cricket's World Cup after their quarter-final defeat against a resurgent West Indies in Karachi on Monday, But where they certainly emerged as winners out of all 12 competing countries was in the public relations arena.

Hansie Cronje and his team created a high- profile image while in Pakistan for the World Cup and the people of that country took them warmly to their hearts.

South Africa were perhaps fortunate to play all their group matches in just the one country while the likes of Sri Lanka criss- crossed the sub-continent like a cricketing yoyo, but they did everything just right as far as people-relations were concerned.

After their own national team, who it would appear from countless newspaper articles in Karachi and Lahore, had effectively committed treason in losing to India in their powder-keg quarter-final, Pakistanis were right behind South Africa to go all the way in the World Cup. 

Not for them the likes of gutless Australia who had refused to play their Group A match against Sri Lanka because of the bomb attack on January 31 which killed over 30 people in Colombo. At the time, Cronje publicly stated that he and his team would have had no qualms about playing in Sri Lanka --- and that was one example of many statements or actions where the South African team did the right thing, pure and simple.

In fact, if one was to put under the spotlight the public image of Hansie Cronje and England's Michael Atherton during the World Cup, it would be hard to find a more black- and-white contrast. Cronje, with great similarity to his rugby counterpart Francois Pienaar, now seems to have an instinctive feel to say and do the appropriate thing at the appropriate time --- whether publicly, at a press conference or in the high street.

Almost embarrassingly at the other end of the scale, the hapless Atherton appears to have the diplomatic dexterity and nimbleness of feet of a drunk elephant with its feet encased in concrete blocks. The Lancashire man has clearly been affected for the long term by the tabloid press in Britain and these days he simply does not care how his image is perceived.

Yet bloody-minded though he might wish to be, his reference to a local journalist as "a buffoon" after the England/South Africa match in Rawalpindi, represented a major error of judgment in manners --- never mind an error by an England captain.

Managing director of the United Cricket Board of South Africa Ali Bacher is well aware of the integral part that the team and the individual image plays in modern-day cricket. "We have very strong views that the image of the game is crucially important --- as well as the image of the players," Bacher said the day after South Africa's loss to the West Indies in Karachi.

"The players must behave on and off the field in a manner which befits the great traditions of the game. It is important to reflect the ethos of the game and, not withstanding the professionalism, that must be paramount. Certainly we in South Africa are very strong in giving every possible back-up support behind the scenes to our players to handle the responsibilities and the pressures that now await international cricketers."

Bacher believes that it is impossible for a young player today to enter the realms of international cricket and not to make errors of judgment and to be able to handle the press confidently unless he is guided accordingly.

"The young players need assistance. If you take cricketers like Paul Adams and Jacques Kallis, if you don't brief them and give them support behind the scenes, they're going to run into problems.

"But we have our Plascon academy which runs every winter and one of the important aspects of that academy is to brief and to guide and almost to educate the young cricketers in these responsibilities.

"Hansie understands the need of the captain to play his part in insuring that the sponsors are looked after, that the media are looked after, that the administrators are looked after and that the ordinary folk in the street are looked after. All in all, we're very proud of our team. And we must never get away from that aspect of cricket which is part of the culture of the game. We must preserve it and certainly we in South Africa will do our utmost to ensure that all the players who represent our country are well-briefed and well-versed in their responsibilities to the great game of cricket."

Bacher emphasises that the United Cricket Board of South Africa will always take a firm stance in this regard: "We are going to drive a very firm and professional show where the players become paramount in our marketing strategy, but, within this context, there has to be discipline and there have to be contractual obligations.

"At the end of the day, the players have got to know their responsibilities to us and we've got to know our responsibilities to the players to ensure that, ultimately, the game of cricket flourishes."


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Cape Town Bidding for Olympic Sponsorship


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 15, 1996 by Gavin Du Venage


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Johannesburg - The Cape Town Olympic Bid committee is about to clinch the two crucial sponsorship deals that will bring it close to the R80-million it needs to fund its bid to host the 2004 Olympic Games.

The two sponsors, almost certainly Sun International and South African Airways, are expected to announce their backing within the next few weeks. SAA is apparently planning a lavish ceremony to announce its support.

The bid committee has already secured support from major corporations like Mercedes-Benz, Unifruco, Eskom, Caltex and Nedbank. However, R80-million is the minimum the committee has to raise if it hopes to present a credible bid. 

Bid representative Paul Johnson would not confirm either SAA or Sun International's participation. He did say that official announcements could be expected soon from a major airline and hotel group.

"The procurement of sponsors is ongoing," he told the Mail & Guardian. "Estimates of how much money we need have ranged from R75- million to R90-million, but the most recent audit showed that R80-million was the cut-off mark."

The bid committee has tried to woo sponsors by offering a package of exclusive marketing rights. These include the right to use Cape Town's Olympic bid logo --- a map of Africa made up of the South African colours over the words: Cape Town 2004.

Another drawcard was to accept only one major sponsor from a specific industry sector. Hence Mercedes Benz will be the only motor manufacturer to support the bid. SAA as the only large South African airline was the sole credible candidate for the committee. It would not even have had to come up with a generous package to have its name attached to the bid, although it would have to do better than suppliers.

Suppliers get to label themselves according to the service they provide. However, to be recognised as a supporter would take substantial financial support. Sun International is already an official sponsor of the South African Olympic team taking part in Atlanta.

Sponsorship runs until September 1997 when the winning city is announced. After that, sponsorship has to be renegotiated with the International Olympic Committee (IOC).

The immediate challenge facing the committee is the presentation of its bid book, which takes place in August. The book, to be published by Churchill Murray, is a technical manual written to specific requirements setting out the bidding city's proposals on how it will provide transport, sports facilities and various other essential elements of hosting the games.

The IOC will select a shortlist of candidates on the strength of the bid books from the 11 competing cities. About half will be eliminated after the books have been analysed.

Deposed South African Rugby Football Union (Sarfu) chief executive officer Edward Griffiths is to edit the book. Griffiths told the M&G he took the job as a stop-gap until his fight to get his post back was settled.

"My priority is my reinstatement with Sarfu," Griffiths said. Sarfu president Louis Luyt fired Griffiths without explanation last month. He said he had no plans to stay on after August, although he would consider extending his commitment if he failed to win back his Sarfu job.

Griffiths payed a major role in organising the Rugby World Cup, experience which will no doubt greatly benefit in planning the bid presentation.

Griffiths dismissed critics who say the event is too large for Cape Town to handle: "A year before the world cup there were great fears that we could not manage such a large event. What happened was we hosted the most successful world cup ever. The bid will take an enormous amount of work, but the underlying success of South Africa is its ability to think big. It can be done."

Griffiths said even if Cape Town did not win the bid to host the Games, "the impressive thing about the bid is that it will transform a city of two halves into a single entity."


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


269 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Business South African Budget: Deficit remains unstable


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 15, 1996 by Simon Segal


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Johannesburg - One of the key components of Finance Minister Chris Liebenberg's Budget is to address fears around the budget deficit and government debt.

These blight an otherwise impressive economic record that boasts the most buoyant growth, lowest inflation, largest net capital inflows and most sizeable fixed investment in two decades.

Liebenberg's numbers for the 1996/97 fiscal year move in the right direction, albeit slowly. The deficit amounts to 5,1% of gross domestic product (GDP) against 6% in 1995/96 (5,5% if transfers to the Central Energy Fund are excluded). The total debt comes to 55,6% of GDP (56%). 

Government's deficit is well above the 3% mark that influential institutions such as the International Monetary Fund and World Bank consider stable.

This is not about ideology or economic orthodoxy. Even a 5,1% deficit figure is a major turn-off to potential investors, both domestic and foreign.

In a world where fiscal prudence is the trend, globally integrated markets judge economies harshly by voting with their money. Liebenberg talks about reducing the deficit by 0,5 percentage points in the next few years.

South Africa's government debt is just below the 60% mark that these institutions consider prudent before a country gets caught in a so- called debt trap. But the trend in South Africa is ominous --- in 1980 to 1981 government debt was 30% of GDP.

The interest bill (R34,4-billion) amounts to 20% of total spending (18% in 1995/96) and tax revenue is up from 24,6% of GDP in 1995/96 to 25,1%.

The deficit totals R28,8-billion (revenue of R145-billion less expenditure of R174- billion).

If loan redemptions are included the gross borrowing requirements for 1996/97 amount to R45,1-billion against R38,4-billion in 1995/96.

This will be financed from short-term loans (R3-billion), government bonds (R36,6-billion) and foreign loans (R2,5-billion).

None of this should prove a problem and put pressure on interest rates, but foreign borrowing becomes expensive when the rand depreciates. The 100-million bond now costs R620-million to redeem compared with R540- million when it was issued earlier this year. In 1995/96, R1,8-billion was raised. In addition to the pound, there was a Japanese yen issue that raised around R1,2-billion.

In the local bond market, the bulk of the funds will be raised in the R153 (matures in parts in 2009, 2010 and 2011), a new 2006 stock and reopened R177 (2007) and R175 (2002) bonds. The R157 (maturing over 2015, 2016 and 2017), which has raised some R18-billion from the Public Investment Commission, will also be put into the market. The bond market gave the final favourable verdict --- rates on the R150 fell from 15,48% just before the budget to 14,88% directly after Liebenberg spoke.

Longer term investors might take a more sombre view. First, Liebenberg's figures have to be trusted. Last year a deficit of 5,8% was budgeted for, or R29-billion. It ended up at 6% (R30-billion).

The main factors behind this larger deficit are serious provincial overspending and shoddy former homeland finances, expenditure of votes from previous years brought forward into this fiscal year, the removal of import surcharges and lower value-added tax revenue owing to reduced inflation.

The major economic problems with a large public debt include "crowding out" private investment, adding to inflationary pressures, impairing incentives to innovate and invest and undermining monetary policy and hence putting pressure on interest rates.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


270 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Business South African Budget: Tight Fiscal Rein


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 15, 1996 by Madeleine Wackernagel


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Johannesburg - Economic growth last year was the best on record since 1988, despite setbacks in the agricultural and mining sectors and a slip in the fourth quarter owing to a decline in manufacturing output. But the doomsters are gaining voice, forecasting a leveling off in activity as the business cycle takes its course.

In a climate of falling inflation, growing investment and improved competitiveness, Finance Minister Chris Liebenberg is optimistic about our economic prospects. A gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate of 3,5 to 4% is expected for the current financial year, but there are some provisos: gross domestic saving fell to 18,5% of GDP last year, against an average of more than 25% in the 1970s and 1980s. South Africa cannot rely on foreign investment alone to achieve sustainable growth. 

The government is doing its bit, keeping a tight rein on fiscal policy, thereby creating an investor-friendly climate. In fact, Liebenberg's deficit target is now an even more ambitious 4% by 1998/99.

But if the world economy as a whole is indeed nearing the peak of the boom --- as indicated by Liebenberg --- then cutting the deficit so sharply would be counter-productive, says Dr Peter Hilsenrath of Syfrets.

"Slower world GDP growth implies a more difficult environment for South African exporters. And with slowing domestic private investment, as well as expected weaker private consumption growth, it is imperative that government investment kicks in to provide counter-cyclical stabilisation." Foreign investment, both direct and portfolio, would be the loser, he adds.

Liebenberg may be acting in anticipation of a recession --- cutting now while the going is still relatively good. Otherwise, the deficit could balloon to 10%, which would definitely not send the right signals to foreign and local investors, says Dennis Dykes, chief economist of Nedcor.

The other big blot on the economic horizon is unemployment --- but a clear plan for job creation was conspicuous by its absence. Liebenberg reiterated government's commitment to

500 000 new jobs a year by 1999, as outlined by Thabo Mbeki, the deputy president, last month, but gave no indication how this was to be realised.

If past performance is anything to go by, the private sector cannot be relied upon to step into the breach: only 55 000 jobs outside the agricultural industry were created in the first year of the upswing, to mid-1995. Liebenberg did, however, highlight the structural problems in the labour market and made a point of setting out the urgent need for more information on how the formal sector works.

"We need to understand the consequences of increased sub-contracting, self-employment and more flexible working arrangements," he said. "Unless we do, government will not know the actual changes in income generating employment or the wage elasticity of employment."

Similarly, he said, the links between formal sector employment and real income changes and the activities of the informal sector need to be better researched.

The fine print of the Budget book outlines some positive steps in addressing the structural problems besetting job creation, such as land reform, support for small farmers, industrial policy and export promotion, small business development and vocational training. Indeed, education is a top priority for government expenditure this year, with R5,5 billion of the total cake, against R4,3 billion last year.

Improved RDP delivery is expected to boost job creation but there was disappointment at the dearth of direct measures. Said Dannhauser van der Merwe, general secretary of the Federation of South African Labour Unions (Fedsal), "Only R100-million was allocated to public works programmes; much more could have been done, plus we have to make sure that the benefits are not undermined by huge job losses through privatisation and public sector restructuring."

Liebenberg was at pains to emphasise the holistic nature of this year's Budget; it was not merely a one-off financial exercise designed exclusively for1996/97. "Some of the measures taken this year should yield results in the short term, others would probably take a year or more, while some should facilitate changes envisaged for later years," he said on Wednesday.

Commentators have been quick to criticise in the past, complaining of too much rhetoric and not enough action. The government is aware that it cannot afford to fiddle while Rome burns any longer --- as long as growth stays on track, there is room for putting fiscal promises into practice.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


271 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Business South African Budget: Taking a Soft Approach


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 15, 1996 by Madeleine Wackernagel


LENGTH: 600 words


 

Johannesburg - The 10,4% increase in total expenditure is higher than expected, mainly owing to the R6- billion allotted to improvement of conditions of service. The process of restructuring the public service is expensive in the first year, says Finance Minister Chris Liebenberg, but the benefits of a more efficient civil service will quickly outweigh the costs.

The process involves downsizing and rightsizing: flattening the gradings, ironing out inequities and paying market-related salaries to encourage skilled workers to stay in the public service. No figure was put on the total number of redundancies envisaged; despite the burgeoning unemployment problem, the measure was generally welcomed. 

Liebenberg stressed a commitment to delivery; revamping the public service is a huge part of that initiative, as is the new South African Revenue Service (SARS), to go on line next month.

The issue of roll-overs was highlighted as part of the new efficiency drive. Housing, while allotted a lower amount than last year, will come out with R4,6-billion, owing to the backlog of unspent monies in the Reconstruction and Development Programme Fund and National Housing Fund.

Education scores with R5,5-billion against R4,3-billion last year. Substantial increases in subsidies to universities and technikons are envisaged, as is a R300-million fund to assist financially disadvantaged students.

Defence spending, while down from 4,5% of Gross Domestic Product to less than 2% this year, is still high at R10,2-billion. Scaling down the defence force is never easy; the defence lobby is a powerful one, says one analyst.

On balance there were few surprises in the expenditure plans, or indeed, in the taxation changes. While the levy on pension funds was expected, other revenue-generating measures amounted merely to tinkering. Excise taxes could have been higher, says the health lobby, while the increase in estate duty and donations tax to 25% was seen as a first step to a capital transfer tax.

'Clearly the government has broadly accepted (Michael) Katz's views on capital transfer tax and a threefold increase in this area of taxation can be expected in the fullness of time. In addition to the rate hike, action on the treatment of interest-free loans in estate planning and restriction on generation- skipping devices can be expected in the capital transfer tax act when it arrives, probably in 1997," said Tenk Loubser of Price Waterhouse.

The lowering of the secondary tax on companies and the marketable securities tax was welcomed. The South African Chamber of Business pointed out, however, that company taxes are still very high relative to our competitors, and called for their abolition.

If there was one criticism of the Budget, from business to labour, it was the lack of boldness. Sacob said that while it took some fiscal steps in the right direction, it did not meet the economic challenges that lie ahead. "Some tough decisions that are needed to improve South Africa's economic performance have not been taken."


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


272 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Business South African Budget: The Year of RDP Delivery


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 15, 1996 by Lynda Loxton


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Johannesburg -There was a predictably mixed reaction from political parties to Finance Minister Chris Liebenberg's 1996/97 budget on Wednesday.

The African National Congress welcomed the fact that Liebenberg had not succumbed to the "short-sighted and insensitive free advice" of the likes of the South African Foundation to sharply increase value-added tax (Vat) while slashing the deficit.

This was never likely anyway, given the extensive consultations with representatives of both business and labour ahead of the budget, but rank and file members must have been somewhat alarmed by the widespread publicity given to the foundation's suggestions and wondered who would win the war of words. 

Labour Minister and chairman of the ANC's national executive economics committee Tito Mboweni said that the budget was a clear rebuff of the foundation's outdated views and set a more sustainable course for growth.

But the ANC did give notice that it expected the government to "remain firmly focused throughout the year on the critical areas of Reconstruction and Development Programme (RDP) delivery" and, as Liebenberg had said, make this the Year of Meaningful Delivery on the RDP.

Mboweni said that although some progress had been made in reprioritising government spending, more should be done, especially to support the critical task of job creation.

He believed that labour intensive public works programmes could play an important role in creating jobs.

The ANC also welcomed progress in introducing tax reform but said that this should be speeded up "so that certainty can be achieved". The controversial introduction of a 17% tax on pension fund income had been handled in a "responsible and strategic manner" and Mboweni called on the industry to co-operate with government to make it work.

"There is no cause in our view for any alarm on the part of members of retirement funds," he said.

National Party finance representative Theo Alant condemned plans to tax pension fund interest and rental income as an "ad hoc" measure that would affect savings. Freedom Front finance representative Willie Botha said the tax "targeted the sitting ducks providing for their retirement".

Democratic Party finance representative called the budget a "spend now, pay later budget" because the budget had not been cut substantially and had instead raided retirement funds.

"The government is forcing future generations of taxpayers and pensioners to pay for its inability to control its excessive expenditure," he said.

Alant welcomed the fact that the government had adopted sound economic policies that had demonstrably led to growth, but warned against complacency.

"The challenge facing the Government of National Unity is to strengthen confidence in the new South Africa and in the government's ability to maintain peace and law and order, and to apply sound economic policies amid signs of growing tensions and support for populist policies," Alant said.

On the positive side, most parties welcomed the reduction of the secondary tax on companies and marketable securities tax, but equally hoped that the planned revamp of revenue collection services would show rapid results.

Liebenberg is banking on getting an extra R1,5-billion from the revamped service but Alant said that progress in getting this up and running had been "unacceptably slow".

The fact that all parties agreed on the need for fiscal discipline and reducing the budget deficit bodes well for continued efforts to bring the deficit down. But the proof of the pudding will be in the eating, and it might not be very palatable.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


273 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Business South African Budget: Beating the Blues


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 15, 1996 by Madeleine Wackernagel


LENGTH: 760 words


 

Johannesburg -This year's Budget had not been expected to raise the roof, nor did it. But Chris Liebenberg, the Minister of Finance, was quietly confident it would be well received by the markets, big business and labour alike. He insisted it was most definitely not a standstill Budget, nor a "holding operation"; indeed, in many respects, it showed courage and innovation.

Business had other ideas. The South African Chamber of Business (Sacob) had pushed for a 1% hike in value-added tax (VAT) --- that didn't happen. But the expected levy on the retirement funds did, at 17%. 

Sacob was unimpressed: "The decision to tax the income of pensions funds will be extremely onerous administratively and is, in Sacob's opinion, badly flawed as it amounts to little more than a raid on the nation's savings. This, combined with the decision not to increase the VAT rate at this time, sends out the wrong message in respect of the relative discouragement of consumption and the encouragement of savings and raises questions about the ability of the government to take tough, and possibly politically unpopular decisions."

Liebenberg emphasised that no deals were done; there was no "trade-off" between labour and the pensions industry. Raising VAT made no sense when substantial unused funds were being rolled over, with the concomitant wasted opportunities for job creation. But the pensions bullet had to be bitten: South Africa's contractual savings industry was the second best in the world, he said, because of low taxes. Its wealth had to be addressed and the Katz Commission proposals made perfect sense.

Furthermore, the regressive nature of VAT argued against an arbitrary increase. To the criticisms from the pension fund industry that the levy will hit the lower-income groups hardest, Liebenberg's response was swift: over a longer-term period of 10 to 15 years, it is the highest income groups that pay more, while the lowest benefit.

Sacob wanted an investor-friendly Budget and in many respects that call was answered. The Secondary Tax on Companies was lowered --- by more than the expected 10%, from 25% to 12,5% and the Marketable Securities Tax was cut in half to 0,5%.

And Liebenberg re-affirmed the government's commitment to fiscal discipline: the Budget deficit target is 5,1% of gross domestic product (GDP), against an out-turn of 6% for 1995/96. The public debt total, therefore, is projected at 55,6% of GDP, compared to 56% last year, so the debt trap spectre is fading, slightly.

Consumers, as long as they don't smoke, drink or drive, have reason to cheer. In line with the government's pledge to iron out personal income tax inequities, tax bands have been further consolidated; the top rate of income tax now kicks in at R100 000 and the minimum tax threshold has been raised from R14 600 to R15 580.

Reaction in the markets was good; the long bond rate was strong at 14,9% after the speech, having been 15,4% in the morning, and the rand also took heart, rising against the dollar to R3,89.

But business and the markets alike had hoped for a more definite statement on relaxing exchange controls and privatisation. All Liebenberg said on the former was that the government was still on track for a gradual move at some stage but that the Budget was not the proper platform for such announcements; on the latter he said steady progress is being made.

His moves towards restructuring the public sector were well received, as were his pledges for more efficient tax collection. Indeed, he could hardly justify an increase in VAT when R10-billion slips through the tax net every year. To this end, the South African Revenue Service will be launched next month --- although the position of chief executive remains empty.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
