Africa News


March, 1996


Arts Tina Turns It On in South Africa


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 15, 1996 by Hazel Friedman


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Johannesburg -It began as an ordinary press conference --- one of those affairs where journalists drink too much, get indigestion from bland answers to banal questions as well as stodgy snacks, and swear never to sacrifice another Saturday afternoon to media hype. But by the time Tina Turner made a predictably, but not insultingly, belated appearance, the pokerfaced press corps had become a cheerleading squad and chorus line, rocking and singing to the sounds of Turner's promotional video.

There are many epithets to describe the lady with the legs that have launched a thousand fantasies, the sonorous yet gritty voice, the smile that could double as a lighthouse and, of course, the sexual energy that is measurable on the Richter scale. But the two words that come to mind most often in relation to a woman whose career has spanned over three decades are reinvention and return. 

Since 1953, when an adolescent and rather blousy Tina Turner from Nutbush City first sang, literally, for her supper, through the 1980s when she claimed her rightful place in the vanguard of popular music, Turner has been resurrected and redefined over and over again. Her post-Ike struggles are already the stuff of contemporary pop-lore, as are her stage and screen performances alongside the royalty of the rock kingdom. Her songs --- like Simply the Best and Private Dancer --- have become international trans-generational anthems.

Sure, her career hasn't been entirely contradiction-free, as demonstrated by her 1979 performance at Sun City in contravention of the cultural boycott, and her Farewell tour in 1988, which turned out to be anything but a goodbye. But in response to a pointed question about why she had returned after such a grand finale, Turner replied: "I still want to fill stadiums, I still have so much to say, to sing and to discover."

Which accounts in part for her return to South Africa. Having arrived a month before she is due to perform the South African leg of her Wildest Dreams tour, Turner will spend the next few weeks rehearsing at Sun City with her team of internationally acclaimed supporting musos, and simultaneously rediscovering the country.

"I remember how wild my first visit to South Africa was," she says. "It just seems like a great place to be."

Her answer to the question of whether she regrets her first ill-timed visit is an unambiguous "No!"

Simply put, Turner doesn't seem to have a politically canny bone in her well-honed body. Free of camera enhancements, she seems also refreshingly at odds with her vampish media image: more demure, much smaller, yet paradoxically bigger --- and unmistakably better. She also seems remarkably free of guile or expediency.

Not for her the dabbing of tears from over- rouged cheeks, or the obligatory sermonising on spiritual homecoming. And she doesn't come across as a talking press-release. Asked how she plans to contribute to the upliftment of black South Africans, she runs a hand through her short, streaked hair (one of many wigs, she frankly admits): "I don't know, I've just arrived."

When informed that she is an inspiration to all victims of abusive relationships --- an accolade she probably receives at every press conference --- she appears almost coy. Her answers are predictable but spoken, believe it or not, with convincing sincerity.

And when a glazed-eyed journalist dedicates an erotic sonnet to her beauty and sexual allure, she seems genuinely delighted. In response to a question about what turns her on in a man, she points to the impromptu bard --- who looks on the verge of climax or collapse.

And her perceptions of South Africa? "Too soon," she says, "but on the way back from the airport I passed cars filled with black South Africans and they smiled at me. It wasn't like I had a sign saying Tina Turner on the roof or anything. But I got the impression that this is a really happy place."

A nayve observation, perhaps, but who can blame her when a crowd of hype-hardened drain- sniffers are sitting at her feet softly crooning: "Simply the best."

Tina Turner performs at Newlands in Cape Town on April 20, at King's Park in Durban on April 23, and at the Johannesburg Stadium on April 26


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Arts Clegg and Mchunu: Together Again for a Concert


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 15, 1996 by Hazel Friedman


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Johannesburg -If there exists a single structure which encapsulates the apartheid era in all its banal brutality, it is the George Goch hostel in Jeppestown. A concrete monolith housing male, Zulu-speaking migrant workers, the drab edifice is enlivened only by shouts of laughter coming from the match-box windows, and the squatter shacks that have sprouted just beyond the razor-wire boundary, like weeds through pavement cracks.

This is familiar turf to Johnny Clegg. But tonight his visit has an edge of urgency. He has come to recruit "soldiers" from the hostel's dance teams to join The Full Story - -- Clegg and Sipho Mchunu's one-off concert in Johannesburg, to be held on March 20. 

The mission is not proceeding as planned.

Earlier, Clegg attempts to rehearse at the Mega Music Warehouse with the Meadowlands Choir, only to discover their Zulu pronunciation fails to match the rich timbres of their vocal chords. In a rousing rendition of Asimbonanga, Clegg almost succeeds in transforming the urbane, Sotho-speaking choir into rough-edged, melodic impis. He coaxes them with a display of street-swaggering Zulu, peppering it with a chorus of "sex, drugs, rock'n'roll" and weaving the melody through the circle of earnest minstrels. The pitch rises and the pace quickens in time to his rhythmic foot-stomping and finger-clicking.

"Uh no, guys, you draw out the syllables too much. They've got to be sharper, more clipped."

It is one of those delicious ironies that an English-speaking white boy should be instructing homeboys how to sing --- if not in their own tongue, then in one they are familiar with.

It is an irony that is enthusiastically embraced by Clegg. Anthropologist by day, impi by night, businessman, muso, husband, father, Zimbabwe-born struggle brat, white Zulu, cultural hero, he and Mchunu changed the face of South African pop at a time when apartheid contrived to keep their cultures apart. These are epithets which Clegg accepts --- in a shrugging, good-humoured sort of way --- and eschews, because they cannot encapsulate the contradictions that colour his life.

"When I was lecturing in the anthroplogy department at Wits," he recalls, "there was this expectation that, as a progressive person, one would be capable of uniting all the conflicting sides of oneself and becoming a truly integrated adult," he says. "But, for me, that is impossible. I have learnt, rather, to accept the fragments and the changes.

"There is a part of myself that identifies with the life of a migrant worker and the accompanying sense of dislocation and displacement."

Which goes some of the way towards explaining the rationale behind his official musical reunion with Mchunu. It is not, he insists, simply a nostalgic attempt to rediscover romanticised roots, or to recapture the glorious epoch when Juluka articulated and symbolised the pain of apartheid and the joy of breaking down barriers of race class and culture.

Clegg explains: "Sipho and I have come together again because, although the bond has never been broken, we want to make the most of the choices and changes. Most importantly, we want to try out the magic again, to see if it still works."

Sitting outside the George Goch hostel, Clegg speaks about the exhilaration of change, and the new challenges ahead.

"Before, the type of songs we sang were of necessity determined by apartheid, but there's an incredible sense of liberation in being able to sing about the contradictions of daily life, about anything. Obviously there has been a loss of innocence in the process. We also tend to romanticise the epoch in which we discovered most about ourselves. In retrospect though, it remains just like any other epoch."

He adds: "This concert will be completely different to the old ones, with a 15-man dance troupe, a 20-piece big-voiced choir, as well as state-of-the-art lighting and staging."

But alongside Clegg's enthusiasm is an unmistakable note of anxiety. His desire to recruit a 15-man dance team from the hostel has run into a potentially serious snag. The migrant elders are demanding a meeting that will decide --- less than a week before the show --- whether Clegg's request will be met. At the core of the problem are rivalries between the hostels along the East Rand. George Goch houses most of the dancers, but Jeppe hostel is the domain of the Zulu elders, and in order to get permission to recruit and train the dancers, Clegg has to travel to Benoni hostel to negotiate with a 20-strong committee.

After a lengthy session of "quietly probing but repectful questions" conducted over litres of Coke and Lemon Twist, an elated Clegg reports that the committee has agreed to let him use the dancers of his choice. It is then that the other Cleggs melt away, and Clegg the Zulu impi merges with the anthropologist.

"Meeting this hostel committee reinforces how traditional hierarchies, structures and codes of honour enable people to carry on, to keep themselves intact. These men come from an enclave in Natal that has been all but forgotten in the process of change. And they are trying desperately to hold on to and perpetuate their beliefs in order to make sense of a changing world. They are men of honour who want nothing more --- not even a percentage of the money I pay the dancers --- than the knowledge that their dancers will be acknowledged and treated well."

He continues: "This process has been like a time warp, like the days of Juluka when we had to fight to prevent the venues we were performing at from closing down, and negotiate our way through every song and concert. I'd almost forgotten about what it was like, what energy it took and generated to play in those days. How wonderful it was."


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Namibia Reconciliation Up Against The Ropes


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 15, 1996 by Denford Magora


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Johannesburg - The reconciliation process in Namibia --- carefully nurtured by President Sam Nujoma since independence --- is teetering after a row over Swapo's treatment of detainees during the liberation struggle and allegations of crimes committed by policemen in defence of apartheid.

The row has led to calls for a South African- style truth commission, but also to unprecedented threats of "civil war" from the secretary general of Swapo, Namibia's ruling party.

A warrant officer in the Namibian police force, Linus Leumbo, sparked off the row by writing to the local press pointing fingers at serving and retired policemen. He alleges that, among other things, these men, whom he named, knew exactly who pulled the trigger on the gun that killed Swapo activist Anton Lubowski. 

Matters took a surprising turn two weeks ago with the publication of The Wall of Silence, a book written by Pastor Siegfried Groth, a German clergyman. The book details torture and other forms of cruel and unusual punishment that Swapo meted out at its camps to perceived renegade members of its guerrilla army. At a church convention last week, clergymen asked that a truth commission be set up urgently to probe the accusations.

To Nujoma, that was the last straw. Last week, he went on Namibian television and, for about half an hour, conducted a personal diatribe against Groth and Christo Lombard, one of the pastor's helpers, whom he referred to as "an apostle of apartheid".

The president said Groth was "never a friend of Swapo" and, therefore, not a champion of the liberation cause. Nujoma charged the book was a one-sided story loaded with "lies" and said that since the pastor was not ashamed of writing these "untruths", he was stepping in to set the record straight in order to maintain "social order".

Nujoma's address added fuel to the fire, and some accused him of abusing his access to state television to promote Swapo's cause.

This week, in one of the most venomous post- independence speeches from Swapo yet, party secretary-general Moses Garoseb said Swapo had opted for reconciliation but Groth and others were opening old wounds. "So, let us open them and see how it hurts."

Saying Nujoma had been insulted, he declared: "I will not reconcile myself, I am on a war path. Maybe what we need in this country now is civil war."

He said the party would not apologise to Swapo fighters who were tortured. "Apologise for what? For defeating the Boers? That is an insult to us black people."

Disturbingly, Garoseb called on Swapo supporters to prepare for war, warning of "bloodshed in this country".

Meanwhile, Leumbo says he is determined to bring those he fingered to book. He has written to the prosecutor general asking for heads to roll.

The prosecutor general responded by saying the name supplied to him by Leumbo as the person who pulled the trigger on Lubowski came from a statement that was taken some years ago. The witness, for some reason, was considered unreliable. So the matter was not pursued and the alleged killer was not interviewed.

But Leumbo says he smells a rat and alleges that this is all part of a cover-up involving the highest levels of the police force.

His mission is by no means restricted to the Lubowski case. He also wants the head of the deputy chief of police and has detailed the man's alleged iniquities at length. The deputy chief professes ignorance and has refused to get into a "mud-slinging match" with the warrant officer.

The Namibian this week reported that the Council of Churches in Namibia has said remarks made by Nujoma on NBC-TV last week subtly attempted to "suppress a constitutionally guaranteed right of freedom of speech" and contained accusations that whipped up fear and uncertainty among sections of Namibian society.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa 'King's Skull' Seized After Return from Scotland


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 15, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Johannesburg -The president, the Prince of Wales, the Xhosa paramount chief, the British prime minister, the Eastern Cape premier and a prominent paleo-anthropologist have all been dragged into South Africa's great riddle of a skull with a hole in it.

Chief Nicholas Gcaleka, a self-appointed sangoma from the Eastern Cape, whipped up controversy when he returned to South Africa from a trip to Scotland early this month with a skull he claims to be that of a Xhosa warrior king killed by British troops at the Cape Colony in the early 1800s.

The aggrieved spiritualist was this week in Cape Town trying to see President Nelson Mandela after an imbizo attended by 30 senior chiefs, including Paramount Chief Xoliliswe Sigcau, confiscated the skull so that scientific tests could be done to establish its true identity. 

The chiefs have lodged a wooden box containing the skull for safekeeping at a mortuary in the Transkei town of Willowvale and are busy setting up a panel of scientists who will be asked to establish whether Gcaleka's claim that the skull is that of the legendary King Hintsa kaPhalo is true.

The sangoma is outraged, saying he was tricked into attending the imbizo at Sigcau's Great Palace and surrendering the skull to the chiefs. Gcaleka told reporters the chiefs have interrupted his plans to rebury the head on May 12, the anniversary of Hintsa's death. He claimed British Prime Minister John Major and the Prince of Wales had telephoned him to say they wanted to attend the ceremony --- and apologise for the chief's slaying in 1835.

Mandela's spokesman Parks Mankahlana confirmed the president had received a letter from the sangoma urging him to intervene in the dispute and the presidency was still considering the matter. But a spokesman for the British High Commission in Cape Town said his office had received no indication that Major or Prince Charles were planning a trip to South Africa.

Transkei lawyer Mda Mda, appointed to represent the Xhosa paramountcy in this matter, told the Mail & Guardian that the chiefs were planning to consult Professor Phillip Tobias, South Africa's foremost paleo- anthropologist, and other international experts, about setting up a panel to judge Gcaleka's claims --- suggesting the riddle will be solved by a bizarre mix of science and the supernatural.

He said Gcaleka had been to Bisho last week to lobby Eastern Cape Premier Raymond Mhlaba for the skull to be returned and said the chiefs were asking the provincial government not to intervene until expert DNA and forensic tests on the skull had been conducted.

When Gcaleka arrived home last weekend, he showed reporters a skull with a neat hole on the right side which was found near Inverness in Scotland. But instead of opening the way for a ceremony designed to bring spiritual peace to the nation, his efforts had the opposite effect.

Chiefs and other traditional healers in the Eastern Cape claim Gcaleka is a charlatan out only to make money and boost his image as a sangoma healer.

Gcaleka claims the hole in the skull is proof that it belonged to Hintsa. But most Xhosa chiefs and other spiritual leaders have disputed this, saying the skull could not be genuine because Hintsa's head was blown apart by his captors. Their scepticism is reinforced by reports in a Scottish newspaper that the skull is actually that of an ancient Celtic monk.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


278 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa President-in-Demand: A Peek at Mandela's Diary


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 15, 1996 by Rehana Rossouw


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

Johannesburg - This is what President Nelson Mandela's diary looks like this week. There are early morning dashes to airports, a meeting with a sports star, that very important meeting in KwaZulu- Natal and plenty of time for rest in between affairs of state.

As far as possible, most of Mandela's afternoons and every Friday are kept free. This Friday though, the imbizo in KwaZulu- Natal is of critical importance, so his day is full. 

Three days a week are devoted to African National Congress business --- Mondays, which he spends at Shell House, and Saturdays and Sundays, when he prefers to stay at his Houghton home.

By late last year, Mandela began complaining that his schedule was so hectic that he seldom had time to read the newspapers and important state documents. He wanted time out to do this so badly that he remarked that he missed the days on Robben Island, where he could spend time reflecting on issues and penning his responses. So he suggested free time in the afternoon, whenever possible.

"The decision to leave his afternoon free had nothing to do with doctors," stressed presidential spokesman Parks Mankahlana.

Mandela's diary is definitely not as hectic as it was this time last year, said Mankahlana. However, the president's office could not produce last year's diary for comparison as it was in Pretoria and his staffers were all in Cape Town.

"Largely, this situation has evolved over a period of time, rather than because of a specific instruction. The staff in the president's office have now all acquainted themselves with the fact that his programme has to be streamlined.

"If six ministers want to see him on a particular day, perhaps three will be re- routed to the deputy president. Instead of doing an interview once a day, we arrange one a week with four journalists present."

Mankahlana said Mandela's programme was currently "manageable and reasonable", although demands for his time keep rising. "We expect that as long as he is alive, people will want a slice of his time. He is popular, he has strong appeal, and everyone wants him at their event."

More often that not though, Mandela just isn't available to judge a fashion show or snip a ribbon and, when the staff at the presidency believe an event needs a representative, other Ministers are co-opted into service to stand in for the president.

"Some people don't like it when they invite Mandela and someone else arrives to represent him. It's not that they want the president of South Africa to attend, they want Nelson Mandela himself."

What most people don't realise is that Mandela's diary is thematic. They would stand a better chance of grabbing his attention if their request for his time found symmetry with Mandela's causes.

In October and November last year, for instance, his diary was cleared of matters of state while he concentrated on winning support for the local government elections.

Since January, he has had one overriding concern --- peace in KwaZulu-Natal. Mandela's staff have had to shape his programme and make it fit into the president's overall plan.

Almost all his speeches this year have preached peace, reconciliation, patriotism and nation building. He has consulted often with King Goodwill Zwelithini, Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi, and ANC KwaZulu-Natal leader Jacob Zuma. He has been following Magnus Malan's trial closely.

On Tuesday he had lunch with Buthelezi to iron out arrangements for the imbizo on Friday. "After Friday's imbizo, he will start gearing up for the local government elections in the Western Cape and KwaZulu-Natal," Mankahlana said.

"With this much foresight, we are able to add to the president's current project without overworking him. There's no Chinese wall though, we can always pitch the programme according to what's high on the agenda."

Most of the diary is drafted by a committee consisting of cabinet secretary Jakes Gerwel, presidential parliamentary councillor Ahmed Kathrada, Mandela's secretary Mary Mxabane and his head of communication Joel Netshitenzhe.

State visits to South Africa and abroad are, naturally, organised months in advance. These are also streamlined, taking into account which countries are most important to visit and which visits can be passed on to the deputy presidents.

The diary committee meets regularly to consider requests for Mandela's time. Obviously, they cannot allocate every minute detail, anticipate every crisis or cater for their boss's whims. When he wants to meet a sports star, like Springbok swimmer Penny Heyns this week, she's slotted in. If he wants a photo opportunity with her after the meeting, it's likewise arranged.

"We can plan almost a year in advance for overseas trips, but visits to South Africa come sometimes with as little as a week's notice," said Kathrada. "So the diary changes all the time."

"We try to take into consideration rest periods for him, but that's also not easy. For instance, when he goes to Transkei to rest, we go out of our way not to disturb him and people land there without previous notice demanding to see him.

"While we try to cut down the programme as much as possible, it's difficult, everybody wants a piece of the president."


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa Truth Commission Exec 'Won't Take Sides'


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 15, 1996 by Eddie Koch


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Johannesburg - The chief executive officer of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, Dr Biki Minyuku, says he will not differentiate between the victims of apartheid atrocities and those who suffered at the hands of the liberation movements.

Minyuku says it is his overall objective to unify individuals who have suffered losses during the years of apartheid, irrespective of which side they were on. 

Human rights violations touched the whole spectrum of South African society. "I do not see my role as playing one organisation off against the other. We are dealing with human beings whose rights have been violated and violations know no affiliation," he says.

Although he is a card-carrying African National Congress member, Minyuku says he does not regard himself as "overtly" ANC. "The fact that I am an ANC member has nothing to do with my effectiveness and efficiency as CEO to the Truth and Reconciliation Commision."

Minyuku says it is his individual right to belong to the ANC, just as it is another's right to belong to any organisation of their choice. However, he would be willing to consider relinquishing his party political membership if the community at large felt it affected his impartiality as the commission's CEO.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


280 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa Go To Truth Commission, ANC Tells Members


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 15, 1996 by Eddie Koch


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

Johannesburg - The African National Congress has instructed its leadership and members to go to the truth commission if they committed human rights abuses during the anti-apartheid struggle --- and, in a gesture of support for the truth process, has withdrawn temporary immunity given to its members by the old government.

"The ANC renounces the temporary indemnities (designed to allow exiled members back into the country before the 1994 elections) as they no longer serve any purpose. The ANC will submit its record, leaders and members to the scrutiny of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission," said a statement issued on Thursday.

"We have nothing to hide. Instead we want to help create a climate in which the healing process of our nation is enhanced." 

This week the Mail & Guardian asked senior officials and Cabinet ministers from the party how it would deal with amnesty applications from its own members to the truth commission and found the ANC grappling to come up with a consensus policy around a number of sensitive issues.

It emerged there is concern in the organisation about groups of Umkhonto we Sizwe commanders who are anxious that they will have to shoulder the blame for the guerrilla movement's attacks on civilian targets carried out in the 1980s.

Members of these groups, said to include some senior MK officials, are demanding to know whether ANC political leaders now in government will go to the commission and accept responsibility for issuing the orders that led to these attacks.

Thursday's statement makes it clear that the ANC leadership will support its rank and file by accepting collective responsibility for actions during the anti-apartheid struggle. The M&G has also established that Joe Modise (now defence minister) is willing to go to the truth commission in his capacity as a former MK commander and member of Umkhonto's political military council subject to policy guidelines currently being drafted by the ANC.

"The ANC will never condone any human rights violations which may have been committed by freedom fighters during the heat of the struggle.

"The ANC has already made public the findings of the Motsuenyane and Skweyiya commissions (which investigated abuses at the movement's detention centres in various parts of Africa), for which our entire NEC has taken collective responsibility," the statement said.

The national executive committee of the ANC recently set up a powerful sub committee including heavyweights like Deputy President Thabo Mbeki, Defence Minister Joe Modise, Intelligence Chief Joe Nhlanhla, Justice Minister Dullah Omar and Transport Minister Mac Maharaj.

This subcommittee has set up a truth commission desk at ANC headquarters to handle a range of issues relating to the truth commission which operates at national and provincial level. Officials in this department have to provide members with advice about how the truth commission will work and has been flooded by requests from victims of abuse at the hands of the security forces.

However some officials have, somewhat unexpectedly, found themselves dealing with requests from members who want amnesty for abuses they committed during the struggle. There were two commissions of inquiry by the ANC into human rights abuses in its detention camps during the 1980's.

"We are hearing some quite shocking things about what people did at this time and it is clear that a lot of people in the organisation are worried about this. We are hoping that the ANC will use the truth commission to finally come clean and deal with these skeletons in its own cupboard," said one official who asked not to be named because the matter is so sensitive.

Early this week Justice Minister Dullah Omar told SABC radio the ANC would instruct its members who feel they committed abuses to approach the truth commission and would adopt an open policy about this. The M&G then submitted a number of questions to the ANC's Department of Information and Publicity and also to the ministers who sit on the NEC subcommittee dealing with the truth commission. These included:

* Will the ANC make public the names of its members who apply to the amnesty committee of the truth commission and the nature of the abuses they committed?

* How many ANC members have already applied for amnesty and what categories of human rights abuse are these applications for?

* Has the ANC stipulated that members who feel they have committed abuses must go to the commission or is this a voluntary/individual decision?

* Will the ANC provide counselling and support for members who decide to approach the truth commission?

There is a general consensus in the ANC that the organisation was fighting a just struggle against an immoral system and, as a whole, does not have to account for the kind of human rights abuse committed by those who created and fought for the apartheid system.

"Apartheid was a crime against humanity and the struggle against humanity was pronounced by the whole international community to be just... The actions of those who fought to maintain apartheid cannot be equated --- morally and politically ---with the actions of those who fought for democracy," according to the ANC statement.

However, within this broad moral framework, there appears to be two main tendencies within the organisation.

One group reacts with indignation at the suggestion that they have anything to account for at the truth commission. Its proponents tend to say attacks against civilians were the exception during the guerrilla struggle and explain the detention camp abuses as the result of heavy infiltration by Pretoria's security forces.

Another section of the movement -- which appears to have swayed official policy -- believes the ANC should use the truth commission to deal, in an open and cathartic way, with the abuses committed in the camps and to compensate victims and families of victims who suffered in these detentions centres.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


281 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large FIFA Throws Out Zambia's Appeal


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 8, 1996 by Peter Fredricks


LENGTH: 730 words


 

Lusaka - The International Football Federation (FIFA) has thrown out a protest which Zambia had lodged against Zimbabwe's use of over-aged players in an Olympics qualifier last year. 

According to sources, the protest which the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) had lodged against Zimbabwe for their use of four over-aged players, was thrown out because of the delay.

Zimbabwe used goalkeeper, Gift Muzadia, strikers Steward Murisa, Edeldert Diriba and Misi, all over-aged players during an Olympics tie in which they eliminated Zambia.

But in a new twist to the whole saga, the Zimbabwean soccer authorities have fined goalkeeper Gift Muzadia ZM$300 - which in itself is an admission of guilt for the offence.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia 'Politicians Manipulating Prices of Mealie Meal'


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 8, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 574 words


 

Lusaka - Politicians are now manipulating the prices of mealie meal through their rhetoric, annoyed farmers claimed yesterday.

Zambia National Farmers Union (ZNFU) president Ben Kapita said in a press statement that his members were concerned about their future following recent outbursts by politicians over the fixing of the price of Zambia's staple food.

Kapita wondered how suddenly every minister has assumed the role of agriculture minister and is making statements on maize pricing. "This government has never kept maize prices from falling. When farmers faced ruin in 1993 they were given promissory notes instead of a good maize price, but when prices rise it appears that farmers will not be allowed to benefit. 

"Farmers are extremely concerned for the future," ZNFU president Ben Kapita said in a statement yesterday. "If prices are fixed now, what hope is there for a profitable maize price when the new crop comes onto the market and the election draws closer."

Kapita said ZNFU shared the concerns over high mealie meal prices because they affected the 600,000 farmers and their families as well.

"But farmers are even more concerned at recent statements by politicians who are trying to manipulate prices through political rhetoric," Kapita said.

Kapita appealed to the politicians, especially ministers to enforce a competition and fair trading act in setting up the long awaited competition commission instead "of making empty noise".

"An impartial investigation, not political rhetoric would show if maize prices are being unfairly fixed," he suggested. Kapita blamed maize imports on poor agricultural policies and poor handling of the sector by the government.

"The ministers who are blaming millers for the high maize meal price must know that stable prices will only come through increased local production which will only be achieved through correct and consistent agricultural policies which are currently lacking," Kapita said.

Last Friday health minister, Michael Sata, accused millers of over charging.

"We called the millers and they gave us the costings of producing a 25kg bag of mealie meal but we discovered that the recommended price could have been around K11,000," Sata said.

Earlier, various government officials including President Chiluba had accused millers of profiteering and threatened to act against them.

"I am ordering that market forces must interact in favour of consumers," Chiluba said on February 22. "This is a serious warning which must be observed immediately."

But Kapita said government should blame itself.

"Government must stop blaming others for their on failures," Kapita said.

March, 1996


Art, Culture and Entertainment Zambian Music Exposed to Piracy


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 8, 1996 by Ballad Zulu


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Lusaka - The closure of Zambia's only recording company, the Teal Records Company, has exposed Zambian music to music pirates.

According to a survey carried out by a Post correspendent, the fastest selling tape on the black market, is a compilation of Zambian music entitled "Zambians. ".

When it just appeared on the black market sometime last year, it beat all other artistes in sales. And yet none of the money is going into the pockets of the hard working Zambian musicians whose music appears on this tape.

Veteran musician Chris Chali of Amayenge Cultural Ensemble whose song 'Mabo' appears on the tape confirmed that there is no one collecting royalties for the cassette.

Zambia Copyrights Society ( ZAMCORPS ) chairman, Jagari Chanda is also at a loss as he seems not to know the source of this pirated work. The only glimmer coming from this dark cloud is perhaps the comfirmation that Zambian music is still very popular.

March, 1996


Ethiopia Court Sentences Editor to 18 Months Imprisonment


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency March 8, 1996


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Central High Court Wednesday sentenced the editor-in-chief of Wolafen, a private Amharic news paper, to 18 months imprisonment for publishing and disseminating mendacious reports which incite war and unrest.

The Second Bench of the Central High Court passed the verdict on Solomon Lemma Gemechu after it found him guilty of repeatedly printing and disseminating war mongering reports contravening the country's press law. 

The court said the defendant has published fallacious reports in various issues of the paper and cited ample evidences including stories entitled, 'EPRDF loses 12 towns in war in Eastern Ethiopia' and 'Black Lion Commando begun operation heading from south to central regions.'

The prosecutor, however, appealed to the court that the punishment should be stiff as the defendant's reports instigate unrest and war.

The counselor of the defendant told the court that the editor-in- chief who was a member of the defunct army, has been engaged in the publishing business which his superficial knowledge of the press law to support his family.

The counselor appealed to the court to acquit the editor-in-chief in consideration of the time he had spend in prison.

Africa News


March, 1996


Ethiopia Ethiopian Art Historian Demands Return of the Axum Obelisk


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency March 8, 1996


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Addis Ababa - Professor Achamyeleh Debela, Director of North Carolina University Computing Center for the Arts, has joined many other Ethiopian scholars in the United States in urging the Italian Government to effect the immediate return of the Axum obelisk looted by Mussoloni in 1937.

Proffesor Achamyeleh issued a statement of support for the return of the obelisk from Durham, North Carolina, to mark the Centenary of the battle of Adwa, which said:

"The Axum Obelisk still in Rome is Ethiopia's cultural treasure, and its removal from its original site by the Italian fascists in 1937 was a grave injustice to the people of Ethiopia, because it deprived them of an extraordinary historical artifact.

"I was delighted to hear that there was a possibility that the obelisk might at long last be returned, and that Italy of the late twentieth century might prove itself a country of understanding and honor above colonial deceit and injustice. 

"If I am dismayed and disappointed it is because no visible measure has thus far been taken to honour declarations that the obelisk would be returned, nor are there any clear indications that these declarations will be honored in the near future.

"There is ample reason for concern, for the Italian Peace Treaty, signed in 1947 almost fifty years ago, stated in Article 37 that all loot taken after 3 October 1935, the date of the invasion, should be returned within 18 months, and the patience peoples of Ethiopia have already had to wait almost fifty years.

"If is of paramount importance that the Italian Government makes a clear statement on the specific steps to be taken for the obelisk s repatriation, and that this be officially communicated to assure the parties concerned. I feel sure that the patience, but persevering, resolve of the peoples of Ethiopia will ensure that justice in this matter will at last be done."

March, 1996


Ethiopia House Approve Federal Supreme Court Appointments


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency March 8, 1996


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Addis Ababa - The House of Peoples Representatives yesterday approved the appointment by the prime minister of the president and vice president of the Federal Supreme Court of the country. The House has also elected three MPs as members of the Federal Commission for Judicial Administration.

Having been briefed on the personal accounts of the appointees by Prime Minister Meles Zenawi, the House has approved the appointment of Ato Kemal Bedri and Ato Menberetshay Tadesse as president and vice president of the Federal Supreme Court respectively. 

Prime Minister Meles said Ato Kemal Bedri had been serving in different judicial positions since he graduated in 1973 from the Law Faculty of the Addis Ababa University with LLB degree.

The premeir further said Ato Kemal, a Hareri by nationality, has also been working in different capacities after the former military dictatorship was ousted in May 1991.

Ato Membere Tsehay Tadesse is also a graduate of the Law Faculty of the Addis Ababa University with LLB degree, according to Ato Meles.

Prime Minister Meles said Ato Menbertsehay, a Tigrean by nationality, had also graduated from a foreign university with a post graduate diploma in his career. Ato Menberetsehay, formerly a law lecturer at the AAU, is currently an employee of a private firm with a monthly salry that doubles the payment for the position he assumed today, Ato Meles said.

Prior to its approval of the appointment of the president and vice president of the Federal Supreme Court, the House of Peoples Representatives has elected Ato Ismael Harun, Ato Mulugeta Gashe and Ato Bereket Simon as members of the Federal Commission for Judicial Adminstration.

Ato Zenebe Alemayehu, a candidate for membership kin the Federal Commission for Judical Administration, lost the election because he got only 10 of the total vote.

The House has later promulgated the law setting the parliamentry recession period as enshrined in the Constitution of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia.

Accordingly, the month-long parliamentary recess will begin on March 10 and end on 10 April. A similar recess of the House will also begin on July 8 and on the Monday of the last week of the Ethiopian month of Meskerem.

The proclamation was made by an overwhelming vote in the House of People's Representatives with only one vote against.

Earlier in the day the House endorsed the minutes of its 25th regular meeting.

287 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology The Crucial Need to Enhance Computer Technology


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 11, 199 by Joseph K'Amolo


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

Nairobi - Besieged with an unfavourable economic situation since the end of the Cold War, Africa now finds itself under pressure to adopt the usage of new information technology which thrives on computers, if it is to compete with the rest of the world favourably.

Information transfer is central in enhancing economic development in any part of the world. Currently, there is talk about globalization of computer usage for data accessibility. At the bottom-line is information transfer which in turn goes with the realisation of the cherished dream of information superhighway. 

In order to avoid economic isolation, Africa therefore needs to make a bold venture into the computer world for more up-to-date information. Such a move calls for the sharpening of tools for conveying information in local commerce and industry as well as for international trade and diplomacy.

It is out this realization that 12 African countries have joined the Internet, the global information superhighway better known as the information web. This move is also seen as the determining factor in their economic survival.

Worldwide, there are more than 137 countries on Internet, thanks to (United States) Pentagon researchers who invented this information technology which was hitherto used exclusively by the US military in communication.

With the liberalisation of this technology, today Internet allows data to move from one network to another much as a letter moves from one city to another.

Northern African countries like Tunisia, Egypt and Algeria had earlier access to the network because of their proximity to Europe and cultural links to the oil-rich Arab world. Other countries on the continent except perhaps for the early experiments conducted in Cote d'Ivoire until recently, have not benefitted much from this new communication technology.

This scenario has changed with countries in southern and eastern Africa joining the cyberspace. Last October, Kenya became the 12th country to join.

The African Regional Centre for Computing (ARCC) is behind the promotion of Internet in the sub-Sahara region. It conducts research and offers training on the use of computer in communication.

ARCC Director, Dr. Shem Ochuodho, says there are over 600 organizations across the region, among them some UN agencies, foreign universities, hospitals and companies which are currently on Internet.

Dr. Ochuodho told APS that cyberspace, a chain of electronic communication networks, has linked 3 to 4 million computers worldwide, bringing together over 40 million people, among them professionals, businessmen, academicians and administrators.

The ARCC contends that countries that have joined the cyberspace will benefit in terms of facilitated research in various fields, obtaining required data or information, and minimising time and information transfer costs. For business men and women, transactions can be conducted electronically through the superhighway.

He however regrets that Africa is not significantly connected to the superhighway. He is nevertheless optimistic that the situation might change, judging from the outcome of a meeting last June in Hawaii which resolved that the continent should forge ahead in this new communication development.

The meeting which brought together 42 Internet groups from 26 countries worldwide, issued a communique that among other issues underscored the need to have Africa connected to the communication web by early 1998. The meeting sent an appeal to African governments to provide an enabling environment for such an undertaking. It called for the reduction of tax levy on computers so that many private and public institutions can acquire them cheaply.

Dr. Ochuodho observes that economic policies vary for different countries resulting in different economic growth, something he laments can be an obstacle in the growth of communication technology.

His pessimism is further heightened by the fact that the initial cost of establishing a computer network for information purposes can be prohibitive not only to some organisations but also governments with low economic growth. In addition, the adaptation of this technology depends on a number of factors such as the extent to which it is acquired, adjusted and absorbed. This again depends on the size and pattern of demand for securing the technology.

Planning and management of the computer technology is also a very crucial factor. This means African countries should be able to plan, know how such technology can be run, have the capacity to maintain it and create awareness about its advantages in regard to economic development. Besides, there is need for a positive attitude to adapt the computer technology to national and local needs and essentially avail other infrastructure like telephones to guarantee such a network.

With the foregoing, those areas that have not been connected with telephones are likely to be left out in this advancement. In Africa, rural areas would thus be affected most, yet this is where the majority of the population lives.

ARCC principal engineer Mr. Koyabe L. Martin cautions that telephones should not be seen as a luxury but as a means to economic advancement. He notes that in Tokyo (Japan) alone, there are more telephones than in the whole of Africa.

Martin admits that the initial cost of installing the new information technology might be high but once it is in place, the viable cost is much lower as seen in some of its advantages which include many to many or one to many communication points at a go as opposed to one to one point as in telephone communication.

He warns that technology can only be slowed but it can never be stopped. Appreciating the right by authorities to hinder such technologies due to security reasons, he nevertheless warns that since information is the key to economic growth, the best governments can do is to use strategies that protect certain information from being misused.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


288 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Comboni: From Humble Start to Sainthood


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 11, 199 by Wafula John


LENGTH: 1374 words


 

Nairobi - It is said of Daniel Comboni, that as the great missionary was saying his prayers at the close of the day in a mission in southern Sudan, a boy jumped over the wall into the mission compound.

"Who are you," Comboni asked they boy. "I am the slave of a camel merchant," was the answer. And who sent you here?" inquired Monsignor Comboni. "God sent me," was the unexpected reply. 

Struck by the boy's answer, Comboni is said to have granted him shelter and began to teach him; first to read and write then on to higher and more difficult things.

In due time the young ex-slave was baptised, taking the name of his protector, and eventually he became the first native priest of the central African Mission.

This tale epitomises the mission of Catholic Bishop Daniel Comboni, founder of the missionary congregations named after him, and the man who will be beatified by Pope John Paul II on Sunday March 17, 1996 at the St. Peter's Basilica in Rome. Bishop Comboni dedicated his life to spreading the Gospel of Christ, educating Africans and recruiting them from rampant slave trade

Daniel Comboni was born in Limone on lake Garda (Brescia), Italy, on March 15, 1831. Comboni's father worked locally as a gardener, his mother, a housewife, bore eight children. Daniel was the only child to survive.

In February 1843, Comboni was accepted as a student at Fr. Mazza's Institute in Verona. Fr. Nicholas Mazza had set up a school for gifted children whose families could not pay for their education. In an outline of his life and work written in 1876, Comboni linked the birth of his missionary vocation with the arrival of Fr. Angelo Vinco who had spent some time in Sudan. While in Verona in search of help, Fr. Angelo gave a talk at the Mazza College.

Wrote Comboni in 1849 of the lecture; "I knelt at the feet of Mazza and as a student of 17 consecrated my life to work in Central Africa."

In December 1854, Comboni was ordained priest and set out with a Mazzian missionary expedition in 1857. After a long arduous journey, they founded a mission station on the banks of the Nile about 1,6000 kilometres south of Khartoum. They called the station Holy Cross.

But within months, the missionaries began to succumb to Africa's tropical diseases and the unfamiliar hot and humid climate. On March 2, 1958, the Superior Fr. Oliboni lay dying. His last words are said to have made a deep impression on the young Comboni and became his guiding star: "Even if only one of you is left, don't give up. God wants this mission and the conversion of Africa to continue. I die certain of this," said Oliboni.

Upon this plea, Daniel Comboni took an oath; "I will never give up; Africa or death." Henceforth Africa, or death became his life-long motto.

Shortly after the death of their superior, the surviving missionaries were ordered to return to Europe to recuperate. Later Comboni was to make six journey to Africa and eventually establish missions, schools and training centres.

At the heart of his mission was a "Plan for the Regeneration of Africa by Africans." This in itself was a revolutionary plan. Ironically the inspiration of "the Plan" came to him at the same St. Peter's Basilica where he is to be beatified.

This became one of the most significant events in his life and a revolutionary approach towards the evangelization of Africa. To minimise the deaths arising from disease and climate and to maximise on Africa's suitability to the African climate, Comboni envisaged a plan that would involve Africans fully in the proclamation of the gospel.

His choice of the phrase "regeneration of Africans" had deep meaning. It was a programme full of hope and expectation, for Comboni it had to be brought about by the African people themselves.

The Regeneration of Africa by Africans had other futuristic concerns which are being understood better today such as gender sensitivity and inculturation. In his plan, African women would be trained as leaders and teachers "who would promote the education of women in reading, writing, keeping accounts.."

In his immense confidence in the people of Africa, as well as his determination "to make available the possibility of full intellectual development for both men and women," Comboni envisaged the establishment of "four great African theological - scientific universities in Africa."

When the Mazza institute decided to withdraw from the mission, Daniel Comboni felt he needed to set up his own missionary institutes. In 1867 he set the Missionary Institute for Africa, later the Comboni Missionary Sisters in 1872. He was nominated Pro- Vicar by the Holy See in 1872, then Vicar Apostolic of Central Africa in 1877 and finally ordained as the first Bishop of Central Africa in August 1877.

One of the greatest services that Daniel Comboni gave to Africa was his immense struggle against slave trade. At first he started by taking some of the slaves for training in Europe. In later years, Comboni was able to buy slaves being whipped as they walked along," he later wrote about an encounter with slave-caravans.

"The small children were carried by their mothers. Other children who were able to walk did so tied by their necks to poles resting on their shoulders so that they could not escape. Yet others, up to 15 years of age had goat skin straps around their necks which were attached to the slave traders," he wrote.

Of the adults, he observed that "some were chained at the feet and yet forced to carry their masters' luggage." But what hurt Comboni most was the inhuman and brutish treatment of the Africans that went along with the long treks. "When the slaves were tired, they were urged along with spears and sticks. Some fell to the ground and were finished off with clubs and spears, others were left to die. Slaves were forced to march in this way for more than 12 hours a day for up to three months," he wrote.

The slave-caravan experience filled Comboni with anger and determination to do something to stop this cruel practice. But his noble duty to Africa was not to last. On October 10, 1881 Bishop Comboni died of black fever and was later buried in Khartoum, Sudan.

Following widespread reputation for holiness through his work which was continued after his death, a decision to open an informative process in Verona and Khartoum for the introduction of the cause of beatification and canonization was started in 1927.

Today, his work is seen in Comboni missions, schools and other training institutions which spread from Egypt down to South Africa and from Benin on the Atlantic Ocean to Kenya on the Indian Ocean. In all, there are 162 Comboni communities in Africa through 56 dioceses in 16 countries. The Comboni Sisters, on the other hand, have 136 communities in 12 countries.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


289 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology AIDS Therapies Based on Plant Ingredients


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 11, 199 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

Nairobi - Two professors of medicine in Kenya and Uganda, are claiming outstanding success in the treatment of the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) brought about by the Human Immuno Deficiency Virus (HIV).

Professor Arthur Obel, formerly of the University of Nairobi, Kenya has previously worked as a senior scientist at the Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI). In an exclusive interview with a local daily on March 1, he claimed that a self-formulated drug, Pearl Omega, had proved a breakthrough in the treatment of AIDS. Dr. Obel is well known in medical research circles in Kenya, having been associated in an earlier controversial AIDS drug called KEMRON, an interferon based treatment.

A number of patients who used the drug claimed that subsequent tests showed that their HIV status had changed from positive to negative. On that basis, they believed they were completely cured. 

These patients were among hundreds of others to whom Pearl Omega had been sold since early last year, at a relatively new government institution, the Kenya Biodiversity Centre, headed by Prof. Obel. The centre's premises are in a go-down in Nairobi's Industrial Area.

Carpenters were busy renovating the premises as Dr. Obel made claims of a breakthrough that has eluded scientists worldwide over the last 15 years since the virus was identified as a killer.

Pearl Omega is given in liquid or capsule form, several times a day. A course of treatment lasting several weeks is quite expensive by local standards - about US dollars 500. Foreigners wishing to buy the drug pay five times as much.

Besides the seven patients whose documents showed they were no longer HIV positive - that they had reverted to HIV negative status, the local daily said it had talked to 31 patients in all.

They claimed that once on treatment, they rapidly regained appetite and the infections associated with AIDS such as diarrhoea, pneumonia and herpes zoster rapidly abated and disappeared.

But no sooner had Obel claimed a breakthrough than Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi declared that as far as the government was concerned, "no cure was certified discovered yet."

And on March 6, a Government statement cautioned Kenyans that to date there is no known cure for or vaccine against AIDS. Signed by the newly appointed Secretary to the Cabinet and Head of the Public Service Mr. Fares Kuindwa, the official statement said the Government was aware of the several drugs developed locally and internationally among them KEMRON, immunex, AZT, PCM4 and more recently Pearl Omega but urged the public to observe preventive and control measures against contracting the HIV virus.

Moi said other scientists of proven integrity had to validate such claims. President Moi warned Kenyan's not to relax their moral standards as the disease was spreading like wildfire in the country.

Observers say President Moi was not impressed by claims of a "cure" having been misled in 1991 by the immune system produced by living cells in response to invading organism, such as viruses. Koech and Obel claimed to be the discoverers of Low Dose Oral Interferon treatment, but it was subsequently shown that this treatment was in fact first described in the British Medical Journal, the Lancet of December 26, 1987 (page 10).

While KEMRON tablets reportedly helped a number of AIDS patients improve their quality of life, it proved generally disappointing.

Neither are Prof. Obel's medical colleagues impressed by his current claims. They have challenged him to avail his Omega data for scientific scrutiny in the accepted scientific manner. They charged he was evasive and vague. Indeed the Kenya Medical Practitioners and Dentists Board, through their Chairman, Prof. Richard Baraza, warned any doctors who used the drug, that they were doing so at their own risk since the side effects were not known.

While Obel was developing Pearl Omega, a Ugandan doctor, Prof. Charles Ssali has treated thousands of patients with a multiple herbal pill called Mariandina. Prof. Ssali, formerly with the Faculty of Medicine, Makerere University, Kampala, claims to have treated 10,000 patients since 1992, at his clinic in the Kyotera suburbs of the Ugandan capital. He claims to have started his research in 1988.

A number of his patients claim that his herbal approach has eradicated the opportunistic infections associated with AIDS. Ssali himself claims 75 per cent of his patients have improved dramatically.

He argues that AIDS is essentially a deficiency disease. A healthy life and a balanced diet are a real barrier to HIV infections. Like an increasing number of doctors in the West, he asserts that minerals like zinc enable the thymus gland in the chest to produce enzymes and hormones which activate cells within the lymphatic system, which in turn become "killer cells" against incoming invaders.

He says drinking alcohol is a bad habit that compounds the problem of HIV in Uganda. Dr. Ssali says his AIDS medicine is formulated from 18 natural compounds. These compounds provide vital micronutrients or serve as anti-oxidants which all play a role in ensuring that pollutants do not adversely affect the immune system.

But Uganda's Health Minister, Dr. James Makumbi, remains skeptical. Late last year, he cautioned Dr. Ssali against using the media to propagate his findings. "The best forum are medical journals like the East African Medical Journal," said Makumbi.

Prof. Ssali wondered why he was being taken to task on the basis that his drug had not been tested on animals. He wanted Dr. Makumbi to explain why foreign companies were testing AIDS vaccines in Uganda without going through similar procedures.

He also reminded Dr. Makumbi and many younger doctors in Uganda, that they owe their medical skills to the knowledge he imparted to them while teaching at the Faculty of Medicine at Makerere University in the 70s and 80s.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


290 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Experts Advise Irradiation to Reduce Food Losses


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 11, 199


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Nairobi - Massive food loss from infestation with insects such as weevils, infestation with micro-organisms such as aflatoxin or other parasites could become a thing of the past if African nations used irradiation technology for the preservation of food. The technology is now widely accepted in the West.

Experts say food loss from insect infestation alone - post harvest storage losses - costs African nations more than 40 per cent of all its agricultural production. 

But food loss from insect infestation is only one of the problems, says Susan Thorp, a development advocate with WREN World Radio.

"Hot, humid conditions prevalent in the tropics mean that many more foods like meat, milk, fish or fruit will deteriorate within a few hours or days, while premature sprouting of tubers and other crops are also major obstacles to keeping foods fresh, wholesome and attractive," says Ms Thorp.

Africa does not have resources for largescale application of many costly technologies like refrigeration or freezing of dry of foods. Consequently, large scale treatment of food to kill insects and prolong shelf life has traditionally been with chemicals.

But Ms Thorp observes: "lingering residues and environmental consideration are forcing the search for alternatives."

Many African nations have problems with insect infestation of cash crops such as cocoa beans, coffee beans or maize. "Insects may even prevent or cause difficulties for potential export to other countries. In Ghana, 60 per cent of foreign exchange is generated by the export of cocoa beans alone."

She observes that at present, the beans are fumigated with ethyl- bromide "a chemical that is now being phased out due to environmental pressure because of its effects on the Ozone layer (in the atmosphere)."

Ms Thorp advocates strongly that food be preserved by irradiation techniques in Africa. This technology is relatively cheap and fully accepted in the United States and many countries in Europe.

Irradiation of food is based on the use of ionising energy from such sources as cobalt-6 as well as electron and x-ray machines adjusted to proper energy levels so they can kill insects, micro organisms and other food robbing creatures.

It is suitable for cereals, vegetables, fruits, tubers, fish, meat and many other foods produced in Africa.

Ms Thorp says African nations which wish to use these technology can find all the help they need from the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO).


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


291 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Priests Told to Stick to Celibacy


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 11, 199


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Arua, Uganda - The Catholic Bishop of Arua in northwestern Uganda, has lamented that some Catholic priests have breached their celibacy vows and in the process fathered children.

Bishop Fredrick Drandua told a seminar in Arua town on March 3, that priests intent on marrying can be allowed to do so in church if they renounce their priesthood and get the Pope's permission to marry.

The matter began when a participant in a seminar on "Counselling, probationary services and the penal system in Uganda," sought to find out from Bishop Drandua how children fathered by priests can get to know their father as is the right of any child. 

The Bishop explained at length, according to the state-owned daily New Vision account of the proceedings of the seminar; "If a priest gets a child, he is suspended from carrying out activities of the church for an indefinite period. When he reforms, he is allowed to return - but only after he has made comprehensive arrangements with the parents of the girl or woman for the upkeep and care of his child."

Bishop Drandua conceded that priests had been dismissed altogether when they continued to get children after the first pardon.

He also explained that children born out of wedlock - the term illegitimate children is going out of fashion - cannot seek to join the seminary "except with the permission of the bishop."

Meanwhile, a Kenyan daily, the East African Standard reports in its issue of March 4, that a Catholic priest is at the centre of a row with his congregation who claim he has broken his celibacy vows and all church norms by allegedly getting married.

The Catholic faithful from Limuru parish, some 30 kilometres from the capital, Nairobi, charged that the priest had constructed a house for his wife adjacent to the church compound. They considered this act a betrayal of the accepted norms of the church.

On Sunday, March 3, the congregation staged a peaceful demonstration demanding the removal of the priest from the area. They waved placards, tree branches as they sang church hymns.

Some of the demonstrators claimed they had presented detailed grievances in a letter to the local Deanery and the Archbishop of Nairobi, Maurice Cardinal Otunga.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


292 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Lawyer Challenges Indefinite Jailing of Editors


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 11, 199


LENGTH: 920 words


 

Windhoek - Zambian lawyer, Mr. Sakwiba Sikota, says he intends to challenge the Speaker of the National Assembly in Zambia, Dr. Robinson Nabulyato for the indefinite imprisonment of his clients - two newspaper editors of the controversial independent bi-weekly The Post.

Speaking to the Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA) here on March 6, Mr. Sikota, argued that the procedures used by the Speaker, Dr. Nabulyato to order the arrest of, and to pass sentence on Fred M'Membe, the Post's Editor-in-Chief, the Managing Editor Bright Mwape and columnist Lucy Sichone, has no backing under the law.

His challenge, is expected to heard on March 12 under a writ of habeas corpus.

MISA further says, the two Zambian editors, whom the Speaker of the National Assembly, Dr. Nabulyato jailed indefinitely after finding them guilty of contempt of parliament on February 27, handed themselves to the police on March 4, while their colleague, Sichone, is still lying low. 

"M'Membe and Mwape did hand themselves in to the police this morning, March 4, while Sichone, a civic activist and freelance columnist for the paper, is still at large," disclosed MISA.

According to MISA M'Membe had been sent to a maximum security prison in the Zambian capital, Lusaka, while Mwape was driven to Kabwe, 150 kilometres away where he too is said to have been imprisoned in a maximum security jail.

Under the writ of habeas corpus application, the parliament will be required to justify on what law or authority it is holding M'Membe and Mwape in prison, Lawyer Sikota told MISA. He added that if the court was not satisfied with the reasons given, it would order the immediate release of the trio.

According to Mr. Sikota, M'Membe and Mwape were expected to be present during the proceedings this week on March 12.

Addressing himself to Section 27 of the National Assembly Powers and Privileges Act, under which his clients have been jailed, Mr. Sikota argued that the sentence passed by the Speaker was not provided for in the 1956 Act. He further explained that once parliament had found someone in contempt, the matter should be handed over to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP).

It was the DPP's duty, and not that of the parliament, to prosecute, Mr. Sikota further stated.

In an earlier interview with Namibian Broadcasting Corporation (NBC), Mr. Sikota said his clients had never been put on trial, and had been found "guilty" by parliament in absentia.

This is totally against all the rules of natural justice, argued Mr. Sikota, stressing that "everyone is entitled to be tried by an impartial tribunal."

In the case of M'Membe, Mwape and Sichone, Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda (who raised the contempt issue when the Post trio wrote about his criticism of a Supreme Court ruling that legislation requiring police permission for the holding of demonstrations was unconstitutional), and Dr. Nabulyato "played the part of accusers, prosecutors, judge and jury," lamented Mr. Sokoto.

But lawyer Sikota was confident the courts will order the release of his clients on grounds of the constitution. The case had brought a "mini constitutional crisis," he argued, adding that the courts will have to over-rule the National Assembly, as the legislative authority has obviously gone way beyond its bounds.

Once a court rules that they (Mwape and M'Membe) are being held illegally, the prison authorities will have to release them, he explained.

And speaking on Sichone's decision not to hand herself in, Mr. Sikota told NBC: "Sichone's position is that she cannot be party to what she clearly sees as an illegal act and answer to a warrant (for her arrest) with no constitutional backing."

He explained that Sichone had a three-month-old baby and so she was not willing to subject the baby to the "terrible conditions" found in Zambia's prisons, where cholera was prevalent at this time of the year.

Meanwhile Zambia's Home Affairs Minister Chitalu Sampa, says M'Membe and Mwape "should be treated like ordinary criminals" while in jail, the state-owned Times of Zambia reported.

Sampa reportedly made the remarks to the imprisoned editors. "A prisoner is a prisoner and there is no special treatment," Mr. Sampa was reported saying. The Minister added that M'Membe and Mwape were not political prisoners.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Sierra Leone Rebels Still Oppose Election Outcome


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 11, 199


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Freetown - The rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF) has repeated its opposition to the general elections held in Sierra Leone late last month, saying it will not recognise any winner of a run-off slated for March 15.

Presidential and parliamentary elections were held on February 26 and 27, the first multi-party poll for nearly 20 years, but the electoral commission said they will have to go into a second round because none of the candidates emerged the outright winner. The exercise was intended to end four years of military rule and to negotiate a peaceful end to five years of civil war in the West African state. 

"None of the candidates obtained the 55 per cent requirement as set out by decree and the constitution. As a result there will have to be a run-off," the head of the Interim National Electoral Commission (INEC), Mr. James Jonah, is quoted as saying in a broadcast.

The rebels had threatened to make the country totally ungovernable and insecure should the elections go ahead, and they were marred by violence, mainly in the capital, Freetown, the north, and the southeastern town of Bo, where several people are reported to have been killed by unidentified attackers.

Against the background of violence, said the electoral commission, Sierra Leoneans turned out in large numbers to vote, pushing polling into a second day. However, civilians charged that the RUF threat was carried out, ironically, by elements of the army who did not want a democratic change rather than the rebels.

Soon after the latest results were announced, an RUF spokesman told the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) in an interview that the rebel movement will not recognise any winner because the

elections were meaningless, with civil war still raging in the country. He said an end to the war must be sought and a new process involving all Sierra Leoneans, including traditional and local leaders, set into motion.

Giving full results of the presidential and general elections, Mr. Jonah said the leader of the Sierra Leone People's Party (SLPP), which is the country's oldest, won the most votes but not enough for an outright victor. Ahmad Tajan Kabbah of the SLPP won 35.8 per cent of the votes and will face his closest rival, John Karefa-Smart of the United National People's Party (UNPP), who received 22.6 per cent in the run-off on March 15.

Talks aimed at ending the civil war were held on the eve of the elections between the rebels and the military government of Brigadier Julius Maada Bio in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, but broke off inconclusively. They resumed on March 3, but were again suspended for consultation. No new date has been set for the resumption of talks.

LANGUAGE: English
