Africa News


March, 1996


Liberia Government Dispute Leads to Sacking of Minister


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 11, 199


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Monrovia - The Interim Government in Liberia has announced the sacking of United Liberation Movement of Liberia - Johnson faction (Ulimo-J) leader, Roosevelt Johnson, as Minister for Rural Development, because a dispute within his organisation has threatened the peace process.

But immediately the announcement was made, Johnson challenged it, arguing that the other members of the Transitional State Council, including Charles Taylor of the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), George Boley of the Liberia Peace Council (LPC), and Alhaji Kromah of Ulimo-K, had no powers to dismiss him.

He charged that under the Abuja Peace Accord signed last August, all members of the State Council had equal status and therefore, no one member could be dismissed by the others. 

Making the announcement on Monrovia radio, an interim government statement, quoted by the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) said the decision was taken because recent developments within John's Krahn wing of the Ulimo threatened to derail the peace process. The government also issued a warrant to search John's premises in Monrovia for weapons.

On March 2, senior members of Ulimo-J announced that they had fired Johnson accusing him of losing control over the fighters. They also said Johnson was responsible for recent fighting between troops of the West African peacekeeping force ECOMOG, and those of Ulimo-J in Tubmanburg, northwestern Liberia.

During the fighting, about 60 ECOMOG troops, mainly from the Nigerian contingent, were reportedly killed, together with scores of civilians caught in the cross-fire.

Johnson has since said he was still in charge as Ulimo-J leader and described those who announced his ouster as disgruntled members of the organisation.

Meanwhile, fighters from the LPC are said to have gone on the rampage in the port city of Buchanan, killing two people and wounding several others. Reports say angry civilians had mounted road-blocks to track down members of a rebel group, whose vehicle knocked down and killed a teenage girl.

The LPC group then retreated and returned with reinforcement, armed with assault rifles and opened fire on the unarmed civilians. The bodies of those killed in the shooting and that of the teenage girl were put on display, with angry demonstrators pleading with the Ghanaian contingent of ECOMOG based in Buchanan, to take stern action and stop the rebels from bringing arms into town.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


295 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Hepatitis B, a Major Cause of Death in Africa


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 11, 1996


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Kampala - Liver disease, resulting directly from infection with the Hepatitis B virus, and indirectly through cancer and cirrhosis, "is the fourth largest cause of death in the world."

Dr. J. Jensen of the American Liver Foundation has warned that the impact of Hepatitis B in public health is generally underrated, particularly in Africa, where as many as 10 per cent of the population are carriers of Hepatitis B. "In some countries in Africa, like Mozambique, as many as 20 per cent of the population may be carriers."

Carriers do not have symptoms and require a blood test to verify infection with Hepatitis B or C. These two types are the more common and contagious varieties, says Jensen. Carriers are still susceptible to cancer. 

He explained that Hepatitis A is spread mainly through water contaminated with sewage. It is generally considered less dangerous.

Hepatitis B and C are spread through contaminated blood, unsterilised hospital equipment and sexual intercourse, the same mode of transmission as the HIV virus.

Meanwhile, among the Karimojong people of north-eastern Uganda, the cultural tattooing of the body has been identified as a major avenue for the transmission of Hepatitis B.

The Karimojong are nomadic pastoralists who occupy a large chunk of land in northeastern Uganda. The area is considered the least developed in the country. The local people engage in regular cattle rustling. Famines caused by droughts are quite common.

Dr. Mathew Emer of Matany Hospital in Karimoja, told the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) Resident Representative in Uganda, Dr. Babatunde Thomas that the reason Hepatitis B was prevalent in Karimoja is partly because the people used the same razor blade while tattooing their bodies.

On HIV/AIDS, Dr. Emer said the prevalence of the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) was considered low three years ago, but recent statistics had shown a steep rise. For example, hospital records at Matany showed that only 2.5 per cent of mothers attending ante-natal clinics had HIV in 1993. This figure had risen to 7.5 per cent by late 1995 - a 300 per cent increase.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


296 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Nigeria Catholic Bishops Urge Rulers to Alleviate Suffering


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 11, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Lagos - The head of the Nigerian Catholic Bishops' (CBCN) Conference Albert Obiefuna has charged that Nigeria was in "great distress" and urged the clergy to prevail upon the country's military leader Sani Abacha to alleviate the people's misery.

Addressing a CBCN meeting on February 28, Bishop Obiefuna called for a "well-worded and courteous" memorandum on the sufferings of the people to be handed to the Head of State.

Bishop Obiefuna singled out the deteriorating security situation in Nigeria and the plight of "thousands of prisoners languishing in jails without trial" as some of Nigeria's most pressing proclaims. 

Nigerian authorities have clamped down hard on political opponents since the military regime annulled the results of the 1993 general elections which publishing magnate Moshood Abiola claimed to have won.

Abiola was subsequently arrested and charged with treason after he declared himself president and is still being held in jail.

Bishop Obiefuna also appealed to his colleagues to condemn what he called "shameful acts" of Nigerian girls allegedly engaging in prostitution in Europe.

Authorities here recently ordered the arrest of three Italian embassy officials over allegations that they had received bribes from some 500 Nigerian women to issue visas to them to travel to Italy to practise prostitution.

The military administrator of Lagos state, Colonel Olagunsoye Oyiniola, who also attended the bishops' meeting, appealed to the clergymen to promote moral growth and religious tolerance in the west African country, which has experienced outbreaks of violent clashes between Christians and Muslims in the recent past.

He urged Roman Catholics to pray for the government's three-year democratisation programme, which is being implemented in phases, and will culminate in the military handing over power to an elected civilian government on October 1, 1998.

Answering Colonel Oyinlola's appeal, the Archbishop of Ibadan, Alaba Job, prayed that; "Your government will ease the burden of the people and bring about peace and tranquility to Nigeria."

Meanwhile security forces have prevented the staging of a play by exiled Nobel literature laureate and human rights activist Wole Soyinka, and arrested two theatre directors in Lagos.

Organisers of the performance said security agents went to a government school where Soyinka's play "Trials of Brother Jero" was being staged on February 29 and ordered the performance stopped before arresting two of the directors.

The directors were taken to the headquarters of the state security service where they were interrogated on their motive of staging the play. They were later released but ordered to report to the police virtually every day.

Soyinka is an outspoken critic of Nigeria's military regime. He recently described Abacha as a "stone-age despot" who intends to cling to power for as long as possible.


LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


297 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Uganda Kenya Airways In Biggest Flotation


BYLINE: The Monitor (Kampala) February 26, 1996


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Kampala - Kenya Airways said it would sell 235 million shares, 51 percent of its shareholding, on the Nairobi Stock Exchange in the biggest flotation since the bourse opened up in 1954.

The airline said in a statement that the share offer would begin on March 25 and remain open for four weeks to April 19.

Kenya Airways Managing Director Brian Davies said the offer was the second phase of a privatisation after the January sale of 26 percent of the airline to Dutch national carrier KLM for $26 million (UShs 26bn). 

The Kenyan government will retain 23 percent of the airline. "The government will be offering approximately 235 million shares for sale. Further details, including the price of the shares, will be announced at a later date," the statement said.

"The flotation will enable all interested Kenyans to participate in the future success of our national airline and ensure that majority of the shares are held by Kenyan citizens," the statement added.

NSE estimated that each share would cost 12 shillings.

Initially, Kenya Airways staff were supposed to acquire three percent of the airline but the Monday statement made no reference to them, suggesting staff had ceded that privilege.

Foreign investors in the Nairobi Stock Exchange (NSE) are allowed to buy up to 40 percent of the shares of local concerns. Davies had previously said foreign investors would be permitted to purchase up to 14 percent of Kenya Airways stock.

The Kenyan public and institutions would take the balance.

Kenya Airways made a profit of 450 million shilligs ($7.7 million) in 1993, the first since its launch in 1977. But the airline is weighed down with debts totalling $15.35 million.

Profits rose to 868 million shillings and the government said it would take over its outstanding debts.

Kenya Airways has eight aircrafts--three Airbus A310's, three Fokker 50's and two Boeing 737's. It has a work force of 2,400, reduced from 3,500 in 1993.

In addition to Kenya Airways, the Kenyan government has listed 42 other public companies for privatisation this year.

The NSE, with a capitalisation of $1.75 billion, is the fourth largest bourse in Africa but accounts but accounts for only one percent of the entire share market. The Johannesburg Stock Exchange still tops in Africa.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Uganda Nile Power Gets Green Flag


BYLINE: The Monitor (Kampala) February 26, 1996


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Kampala - East Africa's first private sector power generation project yesterday recieved a go-ahead from the Uganda and USA governments, with the execution of a Memorandum of Understanding between the Uganda Electricity Board and Nile Independent Power Ltd.

The memorandum will enable UEB to finish a Power Purchase Agreement with NIP for up to 340 MW of electricity. This is the first such private deal in Sub-Sahara Africa.

Nile Independent Power Ltd. is a joint venture between the EAS Corporation, of Arlington, Virginia, and Madhvani International, the management and development company of the family of the legendary East African industrialist, the late Jayant Madhvani.

The EAS Corporation, a leading global power company, generates and sells electricity in over 30 countries world-wide. NIP is to build, own and operate a 340 MW hydro-power project on the river Nile, near Dumbbell Island located approx. 10 kms. downstream of the existing Owen Falls dam at Jinja. With the completion of the present works at Owen Falls and this NIP's station, Uganda will have a capacity of at least 650 Megawatts by the year 2001.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Uganda January Coffee Sales Set Over 10 Year Record


BYLINE: The Monitor (Kampala) February 26, 1996 by Joseph Were


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Kampala - At a total of 552,532 bags for January, valued at US $50.2 million (Shs 50bn), Uganda has recorded the highest shipment ever in a single month since the early 80's. But uncertainty in the direction of international prices and the growing influence of pre-finance by external banks continue to lower profits in the local market. 

The Uganda Coffee Development Authority (UCDA) report for January says that although international prices remain high, local farmers are earning comparitively less than during the same period last coffee year. The January price of between Shs 600-700 Kiboko (unprocessed coffee) and Shs 1,300-1,450 per Kg for FAQ (processed coffee)compare unfavorably with last year's prices of 800-1000 and 1800-2000 respectively during the same period.

A 1995 World Bank report paints a gloomy picture of the Uganda coffee market and predicted a continued drop in profits. The report that Ugandan financial instituitions, especially Uganda Commercial Bank (UCB), are losing the coffee processing and marketing business to off-shore banks. 45 percent of an estimated Ug Shs 75 billion obtained for coffee purchasing and marketing was provided by non-Ugandan banks. The World Bank report says Ugandan farmers were driven to foreign banks by high real interest rates charged by domestic banks. It notes that as international prices drop competition from off-shore sources, it will have a more powerful effect on demand for funds in the local market, leading to a decline in margins.

A UCDA source said that the World Bank's gloomy predictions are credible, but said in the short run international pre-financing provides healthy competition in the market and prompt payment for farmers. According to a yet to be published UCDA document, following the liberalisation of the coffee market, over 80 percent of coffee finance is pre-financed by foreign financial institutions.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


300 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Special Report on Journalists' Sentencing


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 1, 1996


LENGTH: 3400 words


 

Lusaka - Speaker of the National Assembly, Robbinson Nabulyato, in late February sentenced Post managing director and editor-in-chief Fred Mm'embe, managing editor Bright Mwape, and columnist Lucy Sichone, to indefinite imprisonment for breach of parliamentary privileges and gross contempt.

The three were found "guilty of libelling and publishing inflamatory and conteptous remarks, contempt and libel, and wantonly contemptuous of the dignity of the house, the speaker and the leader of the house" respectively. We reproduce in full what they wrote in their respective columns.

Fred's Dairy - by Fred M'membe

Last week Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda, legal affairs minister Remmy Mushota, and energy deputy minister Ernest Mwansa opened a vicious attack in parliament on the Supreme Court for declaring sections 5 (4) and 7 (a) of the Public Order Act unconstitutional.

Vice-President Miyanda and other ruling MMD officials have every right to feel disappointed with the Supreme Court's ruling on the Public Order Act as it was a treasured political weapon in their hands. 

They used the restrictive laws not only to stop anti-government protests but also to harass and humiliate their political opponents.

The Act enabled MMD officials to hold meetings at very short notice as they did not, in most cases, require police permits as most of their top party officials are also ministers. And the police is under the control and direction of those who are in power.

Supreme Court's ruling has, in some very big way, levelled the political play field in so far as mass mobilisation through political meetings is concerned. The ruling MMD has indeed lost some political advantage. And looking at the way the MMD officials are reacting to the Supreme Court judgment loss must have been gigantic - the bigger the advantage the greater the resistance to losing it.

Miyanda missed point over writers attack.

Behind the scene - by Bright Mwape

I FEEL let down yet again by the conduct of Vice-President Brigadier general Godfrey Miyanda. When he went promo and starred in Victor Oladukun Tunnel and Torture 'advert' on CBN, I thought it was for sheer want of leisure-time off whatever you can imagine keeps him busy in the veeps office.

But I thought he was totally of tangent on Tuesday when he went to cry before the speaker of the national assembly that he be protected from the arrogance and cheek of writers like Fred M'membe and Lucy Sichone.

Not that any generals don't cry. The generals must be allowed to cry and weep. It's normal. As one philosopher once put it, "even the fish cry's only the water retains its glitter of confidence."

But not even that is my issue. Miyanda let me down for failing to distinguish between an office as an institution and the individual.

He failed to read the principle of the people's disgust at his fellow MMD cohorts attack is that these are injuring the greater integrity of the office of the chief justice and the judiciary in general. The gist of the public outburst including the high sounding Lucy Sichone and Fred M'membe attacks was less intended at curtailing Miyanda's freedom of speech as of reminding him that when he takes on the judiciary in that manner Zambians have a duty to rise to its defence because it is their last hope.

What the people are saying regardless of their affiliation is that the chief justice should be left alone.

Their concern is their wider implication of calls for his removal let alone the Miyanda backed attempt to go round his judgement and retain exactly what the judiciary ruled against.

Miyanda as a politican must know that he has had demonstrable 'privileges' even illicit ones, to protect him from so many verbal and written attacks inspite of his blunders.

When he and other politicians are injured by my writing they should run to the 'Chief Justice' and try hard to use that institution to sqeeeze me into jail or drain my pocket.

Even when that fails the Miyanda's would summon their security to survet, haras and intimidate me. If that is too indirect I would be clobbered by thugs of party cadres who have never known the word 'reason' in their life time. They would not be arrested or charged because they are protecting the President or is it the 'power.'

Now I learn the Miyanda's can even abuse parliament to add to their list of protectors.

If you add to this physical bodly guards, guns, alarms, sirens, cars and other you would understand Miyanda's shock when all this fails to hold the sharp edge of Lucy and Fred's writing from piercing his heart.

But when all this is their's have the Miyanda's in their plural, thought about who is there to protect the more important institution when it turns freedom of assembly from a previledge of the Miyanda's to a right of over eight million people?

The protection of the intergrity of that institution will not be left to today's holder of that office, Mathew Ngulube. It is not his issue. Infact Ngulube should not even waste his time answering back the Miyanda's. We the people, whose institution that s, will rise to its defence at whatever risk to ourselves. It is for our benefit. Not even parliament will hold us back.

Thats why those in the judiciary getting compromised will not equally receive our support.

Therefore Mr. Speaker Sir, I rise on a counter point of order. You have an obligation to recognise that you are ruling on an issue which goes beyond M'membe and Sichone. It is one of the people versus the executive over the independence of the judiciary. Are the Miyanda's in order? I beg to move.

Miyanda has forgotten about need for justice!

Lucy on Monday - by Lucy Sichone

Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda is alive and addressed by his title of Brigadier General because of the courage and integrity of a few men in thejudiciary who defied KK to ensure that justice was done when he was arraigned on a treason charge of which he was not guilty.

Miyanda cannot have forgotten the courage of one judge who refused to sit and hear his case until his jailers removed the chains with which he was shackled in the court room. Miyanda could not have foregotten that in the circumstances of the Second Republic, it took men of courage and integrity to acquit him of a crime for which the government decreed him guilty. Yet KK even in cases such as that of Miyanda where courageous judges dispensed justice in defiance of his wishes, never abused a one-party rubber stamp parliament to attack the decisions of those judges who risked their necks for Miyanda's constitutional rights to equality, justice and protection of the law.

In view of this, Miyanda's condemnation of the courage and integrity of the Supreme Court judgment which merely applied Article 1 (2) of the Constitution which reads "This Constitution is the supreme law of Zambia and if any other law is inconsistent with this Constitution, that other law shall to the extent of the inconsistency be void" was cheap, false and cowardly. Miyanda's statement was cheap and false because Section 7 of the Public Order Act was declared void only to the extent where the exercise of the right to assembly could be enjoyed at the discretion of a policeman.

The requirement for the police to maintain law and order at any assembly still remains in place.

It was a cowardly statement because he could only attack a decision made by men of the stature, dignity and integrity of Mathew Ngulube from behind the protective skirts of grand mother Nabulyato. I have no doubt that Miyanda being a devout Christian had in mind the parable of the unmerciful servant whose many debts were forgiven but who withheld the same kind of mercy shown to him from his debtors and had them thrown in prison. The Bible says that when the master who had forgiven his servant heard what he had done, he had the unmerciful servant thrown into prison for not extending the same kind of justice shown to him by his master to his debtors. Miyanda is depending on Nabulyato to save him from the natural consequences of his actions and soothe his conscience. What hypocrisy?

If Miyanda was an honest man he could not have lined political violence which is being fanned by himself to the decision of the Supreme Court. And by the way the re-enactment of the POA will not solve the problem of its invalidity by Article (2) of the Constitution and as long as we have individual judges of courage and integrity, such a law will not stand. The veep will just have to be a man enough and abolish the bill of rights as it exists in the Constitution and rule in the manner everyone, including his colleagues in the MMD know he would like to rule - as a Christian Abacha. For as someone said of Lyndon Johnson "One cannot imagine an act so small that he would not commit it, nor words so hollow that he would not utter them. He is a crescendo of hypocrisy and pettiness who has managed to congeal in one personality the worst elements of man's most honoured traits. He is capable of anger but not passion, he is pious without being religious, tough without being brave, sincere without honesty and vain without pride."

As for the honourable MPs who called for the removal of Mathew Ngulube from his job, I can only advise that individuals of the calibre of the current Chief Justice do not depend on the trappings of office to be heroes. They are heroes because of what they are and not what they do.

I know that this is difficult to understand in a country where there are no heroes, no role models, where honour and integrity are conspicuous by their absence.

Ngulube, outside the CJ's office would still command the same kind of respect that would compel most of us in need of a role model, guidance and just old fashioned advice to seek him out and and learn from his experience. The assumption here of course is that he has always been and continues to turn down consultancies and offers of jobs from around the

Commonwealth and USA in order to help those of us who benefit from his wealth of legal knowledge and plain common sense. Further, I know that it is a trait of human nature to judge others by our own standards.

Consequently, those who measure their wealth by their job description, believe that all persons depend on their positions for some measure of stature, respectability and dignity. In fact it is the other way round; it is inherent integrity of the person that vests an office with qualities of respectability, integrity and dignity.

The current leadership crisis has been brought about by a critical shortage of men and women capable of imparting honour, integrity and dignity to their offices whether it be in judiciary, executive, legislature, civil service, etc.

In the circumstances, it is absolutely necessary that I pay tribute and salute Justices Ngulube, Muzyamba and Sakala in their capacities as human beings, because it is the qualities of their humanity that is reflected in that landmark judgement which shall be forever cherished by all freedom and peace loving Zambians.

Miyanda's court ruling 'justified' - what will replacing the Public Order Act mean?

Last Thursday Vice-President Miyanda, who is also the leader of the House, told parliament they will make another law in the place of the lost Public Order Act.

"We will make amendments to see that sense comes to the law so that we don't have anarchy," Vice-President Miyanda told parliament last Thursday.

"The courts should have cast their nets wider and looked at the wider implications of their judgements."

But what does this mean? Doesn't it mean bringing back another Public Order Act under a different name? What are the implications of all this if it is effected? Does it undermine or strengthen the separation of powers?

But Vice-President Miyanda is not the only top government official attacking the Supreme Court and it's judgment.

Legal minister Remmy Mushota, who seems to be living only for today with little interest in tomorrow, has gone beyond criticising the Supreme Court judgment to attacking the political affiliations of the individual judges, of course in a cowardly manner - without giving names or elaborating.

Last Wednesday Mushota told parliament that judges should refrain from political party membership because this would clout their judgments.

"When the judiciary set a political platform in their judgments they risk antagonising the legislature," Mushota told the house. "Any attempt by anyone to use the bench for legislation would land them into trouble."

Energy deputy minister Ernest Mwansa accused the Supreme Court of imitating what happens in other countries.

"The problem is that people imitate what happens in other countries like the United States," Mwansa told parliament last Wednesday. "It is possible for people to demonstrate without permits in the United States because there were enough policemen to deal with the crowds which was not the case in Zambia."

Whereas I agree with Mushota that the judiciary is not the legislature, I believe the High Court and the Supreme Court has power to declare acts of parliament unconstitutional. This is not equivalent to "using the bench for legislation", as Mushota claims.

What seems to be clear now is that the executive doesn't seem to accept, in practice rather than in theory, the separation, or indeed the sharing of, power among the three arms of the state - the executive, judiciary, and legislature.

In Zambia, as matters stand today, the independence of the legislature is not more than a theoretical ideal.

The executive controls and directs parliament. The leader of the house, the Vice-President and the man who lead the attacks on the Supreme Court judgment in parliament, is the number two man in the executive. The majority of the members of the legislature are executive officials. The executive determines who should be speaker and deputy speaker. The composition and character of this parliament is of very little practical significance in the separation of powers. It is purely symbolic.

And having taken over the functions of parliament, the executive has become excessively greedy and would also like to interpret the Constitution and all other laws, taking over judiciary functions.

It is common knowledge that some judicial officers, at various levels, have offered themselves to the service of those in charge of the executive. They consult and brief members of the executive in all matters in which they think they have an interest.

Judicial officers who were seen to be supporters, or ruled in favour, of the MMD were rewarded with promotions after the change of government. These favour-seekers are not even ashamed to allege that those who rule against the MMD and government have political affiliations with the opposition or former president Kenneth Kaunda.

But these are not the judicial officers Mushota is concerned about, because they always, in material matters, rule in favour of the ruling MMD.

The MMD government, like it does with everyone who refuses to toe it's line or takes an independent position, is trying to discredit Chief Justice Matthew Ngulube, Justice Weston Muzyamba, and Justice Ernest Sakala as being supporters of some opposition parties. And if these belong to the opposition, and since no person can be independent in this country, it will be interesting to know which political party deputy Chief Justice Bonaventure Bweupe and Justice Chaila belong to. It is certainly not an opposition party!

This is the some total of Mushota's insinuations.

But if the Supreme Court can be said to be so weakly constituted what type of justice can those involved in legal battles in magistrate courts with a president expect to get. If the Chief Justice can be harangued in parliament in that way what more a mere magistrate or an ordinary High Court judge? These may probably explain why two High Court judges, Lombe Chibesakunda and David Lewanika, who enjoy some considerable respect as human rights judges, opted not to rule against the State.

As for Mwansa's claims that "the problem is that people imitate what happens in other countries like the United States", the deputy minister forgot that the parliament he was talking from is an imitation, the suit, shirt, necktie, shoes, pair of socks, underwears and the wrist watch he was putting on are imitations. The Speaker's robe is an imitation from England.

The Constitution of the Republic of Zambia and its bill of rights is an imitation. There is no need to labour much on this, the best thing for Mwansa would be to shut up.

It is clear that there are some serious separation of powers deficiencies in our system of government, but we should not allow it to be weakened further by wicked men, because, as we have seen, it does to some extent provide an important safeguard against the potential abuse of power by the executive.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


301 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zimbabwe Project Turns Convicts Into Breadwinners


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 6, 1996 by Tim Chigodo


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

Nairobi - Serving a jail sentence can be a traumatic experience. But for female inmates in one of Zimbabwe's jails, prison life has also turned into a learning forum where they have acquired skills that enable them try new job outlets upon release.

Most female inmates never see a judge or magistrate again. Chikurubi female prison in north-eastern Zimbabwe, near the capiutal Harare is now turning out qualified women who upon being freed are becoming useful members of a society that once frowned upon their deeds. Gweru is the only other women's prison in this southern African countrty. 

Just 10 per cent of women prisoners in Zimbabwe come before the courts again after their release, suggesting that women are far more likely than men to reform in jail. Also a significant number of women are in jail for infanticide and baby dumping, two offences that hardly anyone commits more than once and which few prospective employers will hold against a job applicant otherwise considered suitable.

Therefore, training for the employment market upon release usually makes very good sense for women prisoners and since most committed the crime that sent them to prison from need or desperation, such training is the best way of ensuring that they never see a judge or magistrate again.

The present sophisticated training project was initiated by Lady Melhuish, the wife of a former British High Commissioner to Zimbabwe in 1985.

Although not the best place to be, some serving inmates feel they have achieved more inside than they would have while outside and that they are far better equipped for life. They have taken prison as a second chance to learn how to lead a decent and honest life on their release. Some are now even running classes as they work out their term.

When working out how she could help the women prisoners, Lady Melhuish came up with the idea of a training centre and discussed it with the Commissioner of Prisons, Mr. Langton Chigwida, who gave her the go-ahead.

Lady Melhuish, who had taught secretarial skills before, volunteered to take part of her time to teach willing prisoners secretarial skills without asking for any payment or assistance from the government.

With the help of her husband, Sir Ramsay Melhuish, Lady Melhuish managed to source donations of typewriters and books from British business people and banks.

The commissioner, Mr. Chigwada, also contributed to the success of the project by building a room at the prison premises where up to today lessons are being conducted.

In an interview at the Chikurubi Female Maximum Security Prison, Lady Melhuish said her wish was for the inmates to get employment when they leave jail. She briefly stopped running the project in 1989 when her husband was posted outside this southern African country.

But during her two-year absence, she arranged for those prisoners who had been with her for a long time and had already passed their advanced examinations to run the classes with the help of prison officers.

"Although it was difficult for them to run the project during my absence they managed to pull through and when I came back, I phoned the Commissioner and was given the permission to take over again. We get a lot of help from people donating second-hand typewriters but we have never had a regular source of income," she told this writer.

According to Lady Melhuish, a charitable organisation, Oak Zimbabwe Foundation, gave them goods worth over Zimbabwe dollars 50,000 (US dollars 5,000) after visiting the project.

Most ex-prisoners who were once in Lady Melhuish's class are now breadwinners for their families. The project could also decrease the number of female offenders most of whom turn to crime because of lack of employment.

The examination results have also been overwhelming. The first 11 students passed, with 10 of them obtaining first-class passes.

Lady Melhuish says there are currently 21 students who will be joined by four prison officers, expected to later join the training class so that they could spread the project in other prisons.

Asked why the project only benefited female offenders, Lady Melhuish said: "I honestly believe that the majority of women are in prison for economic reasons, mostly because they will be trying to fend for their children. But with enough resources we might consider setting a similar project for male offenders."

She added that most women were willing to learn and everyday there were more eager to join the class. But because of lack of space and few facilities they are turned down.

Diana Musa (32) and Viola Hakata who are both serving jail sentences for theft, felt that the project was useful as it would help to improve their lives outside. Already the pair have obtained two certificates each.

For Agnes Samoto, who is in for fraud, the unpleasant side of prison life does not put her down so much for the project keeps her mind occupied. Samoto, who by the beginning of this year still had two months of her sentence remaining, said she hoped to get a job with the qualifications acquired in prison.

Others whom APS spoke to said although they already had the secretarial skills, the project helped to refresh their minds. However, they were all grateful to Lady Melhuish for her devotion. "She is a very nice woman," said Agnes.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


302 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large The Costly Search For Peace In Endemic Conflicts


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 6, 1996 by Wafula John


LENGTH: 1720 words


 

Nairobi - Peace seems as elusive as ever all over the world. In Africa, the search for peace continues as various countries are faced with civil wars that somehow seem endless.

A resource person commenting about the threat facing the ordinary world as a result of conflict says; "If an anthropological expedition from another galaxy arrived on earth today, it would surely be impossible for them to give a rational explanation of human behaviour.

"How would they explain that we spend 250 times more on arms than we do on peacekeeping? What would they say about the 22 million people killed in wars since 1945? About the fact that 84 per cent of those killed were civilians, compared to 50 per cent of casualties in the Second World War? About the 24 million people forced to flee and become displaced people within their own countries, and the 18 million who have become refugees abroad, all as a result of conflict?"

Writing a foreword to The Cost of Conflict, a 1994 Earthscan publication summarizing case studies of conflicts worldwide, Rt. Hon. Lord Judd of Portsea, also notes that so much of the work done to raise the quality of life of our fellow human beings is frustrated and negated by conflict. 

Says Lord Judd in the 1994 publication that tries to evaluate the costs and benefits of conflicts; "In my six years as Director of (British charity) Oxfam, our priority was, as it is now, long term development. But over 50 per cent of Oxfam's work was in areas of conflict. In Africa, 70 per cent of our work was war-related...In the 1990s all the relief and development agencies are grappling with humanitarian suffering and death, in what Oxfam has called "a decade of disasters." Judd has since retired from the British charity.

Instead of promoting independence and development, most of Africa's efforts and external aid today are being channeled to deal with the collapse of civil society and economic destruction. Even programmes initially earmarked for other developmental activities such as the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) are now directing their much needed resources to resolving conflict and settling conflict victims.

These disasters are graphically demonstrated by the number of people being forced to flee their homes in circumstances which involve untold human suffering. A half of Africa's estimated 20 million people said to be presently displaced from their homes have been forced to flee as a result of conflict. The rest have been compelled to leave by hunger and rural poverty.

Mozambique's 30-year-old war covering the pre-independence period (before 1974) up to the end of the post-independence civil war in 1992, was responsible for the displacement of some 5 million people internally and another 1.7 million into neighbouring countries.

In the Sudan, as a result of on-going civil war since 1983, over six million people have reportedly been displaced. Some 5000,000, mostly civilians have died whereas up to one million have been injured as a direct result of the war.

Many refugees have been created from civil wars. An official at the United Nations High Commissioner

for Refugees (UNHCR) in Nairobi, says that even when humanely treated, the refugee still feels humiliated, no longer in control of his destiny and at the mercy of others. This undoubtedly generates anger and a feeling of helplessness," said the UN officer who chose anonymity.

The disruptions occasioned by conflicts in Africa often deprive displaced people of many things. Among them, according to the UNHCR official were property, work, role and status, family, neighbours, friends, nationhood and such other facilities as schools, hospitals and institutions of worship.

However, the cost of Africa's conflicts is always a lot more than the immediate visible human suffering. In Mozambique's war, first against the Portuguese then later against the insurgent National Resistance Movement (RENAMO), the economy, health services, education, the infrastructure and even internal trade virtually collapsed enhancing a dependence syndrome.

In this southern African country, 45 per cent of the schools had by 1993 either been closed down or destroyed. The elephant population had dropped from 65,000 to 13,000 and by 1993 it was estimated that it would cost US dollars 600 million to rehabilitate the country's roads.

The raging civil war in southern Sudan on the other hand, has reportedly stalled oil mining, costing the Sudan an estimated annual earning of US dollars 136 million.

But as Africa suffers the repercussions from conflicts, the true beneficiaries of these macabre settings are said to be the suppliers of firearms. Africa's conflicts are said to be good fodder for firearm barons as the warring factions will out of necessity, increase expenditure on the purchasing of militaryware.

It is ironical that the five permanent members of the security council (the United Kingdom , France, Germany, the United States and Italy), which have the ultimate responsibility for peace keeping worldwide, are reportedly the most prolific suppliers of firearms. In 1993, the Permanent Five as they are known, are said to have accounted for 95 per cent of all arms exports to the Third World.

In the Sudan for instance, military expenditure rose five-fold in 10 years, from US dollars 34.5 million in 1982 to US dollars 1.01 billion in 1992. Worse still, these expenditures were incurred while drought and famine ravaged the country.

Thus, Africa's conflicts are setting in motion absurd priorities where African leaders spend colossal amounts of money on guns while millions of their subjects starve. As a result of conflicts in Africa and the resulting absurdities and sufferings that go with them, a number of individuals and organizations are looking for home- grown solutions to stem off or reconcile these conflicts.

Last October, International Alert, a London-based group concerned with global peace and human rights violations, convened a workshop at the Red Cross Centre, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, where individuals and organisations interested in peace initiatives debated on "Regional Mechanisms for Early Warning and Preventive Diplomacy in Africa".

Professor Hizkias Assefa, Director of the Nairobi Peace Initiative (NPI) a local non-governmental organisation working in the realm of peace seeking and reconciliation, said that the meeting discussed "ways of nipping conflict in the bud."

In the resultant report, the workshop recommends that "conflicts can be a vehicle for social change that can be managed with the question posed as to whether conflict prevention might suppress legitimate social change."

The report further cautions; "It is important in approaching conflict prevention in Africa, to take a critical perspective, consider the specific contexts, include as a factor the needs and demands of the marginalised, to be clear of objectives, consequences and interests, and to be aware of value judgements."

The meeting also came up with various recommendations meant to address the problem of arms and ammunition and how to involve local people particularly women in the peace process.

Still, some actors in the peace and reconciliation seeking groups think that to resolve the impasse of African conflicts, grassroots people have to be consulted and indeed be made active participants of the peace process.

"People at the grassroots level, must be made aware of their role as peace-makers. Education and information for these people is particularly important in early detecting and resolving conflict," says Mr. Greg Darr of People for Peace, a local peace lobby group.

He adds that indigenous aspects of peacemaking must be incorporated in the process of peace seeking and reconciliation. Mr. Darr notes that local aspects to conflicts such as culture, economic differences, marginalization and inbuilt prejudices ought to be well understood when dealing with conflicts and how to resolve them.

On the other hand, there are those pursuing the attainment of civil peace in Africa who like the Catholic Church, believe that "the root cause of violent conflicts is in people's hearts and unless that is dealt with, the situation in the world will not change."

Whatever opinions different institutions and individuals pursuing the issue on peace in Africa hold, it is becoming clear that more and more people are getting genuinely involved in efforts to attain civil peace. More than ever before, peacemakers are now seeking not only indigenous wisdom in combating conflict but also local participation.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


303 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Project To Put Africa On Information Superhighway


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 6, 1996 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Nairobi - Due to endemic poverty, Africa is caught in a trap of underdevelopment. One reason for this is that the continent has inadequate telecommunication facilities. And because it is poor, its telecommunication infrastructure remains underdeveloped. But something is being done to help redress Africa's backward telecommunication.

More than 35 years ago the late flamboyant Togolese leader, Sylvanus Olympio lamented that it was more difficult to make a telephone call to Accra in Ghana from Lome in neighbouring Togo than to call Paris or London more than 1,600 kilometres away in Europe. 

He also lamented that to call most parts of Africa from within the continent, one had to be linked via London or Paris. Unless Africa could get away from this apron attachment to Europe, argued Olympio, the continent would remain destined to play a marginal role in world affairs.

Now things are likely to change, thanks to the ambitious Africa One project being implemented by the giant American telecommunications company, American Telephones and Telegraph Corporation (ATT). The project proposes that by 1999, a hi-tech fibre optic cable would be in position under the sea off the African coastline which would link a total of 42 coastal cities in Africa from Cape Town, South Africa to Cairo, Egypt. This would vastly improve telecommunication possibilities on the African continent and boost its social-economic development.

Dr. Moses Osum, a Nigerian engineer who is in charge of Africa One project at the ATT-Bell Telephone Laboratories in the United States says the undersea (submarine) fibre optic cable will form a giant fibre optic loop around Africa measuring approximately 32,000 kilometers. Dr. Osum emphasised that while the Africa One loop would directly connect Africa's coastal countries, the countries in the interior would have automatic access to it either by satellite or land links. The Africa One loop would also be connected to fibre- optic cables linking America, Europe and Asia,

Unlike ordinary telephone wires which depend on electrical signals to transmit information, a fibre optic cable uses light impulses to achieve the same. A fibre optic cable is a vast improvement over ordinary submarine cables which means tens of thousands of calls and other data can be transmitted simultaneously - telephone conversations, data, facsimile (or fax) video-phone, electronic mail etc.

Dr. Osum who also heads the Optical Transceiver Department at ATT- Bell Telephone Laboratories, says fibre optic cables would require minimal maintenance "because there are very few parts that can go wrong." It would also be laid deep in the sea off the African coast.

Last December in Nairobi, Kenya, Ms. Glenda Jones, a senior executive at ATT Africa One project, said once the scheme is off the ground, it will provide "an efficient, cost effective backbone for advanced telecommunication within Africa itself, as well as access Africa to the vitally important Global Information Network - the Information Super Highway."

In this way Africa would be boosted not only in its ordinary telecommunication but in new dimensions and facilities like telemarketing (buying and selling via the computer) and video teleconferencing - bringing

people together from all over the world in a conference using television screens and computers thus avoiding the hassles of long distance travel.

The initial drawback is still the funding. The Africa One project will cost approximately US dollars 3 billion and will likely be hampered by cost over-runs. Ms. Jones said this problem was being sorted out. The World Bank, the African Development Bank and a consortium of private investors have already shown keen interest in the proposed venture.

The ATT which started the Africa One project in 1993 at the behest of the International Telecommunications Union, says once the funds hitch is sorted out, a fully operational cable would be in place by 1999.

The availability of hi-tech telecommunication facilities would help attract new investments and promote Africa's international trade. The project will jump start Africa's woefully inadequate telecommunications and make the same easier for all.

Dr. Osum, himself an inventor who originated a number of new electronic devices used by ATT which is one of the largest companies in the world today, is particularly keen to see Africans enter the Global Information network. He says education, health care and agriculture will be some of the areas that would be boosted tremendously by accessibility to the Network.

People can be educated right in their villages. In health care, specialists can provide vital life saving information that can help in the treatment of a desperately ill patient deep in the African interior. Africa has a lot of resources but markets elsewhere in the world are ignorant about these resources.

Africa One will be run by a company to be incorporated in the Indian Ocean nation of Mauritius later this year.

Statistics show that most African countries have fewer than 0.25 lines (i.e less than one per cent) per 100 people. Uganda is one such country in Africa but the government has unveiled plans to increase telephone line availability to 2 lines per 100 person by the year 2000.

Compared to advanced nations like Britain, Japan and the United States who have between 50-80 lines per 100 people, Uganda's projected line availability is still very much a Third World situation. However it will be a major boost to its economy.

With a Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth rate of 5.5 per cent during the past few years, Uganda has one of the fastest growing economies among developing countries. It has a per capita income of US dollars 286.

Currently, Uganda offers 42,000 subscriber lines. But within the next five years, demand is projected to reach 300,000 lines.

According to Mr. Kirunda Kivejinja, the Minister for Works, Transport and Communications, the Uganda Posts and Telecommunications (UPTC), will be restructured to allow the formation of a new private liability company to be called Uganda Telecommunications Limited (UTL). Private investors would be allowed to invest in the new venture.

Uganda would also allow a second national operator of telecommunications in order to ensure that UTL does not function as a monopoly, says Kivejinja in a policy document released recently.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


304 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Egypt Human Rights Body Condemns Killing Of Christians


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 6, 1996


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Cairo - Human rights group Amnesty International has condemned the slaying of six Christians and two Muslims by Islamic extremists in Egypt's southern province of Asyut.

Islamic militants opened fire on a crowd of people in the Asyut village of Etmaniya, about 400 kilometres south of the Egyptian capital, on February 24, killing six Christians and two Muslims.

An Amnesty statement said: "The region where the killings took place is predominantly Coptic Christian and it appears that the killings were on account of religion." 

Egyptian and Arab human rights groups have added their voice to condemnation of the sectarian violence, with the Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights expressing its "strong condemnation of the massacres organised by armed violent groups.

"Copts are becoming the chief target for these groups. These innocent citizens are being murdered for purely religious reasons," the organisation said.

At least 24 people, including 11 Coptic Christians, have been killed in the Bedari region of Asyut, where Etmaniya is also situated, in the past few weeks in a spate of violent extremist attacks, which have also led to stepped-up police crackdown.

Muslim militants fighting to overthrow the secular government in Cairo and replace it with an Iranian-style Islamic administration have killed nearly 1,000 since they began their violent campaign in 1992.

They have previously mostly targeted members of the security forces and foreign tourists, but the February 24 murder of six Christians could be an indication that the extremists may be starting to turn their guns against non-Muslims, especially Christians who do not support the installation of an Islamic fundamentalist government in Egypt.

In another development, local authorities in the Nile Delta village of Kafr Dumyan, some 150 kilometres northeast of Cairo, called in the police on February 27 after violent clashes, pitting Muslims against Christians, broke out.

According to an official version on the situation there, violence was sparked by a rumour that a local priest planned to expand a church to create more room for the faithful.

Thousands of Muslim villagers then gathered and attempted to set the church on fire before police intervened.

Some villagers said Muslims looted their homes, but authorities described the Kafr Dumyan disturbances as a "minor incident" lasting just half-an-hour.

There are an estimated six million Coptic Christians in Egypt, according to figures issued by the church. This northern African country has a population of some 54 million people.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


305 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zimbabwe Politician's Wife Denies Betrayal Before Elections


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 6, 1996


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Harare - Vesta Sithole, wife of veteran Zimbabwean politician, Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole has vehemently denied accusations that she had betrayed him politically.

Reports in Zimbabwean newspapers quoted Rev. Sithole alleging his wife was working with the ruling Zimbabwe African National Union - Patriotic Front (ZANU-PF) of President Robert Mugabe to ensure the political downfall of ZANU-Ndonga party of Rev. Sithole.

But talking to the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) on February 27, Mrs. Sithole said she was concerned about her husband "because he is not behaving like himself lately. 

"It is painful when people create things that are not real," said Vesta Sithole.

She explained that she lives together with her husband, cooks for him and makes his bed and was at a loss to understand the origin of her husband's accusations.

The Rev. Sithole, 76, has a history of health problems, a situation that was aggravated last October, following his arrest after a group of people made an abortive attempt in Harare on the life of Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe, 72, who has been in power since independence 16 years ago. Sithole denied any involvement and is out on bail in a case still pending in court.

Supporters of Rev. Sithole's ZANU-Ndonga party say the charges were trumped up to get their leader out of the way in the presidential elections due from March 16 to 17 in which Rev. Sithole is a challenger to President Mugabe.

However, observers expect Mugabe to sail through easily due to weak challengers and voter apathy. There is an estimated 4 million potential voters in Zimbabwe but election registers contain less than 2.5 million names, few of whom care to vote. In 1994, Sithole said that Zimbabweans have become apathetic to elections because Mugabe's ZANU-PF "routinely rigs elections and intimidates voters."

Analysts say the real issues close to the hearts of rural Zimbabweans is land redistribution which Mugabe promised to effect many times in the past but turned out to be fraught with problems. In Zimbabwe, most of the farmlands belong to about 100,000 white farmers. The southern African country has a population of nearly 8.5 million people.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Burundi Peace Initiative Postponed


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 6, 1996


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Addis Ababa - The Burundi peace initiative, due to have taken place in the Tunisian capital, Tunis on March 3, has been postponed to a later date yet to be announced.

Former American President Jimmy Carter announced the postponement of the meeting on February 29, one week after fixing the date for it.

His Atlanta, US-based Carter Centre is involved in peace initiatives on the African continent. 

The Tunis meeting was due to bring together leaders from the Great Lakes Region of eastern and central Africa - Zaire, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi and Tanzania in an attempt to defuse the volatile situation in Burundi and the humanitarian crisis posed by the estimated 1.7 million Rwandese refugees in camps in

Rwanda. Both Zaire and Tanzania want the refugees to return home "as soon as possible." Zaire is using its army to put pressure on them to leave.

Kenya was not mentioned in the earlier dispatch from the Carter Centre. It had been expected that Kenya would host the meeting President Daniel arap Moi announced soon after his return from a trip to Israel, mid-February that Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni had called him in Israel to let him know that the regional leaders had chosen Nairobi as the venue for the Burundi peace initiative.

The Tunis meeting would have been the second time in four months that the Carter Centre had organised a summit for leaders of the Great Lakes Region. The first meeting was held in the Egyptian capital Cairo, last November. It achieved little because there was a lot of polarisation among the participants.

When the next summit is held, it will re-assess promises made during the "Cairo Declaration" that generally remain unfulfilled. Besides defusing the crisis in Burundi, it will look into how to "accelerate the large scale return of the Rwandese refugees."

Meanwhile, African Foreign Ministers met here from February 22 to 29. Informal consultations on the ethnic killings in Burundi made part of their deliberations. One of the guest facilitators at the meeting was former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere.

The Secretary General of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) Salim Ahmed Salim emphasised that it was crucial for the people of Burundi to realise that dialogue holds the key to solving the inter- ethnic bloodshed in their country. Salim opposed plans for a proposed stand-by peacekeeping force put forward by United Nations Secretary General Boutros Boutros Ghali.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large African Churches Asked To Train More Women in Media


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 6, 1996


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Nairobi- The Church in Africa should avail more funds to train women in mass media.

The fact that the number of women admitted to church-run training institutes such as the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) Communication and Training Centre is not on the rise but dwindling, is in itself a strong enough arguement. 

Talking to APS on February 28, the Centre's Communication Consultant Mr. Polycap Ochilo said the six-month Media Production Course this year admitted five women compared to seven in 1995. The course began on February 15.

"This clearly speaks for itself. The number of women being admitted in the church-run communication centres such as the AACC is dwindling while that of men is on the rise," he pointed out.

He said the 21 participants for this year's media production course have been drawn from Uganda, Ethiopia, Ivory Coast, Angola, Sudan and host Kenya. By the time of going to press, 18 students had already arrived but three were still expected from Tanzania, Ghana and Zaire.

The AACC Communication Consultant said students will be exposed to various modes of communication such as broadcasting techniques, script-writing, photography and news and feature writing for both electronic and print media.

"We also intend to run short courses between September and December, geared towards exposing participants to the role of the media in community participation and development," Mr. Ochilo further told APS.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


308 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Lutheran Churches Challenged On Human Rights


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 6, 1996


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

Moshi, Tanzania - Participants attending the Lutheran World Federation (LWF) Africa Workshop on Human Rights in this northern Tanzanian town from February 19 to 23, have underscored the need for churches in Africa to play a prophetic role and challenge any government or authority which violates human rights.

The workshop, jointly organised by the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Tanzania (ELCT) and the LWF Office for International Affairs and Human Rights, deliberated on issues under the theme, Equal Value- Equal Rights; The Challenge of Ethnic Diversity in Africa. It brought together some 40 participants mainly drawn from LWF member churches. Among Ecumenical organisations represented was the Nairobi-based All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC). 

The Tanzania workshop was part of a series of regional workshops organised by the LWF in its endeavour to equip member churches to be more active in the field of awareness of universal human rights while having a clear understanding of how concern for human rights relates to Christian faith and ecclesiology.

It was convened with the aim to raise awareness of human rights, including civil and political rights as well as social and cultural rights, and the ways in which they relate to the consciousness and practices of local communities.

The forum also sought to increase knowledge about the local, regional and international mechanisms for the protection of human rights and to provide training in the use of these mechanisms in addressing actual human rights cases.

Also included in the objectives of the workshop was the need to increase awareness of democratic structures and processes, with emphasis on people's participation in decision-making, including election procedures.

The theme, Equal Value-Equal Rights; The Challenge of Ethnic Diversity in Africa, was meant to help participants move away from approaching the topic of human rights merely in a theoretical and removed experience. The subject aimed at inviting participants to be active in reflecting on human rights violations as an issue which is nearer home.

The meeting acknowledged that in recent years, many of the problems facing Africa have had to do with ethnic differences between peoples who have lived harmoniously together. The toll of human suffering in ethnic-related conflicts in Burundi, Rwanda, Somalia, Sudan and Liberia, to mention a few cases, cannot be ignored.

The five-day workshop was organised against the background that ethnic reality and identity are not necessarily evil but the misuse of ethnic identity is evil. The workshop worked towards identifying the

fine distinction between the two ethnic features with the hope of helping participants identify human rights violations motivated by ethnicity and seek ways to address these contextual violations.

The workshop chose the theme on ethnicity because the number of conflicts and tensions based on the same has increased dramatically in Africa, and ethnic conflicts, to a much higher degree than conflicts between states, present a tragic record of human rights violations.

At the end of the meeting, participants agreed that since many (ordinary) people are ignorant about their rights, it was crucial for churches to promote human rights awareness especially at grassroots level, and in so doing make the distinction between ethnic diversity and ethnicity and how the former can be used positively to build rather than destroy a society.

They also highlighted the need for churches to conduct seminars and training workshops for staff members so that every member can become an advocate for human rights.

The meeting also recommended that churches work towards the inclusion of human, civic, political, economic and environmental rights in the ordinary school curriculum as well as in theological training centres.

The participants also recommended that churches disseminate information on human rights through public and church media on various societal levels and also produce and distribute reading materials on human rights. This information should be translated into local languages, alternatively, education can be conducted through drama groups and audio-visual aids.

The Moshi meeting also underscored the need for churches to develop or strengthen specific ministries in hospitals, prisons and refugee camps among other vulnerable communities where they (churches) should also provide counselling on human rights, facilitate or organise small group discussions, eventually becoming a resource centre for human rights.

On the family level, churches were called upon to promote the rights of women and children in family, society and the church by conducting workshops, and seminars on women's and children's rights and carrying out research and case studies on the meaning of marriage and the role of the family in Africa.

Regarding ecumenical networking, the human rights workshop underlined the need for churches to form ecumenical networks and cooperate with other organisations.

Apart from working with other churches through national councils, the workshop also emphasised the need for Lutheran churches in Africa to develop a regional network in collaboration with and facilitated by the LWF. Similar networking through the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) human rights desk was also proposed.

Member churches of the LWF represented at the Moshi meeting included among others, the Lutheran Church of Christ in Nigeria, the Lutheran Church in Liberia, the Ethiopian Evangelical Lutheran Church Mekane Yesus, Moravian Church in Southern Africa and the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Zaire.

The Lutheran World Federation is a communion of Lutheran churches all over the world. Founded in Lund, Sweden, in 1947, the LWF currently has 122 member churches representing over 54 million of the world's 56 million Lutherans. In Africa LWF has 25 member churches with a total 7.5 million faithfuls..

The LWF acts on behalf of its member churches in areas of common interest such as human rights, theology, humanitarian assistance, communication, and the various aspects of mission and development work.

In response to a basic Christian concern, the LWF monitors human rights abuses around the world closely and in consultation with its member churches, makes representation on behalf of individuals and groups whose rights and dignity are violated.

The LWF peace fund has enabled progress to be made in encouraging peace efforts in such volatile areas as Central America and the Middle East. Member churches are assisted in establishing offices for human rights and peace efforts. In addition, pastoral delegations, staff visits and consultations contribute to a global ecumenical ministry for justice and peace.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


309 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Church Meeting Set On The African Child


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 6, 1996


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Nairobi - Zimbabwe will be the venue for a week-long church-sponsored consultation on the African child.

The March 10 to 17 event in the capital, Harare is being sponsored by the Association of Evangelicals in Africa (AEA) in partnership with the World Vision International, Compassion International and the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC).

The consultation will deliberate on the theme, Generation at Risk: What Future. Some 100 participants drawn from children organisations and agencies in Africa are expected to attend. 

The topics to be discussed will include the child in especially difficult circumstances with special emphasis on children of war, education, child growth and development. Other highlights include emphasis on accessibility of medical care and nutrition, social, cultural, economic and political effects on the African child, health and children's rights.

Against the background that problems affecting the African child will not disappear overnight but their effects can be mitigated to ensure that they do not target the children, the meeting hopes to share resources, data and information and urge leaders to prioritize the plight of the African child and put them on the list of agenda for "First Call for Action."

The consultation is also expected to provide a platform for continental networking for all groups with concern for children.

The idea of holding the consultation was mooted in November 1994 during the Pan-African Christian Leaders Assembly (PACLA), held in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi and attended by some 800 Christian leaders.

At the PACLA assembly, the leaders underscored total commitment to the African child for the sake of the future of the continent. AEA was mandated to pursue the vision for the African child through its newly established children commission, the Evangelical Focus on Children (EFOC).

The African Child consultation is a follow-up of PACLA's ten-point plan of action that was spelt out after the conference.

Commenting on the forthcoming meeting, a delegate to the consultation, the Rev. Dr. Setri Nyomi, of the AACC Christian and Family Life Education Department said: "The idea to meet is very central. We look forward to its outcome", he said. On the AACC's commitment to issues pertaining to the African child, the Ghanaian church minister, who also coordinates the AACC's the Selfhood of the Church Unit said his department in close operation with the Women's Desk of the AACC, has already published a book, the Child Survival Study Guide.

Speakers at the Harare meeting will include Zimbabwe's Minister for Health and Child Welfare, Dr. T. Stamp; the AEA General Secretary Dr. Tokunboh Adeyemo; Rev. Phylis Byrd, the AACC Associate General Secretary; Zimbabwean Member of Parliament, Dr. Inonge Lewanika; Dr. Nyomi, and Kenyan woman scholar, Dr. Edda Gachukia, among others.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large New UN Unit To Serve Great Lakes Region


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 6, 1996


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Nairobi - The media will be part of a new information unit formed by the United Nations Department of Humanitarian Affairs to foster greater understanding and awareness of issues in the traumatized Great Lakes Region of Africa.

The unit officially known as the Integrated Regional Information Network (IRIN) also aims at stimulating an "esprit de corps" among the diverse disciplines such as military, political, humanitarian work, law and media which are responding to the complex emergency affecting the Great Lakes.

It also contributes to better informed and more effective humanitarian action, including emergency preparedness of fostering greater awareness and understanding of regional issues. 

Ben Parker, Deputy Coordinator of IRIN observes that the "Great Lakes Region at present, is a traumatized and terrorised part of the world whose tragedies, when not overlooked, are often misunderstood." As such IRIN will attempt to tackle the logistics of information flow through electronic mail where needed and appropriate and also through the use of traditional channels such as satellite, phones and high frequency radio telex.

Other parties to the network will include national authorities, non- governmental organisations (NGOs), United Nations agencies and donors, human rights organisations, political parties, regional Institutions, Academia and the Media.

The Great Lakes Region has recently experienced untold suffering particularly following the genocide in Rwanda in 1994 and the intermittent fighting in Burundi. Hundreds of refugees continue to flee to neighbouring countries such as Tanzania and Zaire, thus creating emergency situations in the surrounding region.

Humanitarian relief and rehabilitation in the Great Lakes would benefit from better management of the information that is already available, and from access to well-presented regional analyses.

The Network will produce public domain reports of UN agencies and peace-keeping operations, NGOs, the Red Cross movement,and the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) and make them available in response to specific enquiries or by subscriptions to mailing lists.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


311 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Clergy Call For Ecumenical Cooperation in Publishing


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service March 6, 1996


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Nairobi - A Catholic bishop here has challenged Christian publishing houses in Africa to co-operate with each other in co-publishing in English and other widely spoken languages on the continent, to enable the rural (majority) people find an avenue through which issues close to them can be articulated.

Addressing Catholic publishers in Africa attending a seminar here from February 12 to 24, Rt. Rev. Bishop Peter Kairo of the Murang'a Catholic Diocese (in Kenya's Central Province region), called upon Christian publishers to think of how they could deploy some of their resources to train writers, editors, and printers among people in the rural areas as a way of not only imparting skills but also sowing seeds of a viable rural press.

The seminar whose theme was Publishing at the Service of Evangelization, was organised by the Paulines Publications, Africa, (Daughters of St. Paul) in Nairobi. It brought together 28 Catholic publishers from 13 countries namely, Ethiopia, Zambia, Malawi, Benin, Ghana, Zimbabwe, Nigeria, Zaire, Congo, Namibia, Tanzania, Uganda and Kenya. 

Bishop Kairo reminded the Catholic publishers that not much has been done in realising the dream of ecumenical publishing and book distribution. "We are still operating within our closets as individual churches. It is disturbing that even our bookshops in most cases remain exclusive domains for Catholic books," he noted.

The Murang'a Diocese Bishop recalled that the First Regional Meeting of Episcopal Commission for Social Communications in English Speaking West Africa held in Ghana, April-May 1973, recommended that apart from co-publishing in English and other widely spoken languages, national Christian publishing houses should also co-operate in giving translation rights of successful books.

Like commercial publishers, Christian publishers mainly produce and distribute publications in cities while the majority of Christians (like the majority of Africa's population) are in rural areas, observed Bishop Kairo. The Catholic bishop noted that this rural bias has some direct bearings on the form and content of the publications, as these tend to focus more on urban issues. "While one realises that there are certain logistical problems of producing publications in rural areas, we have the challenge to change the imbalance that is now in favour of cities," he said.

On the pricing of publications, Bishop Kairo said that while books, magazines, newsletters and other publications have become very expensive because of high input costs, Christian publishers have an obligation to "make very deliberate efforts to make those publications affordable."

He singled out Paulines Publications for their efforts in making reading materials affordable. A case in point is their recent publication, Towards and African Narrative Theology. "I am sure that if this publication had been done by a commercial publisher, the price would have been prohibitive," noted the Murang'a Diocese Bishop.

The 416-page volume, authored by Maryknoll Missionaries Father Joseph Healey and Donald Sybertz, is a summary of Africa's native wisdom in the form of proverbs, myths, riddles, sayings, plays and songs. It sells at Kenya shillings 200 (about US dollars 4).

Paying tribute to those publishers who have realised the need to empower Christians by publishing in local languages, Bishop Kairo said although the need to publish in local languages is sometimes a controversial issue, there is no way any Christian publisher can ignore the fact that African languages are the key to grassroots communications.

"Publishing in local languages does not just make the material more accessible to those who are not highly literate but also enobles languages that have been denigrated even though theircommunication is overwhelming," Bishop Kairo noted.

Participants, whose theme reflected on the Pastoral Exhortation, "The Church in Africa", shared policies, achievements, problems and future plans of their respective publishing houses. With the help of experts, they acknowledged the need to clarify their policies by improving professionalism in publishing, book production and marketing.

The Catholic publishers resolved to help in the evangelization of Africa by publishing materials which answer people's spiritual, moral, cultural, educational and socio-economic needs and committed themselves to promote justice and peace.

The seminar also highlighted the need to encourage local literature and oral culture, saying these could only be achieved if publishers do not isolate themselves.

Participants agreed on the need to form an association, the Association of the Catholic Publishers in Africa (ACPA) which aims at fostering communications and practical cooperation among publishers and with the Church.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
