Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa Mandela's Health: 'An Inspiration To Geriatrics'


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 8, 1996 by Rehana Rossouw


LENGTH: 1427 words


 

Johannesburg - It's hard to regard a man who jets across a continent and back in three days, gets to bed after 1am, then chirps energetically at the media seven hours later, as a geriatric. But at 77 years and seven months, Nelson Mandela is one.

At that age, the degeneration of the body affects all major functions. Yet specialists and doctors consulted by the Mail & Guardian this week about the president's health are in awe of his energy and mental faculties. 

"He's an inspiration to geriatrics all over the world. At an age where many are in retirement homes contemplating their navels, he's not only holding his own nation together but swanning across the globe solving other countries' problems," said a Cape Town physician.

On Monday Mandela's doctors will reveal the results of a three-day battery of tests conducted to dispel rumours of poor health.

Mandela left the Park Lane Clinic on Thursday with a clean bill of health from his physician, Dr Michael Plit. An electrocardiogram had shown his heartbeat to be "textbook perfect", with no signs of coronary artery disease. X-rays indicated his lungs were in excellent condition.

It's difficult for doctors not present at the clinic this week to identify weaknesses in the president's health, but they could provide general pointers to areas of concern.

The most important check this week was of Mandela's cardiovascular system. If it falls outside the expected range he should be treated to reduce the risk of heart failure. Yet the risk of Mandela's suffering a heart attack is low.

Older people are also significantly more likely to develop an irregular heart beat, doctors said. This can result in a stroke. Mandela's ECG would determine whether this is a problem.

"His favourite exercise is walking and all he really needs to do is work up a sweat three times a week through aerobic exercise like walking," said a physician.

The incidence of diabetes does increase among older people, but doctors believe that if Mandela sticks to his sensible diet there is no reason for him to be at risk of contracting the disease.

Because Mandela contracted TB while in prison, his lungs will have been checked this week. He does not smoke, so lung cancer is a low risk, and there is also no cause to worry about emphysema or asthma.

The chances of Mandela having cancer are significantly reduced because of his lifestyle. He has had a prostatectomy, so there is no chance of prostate cancer and, because he is black, the risk of skin cancer is insignificant. He would have been screened for stomach and bowel cancer this week, though.

There are only two recorded cases of black men with Alzheimer's disease in the history of medicine, so Mandela is an unlikely candidate.

"There is very little likelihood he is suffering from senility. The first thing that goes is memory, long before judgment suffers. There is no sign of the president having memory problems. He makes speeches without notes and quotes extensively from previous meetings and incidents in the past," said a physician.

Doctors are concerned about the stressful life Mandela leads, but, commented one, "He does not strike me as a stressed person, although we have seen him come close to losing his temper a few times ... PW Botha was a prime candidate for a stroke because of the way he used to get worked up over everything."

Doctors believe that, unlike other politicians, Mandela is fortunate to have sustained friendships spanning decades. Many powerful men are surrounded by hangers-on basking in their glory but unavailable to support them when they are stressed.

University of Cape Town Professor in Geriatric Medicine Stephen Louw said although Mandela appeared unusually able to dissipate stress, he was concerned about the president's punishing schedule.

"After watching the television programme A Day with the President last year, I felt it was a bit unrealistic to expect so much from him. He flew to Cape Town and back to Johannesburg late at night in one day -- that would be exhausting for most people," Louw said.

His programme should be more tightly controlled, said Louw."He's obviously an immensely conscientious person who believes he must be available when needed. This may be healthy for the nation, but it could be hazardous to his health."

Mandela's Health:

Brain: While the incidence of senility and dementia does increase among older people, doctors say Mandela's public performance shows no sign of either. As a black man, the chances of his contracting Alzheimer's disease are practically non-existent

Stress: Mandela may look troubled here, but doctors say that he handles stress very well

Heart: Mandela's race, non-smoking habits, careful eating, 27-year prison diet and frequent exercise reduce the risk of a heart attack. But doctors will have checked his cholesterol and given him an ECG to see if there are any signs of an irregular heart beat

Weight: Certainly not overweight. He exercises regularly and does not seem to have a sweet tooth

Blood pressure: There is an increasing incidence of high blood pressure among South Africa's black population. If the president's pressure falls outside the expected range of between 150/90 to 160/95, he will need treatment to reduce the risk of heart failure

Ankles: Some observers have noticed a slight swelling of the ankles, which can point to slight heart weakness

Eyesight: Mandela has had one minor operation for blocked tear ducts, the result of working in the Robben Island limestone quarries

Hearing: He shows signs of auditory degeneration, normal at his age

Lungs: Because Mandela contracted TB while in prison, his lungs will certainly have been checked this week. There is no cause to worry about emphysema or asthma because Mandela is capable of walking long distances

Bowel and stomach: The chances of Mandela having cancer are significantly reduced because of his lifestyle. He would have been screened for stomach and bowel cancer this week, though. The other most likely forms of cancer, affecting the skin and prostate, are unlikely because he is black and has had his prostate removed

Bladder: Doctors will have checked uric acid levels for any sign of kidney problems

Muscles: His muscle tone appears to be quite good and he seems strong and agile. There are no indications of some of the usual signs of age, like stumbling or falling often. 'He can probably duck quickly if someone shoots at him,' says a physician

Diary: Too full. If there is any reason to be concerned, it is that he leads a life which would exhaust a 20 year old.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


331 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


ZAMBIA; "The Post" Trio's Indefinite Imprisonment To Be Legally Challenged


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (Windhoek) March 8, 1996


LENGTH: 814 words


 

Windhoek - Sakwiba Sikota, lawyer for two editors of "The Post" newspaper jailed indefinitely by the Speaker of the National Assembly for being in contempt of Parliament, is to challenge his clients' conviction. Sikota said that the procedures used by Speaker Dr Robinson Nabulyato to order the arrest of, and to pass sentence on, editor-in-chief Fred M'membe and managing editor Bright Mwape have no backing under the law. His challenge is to be heard on 12 March under a writ of habeas corpus. M'membe and Mwape handed themselves in on 4 March and are currently being held in maximum security jails, while columnist Lucy Sichone is still at large.

Sikota stated that under the writ of habeas corpus application, Parliament will be required to justify on what law or authority it is holding M'membe and Mwape in prison. Sikota also said that if the court is not satisfied with the reasons given, it will order the journalists' immediate release. M'membe and Mwape are expected to be present during the proceedings next week, Sikota said. 

Sikota added that, in terms of Section 27 of National Assembly Powers and Privileges Act enacted on 28 September 1956 by the Federal Parliament of the then colonial Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, "no prosecution shall be instituted for an offence under this act." Sikota, therefore, argued that the sentence passed by Nabulyato was not provided for in the 1956 Act. He further explained that once Parliament had found someone in contempt, the matter should be handed over to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP). It was the DPP's duty, and not that of Parliament, to prosecute, said Sikota.

In an interview with the Namibian Broadcasting Corporation (NBC), Sikota said his clients had never been put on trial, and that they were found "guilty" by Parliament in absentia. "This is totally against all the rules of natural justice. Everyone is entitled to be tried by an impartial tribunal," said Sikota. In the case of the trio, Sikota said that Nabulyato and Vice-President Godfrey Miyanda "played the part of accusers, prosecutors, judge and jury." Miyanda himself raised the contempt issue when "The Post" trio wrote about his criticism of a Supreme Court ruling that legislation requiring police permission for the holding of demonstrations was unconstitutional.

Sikota was confident the courts would order the release of his clients on constitutional grounds. The case has brought about a "mini-constitutional crisis," said Sikota. "The courts will have to overrule the National Assembly, as the National Assembly has obviously gone way beyond its bounds." He added: "Once a court rules that they (Mwape and M'membe) are being held illegally, the prison authorities will have to release them."

Speaking on Sichone's decision not to hand herself in, Sikota further told the NBC: "Sichone's position is that she cannot be party to what she clearly sees as an illegal act, and answer to a warrant (for her arrest) with no constitutional backing." He explained that Sichone has a three-month-old baby and so she was not willing to subject the baby to the "terrible conditions" found in Zambia's prisons, where cholera is prevalent this time of year.

Meanwhile, Home Affairs Minister Chitalu Sampa says M'membe and Mwape "should be treated like ordinary criminals" while in jail, according to the state-owned "Times of Zambia". Sampa reportedly made the remarks after he was asked by "The Post"'s lawyers to give preferential treatment to the imprisoned editors. "A prisoner is a prisoner and there is no special treatment," Sampa is reported as saying. He added that M'membe and Mwape were not political prisoners.

BACKGROUND: The three had been lying low since they were found guilty by Speaker Nabulyato of being in contempt of Parliament. On 27 February, Nabulyato sentenced the three to indefinite imprisonment under the Protection of Parliamentary Privileges Act, legislation dating back to British colonial rule. On 29 February, police offered a reward of Kwacha 2 million (US$ 2000) for information leading to the arrest of the three.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Ghana Three Journalists Released on Bail; Case Forwarded to Supreme Court


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (New York) March 8, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

New York - In a brief hearing on 23 February 1996, Circuit Court Judge Nuhu Bila granted bail in the amount of 6 million cedis (US$ 4,000) for journalists Nana Kofi Coomson, editor-in-chief of "The Ghanaian Chronicle", Eben Quarcoo, editor of weekly "The Free Press", and Tommy Thompson, publisher of "The Free Press". The three journalists posted sureties and were unconditionally released. 

Judge Bila also announced that he was referring the constitutional issues of the case to the Supreme Court. The case is to be adjourned indefinitely until the Supreme Court renders a decision.

Dr. Ofosu-Amah, counsel for the defendants, stated that the issues to be addressed in the near future will include: the viability of old laws and their enforcement under the country's new constitution; an examination of existing Supreme Court laws and to what extent they are media friendly; and a plan to highlight the laws that are believed to be unconstitutional with regard to freedom of expression.

BACKGROUND: Coomson, Quarcoo, and Thompson were charged with "publishing false news with the intent of injuring the reputation of the State," a violation of Section 185 of the Criminal Code of 1960, an ordinance of the colonial era. Both "The Free Press" and "The Ghanaian Chronicle" reprinted in their 31 January and 1 February editions, respectively, a story published in the New York-based bi-weekly "The African Observer" reporting that Ghanaian diplomat Frank Benneh, of the Ghanaian Permanent Mission to the United Nations in Geneva, had been arrested in Switzerland for selling drugs. The article also alleged that the government of President Jerry Rawlings had used proceeds from illegal drug sales to buy arms.


LOAD-DATE: March 9, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Update on Ebola Haemorrhagic Fever in Gabon


BYLINE: World Health Organization February 29, 1996


LENGTH: 625 words


 

Geneva - As of 27 February, 24 cases of which 17 were fatal had been reported. 

Control measures instituted in Gabon by the Ministry of Health and an
international medical team appear to be containing the further spread.
However, sporadic secondary cases can still be expected.

Teams sent to investigate rumours of cases in Djoum on the border between Gabon and Cameroon did not find any case of suspect Ebola haemorrhagic fever.
Another team was sent from Brazzaville on 26 February to villages in northern part of Congo for a similar inquiry.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Golf: 200 To Participate In ZGU/ZAF Tourney


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 1, 1996 by Jeff Kapembwa


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - More than 200 golfers take to the courses in the Zambia Golf Union (ZGU) and ZAF golfing events which tee off in Lusaka and Kitwe this weekend.

Insurmountable scratch handicap, Kelvin Phiri, will put to test his skills when he defends his title during the ZGU Nkana open on Sunday, Barry Siwale stakes his pride in the ZAF day invitation tomorrow. Chainama Golf club will host the ZGU B division event on Sunday.

Phiri who will lead a pack of 93 golfers during the 36-hole event will face tough opposition from veterans and one time professionals, Peter Armstrong of Lusaka and Geoffrey Chishiba of Ndola.

Armstrong is the title holder of the Independence Cup he won last year at the same club in Kitwe.

Other notables expected to "stake bets" with Phiri are Luanshya's Patwell Sikelo, Martin Banda of Chainama, plus one handicap Muhammed Zulu, The Seno brothers, Oliver and Anthony, Frazier Siwale and Aaron Simfukwe of Ndola Golf club.

Phiri who was crowned Southern Zone order of merit and is the champion for the Parker Cup is however undaunted by the challenges and is hopeful he will retain the mantle.

"I have been preparing for the championship for some time".

Chainama will this weekend be a haven of golf when ZAF hosts its annual 18-hole invitation tournament in which more than 40 golfers are expected to test their supremacy.

Chainama will host ZGU B division championship on Sunday in which six handicap Bruce Chinungi will need to show upstarts the rudiments of the sport.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Business Zambia A 'Key African Territory'


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 1, 1996 by Sipo Kapumba


LENGTH: 214 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia has been described as a "key African territory" in Standard Chartered Bank PLC's operations in Africa, a top bank official said in London on Wednesday.

Standard Chartered group chief executive, Malcom Williamson, said in a press release yesterday when he announced the group's record pre-tax profit of 661 million (K1.2 trillion), for 1995, up 30 per cent from 1994. 

"Focus for investment in Africa will be in Kenya, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Botswana and Ghana to improve service and product delivery in these key African territories," Williamson said.

Profits before tax in the bank's African operations increased by 35 per cent over 1994, he said.

Williamson said strategies announced last year to develop franchises in Asia, Africa and the Middle East had paid off as shown in the record profit.

As a result of its strong showing, the share price on the London Stock Exchange rose from 280 pence to 548 pence between January and December.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


336 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Government To Proceed With Voters' Roll


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 1, 1996 by Reuben Phiri and Jeff Kapembwa


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - Government does not necessarily have to reach the 4.6m eligible voters target and will go ahead and prepare a voters' roll without it, an official has said.

Public liaison officer at elections office, Joel Sikazwe, said in an interview yesterday that the exercise would not be extended. 

"It's not numbers that matter although the extensions were done due to the outcry from interested parties. This time nobody is advocating an extension," Sikazwe said, and added: "The figures we have are merely target figures but if we fail to achieve them we shall go ahead and prepare the voters' roll."

Sikazwe was reacting to calls to extend the voters' registration exercise which ends today.

Foundation for Democratic Process (FODEP) president, Reverend Foston Sakala, made the appeal on Tuesday during ZNBC's radio programme Tell the Nation .

"If we score less than 50 per cent at the end of the exercise, then the government will have no chance but to allow the exercise to go on until we reach at least 50 per cent of the figure of eligible voters," Sakala said.

He said government should only consider closing the exercise after 60 per cent was recorded.

The exercise which started in December last year has already been extended twice but has registered only 1.6m of the eligible 4.6m voters by February 9.

By last week, government claimed 2.1 million people had registered.

But Nikuv computers project manager, Gershon Korda, said his company is willing to continue with the exercise if they are asked to do so.

"We are ready to continue with the voters' registration exercise at any time if we are asked to do so by government because they are our employers," Korda said in an interview yesterday.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

337 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Opposition Calls For President To Step Down


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 1, 1996 by Masauso Lungu


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Lusaka - Leader of the opposition Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) has called on President Chiluba to resign from presidency for misgoverning the nation.

ZDC president, Dean Mung'omba, also asked donors to impose sanctions on Chiluba's government before the country falls into a major disaster.

He made the call yesterday at a press briefing where he listed many ills affecting the nation. 

Mung'omba said his party has considered the crisis facing the nation and is convinced that unless immediate and concrete steps are taken to remedy the situation the country will meet a major disaster.

"We are calling upon President Chiluba, for once, to heed the nation's lament and step down as head of state to allow the creation of a transitional government to supervise matters of the state, particularly the forthcoming national elections," Mung'omba said.

Mung'omba appealed to the donor community to impose sanctions on the Chiluba government to facilitate his resignation as President.

"We call upon the friends of Zambia, particularly our co-operating partners to censure and put sanctions on this regime that has, without restraint, continued to misgovern our country and is driving our people towards confrontation," he said.

Mung'omba accused the MMD government of having failed to conduct the voters' registration which he described as a disaster.

"After 30 years of independence, and in a democracy, one would have thought the voters' registration exercise and the preparation for elections would be the easiest, but we fear violence may erupt if the whole process is not reviewed, and made transparent particularly the stakeholders," Mung'omba said.

The ZDC president also said his party is committed to good governance and performance but will not obey unjust laws.

"We shall not obey unjust laws such as the amendments made to the Public Order Act," he said.

He said the amendment of the Public Order Act is gross contempt of the judiciary and makes the mockery of this democracy.

"ZDC will seek redress in the courts of law against this parliamentary treachery, and we call upon the people of Zambia to continue enjoying their rights as provided for in our constitution," Mung'omba said.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Securities Exchange And Central Bank Hold Talks


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 1, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Lusaka - The Securities Exchange Commission is holding talks with the Central Bank on possibilities of phasing out the high yielding 28-day treasury bills in a bid to attract institutional investors participation on the Lusaka Stock Exchange (SEC).

SEC chief executive, Mumba Kapumpa disclosed in an interview yesterday that the move was prompted by the limited participation of institutional investors at LuSE who had opted to invest in treasury bills for quick returns.

"We are discussing with Bank of Zambia on the possibilities of phasing out the twenty eight day treasury bills or increasing interest rates on the 180 day bills," Kapumpa disclosed explaining that: "Most institutional investors have opted to put their money in the former and avoiding participation on the Lusaka Stock Exchange hence the little activity," Kapumpa disclosed. 

SEC and the LuSE held meetings with the financial institutions and pension funds to encourage their participation on the capital markets.

"The meeting was very successful and the institutions have shown commitment and in addition to that next month we will be holding a seminar for managers in these institutions," Kapumpa said.

Among those who attended the meeting were Zambia National Provident Fund, Civil service Pensions Board, Mukuba Pensions board and the central bank governor, Jacob Mwanza.

Also commenting on the meeting LuSE general manger, Charles Mate echoed Kapumpa's call on financial institution's participation on the capital markets.

"Institutional investors have a critical role to play in capital market development especially at a time that investment opportunities have been limited. What we are trying to tell them is that the creation of the stock market plus these institutions' participation opens up these investment opportunities," Mate said .

Meanwhile, Zambia Privatisation Trust Fund manager, Thomas Ryan has disclosed that the floatation of the remaining 10 per cent Zambia Breweries shares to the public has been rescheduled to next year because of the current poor prices of shares on the LuSE.

Ryan was speaking during a Zambia Privatisation Agency Forum.

"We hope to float the shares on the Lusaka Stock Exchange next year unlike the earlier announced second quarter of this year due to the poor performance of shares on the stock market," Ryan said adding: "The shares will remain in the trust fund hands until our trustees view a rise in demand and price."


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Soccer: Players, Clubs Get Warning On Procedures


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 1, 1996 by Samsom Mujuda


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Lusaka - All Players heading for professional careers outside the country will be dealt with if the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) does not sanction their trips.

Association general secretary, Hermann Mpashi, who sounded the warning at a press brief yesterday , also warned of tough measures against local clubs not following the laid down regulations in getting players from other teams. 

"Clubs and players are given a timely warning that the executive committee shall severely punish clubs and players not complying with the standard procedures," Mpashi said.

He added that it is a FIFA requirement that players going out of the country for trials must clear with the football association in advance.

Zambia's 1995 Footballer of the Year, Dennis Lota , hardman Mordon Malitoli, Jones Mwewa and Tenant Chilumba, all went out without the knowledge of the FAZ, while Power Dynamos want to start talks with Lusaka Dynamos on defender Ronald Mukoshya after they got the player almost a month ago.

But Mpashi, was however careful not to say he was talking of the conduct of Power Dynamos and instead generalised the issue.

He also said at the moment there is no agent recognised in Zambia.

"If one wants to act as a FIFA agent he should first of all apply to the Football Association of Zambia. At the moment there is no Zambian recognised agent," he said.

LANGUAGE: English

March, 1996


Arts, Culture and Entertainment Nkoma To Release Eight Track 'Demo' Album


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 1, 1996 by Samson Mujuda


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - After years of struggling, Martin Nkoma alias Jah Luther, has finally popped out a make-up studio with an eight track demonstration album, "Fire".

Nkoma hopes to use this demo to blow his own trumpet because in the past he has just held live shows. The rhythm is all reggae. 

"I have completed my demo tape and it has eight tracks. I am going to use this demo for my publicity. I have already taken it to the radio," said Jah Luther in his assumed Jamaican patois.

He hopes to splash his sweet raggae music on the market by March this year.

The songs on the demo include the title track "Fire", the pumping "Children Play", the bass-powered "Mother Africa", the silky smooth "Uncle", the moody "Mighty Messenger", the emotive" HIV" and the laid back "Chibusa".

Luther explains the lyrics of "Fire " thus: "In Fire I try to talk about life as being a flame of life, you see. Life is like a flame. We are burning, living, you see."

Luther was backed by the rhythm and blues band, Echo Heart to produce Fire.

"Man I recorded Fire using a four track recorder and I also recorded it using my friend's equipment in Lusaka's Roma," Luther says.

Luther who is also Zambia Union of Musicians ( ZUM ) music resource center manger at Evelyn Hone College said they are working out a way of coming up with a small time studio for the musicians who use the center to be able to come out with demo albums.

"We are going to be using a four track recorder, a key board, a rhythm composer and the equipment that we have here. At least that will help the young musicians to come up with demo tapes instead of just rehearsing for live shows," he said.

March, 1996


Africa-at-Large Soccer: Local Matches To Be Transmitted In Europe


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 1, 1996 by Samson Mujuda


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - A British communications firm has offered the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) a contract in which it will be beaming live all local league, cup and international matches to Europe and the rest of Africa.

Communications Services International (CSI) wants to have the sole right to transmit all local premiership, cup matches and matches involving both the senior and junior national teams and has offered FAZ a reasonable amount for the deal. But the cash FAZ will reap will depend on the response from viewers.

CSI executive Barry Lambert , currently in the country, confirmed he has had talks with FAZ and hinted that if all goes well his organisation will sign the contract for television coverage.

"CSI is delighted to announce that it will soon be signing a contract for television coverage to Zambia and internationally with FAZ".

"We are going to provide coverage to the Super Division and Cup games. CSI is a reputable television company," Lambert said.

And FAZ chairman, Michael Chiti, said the contract once signed would bring revenue to the association through television rights and expose players to the European market.

"We will start selling players to European clubs and not countries like Saudi Arabia," Chiti said.

South Africa is a beneficiary of CSI but Zambia will be the first country in Southern Africa to benefit through the arrangement of the contract.

Meanwhile FAZ treasurer, Musa Kasonka, has denied his association is involved in double dealings with Blue Orchid and KAM.

"The fact that Blue Orchid are our agents does not stop other agents from dealing with us directly".


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996

Africa News


March, 1996


Zambia Mpezeni's Call Timely (Column)


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) March 1, 1996


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Lusaka - Does President Chiluba, as head of state need an invitation to attend?

The call by Mpezeni, the paramount chief of the Ngoni of Eastern province, to keep politics out of traditional ceremonies was timely. 

It was good advice to the members of the opposition UNIP, and probably Liberal Progressive Front, who are trying to make political capital out of the fact that President Fredrick Chiluba was not invited to the ceremony, he had 'invited' himself.

This is cheap politics. Does President Chiluba, as head of state, and indeed a Zambian citizen, need an invitation to attend such a public gathering of the Ngoni people?

We appreciate it is impossible for the President to attend such a ceremony 'incognito' but that should not stop him from doing so. And if an invitation was necessary why wasn't he invited anyway? After all, President Chiluba's wife Vera, comes from Eastern province. The President is a son of Eastern province. And this should also be a good lesson for President Chiluba and his ruling MMD officials that it does not pay to politicise ceremonies or funerals in areas where they may be popular themselves. They are also guilty of this same vice.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
