Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa The 'Third Force' Beast Goes Belly-Up


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 1,1996 by Ann Eveleth


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

Johannesburg - History will also be in the dock when the multiple murder trial of former defence minister Magnus Malan and 19 other security force officers gets under way next week.

As it starts under the grey stone pillars of Durban's Supreme Court on Monday morning, the legal floodlights will turn on to the murky genesis of the "third force" and how the security forces helped create the myth of "black-on-black" political violence.

A new charge added to the indictment this week suggests a conspiracy far beyond the gruesome 1987 murder of 13 innocent civilians in KwaMakhutha with which they were originally charged.

The alternative count of conspiracy "to wrongfully and intentionally kill members of the ANC, UDF (United Democratic Front) and related organisations" broadens the initial charges of murder, attempted murder and conspiracy to murder to the murder of UDF activist Victor Ntuli. 

It places back-room schemes of the shadowy State Security Council squarely on the centre stage of the carnage which has by now claimed at least 20 000 lives.

The foul winds of the "ethnic" brew the security forces allegedly stirred still blow in the province more than a decade after Inkatha Freedom Party leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi allegedly detailed his security "requirements" to then Military Intelligence head Tienie Groenewald.

But, as the men who allegedly responded to that request for security stand trial in a courtroom that will probably be packed with many of the "terrorists" they once targeted, the opportunity is there for them to finally clear the air.

Ironically, the trial is likely to increase tensions in the province as political parties use it to score propoganda points in advance of the local government elections due in May.

The IFP will use the trial to mobilise its mainly rural constituents again in a campaign that paints the party as the victim of an ANC conspiracy. The ANC will use it to portray the IFP and the National Party as the aggressors of war -- vital in its bid to win over Indian and white voters in the province.

With a court transcript that promises to read like a who's who of apartheid state-sponsored violence, the world will be watching the proceedings. Even ordinary civilians may find themselves under the glare of the public spotlight as the witnesses -- ranging from alleged co-conspirators to others listed as being from "Autopage cellular" and "Radiospoor" -- take the stand.

Unfortunately, it will be standing room only outside the court, with 65 spectators -- including 20 journalists -- allowed into the public gallery. Even the seven defence teams will have a tight squeeze after extra space was taken up to expand the dock for the 20 accused.

Watching the proceedings in-tensely will be the Investigation Task Unit (ITU), which faces its first crucial test more than a year after it began probing KwaZulu-Natal hit squads. Mired in unwanted political controversy throughout its existence, the team -- led by its indomitable director, Frank Dutton -- has achieved what previous commissions could only dream of: getting to the belly of the proverbial beast.

If the unit's allegations are validated, it will be a milestone in South Africa's legal history.

For Dutton -- whose successes in solving the Trust Feeds massacre, which sent killer policeman Brian Mitchell and others to prison, and on the Goldstone Commission placed him under the glare of public ridicule years ago -- a conviction will be a personal vindication for the course he has chosen.

The short walk to the Durban Supreme Court down Salmon Grove's single block in the old section of Durban adjacent to the bay is a stark contrast to the long road Dutton and his team have travelled to get there.

From the constant condemnation of the IFP to the indignant outcry of the right wing when Malan and others were arrested, the ITU has battled on, gradually piecing together one of the most astonishing chapters of South Africa's sordid past.

Monday morning will be the beginning of the end of that chapter. The trial will feature a battle of legal giants as the prosecution advocate, KwaZulu-Natal Attorney General Tim McNally, squares off against the chief defence advocate, former Witwatersrand attorney general Klaus von Lieres, and six other advocates. It is set down for three months, but could take more than a year.

The case will cost the taxpayer millions of rands as the Defence Ministry has said it will pay the costs of former and serving members who are on trial. It is still unclear who will foot the bill for the airfares and accommodation for the accused, most of whom live outside KwaZulu-Natal.

The Mail & Guardian disclosed last November that key witness, Major JP Opperman, has been under witness protection in Europe with his family. He will have to be flown in for the trial. Opperman will tell the court that he was at the heart of Operation Marion, the covert state plan to train a paramilitary unit for the IFP.

He will be giving evidence against his former defence force bosses, and may say he decided to own up after reading a press interview with former political commissar for Inkatha's paramilitary forces, Daluxolo Luthuli. At the time, Luthuli told a reporter from the M&G that he had personally been in charge of a 300-strong hit squad which operated out of Ulundi.

Andre Cloete, another former permanent force member, will also give evidence against his former leaders.

Their testimony, together with that of Luthuli and dozens of other witnesses, as well as stacks of documentation seized from Military Intelligence, is expected to put pressure on a number of other politicians also believed to have facilitated the birth of the "third force".

Mangosuthu Buthelezi's name -- which featured in the original indictment and again in this week's supplementary indictment -- will resonate throughout the trial.

Deputy President FW de Klerk, who has announced his intention to make submissions to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission on behalf of the NP, will also have his ears glued to the testimony in anticipation of his submission.

Those in the dock, however, will have little recourse to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission at this stage. While they could ask for a stay of proceedings to apply for amnesty, McNally, the judge and the Amnesty Committee will have to agree to hand the case over to the commission -- and even then, the nature of the alleged crimes may preclude amnesty.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996

Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa Mandela Rallies Support For New Weapons Laws


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 1, 1996 by Marion Edmunds


LENGTH: 467 words


 

Johannesburg - President Nelson Mandela has been personally lobbying political parties for support on new legislation to crack down on the causes of violence in Kwazulu-Natal.

This was confirmed by the president's spokesman Parks Mankahlana, who said the president was eager to close the loopholes in certain laws which made it possible to carry dangerous weapons in potentially explosive situations.

This follows three weeks after Mandela, in his speech at the opening of Parliament, mourned the extent of the violence in KwaZulu-Natal, and said that measures would be introduced to ban the carrying of dangerous weapons during public demonstrations. 

Mankahlana said the talks, held separately with each political party in Parliament, were in anticipation of draft legislation which would come from the justice and safety and security departments.

He said the legislation would not introduce a direct ban on all weapons, but merely try to control the carrying of them under certain circumstances.

Mankahlana said Mandela had been meeting IFP leader Dr Mangosuthu Buthelezi continuously to discuss the violence in Kwazulu-Natal, but would not say whether Buthelezi had given Mandela support for the proposed new legislation.

The carrying of dangerous and cultural weapons has been a bone of contention between political parties since the negotiations over the transition from apartheid rule to democracy. The Inkatha Freedom Party could not be contacted for comment by the time of going to press.

Meanwhile, the Democratic Party has given its unequivocal support to the measures, on the condition that new laws are implemented in an unpartisan way.

DP leader Tony Leon said Mandela had promised that the measures would not be used as a "club with which to beat Inkatha on the head". Leon said Mandela had promised that ANC members who had transgressed the law would also be brought to book.

Sources in the Freedom Front said General Constand Viljoen was reserving his position on the proposals at this stage.

The National Party said they had given their support to Mandela on the principle of the legislation and would discuss the details in Cabinet.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


360 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1996


South Africa Lawyer Here To Prepare Case Against Chemical Firm


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) March 1, 1996 by Eddie Koch


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Johannesburg - English lawyer Richard Meeran arrived in South Africa this week to prepare a multi-million-rand lawsuit in the British courts against Thor Chemicals for damages suffered by 20 workers, exposed to high levels of mercury toxins, at the multinational's subsidiary in KwaZulu-Natal.

The case is a landmark one because it is poised to help ensure that British companies operating in South Africa and other developing countries are forced to apply the same strict health and safety standards, which apply in their home country, to subsidiary operations in the Third World.

The opportunity to sue in British courts arose when the House of Lords, the highest court of appeal in England, this month refused to entertain an appeal by Thor for the litigation to be heard in South Africa where the health and safety legislation is less advanced than in Britain.

Meeran originally sued the parent company in mid-1994 on behalf of three workers whose health was seriously damaged after being exposed to high levels of mercury at a Thor plant in Cato Ridge that was importing toxic waste from the United States and other countries, which refused to process the material because of its dangers. 

Two of the workers, Peter Cele and Engelbert Ngcobo, died while the third victim, Albert Dlamini, is permanently disabled at the age of 28.

It was this case Thor appealed against, arguing South African courts were the most appropriate forum for it to be heard. The House of Lords's rejection of that appeal this month cleared the way for South African victims of Thor to litigate in England.

The milestone decision encouraged Meeran to come to South Africa and prepare a case for another 17 workers whose health was seriously impaired, allegedly by chronic exposure to mercury toxins at the Cato Ridge plant.

He is currently collecting information to quantify the extent of the claims these workers will bring against the company.

An official commission of inquiry has been appointed by President Nelson Mandela to probe why the previous government allowed Thor to bring such dangerous waste into the country -- and the company has since been forced to shut down its mercury recycling plant.

Meeran believes civil claims lodged in England by the victims of British subsidiaries will help force multinationals operating in the Third World to abide by the same health and safety standards that apply in their home country.

He has gathered evidence which shows Thor moved part of its British plant to South Africa in the 1980s after that country's health and safety executive, which monitors health standards in local firms, expressed concern about the high levels of mercury in blood and urine of workers in England.

Meeran argues the parent company should bear major responsibility for the damage caused to its South African employees because Thor management in England played a strong role in the design of the Cato Ridge factory and moved some of the British plant and its personnel to KwaZulu-Natal.

The lawyer has not completed an assessment of the damage caused to the South African workers through loss of income, pain and suffering but estimates their claim will come to a total of $1-million. The British company has a turnover of about $50-million a year.

Thor management in South Africa argues the health of the first three workers was caused by acute exposure to mercury from an act of sabotage rather than bad company practice at the Cato Ridge plant -- a claim which Meeran says was refuted by Dr Lazlo Magos, an internationally-renowned toxicologist, who examined the victims' medical and work records in preparation for the case and found they suffered chronic exposure over an extended period of time.

The company also refuses to accept the health of the other 17 workers is in any way related to mercury exposure.


LOAD-DATE: March 4, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April, 1996


Ghana Journalists Group Protests Detention


BYLINE: Committee to Protect Journalists (New York) April 30, 1996


LENGTH: 467 words


 

New York - Letter to His Excellency Jerry John Rawlings, President of the Republic of Ghana, The Castle, P. O. Box 1627, Accra, GHANA.

Your Excellency, The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) strongly protests the April 17 detention of Eben Quarcoo, editor of the weekly "The Free Press," and the newspaper's publisher, Tommy Thompson.

On April 17, Quarcoo and Thompson were summoned by the police to answer accusations of violating Section 185 of the 1960 Criminal Code, "publishing falsehoods with the intent of injuring the reputation of the State." They were detained for five hours, interrogated, then released on an exorbitant 10 million cedis (US$ 6,700) bail each. They were never charged. 

The accusation against the pair arose from an April 10 front-page article in "The Free Press" that was culled from an article in the March 14-27 issue of the New York-based, bi-weekly newspaper, the "African Observer."

In reference to outstanding criminal libel charges that Thompson and Quarcoo currently face in Ghana's Supreme Court, "The Free Press" prefaced the article with the disclaimer: "We are publishing (this) story without malice, contempt or prejudice to let Ghanaians know what they are saying about their president elsewhere."

As a nonpartisan group of journalists committed to the defense of its colleagues' rights worldwide, CPJ contends that this latest incident of harassment against "The Free Press," the third in two years, is excessive and misdirected. Having written to Your Excellency earlier this year, we reemphasize our call for an end to the harassment of Ghanaian independent journalists; the elimination of pernicious, anti-press laws, such as Section 185 and criminal libel; and the creation of an environment in which Ghanaian journalists may do their jobs freely and safely. These rights are guaranteed by Article 19 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights and Article 9 of the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights, both to which, we again respectfully remind Your Excellency, Ghana is a signatory.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

Sincerely, William A. Orme, Jr., Executive Director, COMMITTEE TO PROTECT JOURNALISTS. 330 Seventh Avenue, 12th Floor, New York, New York 10001 USA. Phone: (212) 465-1004. Fax: (212) 465-9568. Email: info@cpj.org


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


362 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Sudan Military War Machine Grinding to a Halt in the South


BYLINE: Sudan Democratic Gazette (London) April 30, 1996


LENGTH: 1520 words


 

London - There were indications last month that the National Islamic Front (NIF) war machine in Southern Sudan was grinding to a halt. A renewed offensive by the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) has demoralised the regime's forces. There are rumours of mutiny among the regime's soldiers in the South, surviving on subsistence rations and unpaid for many months. The threat of a war front opening up in Eastern Sudan has posed the regime military problems it could do without. The regime's response has been to play at making cease-fires with Riek Machar's Southern Sudan Independence Movement (SSIM) and to pursue once more the peace initiative of the Intergovernmental Authority for Drought and Development (IGADD). Meanwhile there is the very real threat of comprehensive sanctions likely to be imposed by the United Nations.

New Front on the Blue Nile 

On 17 March the SPLA announced that it had reopened a war front in the Blue Nile province by capturing the little known but strategically important garrison post of Khor Yabus. The post lies twenty-five miles to the south of Kurmuk, a town which was first captured by the SPLA in 1987, causing blind panic in Khartoum. The town is close to the Rosieres Dam at Damazin, which supplies the electricity to the national capital. The threat in 1987 was considered serious enough for the government of the day to devote all its resources to repelling the invasion of the North by the SPLA. That government was in a considerably better position, economically and politically, than the NIF regime is today. With the capture of Khor Yabus and the destruction of an entire battalion there, the SPLA has sent a serious warning to Khartoum. At the time of going to press, the SPLA has just been reported to have captured two more garrison towns in Upper Nile province, Pachalla and Maban Fashala in Southeastern Upper Nile; and Shalifil in the Blue Nile Province.

The SPLA operations in Southern Blue Nile are under the overall command of a local man, Commander Malik Agar. He is also the SPLA's administrative governor for the area. His tactics are based upon his detailed personal knowledge of the local terrain. The field command of the SPLA forces is being managed by Commander John Kong Nyuon.

By opening up the front in Southern Blue Nile the SPLA has demonstrated its control of the border areas in Southern Sudan and its ability to return to areas that it had to evacuate in 1991 following the aftermath of the fall of the Mengistu regime in Ethiopia and schism within the movement at Nasir in August of that year.

Rumours of Mutiny

Even before the latest SPLA offensive began, rumours abounded that there was widespread discontent within the regime's army in the South. The effects of the regime's policies, preferring to use the Popular Defence Forces (PDF) rather than the regular army, and the lack of clear objectives in the war, have sapped soldiers' morale. Reports of mutinies were given credence when the army chief of staff in Khartoum visited some units in the South. A battalion based at Liria, on the road between Juba and Torit, was reported to have disobeyed orders to engage the SPLA during February. When allocated ammunition, they fired it into the air and refused to move out. They demanded a personal meeting with the chief of staff, which is why he made the journey South.

One of the mutinying troops' demands is to be transferred back to the North. They had been assured that their tour of duty in the South would only last for six months, yet it has gone on much longer--four and a half years to be exact! Another of their demands is the payment of their salaries which they have not had for five months. They have no money with which to supplement their subsistence rations.

The chief of staff promised that all their demands would be dealt with following his return to Khartoum. Recognising that these were words rather than actions, the troops informed him that they would not be carrying out any duties until their demands had been fulfilled.

Other rumours emerging from the South have spoken of army units seriously considering switching allegiance and of joining forces with the SPLA. The garrison at Yirol, in Bahr El Ghazal, under its commander Lieutenant Colonel El Sheikh Mahmoud Abushara, is reported to have already turned itself over to the SPLA.

Cease-fire with Machar

In an apparent attempt to reduce its commitments in the South, and to encourage the SPLA to halt its offensive, the regime and Riek Machar's Southern Sudan Independence Movement (SSIM) both unilaterally declared cease-fires. Not surprisingly, these announcements for cease-fires were not taken too seriously by observers because it is well known that there has never been any serious fighting between Machar's forces and those of the regime. In 1992, Machar claimed to have attacked Malakal, but that turned out to be the work of a Nuer spiritual leader, Wurnyang. When the regime's forces moved in 1994 to recapture Machar's headquarters at Nasir, the town was taken without any battle.

To all intents and purposes, it seemed that the regime's intention was to goad the SPLA into agreeing to a cease-fire. Previously, the SPLA has always gone along with these unilateral temporary cease-fires because to do otherwise would have been to appear to be against a peaceful settlement of the conflict. However, that was at a time when the international community took the regime's protestations of peace at face value. That is no longer the case. The regime has been condemned internationally and its delaying tactics are now well known.

Returning to IGADD

The rapprochement with Mr Machar was one side of a twin policy pursued by the Khartoum regime. The other involved the reactivation of the IGADD peace process some two years after the regime walked out on it. Visiting Nigeria and Kenya, Lieutenant General Omer El Behir declared that he wanted peace in Sudan. He informed Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi that he wanted to participate in the IGADD peace process, without conditions, on the basis of the six principles document that the organization had produced.

On 21 March, whilst attending the regular meeting of the IGADD heads of state in Nairobi, El Beshir gave the impression that the whole meeting had been arranged to discuss the Sudanese peace process. He also gave the impression that the summit was designed to reconcile him with his political neighbours in the IGADD organisation. Unfortunately for him, nothing is ever quite what it seems.

Not For Peace

The meeting had nothing to do with the peace process, although peace for the region might have been briefly discussed during the meeting. The meeting was essentially an organisational one which discussed all of IGADD's affairs. It would be too simplistic to believe that a simple hand shake between El Beshir and the Ugandan and Eritrean leaders could undo the enmity and mistrust which exists between the countries.

On a final footnote to the above events, it has been speculated that the regime is considering handing over Upper Nile province to Riek Machar and removing its own army units from the province. Mr Machar would then be given support to pursue his conflict with the SPLA. The reasoning behind such a move would be the regime's ability to relocate the troops from Upper Nile to the expected war front in Eastern Sudan. Just how much truth there is in this story remains to be seen; but Mr Machar and three of his lieutenants were sighted in Khartoum recently.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


363 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Zambia Parliament Opens as Political Parties Hold Big 'Indaba'


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency April 30, 1996 by Lewis Mwanangombe


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambian Parliament this afternoon resumed sittings with little evidence of increased security activity on the National Assembly grounds.

For now the focus of attention was on Mulungushi International Conference Centre, next door, where secretaries of major political parties were still meeting behind tightly closed doors.

These officials are trying to come up with an acceptable agenda on topics which can be discussed by leaders of all political parties now aspiring to take up reigns of government after the coming presidential and parliamentary elections.

The officials, who convened at about 9:30 hours, were still locked up in their meeting at 15:00 hours with information variously coming out to the press that a final communique on deliberations will be released to media people by about 15:30 hours or an hour later. 

In the National Assembly business was expected to be light on this first day but there was no doubt that all three political parties represented in the house are primed to fight to the bitter end for their diverse positions as regards the most burning question - which is the adoption of the draft Mwanakatwe Republican Constitution which should turn into law before the present sitting is out.

Zambia's foremost opposition political party, UNIP, is campaigning vigorously for the adoption of the new constitution by a 'constituent assembly' in the hope that this kind of assembly will push aside the clause which restricts the Zambian Presidency only to citizens whose parents were also Zambians.

For now the clause is seen as a major turnstile in the political path of former State President Kenneth Kaunda whose parents came from Malawi and who himself, for reasons which he has not explained, failed to take up Zambian citizenship until 1970 when his one time childhood and later bitter political foe, Simon Mwansa Kapwepwe, begun to disclose to the nation at large that in fact the President was still a Malawian.

Dr Kaunda has himself repeatedly informed the nation that he is a Zambian and that he intends to stand, 'with or without the new draft constitution.' The Government has politely reminded him that laws are for obeying and those who choose to break them, knowingly or otherwise, are subject to punishment irrespective of their status in society.

Tied to the issue of the new constitution is the holding of next Presidential and Parliamentary elections which some sections of the community would like to see held under the old constitution, 'to humour the oldman' and restore harmony in the land.

But government has made its position clear - and this is that the new constitution will have to be adopted by parliament under this session pointing out that when the clause was petitioned for by those who submitted at the sittings of the Mwanakatwe Constitutional Review Commission, Dr Kaunda was in self imposed retirement and totally out of the picture.

That the 'spike' is hurting him now, is never intentional. This position is accepted by government supporters who are quick to point out that in his time Dr Kaunda brooked no challenge and that was why his party's constitution was literally altered overnight so as to bar the late veteran politicians Harry Mwaanga Nkumbula and Simon Mwansa Kapwepwe and Chiluwe who is now walking the streets of Lusaka a poor and broken man.

On Sunday when Dr Kaunda was asked by a Zambia National Broadcasting Corportaion Television reporter why he had seen it necessary to bar Kapwepwe, Nkumbula and Chiluwe from challenging him, his only responce was that it had not been done by him.

"I never barred anybody from contesting. Ask my colleague (Mainza) Chona, he will tell you more what happened," he said not looking into the camera. Mr Chona is the man seen by most Zambians as the 'fall guy' in the drama which brought in one party rule and its excesses and who when the chips were down was being singled out for vicious condemnation by detractors of the system. He has not complained.

That there is a lot of lively debate ahead of the session which started today is never in doubt. Most people, however, are sure what will go on in parliament will be dictated by the political 'indaba' now convened at Mulungushi Centre and which is expected to climax with the summit of heads of all 'serious-minded' political parties.

Source: ZAMTODAY.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

April, 1996


Zambia Restore House of Chiefs


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency April 27, 1996


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Sinazongwe - Chiefs in Sinazongwe district of southern province have appealed to government to restore their authority through the revival of the house of chiefs for them to participate fully in national development.

The appeal was made through southern province deputy minister Elias Miyanda when he paid a courtesy call on chief Sinazongwe yesterday.

The chief among other things asked government to restore the House of Chiefs, a thing he said was vital and enabled chiefs in the country share knowledge on how to force ahead in development. 

"We want the House of Chiefs very badly because it is an important institution," Chief Sinazongwe has appealed to government.

The chief has also urged government to ensure that food harvested this year was not all sold.

He said Zambia should have food security and reduce dependence on imported food from other countries.

The chief who touched on a wide range of issues also reminded the ruling MMD to ensure local communities chose their own parliamentary candidates through primary elections.

He said should the imposing system continue, then the MMD should have itself to blame for any outcome at the presidential and parliamentary elections.

Chief Sinazongwe slammed at some local politicians whom he accused of interfering with work of civil servants in the district. he said some politicians wanted to take over government workers jobs.

"It seems some party officials here want to take over public workers' jobs and ask them to stop because the workers are trained people. We want development here," Chief Sinazongwe said.

And Mr Miyanda said politicians were not islands and as such should work with the people.

He said it gave him sense of pride to have chiefs who understood issues of national growth.

"Leadership requires tact and understanding. As politicians we must share views with the people and not pushing them around," Mr Miyanda said.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA

Africa News


April, 1996


Business and Finance Union Blames Government For Agriculture Decline


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 29, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia National Farmers Union (ZNFU) last week attributed the near collapse of the country's agricultural sector to the shift in government's priorities.

Speaking at the official opening of the the ZNFU 91 congress last Thursday , ZNFU president Ben Kapita said the drop in the productivity of the sector and the resultant continued "food begging"Jwas a clear indication of the failed agricultural policies and lack of government support for the farming industry.

"It is a well known fact that even trading has received better treatment from our government than agriculture which has become a Cinderella sector," Kapita charged. 

The ZNFU president further called for the maximising of tax incentives in the agricultural sector to enable it meet government's target of five per cent annual growth.

"The major factor restricting growth is limited in finance," Kapita said. "It is therefore imperative to maximise the investment capacity of the sector by minimising input taxes."

Kapita complained that despite the Zero rating on some of the inputs, "the sector is still heavily taxed by both government and now increasingly by the councils".

He further attributed the decline in production to other unattended problems the sector had been encountering such as insufficient debt relief, poor state of rural infrastructure and a failed crop marketing system.

He further challenged the government to explain where funds collected from the fuel and electricity levy were being channelled, as the farmers had not benefitted from such money.

"We want to know where the money is or if at all the funds have been plundered," Kapita said."The Mkushi farming block which was to benefit from the funds still remains in the the dark and the feeder roads are still in an appalling state which begs the question as to how the levy was used."

Reacting to Kapita's sentiments agriculture minister Suresh Desai, in an interview last Thursday, urged the ZNFU president to " adequately research" before critising the government.

Desai explained that incentives had been granted to the sector through the VAT Zero rating of most inputs.

"What Kapita is saying is far from the truth, and I can only say it is because of lack of information on his part," Desai said. " I advise him to research adequately before criticising government efforts."

Desai added: "The government is still committed to the development of the agriculture sector as can be seen by the coming of the ASIP programme although I must admit that it will take long to implement."

But Desai could not disclose which areas had benefitted from the money collected from the fuel and electricity levy.

Desai also disclosed that his ministry was setting up a US$10 million Rural Investment Fund that would be coordinated by the ZNFU executive director, George Grey.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Sports - Olympics Judo: Two Judokas Dropped From Atlanta '96


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 30, 1996 by Brian Malama


LENGTH: 200 words


 

THE Zambia Olympics and Commonwealth Games Association (ZOCAGA) has chopped two judokas from the 13-man team picked to represent Zambia at the "Atlanta 96" games.

"We shall only send six athletes and six amateur boxers in whom we have a lot of confidence," he said, disclosing that the council had also decided to include two more boxers, Victor Kasote and Christopher Mphande. 

ZOCAGA boss, Patrick Chamunda, who announced the decision to drop off the two, Moola Lipile and Hilter Shakanugu, claimed the judo association was not serious with the training for the two judokas.

But the move has angered officials in the Zambia Judo Association who think it was unfair.

"It is not fair for ZOCAGA to just drop the judokas. They are not serious with the Olympics and I wouldn't be surprised if they drop even boxers," moaned a judo official in Lusaka.

April, 1996


Business and Finance Zambia Losing Out On Uneven Trade With South Africa


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 30, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Lusaka - Zambia is losing over US$100 million annually due to un level trading ground with South Africa, disclosed Zambia Association of Manufacturers (ZAM) chairman, Mark O'Donnel in an interview yesterday.

O'Donnell said "lack of seriousness" in balancing trade had cost the country greatly in terms of export earnings.

"South Africa has a lot of protective tariffs in some cases as high as 80-90 per cent," O'Donnell carped. "When you add VAT on the exports, you find that Zambian goods cannot compete with their goods." 

The ZAM chairman said Zambia's exports to South Africa were only R100 million while her imports from the same country were R1.1 billion per annum.

"This imbalance is costing us a lot of money in terms of exports that can't be executed because of high tariffs in that country," he said.

But the ministry of Commerce, Trade and Industry is trying to negotiate a non-reciprocal preferential trade agreement with South Africa and the Southern African Customs Union(SACU) that will secure a market for selected products.

"The purpose of the proposed agreement is to secure market access for a selected range of exportable products from Zambia which have a market potential in the Republic of South Africa and indeed the SACU," said Oliver Sikafweba, director of trade at the commerce, trade and industry ministry, in reply to a Post query, adding: "Zambia exports are at present not in a position to penetrate that market because of high external tariffs of the customs union."

The commerce, trade and industry ministry has since submitted a draft trade agreement to South Africa under which a joint study group will be formed to analyse the list of products submitted by Zambia with a view to arriving at a list that would be agreeable to both sides.

A consultative meeting has been set for August this year, where SACU ministers will meet to discuss among other issues Zambia-SACU Trade Agreement.

But the Export Board of Zambia(EBZ) feels little will come out of the August meeting.

"The conclusion of the trade protocol in August may not be finalised soon because South Africa is dragging its feet on the matter," EBZ executive director, Mwansa Musonda, said in an interview last Friday, adding: "We shall only start benefitting when they remove protective tariffs."

And a source in the South African government disclosed that the Zambian government has been told that it will be very difficult to set new trade terms which will take away the good deals businessmen have negotiated for themselves.

" Your former minister of commerce, Dipak Patel came here and he was told the South African government cannot work to reverse the excessively good incentives its businessmen have gotten for themselves from the Zambian government," the source revealed. " South Africa, unlike Zambia, has sacred cows."

But W.J. Swanepoel, a councillor at South African High Commission in Lusaka says her country labours under a number of constraints at the moment which have slowed it down from taking rapid decisions on bilateral trade agreements and related matters.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April, 1996


Business and Finance Traders Evade Revenue "Duties"


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 30, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Lusaka - The government is losing millions of Kwacha in tax revenue as smuggling of commodities from around the southern African region continues.

But even the marketeers of the imported goods are complaining of loss of business due to high taxes and the Kwacha's decline.

In April 1995, the government introduced Value Added Tax and the Zambia Revenue Authority (ZRA) changed personnel at all points of entry into the country. 

However, the measure does not seem to have helped as problems of smuggling persist, though at a lower level, ZRA claims.

The petty traders, having had their significance ignored by the government, complain that duty on imported products especially goods imported by local traders, is too high.

Outside Luburma Market in Lusaka, an illegal market now commonly referred to as "Zambia-Zaire", has over a thousand 'international' traders who have set up makeshift stalls. Regardless of the crowded conditions, the traders say business is slow.

"The problem with our customs people is that they have no uniform taxes. For the same type of goods and the same amount, your friend will be charged one fee and you another. Nothing is written down as to what people are supposed to pay and such practice leads to dishonesty among traders," said Brian Kapoba, who often imports goods from Zimbabwe.

"People are using trucks and other dubious routes to pass the goods through without a customs check. Then at least all you have to worry about is the depreciation of the Kwacha," he said.

The Zambia Revenue Authority failed to reply to a written query on the matter yesterday but had previously said they had collected more revenue from taxes in 1995 than had ever been recorded.

Estelle Masiwa, from Dar-es-Salaam, said the devaluation of the Kwacha had disappointed a number of Tanzanian and Zimbabwean traders who had incurred huge losses during the last month.

"We don't have a lot of capital and any changes to Kwacha affect us greatly. We calculate the required profit from our goods at the time we start off but by the time we sell our goods here, the Kwacha would have depreciated further and our profit is reduced if at all you get any," she said.

Susan Katembo from Luapula Province said it was now taking longer for her goods to sell as even the customers had reduced in the past two months.

"The dollar is getting more expensive to buy and we find ourselves literally being out of business because we cannot afford to increase our capital. Anyway, we still keep trying to find ways of selling our products because we have to make a living. Even when we collect our goods from TAZARA in Kasama we haggle with the officers otherwise you work for nothing as they charge so much," she said. "If only ZRA could reduce their duty to manageable levels, they might even get more revenue from us. We would be more willing to pay and they would even lessen corruption amongst their ranks."

Lusaka City Council public relations manager, Daniel M'soka, said the council had been trying to work with immigration to flush out illegal trading but nothing had been done so far because there was not enough manpower. Instead, the council has opted to levy the traders a K500 fee sometimes.


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

April, 1996


Zambia Kaunda: No One Will Bar Me From Contesting


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 29, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 227 words


 

Lusaka - Opposition UNIP president, former president of the Republic of Zambia Kenneth Kaunda, yesterday maintained no one is going to bar him from contesting this year's presidential elections.

President Kaunda, who was speaking at his 72nd birthday braii at Lusaka's Dora Tamane Nursery School yesterday, insisted he was a very peaceful freedom fighter. 

"Nothing will stop me from contesting the elections," president Kaunda declared in an interview yesterday.

"The MMD has no powers to stop me and I will only be stopped by the will of Zambians at the elections."

The UNIP leader charged that while he was a peaceful man, the MMD has presented him as a very violent man for fear of losing the elections.

"I fought colonial rule peacefully and I will fight this government peacefully. I am a very peaceful man, I have taken peaceful means of struggle purely on principle," president Kaunda said. " But this government is telling people that Kaunda is violent, which is not true."

April, 1996


Zambia Former President Stabbed


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 30, 1996 by Masautso Phiri


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Lusaka - Former president Kenneth Kaunda was stabbed at Ndola's Mushili township on Sunday April 21 and opposition UNIP has accused President Frederick Chiluba's government for the attack.

UNIP claims the government's denial of the incidence that was not announced or reported by anyone was meant to cover its tracks in case of any fatality.

The UNIP president was attacked by an unknown assailant soon after his Mushili rally. 

"I didn't know I had been attacked until I saw blood on the back of my hand," Kaunda revealed in an interview in Lusaka yesterday. " Soon after I felt a very uncomfortable pain."

Kaunda said he was first treated in Ndola and later in Lusaka. And both local medical specialists said whatever it was Kaunda was lucky it missed the veins on the back of his hand which if they had been affected could have been fatal.

They advised further tests for poisons and treatment in South Africa where the former president was flown last Thursday in a trip only known to his inner circle.

"No-one at Freedom House knew about it. I only knew about it on Thursday just before he flew out. Where did the ministry of Foreign Affairs get its information? Why were they anxious to talk about it? Why do they deny what UNIP did not talk about?" asked the party's administrative secretary Basil Kabwe in an interview yesterday.

But Ministry of Foreign Affairs surprised the party when on Saturday, April 27 it refuted what it termed "rumours in the foreign media that Kaunda was stabbed at a recent rally on the Copperbelt".

"I think they knew about it because they orchestrated it themselves and they are behind the attack," said UNIP vice- president Inyambo Yeta in an interview yesterday.

UNIP insists the party never released any information on the attack which occured after the Ndola rally as Kaunda's convoy was slowly making its way through the crowd and the former president was greeting some supporters. According to Kaunda no one in UNIP issued any statement and while in South Africa he had strict instructions issued "not to speak to the press".

And UNIP central committee member, Rabson Chongo, who last year received a hand written letter warning the former president not to accept to be transported by air to Ndola to face charges of illegal assembly was convinced the attempt was made by a government agent.

"The government has given itself away by lack of concern. It didn't come to UNIP to verify or find out so they can investigate the matter," Chongo said in an interview yesterday.

But Kaunda has now linked the latest incident to previous attempts on his life, including one outlined in the Zambia Intelligence Security Service documents from between Lusaka and its Mansa office published in The Post on June 23 last year. The letter dated May 29, 1995 and addressed to the director of 'B' branch revealed a plan to assassinate Kaunda should he show signs of being re-elected president. And when this letter was later presented in Parliament by Malambo Member of Parliament, Wezi Kaunda, the Speaker waived his immunity and the government threatened to have prosecuted under State Secrets Act.

"I don't know who could have done it but I have now linked it with past threats to my life," Kaunda. "We should be careful not to plan to take life cheaply. We have never planned to take life. It's them who are doing so in a 'Christian' nation."


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April, 1996


Zambia Officials 'Boycott' Gabon Memorial


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 29, 1996 by Masauso Lungu


LENGTH: 400 words


 

Lusaka - Families of the national soccer team players who died in a plane crash off the coast of Gabon yesterday appealed to President Chiluba to release the air disaster report.

Speaking at the memorial service at the burial site Lusaka's Independence Stadium, the families' committee chairman Edmond Mutale, father to the late goal wizard Kelvin, also warned politicians not to make political gain out of the Gabon report.

"Whilst we appreciate all the assistance that has come our way from government, we regret that our government has not been forthcoming and sincere concerning the plane crash," Mutale told the wailing widows. 

"We the bereaved families are compelled with a burning desire to know the contents of the report, even today they are not with us because to them the chapter is closed, and all is well, shame."

Mutale added: "Promises on the release of the report have continued to come from the corridors of power without any fruits at all, it's a shameful thing. We are appealing to you Mr. President with tearful faces to let us know the contents of the report because we are the ultimate losers, and this will erase suspicions haboured by the families concerning the disaster."

Mutale told politicians that anyone trying to make political gain out of the Gabon report will be considered inhuman by the families.

"If these politicians have correct information about the report, why not tell us, instead of using it to achieve their selfish goals," Mutale warned.

The memorial service was attended by UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda and a number of his central committee members.

No government official was present, but MMD national secretary Michael Sata defended government saying they were not invited by the families.

"The service was not organised by government, but the families, and for one to attend such functions, you need an invitation card, we never got any," Sata said.

April, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia: Format Change For Competitions Suggested


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 29, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - City of Lusaka football club has requested the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) and the sponsors of the BP top-eight cup, BP Zambia Limited, to change the format of the competition to save clubs from liquidation.

Chairman, Simataa Simataa, whose club has written to FAZ, BP Zambia and all clubs taking part in this year's BP top-eight competition, pointed out transport costs clubs have to spend during the competition as one reason the sponsors have to change the format. 

"If they can allow the cup to be played on a two-leg system where all clubs play both away and at home to get something from gate takings, and also if they can increase their money involved in the whole cup because as it is now, it does not make any economic sense because clubs overspend in preparations, while some clubs are even knocked out in the first round,"observed Simataa in an interview last week Tuesday.

FAZ general secretary, Hermann Mpashi confirmed getting the letter from City which has also been sent to Mufulira Wanderers, Power Dynamos, Zamsure, Kabwe Warriors, Roan United Konkola Blades and Lusaka Dynamos.

"Yes I have got the letter from City but we are still to sit as FAZ to look at it. I think it will be better if you can wait for sometime," said Mpashi.

In South Africa, the sponsors of the BP top-eight cup settle camping and transport costs for all participating teams which is not the case in Zambia where BP only pays the top four teams after the finals of the competition.

April, 1996


Sports - Soccer Zambia: Association Elections Crisis Looms


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 30, 1996 by Reuben Tonga


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - The Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) elections scheduled for this week may not take place as a constitutional crisis ensues with delegates still in the dark as to as which constitution must be followed.

But some vetoed candidates believe the move to create confusion on the use of the constitution was planned by the interim FAZ executive to prolong its stay at Anchor House. 

"They have decided to veto some of us out of the elections using the 1994 constitution when they know for sure that currently there are constitutional debates going on. In normal cases, FAZ must have known that it is not yet clear as to which constitution the general elections will be based on, we can either use the 1994 one or the one currently under review," said Profund Warriors secretary George Kasengela, whose bid for a sub-committee post was thwarted by the veto.

But FAZ general secretary, Hermann Mpashi, said his association was going to use the 1994 constitution for the elections.

"We will use the 1994 constitution and if there will be any changes in the use of the constitution, we will be directed by the council on Saturday. The elections are surely on, said Mpashi, who explained that should there be any need to use the reviewed constitution, his office will follow what the council will decide.

"People must not think I am making personal decisions , I am just following the 1994 constitution. Who am I to start changing things," wondered Mpashi at a press brief yesterday.

And aspirant for the vice-chairmanship, James Mazumba, who has also been axed by FAZ, is also angered at the turn of events.

LANGUAGE: English

374 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Zambia Constitution Bill 'Blocked' In Court


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 29, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Lusaka - An application was last Friday filed in the Lusaka High Court to stop the government from enacting the Constitution of Zambia (Amendment) Bill number 17 of 1996 into the supreme law of the land.

Opposition Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC), represented by human rights and constitutional lawyer John Sangwa, last Friday applied to the High Court for a judicial review of the government's decision to amend the present constitution.

In the case that will be heard by justice Bobby Bwalya today, ZDC is claiming that what the government is calling an "amendment" is in fact an adoption and enactment of a totally new constitution.

In their application ZDC claims that the decision by President Frederick Chiluba and his cabinet to amend the present Constitution in the manner suggested in the bill "is ultra vires of Article 79 of the Constitution in that it seeks to alter or destroy the basic structure or framework of the present Constitution". 

ZDC claimed that the proposed amendment to the preamble will alter the secular character of the present Constitution hence change its basic structure or feature.

They also pointed out that the proposed amendment bill's Article 91(4) (f) which accords presumptive constitutionality to legislative Acts and stops judiciary inquiry into legislative motives or the regularity of the legislative process "will undermine the idea of judicial review and the concept of separation of powers, checks and balances which are the basic features or structures of the present Constitution".

They also argued that the 'amendment' alters the basic features of the present Constitution by disqualifying persons, who are eligible under the present Constitution, to stand for election as president of the Republic of Zambia.

The proposed amendment in Article 98(5) of the bill is also said to be seeking to alter the basic structure of present Constitution by undermining the independence of judiciary.

ZDC also wants the court to consider an order prohibiting the President Chiluba, his cabinet, or the national assembly from proceeding with the consideration, discussion, debate or the enactment of the bill into law.

"The court will have to define the term amendment because the Constitution of Zambia ( Amendment) Bill seems to be bulkier than the present Constitution," claimed ZDC president, Dean Mung'omba, in an interview yesterday.

The bill has 139 articles whereas the present Constitution has 113.

And the bill seeks to repeal nine out of ten parts of the existing constitution. Only part three of the existing Constitution has not been touched.

It remains to be seen whether parliament will continue with the debate on the bill in view of the fact that it is now in court. Previously, parliament has deferred debate on matters in court describing them as "subjudice".

However, chief government spokesman, information minister Amusaa Mwanamwambwa, said yesterday he could not say much on the matter as it is in court.

"I can only say the government is looking forward to the high court decision if ever the high court will accept such a case. As for stopping debate on this issue, we all know that parliament is the autonomous law-making body," he said.

Opposition National Party spokesman, Sam Chipungu, said the debate on the Constitution bill would never rest until it was decided by a constituent assembly.

"We want to hear what the people submitted to the Mwanakatwe Constitutional Review Commission in parliament and not government views," he said in an interview yesterday.

And UNIP member of parliament, Professor Patrick Mvunga, has also said his party has been studying the issue with the view of taking it to court.

"We, as UNIP, have been looking at the issue with the view of taking it to court because it is now clear that the MMD do not want to listen to people," Professor Mvunga said in an interview yesterday. "But since ZDC is also taking the case to court, we wouldn't mind a joint court action."


LOAD-DATE: May 14, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


375 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


United States and Africa (DOCUMENT) 'Energetic' U.S. Involvement in Liberia


BYLINE: Washington Office on Africa April 29, 1996


LENGTH: 2137 words


 

Washington, D.C. - Letter to President Clinton dated April 26, 1996.

We are writing to join our voice to those of the many Liberians and friends of Liberia who are urging sustained and energetic US involvement in restoring the prospects for peace desired by the vast majority of Liberians.

We applaud your recent decision to allocate an additional $30 million to the West African peacekeeping force (ECOMOG) to enable it to maintain a level of stability sufficient to permit longer-term peace efforts, as well as urgent humanitarian relief, to take place. And we welcome the assurance that the US will isolate anyone taking governmental power in Liberia by force. However, our consultations with colleagues in the churches and other organizations, both with Liberians and others familiar with that country, convince us that this alone is certain to be insufficient. Without a higher level of US engagement, renewed peace efforts will be vulnerable to violent and perpetual collapse. 

The primary responsibility for the war over the last six years--and for the latest violence in Monrovia--lies with the leaders of the Liberian armed factions, who have put their personal quests for power above the desire of Liberians for peace. The record of the West African peacekeeping force, which brought some stability to parts of Liberia, has been mixed, and its failure to react when violence broke out early this month was a proximate cause of the high level of destruction.

But the international community must also shoulder a large share of the blame for the current disaster. And in the case of Liberia, with 150 years of close US ties, "international community" means above all the United States. The US failure to respond to the initial outbreak of war in 1989-1990 cost the lives of thousands of Liberians and consumed close to $500 million in emergency aid. Many observers warned that the latest peace agreement was doomed to collapse without adequate international support for disarmament of the militias and for the peacekeeping efforts of ECOMOG. That support did not come--a failure which invited a costly humanitarian disaster and set the scene for the evacuation of US citizens and many other foreign residents earlier this month.

It would be an unacceptable betrayal of our moral values and abdication of leadership for the US simply to walk away. But half-hearted efforts to assist are highly likely to sow the seeds of repeated failure. Our response must be thoughtful, holistic, and effective. Liberians, other Africans, and the rest of the world are looking to the US for leadership.

We do not venture to suggest the details of what needs to be done. But there are several points that stand out as indispensable:

(1)West African states must continue to play a central role in peacemaking and peacekeeping, regardless of the shortcomings of their past involvement. While Liberians want peace, they are at the mercy of small armed factions. West African nations are willing to provide the security necessary for Liberians to survive and to rebuild their country. But these states on their own do not have the diplomatic clout, the credibility, or, above all, the logistical resources to do the job.

It follows that:

(a) The US must continue energetic and consistent engagement in the diplomatic process and be willing to demonstrate its urgent concern. Africans and friends of Africa perceive a double-standard in the disproportionate attention which the US government appears to devote to crises in Europe and the Middle East as compared with equally serious ones in Africa.

(b) The US must provide promptly the necessary material means for ECOMOG to be an effective peacekeeping, and, if necessary, peace enforcing presence. We understand that adequate ECOMOG engagement may entail costs as high as $12 million a month over several years, for which the US would have to take primary responsibility.

(2)There is need both for immediate action and for long-term engagement. Even if the latest cease-fire holds, humanitarian agencies cannot return without some assurance that they will not need a new rescue operations a few weeks or months later. And that means the rapid reestablishment of a safe haven in Monrovia. At the same time, however, the longer-term peace process needs to be restarted, restructured and provided with adequate international resources to give it a real chance of success.

Among the implications:

(a) ECOMOG must be the primary force for interim stability, first of all in Monrovia. But the US must take a proactive role in directly and immediately supplying the necessary means for it to do so. We recognize that, in practice, this may mean the need to use the US troops already on the scene, in well-defined roles to deliver logistical and communications supplies to ECOMOG. Improvements in ECOMOG performance are imperative. But for that to happen, the support must be forthcoming without delay. It is essential to avoid the lengthy delays that have sometimes accompanied earlier supplies of equipment for African peacekeepers, both in Liberia and in the case of Rwanda in 1994.

(b) Before Liberians themselves can maintain peace without the presence of an outside force, a number of steps must take place, including the disarmament of factions, the election and installation of a legitimate civilian government, and the training of at least minimal Liberian security forces, primarily police. The ECOMOG presence must be guaranteed for the minimum one to two years that such a process could entail. During this period the US should help ECOMOG to maintain adequate force and equipment levels and to achieve greater professionalism. At the same time, the US should encourage diversity within ECOMOG, facilitating the involvement of all willing West African states.

(3)In order to succeed, the peace process must be linked to plans for demobilization and reintegration of combatants, must provide political space for the vast majority of unarmed Liberians and civil society institutions, and must not be held hostage by any of the leaders of armed factions. The US must play an active role in providing high-level and consistent diplomatic pressure and financial resources in support of each of these prerequisites.

Among the implications:

(a) Continued participation by faction leaders in the political process should be contingent on their cooperation with disarmament. To prevent the leaders of armed factions from holding the process hostage they must be disarmed as specified in the Abuja peace agreement. This action should be accompanied by strong and effective pressure on neighboring countries, particularly Cote d'Ivoire, Burkina Faso and Guinea, to restrict the supply of arms to the factions.

(b) Disarmament of the factions will not be possible without simultaneous planning for demobilization and reintegration of combatants and restoration of civilian economic opportunities. Delays in planning these elements were one of the critical reasons for the failure to disarm in the period since last fall. Such a comprehensive plan will be costly. But it is more practical--and, in the long term less costly--than responding to repeated humanitarian emergencies.

(c) Additional steps must be taken to guarantee a much more active role for civilian institutions in the transition process. Last year's Abuja peace agreement was heralded by some and criticized by others for making the faction leaders the key players in the transitional government leading to elections. This process can only work if prompt disarmament and international protection for civilians is implemented simultaneously. Unless new adjustments in the next phase create space for civilian political activity, the peace process will again be doomed to collapse.

In closing, we would like again to thank you for your recent decision to provide more support for ECOMOG and for the clear stand taken by the Twaddell delegation to Monrovia against any effort by the armed faction leaders to seize power. We know that in practice it will be difficult to implement the necessary high-level US commitment to promote peace in Liberia. We urge you to stay the course.

Signed: Dan Hoffman, President and Imani Countess, Executive Director

For more information on, contact the Washington Office on Africa (WOA) -- a not-for-profit church, trade union and civil rights group supported organization that works with Congress on Africa-related legislation. 110 Maryland Ave. NE, #509, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. E-mail: woa@igc.apc.org. Web: http://www.igc.apc.org/apic/index.shtml.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April, 1996


Botswana (DOCUMENT) Mandela Welcomes Masire


BYLINE: South African Communications Service April 29, 1996


LENGTH: 894 words


 

Pretoria - Speech by President Nelson Mandela at a banquet in honour of
President Masire of Botswana, Cape Town, 23 APRIL 1996.

Your Excellency President Masire and Lady Masire; Deputy Presidents; Honorable Ministers; Distinguished Guests; Ladies and Gentlemen.

Your words of encouragement to the Constitutional Assembly this morning, Mr. President, as our legislators finalise South Africa's new constitution, will remain deeply etched in our hears for years to come.

They reminded us of the joy across the sub-continent 30 years ago, when Botswana gained her independence and set out on the course of democratic majority rule. They reminded us of the intervening period of blood and sweat as the people of your country sacrificed to ensure that their brothers and sisters in Angola, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Namibia and South Africa too, attain their freedom and dignity. 

They also reminded us of the tenacity of the Botswana people to protect and nurture democracy and to achieve high rates of economic growth in the midst of adversity.

And so, we in South Africa have the opportunity today to play host to you, and through you, to embrace the people of Botswana in a gesture of gratitude and defence.

The irony of our history is that such friends and allies for generations, could only exchange official state visits only now, as the century draws to a close.

It is therefore with great joy that I welcome President and Lady Masire to the free South Africa for which we have all been striving. I sincerely hope that you feel just as comfortable here as we felt in your country.

We are proud that the special relationship between our countries is rapidly coming of age. This underlines the fact that the bonds of history, geography and culture that nature has decreed, apartheid could not rend apart.

Mr. President.

South Africa's democracy is now almost two years old; and it is poised for even better expression in our new constitution.

Freedom from apartheid brings the opportunity for South Africans to address their basic needs. While we have no illusion about the enormity of the task, we have no doubts about the successes we are registering. Freedom from destabilisation brings also the opportunity for building equitable relations between our countries, and for us jointly to contribute to the development of our Southern African region and our continent as a whole.

Our country has much to learn from Botswana - both from your towering successes and your efforts to deal with the difficulties.

All these attributes have made Botswana, and you. Mr President, a natural and capable leader of the region's collective efforts towards growth and development, within the framework of SADC. We also value your leadership in the region's efforts to promote peace and stability on our sub-continent and further afield.

In all these spheres, South Africa stands ready to work with Botswana and other neighbours to attain the best for our peoples.

The rapid development of bilateral relations between our two countries has brought increasing co-operation in almost every area of government and the private sector. Many of our Cabinet Ministers and members of provincial executives have visited Botswana, and so have senior leaders from Botswana visited South Africa, over the last two years.

Our bilateral discussion earlier today underlined the progress that is being made in completing negotiations on the customs union and in other bilateral and multilateral matters. So should it be among friends, neighbours and partners in development.

Mr President;

Your visit has afforded us the opportunity to bestow on you the Order of Good Hope.

In doing so, we recognise not only the self-sacrificing support which you and your people gave to the people of South Africa, but also your contribution to creating the framework within which we can all pursue the still greater challenge of regional peace and development.

Ladies and Gentlemen;

I ask you to rise and raise your glasses in drinking a toast to President Masire and the people of Botswana, and to the ever deepening bonds of friendship between our peoples. .


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Swaziland (DOCUMENT) Mbeki Pays Official Visit to Swazi King


BYLINE: South African Communications Service April 29, 1996


LENGTH: 187 words


 

Pretoria - Issued by: Office of the Executive Deputy President T. M. Mbeki on April 26, 1996.
Contrary to reports in the media that Executive Deputy President Mbeki today travelled secretly to Swaziland, this Office confirms that the visit was an official one at the invitation of His Majesty King Mswati III. 

It was also incorrectly reported that Deputy President Mbeki was in Swaziland to discuss that country's political situation.

The purpose of the meeting between Deputy President Mbeki and His Majesty is to discuss Swaziland's claims to territory in Mpumalanga Province and KwaZulu Natal.

On his return to South Africa this evening, Friday 26 April 1996, Deputy President Mbeki will report to President Nelson Mandela on the outcome of his discussions with His Majesty King Mswati III.
