LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


378 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


United States and Africa State Department Welcomes Commonwealth Report on Nigeria


BYLINE: U.S. Department of State April 25, 1996


LENGTH: 427 words


 

Washington, D.C. Statement by Acting Spokesman Glyn Davies: The United States welcomes the April 23 recommendation by the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group (CMAG) that Commonwealth nations implement new measures to register their continuing disapproval of developments in Nigeria.

Several of these recommendations are consistent with measures already adopted by the European Union (EU) and the United States. These measures include visa restrictions on members of the Nigerian regime and their families, withdrawal of military attaches, termination of military training, and an embargo on arms exports. The recommended downgrading of cultural and educational links, and the banning of sporting contacts, with the exception of the Olympics, also complement avenues the United States is pursuing. 

By adopting the Ministerial Group's recommendations, the Commonwealth and its member countries will be joining an increasing number of international voices calling for real progress on a rapid, transparent transition to democratic rule and respect for human rights and the rule of law in Nigeria. The Ministerial Group's recommendations and the U.N. Human Rights Commission's April 22 unanimous adoption of a resolution on the human rights situation in Nigeria demonstrate that the international community will not permit governments such as Nigeria to impede democratic progress and ignore standards for human rights with impunity.

We share the Commonwealth's view that the general human rights situation in Nigeria continues to deteriorate. Notwithstanding the holding of non-party local government elections in March 1996, new restrictive decrees issued by the government of Nigeria cast doubt on its commitment to the democratic process. New measures such as those proposed by the CMAG, implemented collectively, offer the best possibility of impressing upon the Nigerian leadership the urgency of taking credible, positive steps toward establishing elected, civilian government in Nigeria. We hope for the early adoption of the Ministerial Group's recommendations by Commonwealth member countries and look forward to the opportunity to consult with them on possible new multilateral economic measures.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


379 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


South Africa (DOCUMENT) Truth Commission Considers Amnesty Applications


BYLINE: Truth and Reconciliation Commission April 29, 1996


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Cape Town - STATEMENT FROM THE ANMESTY COMMITTEE OF THE TRUTH AND RECONCILIATION COMMISSION on April 24, 1996.

The Committee on Amnesty of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission today began its consideration of whether applications for amnesty meet the requirements of the Promotion of National Unity and Reconciliation Act. 

The Committee will meet for two days in Cape Town and hopes to give consideration to some 60 or 70 applications.

The process in which the Committee is engaged at this meeting is governed by, inter alia, Section 19 of the Act. (Attached to the statement for ease of reference.)

If the papers covering an application are in order, the Committee will examine its merits. It may ask for further investigation of a matter, and it may afford applicants the opportunity to make further submissions.

However, it is conceivable that decisions to grant or reject applications could be made this week. Such decisions will not be announced by the Committee, but will be forwarded to the full Commission for it to announce at its discretion and in terms of the Act.

The Committee has not yet reached the stage of holding hearings. In terms of Section 19(4) of the Act, hearings will be held when applications relate to gross violations of human rights as defined in the Act. In such cases, all interested parties will be notified. Announcements on hearings will be made in due course.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


380 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Sudan Churches In Southern Sudan Vow To Uphold Peace


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 29, 1996 by Osman Njuguna


LENGTH: 1627 words


 

Nairobi - For four consecutive days, deliberations revolved around similar issues -- peace, unity and reconciliation among the Sudanese.

Despite time and effort spent to end the long-standing civil war in Sudan, hundreds of thousands of Sudanese, particularly the majority Christians in the south continue to undergo untold sufferings. Recently, a group of church leaders meeting at Machakos town, some 65 kilometres south-east of the capital, Nairobi, under the auspices of the New Sudan Council of Churches (NSCC), agreed that despite the complex social and political situations in Sudan, the church must be part and parcel of the issues at hand as these affect the spiritual and general well-being of the people.

The April 14 to 18 Sixth General Assembly of the NSCC was attended by bishops, pastors and lay persons who represented member churches namely the Catholic Church, Episcopal Church in Sudan, the Presbyterian Church of Sudan, Africa Inland Church, Sudan Interior Church and the Sudan Pentecostal Church, all of which operate in the commonly referred to as "liberated areas" in the south.

"The church in Sudan is not new to the issues at hand-peace, unity, peace and reconciliation. We have discussed them for too long. But one big disappointment we have always registered is that those assigned to handle the same problems at the political level have always let us down," said Bishop Taban Paride of the Torit Diocese, when he addressed the meeting. 

The Catholic clergy, was referring to the "lack of unity" among some of the leaders of the liberation movements in the South. "I have always wondered, and I want to imagine that I am not alone, why they find it difficult to work together," he said.

Bishop Paride however noted that such odds should not de-rail the peace process at home. "We must continue to intensify the need for peace, unity and reconciliation among them political liberation movements and Sudanese in general, with the hope that one day we shall all see the light and unite, uphold peace and reconcile with each other for the progress of the entire Sudan," he noted.

Like others attending the NSCC General Assembly, the Torit Bishop criticised the recent signing of the so called "peace agreement" between Dr. Riak Machar of the South Sudan Independence Movement (SSIM) and the Khartoum Government.

Posed Paride; "How on earth can one person decide to commit the entire or a section of the southerners into this kind of business? If both Machar and Khartoum Government were serious about peace, they should have involved the

entire community in the south through their liberation movements, but the contrary is what has happened."

On April 10, both SSIM and Khartoum Government were reported to have signed a political charter "to bring to an end the on-going civil war in southern Sudan." The accord was reportedly reached after secret and persistent talks between the two sides during the last few months.

According to a press statement then, SSIM and the Sudanese Government were agreed on the principle of peace settlement for the conflict, and stressed the unity of the Sudan within its boundaries which were inherited from British administration. The parties also resolved that an interim period be set, after which a referendum would be conducted by the people of southern Sudan to determine the political future of the region.

But a spokesman for the SSIM commenting on reactions from the NSCC assembly told APS; "This is nothing short of a workable document towards a lasting solution to the civil conflict in the Sudan. To us, it is a good move and we stand by its contents."

Addressing the Assembly, Bishop Paride said he doubted the commitment of the Khartoum Government to the recent "peace agreement". "We need to do a lot of homework before we accept what the Khartoum government is saying in the peace agreement. We should not be in a hurry. We need to examine ourselves and others calling for such an agreement."

The Catholic clergy also told the more than 50 delegates attending the NSCC meeting that Government soldiers were "dropping bombs" in some strategic areas in the south, with the aim to kill and maim the poor people in the region. "But sometimes, these bombs have landed on children, elderly men and women or sometimes on poor creatures such as rats and snakes, but not on the targeted rebels," Bishop Paride lamented.

A recent church report supports Bishop Paride's claims on bomb dropping..."As an example we can report that on February 8, 1996, the Khartoum Government dropped from the air approximately 40 plastic TNT land mines near a community water supply in Ikotos, Eastern Equatoria, southern Sudan. This marks an escalation of what appears to be a concerted effort to target the civilian population of southern Sudan."

According to the church report, the plastic land mines are sometimes designed to be especially attractive to children, and their use renders many roads impassable, thereby making it impossible to transport relief goods and personnel by land.

And in an open letter, two American church missionaries, working in southern Sudan, Rev. Philip and Louise Rieman of the Church of the Brethren Missionaries, wrote to President Bill Clinton on April 10, expressing their concern over the dangers posed by the presence of land mines in some areas in Sudan.

They wrote: "While we have had the good fortune not to have ever stepped on or run over a land mine, one of our own NSCC trucks has and it was badly damaged. The driver lost his hearing in one ear but was otherwise not injured.

"Another NSCC truck hit a land mine but for some reason it did not detonate. We have personally had to drive over roads that were supposedly cleared of land mines the previous hour," the two American missionaries stated in their open letter.

At the NSCC General Assembly, another speaker also questioned the Khartoum Government's commitment to peace, unity and reconciliation as stated in the April peace accord against the

background that "this government is spending nearly US dollars one million daily on war and war-related issues in southern Sudan."

Turning to the work of churches in southern Sudan, the NSCC chairman, Rt. Rev. Daniel Zindo expressed concern not only for the loss of lives and material but the effects of the civil conflict on pastoral activities.

"For example, we would have held our General Assembly at Leer in Upper Nile region, but this was impossible due to the current war situation in the south. This forced us to come to Machakos, simply looking for a peaceful place to hold our sixth NSCC general assembly," he noted.

And when the delegates resolved that the next NSCC General Assembly be held at Leer, Upper Nile, the same concerns about insecurity came up. "We need to consider a lot of things before we say yes. Let us go to Leer for our seventh General Assembly," said one of the delegates, making his contribution to the discussions.

And at the end of the five-day meeting, participants resolved that churches in the Sudan should sustain their calling and work for peace, unity and reconciliation.

The Sixth Assembly also called upon churches to promote peace making initiatives at the grassroots and intercommunities level, and involve both women and youth in the process.

The assembly delegates also recommended that NSCC should establish desks for youth and women activities.

The issue about the location of NSCC headquarters also came up. Delegates recommended that the council should consider seriously shifting the offices from the Kenyan capital, Nairobi to Narus, southern Sudan, about 50 kilometres from the Kenya/Sudan border.

Responding to the proposal on office location, the acting NSCC Secretary, Mr. Rob Haarsager, confirmed that shifting to southern Sudan is a priority and the council has already put up some buildings for that purpose.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


381 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Africa-at-Large Who Will Free Africa's Soils From Land Mines?


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 29, 1996 by Wafula John


LENGTH: 1507 words


 

Nairobi - Even as the United Nations Review Conference on Certain Conventional Weapons met in Geneva, Switzerland, from April 22 to May 3 to discuss the banning of land mines, sub-Saharan Africa continues to suffer the monstrous effects of this weapon duped "the poor man's weapon."

Land mines are dreaded in sub-Saharan Africa because of their capacity to kill and maim decades after the conflict is over. Worse still, these weapons kill indiscriminately. Still, most of the victims are innocent people including women foraging for firewood, children playing in the fields, and herdsmen tending their flocks of livestock.

Indeed as one observer puts it, mines are conventionally purposely used to kill civilians so as to defeat the military. "These weapons directly aim at civilians, and perhaps only the military will be spared," he says. During World War I, land mines were hardly used as a weapon and only five per cent of the casualties were civilians. 

In Rwanda and Somalia, where land mines are excessively used in ethnic conflicts, some 80 to 90 per cent of the casualties are said to be civilians.

Ahead of the Geneva Review Conference, the Secretary General of the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC), Rev. Jose Belo Chipenda, notes that people in Africa will continue to die long after formal agreements have been signed due to the heavy mining of the continent.

Calling for a complete halt to the production, stockpiling, transfer and deployment of land mines, Rev. Chipenda adds; "Just as ecologists all over the world are concerned with pollution of air and water, in Africa we are greatly exercised about the destructive effects of land mines."

Of the more than 100 million land mines deployed all over the world, 30 million of these "toys of death" are planted across at least 18 countries in Africa, mainly in sub-Saharan African soils, according to the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC).

In Angola, ICRC reports, thousands of hectares of farmland and forest are no longer productive because of the haphazard deployment of land mines. The civil war wrecked southern African country of 10 million people is reportedly home to some 10 million mines. Hence, in this country, every living person is a potential victim of a mine lurking somewhere to either kill or maim.

In Mozambique, reports the ICRC, the presence of 3 million land mines has hindered economic recovery as well as the repatriation of refugees. Nearly 2 million Mozambicans are said to be too afraid to return to their homes lest they step on a mine and are blown away.

Somalia is said to be littered with 1.5 million land mines, the Sudan between 2 and 5 million, Rwanda and Burundi 100,000 while Liberia and Ethiopia account for 600,000 mines.

Why are these seeds of death so popular with war lords in sub- Saharan Africa? Aptly referred to as "the poor man's weapon", a land mine can be procured for as little as three US dollars. Worse still land mines promise to become even cheaper with advanced technology which makes them increasingly affordable weapons for impoverished sub-Saharan Africa warlords.

What further endears the landmines to the region's warring factions, is the changing nature of conflicts, according to Nicoletta Dentico of the Rome-based International Documentation and Communication Centre (IDOC).

Dentico explains that the nature of warfare, more so in sub-Saharan Africa, has changed in recent decades. "Many wars are long-running, internal and low intensity (consider Mozambique), often involving cash-starved militaries for whom low cost, low technology land mines are a weapon of choice."

"Such conflicts," she says, "are not fought on conventional battlefields, rather entire countries become theatres of war." She adds; "Mines, are today laid in vast quantities across whole zones, thereby taking the clear feature of strategic weapons."

Other than being strategic weapons of today's sub-Saharan Africa, technological advances have made mines lighter, easier to disguise, and even more lethal. Worse still they now come in plastic camouflages which make them even more difficult to detect.

According to a Lutheran World Federation (LWF) publication, Development, Education Forum, (December 1995), the sub-Saharan scenario appears more bleak because land mines can now be easily obtained from other African countries.

Already three African nations, namely Egypt, South Africa and Zimbabwe have joined the list of land mine exporters to sub-Saharan countries. Thus, warring factions in the region can now purchase land mines from their own doorsteps.

It is now clear, as one UN official put it, that land mines are "one of the worst man-made environmental disasters of the century. Other than hide the ability of such countries like Angola and Mozambique to rebuild their post-war economies, land mines also cause untold human suffering both in terms of deaths and loss of ability to work due to disabilities arising from amputations. Angola alone, reports the IDOC publication, has well over 100,000 amputees.

However, clearing the mines in the region has not been as easy as sowing them. Demining has been a painfully slow and dangerous procedure.

First, has been the reluctance of rich countries and donor agencies to commit themselves towards the demining process. Then there has been the arduous process of demining itself.

Unfortunately, the surest and most common method of mine clearance involves an individual walking in a minefield and poking a mine detecting rod into the ground until a mine is located and destroyed.

This process, referred to as prodding, is quite slow, dangerous, and very expensive. IDOC estimates that it will take seven to ten years and US dollars 30 to 40 million to rid Mozambique alone of its estimated

2 to 3 million land mines. To demine the entire African continent would cost upwards of US dollars 400 million. Worse still, whereas a mine costs 3 dollars the UN has estimated the cost of clearance including support and logistics at 300 to 1,000 dollars per mine.

Other than the monetary cost, there is also the cost in human life. IDOC estimates that for every 5,000 mines cleared, one disposal expert is killed and two injured. Hence, to rid the African continent of mines 12,000 experts would be blown up. Among them, 4,000 will be killed.

Still, the slow process of demining is reportedly taking root in some sub-Saharan African countries. But this task is mainly being carried out by Non-Governmental Organizations. Already, six NGOs are said to be carrying out the demining process in Angola but only a few thousand mines are said to have been defused since early 1995.

With these sombre facts, over 100 NGOs and church bodies met in 1991 and founded the International Campaign to Ban Landmines, which was lobbying for the banning of land mines in last week's Geneva meeting.

Worldwide religious leaders have also added their voices to the condemnation of the manufacture, trading in and use of land mines as a conventional weapon. These include the head of the worldwide Roman Catholic Church Pope John Paul II, World Council of Churches (WCC) General Secretary Dr. Konrad Raiser, his LWF counterpart Dr. Ishmael Noko, and the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) President Archbishop Desmond Tutu.

Whatever actions will arise from the recent Geneva meeting, one cannot help but feel sorry for the civilian population in affected regions all over the world.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


382 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Rwanda When Accusing Fingers Point At Clergy


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 29, 1996 by Ruth Nyona


LENGTH: 1654 words


 

Kigali - At one time or other, a section of the Church in Rwanda has been accused of participating in the massacres that took place in the country between April and July 1994, leaving more than 500,000 people dead.

A report released in April last year by Amnesty International and Africa Watch, both human rights organizations, blamed the Roman Catholic for ideologically contributing in preparing genocide and massacres in Rwanda.

With the end of the genocide in July, the Tutsi dominated Rwanda Patriotic Front (RPF) took the church in this central African country to task for ethnic hatred and collaboration with the country's rulers.

Elsewhere, the role of some Anglican bishops and priests during the horror, caused widespread criticism from both within and outside Rwanda. The tragic experience by the church was also realised by Seventh Day Adventist (SDA) Christians, who according to reports, were among Christians who took part in the killings in this central African country. 

At one time, visiting Rwandan Foreign Minister Anastase Gasena told a news conference in the Belgian capital, Brussels; "The church failed, the Catholic church failed," adding that Catholics should make deep reforms in their evangelical message. The three churches in the mainly Christian nation have not been spared embarrassment with reports of priests having played a role in the genocide.

The Rwanda War Crimes Tribunal was created by the United Nations Security Council in November 1994. It set up operations in Arusha, Tanzania, with the mandate of trying those charged with involvement in the ethnic carnage between January 1 and December 31, 1994. So far, a number of suspects have either been imprisoned, put under house arrest or under investigation.

In France, a Rwandan Catholic priest, Wenceslas Munyeshyaka was placed under investigation on suspicion over the killings in his country. He was accused of giving Hutu militia lists of Tutsi sympathisers later taken away and killed as part of the genocide characterised by ill-treatment, torture and degrading activities.

Fr. Wenceslas who was a vicar at Holy Family Church fled to Zaire and later to France when the Tutsi-led RPF finally seized power in July 1994, but terrible accusations followed him and was indicted. Moreso, two Rwandan nuns who fled to Belgium were also accused of complicity in the massacre. In Rwanda, thousands of victims died in churches where they had sought refuge.

The London-based human rights organisation, Amnesty International reported that clergy told people fleeing the massacre to seek refuge in churches where they would then be killed.

The Adventist Press Service also reported that a retired Seventh Day Adventist minister Elizapham Ntakirutimana was put under investigation for his suspected involvement in the genocide in Kibuye during violence.

A report in the Washington Times daily quoted a spokesman of the International Criminal Tribunal in Rwanda, naming Ntakirutimana as one on the list of persons presumed guilty. Another suspect is an Italian monk who was put under house arrest by Rwandan authorities in June 1995.

In April the same year, Rwanda Bishops' conference reported two nuns were being held in the Rwandan capital, Kigali along with two Priests in Gitarama and two others plus a seminarian in Butare.

Although Rwanda's Bishops Conference had condemned earlier massacres, protested the use of ethnic ideology and called for ceasefire in the civil war, the situation could not be contained.

Rev. Jean Baptiste Rugengamanzi, a Hutu heading the Kigali diocese, described as unconfirmed, reports by Africa Watch and Amnesty International human rights groups, that priests actively encouraged murderers and carried guns themselves.

"What could the church do? The church has taught people to love, it has taught charity not to kill, I think our role was to invite people to make peace and we did. Had we to go fighting with guns?" he asked.

Rev. John Skinnader, an Irish priest working with an Irish relief agency, said the massacres in Rwanda were of a profound nature that went to the core of human identity - a ceremony that asserted human dignity - a dignity that countless Rwandans lost when they disobeyed the commandment 'Thou shall not kill'.

Despite criticism, humiliation and embarrassments experienced by Christians worldwide, top church leaders made pastoral visits to the war-wrecked Rwanda. Top on the list was the spiritual leader of the worldwide Anglican communion, Archbishop of Canterbury George Carey.

Archbishop Carey visited Rwanda for the first time in May 1995 with the purpose of demonstrating the prayerful support and compassion of the worldwide Anglican communion.

During his visit, Carey further witnessed the distrust that the people had against the church when he preached at Kigali Episcopal Church--it was a little more than half full.

In July 1995, South African Archbishop Desmond Tutu who is also the President of Nairobi-based All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) visited Rwanda and called for understanding towards clerics who might have taken part in the genocide.

Rev. Jose Chipenda, the General Secretary of the AACC who accompanied Archbishop Tutu, said the visit was intended to show the solidarity of African churches with the suffering people of Rwanda and to encourage reconciliation for the good of Africa and for the sake of present and future generations in Rwanda.

The Roman Catholic Pope John Paul II in a letter addressed on March 14, 1996, to Bishop Thaddee Ntihinyurwa, the President of Rwandan Bishops Conference, said the church cannot be held responsible for wrong deeds of its members who violated church teachings.

And in November last year, the SDA world President Robert S. Folkenberg during a visit to the small Central African nation, called on the nation's clergy to shun claims of names and forms of Christianity.

Folkenberg addressed about 20,000 people, Rwandan Vice President Paul Kagame and Adventist Pastor included. He noted that the future of Rwanda does not lie in the hands of Government and civil authorities but it is up to spiritual leaders to call for conversion and transformation.

Still, Folkenberg could not understand why the spirit of the Gospel was not sufficient to stop the killings in a nation where 95 per cent of the population including almost 300,000 Adventists claimed Christ's name.

The communication Director of SDA world headquarters Ray Dabrowski says the SDA church condemns atrocity in any form. "We are supportive of the initiatives of the Rwandan Government to bring to justice those who are responsible for illegal activities in the country's crisis," he says.

Pope John Paul II on the other hand called on Catholic faithful involved in the killings to be brought to trial. All members of the church who sinned, the Pontiff declared, must have the courage of bearing consequences of their deeds against God and their neighbours.

According to available figures in Rwanda, SDA Christians are organised into 806 churches with 285,000 baptised adult believers. The Anglican Church, commonly known as the Episcopal Church is said to be a minority in this former Belgian protectorate.

Church reports say possibly 225 SDA church workers and 10,000 members died, while nearly 250 Catholic priests, nuns and missionaries were killed during the 1994 massacres in Rwanda.

The Catholic church in Rwanda is said to have experienced divisions long before the April 6 mysterious plane crash that killed Hutu President Juvenal Habyarimana and his Burundian counterpart Cyprien Ntaryamira.

Being one of the institutions open to Tutsi, half the Catholic clergy were Tutsi in a country that was more than 80 per cent Hutu. But this was unbearable according to Rev. Octave Ugira, a Tutsi and Jesuit priest.

Ugira said, "militiamen used to say we have nothing to do with God. They said virgin Mary was a Tutsi woman and she had to be killed." Ugira heads a church centre in Kigali where 17 priests and nuns were killed.

The church in what was predominantly a Catholic nation lost its moral authority and it will be difficult for leaders to rebuild it. A good number of Rwandan say they still believe in God but not the Church at large.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April, 1996


Uganda Presidential Aspirants Pledge Peaceful Campaigns


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 29, 1996


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Kampala - As Uganda's election campaigns intensify, representatives of the three presidential candidates have issued a joint communique in which they pledge to ensure that credible elections take place in the country without further incidents of violence.

In a joint statement issued on April 18 here at a consultative meeting for all representatives of the three presidential candidates, which was also attended by the Interim Electoral Commission (IEC) Chairperson Mr. Stephen Besweri Akabway, the three, namely Yoweri Museveni, Mayanja Kibirige and Paul Kawanga Ssemogerere agreed to keep to the IEC rules.

The IEC regulations specify among other issues that no supporters of any presidential aspirant should carry a campaign poster belonging to another candidate and there should be no provocation from supporters if a different candidate is holding a rally. 

These guidelines were issued earlier by the commission but they have often been disregarded. Supporters of Museveni have continued to disrupt meetings of opposition candidates as police look on helplessly. The IEC only acted after two incidents (one at Makerere University and the other at Bwaise, north-east of Kampala, in which the opposition supporters were provoked and they hit back.

Meanwhile, leaders of the rightwing Evangelical Churches in Uganda, commonly referred to as Balokole or "Born Again", have issued a statement in which they disassociate themselves from the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) of Joseph Kony.

The eight pastors say Kony did not belong to any of their churches and that his political, military and religious programmes are parallel to theirs.

The Chairman of Born Again Churches of Uganda, Pastor Simeon Kayiwa said they were prompted to make the clarification following remarks made by presidential aspirant Dr. Paul Ssemogerere recently during his campaign rallies in Mpigi District, central Uganda.

Ssemogerere reportedly said he would send the Born Again Christians to discuss the restoration of security in northern Uganda with Kony.

"It was herein implied that since Kony's organisation is called the Lord's Resistance Army, he belongs to our born-again camp and he, (Ssemogerere) would comfortably send us to tread the jungle which we are already familiar with," said Kayiwa.

"We would like to state in the strongest terms that Kony's organisation or Kony himself have nothing to do with our churches and we should not be linked with him as a fellow brother in Christ," the Balokole chairman clarified.

The pastors said the purpose of their communique was to clear their name and not to attack or discredit Ssemogerere as a presidential candidate.

When contacted about the claims made by the Born Again, a spokesman of Ssemogerere who chose anonymity dismissed the statement saying, "We have heard about the two leaders, Kayiwa and Sserwadda visiting Rwakitura where they were allegedly given money to distribute."

He went on; "If you are careful, you will hear of more night prayers than before, but do they even have proof that Ssemogerere has ever made such remarks? Mpigi is not very far from here, which particular place are they talking about so that you people (referring to the press) can go and find out for yourselves."

The spokesman cautioned people against taking everything that is said as the Gospel truth. He further advised the Balokole that if Ssemogerere had made such a careless remark then they should have taken up the issue with the person instead of rushing to the newspapers.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April, 1996


Egypt Muslim Extremists Say They Killed Tourists In Egypt


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 29, 1996


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Cairo - Four gunmen raked a crowd of Greek tourists with bullets at a hotel near the pyramids on April 18, killing 18 and wounding 13 in the worst massacre of foreigners in four years of violence pitting the Egyptian secular government against Muslim fundamentalists seeking to turn the country into a hardline Islamic republic of the Iranian type.

The assailants, Muslim militants of the Jamaa Islamiyya fundamentalist group, armed with Kalashnikovs and a revolver sprayed the holidaymakers at point blank range outside the Europa Hotel on the road leading to the Giza pyramids outside Cairo.

The 18 killed in the carnage, most of them elderly, including 14 women, were Greek tourists on an Easter visit to Middle East holy sites, an Interior Ministry spokesman said.

Twelve members of the Greek group were also injured along with an Egyptian who worked in the hotel garage, doctors at the Al-Ahram hospital said. Seven were in serious condition. 

"Four men got out of a Volkswagen minibus, they kept firing for almost five minutes. It was horrible. Then they got back in the van and drove off," said Abdel Hamid Imam, a hotel worker.

Eline Kaminisco, in her late 50s, who was wounded in the shoulder, added: "I saw two of them, wearing black shirts. Their heads were nearly shaven and they had light beards. They just opened fire and fell behind the bus."

Pools of blood spattered the hotel lobby and entrance in the aftermath of the massacre, a shattering blow to Egypt's tourist industry which has been recovering from previous attacks in which 12 tourists had died.

But on April 20, Egypt's main armed militant group, the Jamaa Islamiyya, claimed responsibility for the killings but said the attack had been aimed at Israelis.

The Jamaa (The Islamic Group) statement said: "The battalions of the martyr Talaat Yassin Hammam announce their responsibility for the April 18 operation in Giza against a group of tourists leaving 18 dead and wounding 15."

The statement added the operation was aimed at "a group of Israeli tourists" who were also staying at the Europa Hotel where the attack took place.

"All Jewish interests on Egyptian territory are targeted until the end of the Zionist enemy's operation against Lebanese territory," the statement said.

The four-star Europa Hotel, five kilometres from the pyramids, is a favorite place for Israeli Arab tourists.

The attack coincided with the height of an Israeli military offensive in Lebanon, which has provoked Arab anger.

The victims were waiting to board a bus to go to the Mediterranean city of Alexandria shortly after breakfast when the attackers jumped out of the van and opened fire.

The tourists said they were part of a group of around 150 Greek tourists travelling around churches and holy sites in the region. They had arrived in Cairo from Israel.

Interior Minister Hassan al-Alfi, as well as the Tourism and Defense ministers visited the scene of the attack and victims at the hospital.

Western tourists have been a target for Muslim militants waging a bloody anti-government campaign since March 1992, in which close to 1,000 people have been killed.

The last deadly attack on tourists was in October 1994 at the Red Sea resort of Hurghada. The Jamaa Islamiyya, the main outlawed fundamentalist group in Egypt, claimed the attack in which two German tourists died.

The first time Islamic militants targeted tourists was in October 1992 in Asyut, southern Egypt, when a British holidaymaker was killed.

Egypt's tourist revenue -- its fourth biggest earner according to Western estimates -- plummeted by more than half from US dollars 3 billion in 1992 to 1.3 billion in 1993 as holidaymakers were scared off.

But during a relative lull in 1995 tourist numbers rose 20 per cent to top 3 million for the first time in three years.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


385 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


South Africa Constitution: Agreement on Minorities Commission


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 29, 1996


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Cape Town - South African legislators took a significant step towards a new constitution on April 19 when a series of agreements between parties mopped up some of the key outstanding issues.

The agreements, coming after an all-night session, will allow a draft bill to be drawn up and published immediately and submitted for debate to the Constitutional Assembly the following week.

The main agreement is over the establishment of a minorities commission, whose aim will be to protect the language, rights and culture of ethnic minorities.

Negotiators from the white Afrikaans-speaking right wingers of the Freedom Front and the dominant African National Congress (ANC) reached the agreement at a closed-door session in the small hours of April 19. 

Members of all parties involved greeted the agreement as a triumph, ending two years of tough debates on the issue.

Retired general Constand Viljoen, leader of the Freedom Front gave credit for the deal to the ANC, saying it was "a brave move."

"I think it is a very great achievement," he said, adding that he believed the basis of the deal could be exported to other parts of Africa that are also grappling with the concept of self- determination for minorities.

Political analysts agreed that the agreement justified the way Viljoen split the Afrikaner right-wing, which was determined to boycott the first all-race election of April 1994, and took his followers into the new Parliament.

MPs and senators broke into relieved applause at the end of the debate, but when sleepless negotiators broke up early on April 19, they left a number of tendentious issues still unsettled.

These include a highly contentious clause in the draft Bill of Rights creating both a right tote and a right to lock-out.

Despite the agreement on the minorities, questions of language and education remain to be formally concluded, although the agreement will have eased the way for this.

The property clause, which attempts to lay down limitations on the right to own property under what circumstances and owner may be expropriated, still needs final settlement.

Cyril Ramaphosa, the chairman of the Constitutional Assembly, said he believed the political agreement is there, but the language needs to be refined.

Another key breakthrough came in when the ANC and the National Party agreed to a compromise on the reference to God in the preamble to the constitution.

The present constitution starts: "In humble submission to Almighty God, the people of South Africa declare..."

Non-believers have objected to the wording, while members of Christian, Muslim and other faiths have insisted on it.

The new version omits the reference, beginning: "We, the people of South Africa, recognise the injustices of our past..." but includes -- in six languages -- a sentence seeking the blessing of God upon South Africa.

The new bill is now being drafted by the Constitutional Assembly's legal advisers and will be debated in the next session of the full assembly, which is made up of all 490 members of both Houses of Parliament.

Under the present interim constitution, the Assembly is required to pass the new constitution by a two-thirds majority within two years of the inauguration of President Nelson Mandela on May 10, 1994.

Admitting that the morning had been packed with emotion, Ramaphosa said after the conclusion of the debate: "We can look forward with confidence to adopting the Constitution on May 8."

Ramaphosa, the ANC secretary general who presided over the Constitutional Assembly -- made up of both houses of parliament sitting together -- chaired the session and agreed to the adjournment provided sub-committees spent the time going through the technical refinements.

Ramaphosa announced at the weekend that he would leave parliament for the private sector once the new constitution takes its final form and is cleared by the Constitutional Court.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


386 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Rwanda Last UN Troops Leave As Hostilities Persist


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 29, 1996


LENGTH: 587 words


 

Kigali - The last United Nations troops in Rwanda left the war-torn tiny central African nation on April 19 after nearly four years of a mission that failed to halt an ethnic genocide that left between 500,000 and one million people dead.

The genocide was carried out by Hutu extremists on men, women and children of the minority Tutsis and moderate Hutus.

The UN troops, 5,500-strong at their peak, were deployed in tiny Rwanda in October 1993 to oversee a power-sharing agreement between majority Hutus and minority Tutsis. 

However, Rwanda exploded into civil war on April 6 the following year after Hutu Presidents Juvenal Habyarimana of Rwanda and Cyprien Ntaryamira of Burundi died in a planecrash near Kigali, suspected to have been brought down by a rocket fired by the Tutsi-dominated Rwandan Patriotic Front (RFP) rebels.

Habyarimana and Ntaryamira both hailed from the Hutu ethnic group, which has an 80 per cent majority both in Rwanda and Burundi.

Ten Belgian UN peacekeepers that were guarding Prime Minister Agathe Uwilingiyimana at the time were killed when she was assassinated on April 7, 1994 -- the first day of the three-months war that ended in July the same year, when the RPF defeated the army of Habyarimana's French-supported regime.

The UN quickly reduced the number of peacekeepers down to just 270, and with a weak mandate, they were unable to halt the slaughter by defeated Hutu militiamen and soldiers wielding guns, machetes and garden hoes.

The minority Tutsis who defeated the Hutu-dominated government army in the subsequent civil war never forgave the UN troops for failing to halt the genocide, and the mandate of the UN Assistance Mission in Rwanda (UNAMIR), ended on March 8 after Kigali refused to countenance a further extension.

The UN troops were also criticised -- but this time by the Hutus -- for standing by a year ago as troops of the new Tutsi-dominated army shot at massed Hutu refugees in the Kibeho displaced persons' camp.

Estimates of the number of dead there ranged from an initial UN count of up to 8,000 -- later amended to around 2,000 -- to a government count of 300.

As the UN troops left, UN Undersecretary General Marrack Goulding also arrived in Kigali the same day to discuss the equipment the UN was leaving behind for the Rwandans -- material rejected as "junk" by Claude Dusaidi, political adviser to Vice President and Defence Minister Paul Kagame, Rwanda's new military strongman.

Dusaidi also charged that the UN mission owed some US dollars 2.5 million in taxes, rents, and benefits for local staff.

The departure of the UN forces came as some 1.7 million Hutu refugees still remained in sprawling camps in neighbouring countries, terrified that they will face retribution if they return, despite government assurances.

Refugee leaders say the departure of the troops and military observers will reinforce these fears.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


387 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


South Africa Truth Commission Ends First Week Of Hearings


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 29, 1996


LENGTH: 774 words


 

East London - South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission looking into atrocities during the era of apartheid ended its first week of hearings on April 19 on a shocking note, when a witness claimed that he had seen the severed hand of a black activist in a bottle at a police station.

Fezile Jacobs, himself a torture victim, said security police had told him it was a baboon hand, but he personally believed it was the hand of a murdered activist, Sicelo Mhilawuli.

Mhlawuli's widow told the commission earlier this week her husband had been buried with one hand missing.

Mhlawuli was one of four activists who went missing in 1985. Their mutilated bodies and burnt-out car were later found near Port Elizabeth, 300 kilometres south of this city in Eastern Cape province. 

Commission chairman Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu said at the end of the first session of hearings that it was clear from testimony during the week that "injustice and oppression of the apartheid era did not stand a chance at all."

Tutu said that women witnesses -- many of them widows -- who have dominated the hearings since they began on April 15, had been "fantastic."

The commission, he added, had been addressed by some 'extraordinary people... The world is amazed as it hears the harrowing stories you have told."

Tutu, who broke down in tears on the second day of the hearings, said he was inspired by the "willingness to forgive. Very few of us can be the same today as we were on April 15 or 16."

During testimony on April 19, black liberation movements were also implicated in apartheid-era killings.

One witness, Nontuthuzelo Mpehlo, told the commission that her activist husband was murdered by black activists in 1986 after being accused of betraying Black Conciousness leader Steve Biko to the apartheid police 10 years earlier.

Biko, whose life was portrayed in Richard Attenborough's movie "Cry Freedom," died in police custody in 1977.

Mrs. Mpehlo said her husband, Mick, was shot dead in the Eastern Cape town of Grahamstown, and before his death, he had been harassed by a mob that stoned his home and accused him of being a police spy.

The family of Welcome Sabatana testified to the commission that, after fleeing South Africa into exile in the 1970s, he disappeared and was feared dead in a Tanzanian camp run by the Pan Africanist Congress (PAC), a South African anti-apartheid group and an offshoot of the ANC.

In another case heard by the commission, World War II veteran Bob Stanford told how he had undergone surgery eight times since he was injured in a racially-motivated 1992 attack by gunmen on a golf club outside East London.

The attack on the King Williams Town club, in which four people died, was one of several believed to have been carried out by the PAC's armed wing, the Azanian People's Liberation Army (APLA).

All sides in South Africa's bloody political struggle were named by the 28 people who gave testimony in the first week of the historic hearings.

But the apartheid security forces, who often used brutal means to combat resistance to the former regime's policies of racial separation, were repeatedly identified as the chief perpetrators of human rights violations.

The hearings marked the beginning of an 18-month search for the truth by the powerful commission, which hopes to unearth the full facts behind all atrocities between 1960 and 1993, the most turbulent of the apartheid years, no matter who the perpetrators or the victims.

The commission started to hold hearings in Cape Town from April 22 before moving on to Johannesburg and KwaZulu-Natal province.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


388 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Namibia Media Body Censures Parliament For Proposed Restrictions


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 29, 1996


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Windhoek - The Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA) based here, has resolved to take Namibian authorities to task over a draft legislation on privileges and immunities of parliament which has been passed by the National Assembly but under debate at a subsequent level.

Authorities named by MISA are the Prime Minister Rt. Hon. Hage Geingob, the Speaker of Namibia's National Assembly, Rt. Hon. Dr. Mose Tjitendero and Hon Kandi Nehova who is the Chairperson of the National Council.

A statement from MISA dated April 22 says, the proposed Privileges and Immunities of Parliament Bill outlaws deliberate and unintentional publication of false information on parliament and its proceedings as included in clause 24 (1) d) of the draft.

The Bill, currently being debated on by the National Council (the Second House) also makes it an offence for anyone to intentionally or negligently publish or disclose any information that has been placed before a committee, prior to it being tabled before the house, as spelt out in clause 24 (1) g). 

Despite the Bill's non-conformity with Namibia's Constitution which guarantees freedom of press, MISA reports that a conviction under the legislation will carry a maximum of N$20,000 (US$5,000) or five years imprisonment.

This south-west African country of some 1.3 million people has seven newspapers -- four dailies and two weeklies.

Reports from MISA say that editors of different newspapers have already written to the authorities calling on the National Assembly and the National Council to ensure that the proposed bill conforms with Article 21 of Namibia's Constitution.

Article 21 guarantees free speech and media freedom as well as international treaties and standards of media freedom and free expression.

However, the editors insist in the letter that clause 24 (1) d) and clause 24 (1) d) of the proposed privileges and immunities of parliament bill be scrapped before it becomes a law.

MISA represents independent media throughout the Southern African Development Committee (SADC) region. Created in 1991, MISA propagates the role played by free pluralistic media in social and political development of any nation.

Meanwhile, MISA reports that The Advertiser reported Michael Hishikushitja, a member of the National Council for the ruling South West African People's Organisation (SWAPO) saying that parliament be empowered to ban journalists who report on classified and leaked information from the select committee.

The April 19 issue of the Advertiser reported that Hishikushitja wanted the ban to apply to anyone including parliamentarians who disclose information from confidential parliamentary documents.

The Advertiser, an independed daily, reported the National Council calling for Parliament's mandate to punish or fine all those found guilty of contempt of parliament.

Reacting to the issue of the proposed bill, human rights lawyer David Smuts told MISA the penal provision of the bill cannot be justified as necessary in a democratic society, adding that the bill will have 'chilling effect' on those reporting government and parliament matters.

Smuts dismissed the draft bill as incompatible with Namibia's constitution which guarantees freedom of press, saying that inaccurate reporting of parliamentary proceedings should not carry stiff penalties.

Another independent daily The Namibian, expressed fear that clause 24 (1) d) will be used against editorial comments on controversial issues as it is not clear who would decide or define what false information is.

Approached for comment by the Advertiser, The Namibian Editor, Jean Sutherland observed; "All information except in few instances like state security should be in the public domain."

Sutherland charged that she does not see anything threatening about information contained in select committee reports even if they are confidential.

MISA further quotes the Editor of The Advertiser, Carol Kotze, saying; "I would find it hard to understand what contempt of parliament could actually be. These people (parliamentarians) were elected by the people and I take it that newspapers are entitled to report what is said in parliament and comment on it."

Kotza was reported saying she felt Hishikushitja was obviously taking a leaf from the 'Zambian book'. On February 23 this year, the Speaker of Zambia's Parliament, ordered the arrest and indefinite detention of two newspaper editors and columnist for contempt of parliament.

The Zambian journalists were charged with contravening the State Security Act for publishing a story in the February 5 Edition of the independent 'Post' to the effect that the government planned to hold a referendum on the adoption of a new constitution.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


389 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Uganda Kampala Recalls Demobilised Troops To Face Guerrillas


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 29, 1996


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Kampala - Faced with an upsurge in guerrilla activity in the north, northwest and the latest cross border raid from Zaire in the southwest of the country, Uganda is recalling 3,000 soldiers who were demobilised two years ago following pressure from the World Bank who wanted Ministry of Defence costs curtailed.

Since last November, there has been an upsurge in guerrilla activity particularly in the north of the country. Between 300 to 400 innocent civilians and scores of rebels and Uganda Peoples Defence Forces (UPDF) men have lost their lives. 

The most active rebel group is Joseph Kony's Lords Resistance Army (LRA) who are remnants of "prophetess" Alice Lakwena's guerrilla force defeated in 1987.

The LRA are led by a former Catholic catechist and are often described by media sources as "fundamentalist Christians".

They have been blamed for the killings of numerous innocent civilians in the north of the country, particularly the districts of Gulu, Apac, Kitgum and Kotido.

Their most daring raid was carried out last February against a convoy of some 20 buses and goods transport lorries under the protection of the UPDF. They killed a number of soldiers and at least 100 civilians before setting most of the vehicles on fire.

Following that attack, an angry President Yoweri Museveni vowed to wipe them out once and for all. He promised the people of Uganda that if Kony did not flee back into Sudan where his bases are located, he would be dead by May this year.

The other rebel group that is reportedly working with Joseph Kony is the West Nile Bank Front (WNBF). It is led by a former Colonel in the army of former President Idi Amin, Colonel Juma Oris. Both Oris and Kony are reported to receive assistance from the authorities in Khartoum, Sudan.

In mid April, an estimated 300 rebels entered the country from Sudan and have engaged the army in sporadic fighting near Pakwach, some 300 kilometres from the capital, Kampala.

Another surprise development is the raid into Uganda by Zaire based ex-Rwanda troops and Interahamwe militia.

On April 22, they struck Kisoro trading post and over-ran a military detachment in the area, killing six people including three UPDF soldiers.

Sources in the UPDF say the 3000 demobilised troops were being engaged through the District Veterans Programme.

Army Reserve Commander, General Salim Saleh, said the men "would undergo fresh drills before being deployed." Salim Saleh is a younger brother of President Yoweri Museveni.

General Saleh defended the decision to re-employ the men saying it was well understood "the veterans are part of the Reserve Force and can be recalled to serve any time."

In the early 90's Uganda had some 120,000 men in the UPDF. This figure was reduced to the current 50,000 under pressure from donor nations.

Meanwhile as we went to press a Lord's Resistance Army spokesman based in Nairobi, Kenya, Dr. Joseph Obito, said the LRA is declaring a ceasefire in their areas of operations in the north of the country which would be effective April 26.

Dr. Obito who was unheard of before on the LRA hierachy, said the ceasefire would allow people in the north of the country to effectively participate in the forthcoming presidential poll on May 9.

The government has not yet commented on the ceasefire announcement which is "conditional on government troops not attacking the rebels."


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


390 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Kenya Official Retract 'Liar' Charge Against Kenyan Bishop


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 29, 1996


LENGTH: 614 words


 

CONFUSION AS STATE OFFICIAL APOLOGISES TO KENYAN BISHOP

NAKURU-KENYA (APS) April 26 - The Provincial Commissioner (PC) in Kenya's Rift Valley Province Mr. Zachary Ogongo, on April 22 issued an ambiguous apology to outspoken Nakuru Catholic Diocese Bishop Ndingi Mwana a' Nzeki after the administrator called the clergy "a liar" two weeks earlier.

The "apology" followed unprecedented pressure from the clergy in Kenya - both Catholic and Protestant -for the Provincial Commissioner (PC) to retract his derogatory remark and apologise to the Bishop.

In a one paragraph statement, the PC in Kenya's largest province said: "For the sake of the comfort of the Bishop who feels his integrity is at stake, I wish to retract my statement to the extent where the matter touches him personally." 

The "apology" is ambiguous and came only a day before the transfer of the PC in the same capacity to Central Province. He has served in the Rift Valley for less than two months.

Moreover the very day the apparent apology was published by the press, the government issued its own statement negating the reconciliation gesture. The government insisted that Bishop Ndingi did not tell the truth about the security situation in Nakuru, some 180 kilometres north-west of Nairobi.

The PC's statement which did not bear the provincial administrator's signature but bore his name at the bottom, was read as a special announcement on the national radio. It described Bishop Ndingi's claims as "alarming, untrue and baseless."

The bishop in a sermon on Easter Sunday said residents living around forest areas in Molo, within the Nakuru Diocese were apprehensive about an outbreak of fresh "ethnic clashes" following the entry of three lorries full of unknown people into the forests of Molo and Njoro.

The Bishop said further that locals had begun to flee in fear of attacks on peasant farmers and cattle rustling had increased.

Similar signs heralded the outbreak of "ethnic clashes" in 1992/1993 when hundreds of peasant farmers lost their lives and thousands of others were displaced. The "clashes" believed to be politically instigated, mainly pitted the Kalenjin tribe against other groups including the Kikuyus and Luhya.

Since his Easter day sermon, overwhelming support for Mwana a' Nzeki has come from a cross section of the nation, including more than 500 priests and bishops from the Catholic and Protestant churches. The clergy urged the government to ensure that law and order prevail in Molo rather than vilify the Bishop.

A plenary meeting of Kenya's Catholic bishops also expressed support for Bishop Ndingi saying nothing short of any apology from the PC would reconcile the Catholic community with the government.

The Catholic bishops said it was not wise for the PC who was new to the area to doubt the remark by Bishop Ndingi who has been based in Nakuru for the past 25 years


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


391 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Africa-at-Large Women Communicators See Little Improvement in Status


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 29, 1996


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Mbabane, Swaziland - Women communicators meeting here from March 31 to April 4 raised concern that African Christian women are likely to see little change from within the mainstream Church by the end of the World Council of Churches (WCC) Ecumenical Decade (1988- 98) marking churches in solidarity with women.

The communicators' workshop attended by 24 women from 13 countries in Eastern, Western and Southern Africa, lamented that generally, church leaders took the Decade's highlights "just like any other issue about women".

"The major issue is not women doing or going about their business without any interference but how to be incorporated within the mainstream and to have a meaningful role to play within the church structures," said a press statement released at the end of the workshop. 

As the meeting reviewed different country reports, participants agreed that although no church leader refused the activities of the decade to take place, the expected support was not forthcoming.

"We expected the church leaders to be fully involved in whatever we do, solidarity as we understood means women working closely with our male counter-parts. But the men have brushed us aside and it is like we are more in solidarity with ourselves than the Church on the whole.

If by the end of this decade we have not seen any serious commitment from our male counterparts, then we have achieved nothing in the last ten years dedicated to us by WCC," said the statement.

The five-day meeting discussed women and the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS); what women have achieved from the WCC Decade and the role of women in communication within the church structures.

It was noted that although there are more women within church communication circles, very few occupy key positions and many lack the necessary training to qualify for higher posts.

The women communicators resolved among other things to; Set up a strong network within the region which will make it easier to know about women activities and to encourage internship programmes with church media organisation to assist the practising women achieve better communication skills.

The communicators also resolved to produce a film on the effects of the International Monetary Fund (IMF)/World Bank Structural Adjustment Programmes (SAPs) on women in Africa.

The workshop was organised by the Harare (Zimbabwe)-based Ecumenical Documentation and Information Centre for Eastern and Southern Africa (EDICESA) on behalf of Africa Communicators' Network. It was sponsored by WCC-Unit IV -- Sharing and Service.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

392 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


United States and Africa (DOCUMENT) U.S. Delinquency Undermines International Programs


BYLINE: Washington Office on Africa April 26, 1996


LENGTH: 2880 words


 

Washington, D.C. - Congressional cuts in U.S. funding for international agencies are having crippling effects on institutions of particular importance to Africa. Unless the United States pays its backlog in overdue assessments, the United Nations may be forced to shut down many of its operations within months. Key UN agencies involved in supporting African development, such as the UN Development Program, are facing drastic budget cuts. The UN peacekeeping budget is also in trouble, with unpaid bills of some $1 billion to countries providing peacekeeping troops, including France, India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Nepal.

In addition, Washington owes almost $1 billion to the World Bank's program of concessional development loans, a principal source of development funds for Africa.

The crisis is so great, and the U.S. responsibility for creating it so clear, that even key U.S. allies such as Britain have suggested a policy of no representation without taxation. Others have suggested that the UN headquarters, which generates an estimated $3 billion in economic activity for the U.S. economy, should be removed to a country with a more mature sense of international responsibility. 

Many members of Congress strongly oppose adequate funding for these institutions. Some are seeking even deeper cuts, and a few openly advocate U.S. withdrawal. The Clinton Administration has proposed funding that would make up part of the arrears and support current programs at modest levels, but it is also pushing for drastic downsizing in many key international programs.

The amounts for these international institutions sound large in comparison to household budgets. But they are tiny compared to U.S. expenditures on other federal budget items. The regular United Nations budget plus the World Bank's soft-loan disbursements to Sub-Saharan Africa (at roughly $1.3 billion and $2.5 billion per year respectively) add up to little more than half of the extra $7 billion Congress tacked on to the $220 billion U.S. military budget last fall.

The entire United Nations system employs fewer people worldwide than the number of Wyoming state employees. There is wide agreement that multilateral institutions do need reform. But given the number of world problems they are being called upon to deal with, they need more resources, not fewer.

African countries are particularly reliant on these international agencies. While African nongovernmental organizations are critical of many international programs, particularly World Bank structural adjustment policies, they have spoken out in favor of continued funding. Multilateral support is essential not only to humanitarian relief and peacekeeping in Africa, but also to investments in education and health, and to building the capacity of African governmental and nongovernmental institutions to address the continent's long-term problems.

Budgeting for the U.S. share of the costs for international organizations falls into several distinct categories. Contributions to the United Nations regular budget, peacekeeping budget, and selected UN agencies are assessed at rates agreed upon in international treaties. Contributions to other UN agencies, as well as to multilateral development banks, are based on voluntary pledges approved by Congress. Almost all these accounts suffered major cutbacks in last year's battles over the fiscal 1996 budget, and they are at risk of still deeper cuts in the 1997 budget currently being debated.

UN Regular Budget

The UN's regular budget supports the operations of the Secretariat, General Assembly, Security Council and other core agencies, such as the UN High Commission for Refugees and the UN Environment Program. It includes funds for publication of Africa Recovery magazine and other information on African economic development. The Economic Commission for Africa is financed from this budget, as are special UN-wide initiatives to support African development.

The UN has already trimmed almost 6% from its projected regular budget for 1996-1997. But UN undersecretary Joseph Connor said early this month that the UN would have to juggle funds by dipping into the peacekeeping budget as early as June. Even so, without new U.S. payments after the U.S. fiscal year begins in October, funds will be totally exhausted by the end of 1996.

U.S. arrears on the regular budget as of mid-April were at least $371 million. We are the only developed country in arrears. In 1994 the United States paid a total of $311 million towards the regular budget. In 1995 and 1996 to date, it has paid only $187 million. By contrast, 41 of the UN's 185 members have already paid their 1996 assessments in full. Countries fully paid up include developed nations such as Italy, Canada, France, and the Netherlands, as well as African countries such as Lesotho, South Africa, Ethiopia, and Namibia.

The Administration's 1997 request to Congress for the UN regular budget is $314 million, $7 million short of what the U.S. owes for calendar year 1996, with nothing for arrears or for the nine months of 1997 before the next fiscal year begins. The budget request also includes $379 million to meet U.S. assessed obligations to agencies such as the World Health Organization and the Food and Agriculture Organization, to which the U.S. owes $130 million.

UN Peacekeeping

In the post-Cold War period, the UN has been called to deal with an unprecedented number of regional conflicts around the globe. Twenty new peacekeeping operations were approved by the Security Council between 1988 and 1993, compared to only 13 during the previous 40 years. At the end of 1995 there were 16 operations under way, with the largest commitments of troops in Angola, Haiti, and Lebanon. The United States provided just over 6% of the troops. The total annual budget grew from less than $200 million in 1986 to nearly $3 billion by 1993.

The assessment rates for UN peacekeeping were agreed in 1973. They are pegged to a country's ability to pay, with an extra 20% for permanent members of the Security Council who have veto power over any peacekeeping operation. The United States has been responsible for 30.8% of total peacekeeping assessments. As of mid-April 1996, Washington was $764 million in arrears.

The U.S. share is equivalent to slightly over 1% of the U.S. military budget. But the payments come not from the cash-flush defense budget but through accounts handled by the State Department, which are among the primary targets of budget cutters. So even the Administration proposal provides only $425 million for peacekeeping in fiscal 1997, including $142 million for arrears.

There are a few other countries with large arrears, notably Russia and the Ukraine. But only the United States, comments Erskine Childers, an expert on the UN system, "is delinquent to this massive extent, in violation of international treaty law, not for reasons of economic difficulty, but because it is withholding its due contributions until every other member country accepts its unilateral demands about UN policies, decision-making and management."

The resultant cash crisis in peacekeeping creates enormous management problems for existing missions, and virtually eliminates the UN's capacity to respond to new crises as they emerge.

World Bank

Critics have strongly faulted the World Bank for imposing rigid structural adjustment policies on developing countries. These programs have all too often had devastating impacts on living standards, with only mixed macroeconomic results. Observers are hoping for somewhat greater responsiveness under new World Bank president James Wolfensohn, who has promised a wider dialogue with nongovernmental organizations and stressed the importance of investment in social development.

While this debate continues, many critics, particularly in Africa, affirm the importance of continued funding at least for the International Development Association (IDA). This branch of the World Bank provides loans for the poorest countries, currently those with per capita income of less than $835 a year. Almost all countries in Sub-Saharan Africa fall into this category. Of $2.4 billion in World Bank lending to Africa in 1995, more than 96% was as IDA loans rather than as standard commercially-backed loans. IDA loans, typically for 35 to 40 years, carry no interest, but only a small service charge.

Roughly half of IDA's funds to Africa support economic reform plans agreed with the World Bank; the rest go to investments in physical infrastructure, government capacity-building, education, population, health, nutrition and water supply. The conditions on which these loans are given, as well as the implementation of specific projects, need ongoing reevaluation. But simply eliminating the funds would cripple many programs essential to African development.

IDA is funded in three-year periods. The United States pledged a total of $3.75 billion for IDA-10 (July 1993-June 1996), of which $934.5 million is still unpaid. The Administration is proposing that the U.S. pay off its obligation to IDA-10 in fiscal 1997 and contribute $800 million a year for the final two years of IDA-11, a 36% reduction from previous levels. Even these limited amounts will be contested in Congress, however. Other developed countries have put up monies for an emergency fund for the first year of IDA-11, in which the U.S. will not participate. U.S. companies will not be eligible to bid on IDA contracts financed by other nations until the arrears are paid.

Voluntary Contributions to UN

The United States makes voluntary contributions to the UN Development Program (UNDP), UNICEF, and several other UN programs. The Administration requested $425 million for these accounts in 1996, but Congress cut this back to only $285 million. The Administration is requesting $325 million for fiscal 1997. UNDP is the UN's lead agency in promoting and coordinating development. With its annual human development reports, UNDP has led a creative rethinking of development in the post-Cold War period. Its offices in many developing countries play a key role in helping to coordinate international efforts. Some $180 million of its approximately $1 billion field program budget goes to African countries.

The U.S. contribution to UNDP for fiscal 1996 was slashed by 56%, to only $52 million. The Administration's 1997 budget proposes restoring the allocation to $78.7 million. This is still significantly less than the amounts provided by Japan, the Netherlands, Denmark, or Germany.

No Significant Savings

Polls show that U.S. public opinion is generally favorable to U.S. contributions to the United Nations and other international institutions. But opponents are able to exploit the fact that most people think the sums involved are far larger than they are.

Cutting U.S. aid to the United Nations achieves no significant savings in the federal budget. Yet if Congress follows the pattern set last year, U.S. international obligations will be under assault as extravagant expenditures. A strong public outcry is essential: the United States should pay what it owes and work to strengthen, not undermine, the international bodies that provide crucial support for peace and development in Africa.

What You Can Do

With the drumbeat of attacks against international institutions setting the tone for debate in Congress, it is essential that Congress and the Administration hear the message that the majority of the American people do not agree with such shortsighted views. You may wish to use the following talking points:

* Payment of U.S. assessments to the United Nations is a legal obligation under treaties this country has signed. U.S. failure to pay is offensive even to many of our closest allies, and will result in loss of U.S. influence and prestige. The U.S. should also pay its fair share of other international programs.

* The amounts spent by international institutions--including the United Nations and the World Bank's IDA--are all relatively small. And the amount the United States is expected to contribute is minuscule in comparison to the U.S. military budget.

* Polls show the U.S. public gives a significantly higher rating (67% favorable) to the United Nations than it does to the U.S. Congress (53% favorable). The majority of the U.S. public does not favor cuts in U.S. support for the UN

* International programs for peacekeeping, development and other areas of international cooperation are absolutely essential for survival and sustainable progress in poor countries around the world, including many on the African continent. Starving these programs is irresponsible, shortsighted, and immoral.

Send your letter to your two Senators and your Representative. You can also send a copy to Sen. Mitch McConnell, chair of the foreign operations subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee, and to Rep. Sonny Callahan, chair of the foreign operations subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee. The Honorable ( ), U.S. Senate, Washington, DC 20510 or U.S. House of Representatives, Washington, DC 20515.

Also send copies to Mr. Anthony Lake, National Security Council, Washington, DC 20500 and to Mr. Warren Christopher, U.S. Department of State, Washington, DC 20520.

For more information on the UN budget crisis, contact the Global Policy Forum, Box 20022, New York, NY 10025. Tel: (212) 501-7435; Fax: (212) 595-8134; E-mail: globalpolicy@globalpolicy.org; Web: http://www.globalpolicy.org/

On the peacekeeping budget, contact the Council for a Livable World Education Fund, 110 Maryland Ave. NE, Washington, DC 20002. Tel: (202) 543-4100; Fax: (202) 543-6297; E-mail: clw@clw.org; Web: http://www.clw.org/

This material is produced and distributed by the Washington Office on Africa (WOA), a not-for-profit church, trade union and civil rights group supported organization that works with Congress on Africa-related legislation. WOA's educational affiliate is the Africa Policy Information Center (APIC), 110 Maryland Ave. NE, #509, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. E-mail: woa@igc.apc.org.

Africa News


April, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Cholera Spreads in Monrovia


BYLINE: World Health Organization (Geneva) April 26, 1996


LENGTH: 280 words


 

Geneva - WHO, together with several partner agencies, has succeeded in delivering fresh supplies of emergency medicines and equipment to the beleaguered Liberian capital of Monrovia, where fighting has left at least 1,450 persons wounded.

Of particular concern is that under the chaotic conditions, a recent outbreak of cholera in Monrovia could quickly spread. 

On Monday, a WHO team confirmed the presence of cholera in the BTC district of Monrovia. Forty-seven cases have also been reported at the IDP compound in Greystone.

A WHO consignment of emergency medicine was airlifted by helicopter from Freetown to Monrovia. The WHO country representative in Liberia is working closely with the Ministry of Health, partner UN agencies and three local nongovernmental organizations to distribute the new supplies to hospitals and health centres in Monrovia and re-organize emergency services.

WHO is also working to limit the spread of cholera and other infectious diseases in the city due to the hazardous water and sanitation conditions, and to strengthen locally available technical capacities to respond to epidemics.

Cholera was also reported from the following countries in the past week: Mali, Niger, Togo and Zaire.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Ebola Outbreak in Gabon Declared Over


BYLINE: World Health Organization (Geneva) April 26, 1996


LENGTH: 174 words


 

Geneva -No new cases of Ebola haemorrhagic fever have been reported in Gabon since the death of the last case on 12 March 1996. The outbreak was therefore officially declared over on 23 April 1996, after a lapse of 42 days corresponding to twice the maximum incubation period. 

The outbreak occurred in the village of Mayibout II, Makokou Health District, Ogooue-Ivindo Province. It was linked to the butchering, transport and preparation for consumption of a chimpanzee found dead in the forest on 24 January 1996.

The total number of cases was 37 (20 males, 17 females) and the mean age was 27 years (range 7 months to 70 years).

Rapid identification of the disease and appropriate control measures quickly brought the outbreak under control.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
