Africa News


April, 1996


South Africa Call for Public Input on Constitution


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) April 26, 1996 by Gaye Davis


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Johannesburg - The Human Rights Committee has asked the Constitutional Court to allow members of the public to appear before it to give their views on the final Constitution, on grounds that much of what has emerged has come out of closed political party negotiations.

The Constitutional Court has set aside the month of June to deal with certifying the final Constitution. It is understood that political parties will be allowed to make submissions as the court considers whether or not the text complies with the 34 principles enshrined in the interim Constitution. 

Human Rights Committee national chairperson Professor Jeremy Sarkin said it was not enough to allow only politicians to address the court. While the Constitutional Assembly had been inundated by public submissions, the amount of influence they had had on the process was open to question.

"Did people who made submissions really make a difference in terms of what the Constitution looks like? When you look at the final draft, it looks like a politicians' document. Was the submission process consultation in theory, or did it allow for consultation in practice?"

An evaluation of the public participation, media, education and plain language campaigns of the Constitutional Assembly carried out in February found that people were more likely to have heard about the Constitution and felt part of the process if they were younger, educated and lived in a town or city than if they were poorly educated, lived in a rural area or were female.

Conducted by the Community Agency for Social Enquiry (Case), the survey sampled 3800 South Africans soon after the draft Constitution was released. Eight percent, or two million adults, had already seen it, while 82%, or 21 million adults, wanted to know more about it.

Case has argued strongly that the education campaign not be halted but be intensified when the final Constitution is launched.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


413 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


South Africa D-Day Looms For Constitution


BYLINE: Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg) April 26, 1996 by Gaye Davis and Justin Pearce


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Johannesburg - Exhausted constitutional negotiators kept smiling -- sometimes grimly -- this week, saying they were on track to meet the May 8 deadline for the adoption of the final Constitution.

But the happy faces barely concealed the reality that the African National Congress and the National Party have finally reached the point of no more compromise on two emotionally-charged issues: single-language schools, and the right of employers to lock out striking workers. Property and language rights have also still to be resolved.

Multilateral talks between the parties continued, with the possibility that parties would submit negotiated amendments, rather than single-party proposals, to save time. While there was speculation that trade-offs could break the logjam, none of the parties was saying so for fear of losing a bargaining position. 

But in a week largely occupied with technicalities and the consolidation of progress made in previous weeks, neither party budged over education and the lock-out, and no more than lip-service was paid to the "spirit of give and take" which has been heralded as the secret ingredient of the progress made in recent months.

For the ANC, the NP demands for the lock-out and single-language schools resonate with the bitter struggles around labour and education in the Seventies and Eighties. For the NP the demands meet an obligation to two crucial constituencies: business, and conservative Afrikanerdom.

ANC negotiator Blade Nzimande sounded despondent about progress on the education clause. "There has been no progress on this issue in the last six months," he said. The solution to the issue would be a formulation of the clause which will allow for the existence of some Afrikaans schools while giving the ANC the guarantee that such schools would not be racially exclusive, yet such a formulation has so far proved elusive.

The NP's Peter Marais said he was "hopeful" about the resolution of the education issue and that it was "a difficult one, because of its emotional content". The Democratic Party has proposed a model which would give a maximum amount of control to the parent body in the running of schools, while maintaining constitutional guarantees against racial exclusivity.

Cosatu representatives were meeting with NP negotiators on Thursday over the lock-out clause. Cosatu and the ANC are standing firm on permitting a compromise in legislation, but not in the Constitution; the NP is resolute it wants constitutional guarantees on the lock- out, education and language issues.

ANC negotiators stuck to the position that the right of businesses to lock out striking workers is not one which is normally entrenched in a Constitution. They are also hopeful that while the NP's position on the lock-out will please the business constituency, it will alienate another important part of the NP support base, the coloured working class, only weeks before the municipal elections in the Western Cape, and that this could cause the NP to buckle on the issue.

At a meeting of the Constitutional Assembly's management committee on Thursday it was decided a flexible approach would apply to tabling amendments. Constitutional Assembly representative Katherine McKenzie said while the deadline was set for noon on Thursday, more amendments were expected the next day.

With the first reading of the Constitution Bill approved in the full Constitutional Assembly on Wednesday night, the Constitutional Committee was set to start considering amendments at 2pm Thursday and would continue from 9am Friday. Another meeting was scheduled for Monday, McKenzie said.

From Tuesday, technical advisers working with the various parties would work on refining the Bill, which would be tabled before a full sitting of the Constitutional Assembly on May 6. Any changes could be dealt with in committee, she said. The deadline of May 8 for the adoption of the Constitution still stood, she said.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


414 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Zambia NGO Activist Resigns


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency April 26, 1996


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Lusaka - The Chairperson of the Non-governmental Organisation Co-ordinating Commitee (NGO-CC) Susan Jere today resigned as chairperson of NGOCC to join the Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) led by Dean Mung'omba.

Speaking at a press conference here, Mrs Jere said that she has decided to join politics to help shape up the destiny of Zambia which needed the perspectives, skills, ideas and knowledge of determined women and men. 

She said that her vision is to channel the women's voting power into a vehicle for changing the women's deplorable condition. She was also responding to the repeated calls for capable and concerned women to come forward and participate actively in the development of Zambia.

Mrs Jere said that although NGOs have been petitioning successive governments in Zambia to end discrimination,exploitation and marginalisation of women for the benefit of the country,the pleas and petitions have fallen on insensitive ears and that the plight of women has continued to be pathetic and has also not been improved at all by the democratisation process ushered in 1991.

She made no apologies for moving from the NGO's world into politics as anyone was free to move from one sector to another. She was proud that she had found a party that has an affirmative policy for all levels.

The vice president of internationaal relations of Zadeco Dr Kasuka Mutukwa welcomed Mrs Jere and extended an invitation to other women and men of substance and capacity to join the party.

Dr Mutukwa said ZADECO is expecting to adopt more women candidates in the 1996 national elecions than any other party adding that Zadeco does not expect UNIP and MMD to do any better as they have continued to marginalise the women.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA

415 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Zambia Lawyers -TELL US ABOUT WITHDRAWN CLAUSES


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency April 26, 1996


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - The Law Association of Zambia (LAZ) has urged government to make public the withdrawal of some unacceptable clauses in the draft constitution before parliament resumes sitting next week.

LAZ Chairman, George Kunda, has also said that it is still not too late for government to provide for a constituent assembly as the only means of adopting the proposed constitutional amendments on consensus. 

Mr Kunda said in a stament today the constitution amendment bill in its present format has some unacceptable clauses on important issues including the independence of the judiciary.

He said LAZ has not seen any form of commitment from government to withdraw the clause on the autonomy of the judiciary despite President Chiluba making an affirmation that such clauses would not be introduced in the draft constitution.

At the annual dinner for LAZ last monthend, Mr Chiluba assured the association that government would not introduce clauses that undermine the independence of the judiciary.

Mr Kunda maintained that his association wants the clause to be removed because it is cognizant of the fact that an autonomous independent judiciary is essential in a democratic society like Zambia.

He said LAZ wishes to make its stand known that should government go ahead and include the contentious clause the association will use the existing law and fight to ensure that the provisions are scrapped from the state books.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


416 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Business and Finance Government To Buy Entire Harvest


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency April 26, 1996 by


LENGTH: 387 words


 

Lusaka - Agriculture, Food and Fisheries Minister, Suresh Desai, today said that the government will this season purchase crops worth k10 billion mostly from rural areas.

Mr Desai told a press briefing here today that the K10 billion would be released by the budget office in good time through the food reserve agency which is aready operational so that crops are not spoiled. 

He said farmers who obtained fertilizers on loan from government stockists under the agricultural credit management programme (ACMP) will be allowed to pay back with maize or other produce.

The total amount due to be recovered from farmers for fertilizer loans under this programme is about K30 billion.

Mr Desai said that apart from the government assisted marketing arrangements, a significant proportion of the total crop will be bought and sold by small scale traders at public markets and by large scale traders who are generating export orders in foreign countries.

''In selling their produce, farmers are reminded to hold back enough for their own household food security and sell only what is surplus to their requirement,'' he said.

He said the ministry has already held discussions with local truckers who have indicated both capacity and willingness to handle the haulage of this years' crop and that government has decided to accord priority to the grading and repair of roads important to the crop marketing and haulage exercise.

Mr Desai said that the national early warning unit in his ministry has forecast a preliminary crop yield of 16,500,000 x 90 kilogrammes bags of maize, 386,200 x 90 kilogrammes bags of sorghum and 573,460 x 90 kilogrammes bags of millet.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


417 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Business and Finance Better Crop Marketing Promised


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency April 26, 1996


LENGTH: 347 words


 

Lusaka - Government has said the appraisal of its past perfomance in crop marketing has resulted in the development of the inventory credit scheme so that the past mistakes and problems are avoided.

Addressing a press briefing in his office here today, Agriculture, Food and Fisheries Minister, Suresh Desai, said government has now found it better to put up a policy to be called the inventory credit scheme aimed at eliminating all problems the crop marketing system faced in the past. 

Mr Desai said the scheme would create a more efficient and problem free crop marketing system which could grow to accumulate sufficient credibility and confidence to attract large scale private sector funding into crop storage and marketing.

He regreted at the same time that in the past two years, the government made funds available to the private sector dealers through the marketing credit revolving fund but its operational modalities were prone to bureaucratic delays, mischanneling of funds and difficulties in effecting repayments.

Mr Desai explained that the inventory credit scheme fund which will be managed by a professional fund manager, supported by one warehouse manager in each of the six marketing zones through out the country, will be able to recover its loans with interest when the trader sells the crop.

The crops that will be eligible for funding under this scheme will be maize, sorghum, millet, sunflower, groundnuts and beans and an initial injection of k12 billion from government has already been set aside for the scheme.

Source: ZAMTODAY-ZANA

LANGUAGE: English

April, 1996


POLICE ACADEMY TO TURN INTO TEACHERS' SCHOOL Zambia


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency April 26, 1996


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Chinsali - Government plans to turn half built Chinsali Police Training College, into a Secondary School Teachers Training College.

Education Deputy Minister, Samuel Miyanda, on Thursday visited the college, whose construction was started by the UNIP government in the 70's and which up to the time of the 1991 multi-party elections had not been completed. 

Mr Miyanda, who inspected the abandoned site yesterday, said the Copperbelt Secondary School Teachers' Training College was to shift to Chinsali once renovations to the infrastructure at Chinsali were completed.

Mr. Miyanda said negotiations between his ministry and the ministry of Home Affairs had been completed adding that the Home Affairs ministry had no objection.

Earlier Senior Inspector of Teacher Training Colleges, James Silwamba, said the COSECO would be moved to Chinsali because the buildings at the current college were cracking uncontrollably.

Mr. Silwamba said the cracking of the buildings at the teachers college had been persistant saying all repair efforts had proved ineffective because he said, the cracks were very unnatural.

During the inspection of the site, the minister was acompanied by many other top education officials who included Provincial Education Officer, Tresphore Bwalya.

The four storey college complex and 20 houses for lecturers about 30 kilometres on the outskirts of Chinsali Boma have seriously been vandalised.

April, 1996


Sports - General Squash: Six Picked For Zimbabwe Open


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 26, 1996 by Brian Malama


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Lusaka - The Zambia Squash Rackets Association (ZSRA) has selected six players to represent Zambia in the Zimbabwe open tournament slated for May 4 and 5 in Harare.

According to sources within the ZSRA, the association has already camped four players in the team that has four boys and only two girls. 

The boys' team includes Bruce Chikabuka, Sydney Mwenechanya, Felix and Lazarous Chilufya while the girls' team comprises national champion, Victoria Chishimba, and Gladys Nonde.

It was decided to send only two girls to the tournament because the level of playing shown by most girls in the country at the moment could not match international standards.

But the ZSRA is broke and is making efforts to raise funds to send the team by Friday next week for the tournament that has attracted the hosts, South Africa, Swaziland, Lesotho, Malawi, Namibia and Zambia.

April, 1996


Business and Finance Bank Quietly Sells Off Gold Reservces


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 26, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela


LENGTH: 320 words


 

Lusaka - Bank of Zambia, facing litigations abroad, has quietly sold off its gold reserves in London.

The last listing of foreign reserves for March shows US$158.452 million, far below the over 100 million pounds the central bank owes to international creditors. 

International banking sources in London revealed that Zambia sold its remaining gold reserves in London last December.

A press query sent to the Bank of Zambia on Wednesday regarding the sale of the gold reserves has not been answered. Instead, Bank of Zambia acting public relations manager, David Kalumba, advised that the information be looked up in the statistics which indicated that Zambia's gross foreign reserves stood at US$158.452.

Kalumba did not provide an answer on the sale of gold reserves nor comment on the bank's frozen assets in London.

The weekly average for the fourth week in April shows internal reserve money in the Bank of Zambia at K54,801 billion.

But the Bank of Zambia is currently facing insurmountable debts through litigations brought by various international creditors.

Meanwhile, donor inflows for the month of March stood at only US$5.107 million.

The penalty rate on treasury bills and bonds has maintained a steady rise from January. It now stands at 73.5 per cent from 50 per cent.

Commercial Banks' weighted lending base rate stands at 50.9 per cent.

Africa News


April, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Red Locusts Invade Zambia


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 26, 1996 by Joe Kaunda


LENGTH: 294 words


 

Lusaka - The Red Locusts invasion has finally hit Zambia, agricultural ministry permanent secretary, Austin Sichinga disclosed in an interview yesterday.

Sichinga revealed that the locusts had crossed over into the country and were reported to be in Sikaonze area in the Southern Province. 

"We have got information that the red-locusts have finally crossed over into Zambia but what I am yet to find out is if they are in their hopper stage or flying stage," Sichinga said yesterday. "But the invasion is mild."

He confirmed receiving the report of the invasion on Wednesday and has started to mobilise aircraft and chemicals to help contain the invasion.

"It is after we find out what stage the locusts have reached that we will know whether we will require aero or ground spraying," he said. "We have already secured helicopters from Zambia Air Force to help in the fight against the pest."

Sichinga assured farmers the spraying will to start immediately.

And commenting on the fight against the Larger Grain Borer (LGB), agriculture minister Suresh Desai said his ministry was bringing in beetles which would wipe out the LGB.

"The beetles will be brought in and bred at Mount Makulu Research Station and we will then send them to the affected areas so that they can start eradicating the pest," Desai said.

Africa News


April, 1996


Ethiopia High Court Hears Prosecutor's Second Witness


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency April 24, 1996


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Addis Ababa - The prosecution witness said yesterday that inmates at a prison in the National Palace were forbidden to read and there was heightened fear and worry every time prisoners were taken out for execution.

The witness who was a civil servant for 17 year during the imperial regime is testifying against the former Derg officials accused of genocide and crimes against humanity. 

The witness, 65 said while being cross-examined by defence lawyers that inmates were allowed to meet relatives only once in a year and made to see sun light for only 30 seconds.

Health services were given only for inmates who were seriously ill, the witness said. According to the witness, religious books, government news papers and books on Socialism were allowed to enter the prison after the International Red Cross Committee had visited the state of the prison.

The witness who said he had been in various prisons of the Derg regime for seven years told the Central High Court the names of 81 out of 89 people who were with him in prison.

The witness said 59 members of imperial cabinet including Tsehafe Tizaz Aklilu Habetwold who were taken out of prison in November 1974 had never returned and he was told of their execution by an official of the Derg government and had also read the story of their legal execution in the Amharic daily Addis Zemen three days latter.

At the end of cross-examination by defence lawyers of the Special Prosecutor s second witness, the Central High Court adjourned session to resume hearing testimonies tomorrow.

423 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Ethiopia Government Establishes Training Centers


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency April 24, 1996


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Addis Ababa - Addis Ababa (ENA) - Prime Minister Meles Zenawi announced here yesterday that 25 training centres would be established through out the country with the aim of producing skilled manpower capable of contributing to the national effort of economic development.

Presenting a six month report to the 27th ordinary meeting of the House of Peoples' Representatives, the Prime Minister said students completing grade 12 would be admitted to the centres to undergo training for 8-10 months.

Prime Minister Meles noted that personnel training, one of the major and decisive factors in the process of building the national capacity, has been given the highest priority in the five-year development programme adding the recently established Civil Service college is making unstilted effort to contribute its share in producing qualified labour to the nation building process.

The college which began training 375 students last year has now increased the number to 507 Prime Minister Meles said, adding it has also finalized preparations to accept next academic year 1,200 students. 

The training capacity of the college would be expanded in the fields of accounting and town planning Prime Minister indicated and said similar trainings would also be given at other higher institutes in an effort to build the capacity of professionals.

According to the Prime Minster the degree level training organized for health officers in Gondar and Jimma towns shall continue in Dilla, South Ethiopia People s Regional State. Preparations have been completed to carry out a geology programme in Makalle, capital of Tigray Regional State, Ato Meles added.

The Prime Minister said 997 woreda executive members are undergoing upgrading courses targeted at arming them with the knowledge and qualification of implementing the five year development programme of the country. The training for executives will also be given at zonal and regional administration levels, he added.

Ato Meles said agricultural production doubled and even in some areas quadrupled as demonstrations indicated at 225 woreda sites embracing not less than 40 thousand farmers. There is a plan, he said, to include in the extension programme 350 thousand farmers in 389 woredas. The programme will also be tested in 104 woredas with inadequate rainfall, Ato Meles said, adding the extension programme will be expanded in all the woredas on the basis of results to be registered in future.

The Prime Minister indicated that 3.6 million quintals of fertilizers bought with 680 million birr were being brought into the country and recalled that the country s fertilizer consumption 3 years ago was below 1 million quintals.

Ato Meles said the Federal Government has provided farmers with a subsidy of 165 million birr to help them withstand the soaring price in the world market of fertilizers.

Encouraging results have been attained in electric line installation, development of telephone services and hydroelectric power construction, he said. The new education and health programmes are being implemented in most of the regions, he added.

In an effort to controlits effect, inflation was reduced from 13.6 percent at the end of last year to 8 percent this year, he said.

Top priorities were given to the consolidation of judicial organs aiming at promoting peace and democracy prevalent in the country, Prime Minister Meles said and pointed out that regions were also organizing their courts anew.

Much has been done this year towards the establishment of a multi national defence force accountable only for the constitution, Ato Meles said adding the national army is being constituted from the armies of political parties in the transition coalition and former soldier as well as recruits.

The defence budget is the lowest both in the world and the African continent as compared to the country s Gross Domestic Product, he said.

There are political tensions in some neighbouring countries though, efforts will be made to make the defence budget compatible with the nation s economic growth, Ato Meles said.

According to the Prime Minister, Ethiopia is promoting good neighbourly relations with Djibouti, Eritrea, Kenya and Uganda while at the same time forging ties with European, American, Asian and Middle East countries.

The measures taken by Ethiopia to prove to the world Sudan's involvement in the attempted assassination here last year of Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak has brought to the country international acclaim, Ato Meles said, adding Ethiopia has been successful in winning international support in the alienation of Sudan from the world community.

The Prime Minister warned that Ethiopia would be forced to take counter measures against Sudanese fundamentalists if they vowed to continue with their destabilising attempts.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

April, 1996


Ethiopia The Week in Brief


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency April 26, 1996


LENGTH: 547 words


 

Addis Ababa - A government official told a meeting of OAU Labour Commission that there was a growing concern over problems of low pay and reduced employment prospects of unskilled workers because of the African economy s stagnation.

In addition he touched on problems of severe and grave indebtedness, mismatch between the prices of imported and exported goods and other problems which were behind Africa's under development.

Death toll reduction

An expert said that practical application of early warning system helped to drastically reduce death toll caused by hunger to less 10,000 in 1993/94 from over one million a decade ago. The expert told a regional training programme that the policy played a significant role in integrating relief with lasting development as a result of food security reserve. 

Cross-examination

Defense lawyers of the former Derg officials on trial wound up their cross-examination of the first witness of the special prosecutor. The witness answered questions posed by 13 defence lawyers including those raised by defendants Captain Begashaw Atalay and Captain Tessema Belay who had dismissed their lawyers.

Fund approved

The Ethiopian Social Rehabilitation and Development Fund's (ESRDF) capacity was boosted when the World Bank approved a 120 million US dollar credit. The credit is planned for the execution of projects undertaken to revitalise institutions that have gone out of operation due to previous droughts and wars and rebuild infrastructure.

Good rains

The National Meteorological Services Agency breathed an optimistic tone when it announced that most Belg-crop producing areas of the country would receive normal and abundant rainfall in April and May. The agency further said the amount and the distribution of Belg or small rains have increased since it started early last month.

Trade mission

A wireless file from the United States Information Service (USIS) revealed that an American trade mission composed of 30 American representatives will visit Ethiopia from May 5 to May 10.

An official of the Corporate Council in Africa (CCA), which sponsored the 26-company investment mission, told a gathering of officials and trade representatives that he was enthusiastic about the mission because "the Ethiopian people have been involved in business ever since Moses parted the Red Sea."

LANGUAGE: English

425 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Zambia Profile: What Makes Emily Sikazwe Tick?


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia April 19, 1996 by Godson Machona


LENGTH: 1134 words


 

Lusaka - Mention the name Emily Sikazwe to many Zambians who know her very well - particularly those in the Women's Lobby group - the reaction is immediate. There is no doubt, Emily, the executive director of the Women for Change, a Non-Governmental Organisation (NGO) working with rural communities using gender analysis as a foundation for women's empowerment and social change, is a woman whose personality reveals positive comments.

"Our objective as Women for Change is to identify and support marginalised women in Zambia, conscientise them about their rights and encourage them to start income generating activities," she says.

Women for Change also offers training in leadership, simple book keeping, project planning and implementation. According to Emily, the first step to empowering women is to ensure that they have the freedom to discuss, share and, ultimately, gain control over their lives. "Empowerment can only begin with participation," she says. "Through which the women gain commitment, mature understanding and confidence in themselves." 

So far, her organisation has assisted women in the Gwembe valley and Magoye East in Southern Province, Sichili and Senanga East in Western Province and Mumbwa in Central Province. "Our field workers live in these areas for three out of four weeks so that they know the communities well," she claims. "They listen to the communities, understand their problems and assist them to find solutions."

But unfortunately her work has been misconstrued by certain people, especially politicians who see it as the work of a frustrated woman whose only aim is "to confuse the womenfolk."

But she is unruffled. "I have always questioned injustice from the time I was a child," she explains, "I never grew up in a family where girls were treated as second class citizens and that did a lot to shape my character."

Emily attributes her philanthropic character to her late grandfather. "My grandfather was a very just man. He used to insist that his workers were fed first before his family ate," she claims, adding that when his fishing boats returned "he would give the catch from the first boat to the orphans, the aged and widows".

But why is she so carried away with women's rights? "Women constitute 51 per cent of our population. You don't expect them to be spectators in the development of society," she says, adding: "Women do 80 per cent of the work yet its the men who enjoy the rewards. For me, it is a challenge to remove this injustice. There is no way we can continue with a system that uses women as beasts of burden."

She gets upset when people (read politicians) trivialise the gender issue. "There is nothing romantic about gender issues, it's about life," she says.

Emily attributes her fighting spirit to her mother who was related to the late Malawian politician, Dunduza Chisiza. "My mother used to be detained for being related to Dunduza and I spent numerous occasions in prison with her," she claims.

She continued living with and seeing victimisation at various levels of society.

When she joined the Lint Company of Zambia (LINTCO), as an agronomist, she was never accepted, she says, "because I was a woman". "I had a Masters degree but they made it a point that I was oppressed," she says. "This is why I will never stop to challenge conventional attitudes and beliefs that inhibit women's full participation in the development of society."

Little wonder, in 1991 she was recommended for early retirement. "I wasn't suprised. I expected it because I used to speak my mind," she says. "In 1987 I made management release all the women so that we could participate in the International Day for Women. It was the first time that such a thing had ever happened."

After LINTCO, she joined Care International on contract. "I helped with identification of projects in rural areas, such as the rehabilitation of water wells and dams in the Southern Province," she says.

In 1992, she saw an advertisement in one of the local newspapers for the position of executive director at the Women for Change. She quickly applied for the post. As executive director, she is responsible for the day to day running of the organisation. "I do a lot of fund raising, network with government ministries and other NGO's within Zambia and the region. I source and compile information for building awareness of gender, women's and participatory education issues," she says.

Despite the general belief about her activities, 42-year-old Emily refuses to be categorised as a feminist. "I just believe in gender equality. Infact, that's what keeps me fueled up," she says.

She adds that her belief in social justice is what gives her the energy to forge ahead. "When people talk about human rights they are talking about social justice," she says. "A wrong is a wrong, be it gender, sustainable development, politics or economic policies. I have got a certain vision and I think that vision is what gives me energy."

Emily believes there is no excuse for denying rural communities basic needs on the pretext that "government has got no money". "They don't need government's money. Create an enabling environment in the rural areas. Build good roads, schools, hospitals and give them clean tapped water and they will survive," she says.

But who is Emily Sikazwe? "I am simply an independent woman who knows her rights," she says.

And you know why she ticks? She says "I can walk into a bar and sit at the counter without batting an eye lid."


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


426 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Arts, Culture and Entertainment (DOCUMENT) African Environmental Videos Released


BYLINE: DSR, Inc. (Columbia) April 25, 1996


LENGTH: 627 words


 

Columbia - A series of short videos showing eight different environmental projects in Africa is now available.

Africa's wild lands, pristine coasts and coral islands can only be preserved by Africans. The video "Tanzanian Features," gives hope the continent's greatest ecological treasures can be saved. It tells of the speed and magnitude of the destruction of the continent's wild lands, which are often spiritual homelands to Africa's people. 

When wild lands were made into national parks, governments would often forcibly remove whole villages from the newly created national park lands, breeding bitterness and dispossessed poachers. The video shows the efforts by the World Wildlife Federation and African governments to constructively involve the people in conservation and profitable businesses based on renewable resources.

During the creation of Nyka National Park in Malawi, thousands of indigenous people were forcible resettled. At first the only local people who profited from the national park were poachers. But bee-keeping had always been an important traditional economic activity before the land was made into a national park. The WWF and the Malawi government allowed people living around the park to re-establish bee-keeping. With the introduction of appropriate very accessible technology honey and bee's wax have become cash crops which have produced prosperity for many local people.

In Madagascar important life-saving medicines have been derived from the land's abundant and diverse flora. But only the international pharmaceutical companies have profited.

A WWF project is providing training in western pharmacology as well as indigenous herbalogy. The intent of the project is to create a local pharmacological industry, and to create a clinic where local herbalists and western trained scientists will work together to develop drugs for international markets.

The growing population of Africa continues to press on the continent's last wild lands and pristine coastal resources. These ecological treasures can be saved if Africans can use these places' renewable resources and are able to once again find their way to their spiritual homelands.

"Africa and Tanzania Features" -- Africa Features: The Bazaruto Archipelago: Saving a Coastal Eden - 7 minutes; Sweet Success: Beekeeping in Malawi - 7 minutes; The Kayas: Kenya's Sacred Groves - 8 minutes; Zambia's Kafue Flats - 8 minutes; Malawi: Land of the Lake - 6 minutes; Madagascar: Wild Drugstore - 5 minutes.

Tanzania Features: Udzungwa Mountains - 7 minutes; Mafia Island - 7 minutes.

Video available in English, VHS, NTSC and PAL (US$19.95/$39.95). Total running time 55 minutes. Produced by World Wide Fund for Nature International (WWF).
Available from DSR, Inc., 9111 Guilford Road, Columbia, MD 21046, USA. Email: dsr@us.net Phone: (301)490-3500, (410)792-4913. Web: http://www.catalog.com/dsr.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

April, 1996


Zambia Election Office Okays Clear Boxes


BYLINE: Zambian News Agency April 23, 1996


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Lusaka - The Elections Office is ready to allow the use of transparent ballot boxes in the forthcoming parliamentary and presidential elections as long as funds to purchase them are made available.

Director, Rabson Mwansa, says in Lusaka today that there was nothing difficult about using transparent ballot boxes because other countries such as France do use them. 

He said that the whole process would be made possible if funds to buy the 10,000 ballot boxes needed for all polling districts are available.

''If someone gives us the funds to buy the 10,000 ballot boxes needed for all the polling districts, we would definately allow the use of the transparent ballot boxes,'' he said.

Mr Mwansa's remarks come in the wake of calls by the Zambia Democratic Congress who say that they would campaign for the use of transparent ballot boxes in the forthcoming general elections so that frauds and other malpractices are minimised.

ZDC believes that the use of transparent boxes would tramendously reduce tension which exist when the ballot boxes are being transfered from one place to another.

Africa News


April, 1996


Business and Finance Energy Shortfall Predicted


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 25, 1996 by Goodson Machona


LENGTH: 520 words


 

Lusaka - Despite the heavy rains last year, Zambia will record a 10 per cent shortfall on it's energy reqeuirements this year, Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation (ZESCO) director of generation and transimission, John Wright, has said.

According to Wright, Zambia needs a total energy supply of 7,825 mega watts but the energy situation forecast for the same period shows that only 7,091 mega watts of electricity would be harnessed.

"This shortfall represents 100 mega watts of energy, which is equivalent to the Victoria Falls, hydro electricity operations," Wright said. "The only way of dealing with this deficit is by energy conservation, importation of energy from Zaire and optimising water management." 

Other measures include improving efficiency and introducing a quota system.

"In order to manage conservation, we would need to correct the power factor, switch off unnecessary loads and encourage off-peak operation," Wright advised.

Meanwhile, ZESCO managing director Robson Mwansa has conceded that his company is inefficient.

Mwansa was responding to a complaint by a consumer, Alfred Mushinga, during a tariff symposium which was held at Lusaka's hotel intercontinental yesterday.

"Yes ZESCO is inefficient. The fact that we have a $3 billion investment and only manage a $100 million turn over annualy which means we are inefficient," Mwansa said, adding: "We are not where we should be."

But he assured the participants that management was working out ways to change this position.

"There is need to change the attitude of our workers. There is definitely need for complete change of mind set," Mwansa said.

And distribution and customer relations director Griver Sikasote said the new tarrifs which are being advertised will be effected on May 16, and will remain the lowest in the region.

He said over 80 per cent of ZESCO's operations are foreign driven, and for ZESCO to survive the high inflation rate at 63 per cent, it has to increase its tarrifs.

"We are very conscious of the way we move our tarrifs, we want to increase, and improve on the service we provide," Sikasote said, adding, "the current tarrifs are very subeconomic, and cannot sustain ZESCO as a viable company."

Sports - General Zambia: Volleyball Academy Lauded


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 25, 1996 by Brian Malama


LENGTH: 254 words


 

Lusaka - The Volleyball Academy at the Copperbelt University has impressed the International Volleyball Federation (FIVB) which has agreed to open up the centre for operations this June.

Visiting programmes co-ordinator Lars Haue- Pedersen, who is in the country to inspect the proposed centre, said he was happy with the existing infrastructure but is yet to present his report to his bosses in Switzerland for approval. 

"It will now depend on the superiors of the FIVB to give a green light," he said.

Zambia Amateur Volleyball Association president, Richard Kachingwe, said players would greatly benefit from the initiative which the FIVB is expected to fund, providing all the necessary equipment.

CBU dean of students Patrick Chunda who is also chairman of Southern Africa Zone Six Universities Sports Association said he was overwhelmed by the gesture especially that the centre would be within the university grounds whose volleyball courts have been lying idle for a long time.

Pedersen is this morning expected to meet sports minister Patrick Kafumukache to sign a sports agreement.

430 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Zambia Tackle Violence From Broader View (Editorial)


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 25, 1996


LENGTH: 440 words


 

Lusaka - Stories of violence against women and child abuse in this country are unending.

What is most worrying, as the judges observed yesterday, is that violence against women, despite efforts to address it, has continued to be on the increase in most parts of the country.

But this scourge must not be viewed in isolation from other crimes in the country. There are so many factors influencing abuses against humanity. 

Crimes are occurring as a result of archaic beliefs and practices, poverty, mental complexes, drug addiction or other reasons.

We should therefore have no illusions about easy solutions to this problem.

What we are dealing with are attitudes, and traditional values which have variant histories and which require a lot of effort to reverse.

The women folk may have been abused more due to several considerations including physical strength.

This one fact underlines the need for society to be sensitive to the plight of women. Not because they are lesser human beings but that realism demands that we be conscious of the physical abilities of both man and woman. After all most abuses have involved physical violence.

Legislation and its correct implementation is vital as the judges who constituted the panel at yesterday's women tribunal observed but this alone will not help. Increased awareness on the subject targeted at attitude change will be a bigger benefit than penal action.

It is important to recognise that such awareness needs the right target groups. The worst perpetrators of such violations may not always be the few that sit in hotel seminars on Women on violence.

Similarly we need to recognise that the most effective way of fighting this is also to engage in active work that helps reverse our economic malaise. We need to accept that economic and social progress in our country is tied to correct political policies and thinking. We should therefore not be pathetic to governance issues surrounding us. All these problems are interrelated.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


431 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Zambia Donor Pressure Affecting Elections Ruling


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 25, 1996 by Chilombo Mwondela, Mervin Syafunko and Masautso Phiri


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Lusaka - The government may be bowing to donor and local pressure over some clauses in the new constitution and may allow former President Kenneth Kaunda to contest this year's presidential elections.

Diplomatic sources revealed in Lusaka last week that the donor community has received firm government assurances that Kaunda would not be barred from contesting this year's elections.

The sources said however that government may retain the citizenship clause in the constitution but it will not be effective until after this year's general elections. 

"We have been assured by the government that the former president will not be barred," the diplomatic sources said. "They have insisted the parental clause will be passed but will not be effective until after the elections."

President Chiluba told the annual general meeting of the Evangelical Fellowship of Zambia that his government has had to give in to donor pressure before being granted financial aid because "donor aid is not free" and has "strings attached".

"Those who give this support also demand something in return and we see them start influencing our political livelihood," the president said.

And chief government spokesman Amusaa Mwanamwamba suggested last week that Kaunda would not be barred from contesting the elections "so long he satisfied minimum qualification requirements for his candidacy."

But in an interview yesterday Mwanamwambwa described the news of government assurances as unfounded rumours.

"I as government spokesman I am unaware about that and it is a surprise to me, who is circulating such rumours even before parliament resumes sitting because everything will be resolved by parliament," Mwanamwambwa said.

By Tuesday this week, however, government position on Kaunda appeared confused with Health minister and MMD national secretary Michael Sata giving contradictory statements within two days.

Sata said on Tuesday that government would allow Kaunda to stand only to reverse it the following day claiming he was misunderstood.

Kaunda was to be barred by a clause defining a citizen as one being born on Zambian soil from Zambian parents also born on Zambian soil.

Although he was himself born in Zambia, Kaunda's parents are of Malawian origin.

Diplomatic sources have mentioned Sata as one of the ministers who has made the assurances to donors.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April, 1996


Zambia Violence Against Women Cases Shock Judges


BYLINE: The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) April 25, 1996 by Sundie Sinkala


LENGTH: 334 words


 

Lusaka - A panel of four judges and a state counsel were yesterday shocked at the high level of violence against women and child abuse in the country after hearing testimonies from some of the victims.

Judges Bobby Bwalya, Sandston Silomba, Peter Chitengi, Florence Lengalenga and lawyer Edward Shamwana, sitting as a second tribunal organised by the Young Women's Christian Association also attributed violence against women to a corrupt police force. 

They endorsed the recommendations by the first tribunal of 1993 on the need to address violence against women.

Reading the verdict after hearing the moving testimonies of five women, including a 14-year-old girl who underwent different ordeals, Judge Bwalya said the situation had not changed.

He attributed the mistreatment of women and children to ignorance among the members of the society who failed to report such incidents and in certain cases failed to exhaust the judicial processes.

"From the five testimonies we have so far heard, it is clear that the situation on violence on women and child abuse hasn't changed much", he said.

Judge Bwalya cited the other reasons for the continued women abuse to downright corruption in the manner the cases were handled by the police.

The pannel also observed that most local court justices were mishandling cases women violence by failing to deal with them conclusively.

He challenged women and people in general to end the practice by educating society and further urged individuals to take up such cases to courts.

Africa News


April, 1996


United States and Africa (DOCUMENT) Law Group Opposes U.S. Visa for Mobutu


BYLINE: International Human Rights Law Group April 26, 1996


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

Washington, D.C. - The following letter was sent by the International Human Rights Law Group, a Washington, DC -based human rights organization, to President Jimmy Carter on April 19, 1996.
I understand that you are currently considering the possibility of holding the third summit meeting of the heads of state of the Great Lakes region in Atlanta this May. While the International Human Rights Law Group greatly appreciates your efforts to promote reconciliation in the Great Lakes region, we believe that inviting President Mobutu Sese Seko to the United States at this time would be inappropriate given his continued efforts to obstruct the transition to democracy in Zaire. I urge you, therefore, to consider alternatives to his physical presence at the Atlanta meeting. I understand, for example, that because of elections in Uganda, President Museveni may participate in the summit by teleconference. I would encourage you to consider a similar arrangement for President Mobutu. 

As you know, President Mobutu is barred from obtaining a U.S. visa under the terms of a Presidential proclamation of June 23, 1993, which directs the Secretary of State to deny a visa to anyone obstructing the democratic transition in Zaire. The visa sanction unambiguously expresses US disapproval of President Mobutu's continuing efforts to undermine Zairian democratization and remains the only effective measure applied by the United States that specifically targets the President and his entourage without punishing the Zairian people at large. The sanction is widely supported by Zairian human rights organizations and other civil society groups. Relaxing the visa sanction now would only convey US acquiescence to President Mobutu's continuing obstructionism at a time when upcoming Zairian elections demand an unambiguous US stance.
Your joint declaration with President Mobutu at Faro last September addressed our concerns that President Mobutu would manipulate efforts to promote regional reconciliation in order to end his international isolation while continuing to bloc meaningful democratic transition within Zaire. President Mobutu, however, has not respected these minimum commitments that he made at Faro, nor has he honored his broader obligations under the Zairian Constitutional Act of the Transition.

The Law Group's greatest concern is that President Mobutu has not taken meaningful steps to ensure the neutrality of the Zairian security forces, despite his commitment to do "everything possible to ensure confidence in the election procedures and results." Neutrality of the security forces is widely regarded as an essential pre-condition to successful elections. President Mobutu has instead tightened his control over the security forces and used them to intimidate individuals and groups working to promote popular participation in the electoral process. For example:
* On November 14, 1995, soldiers from SARM, the military intelligence service, arrested Mr. Kabila Kakule for having translated the official documents of the Sovereign National Conference, including the draft constitution, into Zaire's four national languages at the request of the High Council of the Republic/Parliament- in-Transition. SARM confiscated all copies of the translations and detained Mr. Kakule for six weeks.
* On November 21, 1995, soldiers from SARM arrested Mr. Batabiha Bushoki, the President of a local human rights organization in Goma, because he greeted and hoped to meet with you during your visit to Goma. Ignoring orders from the Regional Governor and the Minister of External Relations to release Bushoki, SARM officers continued to detain Mr.Bushoki until President Mobutu personally interceded nine days later.
* Rather than submit to the authority of the civilian government as required by the transition constitution, the Civil Guards have increasingly linked their activities to SNIP, the national intelligence service. Consequently, they remain unaccountable to anyone except President Mobutu himself.
President Mobutu made an additional commitment at Faro to thoroughly investigate the violent repression of a peaceful PALU (Unified Lumumbist Party) demonstration by the security forces on July 29, 1995. He also promised to pursue appropriate legal action against those responsible. The Voix des Sans Voix (Voice of the Voiceless), a Zairian human rights group, confirms that to date there has been no official inquiry nor has any legal action been initiated. Meanwhile, PALU officials filed suit against the authorities several months ago, but are still awaiting action by the Procureur General de la Republique.
Although President Mobutu repeatedly expressed his willingness to cooperate with international efforts to facilitate the repatriation of the Rwandan refugees in Zaire, his concrete actions have been less than encouraging. At Faro and subsequent meetings, President Mobutu promised to separate intimidators from the broader refugee population in the camps in eastern Zaire. To date, however, he has identified only a handful of such intimidators. Moreover, President Mobutu has not honored his promise to allow arms inspectors to be posted at the Goma Airport to stop the flow of arms to the Rwandan refugees. In fact, President Mobutu refused to authorize the visit of a group of UN experts investigating flow of arms into the Great Lakes region. Finally, the Law Group is very concerned over Zairian efforts to strip Zairians of Rwandan origin (Banyamulengue) of their Zairian citizenship and expel them to Rwanda.
Despite repeated promises not to obstruct his country's transition to democracy, including those made at Faro, President Mobutu continues to do just that. His visit would engender criticism, demonstrations and certain embarassment for the administration. It would be unfortunate to reward his intransigence with the international legitimacy a visit to the United States would bestow.

Signed, Gay J. McDougall Executive Director International Human Rights Law Group.
cc: The Honorable Anthony Lake, Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs; George E. Moose, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
