Africa News


April, 1996


United States and Africa (DOCUMENT) West Africa Seeks U.S. Military Deployment in Monrovia


BYLINE: Friends of Liberia April 25, 1996


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 747 words


 

Washington, D.C. - Friends of Liberia has learned that Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings, chairman of the Economic Community of West African States, has requested that President Bill Clinton deploy U.S. military forces and provide other resources to help the ECOWAS West African peacekeeping force restore security to Monrovia.

Dr. Mohamed Chambas, Ghana's Deputy Foreign Minister, speaking from Accra, said President Rawlings had made the request for U.S. military assistance through diplomatic channels. The request, according to Chambas, is for a short- term commitment of American troops on the ground until ECOMOG, the West African peacekeeping force, can effectively resume its role. U.S. Special Envoy Dane Smith is expected in Accra on Monday for a meeting with President Rawlings. 

Kevin George, president of Friends of Liberia, an 800-member group of Americans who espouse a democratic resolution to Liberia's civil war, said "the presence of a U.S. security force, in Africa's most pro-American country, is viewed by President Rawlings as absolutely necessary for the purpose of restoring calm, protecting relief programs and preserving order in Monrovia." George said the extraordinary nature of such a request underscores the desperate needs of Liberians and their West African neighbors. "For President Clinton to decline this request will not only lead to unnecessary further tragedy in Monrovia, but also greatly exacerbate the decay of U.S. influence in all of West Africa at a time when our foreign policy objectives ostensibly call for peace and democracy."

Fighting erupted April 6 in the capital city of Monrovia, previously a safe- haven for one-million Liberians, after a standoff between factions at the edge of the city escalated into a full-scale street battle. ECOMOG forces had been unable to contain the face-off between small groups of combatants representing members of the ruling council and those of an ousted minister. As the peacekeeping operation fell apart, rival factions conducted a running battle and looted homes and businesses. The fighting finally centered on an army barracks compound, where some 45,000 civilians were holed up. Casualties mounted as the militias representing two ruling council members bombed the seaside barracks. Mediation over the past weekend by envoys from the United States and Ghana, coupled with the arrival offshore of a U.S. naval flotilla carrying over 1,800 Marines, has helped bring about a tenuous cease-fire.

The heads of seven U.S. organizations -- Africare, Trickle Up, International Rescue Committee, Service and Development Agency, United Methodist Committee on Relief, World Relief, and the Women's Commission for Refugee Women and Children -- signed with Friends of Liberia a letter urging President Clinton to extend U.S. military protection to relief efforts in Monrovia. They cited the outbreak of disease and dwindling supplies of potable water as signaling the potential for a "humanitarian disaster of monumental proportions."

The organizations pointed out that the history of ties to this longtime U.S. ally, with its distinctly pro-American society, assures that humanitarian intervention by the United States will be welcomed not only by Liberians, but by the West African nations that created the peacekeeping force to prevent a regional conflagration.

President Rawlings is expected to make a similar case to U.S. Special Envoy Smith in their meeting next week and at an ECOWAS Heads of State Summit on May 8. Rawlings said recently in Ghana that the West African peacekeeping troops, at their current strength of 8,000, are inadequate to effect the type of security relief workers need to reintroduce order in the city.

For further information, contact Kevin George, 703-528-8345, Fax: 703-528 -7480. P. O. Box 28098, Washington, D.C. 20038.


LOAD-DATE: April 29, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


435 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Somalia Violence On The Upsurge


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 24, 1996 by Corinne Archer


LENGTH: 1945 words


 

Mogadishu - One never knows what is going to happen next in Mogadishu. Everything is unorthodox, from the moment the twin-engine plane touches down on a beach strip some 30 kilometres north of the city to the jolting ride through sand dunes until arrival at the once- beautiful Indian Ocean idyll.

The dusty route passes alongside kilometre upon kilometre of sandy beaches lapped by the blue ocean waters. Paradise, if one ignores the five armed guards crouching in the back of the truck, numerous roadblocks and prolific gun-toting Somalis. 

Guns and people increase as one approaches the centre of the devastated city, north of the American imposed "green line" dividing Mogadishu between Somali's two major warlords: Ali Mahdi Mohammed in the north and his arch rival in the south, General Mohammed Farah Aideed. Fighting is sporadic at the moment, but the city is like a tightly coiled spring and tension mounts as one approaches the border between the two halves.

Since the north imposed the deterrent Islamic Sharia law - which punishes crime by flogging, amputation or death - and an order banning the carrying of weapons, the situation has eased somehow in that part of the city. There is a degree of normality as people go about their daily business amid the bullet-scarred ruins of formerly elegant buildings.

But the atmosphere is more menacing in the south where Aideed has armed his militias to the teeth and introduced a "tax" on goods entering the area, enforced by Kalashnikov-carrying toughs who man the collection points.

The demarcation line is probably the most inflammable area of the city and totally unpredictable. One can sail unhindered between the two halves one day, but the next come face to face with a hostile crowd brandishing and loading guns, before pointing them threateningly at the vehicle. It is a war of nerves. On one hand it may just be a case of sabre-rattling, but on the other, thugs are liable to pull the trigger without warning.

To all intents and purposes the world has left Somalia to get on with it, despite a reaffirmation by the United Nations which finally pulled out its troops early last year, of its commitment to the country. Last February, a fact-finding mission held talks with both Aideed and Ali Mahdi during which the latter appealed for more humanitarian aid, saying he feared renewed famine if Somalia remained internationally isolated.

Aid agencies left a long time ago, hot on the heels of the abortive 1992-95 United States and UN missions to restore peace to the country. A handful of relief agencies operate north of the green line.

In the south, only one organisation remains. SOS Children's Villages - a non-governmental organisation which was in place long before the civil war broke out in 1991 - runs the only properly functioning hospital in the entire city, caring mainly for children. Its wards are full of pot-bellied infants suffering from severe malnutrition, malaria, cholera and tuberculosis. Hundreds of mothers throng the gates daily seeking help for their children.

The former children's hospital, Benadir, has become an Aideed clan hospital. And the so-called state hospital, Digfer, also in the south is drab, dingy and barely functioning. Otherwise private clinics exist for the rich.

The international airport and main harbour are insecure and therefore in-operational, so food and medical aid have to be trucked in from private air strips and ports to the north and south of the city, heightening the danger of attacks and looting.

In an anarchic situation, every possibility can be exploited, including the provision of power, water and telecommunications which again only the very rich can afford. Most people go without.

The wealthy are also setting about reconstructing parts of the shattered city. Here and there, lavish villas are being restored to their former glory - signs of opulence amid the ruins. Not far from the former UN and US compounds, now plundered and destroyed, work was under way to rebuild a palatial four-storey residence set among palm trees and vibrant bougainvillae.

At Mogadishu's sprawling Bakara market anything can be acquired for a price. Besides serving as a huge open air arms bazaar, Bakara is the place to find passports, degree certificates or money changers who can come up with thousands of US dollars within minutes.

Opportunists, it seems, abound. A local mullah gets louder. "Probably through a looted sound system," residents remark stoically.

War weary Somalis have had their hopes raised and dashed so many times since the start of this decade that they are cynical about peace. Aideed, chasing his cherished dream of becoming Somali president, could not wait and declared himself Somali leader last June. At the moment, he is concentrating his militias outside Mogadishu, in the Baidoa and Kismayo regions, which has given the city a brief respite, but the anarchy now raging has become endemic.

In-clan fighting is complicated by squabbles among sub-groups belonging to the same family. People kill and maim with impunity. Reason lies in the barrel of a gun or the flick of a knife. In one incident, a young man had his throat slit form ear to ear in an argument over the equivalent of 50 US cents, a reminder that violence is always prevalent and that the absence of all-out fighting should not lull one into a false sense of security.

As the intricate politics of the country become more and more entangled with news of defections from Ali Mahdi's Abgal clan to Aideed's side, killings of prominent personalities who do not appeal to one side or the other are on the rise and the chances of a national reconciliation government are pretty remote. Many Somalis believe the answer to the country's problems lies in the creation of regional governing councils along clan lines, but influential businessmen have no interest in seeing an end to the conflict and as usual the powerful warlords will not relinquish their power bases without a fight.

By the time of going to press, three Somali political organisations and movements in the Kenyan capital , Nairobi, on April 15 announced the formation of a consultation group that aims to seek a peaceful solution to their war-wrecked nation of an estimated population of 7 million people.

Led by Mr. Mohammed Awale, international relations secretary for the United Somali Congress (USC) and Somali National Alliance (SNA), the Somali factions meeting during a four-day consultative conference on the crisis at home, decried the suffering of the people of Somalia as a result of continued disagreements among the various factional leaders and the overriding factor that there is no government in place.

Mr. Awale and his team comprising among others, Yusuf Mohamed of the Somali National Democratic Union, Mr. Mohamed Abdi of the Union of Somali Peoples, Mr. Abdullahi Bashir of the Union of Somali Roots and Abdurahman Hassan, representing the Somali Salvation Democratic Front, hoped to deliberate on ways and means of establishing


LOAD-DATE: April 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


436 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


d Science, Medicine and Technology Few Gains From Aids Research For Africa


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 24, 1996 by Wafula John


LENGTH: 1520 words


 

Nairobi - As the world researchers intensify efforts to seek treatment for the dreaded Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) with an arsenal of palliative drugs and potential vaccines, sub-Saharan Africa, home to about 70 per cent of the world's estimated 15.5 million sufferers, is disturbingly removed from the scene of serious research and runs the risk of benefiting least from ongoing findings.

Media sources say that today, 15 years into the AIDS pandemic, patients have the promise of controlling the deadly HIV virus that results in AIDS, "thanks to a sudden influx of new drugs unlike that ever marshalled against any other disease before."

Gordon Nary, executive director of the International Association of Physicians in AIDS Care is quoted saying, "it is such an extraordinary time of both discovery and hope. For many people today with HIV, there is a very good possibility."

The good possibility alluded to lies in the fact that these new drugs, called protease inhibitors, "attack the HIV virus that causes AIDS differently from all other medicines, and the two newest ones, Hoffman Laroche's Saquinavir and Abbot Laboratories more powerful Indunavir can almost eliminate virus Lurking in patients' blood." 

The bad news is that these drugs have been developed by private researchers and are not tailored for the poor sub-Saharan patient who heavily depends on poorly equipped public health facilities.

AIDS patients, until now had five choices: AZT, DDI, DDC, D4T and 3TC. All reportedly worked the same way, targeting an enzyme called reverse transcriptase that is important if HIV is to reproduce. But the drugs are said to have helped only modestly, and HIV quickly mutates to resist them.

Scientists specifically designed drugs to target a second enzyme, protease, that is vital to another key step in the reproduction of HIV.

When combined with older medicines, the two most powerful protease inhibitors can cause the amount of HIV floating in many patients' blood to plummet by up to 98 per cent. However, caution is given that HIV still lurks elsewhere in the body. Thus, the drugs are not a cure.

With various reports about new developments against the dreaded killer AIDS, sub-Saharan Africa is nowhere near benefiting from the emerging AIDS therapies, primarily because of the prohibitive costs of the newly developed drugs. Treating HIV as a chronic disease, says executive director of the International Association of Physicians in AIDS, Gordon Nary, could cost each patient 250,000 US dollars. Adding shipment costs and the profits to be made off sub- Saharan patients, the cost of such drugs would be prohibitive by the time they reach African patients.

London based PANOS Institute in its February 1996 Media AIDS Information sheet states that the best medical solution to the AIDS epidemic in sub-Saharan Africa, and indeed for the rest of the developing world, lies "in the development of a vaccine, rather than a cure, according to an increasing number of scientists."

The report further argues that a vaccine is likely to be less expensive than a drug treatment and may only need to be administered once.

Three developing countries; Thailand, Brazil and Uganda agreed to conduct trials of experimental vaccines developed in the United States of America. But whereas these trials have been going on in Thailand since 1995, the Ugandan tests seem to have hit a snag.

Kapitaine Khantawai, the Technical Officer of the Global Programme on AIDS in Uganda, (a World Health Organisation Programme) told APS that the much awaited trials are yet to take off. "We do not know what really is going on, the issue seems to be fizzling out," he explained. The WHO office in Entebbe, Uganda, which should be conducting the trial vaccines declined to give any comments.

On the other hand, the Kampala- based AIDS Support Organisation (TASO's) director, Sophia Mukasa Moniko, told APS that the office does not know anything about the proposed trial vaccines.

TASO, which reaches out to over 40,000 AIDS patients in Uganda is the first organised community response to the AIDS epidemic in the East African country.

Founded in 1987 by a group of volunteers, TASO provides counselling, AIDS information, nursing care, educational support and material assistance to people with HIV/AIDS and their families.

"For now, all our treatment is made up of palliative care, counselling and social support. We deal with restoring and improving hope. We are using neither vaccines nor curative drugs," she told this writer.

However, even with the emergence of trial vaccines, few scientists believe that a vaccine will be available within the next five years. Still, PANOS reports, the emerging trial vaccines are beset by a number of problems.

The main problem is that the HIV virus is highly variable. The Media AIDS Information reports that there are two types of HIV,- HIV-1 and HIV-2, both of which cause AIDS. HIV-1 is by far the most common, hence most current vaccine research is directed at it. HIV- 2, prevalent in West African countries, is said to have been hardly researched on. This means that even if a vaccine was successfully developed against HIV-1 most of the western parts of sub-Saharan Africa will still have no vaccine.

Worse still both viruses (HIV-1 and HIV-2) are said to appear in many different forms. A vaccine based on one form may or may not provoke an immune response that "recognises" others.

As if this were not enough, even the HIV-1 type alone is classified into approximately nine other sub-types, from A through H and O.

In sub-Saharan Africa different sub-tribes of the HIV-1 variant proliferate. Sub-tribe A, for example, is found in Central and East Africa, B in Southern Africa, D in East, Central and Southern Africa, F in Zaire and G, H, and O in West Africa.

This proliferation of sub types in sub-Saharan Africa, makes it very arduous for scientists to develop suitable vaccines. "A major problem facing scientists, is that a vaccine which protects against one subWorse still, the variant vaccine being tested in Thailand today is based on type B which is found in the Americas, Europe, Japan and Thailand. The subtype B has dominated the epidemic in much of the industrialised world. Hence the trial vaccines currently going on have nothing to do with sub-Saharan Africa.

type may not provide protection against someone infected with other sub-types," says the PANOS publication.

Says Dr Khisa Joseph who runs a private clinic in the Kenyan capital, which also gives advice and care to AIDS patients; "Scientists in sub-Saharan Africa must intensify research on the cure of the dreaded AIDS pandemic. Dependence on Western researchers might eventually not help much as they carry out their research with their own people in mind."

According to the PANOS report, "there is little effort going into developing vaccines based on subtypes prevalent in Africa, such as A and D". Apart from the scientific problems, "there has been little practical focus on the needs of the developing world. Vaccine research and development is extremely expensive," the report adds.

Even as concerned scientists and others focus their efforts on establishing initiatives to accelerate the development of vaccines that the world can afford, African scientists and governments should prepare for action and seriously plunge into the research process too. Minus the input from Africans, nobody will make efforts to alleviate the suffering of the estimated 11 million HIV/AIDS patients currently in sub-Saharan Africa.


LOAD-DATE: April 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


437 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Science, Medicine and Technology Meningitis Epidemic Hits West Africa


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 24, 1996 by Sam Gonza


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

Nairobi - Over 30,000 prospective Muslim pilgrims from Nigeria will not travel to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, for the annual Hajj Pilgrimage. The religious devotees have been banned this year due to an unusually severe meningitis epidemic that has swept through the northern part of this West African country over the last four months.

The dry season is just coming to a close in Africa's "meningitis belt" comprising Nigeria, Niger, Burkina Faso and Mali. During the period November 1995 to March 1996, the World Health Organisation (WHO) confirmed more than 9,000 deaths out of some 75,000 people who contracted cerebro-spinal meningitis in the region. 

The outbreak was complicated by flare-ups of cholera, measles and inflammation of the stomach and intestines, probably due to blood poisoning. Experts say new disease dynamics in Africa only make more intricate the fight against meningitis.

Nigerian military authorities have complained bitterly following the decision by the Saudi authorities. However, authorities in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia do not trust Nigerian vaccination certificates and fear the sudden entry of a large number of citizens from this country will endanger millions of other pilgrims visiting Muslim Holy sites this April.

Foreign relief agencies led by Medicins Sans Frontiers flew millions of vaccines into Nigeria, Niger, Burkina Faso and Mali - "the African meningitis belt" - in an effort to contain the seasonal outbreak of cerebro spinal meningitis that has claimed thousands of lives, mainly children.

Some of those lucky to survive may be maimed for life due to the damage caused to the brain and spinal cord tissues. Surviving victims may suffer permanent damage to their hearing (they become deaf) while other effects include epilepsy, constant headaches and poor coordination.

In the small West African nation of Burkina Faso with some 9 million people, authorities say more than 2,000 perished during the first three months of 1996. The exact number of people killed in the same epidemic in the more populous Nigeria will probably never be known. The authorities are notorious for doctoring such statistics. In February, Ichechukwa Madubuike, Nigeria's Health Minister said 15,000 people had died, an assertion that was quickly denied by the military government.

It is significant that most of the deaths occurred in the northern areas of Kano-Kaduna - Sokoto. Kano is the home state of military strongman General Sani Abacha.

At the peak of the epidemic in January/February, reports spoke of more than 100 deaths per day. Medical workers bitterly complained of inadequate facilities to fight the disease. Relatively cheap drugs like chloraphenicol were missing at this critical time.

Dry season meningitis is a bacterial infection. The culprit bacterium Neisseria meningitidis is a common one and is usually spread by sneezing and coughing. Normally, these bacteria live harmlessly in the nose or throat of the individual but for reasons that are not understood may suddenly becomes a killer. The bacteria penetrate the body's natural defence system (the immune system) enter the blood stream and proceed to attack the brain including its membranes (meninges) and the spinal cord. If not diagnosed and treated early, this disease is a swift killer. Death may ensue within 24 hours.

The WHO says in recent decades, most of the countries within the "meningitis belt" have experienced large outbreaks every eight years. However, quite significantly, intervals between major epidemics "have become shorter and more irregular since the 80's."

Epidemics usually expand rapidly and peak within weeks but may last several months - as it did this year in the absence of vaccination campaigns.

The warning is clearly on the wall. Health planners in the meningitis belt nations should understand and work in future to contain the worst ravages before they happen.

Dr. Michel Englebert of Medicins Sans Frontiers - Belgium, working in Nairobi says, the entry of foreign variants of the common meningitis germ has somehow complicated the picture. Meningitis A is the common organism of cerebro-spinal meningitis but a variant of this was traced from Nepal in 1983 to the meningitis belt in Africa via the Middle East in the late 80s and early 90s.

Another common player is meningitis C. The important point to be noted is that Asian variants of the common meningitis strain do not respect the seasons. The result is that the seasonal nature of the epidemics could change in those annually affected areas of Africa. More cases of non-seasonal epidemics may also be seen elsewhere in Africa.

"For example in 1994, there was an outbreak of meningitis in the refugee camps in Goma, Zaire. At the time, we had not realised that the Asian variant was in Africa. That outbreak was unusual because it came at the beginning of the rain season," observes Dr. Englebert. The Asian variant does not respect seasons, he observed.

Factors affecting the occurrence and spread of meningitis epidemics in "the belt" include decreasing immunity in a population, overcrowding and climatic conditions such as the dry season and prolonged droughts. Some of these factors explain why meningitis has become a major killer of inmates in prisons across the African continent. Indeed General Olusegun Obasanjo, now a political prisoner in Nigeria, had to be moved for fear that he would get the disease in one badly affected prison in the recent epidemic in Nigeria.

Dr. Englebert says sand and dust storms during the dry season in the affected areas are believed to damage the cellular lining of the throat and nasal cavities (mucosa), facilitating the entry of germs into the body.

Understanding the meningitis symptoms is absolutely important if lives are to be saved. For an infant below one year, symptoms include diarrhoea, vomiting, complete weakness (lassitude) and bulging fontanelle - the soft spot on top of the baby's head. This may be quite evident in the anterior fontanelle. The bulge is due to increased fluid pressure around the brain.

Among adults, symptoms include high fever, severe headache, neck stiffness vomiting and pain in the joints. Children older than one year who complain of headache, stiff neck and have high fever should see a doctor. Many children die needlessly each year because a parent dismissed such symptoms as a small matter.

Dr. Englebert says Medicins Sans Frontiers -Belgium, has trained community health workers in refugee camps in Kenya to detect very quickly diseases like cholera and meningitis. The cheapest antibiotic in the treatment of meningitis is chloraphenicol.


LOAD-DATE: April 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


438 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Kenya History Told in Bishop 's New Book of Sermons


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 24, 1996


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Nairobi - A challenging collection of 24 prophetic sermons preached by the Rt. Rev. David M. Gitari of the Church of the Province of Kenya (CPK), has been published in a new book entitled, "In Season and Out of Season, Sermons to a Nation."

The book launched at a press conference on April 18 here, includes a sermon Rev. Gitari preached following the assassination on March 3, 1975 of J.M. Kariuki, an anti-colonial activist and populist Member of Parliament. It was broadcast live from the Nairobi Baptist Church following a verse by verse analysis of the Kenya National Anthem in the radio programme, "Lift up your Hearts".

This is a sermon that earned the bishop, then only a priest, a lot of wrath from State House Mombasa and the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting, both asking him to explain the texts of the sermons. 

Other notable sermons in the book include a sermon entitled, "Who knows". It calls for peace and the need to be united, then only two weeks before the August 1982 attempted coup that lasted a day.

Each of the 24 sermons is an attempt by Gitari who is at pains to apply the biblical message to the complex contemporary scene in Kenya influenced by the example of such preachers as Martin Luther King and John Stott.

In his characteristic style, Rev. Gitari is not afraid to speak out on social and political issues and against corruption and injustices. Where appropriate, the setting and background of the sermon is provided as well as events which followed the preaching.

Answering questions from journalists, concerning involvement of clergy in politics, particularly the recent case of the Retired Anglican Archbishop Manasses Kuria as umpire of the opposition Forum for the Restoration of Democracy (Ford-Kenya) elections, Bishop Gitari said Archbishop Kuria accepted the role in very good faith but has been let down by the people he was trying to help. He noted that being a returning officer was a very complex issue especially when one did not have direct access to the grassroots people in the short time available.

The Acting Archbishop of the CPK stressed that his church has been engaged in the democratic process in this country, has not shied away from politics and will not do so in the future.

The church has in the past conducted civic education with other churches and groups to educate people about their rights and issues of justice, and she will continue to do this, Rev. Gitari stressed.

He pointed out that a clergyman's involvement in politics was done out of one's own conviction but added that religion and politics cannot be separated because both advance the betterment of the human person.

The Acting Archbishop caused laughter when he said that politicians are happy when they are praised by clergy but the moment they are criticized they tell the clergymen to shut up and not mix religion with politics.

But where one wants to be a member of parliament, Bishop Gitari said such a person should resign his church position and be elected to parliament.

On the issue of elections of the Bishop of the Mt. Kenya South Diocese, the CPK Dean said four names had been approved by the Provincial Electoral College.

The candidates are the Very Rev. Peter Njenga, Provost All Saints Cathedral, Nairobi, Rev. Canon David Njoroge Kamau, Rev. John Wanjihia and Rev. Samuel Muturi, the latter three from Mt. Kenya South.

The Diocesan Synod of Mt. Kenya South will meet next month to elect their new bishop from among the four.

The election of the third Archbishop of the CPK will remain pending until most of the church's 22 dioceses present the names of their delegates to represent them at the elections. Archbishop Kuria retired in December 1994.

The book by Bishop Gitari was published by Paternoster Press, United Kingdom. The 155-page book is available in leading bookshops in the country at a cover price of KShs. 400 (US dollars 7.)

Present during the launching ceremony was the Rev. Canon Gideon Ireri, Director of CPK's Justice and Peace Commission.


LOAD-DATE: April 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April, 1996


Sudan Southern Faction Criticized for Accord with Khartoum


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 24, 1996


LENGTH: 734 words


 

Machakos, Kenya - Bishop Taban Paride of Torit Catholic diocese in southern Sudan has challenged churches to redouble their efforts on issues pertaining to peace and reconciliation.

"It would be naive to imagine that all is well when we have some parts of southern Sudan seriously affected by insecurity yet at the same time some of us are busy signing the so called peace agreements with our enemies without full consent of the entire affected community," the Sudanese Bishop told the General Assembly of the New Sudan Council of Churches (NSCC) meeting here, some 65 kilometres southeast of the capital, Nairobi.

The Catholic prelate was referring to the recently signed peace agreement between Dr. Riak Machar's South Sudan Independence Movement (SSIM) and the Khartoum Government of Lt. General Al Bashir. 

"How can Dr. Machar accept to enter into such a deal with Bashir - when he clearly knows that the latter is not committed to "real" peace and reconciliation? And why commit the community in the south when he knows this?" Bishop Paride posed.

He further told the 50 delegates at the April 14 to 18 Assembly, among them bishops drawn from the NSCC member churches, that such actions (signing of the peace agreement) for individual rather than community benefits clearly explained that churches, as one of many institutions involved in peace and reconciliation in southern Sudan, had yet a wider role to play.

On April 4, this year, Machar and the Khartoum government signed a political charter "to bring to an end the on-going civil war in southern Sudan."

According to a press statement reporting on the agreement, the pact between both parties was reached after secret and persistent talks between the SSIM and the government during the last few months.

Addressing the NSCC Assembly, John Garang led Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) Secretary for Humanitarian Affairs Mr. Arthur Akuien Chol said Dr. Machar's recent action went a long way to prove that some of "our brothers are not for real peace and unity for the entire south.

"I think the action is proof that some of our brothers would rather work with our enemies than with their brothers. This, in a way is a big drawback for the liberation struggle we have waged against the Khartoum government over its domination of the majority southerners," the SPLA official noted.

Several speakers stressed the need for the NSCC to facilitate the shifting of its operational headquarters from the Kenyan capital, Nairobi to Narus - about 50 kilometres from the Kenya/Sudan border.

"It is logical that we start to think seriously when and how we should serve our people from inside and not from Nairobi," said one delegate, in his contribution during one of the sessions.

In an interview with APS, the Acting NSCC Executive Secretary, Mr. Rob Haarsager said of the location of offices, "things are gradually moving toward that direction but with no deadlines as some delegates would like to see."

The assembly was also attended by a number of ecumenical partners, mainly from Britain, Germany and Ireland.

It attracted delegates from the five- member churches of NSCC, namely the Roman Catholic Church, Episcopal Church of Sudan, Presbyterian Church of Sudan, Africa Inland Church and Sudan Interior Church. The Sudan Pentecostal Church, an associate member of NSCC was also represented.

The member churches of NSCC operate in the liberated areas of southern Sudan. The NSCC was officially instituted in 1990. Its first General Assembly was held in 1991.


LOAD-DATE: April 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.

April, 1996


Ethiopia Refugees Repatriated from Djibouti


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency April 18, 1996


LENGTH: 240 words


 

Addis Ababa - Some 1,041 Ethiopian refugees voluntarily returned home on 11th April 1996 by the third and last train convoy under phase four of a successive repatriation mission which began on 21 March 1996 and brought in 1,493 persons from the same country.

According to a press statement issued by the public information section of the United Nations High commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) the repatriation mission concluded the mass voluntary repatriation of Ethiopians from Djibouti after a total number of 4,052 refugees were repatriated in 1996. 

It said, upon arrival in Dire Dawa, the repatriates were given the necessary materials and money for their on-ward transportation from Dire Dawa to final destinations. They were also each given 50 kilogrammes of wheat grain and 10 kilogrames of pulses, it added.

Beginning from 20 September 1994 through 11 April 1996, a total number of 35,930 Ethiopian refuges have been repatriated from Djibouti on a voluntary basis with the assistance of the Ethiopian Administration for Refugee and Returnee Affairs (ARRA), the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the World Food Programme (WFP), the statement concluded.

April, 1996


Ethiopia Good Rains for Crops Predicted


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency April 18, 1996


LENGTH: 200 words


 

Addis Ababa - The National Meteorological Services Agency has announced that most Belg-crop producing areas of the country would receive normal and abundant rainfall in April and May.

In its weather forecast and early warning system, the agency said the amount and the distribution of Belg or small rains have increased since it started early last month. Satellite evidence showed the lowland areas in the south-eastern of Somali Regional State, which had little or no rainfall in the past and localities in Borena, Oromiya Regional State, will have increased rain showers.

It predicted that the amount of rainfall in belg-crop producing areas, mainly in the Amhara, eastern parts of Tigray as well as in the central and eastern parts of Oromiya, would gradually decrease in mid May, while Gambella, Benshangul Gumuz, southern Ethiopia and Somali regional states would receive very little rain.

Ethiopia Cross Examination in Trial of Former Officials


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency April 19, 1996


LENGTH: 267 words


 

Addis Ababa - Cross-examination by defense lawyers of the first witness of the Special Prosecutor on charges against senior officials of the defunct Derg regime wound up here at the Central High Court, which adjourned the hearing to the testimonies of other witnesses set for April 23.

At a hearing that resumed yesterday at the first Criminal Bench of the Central High Court, the witness answered questions posed by 13 defense lawyers including those raised by defendants Captain Begashaw Atalay and Captain Tessema Belay who had dismissed their lawyers. 

Majors Kassaye Aragaw and Melaku Teferra who had also dismissed their defense lawyers said they had no questions to the first witness. The court ruled out the appeal made on the occasion by the two defendants on the ground that it would not hear an appeal while undergoing cross- examination and advised them to submit it in a written form to the office of the court.

Despite its decision to continue the hearing yesterday, the Special Prosecutor requested the court to postpone the hearing of the second witness for next Tuesday because he was not ready to bring the witness before the court.

The court resumed the proceeding after assuring that all the defendants were present in the court room.

Ethiopia Airline Celebrates Anniversary


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency April 21, 1996


LENGTH: 360 words


 

Addis Ababa - The remarkable gains achieved over the past two years are the living testimonies to the highest stage of development the Ethiopian Airlines has reached .

The remark came from Deputy Prime Minister and Defence Minister Tamirat Layine on the occasion of the Golden Jubilee of the EAL which was celebrated here yesterday. 

He said the EAL has shown a significant change following the restructuring it underwent and the increase in its annual budget.

The profit obrained by the airlines has grown from 10-15 million birr 2 years ago to 100 million afterwards, he added.

The Deputy Prime Minister recalled that the steps taken by the government two years ago to restructure the EAL with the aim of enabling it to become profitable was either wrongly understood or destorted on purpose by some parties. He said however, the government had a strong conviction that the restructuring would be instrumental in bringing about an encouraging and a promising result within the airlines such as the one that has just been registered.

Ato Tamirat pledged government's continued support for the effort of ensuring increased improvement and growth of the EAL and called upon the management staff and workers of the airlines to join hands in building the institution s capacity.

Dr. Ahmed Kellow, General Manager of the EAL commended workers of the enterprise for registering great economic victories over a very short period of time.

On the occasion, Defence Minister Tamirat and other invited guests visited the different sections of the airlines.

Science, Medicine and Technology Ethiopia Inoculates Cattle Against Anthrax


BYLINE: Ethiopian News Agency April 22, 1996


LENGTH: 146 words


 

Addis Ababa - Ziway - Over half a million head of cattle were inoculated against anthrax, animal killer disease during campaign carried out in four woredas of East Shoa Zone for the past six months, woreda agricultural offices said.

The offices said vehicles and back animals were used to transport field workers and vaccination equijpment to far off localities in Shashemene, Arsi-Negelle, Dugeda-Borena and Adamitulu woredas.

The field workers said they were unable to extend the vaccination programme to other areas due to shortage of medicines and vaccination equipment.

445 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Africa-at-Large Pope in Tunis Appeals For Religious Dialogue


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 24, 1996


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Tunis - Pope John Paul II has appealed for dialogue between Christians and Muslims, but in the same breath attacked religious fundamentalism of any kind.

The first ever Catholic Pope to visit Tunisia, John Paul II used the 10-hour visit to the Tunisian capital on April 14 to appeal for dialogue and tolerance between Christians and Muslims, and called for the release of seven French Trappist monks kidnapped on March 27 by Islamic extremists in Tunisia's strife-torn western neighbour, Algeria.

The Roman Catholic pontiff also met President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali and the country's civilian authorities during the whistle-stop visit, during which he called for "deeper mutual understanding" between Christians and Muslims.

On his 70th foreign trip since becoming pope in 1978, John Paul celebrated mass in the 100-year-old cathedral in Tunis before some 1,500 people representing the country's tiny Catholic community. 

He urged them to continue their social action "in collaboration with your Muslim friends."

The Pope then left Tunis for Rome after ending the visit with a brief trip to the ruins of the Roman amphitheatre at Carthage in remembrance of martyred Christians.

Earlier, holding his first mass in an Arab Muslim country, the pontiff declared: "Diverse of language, culture, origin, you are the living image of universal church. The ferments of unity and solidarity should emerge from your links with the North and the South, East and West."

During mass, John Paul II also evoked the issue of the kidnapped Trappist monks in Algeria, saying he hoped "to see an end to their ordeal."

Europeans mingled with Tunisians on the cathedral square, as many were unable to enter the building due to tight security measures enforced by Tunisian authorities.

Afterwards, the Pope met eight bishops from the Episcopal Conference of North Africa including those from Tunisia, Morocco, Libya and Algeria, where several priests and nuns have been killed or abducted by Islamic militants.

With them, he prayed "that peace and reconciliation come quickly to Algerian soil, in the just respect of differences," and also voiced solidarity with the Libyan people living under a UN embargo "which seriously affects the daily life of the population."

The Pope also launched an appeal for peace in Africa and in countries of the Mediterranean region, in particular in the Middle East, and condemned fundamentalism in any guise, insisting that "no one can kill in the name of God, no one can accept killing his brother."

After mass, the 75-year-old pontiff, who has suffered several bouts of ill-health in recent months, but looked relatively fit, went on a short walkabout to greet several hundred Catholics and Muslims, whose posters and banners in French and Arabic welcomed the head of the worldwide Roman Catholic Church to a country where "tolerance reigns."

He evoked the importance of "a brotherly relationship, always deeper, more spiritual" between Catholics and Muslims in this country of some 8 million people.

"Where violence and discord is sown, you should act as messengers of peace coming from God and reconciliation," he said.

Referring to Mediterranean peoples' "common fate," the pontiff stressed the importance "of peace and the renunciation of all violence within each society and between nations, so that dialogue and cooperation between the countries of the North and the South can develop."

President Ben Ali, who has cracked down harshly on Muslim fundamentalism in Tunisia, said: "Tunisia, a country of moderation, dialogue and tolerance, and a beacon of Islam, ... is honoured to welcome the Holy Father."

Civil strife in Algeria has claimed some 50,000 lives since January 1992.

Tunisia, the first part of North Africa to see Christian missionaries in the fourth century, has no more than 20,000 Catholics today, compared with some 260,000 when the country gained independence from France in 1956.

Relations between Tunis and the Vatican have traditionally been good, which has not always been the case with other countries in the region.


LOAD-DATE: April 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


446 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Liberia Archbishop Recounts Fighting After Evacuation


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 24, 1996


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Freetown - Monrovia's Roman Catholic Archbishop Michael Francis was among those evacuated from the Liberian capital to neighbouring Sierra Leone on April 14, after being robbed at his home in the Liberian capital.

Speaking on arrival here, Archbishop Francis said of his unidentified attackers: "They came to my house. They wanted money and held us at gunpoint, so we gave them all the money we had."

Amid continuing unrest in Liberia, forces loyal to warlords Charles Taylor and Alhaji Kromah were continuing a week-old siege of rival fighters holding some 600 hostages in the Barclay Training Center (BTC), a central barracks. 

The Liberian-born Archbishop said there were "hundreds of people" outside the United States Embassy compound in Monrovia trying to leave the city.

"In this situation, what can you do, where can you go when your life is at stake?" he said, when asked why he left the country he had lived in for more than 20 years.

He said he thought the current crisis was the worst in Liberia's history and announced he would travel shortly to the Vatican to discuss the crisis with Pope John Paul II.

The archbishop's departure came as rival forces unleashed confused attacks on an army barracks packed with several thousand rebel Krahn fighters holding hundreds of hostages and thousands of refugees, while at least 15 corpses were strewn around the area of the Barclay Training Center (BTC), surrounded by Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Forces of Liberia and Alhaji Kromah.

The fighting at Barclay Training Centre barracks which has intensified since it started on April 7 when government troops in pursuit of ULIMO-J leader, Roosevelt Johnson, who had fled his home in the northeastern district of Sinkor, "were attacked by (members) of the Krahn faction loyal to Johnson, "many of whom live in the barracks, according to a government statement broadcast on radio.

At least 156 people have died in the camp in the past few days, and several hundred others wounded.

The ruling council of state also confirmed that the heavy fighting had broken out at the central barracks between supporters of Johnson, currently wanted on murder charges, and government troops.

The government also confirmed Krahn fighters had sprung former chief of staff Charles Julue from a jail in Barclay Training Centre, where he was serving a seven-year term jail term for his involvement in a coup plot.

Julue was released by "dissidents" of Johnson "and is well-armed and fighting alongside Johnson's forces," according to a government statement.

It said several prisoners at the Monrovia central jail had also been released and armed to fight alongside fighters loyal to Johnson.

There are also reports that members of the Armed Forces of Liberia, a mainly Krahn faction and formerly the West African country's regular army under Julue's command, had joined the Johnson camp.

Liberia's ethnic Krahns, who are the centre of the latest bloody fighting, the worst seen in the capital in the last four years, dominated the upper echelons of this country throughout the 1980s, even though they comprise less than 10 per cent of the estimated 2.6 million population.

Johnson, who until his ousting last month led the Krahn wing of the United Liberation Movement (ULIMO-J), is not a member of the interim collective presidency, unlike fellow Krahn George Boley, leader of the Liberia Peace Council (LPC), another armed faction.

The Krahns come from the southeast of Liberia and first appeared on the political scene in April 1980 after a coup led one of their number, Master Sergeant Samuel Doe, which ended years of domination by descendants of freed slaves who founded Liberia in 1922.

The murder of Doe's predecessor, President William Tolbert, and the televised execution of 13 ministers and senior government officials, set the brutal tone of the first Liberian regime to be run by an indigenous ethnic group.

Key political and military posts were quickly filled by Krahns.

Doe gradually eliminated all opposition and installed a corrupt reign of terror that fuelled bitter ethnic rivalry.

He was tortured to death in September 1990 by a breakaway faction of the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), led by Charles Taylor, the man who set off Liberia's civil war in December 1989.

At the last peace negotiations, which ended in an accord signed last August in the Nigerian federal capital Abuja, the Krahns put forward a united front, delegating Boley to sit on the collective presidency.

Krahn fighters are now dispersed among the Armed Forces of Liberia - formerly Doe's presidential guard but reformed since his death - the LPC, based in the southeast, and ULIMO-J, founded in March 1994 by Johnson after the original ULIMO split into Krahn and Mandingo wings.


LOAD-DATE: April 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


447 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Nigeria Nearly 800 Dead In Inter-Ethnic Clashes


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 24, 1996


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Lagos - Nearly 800 people have died in inter-ethnic clashes in two incidents in Nigeria, the country's press have reported.

In the first incident, around 700 people were killed in the past one week along Nigeria's southeastern border with Cameroon, the independent daily Tribune reported on April 16.

The newspaper said 200 people were injured in the clashes in Cross River State, but a government official, while confirming the clashes, said the newspaper's toll was exaggerated. 

Clashes between Ugep and Adim people were sparked over land disputes in the regions of Yakur and Biassa, the newspaper said.

Public buildings, including schools, were destroyed by fires and women and children from both communities fled villages fearing an escalation of violence, it said.

The state's military administrator, Colonel Gregory Agbonemi, has ordered stepped up security to restore calm to the area and announced an inquiry into the clashes, the newspaper said.

On April 15, the official News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) reported that about 80 people were also killed and 6,000 forced to flee their homes in clashes between Karimojos and Fulani herdsmen in Nigeria's northeastern Taraba state.

The fighting erupted on April 7 in the town of Karim Lamido and spread to other parts of the region, NAN reported late on April 14.

The violence followed an alleged rape bid by a Fulani, NAN said, quoting villagers, who said the man overpowered his Karimojo victim and sliced off her left hand with a knife.

Police and local officials had called on Karimojos not to retaliate, saying the incident was an isolated one.

A series of peace meetings between the two communities resulted in a short period of calm, but on Easter Sunday homes in the village of Madaka were set on fire, allegedly by Fulanis, while the villagers were in church, triggering the violence.

The dead included 21 people whose burnt bodies were deposited at a government mortuary in Bambur, NAN reported. More than 10 people died when a mob attacked a police station in Karim Lamido.

In the two communities, more than 500 houses have been destroyed and their owners have fled to the neighbouring states of Adamawa and Bauchi.

State police chief Alhaji Yunusa Yahaya said 20 people had been arrested. Soldiers and armed police officers have been deployed to halt the violence.


LOAD-DATE: April 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


448 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Kenya FORD-K Congress Ends in Disarray


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 24, 1996


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Nairobi - Retired Anglican Archbishop Manasses Kuria abruptly quit his role as umpire at a delegates congress of Kenya's leading opposition party, Forum for the Restoration of Democracy (FORD-Kenya) party, after an intended leadership poll on April 13 degenerated into acrimonious exchange and stone throwing between two factions in the party.

Police had to fire tear gas to quell the rival combatants in the inter-party fracas that left a number of people injured at Thika Stadium, the congress venue, 30 kilometres from Nairobi.

The congress was called to sort out a long standing leadership wrangle in Ford Kenya but it never achieved it purpose after a bitterly frustrated Kuria abruptly terminated his mediator and umpire role. He had stepped in last month after a number of prominent would be mediators turned down the task. 

There are two camps within the party. That of Kijana Wamalwa, the incumbent leader of Ford-Kenya and the camp of Raila Odinga, son of party founder, the late Jaramogi Oginga Odinga. Raila has never accepted his earlier defeat in party polls held in 1994.

Raila Odinga leads a mainly Luo faction (third largest of Kenya's ethnic groups) while Wamalwa has broader national support including Luos, besides that of his own Luhya community, Kenya's second largest group after the Kikuyus.

A dress rehearsal for the violence at Thika happened three days earlier when a youth was stabbed to death within the precincts of the Anglican All Saints Cathedral, Nairobi, where Archbishop Kuria conducted a meeting of rival factions. The retired prelate had to summon police to disperse the rival youth gangs.

During the abortive congress at Thika, the whole exercise collapsed after Raila's supporters and their leader charged that Kuria favoured Wamalwa. The two factions also failed to agree on procedures and delegates' list. By early afternoon, an exasperated Kuria had enough of the anarchy and he called it quits.

As he was leaving the venue some youths attacked his car with stones but he was not injured. Police intervened and the prelate was able to leave.

After the collapse of the congress, the rival Wamalwa and Raila factions held their own separate elections which analysts say are a sign of a split in Ford-Kenya.

In the meantime, Nakuru Catholic Bishop Ndingi Mwana a' Nzeki has received overwhelming support from clergy in Kenya - both Catholic and Protestant - in the wake of concerted attack on him by politicians and government officials, following remarks he made expressing fear of a resurgence of the much dreaded ethnic clashes in a section of the Rift Valley Province.

More than 500 priests and bishops have sent messages of solidarity and support for the bishop. The clergy urge the government to ensure that law and order prevail in the Molo area of Nakuru Diocese, some 180 kilometres north-west of Nairobi, rather than vilify Bishop Ndingi.

The matter started on Easter Sunday when Bishop Ndingi urged the government to investigate reports by people in Molo area of his diocese that unknown people had been seen entering the local forests. The alleged strangers in the forest had caused great anxiety as it was feared they were using the forest in preparation for a new round of ethnic clashes.

In 1992/1993, Molo area was a major flash point that left hundreds dead and thousands displaced. The clashes believed to be politically instigated, mainly pitted the Kalejin against other groups including the Kikuyu and Luhya.

At the height of varied reactions to Bishop Ndingi's claims, the Nakuru District Commissioner, John Abduba on April 10 led a team of government officials and journalists into the local forests to verify whether any attackers were hiding there. The journalists also talked to residents in the area.

In response to the matter, Embu Catholic Bishop John Njue said issues raised by his Nakuru counterpart "were quite sensitive and should be thoroughly investigated."


LOAD-DATE: April 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


449 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Sudan Authorities Deny Attacks on Nuba


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 24, 1996


LENGTH: 987 words


 

Nairobi - The Sudanese Embassy in Nairobi has dismissed as propaganda a statement released here by the Sudan Catholic Information Office (CSCIO). The statement charged that Government of Sudan forces comprising 700 men from El Saraf el Ahmar garrison on March 23 and 24, burned down two villages in the Nuba Mountains, destroying crops in the field and stock in granaries.

Speaking to APS the Counsellor of the Embassy, Mr. Ali Sadiq asserted that it was illogical for the government which has always tried to assist its people to also engage in acts of destruction, further emphasizing that "it is the government's noble responsibility to assure security and protect the people."

Mr. Sadiq said he was ready to issue a visa to anyone who cared to find out the truth rather than believe accounts from the SCIO. He likened the Catholic Information Office report, attributed to Msgr. Macram Max Gassi, the Catholic Bishop of El Obeid and Father Kizito Sesana, to similar reports by human rights organisation Amnesty International, which he said was constantly at war with the Islamic Government of Sudan. 

Mr. Sadiq said his government did not discriminate against any section of the community, whether they were Christians or not, pointing out that Sudan's Foreign Affairs Minister and the Vice- President are Christians.

Reacting to the SCIO statement, the Sudanese Ambassador to Kenya dismissed anything coming from a Christian source as false and thus should not be believed.

The SCIO statement dated April 16, says that the government forces attacked, looted and burnt the two villages in Kauda and Toror in the Nuba Mountains, Southern Kordofan.

The attack, according to Fr. Kizito and Msgr. Max Gassi, left more than 1,000 families homeless and without food. The victims lost property which included clothes, agricultural implements and seeds. However, there were no casualties among the civilians for they had been evacuated in advance by the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), the Catholic clergy said.

The attacks were also extended to the local Catholic Church in which the government forces also desecrated the tabernacle, smashed into pieces the figure of Christ on the cross, and looted a statue of Mary, mass and prayer books, altar clothes and priest vestments, said SCIO.

The government forces were, however, repulsed by the Southern Sudan-based SPLA forces which engaged them in the two villages, forcing them to retreat into Kadugli, the report added.

The SPLA claimed an upper hand in the fight in which it said 25 soldiers from the government forces were killed with the southern movement force losing five men.

Giving an account of what he had seen when he was part of a delegation from Nairobi that visited the area on April 14 and 15 and witnessed the destruction, Msgr. Gassis said the main motive behind the Islamic Fundamentalist regime's attack on the villages was to terrorize the civilian population and force them to join the so called "peace Camps", where women and girls are raped or taken as concubines while male children are enslaved or trained to join the Islamic militia.

The Catholic Bishop of El Obeid said such actions are targeted not primarily at the SPLA but against the civilians to create fear and hunger so that they are forced to join the infamous "Peace Camps," where he says there is ample documentation that a policy of ethnic genocide is methodically implemented.

The other reason for such actions, he said, was to raise the morale of the army which has been demoralized in recent months having been defeated in Eastern Equatoria and other places.

Msgr. Gassis re-affirmed the church's commitment to defend human rights as that was part of her mission in the world.

He condemned the Khartoum regime's action in the Nuba Mountains in the north, terming it as barbarous and immoral.

The Bishop appealed to the world community, the Church and non- Governmental Organisations (NGOs) to go to the rescue of Sudan's Nuba population who need shelter, medicine, food, salt, clothes, utensils and soap.

He pointed out that the Nuba Mountains region received very little assistance from the international community or from NGOs since the Sudan government "keeps telling them that the Nuba are assisted by the regime, when in reality the regime starves them and abducts their women and children and burns their crop."

The Nuba Mountains in northern Sudan, stretching over 77,000 square kilometres, is home to some 50 black groups. Today, this area is believed to host only 200,000 people out of more than one million before the current civil war broke out in 1983. The bulk of the area inhabitants have either died, or are living in exile, have been abducted into slavery or deported to occupy up to 100 government "peace villages."


LOAD-DATE: April 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


450 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


South Africa Tutu's Tears Launch Truth Hearings


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 24, 1996


LENGTH: 707 words


 

East London - Archbishop Desmond Tutu, Nobel laureate and chairman of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, broke down and sobbed on April 17 on hearing victims of apartheid-era atrocities tell of police torture, murder and mysterious disappearances.

Tutu and his fellow commissioners, who started the formal hearings on April 16 listened compassionately as one witness after another at the commission's first public hearings, choked back tears and recounted harrowing stories of human rights violations at the hands of political enemies and police.

But it was Tutu's turn to cry when the last witness of the day, elderly former activist Singogokwana Malgas, told how beatings during the 30 years he spent in and out of police cells had left him in a wheelchair. 

The 65-year-old Archbishop of Cape Town buried his head on the table in front of him and wept.

"I thought I was tough," Tutu told journalists after the commission adjourned in this Eastern Cape province port. "I thought I was going to survive today ... I keep on thinking whether I am the right person for the Truth Commission."

The commission is charged with probing politically-linked crimes committed at the height of apartheid between 1960 and 1993.

The commission was forced to postpone the scheduled testimony of Joyce Mtimkhulu, whose son Siphiwo disappeared mysteriously in 1982, because of threats of legal action by two senior military officers against whom she was going to give evidence.

The two men asked a Cape Town court for an interdict to stop Mtimkhulu from taking the stand and to force the commission to hand over to them confidential written statements she made earlier to its investigators.

The court postponed argument on the interdict until April 24 when the commission said, it will fight for its right to keep evidence confidential until witnesses have testified.

By the time of going to press, 15 witnesses had appeared before the commission, which is empowered to grant reparations to victims and amnesty to perpetrators who confess their part in political crimes.

Most of the witnesses have so far implicated the former National Party Government or its agents in human rights abuses, but on April 16, for the first time, President Nelson Mandela's African National Congress (ANC) was also accused of atrocities.

Bessie Mdoda said her son, Xola Jebe, an ANC guerrilla, had disappeared in one of the ANC's detention camps while fighting outside of South Africa in 1981 and had not seen since, despite claims by ANC leaders in 1990 that he was still alive.

The widows of the so-called "Cradock Four" - a group of anti- apartheid activists who in 1985 were found charred and mutilated - also told the commission on April 16 of their fruitless struggle to bring their husbands' killers to justice.

After two inquests and press revelations of a secret document in which senior military officers ordered the permanent removal from society of Matthew Goniwe and his three friends, it was found that the apartheid government was responsible for the deaths, but no person was ever prosecuted.

The commission offered the families some relief when they promised to put pressure on South Africa's new democratic government to ensure they receive financial compensation promised last year.


LOAD-DATE: April 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.


451 of 629 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1996


Uganda Cardinal's Critique of Electoral System Stirs Controversy


BYLINE: All Africa Press Service April 24, 1996


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

Kampala - Uganda's Roman Catholic Church has sharply criticised a Kampala newsletter for describing the head of the Catholic community in this East African country as a "drunkard."

In a statement read to all Catholic churches in Uganda on April 15, the church described the attack by the Uganda Confidential as an "unfair affront to the Cardinal and an insult to all Catholics."

In an editorial published on April 12, the Uganda Confidential, a privately owned periodical, reported that Cardinal Emmanuel Wamala had been "influenced by alcohol" when he criticised the country's electoral process of being over shadowed by violence, voter bribing and intimidation.

The attack by the paper, said to have strong ties with the ruling National Resistance Government followed several others in form of reader's letters in the government- owned New Vision daily, one of which described Catholic priests as "hypocrites in red cassocks." 

The latest furore was prompted by a Reuters news agency report claiming that the Cardinal had made a direct attack on the person of President Yoweri Museveni during the clergy's Easter message.

Cardinal Wamala has denied the report as "a total distortion of his message which was broadcast live on Radio Uganda and Television on Easter Sunday.

In a related development, a campaign centre of President Yoweri Museveni's main opponent in Uganda's May 9 elections, has accused state security agents of having been behind election violence on April 14 that disrupted Democratic Party President Paul Ssemogerere's rally.

During the incident in which thousands of people were injured, an unidentified man carrying Museveni's portrait hurled insults at the 5,000 strong crowd stirring up a stampede that sent security agents shooting at random.

In the statement published here on April 15, the DP leader's campaign team singled out two senior members of Museveni's task force, three senior officers of the Uganda Army and several members of the country's Internal Security Organisation, who they said were behind alleged plots to disrupt Ssemogerere's rallies.

Incidences of violence have been reported in campaigns ahead of the first elections in Uganda in a decade. On April 9, mobs of President Museveni's supporters in the western town of Masindi stoned the entourage of another presidential aspirant Mr. Mohammed Mayanja, forcing him and his team to flee as they tried to address a rally in the town believed to be a stronghold of the incumbent Ugandan president.

Uganda Police spokesman Mr. Bob Ngobi, says his men are overwhelmed by the violence and has appealed to voters, especially President Museveni's supporters to calm down.

Meanwhile, President Museveni has supported the head of the Catholic Community in this East African country over the latter's criticism of the campaigns to the May 9 presidential poll.

Addressing supporters on April 15 in Mbarara, 272 kilometres south- west of Kampala, Museveni said the campaign to Uganda's first general election in over a decade was over shadowed by bad language.

"I have heard of bad language being used by aspiring candidates against one another, I do not support this and I advise it to stop," Museveni said.

In his Easter Sunday message, Cardinal Emmanuel Wamalwa had attacked "dirty mouthed politicians who should stop the uncivilized act."

The Cardinal also preached against election rigging and called for "truth and justice."

Meanwhile the charge d'affaires at the Royal Nertherlands Embassy in Kampala, Nellke Linsen, has warned that the rebel war in Northern Uganda could be misused to influence results at the elections.

The Dutch diplomat did not say who would misuse the war but it is widely believed that the North is a stronghold of the opposition represented in the elections by Museveni's key opponent, Dr. Paul Ssemogerere.

"If five districts (in Northern Uganda) are excluded in the elections out of sheer necessity, then the legitimacy of the elected government will be in question," Mrs Linsen said in a press statement on April 15 which also urged the government to stop the war before the elections on May 9.

The Netherlands charge d'affaires also announced a grant of US$1.2million to the Uganda Interim Electoral Commission.

In a separate development, the East, Southern and Central Africa Union of Muslim Councils has congratulated Libyan pilgrims to Mecca for having defied United Nations sanctions and flown to Saudi Arabia for the holy Hajj.

"The sanctions are a violation of the freedom of worship for Libyan Muslims because they prevent them from fulfilling the holy Koran which says they must visit the holy place of Allah without seeking permission from an earthly authority including the UN," the Secretary General of the East, Southern and Central Africa councils of Muslims, Sheikh Abdu Sengoba said in a statement published at the body's head quarters here on April 17.


LOAD-DATE: April 25, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1996 AllAfrica, Inc.
